Triage of the Heart

by Coven_crafted

Summary

After losing a patient, the guarded Dr. Agatha Harkness leaves Boston General for the quieter halls of Westview General Hospital. Small-town life isn’t easy for someone who’s built her walls high... until a certain firefighter makes her heart stir in ways she thought she’d forgotten.

Notes

I had planned to release this after Kinktober week but thought I would offer a slight break from the smut for those who needed it (not me...I'm obsessed with you all)

Chapter 1

The morning light over Westview was thin and grey, the kind that promised nothing. 

Perfect. Agatha preferred beginnings that didn’t try to romance her.

By 7:15am she was already on the surgical floor, lab coat immaculate, hair pinned back with mathematical precision, stethoscope gleaming like a weapon. She’d arrived early on purpose, she wanted to see the place before anyone expected warmth from her.

The plaque on the open office door read- Dr Natasha Romanoff- Chief of Surgery.

“Dr. Harkness,” came the low, assured voice from inside. “Come in.”

Natasha Romanoff was precisely the kind of woman who could make a hospital obey without raising her voice — poised, economical, with eyes that could flay through fabrications. She gestured to the chair opposite her desk.

“Welcome to Westview General,” she said. “Smaller hospital than you’re used to, but you’ll find the work no less meaningful.”

Agatha sat. “I’m here for meaningful, not glamorous.”

“That’s good,” Natasha said. “You won’t find much glamour here. What you will find—” she flipped through the folder before her, “—are strong letters. ‘Unflinching in crisis.’ ‘Surgical instincts beyond her year.’ ‘Composed under pressure.’ That’s quite a reputation, Dr. Harkness.”

“Product of long hours and hard work.” Agatha said.

Natasha nodded once. “And a loss,” she said carefully. “A patient. I’m sorry.”

The words were simple, but they found their mark. Agatha’s mouth went dry.

“I appreciate that,” she said, clearing her throat, her voice neutral, clipped.

Natasha closed the folder, tone softening. “You’ll fit in here. We’re a smaller, less political hospital, no fancy clinical trials. But the staff’s close. Feels like one big family.”

Agatha gave the faintest eye-roll before she could stop herself. “I’ll take that under advisement.”

Natasha smiled. “You just want to do your job.”

“That’s why I’m here.”

“Then do it well. And try not to terrify the nurses before lunch.”

“No promises,” Agatha said, standing.

Natasha’s laugh followed her out the door.

                                         


The first half of the day crawled by.

Westview General, as it turned out, was quiet. Too quiet. The kind of quiet that felt less like peace and more like sedation.

By 10:00am, she’d seen three sprained ankles, two allergic reactions (one to peanuts, one to shellfish), and one very dramatic woman convinced her appendix was rupturing —it wasn’t.

A construction worker came in with a bandaged hand, claiming he’d been bitten by a “rabid pigeon.” It was, in fact, a parakeet.

A high-schooler arrived shortly after, clutching his side and moaning in agony. The diagnosis? Gas.

By noon, Agatha was contemplating the meaning of her career choices. She’d left Boston General — the heart of surgical innovation, the adrenaline capital of the Eastern Seaboard — for this.

She checked her reflection in the medicine cabinet mirror during a brief lull.
 “You wanted quiet,” she muttered to herself. “Congratulations.”

At 2:30 p.m., Nurse Wanda Maximoff appeared beside her, arms crossed, watching her update a chart.
Wanda had the kind of presence that didn’t announce itself — it arrived. Her scrubs were a deep wine-red, a shade that looked deliberate against her pale skin and auburn hair, which she’d twisted into a loose braid that was already escaping its tie. A faint scent of coffee and cinnamon followed her, oddly grounding in the sterile air.

“You’ve had the full Westview experience already, huh?” she asked, her accent a soft, melodic lilt that turned even sarcasm into something kind.

Agatha didn’t glance up. “If by experience you mean mild tedium and several questionable uses of the emergency department, then yes.”

Wanda’s grin widened, her teeth catching the light. “You’ll get used to it. Some of the regulars come here for attention, not medicine.”

Agatha finally looked over. Wanda’s eyes were green — really green — sharp when she focused, warm when she smiled. They were warm now. 

Agatha signed the bottom of the chart, unamused. “Fascinating.”

Wanda leaned lightly against the counter, close enough that Agatha could feel her presence without it being intrusive. “Cheer up, Doctor. You’ll get a real one soon enough.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “I’m not sure I believe in that anymore.” She shut the chart with a decisive snap. “Everyone seems to be bleeding metaphorically.”

Wanda laughed softly.
“Give it time. The night shift likes to keep things interesting.”
There was something knowing in her tone, a teasing sort of warmth, like she’d seen a hundred doctors come through, all sharp edges and ambition, and decided this one didn’t have to stay made of ice.

Agatha didn’t like the implication of give it time.

She preferred control. Schedules. Predictability.

By 3:00pm, she was restocking a supply cart when another voice — confident, amused — carried across the ER.

“So you’re the Boston import everyone’s been whispering about.”

Agatha turned.

A tall Black woman stood in the doorway, posture relaxed, a smirk playing at the edge of her full mouth. 

Her pink scrub sleeves were rolled to her elbows, showing strong forearms dusted faintly with flour-white powder from latex gloves. The buzzcut made her look severe in theory, but somehow it only added to the startling beauty of her face — clean lines, striking eyes, and a self-assurance that bordered on arrogant.

Her badge read DR. JENNIFER KALE.

“Dr. Kale,” Agatha said, offering a polite nod.

“The one and only,” Jen said, stepping in. “Emergency medicine. We’ll be sharing the joy that is Westview General.”

“Charming,” Agatha said, flat as glass.

Jen’s grin grew. “Boston General, right? Big leagues. I did a trauma rotation there once — lasted two months before I realised that I value my sleep and sanity.”

“Then you made the right choice,” Agatha replied without looking up from her chart.

“I usually do,” Jen said easily. “Though the Chief said you don’t blink under pressure. That true, or is that just your reputation?”

Agatha kept her tone neutral. “I suppose that depends on what you’d call pressure.”

Jen chuckled, clearly enjoying herself. “Touché.”

Agatha moved to file the chart. “If you’re trying to test me, Dr. Kale, I assure you I’m not very interesting.”

Jen tilted her head. “I’m starting to think that’s not true.”

Agatha gave her a level, unimpressed look. “You think a lot, apparently.”

Jen grinned wider, unbothered, intrigued. “I do. Keeps the brain sharp.”

“Well,” Agatha said, stepping past her to reach for a set of gloves, “try not to overexert yourself.”

That earned a short laugh — genuine this time. “All right, Doctor Harkness. I’ll leave you to your peace and quiet. But fair warning — nobody keeps to themselves here for long. The walls in this place talk.”

“I don’t listen to walls,” Agatha said curtly.

“Sure you don’t.” Jen winked, turning toward the main corridor. “See you at hamdover.”

When she was gone, Agatha exhaled slowly and realised she’d been holding her shoulders a little too stiff. The last thing she wanted was idle gossip surrounding her here.


By 6:00pm, the sky had bruised itself purple outside the windows, and Agatha was counting the minutes until she could hand over to the night team. Her first day had been an endless carousel of non-urgent absurdities — and the thought of doing it all again tomorrow left her feeling vaguely cheated.

She was slipping her pen into her coat pocket when she heard it.

Sirens.

Loud, close, cutting through the hum of the hospital like the first real heartbeat of the day.

The intercom crackled to life- “Multiple trauma incoming — MVC on Highway 22. Estimated arrival, three minutes.”

Everything shifted at once.

The tired rhythm of the ER quickened, snapping into sharp, controlled movement. Nurses moved with practiced coordination, monitors flickered to life, gloves snapped.

Adrenaline surged through Agatha’s bloodstream — that clean, steady rush she hadn’t felt in months.
She pulled on gloves, tied her trauma gown over her white coat. The old rhythm returned as naturally as breathing.

The double doors burst open.

Two stretchers rolled in, soaked, rainwater dripping onto the tile. 
Paramedics shouted vitals over the din. Behind them came four firefighters, uniforms damp, boots heavy with soot and grit.
“Collision with a semi,” someone called. “Driver’s side crushed!”

Agatha moved without hesitation. “Get me the field report,” she said sharply.

A paramedic — young, petite, dark hair sticking to her forehead with red and orange flashes poking through some strands— peeled off her gloves and stepped up beside her. Her badge read ALICE WU-GULLIVER.

“Patient was unresponsive at scene,” Alice reported quickly, still catching her breath. “BP eighty over fifty when we found him. We stabilised him with two large-bore IVs, got fluids running before transport. Pulse was weak, but we brought it up to ninety by the time we got here.”

Agatha checked the patient’s vitals, already moving in sync with the report. “Good work. You bought us time.”

Alice blinked — startled by the compliment, perhaps because it came so clipped, so precise. Then she smiled — a wide, genuine grin that brightened her whole face.

“Thank you, Doctor.”

Agatha didn’t look up again — couldn’t, not when adrenaline still buzzed in her fingertips — but she allowed herself the faintest nod.

“Let’s get him to trauma one,” she said. “Page radiology. We’re moving.”

The next half-hour passed in the rhythm she lived for — clear orders, measured chaos, life hanging in the balance and her hands the hinge between it.

She stitched, suctioned, stabilised. The hum of the ventilator and the controlled bark of instructions filled the air around her like music.

When the patient was finally transferred to ICU, stable and breathing on his own, the room deflated with quiet satisfaction.

Tony Stark — a firefighter who’d swaggered in with EMT — leaned on a gurney nearby, watching her. 

“You’re something else, Doc. You run that room like a war general.”

Agatha snapped off her gloves. “It’s called doing one’s job. You should really try it sometime.”

He grinned. “You make it look scary. I like a woman who terrifies me.”

Before she could reply, Wanda walked by with a knowing smile. “Don’t mind him,” she said to Agatha. “Stark flirts with everyone who moves. You’re just the first one to shut him down before he could finish his sentence.”

“I’m definitely not interested.” Agatha said dryly.

Wanda laughed. “You’ll fit in just fine here.”

Agatha doubted that.

But as she looked around the trauma bay, something inside her eased despite herself.

Tony Stark was leaning against the wall, sweat-soaked and grinning like he’d just won something. Nurse Maximoff was rolling her eyes at him, fond and exasperated all at once as she wiped down an IV pole.

Across the room, Dr. Kale was speaking softly to a patient on the next gurney — a teenage girl, shaken but alive. Jen’s deep voice carried reassurance without condescension, her tall frame bent slightly so she could meet the girl’s eyes.

“Hey,” Jen said, smiling just enough to be kind but not patronising, “you’re all right now. Deep breaths, okay? You did good.”

Her gloved hand steadied the patient’s trembling one as she checked vitals, voice low and even, a steady anchor in the noise. There was a gentleness there that Agatha hadn’t expected, and for a brief, uncomfortable moment, she admired it.

Noted it, then dismissed it.

Focus, she told herself.

Maybe Westview wasn’t glamorous.
 Maybe it wasn’t Boston.

But for the first time in weeks, she felt something close to what she used to feel — the hum of life at her fingertips, purpose crackling in her blood.

She peeled off her gloves, set them aside, and finally allowed herself a long exhale.

That was when she noticed one last firefighter standing near the bay doors, just outside the circle of motion.

She hadn’t spoken much through the chaos — just assisted where needed, calm and steady, movements precise. Dark hair still damp, face streaked faintly with grime, she was quieter than the rest.

And then Agatha saw it- blood dripping, slow and rhythmic, from the cuff of her jacket.

Not patient blood. Her own.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed. “You,” she said sharply, crossing the space in a few strides. “You’re bleeding.”

The firefighter glanced down at her sleeve, as if only now noticing the red seeping through the heavy fabric. “Caught it on the wreckage,” she said evenly. “Metal edge. It’s nothing.”

“Nothing,” Agatha repeated flatly, “is not currently staining my floor.”

The woman hesitated — then, finally, the smallest flicker of a smile tugged at her mouth. There was a faint gap between her top teeth, and somehow, it made the smile disarming instead of careless. “Noted, Doctor.”

“Sit,” Agatha ordered, already snapping on a new pair of gloves. “Before you pass out and make my evening worse.”

There was a quiet beat of surprise, then the firefighter obeyed without argument, sinking onto the edge of a gurney.

Up close, Agatha saw the tear in her jacket sleeve, the deep but clean laceration along her upper arm — just above the bicep, where the muscle was corded and firm beneath tanned skin. She was strong, but not bulky — the kind of strength built from long shifts and real labour, from holding weight that wasn’t hers to carry.

“Name?”

“Vidal,” she said. “Rio Vidal.”

Agatha didn’t respond immediately, too focused on cleaning the wound. The skin around it was slick with a mix of rainwater and blood.

“You’ll need sutures,” she said, brisk and efficient.

Rio gave a small shrug. “I’ve had worse.”

“Unimpressive,” Agatha replied dryly, reaching for the needle driver. “Hold still.”

Rio did. Silent. Unflinching.

The silence between them wasn’t awkward — just heavy, filled with the quiet rhythm of Agatha’s work and the muffled hum of the ER winding down.

When she tied off the final stitch, Agatha sat back slightly. “You’ll live.”

“I’ll put that on a T-shirt,” Rio said softly.

Agatha raised an eyebrow, but the corner of her mouth betrayed her. Just barely.

Rio’s answering smile was small but real.

When Agatha finally stood, peeling off her gloves, she caught herself watching the firefighter a moment longer than necessary — taking in the calmness, the steadiness, the faint smear of soot at the edge of her jaw.

“Keep it clean and no heavy lifting for a week.” she said, almost absently.

“Yes, ma’am.”

Their eyes met — calm brown against storm-grey — and for a heartbeat too long, Agatha felt something shift. 

Something small but undeniable.

Maybe Westview wasn’t as dull as she’d thought.

 


The rain had stopped by the time Agatha left the hospital. The air was cool and heavy, the streets slick with a sheen of mist that glowed under the lamps. She drove slowly, windows cracked just enough to let the damp air in to keep herself awake.

It was a short drive, ten minutes at most, down quiet roads lined with old oaks and tidy houses whose porches already bore the soft fllicker of evening lights.

The cottage sat near the end of a curved lane, half-hidden by ivy and a garden that looked too wild to be accidental. A warm light glowed behind its windows.

Agatha still wasn’t used to it — to the narrow driveway, to the uneven path of flagstones leading to the door, to the faint creak of the porch underfoot. She’d only been here a week, but everything about it felt distinctly Lilia, deliberate chaos, comforting clutter, plants in every possible surface and the faint scent of sage and something sweetly floral in the air.

She unlocked the door and stepped into warmth.
“About time,” Lilia called from the kitchen. “I was starting to think that hospital had consumed you.”

Agatha smiled faintly, hanging her coat and bag by the door. “I survived.”

“You sound disappointed,” Lilia said. She was at the stove, hair a soft silver crown pinned in its usual twist, wearing a shawl patterned with constellations and patchwork. 

The smell of rosemary and garlic filled the room.

“I’m not disappointed,” Agatha said, moving toward the kitchen. “Just… unimpressed.”

Lilia turned, amusement flickering in her dark eyes. “Ah. So the day went well.”

“If by ‘well’ you mean dull beyond comprehension, yes.”

“Small towns will do that,” Lilia said, ladling stew into two bowls. “People here come to the ER for something to do.”

“I’ve noticed,” Agatha muttered, lowering herself into a chair at the kitchen table. The wood still smelled faintly of polish and lemon, everything in this house had a scent.

Lilia set a steaming bowl in front of her, then took her own seat across the table. “Eat. And no back-talk.”

Agatha obliged, taking a spoonful of lentil stew — the same recipe Lilia had made when she was sixteen and studying for exams at the Calderu kitchen table, back before med school, before Boston, before everything.

“I’m too tired to be hungry,” she said, but kept eating anyway.

Lilia smiled faintly. “First week’s the hardest. You’ve been running on nerves and caffeine since you arrived.”

Agatha gave a short, humourless laugh. “I’ve been running on instinct.”

Lilia watched her quietly for a moment, something thoughtful passing over her face. “You know,” she said, “I wasn’t sure you’d actually come.”

Agatha’s hand paused midair.

“You sounded…” Lilia searched for the word, “shattered. When you called.”

Agatha set the spoon down, jaw tightening. “That’s a little dramatic.”

“True, though,” Lilia said softly. “You were crying… You don’t cry.”

Agatha looked away, eyes fixed on the grain of the table. “I couldn’t stay there, Lilia. Every corridor was him. Every nurse remembered his name. Every time I scrubbed in, I saw his face.”

“Nicky,” Lilia said quietly.

Agatha’s breath caught — a sound, not quite a sob, more a tremor she refused to let through.

Lilia reached across the table, laying a hand over Agatha’s. “So you came here. Like I told you to.”

“You didn’t tell me,” Agatha murmured. “You commanded”

“I offered,” Lilia said with a small smile. “You just finally said yes.”

Agatha let out a slow breath. “You’ve been here ten years now. It still feels like I’m intruding.”

“You’re not,” Lilia said simply. “You’re home.”

“Your home,” Agatha corrected.

“Our home,” Lilia said, firm but kind. “It was always waiting for you. You just needed to be ready to arrive.”

Agatha said nothing for a long moment. The ticking of the old kitchen clock filled the space between them.

Finally, Lilia changed the subject, voice lighter. “And how was your first shift? Surely Westview gave you something worth your talent.”

Agatha hesitated, then nodded. “Multi-vehicle collision. One critical. Several minor. It was… chaos.”

“Which means you loved it,” Lilia teased gently.

“I didn’t hate it.”

Lilia smiled knowingly. “That’s as close to joy as you get, my dear.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, but there was no heat in it. “The team handled it well. Kale — the ER doctor — was competent, even kind. Maximoff was… efficient.”

Agatha paused, a small smile creeping on her face as brown eyes and a small gapped tooth smile flashed in memory.

“And?”

Agatha hesitated, fighting the pull of the memory — the smell of rain, the hush after the sirens, and that quiet firefighter sitting on the gurney as Agatha stitched her arm, her warm brown eyes never leaving Agatha’s face.

“And one of the firefighters was injured,” Agatha said finally. “Laceration on her arm. I sutured it.”

Lilia’s brow arched, smile curving with subtle delight. “Ah. And?”

“And nothing,” Agatha said, perhaps a little too sharply. “She was polite. Cooperative.”

“Pretty?”

Agatha’s spoon froze halfway to her mouth. “Irrelevant.”

Lilia’s smile deepened. “Which means yes.”

Agatha exhaled heavily. “You’re insufferable.”

“Part of my charm,” Lilia said.

“I don’t know why I tell you anything.”

“Because I raised you,” Lilia said simply. “And I still know how to read you better than you do yourself.”

Agatha smirked faintly. “Unfair advantage.”

“Someone has to keep up,” Lilia said. She leaned back, folding her hands. “You’ve been here a week and already sound… different. A little less haunted.”

Agatha stared down at her stew, the surface trembling with the faintest ripple. “Maybe I’m just tired.”

“Or maybe,” Lilia said softly, “something here is good for you. Someone, perhaps.”

Agatha shot her a warning look, but it only made Lilia’s grin widen.

“Go to bed,” Lilia said, standing to clear the dishes. “Before you start arguing with me and lose.”

“I never lose.”

“Mm,” Lilia hummed. “We’ll see.”

Agatha rose, collected her coat from the hook, and paused at the threshold of the hallway. “Goodnight.”

“Goodnight, my girl.”

She climbed the stairs to the small guest room — hers now — and paused at the window, watching the fog drift across the garden.

It still wasn’t home, not quite. The walls didn’t know her yet. But the air felt easier to breathe.

And somewhere, behind the static hum of the night, she could still hear that quiet voice from the ER saying:
Noted, Doctor.

Chapter 2

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

A week had passed since Agatha Harkness started at Westview General.

The town had already begun to sink its quiet rhythm under her skin — the soft fog each morning, the half-empty streets at dawn, the scent of damp leaves that clung to everything. 

The hospital itself was smaller than she was used to, slower, but there was comfort in the predictability of it.
Every day began the same, a coffee so strong it could dissolve metal, a ten-minute drive from Lilia’s ivy-covered cottage, and a mental checklist of everything she intended to control.

By the time she walked through the staff entrance, coat crisp, hair pinned, expression unreadable, she was the version of herself she knew best, precise, detached, competent.

The ER was already awake, humming with its usual morning chorus of machines, monitors, and human noise.

“Dr. Harkness!”

The bright voice came from the nurses’ station. Wanda, in her burgundy scrubs, waved a clipboard like a flag.  
“Your new intern’s here! Been waiting half an hour. Looks like he’s aged a year from nerves.”

Agatha frowned. “Intern?”

“Chief Romanoff’s orders,” Wanda said, trying, and failing, to hide her grin. “She said you’re exactly the kind of influence he needs.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened slightly. “God help him.”

Wanda chuckled. “He’s by the coffee machine. You’ll know which one.”

She didn’t elaborate, which was warning enough.

Sure enough, at the far end of the corridor stood a young man wh looked like he’d wandered out of a college band and gotten lost in the hospital. 

He was tall and awkward, all elbows and curly black hair, a stethoscope hanging too low around his neck. The faint trace of black eyeliner made his wide brown eyes look even bigger like a startled cat.

He noticed her instantly and froze, mid-sip of coffee.

“Dr. Harkness?” he blurted, spilling half the cup down his sleeve.

Agatha blinked once. “That would be me.”

“I’m—uh—William Caplan! Your intern!” He fumbled his ID badge straight. 

“Huge honour. Really. I read your case report on mitral valve rupture at Boston General. The one where you—uh—used a modified continuous suture pattern instead of standard interrupted technique? Genius!”

Agatha stared at him for a long moment. “You read my case reports.”

“Yes! And your trauma management notes. And, uh, the emergency thoracotomy article from the—”

“Stop talking,” she said mildly.

He stopped.

Wanda, passing by with a chart, murmured under her breath, “He’s very enthusiastic.”

“I can tell,” Agatha replied.

Caplan straightened his coat, trying to recover. “Right. Sorry. I just—uh—wanted to say it’s an honour to work under you. I promise I’ll work hard. Really hard. Maybe too hard.”

Agatha studied him for a moment, the nervous shifting, the bright eyes, the too-big coat. “How old are you, Caplan?”

“Uh… twenty-four, ma’am. Doctor.”

Agatha tilted her head slightly. “Are you sure? You look like you should still be asking permission to go to prom.”

His mouth opened, then closed again. “I—what?”

Wanda laughed outright from behind the desk.

Agatha smirked faintly. “I’ll call you Teen. Easier to remember.”

“Teen?” he echoed, bewildered.

“It suits you.”

“I—okay,” he said weakly. “Teen it is?”

“Good,” Agatha said, already turning toward the triage wing. “Now come on, Teen. Observation first. No interruptions unless I ask. And if you faint, do it somewhere discreet.”

“I don’t faint!” he said too quickly.

“Good. Then keep up.”

He followed at a near jog.

The first hour went smoothly enough. A sprained wrist, a mild concussion, a diabetic fainting spell — the usual small-town emergencies. Teen hovered close but quiet, scribbling notes that looked frantic even from a distance.

By the time they returned to the nurses’ station, Dr. Kale was leaning over a counter, chatting with Wanda while sorting through patient files. Her laugh carried easily across the room.

Jen straightened when she saw Agatha approach, tall and effortlessly striking, her buzzcut gleaming under the fluorescent lights. “Morning, Doctor Harkness. Breaking in the new kid?”

Caplan went a little pink. “Trying to keep up.”

Jen gave him an approving smile. “Good luck. She doesn’t slow down for anyone.”

“The way everyone should be,” Agatha muttered.

Jen’s grin only widened. “That’s why we love you, Harkness. Keeps the rest of us honest.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “Is that what we’re calling it?”

“Sure,” Jen said lightly. “Honesty, fear…same thing.”

Wanda snorted behind her hand.

Agatha ignored them both, flipping open a chart. “If the two of you are quite finished, some of us have work to do.”

Jen smirked. “You’re going soft. You gave the kid a nickname already.”

Agatha didn’t look up. “Easier to remember, I’m managing expectations.”

“Of him or yourself?” Jen teased.

“Both,” Agatha said coolly. “Now, if you’ll excuse me, Teen and I have patients.”

Wanda grinned as Agatha swept away, Caplan scurrying after her. “She likes you already!”

Caplan blinked. “Thats liking me?”

“Coming from her?” Wanda said. “It’s practically a hug.”

It wasn’t glamorous. It wasn’t Boston.
 But as Agatha moved through the rhythm of the ward — clear orders, steady work, quiet control — she felt, for the first time since arriving, the smallest glimmer of steadiness.

Detached, yes. But functional.
 Exactly how she liked it.

By midafternoon, the ER had settled into its rhythm, controlled chaos, the kind Agatha could measure her pulse by. Her new intern, Teen, had stopped tripping over cables, which she decided counted as improvement.

She was reviewing discharge notes when Wanda’s voice called from the corridor.
 “Bay Four, Doctor — one of your old patients. From the crash last week.”

Agatha didn’t look up. “Mine?”

“Technically,” Wanda said, a teasing lilt in her tone. “You did the sutures.”

Agatha finished signing the chart and moved to the next bay.

And there she was again, the firefighter from that night. 

Vidal.

She sat quietly on the edge of the gurney, hands clasped in her lap. Her dark hair was tied back, a few curls escaping around her temples. Her navy Fire & Rescue T-shirt clung to her shoulders, sleeves short enough to show off those damn toned forearms. 

She had the kind of stillness that drew attention without asking for it- quiet, composed, eyes lowered as she waited.

Agatha’s gaze went to her arm immediately. 

The dressing was half off. The sutures — her sutures — had torn.

Agatha’s voice cut clean through the hum of the room. “You reopened the incision.”

Rio looked up at her, startled but not defensive. Her voice was soft, steady. “I think I caught it on something. It started bleeding a little a few days ago, but it stopped.”

“Bleeding a little?” Agatha repeated, stepping closer. “You were told to avoid lifting anything heavy. Clearly that instruction was too complex.”

Wanda, across the bay, smirked. “Easy, Doctor. She came back, didn’t she?”

Agatha ignored her, snapping on gloves. “Sit up straighter.”

Rio obeyed immediately, shoulders straightening, gaze dropping again. She didn’t flinch when Agatha began peeling back the edge of the dressing, though her breath hitched when antiseptic touched the skin.

The wound had reopened in two places — not badly, but enough to irritate Agatha’s sense of order.

“What did you lift?” Agatha said.

Rio hesitated, then nodded once. “We had a training drill. I didn’t think—”

“Clearly.” Agatha’s tone softened, almost imperceptibly. “You’re fortunate it didn’t reopen completely.”

Rio’s eyes flickered up — warm brown, deep and steady. “Sorry.”

It wasn’t defensive, just simple and sincere.

Something in Agatha stilled. She wasn’t used to apologies that weren’t excuses.

“Don’t be,” she said briskly, reaching for a fresh suture kit. “Just hold still.”

Wanda moved closer, rolling up her sleeves. “I can do it—”

“No,” Agatha interrupted. “She’s my patient. I’ll redo them.”

Wanda’s smirk returned, softer this time. “Of course.”

Agatha focused on her work, the neat precision of motion, the familiar rhythm of needle and thread. 
Rio didn’t move, didn’t fidget, didn’t even look away. Only the slow rise and fall of her breathing betrayed her discomfort.

“Not squeamish,” Agatha murmured, mostly to herself.

Rio’s lips curved faintly, not a smile, exactly, but something gentler. “We see worse.”

Agatha tied off the final stitch, checked the alignment, and sat back. “That should hold this time. Try not to sabotage my work again.”

“I’ll be careful,” Rio said quietly.

“Good,” Agatha replied.

When she reached for the gauze, Rio lifted her arm slightly to make it easier — not meeting Agatha’s eyes, but her movement was careful, almost considerate.

“Keep it dry for forty-eight hours,” Agatha instructed. “If it pulls again, come straight back.”

Rio nodded. “Thanks, Doc.”

Her voice had that low steadiness again — unhurried, self-contained. It left no room for banter, no invitation to flirt. Just quiet sincerity.

Agatha found herself watching her longer than necessary as Wanda applied the final strip of tape.

When Rio slid off the gurney, pulling her jacket back on, Wanda’s gaze flicked between them — all knowing amusement. “Take care, Rio,” she said warmly. “We’ll see you soon, hopefully not for stitches.”

Rio gave a small nod. “Hopefully.” Then she looked once, briefly, toward Agatha. “Have a good evening.”

“You too,” Agatha said automatically.

When she was gone, Wanda turned, arms folded, that smug smile firmly in place.

“What,” Agatha said flatly.

“Nothing,” Wanda replied, her tone anything but innocent. “Just nice to see you doing hands-on follow-up care. It’s very… nurturing of you.”

Agatha gave her a cool glance. “Don’t start.”

“I wouldn’t dream of it,” Wanda said, already walking away. “Though if I were dreaming, I think I’d keep that look you had on your face just now. Very rare.”

Agatha glared after her, then exhaled through her nose.

“Teen,” she called, as she pulled off her gloves.

Her intern poked his head around the corner, eyes wide. “Yes, Doctor?”

“Clean the bay.”

“Yes, Doctor!”

He scurried in with a mop and bucket.

Agatha straightened her coat, composed again, and told herself that the faint warmth under her skin was irritation — nothing more.

 

By the time the clock edged toward 8:00pm, the ER had thinned to its usual end-of-shift lull — the kind of calm that wasn’t truly calm, just the eye of the storm before night shift took over.

Agatha was finishing her last notes when Wanda appeared at her elbow, eyes wide and full of hope.

“Shift’s over,” Wanda said lightly. “You’re coming out with us.”

Agatha didn’t look up. “Us?”

“Me, Jen, and Alice,” Wanda replied. “Drinks at The Witches’ Road. It’s tradition. You’ve survived your first full week , we should celebrate.”

Across the nurses’ station, Jen was perched on the edge of the counter, perfectly composed as always. 

Her soft pink blouse was tucked into tailored slacks, gold hoops glinting under the hospital lights. Even after twelve hours on her feet, she looked editorial.

“Come on, Harkness,” Jen said, crossing one leg elegantly over the other. “A drink won’t kill you. I mean, you’ve got to loosen that spine sometime.”

“I prefer to remain upright,” Agatha replied.

From the far end of the hall, Alice, still in her paramedic uniform, waved shyly with one hand while fiddling with her radio. “We’re just going for one drink,” she said in her soft, deliberate tone. “It’s not really optional. Jen said so.”

“I don’t recall giving her authority over my schedule,” Agatha said.

“She takes it,” Wanda said with a grin. “You’ll like it there. Low lighting. Good vodka. Questionable decor.”

Agatha slipped her pen into her pocket, calm as ever. “I’ll pass.”

Jen rolled her eyes, though her smile stayed fond. “You’re going to have to make friends eventually, Doctor.”

“I have acquaintances,” Agatha said crisply. “That’s sufficient.”

“Mm-hm.” Wanda arched a brow. “Well, when you get tired of drinking coffee and judging humanity from a safe distance, you know where to find us.”

“Sure,” Agatha said, standing and collecting her things.

Jen smoothed the sleeve of her blush-pink blouse, adjusting the fine silk scarf at her neck. 

“Your loss, Harkness. After 3 martini’s I can do a mean Adele on kareoke.”

Alice, leaning shyly against the counter in her navy paramedic jacket, blushed but smiled. “You promised you were going for one drink.”

“I did,” Jen said easily. “But my girlfriend didn’t say what size.” She reached out, brushing her fingers against Alice’s wrist, the gesture soft and fond.

Wanda grinned at them both, tucking her clipboard under her arm. “Come on, lovebirds. Let’s leave the good doctor to her paperwork and solitude.”

“Tragic,” Jen sighed dramatically. “Imagine spending a Friday night filing charts when she could be sipping gin and judging humanity from a bar stool.”

“I can judge humanity perfectly well from here,” Agatha replied without looking up.

Wanda chuckled, already pulling on her coat. “Suit yourself. One day you’ll join us and realise we’re much better entertainment than your patient reports.”

“Doubtful,” Agatha said dryly, signing the last page.

Alice offered her a small, polite smile. “Goodnight, Doctor Harkness.”

Agatha nodded. “Try not to end up in my ER.”

“Always the optimist,” Jen teased, looping her arm through Alice’s as they headed down the corridor.

Agatha ignored her and headed for the staff room.

They were good people. That was the trouble.
 Good people tried to get close.

The drive home was quiet, the kind of small-town stillness that made her chest ache if she thought about it too long. The roads were mostly empty, streetlights washing everything in pale amber.

Halfway down Main Street, the radio crackled to life, static giving way to the low, familiar hum of Fleetwood Mac. Something from another decade —all velvet and longing, the kind of song that knew how to fill silence without demanding too much.

By the second chorus, she realised she was humming softly, almost under her breath, the sound foreign to her own ears. 

The kind of small, unguarded habit she thought she’d left behind in Boston.

When the song ended, she exhaled, switched the radio off, and let the quiet settle again.

By the time she turned onto Lilia’s street, the moon had risen pale and full over the houses, and a soft light glowed through the cottage windows.

When she stepped inside, the scent of candle wax hitt her immediately.

“Good lord,” Agatha muttered, hanging her coat by the door. “It’s a fire hazard in here.”

Lilia Calderu looked up from the dining table, where at least a dozen candles burned at different heights, wax dripping into little glass dishes. The light haloed her silver hair and glinted off the edge of a tarot deck spread in a neat crescent.

“You’d think a woman who spends her days surrounded by beeping machinery would appreciate a little atmosphere,” Lilia said.

“I’d appreciate not dying of smoke inhalation.”

“You worry too much.”

“It’s literally my profession,” Agatha said, moving to pour herself a camomile tea.

Lilia smiled. “You sound tired.”

“I am.”

“Then sit. You’re due a reading.”

Agatha sighed, but obeyed, settling into the chair opposite her. The air smelled like sage and something faintly sweet — maybe honey.

Lilia turned the top card of the deck. 

The Tower.

Agatha eyed it. “Charming.”

“It’s not about disaster,” Lilia said, her voice soft but steady. “It’s about necessary upheaval. What falls apart to make room for truth.”

“Fitting.”

Lilia’s mouth curved. “Precisely.”

She turned another card — The Lovers, reversed.

Agatha snorted. “Oh, here we go. Is that supposed to mean I’ll never find my one true love?”

“It’s observation,” Lilia said simply. “A reminder that denial is a poor disguise for fear.”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed. “You’ve been waiting a while to say that, haven’t you?”

“Maybe,” Lilia said, smiling. “You came here to heal, my dear. But healing doesn’t happen in isolation.”

Agatha folded her arms, looking away. “I’m fine.”

Lilia studied her for a long, quiet moment. “You always say that. You said it at ten when your mother forgot your birthday. You said it at twenty when Boston nearly broke you. You said it two weeks go when you walked through my door looking like a ghost.”

Agatha said nothing.

Finally, Lilia reached forward and flipped the third card. 

Temperance.

“Balance,” she murmured. “Between what you control and what you feel. That’s your lesson, Agatha.”

Agatha’s mouth twitched — not quite a smile, but something near it. “You’re enjoying this far too much.”

“Only because it’s true.”

Agatha stood, brushing her hands against her slacks. “You should blow half of these candles out before bed.”

Lilia chuckled. “You’re a doubter.”

“And you’re combustible,” Agatha said, moving toward the stairs.

“Sleep well, my girl.”

“Mm.”

Agatha paused at the landing, glancing back. The candles flickered in the dim, their light spilling across the table — The Tower, The Lovers reversed, Temperance.

She shook her head and climbed the rest of the way up, telling herself she didn’t believe in signs.


She showered, changed, and slipped beneath the cool sheets, the faint scent of Lilia’s lavender detergennt clinging to the pillow. The cottage was silent but for the soft crackle of candles burning down somewhere below.

Sleep came slowly.

When it did, it came with the sound of sirens.

The dream unfolded in sterile white — monitors beeping, gloves snapping, her own voice echoing commands she’d said a thousand times.
 Clamp. Compress. Keep pressure steady.

There was a child on the table. A boy.

Nicky.

Big brown eyes, too large for his face, looking up at her as though she were something more than mortal. His lips were moving, but no sound came. Just the faint rasp of a failing breath.

“I’ve got you,” she heard herself say, the words autonmatic, desperate. “Stay with me.”

The monitors wailed. Her hands pressed harder, but her fingers slid on blood. The room blurred, light burning at the edges until she couldn’t tell where her hands ended and his skin began.

“Nicky—”

His eyes blinked once, slow and pleading. And then — impossibly — they weren’t his anymore.

They were older. Darker. Steady.

Warm brown, like the earth after rain.

Agatha froze, her breath catching. The boy’s face shifted, not in shape, but in presence. His hair darkened, his jaw sharpened, the soft curve of youth giving way to something stronger, quieter.

Rio.

The same calm gaze that had met hers in the ER, wordless and unflinching.

For a moment, the world stilled. The beeping faded. Her heartbeat filled the silence.

Then Rio spoke, not alous, but in that strange, echoing way dreams allowed.
 You can’t save everyone, Doctor.

Agatha reached for her, but her hands met nothing but light, blinding and weightless.

She gasped awake.

Her room was dark. The air smelled faintly of candle wax and sweat. The ticking of Lilia’s clock was too loud.

Agatha pressed the heel of her palm to her eyes, forcing her breathing to steady. Her throat was tight, her skin damp with sweat.

It was just a dream.
 It had been months since Nicky.
 And Rio Vidal was a firefighter with a decent pain threshold, nothing more.

She turned on her side, eyes fixed on the dim light under her door, the last flicker of candles dying somewhere downstairs.

But even as sleep crept back in, the image stayed, those same brown eyes, open and unafraid, watching her from the edge of memory.

Chapter End Notes

I have so much of this already written but I keep going back to change parts I'm not completely happy with.

Hopefully I can update on Saturday.... if I'm not too distracted with everyone else's Kinktober fics :)

Chapter 3

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes


It was her first day off since arriving in Westview.

Lilia had insisted.

“You can’t spend your life under unnatural fluorescent lights,” she had said, shooing Agatha toward the door with a mug of tea. “Go breathe. Touch some grass. Engage with existence.”

Agatha had muttered that her existence was perfectly engaged in patient care, but Lilia only smiled that infuriating, knowing smile.

So now she was outside, walking aimlessly through a town that still didn’t feel like hers.

Westview in the spring sun looked almost picturesque. The air smelled faintly of rain and tulips, and the streets were lined with old elms and neatly painted porches. People waved as they passed. Children dragged scooters down the pavement. It was all so peaceful that Agatha found it vaguely unnerving.

After a few blocks, she found herself standing before a café called The Rabbit Hole. Its chalkboard sign promised Coffee, Cakes, and Peace.

She doubted the last one but went in anyway.

The bell above the door chimed softly. The air was warm, filled with the scent of espresso and sugar. She ordered a black coffee, her go to, and took a seat near the window.

It was quiet here. Gentle conversation, the low hiss of the espresso machine, and a faint hum of an old Bruce Springsteen song playing overhead.

She let herself relax, just a little.

Then she heard a familiar voice at the counter.

“Two oat lattes, please, and one of those croissants before Kate gets there first.”

Agatha looked up. Alice Wu-Gulliver stood at the counter, still in her navy paramedic uniform, her curls pinned neatly back, red flashes peeking through. She looked a little tired but content. Beside her was a younger woman with sharp dark brows, soft features, and a grin that bordered on trouble. Her name tag read Kate Bishop, EMT.

As the barista handed them their order, Kate turned and immediately spotted Agatha by the window. Her grin widened.

“Is that her?”

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “Excuse me?”

Alice followed her gaze, surprised, then smiled. “Doctor Harkness! I didn’t see you there.”

Kate nudged her lightly. “The Doctor Harkness? I’ve heard about you. You’re kind of a legend at the hospital already.”

Agatha took a slow sip of coffee. “Legends are usually dead.”

“Maybe that’s why you look so pale,” Kate said easily.

Alice gave her a look. “Kate.”

“What? I meant it as a compliment,” Kate said, grinning. “You’ve got this whole mystery thing going. People talk.”

Agatha blinked once. “People need hobbies.”

Alice laughed softly under her breath. “Don’t mind her, Doctor. She’s running on three hours of sleep.”

“Delirium suits her,” Agatha replied.

Kate placed a hand over her heart in mock injury. “Wow. You really are as sharp as they say.”

Agatha’s lips twitched, not quite a smile but close enough to surprise even herself.

Alice adjusted the tray in her hands. “You missed a good night last night. The Witches’ Road was packed. Jen and Wanda dragged half the hospital staff out.”

“Sounds riveting,” Agatha said. “It seems exercised good judgment and stayed home.”

Alice smiled faintly. “Probably wise. Though you would’ve been impressed—my roommate even showed up. That almost never happens.”

“Your roommate?”

Alice nodded, a hint of amusement in her tone. “Yep. It’s rare. About as rare as seeing you outside the hospital.”

Kate laughed. “So last night was basically historic.”

Agatha stirred her coffee. “I see Westview takes its milestones seriously.”

Alice’s eyes softened. “You should come next time. It’s good for morale.”

“I have adequate morale,” Agatha said.

Kate grinned. “Of course you do.”

Their drinks were called up, and Alice turned to collect the tray. “Well, we won’t keep you. Enjoy your day off, Doctor. Lilia must be proud she got you out of the house.”

Agatha frowned slightly. “You know Lilia?”

“Everyone knows Lilia,” Alice said, as if it were obvious. “She helps at the community garden, does readings for half the town, fixes things when people are falling apart. She’s… sort of the unofficial mayor, if we’re honest.”

Agatha frowned slightly. “I see.”

Kate grinned. “Yeah, Lilia’s a legend. If you ever need something in this town, she knows who to call.”

“Fascinating,” Agatha said, though her tone made it sound anything but.

Alice adjusted the tray again. “Well, we won’t keep you. Enjoy your day off, Doctor. Tell Lilia we said hi.”

“I’ll… do that,” Agatha replied.

Kate waved. “See you around, Doc.”

The bell above the door jingled softly as they left, laughter spilling into the sunlight.

Agatha stayed for a while longer, the coffee cooling in her cup. Outside, the small town went about its quiet business.

She found herself thinking about what Alice had said — Lilia fixing things, being known. It shouldn’t have surprised her. Lilia had always had a gift for knowing people, for weaving herself into places as though she’d always belonged.

Still, Agatha couldn’t shake the faint unease that came with realising just how much of Westview seemed to orbit the woman who had raised her.

 

 

The sun was low when she eventually returned to the house. The air had cooled, carrying the scent of lilacs from the garden. Through the kitchen window she saw Lilia moving about the stove, sleeves rolled up, the soft flicker of candlelight turning the small kitchen gold.

“I survived my day off,” Agatha announced, stepping inside and hanging her coat on the chair.

Lilia looked over, smiling. “You say that as if the town would attack you.”

“It nearly did. People kept trying to talk to me.”

“That sounds terrible,” Lilia said with mock sympathy. “Did you at least talk back?”

“Occasionally,” Agatha admitted, moving to the counter. “You’ve made quite a name for yourself in this place, by the way. Everyone seems to know you.”

“Of course they do. I’ve lived here a decade.”

Agatha picked up a loaf of bread and started slicing it, each cut precise. “They talk about you like you’re some kind of local oracle.”

Lilia chuckled, tasting the sauce. “When people don’t understand something, they give it a title. Oracle. Witch. Wise woman. It’s all the same word wearing different shoes.”

“I’m sure it’s flattering.”

“Mostly it’s exhausting,” Lilia said, setting the spoon aside. “But I listen, and people trust me. That’s all it takes.”

Agatha poured two glasses of water and leaned against the counter. “You’ve always made that sound easy.”

“It’s easy when you care.”

“That’s your mistake, then.”

Lilia gave her a patient look, the kind she’d used since Agatha was a child. “You can pretend not to, my dear, but I know better.”

Agatha said nothing.

Lilia gestured to the table. “Sit before that sharp tongue of yours curdles my sauce.”

Dinner was quiet, the air heavy with the smell of garlic and herbs. Candlelight shimmered across the plates. Outside, the sky had gone dusky blue, rain whispering faintly against the window.

After a few minutes, Lilia broke the silence. “You look lighter tonight.”

Agatha blinked. “Do I?”

“You do,” Lilia said simply. “Your shoulders aren’t trying to touch your ears anymore. I take that as progress.”

Agatha sighed softly, pretending to focus on her food. “You always exaggerate.”

“I just always notice,” Lilia countered gently.

They ate a little longer in companionable silence. Lilia poured tea once the plates were cleared and settled across from her, hands folded around the cup.

“This place suits you,” she said after a moment. “You might not believe it yet, but it does.”

“I didn’t come here to be suited to anything. I came here to work.”

“Working and living aren’t the same thing,” Lilia said.

“For me they are.”

“Not forever,” Lilia replied softly, a small smile touching her lips. “You’ll see.”

Agatha lifted her cup, the steam warming her face. “You’re being weirdly cryptic again.”

“I prefer the word patient.”

Agatha gave her a flat look. “You enjoy annoying me far too much.”

“I enjoy watching you pretend you don’t have a heart,” Lilia said, not unkindly.

Agatha leaned back in her chair. “You’re impossibly soft.”

“And you’re predictable,” Lilia said, still smiling. “Now finish your tea before it goes cold.”

Later, upstairs, Agatha paused by the window. The rain had stopped, and the town was quiet. A few lights still glowed in nearby houses, soft and domestic.

For a moment she thought she heard a siren somewhere in the distance, faint and far away. Then it faded, leaving only the sound of the wind through the trees.

She turned off the lamp and went to bed, telling herself that tomorrow would be better.

 

 

 

 


Morning light leaked across the mirror, pale and merciless.

Agatha stared at her reflection, studying the hollows beneath her eyes, the faint grey shadows carved by too many sleepless nights. Her hair was pinned neatly, but her eyes were dull, once sharp and alive, now flat as winter glass.

She touched the edge of the sink, her knuckles whitening.
 “Brilliant,” she murmured at her reflection. “You do look half dead.”

The woman in the mirror said nothing.

Downstairs, the scent of baked cheese and herbs filled the air. She followed it to the kitchen, where Lilia was taking a bubbling lasagna out of the oven, humming under her breath.

“Please tell me that isn’t breakfast,” Agatha said, pulling her coat tighter.

“It’s lunch,” Lilia replied. “Though not ours.”

Agatha frowned. “Then whose?”

“The firehouse.”

Agatha blinked. “Firehouse?”

Lilia waved a hand as she covered the dish with foil. “I make them lunch once a month. Sometimes more if they’ve had a rough few weeks. Keeps them fed and loved.”

Agatha poured herself coffee. “They’re firefighters, not stray cats.”

“Even heroes need fed,” Lilia said lightly. “You’ll be passing by the station on your way in, won’t you? Take it for me.”

Agatha stared at her over the rim of her mug. “You want me to deliver food?”

“Yes.”

“Because?”

“Because I asked” Lilia said, smiling.

Agatha sighed. “You’re too nice.”

“And you’re stubborn,” Lilia said, tucking the dish into a carry bag and pressing it into her hands. “Now go be kind. It won’t kill you.”

The Westview Fire and Rescue station stood near the edge of town, red brick against a pale morning sky. 

Agatha parked, straightened her tan trench coat, and stepped inside with the lasagna balanced carefully in her arms.

The air smelled of metal and soap. Voices echoed through the open bay — low laughter, the clatter of tools, someone tuning a radio.

A tall blond man turned toward her, wiping his hands on a rag. His shirt read CPTN ROGERS.

“Can I help you, ma’am?”

“Dr. Agatha Harkness,” she said crisply. “I was told to deliver this.” She lifted the dish slightly. “From Lilia Calderu.”

His expression softened instantly. “Ah, Lilia. She’s the best. You must be her new house guest, then.”

“Reluctantly,” Agatha muttered.

Steve chuckled. “We love her cooking. Tell her we’re very grateful.”

“I’ll pass it along.”

Before he could reply, another voice cut through the space.

“Well, well, if it isn’t Westview General’s very own ice queen.”

Tony Stark sauntered over, smirk firmly in place, coffee mug dangling from his fingers.

Agatha’s expression didn’t shift. ”Stark.”

“Doctor Harkness,” he said, leaning against the counter. “Back so soon? What’d we do to earn the honour?”

“I was coerced.”

“Shame,” Tony said. “You could’ve just said you missed me.”

Agatha gave him a measured look. “If I ever miss you, it’ll be because I’ve suffered a head injury.”

The firefighters around them burst into laughter. Tony winced theatrically. “You know, Doc, one day that razor tongue’s gonna cut something vital.”

“One can only hope it’s you,” she said, brushing past him to set the dish down.

Even Steve had to look away to hide his grin.

“Play nice, Stark,” he warned.

Tony held up his hands in surrender. “I’m trying! She’s just immune to charm.”

“I’m immune to bullshit,” Agatha said without looking at him.

The laughter rolled again, and Tony muttered something about “tough crowds” before retreating toward the coffee pot.

Agatha smoothed the foil on the dish, ready to leave — but her attention caught on movement across the bay.

Firefighter Vidal was loading gear into the back of a truck. Her navy shirt clung to the lines of her shoulders, short sleeves showing off tanned arms that flexed with quiet ease as she lifted a heavy hose and coiled it neatly. Her dark hair was tied back, a few strands escaping around her face.

Agatha froze before she could stop herself.

There was something hypnotic about the precision of her movements — the strength without aggression, the quiet focus. When she turned slightly, Agatha caught a glimpse of her profile, and something in her chest tightened. Calm brown eyes. That same composed stillness she remembered from the trauma bay.
And then, as if sensing the stare, Rio looked up.

Their eyes met.

Agatha didn’t move, didn’t breathe. It was a heartbeat — maybe two — but it was enough. A faint, polite smile curved the Rio’s lips before she looked away, lifting the last piece of equipment into place.

Agatha’s pulse jumped. She forced herself to clear her throat and turn back to Steve, who was politely pretending not to notice.

“Well, food’s delivered,” she said briskly. “I should go.”

Steve smiled. “We appreciate it, Doctor. And Lilia too.”

Agatha gave a curt nod. “Of course.”

She walked out, heels clicking against the concrete, and didn’t allow herself to look back.

Not until she was already outside, the sunlight too bright against her eyes.

From the driver’s seat, she caught one last glimpse through the open bay doors —Rio standing by the truck, brushing a strand of hair from her face as she laughed at something one of the others said.

It wasn’t loud laughter. Just soft, shy and genuine.

Agatha started the car and pulled away, jaw set.

She told herself the tightness in her chest was irritation.

Nothing more.

But as she drove toward the hospital, her thoughts kept circling back to those steady brown eyes and the hint of warmth in them that somehow made her own reflection from that morning feel even colder.

 


The hospital was too quiet, again.

Not the peaceful kind of quiet — the oppressive kind that filled the hallways when the chaos stopped. 

Agatha hated it. She thrived on the noise, the movement, the pulse of adrenaline that made her mind sharper than her grief could ever dull it.

Now, with the monitors humming softly and the air too still, her thoughts had too much room to breathe.

She was finishing up paperwork when she noticed Wanda Maximoff standing at the nurses’ station, unmoving, her usual brightness dimmed to a faint flicker. The nurse’s red hair had fallen from its bun, a loose strand tucked absently behind her ear. She was staring at a chart but clearly wasn’t reading it.

“You’re quiet,” Agatha said, her tone more clipped than concerned. “That’s unnatural for you.”

Wanda blinked, startled, then smiled faintly. “oh, just thinking.”

“About what?”

“Nothing good,” Wanda admitted, her voice soft. “It’s the anniversary of my brother’s death. Three years today.”

Agatha froze, pen hovering above the page. She hadn’t expected that kind of honesty. Most people hid grief behind chatter. Wanda offered hers like a confession.

“I see,” Agatha said after a moment, her voice quieter than usual. “I didn’t know.”

Wanda shook her head. “You couldn’t have. He died suddenly. Some days I still feel like I’ll turn a corner and find him there. Silly, isn’t it?”

“Not at all.” Agatha set down her pen. “Loss does that. It tricks the mind into waiting for someone it already knows is gone.”

Wanda’s eyes lifted to hers, faintly wet but calm. “That’s… exactly it.”

Agatha shrugged lightly, as if trying to diminish her own words. “You learn to live with the echoes. They never quite fade.”

For a moment, neither of them spoke. The low hum of machines filled the space between them.

Then Wanda smiled faintly, the expression tired but genuine. “You know, you’re a good friend, Agatha.”

The word hit like a sudden drop in pressure.

Friend.

Her breath caught — so fast she almost didn’t notice it until her throat ached.
 She hadn’t heard that word used for her in years. Not since—
Nicky.

The boy with the fragile heart and bright smile. The one who’d looked up at her with wide brown eyes and said, You’re my friend, right, Dr. Harkness?
 She had promised him she was.

And then she’d lost him.

Her chest constricted. The room blurred at the edges.

“Excuse me,” she said abruptly, voice steady but thin.

Wanda blinked, concerned. “Agatha? Are you—”

“I have charts to finish,” she said quickly, already turning away. “You should take your break.”

Before Wanda could answer, Agatha walked off, her heels echoing down the hallway, sharp and fast.

She didn’t stop until she reached the supply room — quiet, dim, blessedly empty.

She leaned against the counter, pressing a hand to her sternum as if she could physically hold herself together. Her eyes burned, but she refused to let them fall.

Friend.

It was such a small word. Such a simple, devastating thing.

After a moment, she drew in a deep breath, straightened her coat, and forced herself back to composure. 
When she stepped out again, no trace of it showed — just the familiar, cool precision of Dr. Harkness.

But all through the rest of her shift, the echo of that word followed her. Not as pain exactly. Something closer to remembering.

 

By the time Agatha arrived home, the sky had dimmed to the colour of cooling embers. The air smelled faintly of lilacs and wood smoke, the kind of soft domestic peace she never quite knew what to do with.

Inside, the cottage was warm. Too warm.

Lilia was at the stove, stirring something fragrant, saffron, garlic, white wine. “You’re home late,” she said without turning.

“Busy day,” Agatha murmured, setting her bag on the counter. “Don’t wait up. I’m not hungry.”

Lilia gave the pan one last stir before glancing over her shoulder. “I made risotto.”

“I noticed,” Agatha said, loosening her collar. “It won’t help.”

“Nothing helps if you refuse to sit still long enough for it to.”

Agatha sighed. “Lilia—”

“I know,” she interrupted gently. “You don’t want to talk. You don’t want to eat. You want to hide.”

Agatha frowned. “Something like that.”

“Then go on,” Lilia said, sighing lightly. “Sulk away.”

Agatha rolled her eyes and turned toward the stairs. “Goodnight.”

She’d only made it a few steps up when a knock sounded at the door.

Lilia’s head lifted, eyes narrowing for half a second before her whole face softened. “Ah,” she murmured, already wiping her hands. “Right on time.”

“Who—” Agatha began, but Lilia had already opened the door.

And there she was.

Rio Vidal stood on the porch, her dark hair pulled back loosely, a faint sheen of fatigue softening the angles of her face. She still wore her navy Fire & Rescue jacket, one hand holding a glass dish — the lasagna tray from that morning.

“Hey Lil,” Rio said quietly. “I just came to return this. I didn’t want it sitting in my car overnight.”

Lilia’s smile widened, kind but not surprised. “Oh Rio, you’re far too polite. You could’ve brought it tomorrow.”

“I was passing anyway,” Rio said. “Didn’t mean to interrupt.”

“You’re not interrupting,” Lilia said. “You’re saving me from eating this risotto alone.” She pulled at Rio’s free hand.

“Oh, I couldn’t—”

“Of course you could,” Lilia said, already stepping back to let her in. “One bowl won’t hurt.”

Rio hesitated. “I don’t want to impose.”

From the stairs, Agatha’s voice cut through, sharper than intended. “She’s right — you should stay.”

Both women turned.

Agatha was standing halfway down the steps, one hand on the banister, pretending indifference even as her pulse picked up.

Lilia hid her smile. “I thought you weren’t hungry, dear.”

Agatha descended the rest of the way with what she hoped was dignity. “Well I changed my mind. You know I hate when food goes to waste.”

“Convenient timing,” Lilia said, voice mild but glinting with amusement. “Well, that settles it.”

She ushered Rio toward the kitchen. “Take off your jacket. Sit down. I’ll grab another plate.”

Rio looked a little uncertain but obeyed, carefully folding her jacket over the back of a chair. She moved quietly, as though afraid to take up too much space.

Agatha poured herself water, acutely aware of her own movements, of the warmth in the air, of the faint scent of smoke clinging to Rio’s sleeves.

Lilia set three plates on the table and served with practiced ease. “So Rio,” she said casually, “how’s work been this week?”

Rio smiled faintly. “Quiet. That’s not always a good thing, but it’s nice for a change.”

“Agatha doesn’t like quiet,” Lilia said.

Agatha gave her a look. “I like being busy.”

“That’s not what I said,” Lilia replied, taking her seat.

Rio’s mouth quirked. “I think I understand what she means, though. Sometimes you need the noise. It keeps you grounded.”

Agatha paused mid-bite, studying her. “Exactly.”

Rio met her eyes briefly, then ducked her head, as if embarrassed by the connection.

The conversation drifted gently after that — work, the weather, small absurdities about Westview life. Rio spoke little but with thoughtfulness, and when she laughed — soft, shy, genuine — something in Agatha’s chest loosened.

Lilia, ever the observer, kept her tone easy and her comments benign, but her eyes missed nothing. She noticed how Agatha leaned forward slightly when Rio spoke, how Rio’s voice grew steadier the longer Agatha listened. The rhythm between them was subtle, quiet, but alive.

When the plates were empty, Lilia rose to pour the wine. “You’ll stay for a glass?” she asked.

Rio hesitated. “Oh— uh— Just one.”

“One’s how it starts,” Lilia teased, and poured anyway.

Agatha smirked faintly. “She says that like it’s sinister.”

“It is,” Lilia said with a wink. “In moderation.”

She poured a little more wine into each of their glasses, then clapped her hands as if suddenly remembering something. “Ah! I nearly forgot — I promised Sharon I’d give her a reading tonight.”

Agatha froze, mid-sip. “Who’s Sharon?”

“My neighbour,” Lilia said cheerfully, already untying her apron. “She’s been in a mood all week; the cards might help.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes. “You’re leaving now?”

Lilia grabbed her shawl from the hook by the door. “It’s only next door, dear. You’ll survive without me for half an hour.”

“Convenient timing,” Agatha muttered.

“I prefer divine,” Lilia said with a mischievous smile. “Enjoy the rest of the wine, you two.”

The front door shut behind her, and silence bloomed in her wake.

Rio looked slightly startled, glancing toward the door and then back to Agatha. “Should I—?”

“No, stay,” Agatha said before she could stop herself. Her tone came out sharper than intended, so she added, softer, “She’ll only chase you down the street if you try to leave.”

Rio laughed quietly. “You’re probably right.”

Agatha sat back in her chair, trying to appear indifferent, though she could feel the warmth rising in her chest. The candlelight between them flickered, catching on Rio’s features — the slope of her cheek, the faint gap between her top teeth when she smiled, the way her eyes seemed to hold more light than the flame itself.

“So,” Agatha said, more to fill the silence than anything. “How long have you lived in Westview?”

“Almost five years,” Rio said, tracing a fingertip along the stem of her glass. “Moved here after my abeuela passed. Needed a fresh start.”

Agatha tilted her head. “And you found one?”

Rio smiled faintly. “Mostly. It’s a quiet town, but the people are good. It’s the kind of place that keeps you, even when you think you might leave.”

Agatha hummed softly. “I’m not convinced that’s a good thing.”

“For some people, maybe not,” Rio said, meeting her gaze. “But sometimes staying still can be its own kind of courage.”

The words caught Agatha off guard. She looked away, pretending to adjust her glass. “You’re oddly philosophical for someone who runs into burning buildings.”

Rio chuckled softly. “You think we don’t have time to think in there?”

“I think most people prefer not to.”

“Maybe,” Rio said. “But when everything’s on the line, you learn to see what matters pretty quickly.”

Agatha’s chest tightened — the echo of Nicky’s voice, of hospital monitors, of losses she couldn’t forget. 
She masked it behind a sip of wine. “And what matters?”

Rio studied her for a long moment before answering. “Connection. People who see you. It doesn’t happen often, but when it does, you don’t forget it.”

Agatha swallowed. “That sounds dangerously sentimental.”

Rio smiled. “Doesn’t make it untrue.”

Silence settled between them again, softer this time. The air hummed faintly with the sound of the clock in the next room and the low murmur of the kettle Lilia must’ve left on.

Agatha surprised herself by relaxing into it. She wasn’t good at quiet — it usually pressed in on her, made her restless — but this was different. It wasn’t empty. It felt… steady.

Safe.

Rio broke the silence first, her voice gentle. “You’re not what I expected.”

Agatha blinked. “Meaning?”

“You’ve got quite a reputation at the hospital already,” Rio said, her tone careful but teasing. “Tough. Unshakable. The kind of doctor who could probably perform surgery during an earthquake.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “All accurate so far.”

Rio’s smile widened. “But I think there’s more underneath.”

“Don’t psychoanalyse me, Vidal. It won’t end well.”

“I’m not,” Rio said, still smiling. “Just… observing.”

Agatha’s mouth twitched, unwillingly amused. “Observation is a dangerous habit.”

“Then we’ve got that in common,” Rio replied.

Something about the way she said it — calm, certain — disarmed Agatha completely. She felt herself soften, the edges of her defences blurring without permission.

When Lilia finally returned, humming softly to herself, she paused in the doorway.

Agatha was still sitting at the table. Rio was laughing — not shyly this time, but easily, her whole face lit with it. Agatha’s head was tipped slightly, her expression unguarded in a way Lilia hadn’t seen in years.

Lilia’s eyes glimmered, but she said nothing. She simply slipped off her shawl and began tidying the counter as if she hadn’t noticed anything at all.

When Rio stood to leave a few minutes later, she thanked them both for dinner again. Her voice was softer now, but brighter somehow too.

Agatha walked her to the door — out of politeness, she told herself — and when Rio smiled and said, “Goodnight, Doctor,” something in Agatha’s chest gave a quiet, unfamiliar flutter.

After the door closed, Lilia spoke without turning around. “You seemed to get on well.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes. “Don’t start.”

“I won’t,” Lilia said, stacking plates. “I don’t need to. Your smile says enough.”

Agatha exhaled slowly. “You’re deluded.”

“And you,” Lilia said gently, “are changing.”

Agatha didn’t answer. She simply gathered the glasses and washed them in silence, pretending not to notice how steady her heartbeat felt — and how long it had been since she’d felt safe enough to let it slow.

Chapter End Notes

If you follow me on twitter you'll know how happy I am to be able to finally upload this and be home in bed 🖤

My plans for this weekend have now been cancelled which means I just get to chill and write again ☺️ comments make me happy

Chapter 4

Chapter Notes

Laying in bed ill has some perks, was able to lock in and write so much of this and also got the next few chapters planned out now too.

When life gives you lemons and all that shit...

See the end of the chapter for more notes


The next few days passed with an irritating lack of logic.

Agatha threw herself into work the way she always did — precision, structure, control.
 Charts balanced. Patients stabilised. Everything in its proper place.

And yet…
Every so often, she’d find her thoughts slipping.
 A voice in her memory — low, steady, patient.
 Sometimes staying still can be its own kind of courage.

She’d dismiss it immediately, of course. Ridiculous sentimentality. The kind of thing that belonged to people who took comfort in candlelight and wine.

But then, she’d look up from a chart and catch herself staring at the ER doors — as if half-expecting someone in a navy Fire & Rescue jacket to walk through.

Why the fuck was she so affected by this woman?

“Doctor?”

She blinked. William — Teen — her intern, was standing by the nurses’ station, holding a chart upside down. “You were, uh… somewhere else for a second.”

“I was thinking about our triage protocols,” Agatha said crisply.

“Right,” Teen said, unconvinced. “Totally looked like that.”

Before she could respond, Wanda’s voice carried from across the station. “Teen, stop pestering the doctor. You’ll give her an aneurysm.”

“I’m just learning!”

“Learn quietly,” Agatha muttered, taking the chart from him.

Wanda grinned, setting a coffee on the counter beside her. “He’s right, though. You’ve been a little… different this week.”

Agatha didn’t look up. “Define different.”

“Less terrifying.”

“That sounds like defamation.”

“Mm,” Wanda said, sipping her coffee. “If I didn’t know better, I’d think someone’s been having dinners with interesting company.”

Agatha’s pen paused mid-signature. “You people gossip like oxygen is optional.”

Wanda smiled into her cup. “It’s Westview, doctor. We live for gossip.”

Agatha exhaled through her nose, forcing her hand to stay steady. “There is nthing to gossip about. Lilia had company, I happened to exist in the same room, and that’s the entire story.”

Wanda hummed. “Of course.”

She turned to leave, tossing over her shoulder, “By the way, Romanoff wants you and Dr. Kale to report to the training field tomorrow. Annual trauma simulation.”

Agatha’s head lifted. “The what?”

“The disaster drill,” Wanda said, grinning. “Fire, police, EMS, and hospital staff all playing nice together. You will love it.”

“I’m sure.”

When she walked away, Agatha stood for a moment, the hospital noise closing in again- monitors beeping, phones ringing, the usual rhythm of work.
 And still, beneath it, something quieter pulsed.

Not distraction, exactly.
 Just… warmth.

She hated that she didn’t hated it.


The next morning, the hospital parking lot buzzed with the low hum of engines and conversation.
 Dr. Natasha Romanoff stood beside an SUV, clipboard in hand, her red hair pulled back into a no-nonsense braid.

“Morning, team,” she said. “You both look thrilled.”

“I was under the impression doctors treat disasters,” Agatha said. “Not create them.”

Natasha smirked. “Consider it character building.”

Jen Kale arrived seconds later, sunglasses perched on her head, dressed far too well for a simulation. “Do we at least get lunch out of this?”

“Catered sandwiches courtesy of The Rabbit Hole ,” Natasha said dryly. “Dont get too excited.”

They drove out to the field on the edge of town where the annual emergency drill was already underway. 
Fire engines gleamed under the sun, mock victims lay across the grass, and the air buzzed with staged urgency.

Jen groaned as she took in the scene. “This is going to be chaos.”

Agatha’s lips curved faintly. “Finally.”

When Natasha handed out assignments, Jen was sent to the EMS team. Agatha’s name, however, was paired neatly beside one of the fire units.

She scanned the list, one brow rising. “Of course,” she muttered. “Fate’s sense of humour again.”

She turned and there she was.

Rio stood near one of the trucks, hair pulled back, sunlight catching the faint sheen of sweat along her temples. She looked calm, focused, more grounded than anyone else around her.

Their eyes met across the crowd with a small flicker of recognition and Agatha’s stomach gave a traitorous twist.

Rio offered a polite, shy smile. “Morning, Doctor.”

Agatha nodded, tone even. “Firefighter Vidal.”

“Looks like we’re partners,” Rio said softly.

“Apparently,” Agatha replied.

The training field was now already alive with motion. Fire crews, EMTs, and hospital staff moved like clockwork, the sound of clanking metal and simulated chaos filling the air.

Agatha adjusted her gloves, scanning the wrecked cars. “Remarkably realistic,” she murmured. “Right down to the melodrama.”

Captain Rogers briefed the teams. “Remember, people, communication and coordination are everything. You treat this like it’s real.”

Beside Agatha, Rio crouched to inspect one of the vehicles. 

“Door’s jammed,” she said, voice calm. “We’ll need the spreader.”

“Go ahead,” Agatha said briskly, crouching to check the ‘victim’s’ vitals. “I’ll handle the patient’s airway.”

Rio moved with quiet confidence, slipping the jaws of the hydraulic tool beneath the crumpled metal. The machine whined, the door shuddered—and then, with a sharp crack, it flew open.

Straight into Agatha’s shin.

“Fuck—Ow!” she hissed, staggering back.

Rio looked up, horrified. “Shit—are you okay?”

Agatha exhaled through her nose, voice taut. “Yes. Perfectly fine. My leg, however, may never forgive you.”

Before Rio could respond, the dummy’s arm suddenly detached at the shoulder and rolled into Agatha’s lap.

There was a beat of silence.

Agatha looked down at the severed limb. Then up at Rio.

Rio froze, mouth falling open. “Fuck. That’s… not supposed to happen.”

“I should really hope not,” Agatha said dryly, holding the arm up by its sleeve. “Our patient appears to have suffered spontaneous dismemberment.”

Tony Stark’s voice carried from the next simulation bay. “Having some performance issues over there Vidal?”

Agatha glared. “Fuck off Stark.”

Rio was already scrambling to reattach the arm, cheeks flushed. “I swear this dummy was intact five minutes ago when I set up.”

“That’s disarming,” Agatha said without thinking. Then she paused, realising what she’d said.

Rio blinked. “Did you just—”

“No,” Agatha said quickly. “Absolutely not.”

Rio smirked. “You did.”

“I did not.”

“You made a pun.”

“I detest puns.”

But Rio was laughing now, shoulders shaking as she tried to reattach the limb, and then—because the universe had a sense of timing—the dummy’s head slipped loose and rolled right between Agatha’s sneakers.

For a moment, neither of them moved.

The fake eyes stared up at her, painted and lifeless. The silence stretched—and then Agatha, against every instinct she possessed, started laughing.

At first it was just a breath—sharp, incredulous—but then Rio looked at her with that wide-eyed mortification, and the laugh broke free completely.

It rolled out of her, helpless and loud, the kind she hadn’t let herself have in years.

Rio’s laughter joined hers instantly—low, breathless, completely unrestrained. She leaned against the car for balance, wiping at her eyes. “Well. He’s certainly not keeping it together.”

“Call psych, he’s got some screws loose,” Agatha gasped, tears forming at the corners of her eyes.

“Call time of death more like,” Rio wheezed. 

By now, several onlookers had turned to stare. Captain Rogers and Chief Romanoff approached, expressions caught somewhere between disbelief and mild panic.

“Doctor Harkness?” Natasha said. “Lieutenant Vidal?”

Agatha tried to compose herself, but another fit of laughter broke through. “Our patient—” she began, pointing helplessly at the dummy, “—has expired due to… complete anatomical failure?”

Rio was doubled over beside her, shaking with laughter.

Steve looked at Natasha. “Is this… normal?”

Natasha pinched the bridge of her nose. “No. No, it is not.”

She turned back to them, tone deadpan. “You’re aware this is a professional exercise, not a comedy routine?”

Agatha straightened, still fighting a grin. “With respect, Chief, the patient started it.”

Rio nodded solemnly. “He just fell apart under pressure.”

That did it. They both dissolved again, laughing so hard Rio had to lean against Agatha’s shoulder for balance.

Steve muttered, “I’ve never seen either of them crack before.”

Natasha sighed. “God help me, I kind of like it.”

When they finally composed themselves—barely—Agatha wiped her eyes and exhaled. “Well. That was undignified.”

Rio was still smiling, breathless and flushed. “Best drill ever.”

“Remind me to request a sturdier patient next time,” Agatha said.

“Tehnically, I picked this one,” Rio countered, her tone teasing but soft.

Natasha crossed her arms. “You two are aware your patient is now technically missing a head?”

“Don’t worry,” Agatha said smoothly. “I dont think he’ll file a suit.”

Steve coughed to hide a laugh, earning him a glare from Natasha.

But as they turned to brief the next team, Agatha caught the faintest smile flickering at the edge of Natasha’s mouth.

Agtha glanced back at Rio, their eyes met, both still shining with laughter, and something warm flickered between them.

Across the field, Jen Kale caught sight of them. Agatha, of all people, was laughing with her head tipped back and her guard completely down. Jen smirked, raising an eyebrow as if to say well, well.

When Agatha’s gaze flicked her way, she gave an exaggerated thumbs-up before turning back to her own team, looking far too pleased with herself.

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the small smile didn’t leave her face.

When Natasha and Steve turned away to brief the next group, the world seemed to shrink again until it was just the two of them standing in the soft aftermath of shared chaos.

They crouched to gather the dummy’s scattered limbs, both still stifling the occasional laugh. When Agatha reached for an arm at the same moment as Rio, their fingers brushed. It was warm, brief, but enough to send a flutter through her chest.

Rio’s laughter faded into a quieter smile. “Guess we make a pretty good team.”

Agatha looked at her, really looked, and for a moment the noise of the crowd and the smell of smoke and melted plastic all disappeared.

For the first time in a very long time, she felt completely, stupidly, wonderfully alive.


—————————

 

The following evening, the ER was mercifully quiet — not still, but steady, humming with the rhythm Agatha liked best.

A few sprains. A mild concussion. One teenager pretending to faint for attention.

After the chaos of the disaster drill, the predictability was almost soothing.

Almost.
