Every now and then, her mind would flicker back to the field, to the sound of Rio’s laughter, to the absurd sight of a decapitated dummy rolling between her boots. The way her own laughter had spilled out unrestrained, shocking her as much as everyone else.

The memory tugged a smile from her that she immediately schooled back into neutrality when she realised Wanda was watching her from across the nurses’ station.

“Don’t,” Agatha warned without looking up from her chart.

“Didn’t say anything,” Wanda replied, too casually.

Jen sauntered up beside her, perfect lipstick, cheeks gleaming, ID badge artfully tilted. “You’re smiling at paperwork. That’s new.”

“I was remembering how peaceful it is when you two aren’t here.”

Jen tilted her head, grin sharp. “Or maybe you were remembering the firefighter you couldn’t stop laughing with at the disaster drill.”

Wanda perked up immediately. “Oh? What firefighter?”

Jen looked delighted. “You should’ve seen it. Agatha and the mysterious Rio, making each other laugh like it was a rom-com. I thought they’d been body-snatched.”

“I was laughing at a dummy losing its head,” Agatha cut in flatly.

“Uh-huh,” Jen said. “And smiling like one too.”

Wanda’s brows rose, eyes bright with interest. “Doctor Harkness, are you fraternising with first responders?”

“Absolutely not,” Agatha said, snapping the chart closed with more force than necessary. “And if this conversation continues, I’ll start assigning both of you to overnight intake.”

Jen pressed her lips together, barely suppressing a grin. “Touchy.”

Wanda leaned toward her and whispered, “Definitely touchy.”

Agatha’s glare silenced them both. “If you’re finished gossiping, some of us are trying to maintain a functioning department.”

Wanda bit back a smile. “Of course, Doctor.”

Jen winked at Wanda. “Anyway, we’re still going out tonight — The Witches’ Road. You should come this time.”

Agatha didn’t even look up. “No.”

Jen leaned an elbow on the counter. “Come on, Doctor Doom. You’re due for some serotonin.”

“I have no interest in public intoxication or loud noises.”

“That’s what you said last time,” Wanda said. “And look how well that turned out.”

Agatha gave her a flat look. “Last time I declined.”

“Exactly,” Wanda said brightly. “So tonight, try something radical— say yes.”

Jen tilted her head, smiling in that disarming way that made it hard to argue. “We’ll even behave. Scout’s honour.”

“Neither of you were scouts.”

“Irrelevant,” Jen said.

Agatha opened her mouth to refuse again—
 and then, for reasons she couldn’t entirely explain, she stopped.

Maybe it was the lingering lightness from the day before.
 Maybe it was the way her body still remembered what it felt like to laugh until her ribs hurt.
 Or maybe it was just the thought of going home to silence and knowing Lilia would read her like an open book the moment she walked through the door, lecturing her again about spending her nights with an old kooky lady.

She exhaled, slow and deliberate. “Fine.”

Wanda blinked. “Wait— fine as in yes?”

“Yes,” Agatha said briskly, as if speed would make it less monumental. “I’ll come. One drink.”

Jen’s grin was immediate and gleeful. “Oh, this is historic.”

“Don’t make it a thing,” Agatha said, signing off a chart. “I’ll regret it instantly.”

“Too late,” Wanda said, already texting. “We’re celebrating.”

“Celebrating what?”

“You saying yes,” Wanda said, tucking her phone away. “The world might end tomorrow, so we’re making the most of it.”

Agatha muttered something about melodrama but didn’t protest.

When her shift ended, she found herself outside The Witches’ Road an hour later, the spring night air warm against her skin. The windows glowed amber, laughter spilling out into the street.

She paused before entering, taking a slow breath. She had dressed in her usual crisp white button down tucked into high-waisted plum trousers, her hair still pinned up from work and her navy trench coat slung over her shoulders.

Inside, Wanda, Kate and Jen were already at a corner table, waving her over.

“Doctor Harkness!” Wanda called, mock-formal. “You came!”

Agatha rolled her eyes but smiled lightly as she made her way over.

“Don’t make a scene,” she said.

“Too late,” Jen said, sliding a glass toward her. “To new beginnings, Doctor.”

Agatha hesitated, then raised her glass. “To questionable decisions.”

Jen set her drink down with a satisfied sigh. “We’re just waiting on Alice and her roommate, then we can properly start.”

Agatha arched a brow. “Roommate?”

Jen smiled over the rim of her glass. “You’ll see.”

Before Agatha could respond, the door to The Witches’ Road swung open, letting in the soft spill of night air and laughter from the street.

Alice stepped in first, cheeks pink from the cold, her usual shy smile brightening instantly when she spotted Jen. Beside her came another figure — taller, shoulders squared under a worn black denim jacket.

Agatha froze.

Firefighter Rio Vidal.

Gone was the uniform and the heavy air of duty. Tonight she looked… impossibly human.

Her dark hair was loose, falling in soft waves around her face. The collar of her green cropped T-shirt dipped just enough to reveal the faint glint of a chain against tanned skin and her defined abdomen was hard to look away from. There was a casual strength in her posture — calm, self-contained — that drew Agatha’s eyes before she could stop herself.

Her pulse skipped, traitorous and immediate.

Alice waved as she and Rio made their way over. 

“Sorry we’re late! She wasn’t going to come until she heard a certain doct—”

Before she could finish, Rio clapped a hand over her mouth, eyes wide. “Al.”

Alice blinked, muffled against Rio’s palm. “—ctor was going to be here,” she finished weakly once Rio let go.

Jen’s grin was instant. “Oh, this just got interesting.”

Rio groaned under her breath, cheeks pink. “Ignore her. She was dropped as an infant.”

Agatha’s voice was perfectly even. “I’m sure.”

She returned her gaze to her drink, forcing her pulse to slow. It was ridiculous to react at all — it was a harmless comment, a throwaway tease between friends.

Still, her mind replayed it in spite of herself.
 She wasn’t going to come until she heard a certain doctor was going to be here.

Her throat felt suddenly dry.

It could mean nothing. People said things like that all the time. Perhaps Alice had meant another doctor entirely. Perhaps it was just a joke. That was the logical explanation.

And yet, logic did nothing to steady the small, traitorous spark of warmth that had settled low in her chest.

She shifted in her seat, schooling her expression into neutrality. “I assume this level of gossip is normal for your town,” she said lightly, tone clipped.

Rio rubbed at the back of her neck, looking mortified. “Unfortunately, yes.”

Agatha nodded once, as if that settled it, though her stomach still felt weightless and strange.

Wanda leaned back, the corners of her mouth twitching like she could feel the air between them shift.

Agatha focused on the condensation sliding down her glass instead, pretending not to notice the faint, shy smile Rio gave her from across the table.

Wanda leaned back in her chair, the corners of her mouth twitching. “Well you made it! Perfect timing. The doctor was just starting to enjoy herself.”

Agatha gave her a sharp look. “Don’t start.”

She could feel Wanda watching her, the faintest smirk tugging at her mouth.

The others shifted to make room, and by some cruel twist of fate, the only open seat was directly across from Agatha.

Rio slid into it, shoulders relaxed, movements unhurried. 

Conversation resumed easily around them. Kate was recounting a story about a disastrous double date, Alice blushing at Jen’s laughter, Wanda stirring her drink as if she were mixing a potion.

Agatha contributed when necessary — precise, polite — but her attention drifted.
 To the way Rio’s hand rested lightly on the table, fingertips tapping the rim of her glass.
 To the softness of her voice when she spoke, low and deliberate, as if everything she said was worth listening to.
 To the unassuming steadiness that seemed to centre the entire table without her even trying.

Wanda noticed. Of course she did.

Halfway through the evening, Agatha caught her watching — that infuriating, all-knowing smile curving at the corners of her mouth. The one she used when she’d spotted a secret before anyone else.

Agatha met her eyes briefly, a silent warning. Don’t start.

Wanda innocently lifted her glass in a mock toast as if to say, Who, me?

Across the table, Rio looked up at that exact moment, meeting Agatha’s gaze.
 A flicker, brief, quiet, charged passed between them. Neither spoke. Neither smiled. Just a pulse of recognition that felt like the world narrowing, for one heartbeat, to the space between them.

Then the moment broke. Jen was teasing Alice about her driving, Kate was ordering another round, and Rio was turning her attention back to the conversation- though not before Agatha saw the faintest colour bloom at the tips of her ears.

Agatha busied herself with her drink, taking a steady sip to cover the way her breath had caught.
She could feel Wanda’s grin without even looking up.

When she finally risked a glance across the table, Rio was laughing quietly at something Kate had said, her face soft in the amber light.

And Agatha — cool, precise, self-contained Agatha — felt something uncoil gently inside her.

It wasn’t attraction exactly, not yet.
 It was the strange, rare comfort of being drawn to someone without meaning to.

The kind of pull you didn’t fight, because it didn’t feel dangerous.
 Not yet.

She reminded herself that she wasn’t here for romance, or love, or anything that could pull her off balance again. She couldn’t afford it. Not after Boston. Not after Nicky. Not after everything she’d built back from.

Feelings were a luxury she no longer trusted herself with.

So she took another sip of her drink, straightened her shoulders, and quietly rebuilt her composure — brick by careful brick — while Rio’s laughter drifted across the table like a melody she refused to learn by heart.


As the night wore on easily, conversation looping through laughter and anecdotes that blurred together with the music. Wanda was telling an exaggerated story about her first week in the ER, complete with hand gestures and terrible impressions while Jen laughed along at the memory.

Kate and Alice were deep in some debate about their worst patient stories, their voices soft and companionable.
 For once, Agatha found herself… content.
 There was no pressure to speak, no eyes on her for answers. The noise was steady, familiar. Human.
She leaned back slightly, letting herself breathe.

Across the table, Rio was quiet, but not withdrawn, listening with that easy attentiveness that seemed to steady everyone around her. 

When Wanda’s story finally dissolved into laughter, Rio turned her glass absently between her hands and looked across the table.

“How’s your leg?” she asked suddenly.

Agatha blinked. “My—what?”

“Your shin,” Rio said, her lips curving just enough to be teasing. “From the drill. The door got you pretty good.”

Agatha’s mouth twitched. “You mean when your equipment attacked me?”

Rio tilted her head, mock-serious. “I prefer the term malfunctioned under duress.”

Agatha arched a brow. “A charming euphemism for clumsiness.”

That earned her a low laugh, soft but genuine. “You’re not limping, so I’ll assume you survived.”

“Barely,” Agatha said dryly. “I’ve filed emotional damages paperwork.”

“Good,” Rio said, eyes glinting. “I’ll be sure to sign my confession.”

The corner of Agatha’s mouth lifted — that same unguarded expression she hadn’t quite managed to suppress since the disaster drill. “See that you do.”

Their eyes held for a moment longer than was proper, long enough for Wanda, sipping her drink beside Jen, to notice and glance between them with barely contained amusement.

Rio looked away first, ducking her head slightly, fingers tracing the rim of her glass. “You laugh easier than I expected,” she said, almost to herself.

Agatha frowned faintly. “Excuse me?”

“At the drill,” Rio said, still not looking up. “You seem like the kind of person who doesn’t let go of control easily. But when you laughed…” she smiled, small and soft, “it felt like the air changed.”

Agatha felt the words land somewhere she didn’t want to examine. “It was a ridiculous situation,” she said carefully.

“Maybe,” Rio murmured. “Still, it was nice to hear.”

Before Agatha could respond, Wanda leaned forward from where she sat beside Jen, chin resting on her hand, eyes glinting with mischief.

“Well, would you look at that,” she said lightly. “I’ve never seen you smile that much, Rio.”

Rio blinked, startled out of her quiet focus. “What?”

Wanda’s grin widened. “You. Smiling. It’s new. You’re usually the quiet, brooding type — makes half the nurses nervous and the other half curious.”

Rio’s cheeks flushed a soft pink. “I… didn’t realise I had a reputation.”

“Oh, you do,” Wanda said, teasing but kind. “Silent, mysterious, perpetually leaning against doorframes. You’ve got the whole thing down.”

Across the table, Jen laughed. “She’s right. You’ve got a very ‘tragic firefighter’ aesthetic.”

Rio’s mouth quirked. “I’ll take that as a compliment.”

Agatha, who had been perfectly still through the exchange, finally said, “Perhaps people smile more when they’re allowed a break from relentless commentary.”

Wanda shot her a look over the rim of her glass. “Touché, Doctor.”

Rio’s gaze flickered toward Agatha then — not teasing, not embarrassed, just quiet amusement. “I’ll admit,” she said softly, “this is a better kind of attention.”

For a moment, Agatha didn’t breathe.

It was the way Rio said it — low, unguarded, entirely sincere — that caught her off balance. Something in her chest shifted, a tug she didn’t recognise. Warmth spread where logic usually lived, and the sudden awareness of it made her spine go rigid.

No. Absolutely not.

She could feel Wanda watching her from across the table, that damned perceptive calm in her eyes, and the weight of it made Agatha’s pulse quicken. She set down her glass a little too carefully, stood, and reached for her bag.

“I should go,” she said, her tone brisdk. “Early rounds tomorrow.”

Wanda blinked. “You just got here.”

“Exactly,” Agatha said. “And I’ve met my social quota for the month.”

She didn’t look at Rio as she turned to leave, but she could feel the firefighter’s gaze follow her — steady, questioning. It made her skin prickle.

The cool night air hit her like a shock when she stepped outside. She inhaled sharply, eyes closing for a moment. The air smelled faintly of rain and smoke, and beneath it, something softer she didn’t want to name.

She told herself to walk, to move, to not think.

She’d made it halfway down the block when a voice called out behind her.
“Doctor Harkness!”

Agatha turned, and there was Rio — crossing the sidewalk, her jacket unzipped, holding out something dark.

“Your coat,” she said. “You left it on the chair.”

Agatha blinked, the words not immediately connecting. “Ah.” She took it, her fingers brushing Rio’s for just a second — a second too long. “Thank you.”

Rio studied her for a beat, brow furrowed slightly. “Are you alright?”

The question was gentle, but it hit too close.

Agatha straightened her shoulders. “I’m fine.”

Rio didn’t move. “You left kind of suddenly.”

“I dislike crowds,” Agatha said quickly.

Rio’s head tilted, and those big brown eyes — wide, soft, infuriatingly earnest — locked on hers. “I didn’t mean to make you uncomfortable.”

“You didn’t,” Agatha said, a little too fast.

“Okay,” Rio said softly, nodding once. “Good.”

Agatha forced herself to breathe, to focus anywhere but on the warmth in those eyes. There was something disarmingly open about them — a sincerity she didn’t know how to stand in front of.

“Go back inside, Vidal,” she managed, voice low but steady. “Enjoy your evening.”

Rio’s mouth curved, just slightly. “You too, Doctor.”

She turned, walking back toward the glow of the bar. Agatha watched her go, the easy rhythm of her stride, the way she tucked her hands into her pockets like she wasn’t in a hurry.

When Rio disappeared around the corner, Agatha exhaled slowly, pressing a hand to her coat where Rio’s fingers had brushed it.

“Pull yourself together,” she muttered under her breath. “You’re just overwhelmed with the social situation.”

But as she walked home through the quiet streets, coat still warm from Rio’s hands, Agatha couldn’t quite convince herself she believed it.

 

 

The hospital’s morning hum had already begun by the time Agatha walked through the sliding doors the next week— the low thrum of voices, distant monitors, the faint hiss of a coffee machine that never seemed to rest.

She was early, as always.
 Control began with punctuality.

Her heels clicked briskly against the linoleum as she made her way toward the nurses’ station, flipping through a fresh stack of patient files. She’d barely reached the counter when she realised she wasn’t alone.

Alice Wu-Gulliver stood leaning against the desk, her paramedic uniform half unzipped, grinning as Jen  scribbled something onto a clipboard beside her. The energy between them was unmistakable — soft laughter, a little too close, the casual magnetism of people who didn’t need to speak to be understood.

“Didn’t know the nurses’ station doubled as a dating lounge,” Agatha said dryly, setting her files down.

Jen turned, one perfectly sculpted brow arching. “Good morning to you too, sunshine.”

Alice flushed immediately, fumbling for professionalism. “We were just, uh— talking about shift rotations.”

Jen smirked. “Sure, babe. Let’s go with that.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, scanning the morning logs. “If you’re going to flirt, at least do it out of the line of sight. Some of us are trying to maintain an illusion of efficiency.”

Jen rested her chin in her hand, watching her with wicked amusement. “You ever think maybe that’s your problem, Doctor? Too much efficiency, not enough fun.”

Agatha didn’t look up. “I’m quite content with my lack of chaos, thank you.”

“Mm,” Jen said, unbothered. “When’s the last time you got laid?”

Alice nearly choked on her coffee. “Jen!”

“What?” Jen said, utterly unapologetic. “It’s a valid health question. Stress relief. Circulation. Blood pressure.”

Agatha froze mid-signature, pen hovering just above the paper. Slowly, she looked up, her expression cold enough to sterilise an operating room.

“When was the last time you used a filter?” she asked.

“Probably around the same time you used a sense of humour,” Jen said, smirking.

Before Agatha could deliver the verbal evisceration that line deserved, a familiar voice interrupted from behind her.

“Used a sense of humour for what?”

Agatha turned, relief flickering behind her practiced indifference, to find Teen standing in the doorway, clutching his clipboard like it contained state secrets. His stethoscope was half tangled, one curl sticking up stubbornly at the top of his head.

“Perfect timing,” Agatha said crisply. “Rounds. Now.”

Teen blinked. “Uh—okay. What were you—?”

“Sex,” Jen said cheerfully, making Alice choke on her coffee.

Teen’s face went crimson. “I— sorry— what—?”

Agatha didn’t miss a beat. “Don’t engage,” she said, already walking away. “It only encourages them.”

Teen scrambled after her, nearly tripping over his own feet. “Yes, Doctor!”

When they reached the hallway, he was still flustered, adjusting his clipboard. “Were they— um— serious?”

“Teen,” Agatha said, voice dry as bone, “if you wish to survive this residency, you will learn to never, under any circumstance, ask follow-up questions.”

“Right. Of course. Noted.” He hesitated, then added quietly, “I didn’t really want the answer anyway.”

Agatha’s mouth twitched — not quite a smile, but close enough to surprise her. “Good instincts. Let’s see if you can apply them to medicine.”

“Yes, Doctor,” he said, scribbling something down just to look useful.

They turned a corner, the rhythmic hum of the hospital settling around them. Agatha’s pulse had returned to normal; the warmth still prickling at her cheeks, less so. Professional order restored.

Finally, she handed Teen a chart. “Langford in three. Post-op in five. Keep up.”

“Yes, Doctor.”

He scurried off, and Agatha watched him go for a moment — all long limbs and nervous energy, still too soft for the work that hardened most people within months. She envied him a little, that eagerness untouched by loss.

The ward was calm for once. Not quiet — it was never quiet — but steady enough that her mind, usually kept disciplined by chaos, began to wander.

Jen’s earlier jab floated back like an echo.

When’s the last time you got laid?

Agatha’s jaw tightened. Honestly. The woman had the tact of a brick through glass.

Still… the question lingered.

It hadn’t even been that long— Had it?

She frowned, flipping through a patient file, scanning lines without actually reading them. Dates blurred together. Months folded into each other, the way they did when your life was ruled by shift rotations and night rounds.

The last time—
Her stomach dropped.

Over a year.

She blinked, startled by her own realisation. A year.

She’d been too busy, of course. The residency had devoured her first. Then came the endless string of overnight shifts, the stress, the constant forward motion she mistook for progress.

And then Nicky.

Her fingers stilled on the edge of the chart.

Nicky, with his too-big eyes and the soft way he’d asked if she could stay until the pain faded.
 Nicky, who had laughed at her terrible jokes.
 Nicky, whose small hand had gone cold in hers before she was ready to let go.

After that, everything in her life had collapsed into function. Eat. Work. Sleep. Repeat. There hadn’t been room for anything else — not laughter, not warmth, not touch.

Certainly not vulnerability.

She told herself it was discipline. That abstaining from distraction made her sharper, stronger.
 But if she was honest — brutally, privately honest — it was fear.

She didn’t trust herself to want anything she couldn’t save.

“Doctor?”

Teen’s voice jolted her from her thoughts. He was standing by the next curtain, clutching a chart to his chest. “Patient’s ready.”

“Right,” she said quickly, smoothing her coat. “Let’s proceed.”

He nodded, stepping aside for her to enter.

Agatha’s movements were automatic again — hands steady, voice even, heart quiet. But the moment of stillness lingered at the edges of her mind like a bruise.

Over a year.

It shouldn’t have mattered.
 She wasn’t that kind of woman — not sentimental, not lonely, certainly not pining.

And yet…
When she closed her eyes for even a heartbeat too long, she saw a pair of brown eyes looking up at her from across a bar table, steady and warm.

It was infuriating.

“Teen,” she said briskly, needing to anchor herself in something solid, “remind me to update the discharge protocol on postoperative monitoring.”

“Yes, Doctor,” he said quickly, scribbling it down.

Agatha nodded once, forcing her focus back where it belonged — on order, precision, control.

But even as she did, she could feel it: the faint, unwelcome hum under her skin.
 The sense that something had started to stir.

Something she’d spent far too long convincing herself she didn’t need.

 


The call came just after sunset.

Agatha had been halfway through reviewing post-op notes when the sharp crackle of the hospital radio filled the corridor — a voice cutting through the static with words that made every head lift.

“—multiple casualties from a downtown fire. Heavy smoke, partial building collapse. Units en route to Westview General.”

An older nurse at the station paled. “That’s the old apartment block on Maple,” she murmured. “Four floors. No sprinkler system.”

Agatha set down her pen, pulse already quickening. “How far out?”

“Five minutes.”

The next few were instinct. Movement. Command.
 She stripped off her white coat and snapped on gloves, barking orders before she realised she was doing it. “Prep trauma bays two through five. Ventilators ready. Notify Dr. Romanoff and Kale — tell them to clear their surgical schedules.”

Nurses and techs scattered. Monitors flickered to life. The air in the ER shifted — that familiar tension, sharp and electric, humming just beneath the surface.

And then—
The radio crackled again.

“Firefighter down. Repeat — firefighter down. Extraction in progress. Vitals unstable.”

The words hit Agatha like a blow.
 She froze mid-step, eyes locked on the radio.

A firefighter.

Her chest tightened before her mind caught up. It was irrational, she knew that. There were dozens of them in Westview. She didn’t know why her pulse spiked like that — why her stomach dropped as though her body already knew.

She forced herself to move. “Double the trauma prep,” she ordered. “Now.”

The ambulance bay doors burst open a few minutes later, red lights spilling across the floor. Paramedics shouted vitals as they wheeled in stretchers — smoke-streaked faces, burns, lacerations. The smell of ash hit like a wall.

And then she saw the uniform.
 Blackened. Torn.

A boot dragged against the gurney’s edge.

For a second, she couldn’t breathe.

“Incoming!” one of the paramedics called. “Firefighter, late twenties, conscious, multiple fractures—”
Agatha stepped forward— And froze.

 

Chapter End Notes

I chose violence today

Chapter 5

Chapter Notes

Very short update to alleviate the suspense....

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Incoming!” one of the paramedics called. “Firefighter, late twenties, conscious, multiple fractures—”
Agatha stepped forward— And froze.

 


It wasn’t Rio.

It was Tony Stark.

His face was smeared with soot, one eye already swelling shut, but the grin was unmistakable even through the pain. “Don’t look so disappointed to see me, Doc.”

For one split second, her body didn’t catch up to her brain.

The flood of relief came fast and sharp — like air after being held underwater too long. Her chest loosened, her knees steadied, and the ringing in her ears dulled to silence.

She exhaled, sharply, the tension in her shoulders releasing all at once. “Mr. Stark,” she said, voice steady again. “I see you’ve found a new way to inconvenience me.”

“Wouldn’t want you getting bored,” he managed through a wince.

“Try harder next time,” she said, checking the monitors as the team wheeled him in. “Let’s get X-rays and a trauma panel— his leg’s at least fractured, possibly worse.”

“Copy that,” one of the nurses said.

As they moved around her, Agatha’s gaze swept the ambulance bay — scanning the crowd of first responders, the chaos of soot-streaked faces, the blur of uniforms moving in and out of triage. She searched for one in particular.

No dark curls. No calm brown eyes. No Rio.

Her stomach tightened again, the earlier relief splintering into unease.

Then Captain Steve Rogers appeared at Tony’s side, streaked with soot but uninjured, his expression grim. 

“She got him out just in time.”

Agatha looked up. “Who?”

“Vidal,” Steve said. “Building came down while they were inside. He went down first, she pulled him out before the roof gave way.”

Something inside Agatha twisted hard, her pulse jumping before she could stop it. 

“Is she—?”

“She’s fine,” Steve said quickly, reading the question in her face. “Bruised, a little shaken. She refused treatment, stayed behind to help the other units.”

Agatha blinked, forcing herself to keep her tone neutral. The relief that surged through her was too big, too dangerous — and entirely hers to contain. She swallowed it down, smoothing her expression into professional calm. 

“Of course she did.”

Steve gave a small smile. “Wouldn’t be Tony’s first choice of hero, but she earned the title tonight.”

Tony groaned from the gurney. “Hey, I heard that.”

“Good,” Steve said dryly.

Agatha allowed herself a single breath — controlled, quiet — before snapping back to focus. “Let’s move,” she ordered, her voice clear and calm again. “X-ray in fifteen, ortho consult on standby.”

As Tony was wheeled toward imaging, she lingered for just a second longer, the adrenaline ebbing from her system.

She told herself she was only shaken because it had been a busy night. Because it could have been anyone.

But when the smell of smoke still clung faintly to the air, and she thought of Rio’s soft smile and caring eyes, Agatha had to grip the counter to steady herself.

The thought of something happening to her.

She wasn’t supposed to care this much.
 Not again.

 

By the time the last of the fire victims had been stabilised, it was past midnight.
 The ER smelled of antiseptic, adrenaline, and smoke — that sharp, acrid kind that clings to skin no matter how hard you scrub.

Agatha moved through it all with her usual precision, issuing orders, double-checking vitals, scribbling notes. On the surface, she was calm, efficient, detached. But beneath that, something restless churned.

Steve’s words replayed in her mind.
 Vidal pulled him out before the roof gave way.

Every time she passed the ambulance bay doors, her gaze flicked instinctively toward them.

Empty.
 No new stretchers.
 No Rio.

Each time she told herself it was irrelevant. She had patients. Protocol. Work.

But the part of her that wasn’t a doctor — the small, inconveniently human part — didn’t believe it.

With every siren that echoed from the distance, her chest tightened, and her eyes flicked up, searching the doorway before she could stop herself. The ER was a blur of motion and noise, but she couldn’t focus. 

Not fully. Not until she knew.

She forced her attention back to Tony Stark’s X-ray summary, her handwriting tightening across the page. Numbers and notes, familiar, grounding — but they refused to quiet the restless pulse behind her ribs.

Then a voice broke through the hum.

“Firefighter Vidal’s here to see Tony,” Kate called from the nurses’ station, slightly breathless. “Just walked in. Said she was fine, but she’s limping.”

The pen slipped from Agatha’s fingers, clattering onto the chart.

She didn’t remember standing. Or moving. Only the sound of her own footsteps echoing against the tile as she made her way down the corridor, her coat trailing behind her like a shadow.

The fluorescent lights seemed too bright, the air too thin. Her pulse thudded in her ears, steady and relentless.

And then — she saw her.

Rio stood near triage, half-turned toward a nurse, jacket slung over one arm. Her navy uniform was streaked with ash and grime. Soot marked the curve of her jaw, a stark line against her skin. Her hair, usually tied back, had come loose around her face, soft curls catching the light.

She looked calm — impossibly calm — as if she hadn’t just walked out of a collapsing building. Her voice was low and even, steady as ever, carrying that quiet authority that never needed to raise itself to be heard.

Agatha stopped a few paces away, the chaos of the ER fading into a distant hum. Relief surged so hard it almost hurt.

Her pulse was erratic, her palms cold. She drew in a slow breath, forcing herself to sound composed.

“You’re supposed to report to trauma if you’re injured.”

Rio turned at the sound of her voice, surprise flickering across her face before she smiled — small, tired, but unmistakably warm.

“Doctor Harkness.”

Agatha’s chest loosened in the smallest, most dangerous way. She took a step closer before she could stop herself. The sharp, chemical scent of disinfectant mingled with smoke and sweat. Rio smelled like the aftermath of fire — burnt wood and adrenaline — a scent that shouldn’t have felt reassuring, but somehow did.

“Don’t,” Agatha said quietly. “Don’t tell me you’re fine.”

Rio blinked, caught off guard by the tone. “I was checked at the scene. Just bruises.”

“Bruises,” Agatha repeated, voice low. “You were inside a collapsing building.”

Rio’s smile wavered, but her tone stayed steady. “I’m alright. Really. Tony—”

“Tony is in radiology with a fractured femur,” Agatha cut in, sharper than intended. “He’s fine. Thanks to you, apparently.”

Rio’s expression softened, the corners of her mouth curving faintly. “He’ll live. He’s too stubborn not to.”

“That’s not the point.” Agatha reached out before she could think better of it, fingers brushing Rio’s forearm. Her skin was warm beneath the soot, the faint tremor of muscle betraying the exhaustion she tried to hide.

“You should be in a bay,” Agatha said softly. “Not standing here pretending you’re invincible.”

Rio’s voice lowered, quiet but sure. “It’s part of the job.”

“And so is following medical instruction,” Agatha replied, but the bite in her voice faltered halfway through. Her throat was too tight, her heart still not entirely settled from the sight of her standing there.

Rio caught it. Of course she did. She always noticed more than she should.

Her eyes softened, that deep brown steady and knowing. “Are you worried about me, Doctor?”

Agatha straightened instinctively, searching for her usual distance. “I worry about all my patients.”

Rio smiled just enough for the gap between her teeth to show. “Good thing I’m not your patient then.”

That earned a glare — faint, half-hearted. “You will be if you don’t let someone look at that leg.”

Rio hesitated, then sighed, conceding. “Alright.”

She followed Agatha toward an empty exam bay. The fluorescent lights above hummed quietly, painting the room in sterile white as Rio sat on the edge of the gurney and pulled off her boot with a wince.

Agatha crouched, her movements precise but gentle, her fingers brushing against soot and fabric as she examined the swelling around Rio’s ankle. The bruise had already begun to bloom — purple and angry against the tan of her skin.

“You pushed it too far,” she murmured.

Rio’s voice came soft, almost apologetic. “Wouldn’t have left Tony behind.”

Agatha looked up then, catching the faint shimmer of sweat along her hairline, the exhaustion clinging to her edges. “You could have died.”

Rio met her gaze, calm and unwavering. “So could he.”

The words settled between them like smoke — heavy, inevitable, lingering.

For a long moment, neither moved. The world outside the curtain seemed far away: the noise, the lights, the endless chaos. It was just the two of them, breathing in sync.

Agatha forced herself to move first. She stripped off her gloves, exhaling through her nose. “You’re impossibly stubborn.”

Rio’s mouth curved. “So I’ve been told.”

Agatha almost smiled. “You’ll need to ice that ankle and stay off it for at least forty-eight hours.”

“I’ll try.”

“No,” Agatha said, standing. “You’ll do.”

Rio’s eyes glinted faintly, amusement flickering through the fatigue. “Yes, Doctor.”

When Agatha turned to dispose of the gloves, she realised her hands were trembling slightly. She clenched them until they stilled.

“Thank you,” Rio said quietly.

Agatha looked back. “For what?”

“For caring.”

The words landed like a stone in her chest. Too direct. Too kind.

Agatha looked away, voice cool again. “Go home, Firefighter Vidal.”

Rio hesitated in the doorway, her hand resting lightly on the frame. The overhead light caught in her hair, turning the soot into something almost silver.

For a moment, neither spoke.

Then Rio’s voice, soft but certain: “Goodnight, Agatha.”

It was the first time Rio had said her name.

The sound of it, low and steady, landed somewhere deep beneath the layers Agatha had spent years building. Her pulse spiked, sharp and sudden, betraying her before she could think.

She blinked, her composure faltering just enough that her lips curved into the smallest, most reluctant of smiles. “Goodnight,” she said, softer than she intended.

Rio turned and walked out, her silhouette framed briefly in the light before the door swung shut behind her.

Agatha stood for a moment in the now-silent bay, her pulse still unsteady and the faintest smile ghosting across her lips.

Then she exhaled, set the chart aside, and pressed her palms against the counter, steadying herself as if the world had tilted slightly off its axis.

One word. Her name.

And somehow, it had undone her completely.

Chapter End Notes

Thoughts?

Chapter 6

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The morning after the fire was heavy and grey, as if even the sky hadn’t slept.

Westview General moved slower than usual with fewer jokes at the nurses’ station, more yawns hidden behind cups of cheap coffee. Everyone had stayed late the night before, and exhaustion clung to the air like static.

Agatha arrived early anyway. She always did. Habit was a form of control, and control was what kept her steady.

She set her bag on the counter, exchanging quiet nods with Wanda and Jen. Neither woman had their usual spark. Wanda’s hair was pulled back messily,, her scrubs creased, and Jen’s eyeliner was smudged, though she still somehow looked elegant.

“Morning,” Wanda said, her voice soft.

“Morning,” Agatha replied, reaching for a stack of charts.

Jen yawned. “I could sleep for a week.”

“You can’t,” Agatha said dryly. “Rounds in fifteen.”

That earned a faint laugh. Wanda shook her head, smiling just enough to break the tension. “Of course you’re still on schedule.”

“It’s how we function,” Agatha said.

Wanda didn’t argue. She just handed her a coffee — black, strong, exactly how she liked it. “Drink it before you start snapping at people.”

Agatha accepted it with a small nod. “Noted.”

Teen appeared moments later, slightly disheveled but determined. “Morning, Doctor! Ready when you are.”

“You’re late,” she said automatically.

“Only by two minutes!”

“Which is still late.” She handed him a chart. “Mr. Stark in Recovery Bay Three. You’re observing.”

Teen straightened. “Got it.”

When they reached the bay, Agatha braced herself for Stark’s usual dramatics. What she didn’t expect was the company.

Tony wasn’t alone.

Two firefighters stood beside his bed-Bucky Barnes, tall and steady as ever, and Rio Vidal.

Rio was out of uniform today, wearing a dark shirt and jeans. Her hair was tied loosely back, the faintest trace of bruising still visible along her jaw. She looked tired but grounded, and when she glanced up, Agatha felt the familiar jolt she was beginning to hate.

Tony was mid-story, gesturing animatedly to a young blonde nurse-- Yelena Belova, one of the newest hires, bright-eyed and far too awake for the hour. Her accent curled softly around her words, each syllable touched with that lilting Russian edge that made everything she said sound almost mischievous.

“So there I am,” Tony said, “smoke all around, building coming down, and I’m trying to carry this guy out with one good leg—”

Bucky groaned. “Tony.”

“What? It’s a good story!”

“It’s bullshit,” Bucky said, crossing his arms. “You didn’t carry anyone. You were half-conscious, pinned under a beam, and Rio pulled you out.”

Yelena’s eyes widened, her voice rising in an admiring lilt. “She did?”

Rio shifted, uncomfortable under the attention. “It wasn’t just me. We worked as a team.”

Bucky shook his head. “You went back in when the roof was collapsing. That’s not nothing.”

Tony waved a hand. “Details, shmetails. What matters is I maintained morale.”

“By screaming like a little bitch?” Bucky said.

“I was not!” Tony shot back.

Yelena giggled, brushing a loose strand of hair behind her ear as she looked up at Rio. “That’s incredible, though. You really went back in?”

Rio rubbed the back of her neck, clearly uncomfortable but too polite to brush her off. “It’s my job.”

Yelena smiled, her tone soft, admiring. “Still, you’re kind of amazing.”

Agatha felt her jaw tighten before she could stop it. The sound of Yelena’s laugh grated against her nerves, that light, airy giggle entirely too close to Rio’s quiet humility. And Rio—kind, oblivious Rio—was blushing.

Something in Agatha’s chest burned hot and unreasonable.

Before she could think better of it, she spoke. “Nurse Belova, you’re behind on your post-op checks.”

Yelena jumped, straightening so fast she nearly dropped her tablet. “Oh! Right, sorry, Doctor!” Her accent thickened slightly with surprise. She gave Rio a quick, almost apologetic smile before hurrying out, the curtain rustling closed behind her.

The moment she was gone, Tony grinned from his pillow. “You have that effect on people, Doc. The whole room chills.”

Agatha ignored him, flipping open his chart. “Your X-rays show a clean femoral fracture. Six weeks non-weight-bearing, then reassessment. I suggest you avoid collapsing structures in the meantime.”

“Where’s the fun in that?” Tony muttered.

“Fun,” Agatha said evenly, “is not a treatment plan.”

Teen scribbled something on his clipboard to hide his grin.

Bucky smirked. “Don’t mind him, Doctor. He’s been milking this all morning.”

Agatha turned her attention toward Rio, who stood quietly at the end of the bed. Her weight was balanced more evenly this time, exhaustion etched on her features.

“How’s the ankle?” Agatha asked, her tone brisk but not unkind.

Rio seemed surprised by the question, then smiled a little. “Better. I did what you said — iced it, kept it up for most of the night.”

Agatha tilted her head, scanning her posture. “And today?”

“Still stiff, but manageable.”

“Manageable,” Agatha repeated, crossing her arms. “You remember what I said about rest?”

Rio nodded, the corner of her mouth twitching. “Something about making your job easier.”

Agatha’s lips curved, just slightly. “I see youre capable of following directions after all.”

Rio’s smile grew, soft and genuine. “I try, Doctor.”

Agatha made the mistake of holding her gaze a moment too long. That same warmth, quiet, steady, utterly disarming, flickered there again, and she felt the jealousy drain into something far more dangerous: affection.

She turned back to Tony’s chart before anyone could notice the flush creeping up her neck.

Tony groaned dramatically. “You two done bonding? Some of us are in agony here.”

Agatha didn’t even glance his way. “If you can complain that loudly, you’re fine.”

Bucky chuckled. “I keep telling him that.”

Agatha made one last note on the chart. “Keep the leg elevated, Mr. Stark. And do try to refrain from heroics for the foreseeable future.”

“Heroics?” Tony said, grinning. “You mean ‘dramatic rescues.’”

“Call it what you like,” she replied dryly, then looked briefly back at Rio. “Try to stay out of trouble,  Vidal.”

Rio’s eyes lifted to meet hers. “I’ll do my best.”

Agatha nodded once, sharply, and turned to leave. Teen followed close behind, still glancing over his shoulder like he was watching a movie play out.

In the hallway, he finally said, “You really do care about her.”

Agatha shot him a look that could freeze fire. “I care about all my patients.”

Teen raised an eyebrow but wisely said nothing else.

Still, as they walked toward the next bay, Agatha’s thoughts refused to fall back into order.

She told herself it was routine follow-up — professionalism, nothing more.
 But when she caught herself replaying Rio’s quiet smile, she knew she was lying.

The day crawled after that.

Even with the steady rhythm of charting, check-ins, and post-op rounds, Agatha’s focus kept slipping, not enough to make mistakes, but enough to irritate her. Normally, she thrived on control. Precision. The satisfying predictability of cause and effect.

But today, everything felt slightly off-kilter.

By late afternoon, she found herself in the staff lounge, sitting at one of the small round tables with her third cup of coffee going cold in her hands. She hadn’t meant to stop moving. She just… had.

The door creaked open, and Wanda stepped in. Her scrubs were rumpled, hair escaping its tie, but she still carried that easy calm that had a way of disarming people without trying.

“You’ve been still for ten minutes,” Wanda said, dropping into the chair across from her. “Should I be worried?”

“I’m taking a break,” Agatha said, her tone clipped.

“Voluntarily?” Wanda smiled faintly. “That’s new.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “Doctors are human.”

“Some of them,” Wanda said, tilting her head. “But not you, apparently. You look like you haven’t stopped since last night.”

“I haven’t,” Agatha admitted. “Too much to do.”

“Or too much to avoid,” Wanda murmured.

Agatha’s eyes flicked up. “Excuse me?”

Wanda shrugged lightly. “You’ve been distracted all day. It’s not like you.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha said automatically.

“That’s what you said last night when I told you to go home,” Wanda replied, soft but firm. “You’ve been fine so many times I’m starting to think you have no other settings.”

Agatha stared at her, caught somewhere between annoyance and something that might have been gratitude. “You should consider minding your own business.”

“I should,” Wanda said easily. “But then who would make sure you don’t fall apart quietly in a supply closet?”

Agatha’s lips twitched, despite herself. “You’re remarkably nosey.”

“Someone has to be,” Wanda said. “It’s part of the small town lore.”

For a moment, they sat in companionable silence. The distant hum of monitors and overhead announcements filled the space between them.

Finally, Wanda asked, “How’s your firefighter?”

Agatha’s pulse stuttered. “She’s not my firefighter.”

“Mm,” Wanda said, sipping her tea. “And yet you knew who I meant.”

Agatha exhaled slowly. “She’s fine. Ankle’s improved. She followed instructions.”

“That must be rare,” Wanda teased gently.

“It is,” Agatha said, setting down her coffee. “And appreciated.”

Wanda studied her for a moment, then nodded as if she’d reached a quiet conclusion. “You know, you don’t have to hold everything together all the time. You’re allowed to care about people.”

Agatha’s voice was calm, but the faintest tremor hid beneath it. “That’s not the problem.”

“What is?”

“Caring tends to end badly,” Agatha said simply.

Wanda’s gaze softened. “Not always.”

Agatha looked down at her hands. “Often enough.”

Neither spoke for a long time after that.

Eventually, Wanda stood, stretching. “You should go home soon. Lilia will worry.”

“She always worries,” Agatha said.

“Maybe because she’s usually right to,” Wanda said, smiling.

Agatha’s mouth twitched into the ghost of a smile. “Go back to work, Maximoff.”

Wanda picked up her tea, pausing at the door. “I am. You should try it… the home part, not the work part.”

And then she was gone, leaving Agatha alone again with her cooling coffee and the faint echo of words she didn’t want to think about.

She sat there for another minute, then finally stood, straightened her coat, and told herself she wasn’t avoiding anything.


She should have gone straight home, Lilia was doing a reading for someone across town, but the idea of the quiet house felt too heavy, too expectant.
So she found herself at the grocery store instead, a small local place with handwritten labels and humming lights. The aisles smelled faintly of citrus and herbs.

It had been weeks since she’d cooked anything. Lilia always insisted on feeding her — soups, caesseroles, stews that tasted like comfort and safety. But tonight, Agatha wanted to return the gesture. Something simple. Pasta, maybe. Wine. A way of saying thank you without having to say it.

She was debating btween two kinds of basil when a voice behind her said, softly, “Doctor Harkness?”
Agatha turned, already halfway through a sigh, but stopped when she saw Alice Wu-Gulliver standing there, clutching a small basket to her chest. She wasn’t in uniform, just dark jeans and a green sweater, her hair tied up loosely. Her smile was shy but genuine.

“Paramedic Wu,” Agatha said, nodding. “You’re not on duty?”

Alice shook her head, a quiet laugh escaping her. “No. I’m making dinner for Jen tonight. We’ve got the apartment to ourselves for once. Rio’s on night duty at the station.”

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “A rare occurrence, then.”

“Yeah,” Alice said, smiling softly. “Between her shifts and ours, the place usually feels more like a drop-in centre than a home. But tonight it’s just us so I’m gonna try cook, I even picked up dessert. Jen loves tiramisu.”

Agatha arched a brow. “Ambitious.”

Alice grinned, a little bashful. “Maybe. I’m not much of a cook, but she deserves something nice.” She hesitated, shifting the basket in her arms. “Rio was teasing me earlier before she left for the station. Said I was trying too hard.”

Agatha’s expression stayed neutral, but the name hit her like a pulse beneath the skin, that strange little thrum she could never quite explain. “Is that so.”

“Yeah,” Alice said, still smiling. “But I think she’s glad I found someone… Then she started talking about you.”

Agatha blinked. “Me?”

Alice nodded. “She mentioned how you handled everything after the fire. Said the hospital staff all look to you when things go wrong. That you’ve got this... calm about you. Like nothing shakes you.”

Agatha adjusted a box of linguine in her basket, pretending to study the label. “I don’t see why she’d bring that up.”

Alice shrugged, her tone gentle. “She notices people. You more than most, I think. She talks about you more than she probably realises.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened slightly. “Admiration tends to fade once people spend enough time with me.”

“Maybe not her,” Alice said softly. “Rio doesn’t connect… easily. But when she does, it’s usually for good reason.”

Agatha looked at her for a moment, the air between them feeling oddly fragile. Then she straightened. 
“Well. Enjoy your evening, Paramedic Wu. Try not to burn anything.”

Alice smiled, cheeks flushing. “No promises. Goodnight, Doctor.”

When Alice disappeared down another aisle, Agatha stood there for a long moment, staring blankly at the shelves of pasta.

She could almost hear Lilia’s voice in her mind, teasing and wise. Stop hiding, my girl. 

Agatha exhaled through her nose, shook her head, and added a bottle of wine to her basket.

It didn’t mean anything.


The house was dim when Agatha stepped inside, the last light of evning spilling through the curtains in soft amber stripes. She hung her coat by the door and set the grocery bags on the counter. The silence felt companionable rather than heavy for once.

She filled the pot with water, let it come to a simmer, and began chopping garlic with precise, practiced motions. Olive oil, basil, a squeeze of lemon, movements that belonged to muscle memory more than thought. The smell rose, sharp and comforting, curling through the kitchen like something alive.

It was strange, cooking again. She couldn’t remember the last time she’d done it properly. In Boston, it had been ramen and vending machines, energy drinks, the kind of exhaustion that made even boiling water seem extravagant. 

By the time she was tossing the pasta, the front door opened, and Lilia’s familiar voice floated in.
“Agatha?”

“In the kitchen,” she called.

There was a pause, then a soft gasp. “You’re cooking?”

Agatha turned just in time to see Lilia standing in the doorway, shawl slipping from her shoulders, eyes wide as if she’d just walked into a miracle.

“Don’t sound so horrified,” Agatha said dryly, stirring the sauce. “It’s edible, I promise.”

Lilia laughed, delighted. “I’ve been trying to teach you that dish for fifteen years, and now you’re suddenly a chef while I’m out of the house? You’ve wounded me, my girl.”

Agatha shrugged, faint amusement tugging at her lips. “You finally got through to me, apparently. It’s the only thing I ever managed to learn properly. Kept me fed back in Boston when I wasn’t running on fumes and ramen.”

Lilia leaned against the counter, arms folded, a smile softening her face. “Ah, yes. The diet of a poor med student.”

“It was efficient,” Agatha said, plating the pasta. “Questionable nutrition, but efficient.”

Lilia moved to the cupboard, pulling out plates and glasses as if the motion might keep her from getting sentimental. “You never cooked in Boston when I came to visit. You always looked like you were trying to outrun yourself.”

“I was,” Agatha said simply. Then she handed her a plate. “Sit. Eat.”

Lilia obeyed, perching at the small kitchen table, the steam from her dish rising in gentle curls. She took one bite, then another, and closed her eyes with an exaggerated hum of approval.

“It’s perfect,” she declared. “Balanced. Bright. Just the right amount of salt. You’ve finally mastered the language of food.”

Agatha sat across from her, resting her elbow on the table. “It’s linguine, not Latin.”

“Cooking is a kind of magic too,” Lilia said, smiling. “The simple kind that reminds you you’re alive.”

Agatha rolled her eyes but didn’t argue. “You always say things like that.”

“Because they’re true.”

They ate quietly for a while, the clink of forks and the low hum of the fridge filling the space between them. Lilia watched Agatha — her almost-daughter — in that way she did when she was thinking too much, and finally said, “You’re calmer tonight. Lighter somehow. Should I credit the cooking or something else?”

Agatha didn’t look up from her plate. “Cooking,” she said after a moment. “Definitely cooking.”

Lilia chuckled, unconvinced but gracious enough not to press. “Then cook more often.”

Agatha tilted her head. “Careful. You might get used to this.”

“My dream,” Lilia said with a mock sigh, “to live long enough to see you eat before midnight and smile while doing it.”

Agatha smirked faintly. “Don’t get used to that either.”

Lilia dabbed her mouth with a napkin and said, almost casually, “I ran into an old friend in town today.”

Agatha glanced up. “Should I be impressed?”

“Maybe.” Lilia’s eyes twinkled. “Doctor Stephen Strange. You know him?”

Agatha stilled. “The surgeon who had the car accident?”

“The same. He’s a therapist now. Works with trauma cases mostly.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened. “Of course he does.”

Lilia studied her for a beat. “He’s very good at what he does. We had coffee. I told him you were here—”

“Lilia.” Agatha’s tone sharpened. “If this is leading where I think it’s leading, stop.”

Lilia tilted her head, unbothered by the warning. “You’ve been carrying a lot, my dear. Talking to someone might help lighten it.”

Agatha let out a quiet, bitter laugh. “I talk to you.”

Lilia smiled faintly. “Oh yes. Every day you pour your heart out over breakfast. I’m drowning in your vulnerability.”

“I’m serious,” Agatha said, and there was an edge there now—too sharp, too brittle. “I don’t need therapy. I refused it in Boston, and I’ll refuse it here.”

Lilia’s voice gentled. “Because it hurt too much to talk about him?”

Agatha froze. The air seemed to tighten. “Don’t.”

Lilia didn’t flinch. “You still blame yourself, even if you won’t say it out loud.”

“I did everything I could.”

“I know you did.”

Agatha pushed her plate away, appetite gone. “Then stop implying I didn’t.”

“I’m not,” Lilia said softly. “I’m saying you never forgave yourself for surviving when he didn’t.”

Agatha’s breath hitched. Her hands clenched in her lap. For a long moment, the only sound was the slow tick of the kitchen clock.

When she finally spoke, her voice was low but trembling. “I’m fine, Lilia. I just... I need to keep moving forward. That’s how I survive.”

“Moving forward is not the same as healing,” Lilia murmured.

“I don’t care what it’s called,” Agatha said, standing abruptly to gather the dishes. “As long as it works.”

Lilia rose too, touching her arm gently. “You can’t outrun grief forever, Agatha.”

Agatha paused, staring down at the dishes in her hands. “Watch me.”

For a heartbeat, neither of them moved. Then Lilia sighed, sadness softening her features. “I just don’t want to watch you disappear under the weight of it.”

Agatha’s throat felt tight. She blinked hard, set the dishes in the sink, and busied herself with turning off the stove. “I survived it once. I’ll survive it again.”

“Surviving isn’t living,” Lilia whispered.

That time, Agatha didn’t answer.

She stood there, back turned, one hand gripping the edge of the counter like it was the only thing keeping her upright. Her reflection in the window looked almost like a stranger — tired eyes, too pale, the faintest tremor in her jaw.

Finally, she said, quieter now, “You’re right about one thing. I did learn something in Boston. I learned that talking doesn’t always help. Sometimes it just makes the silence louder afterward.”

Lilia’s eyes glistened, but her voice stayed calm. “Then maybe what you need isn’t silence. Maybe it’s someone who knows how to listen.”

Agatha swallowed hard. “Goodnight, Lilia.”

She left the kitchen before Lilia could reply.

From the doorway, Lilia watched her disappear up the stairs. Then she turned back to the table, exhaled softly, and whispered to the quiet room, “You can keep running, my girl, but your heart will catch up eventually.”


Mornings at Westview General were different.

In Boston, Agatha had lived for chaos — the rush of sirens, the blur of movement, the constant demand that made her feel alive. But here, in this smaller hospital tucked between quiet streets and sleepy cafés, the chaos came in softer waves. It was slower, steadier, and against all logic, she found she didn’t hate it.

It wasn’t what she was used to. But lately, Agatha was beginning to understand the value of a calm start.

She was midway through signing off a case when a familiar voice came from the doorway.

“Doctor Harkness.”

Agatha looked up. Chief Natasha Romanoff stood with a clipboard tucked neatly under one arm, posture sharp even this early. She had the composed, faintly amused expression of someone who’d already been awake for hours.

“Chief,” Agatha said, setting down her pen. “If this is about the rotation schedule, I—”

Natasha lifted a hand. “Relax. I’m not here to scold you.”

Agatha blinked, wary. “That would be a first.”

Natasha smirked and crossed the room, resting against the edge of the desk. “Actually, I’m here to say something nice, which, as you know, pains me deeply.”

“Shall I prepare myself?” Agatha asked dryly.

Natasha ignored the jab, her tone softening just enough to be sincere. “You’ve made an incredible start here, Harkness. The staff talk about you — in good ways, I promise. You’ve already set a new standard in the ER.”

Agatha leaned back in her chair, studying her. “If this is an elaborate setup before you ask me to take on another intern, I’m not falling for it.”

A small laugh escaped Natasha. “No setup. Just recognition. Wanda says you’re a machine, and Jen called you terrifyingly competent. Even Teen seems devoted to you.”

“Teen is terrified of me,” Agatha corrected.

“Same thing,” Natasha said. “Whatever you’re doing, keep doing it.”

For a moment, the compliment hung there — rare and genuine, like sunlight breaking through early fog. 

Agatha didn’t quite know what to do with it.

“I didn’t come here for approval,” she said, quieter than before. “Just to work.”

“I know,” Natasha said. “That’s why you fit here. Westview isn’t Boston — it’s smaller, closer. We notice when someone gives a damn.”

Agatha looked down at her coffee, the steam curling faintly. “That’s not always a strength.”

Natasha’s smile softened, something knowing behind it. “It is when you let it be.”

Agatha didn’t answer. She never did when someone hit too closed to truth.

Natasha straightened, glancing toward the hall as the morning noise began to build. “Try not to live in this place. Even great doctors need to remember what morning light looks like outside of these walls.”

“Noted,” Agatha said dryly.

“Good.” Natasha started for the door, then paused. “You’re doing well, Doctor. Better than you think.”

When she was gone, Agatha sat for a long moment, staring at the space she’d left. Compliments had always made her uneasy. They felt like a test — one she might fail if she let her guard drop.

But for the first time in a while, she allowed herself the smallest breath of pride. Just one. Then she opened the next chart and went back to work.

Her eyes scrunched as she read the details of the patient on the chart, she didn’t recognise the name as she scanned and focused on the patient’s date of birth. 2018. 

A child.

A paediatric case had been mistakenly filed between her charts.

Peadiatrics was the one ward Agatha avoided whenever she could.
 She didn’t need to be told why.
 The smell of disinfectant laced with sugar from the nurses’ pockets, the laughter, the bright murals — it all pressed against something raw inside her chest.

Nicky’s laughter had sounded like that.
 The memory came sharp, like a needle prick behind her ribs.

But now she had to deliver a file. A simple drop-off. Nothing more.

The elevator doors slid open onto the bright chaos of the peadiatric floor — the sound of laughter, the patter of small feet, and somewhere in the middle of it, the soft, happy bark of a dog.

She froze.

A therapy dog sat in the corridor surrounded by a ring of children in hospital gowns. The handler smiled as one of the nurses handed out treats, and crouched among them was a figure Agatha recognised instantly.

Rio.

She was wearing her navy Fire & Rescue T-shirt, navy cargo’s and her black work boots. Her dark hair was tied back loosely, and she was laughing, head tipped forward as the dog licked her hand.

Agatha’s heart gave an unsteady jolt.

Rio guided a small boy forward — maybe six or seven, pale and thin but grinning — coaxing him closer to the dog. “He likes brave kids,” Rio said gently. “And you look pretty brave to me.”

The boy reached out, tentative, and the dog leaned into his hand. The other children clapped, soft and delighted.

Agatha took a step back, breath hitching.
 Her vision blurred — not from tears, but from the way memory hit without warning.

Because for a heartbeat, the boy’s brown eyes weren’t his at all. They were Nicky’s.
 Wide, trusting.
 Begging her to do something she couldn’t.

Her throat closed. The sounds around her warped — laughter too loud, the bark echoing like static in her ears. The colours of the hallway seemed to smear, bright blues and yellows bleeding into one another until she couldn’t focus. Her pulse thundered in her ears, each beat heavier than the last.

She tried to breathe but the air wouldn’t reach her lungs. The walls felt too close, the light too sharp. Her fingers went numb where they clutched the chart.

Not here. Not now.

Her body wouldn’t listen. Her knees trembled, her chest seizing around air that wouldn’t move. She reached for the counter, fingertips catching the edge, but the world was already dimming at the edges.

“Doctor Harkness?”

The voice came through muffled at first, like underwater — steady, low, familiar.

Then closer. “Agatha?”

A warm hand touched her shoulder, grounding and real. “Hey,” Rio said quietly, voice cutting through the static. “Come with me.”

The world tilted, but Agatha let herself be led through a side door, into one of the quiet consultation rooms. The door clicked softly behind them, sealing out the noise.

“Sit,” Rio said gently, guiding her toward the chair. Not a command, just calm certainty.

Agatha sank down hard, pressing her palms to her eyes. “I’m fine,” she tried, but her voice came out thin and ragged.

Rio crouched in front of her, voice steady but urgent. “You’re not breathing right.”

“I—” The word broke apart, her chest hitching. The room swayed faintly.

“Okay,” Rio murmured. “Then just follow me.”

Her tone was soft, deliberate like she’d done this before. She took Agatha’s trembling hand and pressed it gently to her own chest.

“Feel that?”

Agatha’s palm met warmth, the slow, steady thrum of Rio’s heart beneath her shirt.

“That’s what you match,” Rio said softly. “In…”
 She inhaled, deep and even.
 “…and out.”

At first, Agatha couldn’t. The air caught, stuttered, fractured in her throat. Her vision shimmered, edges still fading in and out, but then the sound of Rio’s breathing filled the silence, calm and rhythmic, and Agatha found herself following almost unconsciously.

One breath. Then another.
 The chaos receded by degrees.
 The world narrowed to Rio’s heartbeat under her palm, and her voice, low, patient, sure.

The tremor in Agatha’s hands eased. The static in her head softened.

“Good,” Rio whispered. “You’re okay. You’re right here.”

Her hand came up to the back of Agatha’s neck, warm and anchoring. The smell of her — cedar wood, pine, faint smoke — slipped through the antiseptic air, grounding her further.

Agatha’s muscles unclenched, her body remembering how to rest. She let her forehead fall forward until it rested lightly against Rio’s shoulder, still shaking but breathing again.

Neither of them spoke. The only sound was the soft, even rhythm of their breaths syncing, one steady, one fragile but returning to balance.

When Agatha finally drew back, her vision was clear again, though her chest still ached with the remnants of panic.

Rio stayed close, her voice low. “Better?”

Agatha nodded, barely. “Yes. Thank you.”

Rio smiled, gentle and real. “Good. You scared me for a second.”

“Sorry,” Agatha whispered. “That wasn’t very professional.”

Rio shook her head. “That was human.”

They stayed like that, neither moving, hands still linked. Agatha didn’t even notice until the air between them became warmer, closer.

She looked up, meeting Rio’s eyes, and the world seemed to slow again but this time, it wasn’t panic. 
It was gravity.

Her gaze flicked to Rio’s mouth just as Rio’s breath caught. For a second, neither of them moved.

Then they leaned in, slow, uncertain.

And just before their lips met—

The therapy dog barked from the hallway, loud and sudden, breaking the spell clean in two.

Rio startled and laughed, quiet and breathless. “Guess that’s my cue.”

Agatha exhaled shakily, a small, embarrassed smile tugging at her mouth. “Apparently.”

They both smiled then, small, fragile, but honest.

“I should get back,” Rio said softly, rising to her feet.

“Of course,” Agatha murmured, smoothing her coat though her hands still trembled faintly. “The children.”

Rio hesitated at the door, glancing back. “If you ever need to step out like that again… don’t do it alone.”

Agatha met her gaze. Her throat tightened, but her voice stayed even. “I’ll keep that in mind.”

Rio nodded once, then slipped out, the door closing quietly behind her.

For a moment, Agatha stayed where she was, the scent of cedar and smoke still clinging to the air.

Then she let out a long breath and whispered to the empty room, “Fuck.”


By the time Agatha made it back to the ER, her pulse had almost returned to normal. Almost.

She told herself it was the adrenaline, the echo of the panic attack, the sharp aftertaste of memory.
 Not the fact that she had nearly kissed someone.
 Not the way that someone’s scent still clung faintly to her sleeve.

The fluorescent lights of the emergency ward felt too harsh after the soft quiet of the consultation room. 
The noise was grounding, though — the hum of monitors, the shuffle of gurneys, the clipped voices of nurses moving with purpose. This was where she belonged. Order. Focus. Control.

Wanda was leaning over the nurses’ station, scribbling a note on a chart when she looked up. “There you are,” she said. “I thought you’d gone home.”

“Just needed air,” Agatha replied smoothly.

Wanda studied her for a moment longer than was polite. “You look a little flushed. You okay?”

“I’m fine,” Agatha said, too quickly.

“Mm.” Wanda’s eyes flicked down to Agatha’s hands, then back up. “You sure? You’ve got that post-adrenaline look. The one you get after surgery.”

Agatha reached for the nearest chart as if to anchor herself. “You’re imagining things.”

“Probably,” Wanda said lightly, though her gaze stayed on her. “Still, if you need five minutes, I can cover.”

“I don’t need five minutes,” Agatha said. “I need people to stop asking if I’m all right.”

Wanda smiled faintly. “Then you might consider looking less like someone who’s just remembered what feeling feels like.”

Agatha blinked at her, expression unreadable. “I have no idea what you’re talking about.”

“Of course not.” Wanda’s voice was soft but knowing. “That’s what makes it so entertaining.”

Before Agatha could reply, a call came through on the intercom: “Doctor Harkness to Bay Two.”

Saved by the bell.

She grabbed her coat and moved quickly toward the doors.

The call in Bay Two turned out to be minor — a sprained wrist, nothing urgent. Agatha reset the joint, wrapped it, wrote her notes, all with mechanical precision. It should have been grounding. Familiar. Safe.
It wasn’t.

Her heartbeat hadn’t quite found its rhythm again, and the ghost of that near-kiss still hovered somewhere behind her ribs, a pulse that didn’t belong entirely to her.

When she stepped out into the corridor, she caught sight of movement near the nurses’ station.

Rio.

She was standing with the therapy dog from Paediatrics, one hand absently resting on the golden retriever’s head as she spoke to Nurse Belova. The young nurse was practically glowing, leaning on the counter, laughing at something Rio said.

Agatha slowed her pace without meaning to.

Rio looked different out here — calmer, cleaner. Her hair was a little messier now, her cheeks flushed from warmth or laughter or both.

Yelena tilted her head, smiling brightly. “You know, you don’t have to wait for official therapy visits. The kids would love to see you any time. I’d… probably love it too.”

Rio blinked, clearly missing the implication. “Oh, yeah. I usually come when the department organises it.”

Yelena leaned forward a little. “Still, maybe next time you could—”

“Firefighter Vidal,” Agatha said before she could stop herself.

Her voice cut cleanly across the ward, and both women looked up.

Rio’s expression softened instantly. “Doctor Harkness.”

Yelena straightened, the smile on her face turning sheepish. “Oh—Doctor Harkness! I was just, uh, thanking her for helping the kids earlier.”

“I see,” Agatha said, her tone even but her eyes sharp. “It’s good to know we’re fostering such… enthusiastic interdepartmental relations.”

Yelena blinked, uncertain whether she was being complimented or scolded. “Yes, Doctor. Of course, Doctor.” She glanced once at Rio, gave a little wave, and scurried off toward the supply room.

Agatha was left standing there, suddenly too aware of the silence that followed. The corridor hummed faintly with the sounds of the hospital — a monitor beeping in the distance, the soft bark of the therapy dog as he shook his fur — but between her and Rio, everything felt unusually still.

Rio shifted her weight, hand resting loosely on the leash. “Sorry if we were in the way. He likes meeting people.”

Agatha folded her arms, tilting her head slightly. “That much was clear. I’m not sure Nurse Belova’s heart will recover.”

Rio blinked, her brow creasing. “What do you mean?”

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “She was flirting with you.”

There was a beat of silence as Rio processed that, her expression softening into faint confusion. “She was?”

Agatha stared at her, half-exasperated, half something else entirely. “Good lord, you really didn’t notice?”

Rio shook her head, frowning thoughtfully. “I thought she was just… being friendly.”

Agatha’s lips parted, ready with some dry remark but it never came. Because suddenly she was struck by the sheer sincerity of it, the way Rio said it with absolute honesty, no trace of arrogance or false modesty. Just genuine bewilderment.

Something in Agatha’s chest squeezed tight.

She turned slightly, pretending to study the therapy dog to hide the warmth creeping up her neck. “You might want to work on that particular blind spot, Vidal. It could lead to… misunderstandings.”

Rio gave a small, uncertain smile. “You mean I should pay more attention to people?”

“That would be a start,” Agatha said, her tone dry though the faint edge of fondness betrayed her.
Rio crouched down to clip the leash back onto the dog’s vest, her movements calm and practiced. When she stood again, she hesitated a moment before speaking. “Actually… I came down to see what time you finish your shift.”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard. “Why?”

Rio smiled softly, almost shyly. “There’s a little ice cream place down by the park. They stay open late. Thought maybe you could use something sweet after the day you’ve had.”

Agatha blinked again, incredulous. “Ice cream?”

“Yeah,” Rio said, tone light. “You know, cold, sugary, comes in cones—”

“I’m familiar with the concept,” Agatha interrupted. “It just seems… juvenile.”

Rio’s smile faltered, the faintest flicker of embarrassment crossing her face. “Oh. I just thought—”

And that was what did it. That quiet, unassuming look — like she was already half-apologising for being kind.

Agatha felt herself soften before she could stop it.

“I finish at seven,” she said, voice gentler now. “And I prefer mint chocolate chip.”

Rio’s head lifted, eyes brightening, her grin blooming slow and warm. “Noted, Doctor.”

Agatha cleared her throat, straightening her posture. “Don’t make me regret it, Firefighter Vidal.”

“I’ll do my best,” Rio said, the therapy dog’s leash in one hand, her smile still lingering as she walked away.

Agatha stood there for a long moment after she left, pulse unsteady and traitorous.

She told herself it was nothing — just ice cream. Just politeness.

But the truth was simpler.

 

 She wanted to see her again.

Chapter End Notes

How many more chapters until you think they cave?

Chapter 7

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

The air outside the hospital was warm and heavy with the faint sweetness of early summer. Agatha stepped through the glass doors precisely at seven, coat folded neatly over her arm, her hair tied back but falling loose around her face. 

She wasn’t sure why her heart had been keeping time with the clock for the last half hour. It was absurd. It was just ice cream, not a date.

And yet, when she saw Rio waiting near the curb, two paper cups of ice cream in hand, something in her chest loosened.

Rio looked at ease, the low sunlight catching in her raven hair, changed from her uniform into dark jeans and a green t-shirt with some cartoonish white dog on the front. Her expression softened when she saw Agatha. “Right on time.”

“Slow day,” Agatha said.

Rio grinned, holding out one of the cups. “Mint chocolate chip. Extra chocolate sprinkles.”

Agatha took it, the paper cold against her palm. “You listened.”

“I told you I pay attention,” Rio said simply.

Agatha looked down at the ridiculous, joyful dessert and felt a small, traitorous smile tug at her mouth.
 
“I don’t think I’ve had ice cream in years” Agatha said as she shook her head but took a spoonful anyway. 
The cold hit her tongue, sharp and sweet, the chocolate melting into mint in a way that was almost indecently good after the sterile bitterness of hospital coffee.

A low sound escaped her before she could stop it- soft, unguarded, a half-moan of pleasure. 
“Fuck, that’s good.”

Rio’s step faltered. Just slightly — enough that Agatha noticed.

When Agatha looked up, Rio was staring at her, eyes wide, a faint flush spreading high on her cheeks.

For a second, neither of them said anything. The sound of traffic hummed softly somewhere behind them, the evening air thick with heat and the faint sweetness of melting sugar.

Rio blinked, her voice softer than usual when she finally spoke. “You really don’t let yourself enjoy things often, do you?”

Agatha frowned slightly, thrown off by the gentleness of it. “What makes you say that?”

Rio gave a small shrug, looking down at her own cup. “It’s the way you said that. Like you’d forgotten what something good tasted like.”

The words landed heavier than Agatha expected. Too perceptive. Too honest. She forced a small, wry smile. “You’re reading too much into a frozen dessert.”

“Maybe,” Rio said quietly. “Or maybe I just notice these things, about you.”

Agatha’s breath hitched — so slight she doubted Rio even noticed. She spooned another bite of ice cream just to keep her hands busy, eyes flicking toward the streetlights instead of the woman beside her.

“You’re unusually observant for someone who claims to like quiet,” she said finally.

Rio smiled at that, the faint pink still colouring her cheeks. “Quiet doesn’t mean I’m not listening.”

Agatha huffed softly, trying not to let it show how much that line disarmed her. “You’re very strange, Vidal.”

“I get that a lot.” Rio said, smiling.

Agatha looked at her then, really looked — the steady, open gaze, the way her voice seemed to anchor everything around her without trying. She hadn’t meant to feel the flicker of warmth that rose in her chest, but there it was, unwelcome and alive.

She took another bite of ice cream to cover the silence, though this time, the sweetness lingered for a different reason entirely.

They fell into step together, leaving the hospital behind as the day softened into twilight. The street lamps were starting to blink awake, and the sound of crickets hummed somewhere in the distance. Agatha tried not to be overly conscious of how close their shoulders were, or how natural it felt to walk beside her.

After a few minutes, she asked, “Where exactly are we going?”

Rio’s smile was small but secretive. “You’ll see.”

She led them through a quiet side street lined with lilac bushes and cracked pavement until they reached the familiar brick outline of the fire station.

Agatha lifted a brow. “Planning to teach me some arson safety tips?”

“Not exactly,” Rio said, pushing through a side gate and motioning for her to follow. “Come on.”

Behind the station, a narrow metal staircase climbed toward the roof. The metal was cool to the touch, glinting faintly under the streetlight.

Agatha looked up at the rickety staircase, skeptical. “If this collapses, I’ll hold you personally responsible.”

Rio glanced over her shoulder, her grin visible even in the low light. “I’m trained to catch you.”

The words were said so lightly, so matter-of-factly, that they shouldn’t have meant anything at all. But something about the ease of them — the quiet confidence, the unspoken I’ve got you beneath the teasing — made Agatha’s pulse skip before she could stop it.

She hoped the dimness hid the heat that crept up the back of her neck. “Well,” she said briskly, clearing her throat, “let’s hope your training is unnecessary.”

Rio chuckled softly and kept climbing.

Agatha sighed, more at herself than at the stairs, and followed with one hand gripping the cool railing, the other clutching her now half-empty ice cream. She told herself it was ridiculous, this faint nervous flutter in her chest. She scaled a twelve-hour ER shift daily without breaking stride, but one smile from a firefighter and suddenly she was unsteady on metal steps.

Get a grip, Harkness.

Still, she couldn’t help noticing the way Rio moved, so easy and sure, as if every motion was grounded in quiet strength. The kind of presence that made you feel, absurdly, like the air itself might catch you if you fell. An addictive high. 

By the time they reached the top, Agatha’s heartbeat had evened out, but the warmth hadn’t left.

And when Rio turned back to offer her a hand — steady, patient, waiting — Agatha hesitated only a second before taking it.

It was warm, roughened slightly from work, and for one fleeting moment, the world below them disappeared.

It wasn’t what she expected. A few chairs, mismatched but comfortable, sat near the edge beneath a string of soft solar lights. A blanket was draped across the concrete, and the view stretched out before them — rooftops fading into the amber-blue horizon, the distant shimmer of the river catching the last of the sun.
