Rio set her cup down and leaned on the railing. “This is where I go when the noise gets too loud.”

Agatha stood beside her, the wind tugging gently at her hair. The town below looked impossibly calm, like it belonged to another world entirely — one where she didn’t have to brace herself for loss every time the hospital pager went off.

“It’s so quiet,” she said finally.

Rio nodded. “That’s why I like it.”

Agatha glanced sideways at her. “You come up here often?”

“When I can,” Rio said. “It helps remind me that there’s more to life than just what I can see everyday”

Agatha’s throat tightened. “That’s very philosophic.”

Rio smiled faintly. “Maybe. But if you don’t believe in the quiet moments, the noise wins.”

Agatha turned back toward the skyline, her chest suddenly heavy and light at the same time. The air smelled like warm asphalt and grass, and for the first time in longer than she could remember, she felt her shoulders lower, her breath deepen.

“You can come up here whenever you want,” Rio said softly. “It’s better with company.”

“Secret clubhouse?” Agatha murmured.

Rio laughed quietly. “Don’t tell anyone.”

Agatha’s lips curved into the smallest, realest smile. “Your secret’s safe with me.”

They stood there in comfortable silence, ice cream melting slowly between their fingers, the world around them shrinking to the sound of wind and the steady rhythm of their breathing.

And Agatha — practical, guarded, unwilling — realised she didn’t want to be anywhere else.

Rio chuckled softly and kept climbing, her voice drifting back over her shoulder. “You know, you look like you’re actually breathing for the first time all day.”

Agatha gave a dry huff, shaking her head. “Don’t tell anyone. I’ve got a reputation for being insufferably composed.”

Rio smiled over her shoulder. “I don’t think being human ruins your image, Agatha.”

The sound of her name again, so soft, steady, spoken with such unguarded warmth. It made Agatha’s breath falter. No one at the hospital said it like that. Most people didn’t say it at all.

She looked away toward the skyline, her pulse uneven. “It’s… not easy to stay human in my job,” she said finally. “You spend so much time pretending things don’t touch you, because if they do…” Her words drifted off into the wind.

Rio didn’t interrupt. She simply leaned against the railing beside her, close enough that Agatha could feel her quiet presence, her steady breath. The silence between them wasn’t awkward — it was patient, almost expectant.

“There was a boy, in Boston,” Agatha said at last, her voice quiet, fragile. “Nicky. I met him when he was two.”
Rio turned toward her, listening — truly listening.

“His parents abandoned him,” Agatha went on. “He had a heart defect, one of the rare ones that no amount of surgery could quite fix. He spent most of his short life in hospital, hooked to machines that beeped more than he laughed.” Her lips curved into something soft and sad. “But he still managed to find joy in everything. He’d draw pictures of dinosaurs on his charts, tell me stories about dragons in the clouds outside his window.”

Her ice cream had melted, but she didn’t notice.

“I was a second year resident,” she continued. “I wasn’t supposed to get attached. But I did. I started visiting him outside the hospital, after shifts. Wherever they placed him next. I told myself I was checking in medically, but that was a lie. I just… missed him.”

Rio’s brow furrowed gently. “You loved him.”

Agatha’s throat worked. “I did. I… thought about adopting him. I even filled out the first few forms. I was going to cut back my hours, take fewer cases.” She paused, exhaling shakily. “But there was always a reason to wait. Another emergency. Another late shift. I thought I had time.”

Her voice broke on the next words. “He died the day before his fifth birthday. I’d already bought his gift.”

The tears came fast, sudden and hot. She pressed the heel of her hand against her eyes, furious at herself for losing control — but once the wall cracked, it wouldn’t stop.

Rio didn’t say anything. She just stepped closer and wrapped her arms around her, slow and sure. The scent of sandalwood and cedar wrapped around her too, grounding her.

Agatha stood stiffly at first, every instinct screaming to pull back, to keep composed — but then something inside her gave way. She let herself lean into Rio, her forehead against her shoulder, breath shaking.

“I should’ve been there,” she whispered. “He was alone.”

Rio’s voice was low and certain. “He wasn’t. You were there every day that mattered.”

Agatha let out a strangled sound that might have been a sob, her fingers clutching at the back of Rio’s shirt.

Rio just held her tighter. “You gave him love, Agatha. That’s what he would’ve remembered.”

They stood there in silence, the hum of the town distant below, the air warm against their skin.

When Agatha finally pulled back, her eyes were wet but steady. She wiped her face quickly, almost embarrassed.

Rio gave her a small smile — not pitying, not fragile, just real. 

“You can talk about him, you know. You don’t have to keep carrying it alone.”

Agatha drew a long, uneven breath. For the first time since Nicky’s death, she didn’t feel like she was suffocating. “I haven’t told anyone most of that. Not even Lilia.”

Rio’s hand lingered briefly on hers. “Then I’m honoured you told me.”

Something unspoken passed between them — gratitude, trust, maybe the faintest flicker of something deeper.

Agatha looked at her, really looked at her, and for once didn’t try to hide the tremor in her smile. “Thank you.”

Rio’s lips curved, soft and certain. “Anytime, Agatha.”

The last of the sunlight slipped away, leaving only the glow of the town below. And as they stood together on that quiet rooftop, Agatha felt the strange, unmistakable lightness of a weight she’d finally set down.

Something about Rio made her feel like she could finally exhale. 

The constant hum of vigilance that lived beneath her skin seemed to quiet when Rio was near, as if her body recognised safety before her mind could. It was absurd and irrational… but undeniable.

She didn’t understand it, this gravity between them, or the strange calm that came with it. But as the last streak of sunlight disappeared behind the hills, Agatha knew one thing for certain-

She trusted Rio Vidal.

And that terrified her more than anything.

Chapter End Notes

This chapter was supposed to be longer but I've split it into two, so I will likely update again this weekend once I tweak the last part of next chapter. It just seemed to flow better by ending this chapter here.

Nicky 🥺

Chapter 8

Chapter Notes

The first half of this was written and edited sober, the second part was written sober-ish... any spelling mistakes are caused by rosé wine brain...

Also twitter voted for longer chapters so this was the next two combined!

No I dont use AI to edit, write or amend. I just have no life outside this fandom

See the end of the chapter for more notes


By July, Westview had surrendered completely to summer.
 Heat shimmered over the asphalt, the air thick with the smell of cut grass and BBQ. Even the trees seemed to droop in exhaustion.

Agatha had no intention of getting involved in the town’s “Season of Giving” festivities, at least not until Lilia and Sharon Davis cornered her in the kitchen one evening.

“You’ll help, of course,” Sharon said brightly, her bracvelets clinking as she waved a clipboard. “We’re short on volunteers for the raffle table.”

Agatha looked up from her tea. “I’m a doctor, not a carnival worker.”

“Community spirit, dear,” Lilia said, smiling far too sweetly. “It won’t kill you to hand out tickets for an hour.”

“I hand out life-saving treatment daily,” Agatha muttered. “Surely that’s enough civic contribution.”

“It isn’t,” Lilia replied, placing a firm hand on her shoulder. “Besides, the fire department is helping raise funds this year. Perhaps you’ll find it… motivating.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes. “What’s that supposed to mean?”

Lilia just smiled, her expression far too innocent. “You’ll see.”

She did — unfortunately.

Two days later, a flyer appeared on the hospital bulletin board:
🔥 WESTVIEW FIRE & RESCUE FUNDRAISER — COMMUNITY CAR WASH! 🔥 

All proceeds go toward the children’s burn unit and summer festival fund.

Below the bold red letters was a photograph clearly taken by someone with no concept of mercy — the crew lined up in sleeveless shirts, grinning for the camera.

Agatha stopped mid-sip, coffee hovering just below her mouth. “Oh for fuck’s sake,” she muttered, scanning the image. 

“Ridiculous. Who designed this? It’s completely unprofessional.”

Still, her eyes lingered.

And then she saw her.

Rio stood near the corner of the lineup, her long, damp hair curling against her neck, water glinting on her tanned skin. She held a hose over one shoulder, expression somewhere between shy and daring, like she hadn’t realised how indecently photogenic she looked. Her toned biceps were flexed, glistening in the sunlight, and Agatha had to press her lips together to stop the entirely involuntary curl of a smile.

“This is absurd,” she told herself under her breath. “It’s objectification. Sexualised nonsense.”

Her gaze, however, betrayed her, dropping back to the photo, lingering too long on Rio’s shoulders, the easy curve of her smirk, the faint shadow at the hollow of her throat.

“Enjoying the view?”

Agatha startled, coffee sloshing perilously close to the rim. “Jesus fucking christ, Wanda.”

The redhead leaned casually against the counter beside her, a knowing grin already forming. “You’ve been oggling that flyer for a full thirty seconds. I counted.”

“I wasn’t oggling,” Agatha said sharply, too quickly.

“Mhm.” Wanda tilted her head, pretending to study the flyer. “Ah. Now I see what’s got you so… professionally concerned.”

“Concerned,” Agatha repeated, as if saying it would make it true. “Because this—” she gestured vaguely toward Rio’s picture, “—is utterly inappropriate.”

Wanda bit back a laugh. “You’re right. Terrible form. That hose placement is practically indecent.”

Agatha glared at her. “You’re enjoying this.”

“Only because you are.” Wanda’s grin widened. “You’re blushing, by the way.”

“I am not,” Agatha said, though the warmth creeping up her neck betrayed her. She lifted her coffee as a shield. “Don’t you have patients to see?”

“Plenty,” Wanda said, pushing off the counter. “But none nearly as entertaining as watching you pretend you’re not completely flustered by Firefighter Vidal’s forearms.”

Agatha nearly choked on her sip. “Get out.”

Wanda laughed all the way down the hall.

When she was finally gone, Agatha glanced back at the flyer. Her fingers hovered over the edge of the page, tempted to tear it down or maybe just fold the corner where Rio was.

Instead, she straightened it again, took a long breath, and muttered, “It’s for charity.”

And yet, as she walked away, she already knew she’d be there.

 

When the say arrived and she arrived at the station, the scene was absurdly lively. There was music playing from a tinny speaker, suds flying, kids running through sprinklers while the firefighters worked in the sun.

Captain Rogers was manning the donation bucket. Tony was wearing aviators and a grin that could get him arrested, crutches propped up by his side.

And there, near the middle of it all, was Rio.

Her dark hair was tied up messily, a few strands sticking to her temple. Her T-shirt was soaked, clinging to her shoulders and back as she worked a sponge over the hood of a sedan. Her skin glistened faintly in the heat — tanned, strong, sunlit.

Agatha’s throat went dry.

Tony spotted her first. “Doctor Harkness! Come to support local heroes?”

“I came for a clean car,” she said crisply, stepping out of the driver’s seat. “Nothing more.”

“Sure you did,” Tony said, grinning. “We’ll take good care of her. Vidal—”

“I’ve got it,” Rio called, wiping her forehead with the back of her wrist before heading over.

Agatha’s heart gave one unhelpful thump.

“Doctor,” Rio said, smiling as she approached. “Didn’t expect to see you here.”

“Charity,” Agatha said, a little too quickly. “And my car was… dusty.”

Rio tilted her head, that faint, amused half-smile tugging at her mouth. “Dusty. Right.”

She took the sponge from the bucket, water dripping from her fingers, and started on the windshield. 

Agatha tried very hard not to stare at the strong line of Rio’s arms, the way sunlight caught in the droplets on her skin, the easy rhythm of her movements.

Tony hobbled by on crutches with a grin. “Doctor, you sure you’re not here for the view?”

Agatha didn’t look at him. “If you value your next check-up, Stark, keep walking.”

He laughed and retreated, whistling.

Rio glanced over, suppressing a smile. “You’re terrifying.”

“Only when provoked.”

Rio bent to rinse the sponge, and Agatha’s composure disintegrated another inch. The movement drew her eyes helplessly downward — to the way Rio’s tight shorts tightened over her thighs, the play of muscle beneath, the glint of sunlight off droplets running down her legs.

For one horrifying moment, Agatha actually forgot how to breathe.

Get a grip, she told herself, jaw tight. You are a doctor, not a deviant. She was washing your car, not starring in a fever dream.

To distract herself, she turned toward the other end of the lot. A group of women were crowded around Steve and Bucky, all laughter and gleaming sunglasses, like a scene out of some ridiculous small-town calendar. Agatha almost scoffed — how pathetic — until she caught sight of Rio again out of the corner of her eye.

Calm. Effortless. Absolutely devastating.

When Rio finally straightened, brushing the back of her wrist across her cheek, a streak of soap stayed behind, leaving a bright white smudge on sun-warmed skin.

“You’re all set,” she said, stepping back. “Should shine for a while.”

Agatha hesitated. “You missed a spot.”

Rio blinked, her eyes darting back to the now gleaming black Mercedes,“Where?”

Agatha stepped forward before she could talk herself out of it she raised her hand instinctively, brushing the pad of her thumb against Rio’s cheekbone.

The soap came away easily.

Her thumb lingered for just a fraction too long.

Rio went perfectly still.

So did Agatha.

For a second, the sounds of the car wash — the shouts, the music, the spray of hoses — faded into something distant and muffled.

Then Agatha pulled back, her composure snapping back into place as if it had never left. “There,” she said. “Now it’s perfect.”

Rio smiled faintly, her voice lower when she said, “Thanks, Agatha.”

Agatha’s hand felt strangely empty. “Don’t mention it.”

She turned toward Captain Rogers, dropping a crisp bill into the donation bucket without a word, and climbed back into her spotless car.

As she drove away, the rearview mirror caught one last glimpse — Rio laughing at something Tony said, sunlight glinting off the water droplets in her hair.

Agatha tightened her grip on the wheel.
 It was just the heat, she told herself.
 Nothing more.

And still, her thumb tingled where it had touched her.

And yet, as she glanced in the mirror one last time, Rio still visible in the distance, watching her car pull away, eyes following until the Mercedes turned the corner, Agatha’s heart did something infuriating.

It fluttered.

A quiet, treacherous reminder that maybe she wasn’t as immune as she thought.


By the time Agatha got home, the sun was beginning to set, the golden light spilling through the kitchen windows, catching in the glass jars lined up on the countre. The usual scent of rosemary and garlic drifted through the air, and laughter floated from the dining table.

Lilia and Sharon Davis were surrounded by papers, half-drunk glasses of wine, and what looked like the chaotic remains of festival planning- lists, ribbons, and a sketch of what might have been a stage layout.

“You’re home late,” Lilia said without looking up. “We were beginning to think you got lost.”

Agatha slipped off her shoes and hung her coat by the door. “I stopped by the station. The charity event.”

Sharon perked up. “The car wash? Wasn’t it marvellous?” She gestured dramatically with her pen. “Such community spirit! And such scenery, if you know what I mean.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow, reaching for a glass of water. “If you mean the fire crew, I imagine the turnout was alright.”

“Alright?” Sharon laughed. “Sweetie, half the town turned up to donate. I saw three women drop off perfectly clean cars.”

“Ridiculous,” Agatha muttered, sipping her water.

Lilia’s smile was quiet but far too knowing. “And yet, I suspect yours wasn’t among them.”

Agatha glanced away. “My car need washing.”

“Of course it did,” Lilia said lightly, twirling her pen. “Charitable and practical. How very you.”

Sharon grinned. “Oh, I’m sure it was practical. Did you happen to see that lovely firefighter of yours? The quiet one with the—”

Agatha cut in, too quickly. “I don’t have a firefighter.”

That earned her a long, silent look from both women.

Lilia hid her amusement behind a sip of wine. “Mhm. And if you did, hypothetically, would she have perhaps gotten you to stay longer than intended?”

Agatha set her glass down a bit too firmly. “I was there for fifteen minutes.”

“Fifteen minutes longer than you usually spend at social functions,” Lilia said, her tone mild.

“It was a car wash not a party.”

Sharon leaned her chin on her hand. “You’re blushing, Doctor.”

“I’m warm,” Agatha said sharply.

Lilia’s eyes softened. “Of course you are, dear. It’s the weather.”

Agatha crossed her arms. “You both sound insufferably pleased with yourselves.”

Lilia chuckled. “We simply appreciate progress when we see it.”

“There is no progress,” Agatha said, though her voice was quieter now.

Lilia tilted her head. “Then why are you smiling?”

Agatha blinked. “I’m not.”

But she was, just barely, the kind of small, helpless smile that slipped out before reason could stop it.

Lilia caught it, of course. She always did.

“Well,” Sharon said, gathering her papers, “I’ll leave you two to your scheming. Agatha, do consider helping with the raffle booth, won’t you? We could use your… professional presence.”

Agatha sighed. “If it will stop you from calling the house every day, fine.”

“Splendid!” Sharon beamed and swept out the door muttering something about pie eating.

When the door clicked shut, silence settled again. Lilia poured herself another splash of wine and gave Agatha that maddeningly patient look.

“Don’t,” Agatha warned.

“I didn’t say a word,” Lilia said.

“You’re thinking a word.”

“Only one,” Lilia admitted, smiling.

Agatha groaned. “Stop meddling. You’re infuriating you kmow that?”

“And you,” Lilia said softly, “are alive again. That’s all that matters.”

Agatha froze at that. For a moment, neither of them spoke.

Then she exhaled, rubbing her temples. “You over read things, as usual.”

“Perhaps,” Lilia murmured, turning one of her tarot cards idly on the table. 

The Lovers.

“Goodnight, Lilia.”

“Sleep well, my girl.”

Agatha turned toward the stairs, her pulse unsteady and her cheeks still warm.

As she climbed, she caught herself brushing her thumb across her palm — the same hand that had touched Rio’s cheek.

She stared at it for a moment, then flexed her fingers as if trying to shake something off.

But she couldn’t.
 Not really.

Because the feeling lingered, faint as soap and sunlight.

 

 

 

 

By the time the Westview Summer Festival arrived, the entire town smelled of sunscreen, sugar, and nostalgia.

Banners fluttered lazily in the heat, paper lanterns hung from strings above the square, and every street hummed with laughter and music.

It was, Agatha decided, an utterly unnecessary level of cheerfulness.

She stood at the raffle booth beside Lilia, who was effortlessly charming the townsfolk while Agatha counted tickets with surgical precision. Her sleeves were rolled up, hair pinned tightly back, sunglasses shielding her from the glare.

“You look like you’re performing a tax audit,” Lilia murmured.

“I’m ensuring no one rigs the raffle,” Agatha said flatly. “Integrity is important.”

“Of course it is, dear,” Lilia replied, rolling her eyes and hiding a smile. “Though most people come for fun, not petty crime.”

Across the square, Sharon Davis was narrating a pie-eating contest with the energy of a sports commentator, voice carrying cheerfully over the crowd.

“And Ralph Bohner takes the lead- no, wait, Phil Jones is making a comeback! Look at that form, folks, that’s years of Thanksgiving practice right there! Oh, and Herb’s dropped his crust! Rookie mistake!”

The gathered townspeople whooped and clapped, children darting between stalls with faces sticky from lemonade and cotton candy. The air shimmered with heat and laughter, the smell of popcorn and engine grease blending in that uniquely Westview way.

The fire department’s dunk tank was the main attraction witha line of townspeople eagerly paying for the chance to send one of the firefighters plunging into cold water.

Agatha tried not to look.

She failed immediately.

Rio was there, of course sitting atop the dunk tank in a red T-shirt and dark scandalously short shorts, laughing as Bucky hurled a ball and missed spectacularly. The sunlight caught her skin, turning every drop of water into gold. She looked easy, relaxed, happy.

Agatha’s pulse tripped.

Lilia followed her gaze. “Something catch your eye?” she said softly.

Agatha didn’t reply. She focused on the raffle tickets instead, shuffling them like a deck of cards that could somehow distract her from the fact that her stomach had just done a ridiculous flip.

Moments later, Wanda and Jen appeared, both wearing matching festival badges.

“Look at you!” Jen grinned. “Raffle queen of Westview.”

“I was forced,” Agatha said.

Wanda leaned against the counter. “You’re glowing.”

“It’s probably heatstroke,” Agatha deadpanned.

Jen snorted. “Sure it is. Not the sight of a certain firefighter about to get dunked?”

Agatha shot her a withering look. “Yousmall town people are insufferable.”

“Adorable, actually,” Jen said.

Before Agatha could retort, a roar of laughter went up from the crowd. Bucky had finally hit the target. Rio disappeared into the water with a splash, surfacing a moment later with a laugh that carried across the square — low, bright, and entirely too infectious.

Agatha didn’t realise she was smiling until Wanda nudged her.

“You know,” Wanda murmured, “for someone who claims not to enjoy fun, you’ve been staring at it for a solid minute.”

Agatha turned sharply. “I’m merely… ensuring proper safety protocols.”

“Of course you are,” Wanda said, voice rich with amusement.

Lilia excused herself to go check on the main stage, leaving Agatha manning the booth alone. She managed five minutes of peace before she heard a familiar voice behind her.

“Doctor Harkness.”

Her breath caught, which was ridiculous, really. She turned, schooling her face into neutrality.

Rio stood there, towel around her shoulders, damp hair curling against her neck. Droplets still clung to her skin, and her T-shirt was plastered to her torso in a way that made Agatha’s brain temporarily short-circuit.

“Firefighter Vidal,” she managed, cool and crisp, averting her eyes back to the pile of raffle tickets. “I see you’ve been… immersed in community service.”

Rio smiled, slow and warm. “You could say that. You enjoying the festival?”

“Immensely,” Agatha lied.

“Mm.” Rio’s eyes sparkled. “Does that mean I’ll see you at the bonfire later?”

Agatha blinked. “The bonfire?”

“End of the night,” Rio said. “Everyone gathers near the field. Music, lights. It’s nice.”

Agatha hesitated, every instinct screaming no. Crowds, noise, sentimentality, none of it was her scene.

But Rio’s eyes held hers, steady and patient, like she was giving her the option to say yes to something that wasn’t duty for once.

“I’ll… consider it,” Agatha said finally.

Rio’s smile deepened, small, knowing. “That’s good enough for me.”

Then she nodded, the faintest blush creeping into her cheeks. “I should get back before Steve volunteers me again.”

“Go,” Agatha said, though her voice came out softer than intended.

As Rio walked away, the sunlight caught the back of her shoulders, and Agatha felt something she hadn’t in a long time — the quiet pull of wanting to be somewhere other than safe.

By the time the raffle table was packed away and the sun had dipped, the square had transformed into something out of a dream. 

Lanterns swung gently from tree branches, glowing like low-hanging stars. The air smelled of roasted corn, woodsmoke, and sugar, and laughter drifted from every corner of Wedstview Green.

Lilia hovered by the front door of the cottage, passing Agatha as she arrived home. 

“I promised Sharon I’d help light the paths by the field,” she said, looping her shawl over her arm. “You should come by later, Agatha. It does the soul good to see people happy.”

Agatha gave a dry hum. “Happiness is rarely contagious.”

Lilia smiled, her eyes warm with the kind of patience only age could earn. “Maybe you’ve just forgotten what it feels like.”

“I remember perfectly well,” Agatha said. “I just prefer my own company.”

“That’s what you always say,” Lilia replied, already heading for the door. “Come if you want to be reminded what warmth feels like.”

The door closed behind her, leaving Agatha in a silence that felt too still.

She told herself she wasn’t going.
 She’d done her part for community morale. She’d smiled politely, raised money, even tolerated small talk. 

Enough.

But then the faint pulse of distant music reached her, the low hum of a guitar, laughter carried on the night breeze and she found herself standing before her wardrobe again.

She stared at her reflection, frowning. The usual choices of a starched shirt and pressed trousers suddenly felt suffocating. Her hand hovered for a long moment before she reached for something buried near the back- a plum linen dress she hadn’t worn in years.

It was soft, sleeveless, and made her feel strangely unarmored. When she let her hair down loose and curling naturally around her shoulders she barely recognised herself.

“You look ridiculous,” she muttered to the mirror. But her voice lacked conviction.

Ten minutes later, she was locking the front door behind her.


The festival was alive when she arrived with a golden light spilling across the green, couples dancing in the grass, and children racing past with sparklers that left silver trails in the air.

Agatha hesitated at the edge of it all, heart ticking faster than it should. Then she saw her.

Rio.

She’d changed into an off white linen shirt, buttoned loosely , beige cargo shorts, and clean white Converse. Her dark hair was down now, curling softly at the ends, still a little damp from the dunk tank. The firelight painted her skin in warm tones, and for a moment, Agatha forgot how to breathe.

Rio was laughing at something Steve said, her hand nursing a plastic cup filled with beer. But when she turned and caught sight of Agatha, the laughter faltered — her smile softening into something slower, almost reverent.

For the first time since Agatha had known her, Rio looked completely speechless.

The look made Agatha’s stomach twist. She hadn’t expected that. She hadn’t expected any of this.

Rio took a small step forward, like she might come over but then another voice cut through the noise.
“Doctor Harkness!”

Wanda’s voice — light and familiar. She approached with Chief Romanoff at her side, the two of them moving easily through the crowd.

“Enjoying the festival?” Wanda asked, cheeks flushed from laughter.

“I’m… present,” Agatha replied.

Chief Romanoff gave her a brief, polite nod. “Good to see you out of scrubs, Doctor. Didn’t think you were the mingling type.”

“I’m not,” Agatha said simply.

Wanda smiled, her gaze flicking toward Natasha with something soft in it. “She dragged me out here,” she said.

“I didn’t drag,” Natasha murmured. “I encouraged.”

Agatha’s lips twitched with the faintest smirk. “Encouragement seems to suit you, Chief.”

Natasha’s answering smile was brief but genuine. “Don’t tell the department. I’ve a reputation to uphold.”

They moved on after a few more pleasantries, Wanda throwing Agatha a parting wink before looping her arm through Natasha’s. The two disappeared into the crowd, leaving Agatha momentarily alone again.

She turned back and then froze.

Across the firelight, Yelena had joined Rio, tugging her playfully toward the bar stand. The younger nurse was grinning, her blonde hair swinging as she poured them both drinks from a jug of something suspiciously pink.

Rio looked bemused but didn’t resist, her expression shy, a little out of place amid Yelena’s bright chatter. 

When she laughed, tilting her head back, Agatha felt something low in her chest tighten unexpectedly.

It was ridiculous.
 Entirely irrational.

Agatha told herself that for the fourth time as she found her eyes drifting toward the bar stand.

She didn’t even notice Alice, Jen, and Kate until they were practically beside her.

“Well, well,” Jen said, voice lilting with amusement. “Isn’t this an interesting view?”

Agatha blinked, startled. “Excuse me?”

Alice followed Jen’s gaze, catching the line of Agatha’s sight straight to Rio and Yelena. Her lips curved into a small, knowing smile. “Oh,” she said softly, the kind of oh that suggested she’d just found a puzzle piece.

Kate, standing beside them, wasn’t paying attention. Her eyes were locked entirely on Yelena. “God, she’s gorgeous,” she murmured under her breath.

Jen snorted. “Kate, you’ve been staring at Yelena for five minutes.”

“Four,” Kate corrected automatically, cheeks flushed. “And it’s not staring. It’s… quiet appreciation.”

“Uh-huh,” Jen said, grinning. “Quiet appreciation for the woman you’ve been in love with for what, a year now?”

Kate groaned. “Will you stop saying that out loud?”

Alice laughed softly, slipping her arm through Jen’s. “She’s not wrong, though. You’ve been pining so long it’s practically part of your personality.”

Kate covered her face with both hands. “I’m leaving.”

“No, you’re staying,” Jen said, looping an arm around her shoulders. “Who knows, maybe Yelena will finally notice you if you keep staring hard enough.”

Agatha, meanwhile, had gone perfectly still — which, for her, was as good as admitting guilt.

Alice’s gaze slid back to her, eyes glinting. “Though I’m starting to think we’re not the only ones noticing that bar.”

Agatha’s head snapped around. “I beg your pardon?”

Jen smirked. “Oh, come on, Agatha. You’ve been staring holes through Rio and Yelena since we walked up.”

“I was not staring,” Agatha said crisply. “I was observing.”

“Observing,” Jen echoed, amused. “Sure. For… medical reasons?”

Agatha’s voice went cool. “It’s called situational awareness. Perhaps you’ve heard of it.”

Alice chuckled under her breath, leaning toward Jen. “She’s defensive. That’s adorable.”

“I am not defensive,” Agatha said.

Jen raised a perfectly shaped brow. “You just snapped at us for saying you were staring.”

Kate, finally looking away from Yelena, frowned. “Wait—what are we talking about? Who’s staring at who?”

“No one,” Agatha said immediately.

“Everyone,” Jen corrected. “Yelena’s flirting, Kate’s pining, and Agatha’s pretending she’s not watching any of it like a hawk.”

Agatha exhaled through her nose, composed but pink at the edges. “You three are incorrigible.”

Alice smiled sweetly. “You love us.”

“That’s debatable,” Agatha muttered, lifting her glass to her lips.

Jen tilted her head toward the bar again. “Well, whatever it is you’re not watching, it looks like Yelena’s succeeding. She’s got Rio laughing now.”

Agatha didn’t respond, but her jaw tightened slightly.

Alice noticed — just barely — and filed it away with quiet intrigue.

Kate groaned into her hands.

Jen, oblivious, grinned and lifted her drink. “To summer festivals, where everyone’s a little too drunk and a little too obvious.”

They clinked cups, and Agatha managed a dry, noncommittal smile, eyes flicking once more toward the bar despite herself.

And there Rio was again, laughing softly as Yelena leaned suspiciously close.

 


The bonfire crackled in the centre of the field, its light rippling gold across the crowd. Children darted around with sparklers, their laughter breaking against the low hum of the band’s music. The heat of the flames carried a familiar, comforting smell of smoke, pine and summer earth.

Lilia sat in a folding chair near the edge of the firelight, shawl draped over her shoulders, a paper cup of wine in hand. She looked entirely at ease, like she belonged here, a part of the town’s fabric in a way Agatha never had.

“Ah,” she said without looking up. “I was beginning to wonder when you’d find me.”

Agatha eased down into the chair beside her. “You assumed I would.”

“I hoped,” Lilia corrected, smiling faintly. “You’ve been quiet tonight.”

“I’m surrounded by loud people,” Agatha said dryly.

“Mm,” Lilia hummed, eyes still on the fire. “That’s not what I meant.”

Agatha didn’t answer. Her gaze drifted over the flames, but inevitably, it wandered back across the field.

There was Yelena, still at the bar stand, animated and laughing. And there was Rio, standing close beside her, smiling that same soft, open smile that seemed to light up everything around her.

Something in Agatha’s chest ached.

Lilia followed her line of sight and — as always understood before Agatha could form words.

“Ah,” she said softly, sipping her wine. “So that’s what this is.”

Agatha stiffened. “What what is?”

“Agatha dear, in all the years I’ve known you, I haven’t seen you look at someone the way you look at Rio before.”

Agatha’s chest tightened. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Let that wall down my girl,” Lilia murmured, her tone gentle, not scolding. “Let your heart feel what it wants.”

Agatha stared into the fire. The flames danced, licking upward as if reaching for something they couldn’t quite touch. “And what if it wants something it can’t have?”

Lilia smiled sadly. “Agatha, I’ve also seen the way that girl looks at you. I’ve known Rio for years. She’s never shown interest in anyone before you came alonmg.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened. “She seems pretty interested in someone right now.”

Lilia followed her gaze toward the bar stand, where Yelena was laughing brightly and animated while Rio stood beside her, smiling politely.

“She’s just being polite,” Lilia said softly. “Look closer. Her smile’s not even reaching her eyes.”

Agatha frowned, watching. And sure enough, once the laughter faded, Rio’s smile lingered only a heartbeat before her expression softened — distracted, searching.

“She keeps looking around,” Lilia said. “Like she’s waiting for someone.”

Agatha’s pulse jumped. She forced a breath, trying to convince herself otherwise. “She’s probably looking for her captain. Or Alice. Or—”

Lilia cut her a look that silenced her mid-sentence.

Agatha pressed her lips together, chewing lightly on her fingernail, an old habit she thought she’d long since broken. She didn’t notice herself doing it until Lilia’s hand brushed hers gently.

“Stop thinking,” Lilia murmured. “For once, just… feel.”

Agatha’s gaze drifted back to Rio. The firefighter was still scanning the crowd slowly, deliberate, eyes sweeping over faces until, for a split second, they seemed to meet Agatha’s across the distance.

Agatha’s breath caught.

Then Rio looked away, her brow furrowing faintly, as if trying to place a thought that wouldn’t settle.

Agatha exhaled, long and shaky, and muttered, “You’re reading too much into things.”

Lilia smiled. The kind of smile that belonged to someone who’d already decided she’d be the hand of fate.

“Oh, perhaps,” she said lightly, swirling her cup. “But sometimes fate needs a nudge.”

Before Agatha could respond, Lilia tipped the last of her cup into the fire.

The flames leapt instantly higher, a burst of heat and light erupting upward with a soft whoosh. The crowd gasped, turning instinctively toward the flare.

Within seconds, half the fire department was on alert — including Rio.

“Lilia!” Agatha hissed, glaring. “What the fuck are you—”

But it was too late.

Rio was already sprinting across the field, towel from the bar still slung over her shoulder, eyes sharp with concern. “Everything okay here?” she asked, breathless as she reached them.

Lilia blinked up at her innocently. “Oh, dear me, I might’ve gotten a bit too enthusiastic with my drink.”

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose. “You threw it into the fire, Lilia, what the fuck was even in there, gasoline?”

Rio crouched to check the edges of the pit, her hand brushing over the grass to make sure nothing had caught. “No harm done,” she said after a moment, looking up and straight into Agatha’s eyes. “You both all right?”

Agatha opened her mouth, but no sound came out.

Her heart was still racing, though she couldn’t tell if it was from the burst of flame or from the nearness of the woman in front of her — the faint smell of smoke and pine clinging to her shirt, the worry softening her expression.

Lilia, of course, noticed everything. She rose with a small, satisfied smile. “We’re perfectly fine, Rio dear. Thank you for coming so quickly.”

Rio stood, nodding, still watching Agatha. “Of course. Just glad you’re both okay.”

Lilia touched Agatha’s shoulder lightly as she passed. “I think you two should sit for a while,” she said, her tone deceptively casual. “I’m going to get another drink.”

Before Agatha could reply, she was gone, slipping into the hum of the crowd with that knowing sway of her shawl.

The night settled thick and golden around them in her absence. The bonfire burned low, its crackle softened by the hush of summer air. Beyond the circle of light, the festival still thrummed with laughter, fiddles, and the faint clink of glass mixed with the sound of children chasing fireflies. Here, though, it felt distant, muted, as if the world had drawn a soft curtain around just the two of them.

Rio crouched near the fire, her movements unhurried. The orange glow painted over her skin, catching on the curve of her jaw and the dark curls loose around her temples. She poked at the embers with a stick, eyes intent on the flame.

“Looks stable,” she murmured, brushing a curl from her face. A faint smile tugged at her lips. “Lilia nearly gave half the fire crew a heart attack.”

“She has that effect on people,” Agatha said, settling onto the blanket. “Her hobbies include meddling and theatrics.”

Rio smiled faintly. “Seems like it works for her.”

Agatha hummed, a small, knowing sound. “She said she’s known you for years.”

Rio nodded, lowering herself to sit beside her. “She and Sharon are always dropping food at the station. Lilia’s kind of the town’s patron saint of comfort meals.”

Agatha gave a soft snort. “And cryptic advice.”

“She’s not wrong, though,” Rio said.

Agatha glanced at her. “About what?”

Rio met her eyes, steady and warm. 

“About you.”

Agatha looked away too quickly. “You barely know me.”

Rio’s voice dropped a little, softer. “Maybe. But maybe I’ve seen enough.”

That made Agatha’s pulse stutter, and she wasn’t sure she liked how easily it did. To distract herself, she nodded toward the bar. “You seem to be getting on well with Nurse Belova.”

Rio blinked, surprised, then smiled. “Yelena? Oh — no, we’re just friends. She’s… persistent, that’s all.”

“Persistent,” Agatha repeated dryly. “Is that what they call it now?”

Rio laughed under her breath, a low, warm sound that made Agatha’s stomach tighten unexpectedly. “Yelena flirts with everyone,” Rio said. “It’s just her nature.”

Agatha tilted her head slightly, eyes sharp. “And you? Do you flirt with all your friends?”

Rio turned toward her fully now, amusement glinting in her brown eyes. “No,” she said, voice dropping softer. “Just stubborn doctors who don’t seem to take kindly to people flirting with them.”

Agatha’s breath caught — quiet, involuntary.

She turned to look at her, startled by the honesty in Rio’s tone, the faint nervousness that softened the edges of her smile. “That’s… bold,” Agatha managed.

Rio’s smile grew, gentler this time. “Not something Im used to hearing.”

The air between them shifted — warmer, closer.

Rio’s hand moved slightly, fingers brushing against the blanket until they came to rest next to Agatha’s. 

Just touching. Not enough to startle, but enough to feel.

Agatha froze. Her pulse thrummed in her throat, the warmth from the fire suddenly unbearable. She should’ve pulled away, said something cutting, but instead she just breathed — slow, shaky.

“Rio,” she said softly, the name slipping out like an exhale.

Rio’s face lit up. She turned to her fully, eyes bright. “That’s the first time you’ve ever said my name.”

Agatha’s lips curved, small and unguarded. “It is?”

“Mm,” Rio murmured, her smile soft but radiant. “You should say it more often. It sounds nice when you do.”

The words hung between them, warm and unguarded.

Agatha’s breath caught. The night pressed close, the firelight flickering against Rio’s face, the faint smell of cedar and summer air tangling in her senses. Everything else blurred away.

For once, her mind — the sharp, clinical machine she trusted above all — went quiet.
 All she could hear was Rio’s slow, steady breathing.
 All she could see were Rio’s brown eyes, reflecting the flames.

She wanted to move closer. Just a little.

Her body leaned before her reason could stop it.

Don’t, her mind hissed. Don’t do this. Don’t make it real.
 But another smaller voice, desperate and hers whispered, Please.

Rio didn’t move away. Her hand, still next to Agatha’s, brushed forward, a light, deliberate touch that sent something electric spiralling up her arm.

Agatha’s pulse was a drumbeat in her ears.
 She could feel herself trembling, on the edge of something terrifyingly human.

Just kiss her, that voice pleaded. For once, just—

A shout split the air.

“Somebody help! She’s collapsed!”

The sound sliced straight through the moment. Agatha’s head snapped toward the commotion — a crowd gathering near the picnic tables under the lanterns.

Then someone yelled, “We need a doctor! Now!”

Everything inside her shifted, her instinct overriding everything else. She was moving before the thought even formed.

She bolted across the grass, the crowd parting as she ran, heart pounding. Rio was right behind her, her footsteps quick, solid, close.

“Lilia,” someone cried. “It’s Lilia Calderu— she just fell—”

Agatha’s blood went cold.

She dropped to her knees beside the blanket where Lilia lay motionless, her shawl fallen to one side, her eyes closed, lips faintly blue.

“Lilia,” Agatha gasped, already checking her pulse. Nothing. “No, no, no—”

Her hands moved automatically, heel to sternum, locking her elbows. “Call it in!” she barked. “Now!”

“I’ve got it!” Rio’s voice came from behind her, sharp and steady, already pulling out her radio.

People scattered. Someone — Jen, still in her festival dress — knelt on the other side, pale and shaking. 

“Oh my God—”

“Move back,” Agatha said, voice breaking around the edges. “Give me space.”

“Agatha,” came another low, calm voice. Chief Romanoff. She crouched down, hand hovering near Agatha’s shoulder. “Let us—”

“No!” Agatha snapped, pumping faster, every compression punctuated by a tremor of fear. “I’ve got her. Don’t— don’t touch her.”

Romanoff’s eyes flickered with something like understanding. “Okay,” she said quietly. “Then talk to me, Doctor.”

“ Patient is unresponsive. No pulse. Suspected cardiac arrest,” Agatha said mechanically, her voice tight and ragged. “We’re starting compressions. Prepare epinephrine.”

Jen’s voice cracked. “Ambulance is on the way—”

“Good,” Agatha said, counting under her breath. Thirty compressions. Two breaths. Repeat.

Her vision blurred — sweat, tears, she wasn’t sure. “Come on, Lilia,” she whispered. “Not like this. Not you.”

Rio was beside her now, kneeling, ready with the med bag. “Agatha,” she said softly, steady as stone. “Breathe.”

“I am breathing!” Agatha barked, voice shaking. “She’s not.”

Her arms ached, but she didn’t stop. Couldn’t. Every press felt like trying to push life back into the only person who’d ever truly been home.

Romanoff reached forward again. “Harkness—”

“Don’t!” Agatha’s voice cracked. “Please, just— don’t.”

Something in it - that raw, breaking edge — froze everyone around her.

Then—

“Got a pulse!” Jen said suddenly, her fingers pressed to Lilia’s throat. “It’s faint but— she’s got one!”

Agatha froze, her whole body trembling as she bent over Lilia, listening.
 A weak, uneven beat under her ear.

“Okay,” Agatha whispered, tears spilling down her cheeks before she could stop them. “Okay. Stay with me, Lils. Come on, stay with me.”

Sirens wailed in the distance, growing louder, closer.

When the paramedics arrived, Agatha was already barking vitals, her tone clipped and urgent even through her shaking.

“She’s in sinus rhythm, weak pulse, probable myocardial infarction,” Agatha said. “I’m riding with her.”

Romanoff nodded. “Go. We’ll meet you there.”

Rio helped lift the stretcher, her movements efficient, but her face pale with worry. When they reached the ambulance, she caught Agatha’s arm briefly, grounding her.

“She’s alive because of you,” Rio said softly.

Agatha met her eyes- wide, wet, wild. “She’s alive for now.”

Rio’s voice gentled. “Then let’s keep her that way.”

Agatha swallowed hard, then climbed into the back of the ambulance, her hands still pressed to Lilia’s wrist, her voice a hoarse whisper against the sirens’ scream.

“Hold on, Lils,” she murmured. “Please.”

The doors slammed shut, sealing her inside with the rhythmic beeping of monitors and the heavy thud of her own pulse. Through the small back window, she caught one last glimpse of Rio standing frozen by the firelight, worry carved into every line of her face.

As the ambulance pulled away, Rio grew smaller, her figure swallowed by the blur of flashing red and gold. A heartbeat ago, Agatha had been on the edge of something almost beautiful- - laughter, warmth, a near-kiss under the summer sky. 

Now, all that remained was the echo of it, slipping further away with every turn of the wheels.

Chapter End Notes

Yes future Wanda/Natasha & Kate/Yelena ☺️

Chapter 9

Chapter Notes

Posting this before the edible hits 🫠

I know I posted ch8 drunk on wine, I promise I don't have a substance abuse problem ...I just hate reality too much.

Hense... I write.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The hospital lights were brutally sharp and cold, washing everything in sterile white. The hum of the fluorescent bulbs filled the air as the paramedics wheeled Lilia through the emergency doors.

Agatha’s voice was steady, automatic. “Seventy-two-year-old female, cardiac arrest at the scene. Resuscitated after four minutes of CPR. Pulse weak, irregular, likely myocardial infraction.”

The ER doctor on duty stepped forward. “We’ll take her, Doctor Harkness.”

Agatha’s hands gripped the rail of the stretcher. “She’s unstable—”

“We’ve got her,” the doctor said gently, nodding to the nurses. “Go clean up, Agatha. You did your part.”

Her fingers refused to release the metal. For a second she just stood there, the world narrowing to the uneven beep of the heart monitor. Then she forced herself to step back.

She didn’t go far. Just outside the curtain, she stood watching the team move with practiced speed — oxygen, nitro, IV line, ECG leads. The erratic blip of Lilia’s heart filled the space, jagged and uncertain.

She had walked into this room every day for months, moved through it with detached efficiency. She knew every corner, from the placement of the crash cart, the crack in the linoleum near Bay Three, down to the hum of the old ventilator that needed replacing. It was her world, her controlled chaos.

But tonight, it all looked different. The lights were too bright, the sound too loud. The air that had always smelled of antiseptic and adrenaline now felt suffocating. Every detail she’d once dismissed as routine suddenly cut sharp against her senses — the squeak of shoes on tile, the hiss of the oxygen, the click of a pen against a clipboard.

She was seeing it as a family member now, not as a doctor. From the wrong side of the curtain.

Her chest ached with the realisation.

She’ll be fine, Agatha told herself. She has to be fine.


The doors burst open again five minutes later.

Wanda was first — still in her sundress from the festival, hair mussed from the run. Natasha followed, composed as ever in jeans and a white shirt, her face set in calm urgency. Behind them came Jen, her heels clacking across the tile, Alice clutching her paramedic bag, Kate looking pale and wide-eyed.

And Rio — in her linen shirt and beige shorts, breathless, short curls messy from the humid night air.

Agatha looked up, startled by the sight of all of them together.

“She’s in Treatment One,” she said automatically, voice rough. “They’re working on her.”

Alice pressed a hand to her chest, visibly shaken. “Is she—”

“She’s alive,” Agatha cut in. “Barely.”

Wanda moved closer, her voice soft but firm. “Agatha, you got her this far. You saved her life.”

“She’s not saved until she wakes up,” Agatha snapped. Her voice cracked at the end.

Natasha stepped forward, calm and controlled, but her gaze was sharp with concern. “Dr Harkness,” she said quietly. “You need to take a step back.”

Agatha’s head turned sharply. “Excuse me?”

“You’re too close,” Natasha said gently. “You’re not objective right now.”

“I’m not leaving her.”

“Agatha—”

But those words broke something. It was the same thing they’d told her in Boston.

She could almost hear it echoing through time- You’re too close. Step away. We’ll take over from here.
The image of Nicky’s face flooded back in, the desperate gasps, the flatline, the impossible silence that had followed.

Please, let me try. I can save him. Don’t take him from me.

The monitors in Lilia’s room beeped unevenly, pulling her halfway between past and present. The floor swayed.

Wanda said something, but the words blurred.

Agatha turned, walking fast down the corridor. She reached the on-call room and slammed the door shut behind her, leaning against the opposite wall as her breath came too quick, too shallow.

Her hands trembled violently. Her chest hurt. The sterile smell of antiseptic filled her lungs.

She pressed her palms over her face.
 Not again. Please, not again.

The tears came suddenly, like something bursting loose, like years of control collapsing all at once.

The door opened quietly.

“Agatha?”

She looked up. Rio stood in the doorway, her chest rising and falling, cheeks flushed and eyes steady.

“How did you—” Agatha began, but her voice broke.

Rio took a tentative step forward. “Wanda said you like to hide in here.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha rasped.

Rio shook her head. “You’re not.”

Agatha turned away, gripping the edge of the cot. “She’s all I have left, Rio. If I lose her—” Her voice caught. “If I lose her, I don’t know how to come back from that.”

Rio crossed the small space between them without hesitation. “You’re not losing her.”

Agatha laughed, bitter and wet. “You can’t know that.”

“No,” Rio said softly, “but you gave her a fighting chance.”

Agatha’s breath trembled. “I can’t go through it again. Not again.”

Rio’s face softened with quiet understanding. “I know,” she murmured. “You don’t have to explain.”

The words cracked something open in Agatha. She shook her head, voice breaking. “It feels the same as… The waiting. The not knowing.”

Rio stepped closer, her voice steady, low. “But she’s still here. You brought her back. That’s different this time.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, a sound caught between grief and disbelief. Her body shook once, hard.
And then Rio simply stepped forward and wrapped her arms around her.

Agatha froze for just a heartbeat and then folded.

The sobs came rough and silent, shaking through her whole frame.

Rio held her tighter, one hand in her hair, the other pressed to her back, steady and sure. “It’s okay,” she whispered. “You don’t have to hold it together right now.”

Agatha buried her face in Rio’s shoulder, breathing in the faint scent of smoke, soap, and pine. The smell was grounding, alive, real.

Rio didn’t try to fix it. She didn’t say it’ll be okay or stay strong. She just held her, her heartbeat slow and steady under Agatha’s ear.

After a while, Agatha’s breathing began to even out.

“She’s strong,” Rio murmured. “You know that better than anyone. You’ll see her again soon.”

Agatha nodded faintly, voice cracking. “I can’t lose her.”

 


The hospital had fallen into the deep hush of early mornin and that strange, sacred hour between night and dawn when even machines seemed to quiet.

Lilia lay in a private room now, her face pale but peaceful under the soft monitor glow. The steady rhythm of her heart filled the silence, an unsteady metronome that still made Agatha flinch every few beats.

She sat in a chair pulled close to the bed, her posture too rigid for someone who hadn’t slept in nearly twenty hours. Her lab coat was folded over the backrest, her scrubs now worn like armour.

Her fingers itched to keep checking Lilia’s vitalks, to do something, but the on-duty team had been clear, she needed to rest. To wait.

She was terrible at both.

The door opened quietly.

“Hey.”

Rio stepped inside, holding two paper cups and a hesitant kind of smile. She’d changed into an old FDWV hoodie and sweatpants.

Agatha blinked up at her, voice hoarse. “What are you still doing here?”

“Bribing the on-call nurse,” Rio said softly. “She said you hadn’t moved for hours.”

She handed her a cup. The rich smell of coffee hit Agatha first, dark, strong, slightly burnt. Her favourite.

“Thank you,” she murmured, fingers brushing Rio’s briefly as she took it.

Rio sank into the chair beside her, careful not to disturb the quiet. “How is she?”

“Stable,” Agatha said. “They’ve got her on fluids, beta-blockers, oxygen. She’s holding.”

Rio nodded, eyes flicking toward the bed. “She looks peaceful.”

Agatha followed her gaze. For the first time in hours, she let herself exhale properly. “She does.”

They sat in silence for a while — sipping coffee, listening to the rhythmic beeping, the hum of the air vents.

Then Rio spoke, voice low. “You love her a lot.”

Agatha’s lips curved faintly, a tired smile. “She’s been my whole world since I was twelve.”

Rio turned slightly, listening.

Agatha stared down at her coffee cup, the paper softening under her grip. “My mother was… not a good person. Cold, cruel, controlling. When she decided she’d had enough of me, she sent me to stay with Lilia. Just for the summer, supposedly.”

She swallowed. “But I never went back.”

Rio didn’t speak, she just watched her with that same patient quiet that made it easy to keep talking.

“She took me in like it was the most natural thing in the world. Fed me, scolded me, made me do the dishes like any other kid. I think she was the first person who ever looked at me and didn’t see a burden.”

Her voice faltered, softening. “I owe her everything. Every good part of me is because of her.”

Rio’s hand moved slowly, deliberate, until it rested gently over Agatha’s.

Agatha froze for a moment, instinctively wary of being touched, but Rio’s hand was warm, grounding.

“She’s lucky to have you,” Rio said quietly. “And you’re lucky to have her. That kind of love doesn’t happen twice.”

Agatha stared at their hands her pale fingers under Rio’s darker, calloused ones and for the first time all night, she didn’t pull away.

Her shoulders sagged, the exhaustion finally breaking through. “I don’t know what I’d do if she didn’t—”

Rio squeezed her hand, gentle but firm. “Don’t,” she said softly. “She’s still here.”

Agatha nodded, eyes wet but no longer spilling. “You should be at home.”

“So should you,” Rio murmured. “But I’m staying.”

Agatha turned her head, meeting her gaze — steady, unflinching, impossibly kind.

“Why?”

Rio smiled faintly. “Because you shouldn’t be alone right now.”

Something in Agatha cracked again, not breaking this time, but loosening. The armour she’d been holding up for hours finally gave way.

“Thank you,” she whispered.

Rio shook her head. “Don’t thank me. Just… breathe, okay?”

Agatha nodded, and Rio didn’t move her hand away.

The hours blurred into one another, the soft light shifting from grey to gold across the hospital roomfloor.

Agatha hadn’t moved much. She sat where she’d been all night, one hand wrapped around a lukewarm cup of coffee, the other occasionally checking the pulse at Lilia’s wrist just to feel its reassuring beat beneath her fingers.

Rio was still beside her, shoulders slouched with exhaustion.

It had been hours since anyone had spoken. Words felt unnecessary.

Eventually, Rio’s radio crackled faintly, a low murmur of voices, the fire station calling her name. She sighed, rubbing a hand over her face.

“I have to check in,” she said softly. “We’ve got inspection rounds this morning.”

Agatha’s heart sank a little, though she kept her tone even. “Of course. Duty calls.”

Rio stood, stretching the stiffness from her shoulders. “I’ll come back as soon as I can.”

“You don’t have to—”

Rio cut her off gently, a small smile tugging at her lips. “I want to.”

Agatha looked up at the softness in her expression, the quiet certainty and managed a faint nod. “All right.”

Rio hesitated a moment longer, then reached down and brushed her thumb against the back of Agatha’s hand. “Get some rest, Doctor.”

Agatha’s lips twitched, almost a smile. “I’ll try.”

Rio grinned. “You’ll do.” She said, mimicking Agatha’s authoritative tone.

And then she was gone the door closing softly behind her, leaving Agatha in the hum of monitors and sunlight.

Hours passed.

Nurses came and went.

Jen stopped by with fresh coffee and Wanda brought a blanket, both gently telling her to take a break. She didn’t.

She couldn’t.

Then, sometime in the late afternoon, the hand beneath hers twitched.

Agatha’s head snapped up. “Lilia?”

Her eyelids fluttered — slow, groggy, but there. A long, shaky breath followed.

“Agatha?” Lilia rasped.

“Yes.” Agatha’s voice broke on the word. “Yes, I’m here.”

Lilia blinked up at her, disoriented for a moment before her gaze softened. “You look like hell, my girl.”

Agatha laughed a wet, trembling sound . “You terrified me.”

Lilia gave a faint smile. “Good. Keeps you humble.”

Tears spilled down Agatha’s cheeks before she could stop them. “Don’t ever do that again.”

“I’ll try,” Lilia murmured. “But I make no promises.”

Agatha exhaled a laugh that turned into a sob. “I thought—”

“You and me both.” Lilia said gently, reaching for her hand. “But I’m still here.”

Agatha gripped her fingers tight.

Lilia’s fingers twitched weakly in Agatha’s grasp, her eyelids fluttering closed for a beat.

“Lilia?” Agatha leaned closer, her voice trembling. “Do you need anything? Water, maybe—”

Lilia gave a faint, dry laugh that rasped against her throat. “I need you to stop fussing and sit still for once.”

Agatha exhaled shakily, relief breaking through the tightness in her chest. “Goddess, you scared me.”

“Good,” Lilia murmured, a ghost of a smile curving her lips. “Maybe now you know how I feel most days, watching you run yourself into the ground. Just stay still with me.”

So Agatha stayed. For a while, neither of them spoke. The only sound was the faint hum of the monitors, the steady rhythm that reminded her that Lilia was still here. 
Still breathing. 
Still fighting.

Finally, Lilia spoke again, her voice low but clear. “Do you remember when you first came to live with me?”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the sudden turn. “Of course I do.”

“You were twelve.” Lilia said softly. “You barely spoke a word to me for the first month. Wouldn’t eat, wouldn’t sleep, sat by the window like you were waiting for someone who was never going to come.”

Agatha’s chest tightened. “You don’t have to—”

“I do,” Lilia said, squeezing her hand. “Because I remember the night that changed. I came downstairs, and you were in the kitchen, trying to boil water for tea. You looked at me like I might throw you out just for breathing too loud.”

Agatha let out a trembling laugh. “You told me I was boiling an almost empty pot.”

Lilia smiled faintly. “And you cried when I told you it was alright. That you could stay as long as you needed.”

Agatha’s throat burned. “I remember.”

Lilia’s voice softened, each word deliberate.

“You were so closed off, Agatha. So afraid to let anyone in. I thought, back then, that you might never trust anyone enough to let them see who you really are. But slowly, you did. You let me in. You started to laugh again. And I saw you for who you are... a beautiful soul who’s just been hurt too many times.”

Agatha’s breath caught, tears gathering in her eyes.

“And when you lost Nicky,” Lilia went on gently, “I saw that same wall go back up. You stopped letting yourself feel. Because feeling meant loss. And loss meant pain.”

Agatha pressed her lips together, her hand tightening around Lilia’s. “You don’t understand—”

“Oh, but I do,” Lilia whispered.

“Because I’ve watched you. You come to this hospital every day and pour your heart into saving people, but you’ve stopped letting anyone save you.”

Agatha looked down, her voice barely audible. “It’s easier that way.”

“Maybe,” Lilia said, her eyes glinting with something fierce and loving. “But easier isn’t living. You think closing your heart will keep it from breaking, but all it does is stop it from beating.”

Agatha couldn’t answer. The tears she’d been holding back finally spilled over, silent and hot.
Lilia reached up, brushing a trembling hand against her cheek. “You’ve found someone who makes that heart remember how to beat again, haven’t you?”

Agatha froze.

Lilia smiled faintly. “You don’t have to say it, my girl. I see it. The way you look at her... the way you try not to. Full of love you’re too scared to name.”

Agatha’s voice cracked. “I can’t lose someone again, Lils.”

Lilia’s gaze softened, but her tone was steady. “Maybe you won’t. Maybe you will. But if you don’t take the chance, you’ll lose yourself instead.”

Agatha lowered her head, shoulders shaking with quiet, exhausted sobs.

Lilia squeezed her hand one last time before letting her eyes drift shut again. “You’ve spent your whole life running from pain, Agatha. Maybe it’s time to run toward something instead.”

Agatha sat there long after, her tears drying against the back of Lilia’s hand, her chest aching with everything she hadn’t said and everything Lilia already knew.

 


For a long time after Lilia drifted back to sleep, Agatha sat in silence, her hand still clasped around Lilia’s, the rhythmic beep of the monitor echoing through the dim room.
 Each pulse of the green line on the screen felt like a heartbeat tethering her to something she hadn’t dared to feel in years.
 Each flicker whispered the same thing over and over.

You’re still here.

Lilia’s words had lodged themselves deep inside her, stubborn and inescapable.

You’ve stopped letting anyone save you.


 You think closing your heart keeps you safe, but all it’s done is stop you from living.

Agatha’s jaw clenched as she stared at the rise and fall of Lilia’s chest.
 She hated how right she was.
 She hated that the truth burned worse than the fear.

She had built her life out of walls — sterile, precise, unbreachable.
 Walls that had kept her from drowning after Nicky.
 Walls that let her function, work, exist.
 But lately, those same walls had started to crack, and she knew exactly who had done it.

Rio.

She didn’t want to think about her, but the thought came anyway, uninvited and unrelenting.


 Rio’s voice in her ear that day she’d panicked, calm and grounding.


 The warmth of her hands.


 The sound of her laugh.


 The way she’d said her name like it was something soft and worth keeping.

You can’t afford to feel, the old voice in her head warned.
 Feeling is how you break.

But another voice, quieter — Lilia’s — whispered, Maybe breaking is how you heal.

Agatha pressed a trembling hand to her mouth, the emotion rising like a tide she couldn’t stop.

“God, Lils,” she murmured, voice hoarse. “You always know where to hit.”

Her eyes stung, but she didn’t wipe the tears away. She let them fall, hot and unguarded, landing on Lilia’s hand.

 For the first time, she didn’t swallow the ache back down. She let herself feel it... all of it.
 

The grief, the longing, the quiet, terrified hope.

And underneath all of that, the truth she’d been running from for weeks.

She wanted Rio.


 Not in passing.

Not in curiosity.


 She wanted her with the kind of clarity that made her heart ache — wanted to reach out and hold on to something real before life took it away again.

The sound of the door opening broke through the quiet.

“Hey,” Rio said softly from the doorway, her voice careful, respectful. “How is she?”

Agatha turned.

Rio stood bathed in the amber wash of the hallway light, her dark hair loose, curling slightly at the ends, her uniform traded for a plain grey T-shirt and jeans. The faint sheen of the day’s heat clung to her skin, and her eyes — those warm, steady eyes — found Agatha’s immediately.

Something in Agatha’s chest tightened and then unfurled all at once.

“She woke up, lectured me,” she managed. “Now shes resting.”

Rio’s shoulders eased. “Good. That’s good.” She stepped inside, voice softening. “You should sit down. You look exhausted. Have you—”

But the rest never came.

Because something in Agatha snapped or maybe it mended. 

She couldn’t tell the difference anymore. 


All she knew was that the space between them suddenly felt unbearable.

Before she could think, she was moving. Two steps, quick, certain - and then she was standing in front of Rio, her pulse pounding so loud it drowned out the world.

For half a second, Rio looked startled, her eyes wide, lips parting to speak but Agatha didn’t let her.
 Didn’t let logic win this time.
 Didn’t let fear decide for her.

 

She kissed her.

 

It was desperate at first, a collision of breath and heartbeat, of too many unspoken things finally finding their escape. 

But then it softened, deepened, turned into something tender and trembling.
 Rio’s hand came up to cradle the back of her neck, steady, grounding, while Agatha’s fingers curled into the fabric of her shirt, afraid that if she let go, the world might vanish again.

When they finally broke apart, they were both breathing hard.


 The world felt different, more sharp, clearer and so fucking alive.

Rio’s eyes searched hers, dazed and bright. “Agatha…”

Agatha swallowed, her voice raw. “I’ve spent so long being afraid to want anything.”

Rio didn’t speak. She just smiled, small, trembling, radiantt and leaned her forehead against Agatha’s.

For a long, fragile heartbeat, there was only silence. 

The hum of the machines, the whisper of their breath.

Then the monitor beside them let out a sharp beep-beep-beep, the rhythm suddenly quickening.

Agatha froze. Rio blinked, startled.

And from the bed behind them came a faint, raspy voice. 

“About damn time.”

Agatha’s head dropped against Rio’s shoulder with a low, incredulous laugh. 

“Of course,” she muttered, not turning around. “Lilia, if you don’t calm down, you’ll set your heart off again.”

There was a soft chuckle from the bed. 

“Sweetheart, after that show, it’s a miracle it’s still beating at all.”

Rio went crimson, stepping back just slightly, while Agatha groaned under her breath — half mortified, half amused.

She finally turned, one hand still brushing Rio’s arm. 

“You’re unbelievable.”

Lilia smiled weakly from her pillow, eyes gleaming. “And you’re finally human. Don’t you dare ruin it by pretending otherwise.”

The knock came without warning. Three sharp raps — the kind that made Agatha instinctively step back, guilt flashing across her face before the door even opened.

“Permission to enter?” came Chief Romanoff’s voice.

Agatha froze, realising too late that she was still holding onto Rio’s arm. Her fingers were wrapped just below her elbow, the faint heat of Rio’s skin still lingering against her palm. She dropped it as though it burned, straightened her coat, and tried to school her face into neutrality.

“Chief,” she said, voice an octave too high. She cleared her throat and tried again. “Chief Romanoff. I didn’t hear you knock.”

“Clearly,” Natasha said smoothly, stepping inside with that deceptively calm stride. 

Her gaze swept over the room, first to Lilia, propped up in bed with a smirk that could melt concrete, then to Agatha, pink-cheeked and fidgeting, and finally to Rio, whose expression sat somewhere between guilty and adorably clueless.

Natasha raised a brow. “Am I interrupting something?”

Lilia gave a slow, feline smile. “Just some oral examinations.”

Agatha’s head snapped toward her. “Lilia!”

“What?” Lilia’s tone was all innocence. “I almost died, sweetheart. I’m allowed to enjoy a little scandal on my recovery day.”

Rio coughed into her hand, her ears turning a deeper shade of red. “Uh—she was just—”

“Checking your pulse, perhaps?” Lilia supplied, grinning wickedly. “Don’t worry, dear, I approve.”

Agatha looked mortified. “Lilia, for the love of god—”

“Relax,” Natasha said dryly, cutting in before Agatha could combust. “I’ve walked into worse scenes. At least everyone’s fully clothed.”

Rio made a small, strangled sound that might have been a laugh. Agatha wanted the floor to open up and swallow her whole.

“Vitals are stable,” Natasha continued, checking the monitor like nothing was out of the ordinary. 

“Excellent recovery, Lilia. Though perhaps you should let Dr Harkness breathe before giving her a heart attack.”

“I was just giving her incentive,” Lilia said sweetly. “She looks better flustered. Don’t you think, Rio?”

Rio blinked. “I—uh—sure?”

“Wonderful,” Lilia sighed, sinking back against her pillow, looking far too pleased with herself. “Now someone take her home before she finds another excuse to hover. She hasn’t slept in thirty hours.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha muttered, still avoiding Rio’s eyes.

Rio’s voice was gentle. “I can drive her. Make sure she gets home.”

“Perfect!” Lilia declared instantly. “She accepts.”

“I haven’t said—” Agatha began, but Lilia wagged a finger.

“Ah-ah. Don’t ruin the moment, my girl. Take the ride. Who knows, maybe you’ll even—relax.”

The last word dripped with implication.

Agatha groaned into her hand. “Oh my...You are insufferable.”

“I’m alive,” Lilia countered, her grin pure mischief. “I intend to enjoy it. You should try that sometime.”

Agatha bent down, pressing a kiss to Lilia’s forehead to hide her smile. “Behave.”

“After the show you two just put on?” Lilia quipped, eyes glinting. “Not likely.”

Rio’s face went crimson. “I—I’ll just wait outside.”

“Good idea,” Natasha murmured.

Once Rio slipped out, Agatha exhaled, pinching the bridge of her nose. “I swear you do this on purpose.”

“Oh, absolutely,” Lilia said serenely.

Agatha rolled her eyes, grabbed her bag, and turned toward the door. “Don’t be distracting the nurses while I’m gone.”

Lilia winked. “Go get your firefighter, sweetheart.”

The door closed behind Agatha just as Natasha turned to Lilia, one brow raised. “What exactly did I just walk into?”

Lilia smiled, utterly unapologetic. “A long time coming.”

Natasha snorted softly, shaking her head. “I’m not even going to ask.”

From the hallway came Agatha’s muffled voice, equal parts exasperated and flustered. “I can still fucking hear you!”

Lilia chuckled, leaning back against the pillow with a satisfied sigh. “Good,” she murmured. “Maybe this time she’ll finally listen.”

Chapter End Notes

Finally 🙌🏻

Chapter 10

Chapter Notes

Shoutout to Advilrio who taught me how to code, was planning to implement some cute text message bubble formatting in this chapter but I will need A LOT more practice before posting it!

Anyway here's a short update, I have most of next chapter done too so that might also be up this weekend after I tweak certain parts but there will be a lot more fluff in the next few chapter... yay!

The morning light spilled softly through the hospital corridors, brushing everything in a pale, forgiving gold. The ER was just beginning to hum with life with the shuffling of nurses changing shifts, the low murmur of voices, the faint scent of coffee and antiseptic.

Agatha moved through it all with quiet purpose, a small paper bag in hand. She greeted no one, but there was a subtle difference in her stride and a looseness to her shoulders, a softness in the set of her mouth that hadn’t been there before.

When she reached Lilia’s room, she paused briefly at the door, composed herself, and stepped inside.

Lilia was awake, propped up against her pillows, the morning news murmuring faintly on the television. 

She turned her head immediately, eyes bright and far too knowing. “Well, look at you,” she said, voice still rough from sleep but rich with amusement. “You’re practically glowing.”

Agatha raised an eyebrow as she set the paper bag down on the tray table. “Good morning to you too.”

“Mmm,” Lilia hummed, eyeing her like a cat eyeing a secret. “Brought offerings, did you?”

“An almond croissant,” Agatha said, sitting at her bedside. “From that bakery you like. I thought you might appreciate something other than hospital oatmeal.”

“Oh, I appreciate it,” Lilia said, tearing off a small piece. “But I’m more interested in the reason behind the good mood that delivered it.”

Agatha blinked innocently. “Reason?”

Lilia chuckled. “You can drop the act, sweetheart. I was there when you practically tackled that poor girl with your lips.”

Agatha froze mid–sip of coffee, colour creeping high on her cheeks. “Lilia.”

“What? I might’ve been half-dead, but my eyesight works just fine,” Lilia said, biting into her croissant.
 “And for the record, that was the best entertainment I’ve had in months.”

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose, exhaling slowly. “You’re insufferable.”

“Maybe,” Lilia said through a smile. “But I’m right.” She nodded toward Agatha’s flushed face. “I haven’t seen that look on you in years. You used to walk around like the world owed you grief. Now look at you — soft around the edges. Practically human.”

Agatha shot her a look. “I am human.”

“Barely,” Lilia teased. Then her tone gentled. “Don’t go hiding behind that mask again. You’ve been keeping people out so long you’ve forgotten what it’s like to let someone in.”

Agatha busied herself straightening Lilia’s blankets, trying for composure. “You make it sound so simple.”

“It’s not,” Lilia said softly. “But neither is living alone in your own head. You’ve done that long enough, my girl. And if Rio makes you smile like this…” She gestured toward Agatha’s faintly blushing face. “Then maybe it’s time you stop pretending you don’t care.”

Agatha looked down at the floor, throat tightening despite herself. “I don’t know how to do this anymore, Lils. Not after…”

“Nicky?”

Agatha nodded, barely.

Lilia reached out, taking her hand with a slow squeeze. “Then let her teach you. You don’t need to have all the answers. You just need to let yourself feel.”

For a long moment, the only sound in the room was the steady beep of the monitor and the distant murmur of morning rounds beginning outside.

Then Agatha exhaled, the smallest smile touching her lips. “Eat your croissant before it goes stale,” she said softly.

Lilia grinned. “Deflection noted. But it won’t save you. I expect details later.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, standing to go. “You’re nosey.”

“Maybe,” Lilia said, leaning back with a satisfied hum. “But you, my dear, are finally happy again.”

Agatha stopped at the doorway, fighting the smile tugging at her lips but ultimately lost. “Rest, Lils. I’ll be back to check on you before lunch.”

Her morning began like every other, rounds, charts, and the low hum of hospital machinery filling the air. 

Everything should have felt familiar. 

Routine. 

Controlled.

But something was different.

Her steps were lighter. Her shoulders less tense. There was a small, almost imperceptible curve to her mouth that she wasn’t aware of until people began to notice.

The first was Billy. He caught up with her outside a patient’s room, walking briskly to match her pace.

“Morning, Doctor Harkness,” he said with too much cheer. “You seem… different today.”

Agatha didn’t look up from the chart she was signing. “Different how?”

Billy hesitated, suddenly less confident. “I don’t know. Happier? You’re walking like someone who got at least six hours of sleep. Maybe even seven.”

Her pen stilled mid-line. Slowly, she raised her gaze to him, one brow arching in warning. “Are you implying I looked miserable before?”

Billy blanched. “No, no! You just seem… less terrifying this morning?”

She regarded him for a long, silent moment before replying in her calmest voice. “Go recheck your notes, Teen. Before I find you scut work.”

He left in a hurry.

For a while, things went smoothly again. Agatha moved through the ER with her usual precision, determined to ignore the faint ripple of warmth that had followed her since the night before. 

But it was there, stubborn and quiet. Every time she caught her reflection in the glass of the nurses’ station, she looked… softer. And it unsettled her more than she cared to admit.

Wanda found her next, leaning over the counter with a patient chart in hand. “You’re humming,” she said casually.

Agatha frowned. “I’m what?”

“Humming,” Wanda repeated, pretending to study her clipboard. “In the corridor. Teen swears he heard it too.”

“That’s ridiculous,” Agatha said, her tone flat. “I don’t hum.”

Wanda smiled, not looking up. “You also don’t smile at lab results, but you did that five minutes ago.”

Agatha rolled her eyes. “You should really find a hobby, Maximoff. Something that doesn’t involve stalking your colleagues.”

“I’ll get right on that,” Wanda said, clearly amused, before disappearing down the hall.

Agatha took a slow breath, her jaw tightening. It was fine. Everything was fine. People were simply bored. That was all.

Until Jen appeared.

She arrived at the nurses’ station with a coffee in hand and that infuriating smirk that always meant trouble. “You know,” she began conversationally, “word around the ER is that Doctor Harkness has developed an actual mood. It’s throwing everyone off balance.”

Agatha didn’t even look up. “Jen.”

“Maybe it’s the weather,” Jen continued, feigning thoughtfulness. “Or maybe it’s got something to do with a certain firefighter who’s been mentioned around here lately.”

Agatha’s grip on her pen tightened. “Jen,” she said again, more sharply this time.

Jen only grinned wider. “What? I’m just saying—if you’ve finally found someone capable of making you smile, the rest of us owe them a thank-you gift.”

Agatha lifted her eyes, expression cool and perfectly measured. “If you don’t leave right now, I’ll have you reassigned to the overnight chart audit for the next week.”

Jen raised her hands in mock surrender, still grinning. “There’s the ice queen I know and fear.”

By the time she walked off, humming under her breath, Agatha could feel the last traces of her earlier lightness draining away. The lines of her face sharpened again; her tone turned crisp, clipped, untouchable.

She told herself it was better this way. Better to keep her guard up. Better to be the version of herself no one dared to pry into.
