But as she moved on to her next patient, the faint memory of Rio’s smile flickered unbidden in her mind, softening her for just a heartbeat before she forced it down again.

By the time Agatha reached Lilia’s room again, her mood had curdled into irritation. The hospital was loud with its usual chaos—ringing phones, the squeak of gurney wheels, the relentless chatter of nurses. 

She was halfway through composing a sharp note about a missed lab order when she looked up and froze.

Rio was there.

She stood at Lilia’s bedside, hair pulled into a tight low bun, the navy of her fire-crew shirt dark against her skin. Cargo pants, scuffed boots, sleeves rolled high enough to show the strong lines of her forearms. 

There was a faint flush on her cheeks, a shy, uncertain grin playing at her mouth, the kind of expression that made something in Agatha’s chest lurch before she could stop it.

On the tray table sat a thermos and a small container, steam curling lazily upward.

Lilia was eating, looking far too pleased for someone in recovery. “You just missed your competition, Agatha,” she said. “Turns out my lunch today was made with actual care.”

Rio looked up quickly, the grin faltering for just a moment. “Hi,” she said, quieter now. “Agatha.”

Agatha’s heartbeat stumbled, but she recovered fast. “Rio.”

It was the first time they’d seen each other since last night—since their second kiss, since she’d agreed to the date Rio promised to plan. And now here she was, in her uniform, smeiling at her like she was the stars and the moon.

Agatha forced herself to move, to speak, to sound like herself. “You’re cooking now?”

Rio’s shy grin deepened a little, her fingers fidgeting with the thermos cap. 

“Always have. My abuela taught me. She said if you love someone, you learn to feed them.” Her voice softened. “She passed a few years ago, but I still cook like she’s watching over my shoulder.”

Lilia smiled around her spoon. “Well, your abuela knew what she was doing. This might be the only real food I’ve had since I checked in.”

Agatha folded her arms, trying not to show how her chest ached at the gentleness in Rio’s voice. “You didn’t have to bring food.”

Rio shook her head. “Lilia’s fed half the fire crew over the years. Figured it was time we returned the favour.”

Lilia’s eyes flicked between them, full of quiet amusement. “And here I thought you were just being sweet on me. But it’s really you just wanted to see the pretty doctor.”

Agatha’s look could’ve sliced steel. “Lilia.”

“What? I’m just saying—you seem lighter this morning, that’s all. Like someone finally reminded you there’s life outside of this building.”

Rio ducked her head, smile flickering, colour rising in her cheeks. “Guess I picked a good day to stop by, then.”

Agatha’s voice softened before she could stop it. “You did.”

They held each other’s gaze a second too long, the rest of the world falling into hush. Then Agatha cleared her throat and turned brisk again. “Lilia’s recovering well. Try not to spoil her or she’ll start expecting room service.”

“I’ll keep it simple next time,” Rio said, still a little pink, but steadier now. “Just thought she could use something warm.”

“She appreciates it,” Agatha said, but it came out quieter than she meant.

Lilia set her spoon down with a clink. “And so do I. Now, unless you two plan on turning this room into a staring contest, I’m going to finish my lunch.”

Rio laughed quietly and wiped her palms on her jeans. “Alright. I’ll give you two some space.”

Agatha tried to answer with something polished and professional, but all that came out was a soft “Alright,” that sounded far too gentle.

Rio’s smile pulled at her mouth, small and a little uncertain, like she was trying not to show how nervous she felt. “I’ll come back later,” she said to Lilia. Her eyes drifted back to Agatha for a lingering moment. 

“Try not to work too hard.”

The words were simple, but something in her tone caught Agatha completely off guard. It was kind. Warm. Almost hopeful, as if she wanted it to matter.

Rio left before either of them could make the moment any heavier. The faint scent of smoked paprika stayed behind, settling into the room like a reminder of her presence.

Agatha did not move for several seconds. Her pulse raced beneath her skin, sharp and insistent, as if the air still held Rio’s warmth.

Lilia watched her with a knowing smile. “She’s good for you,” she murmured.

Agatha exhaled, composing herself. “She’s… distracting.”

Lilia chuckled. “You say that like it’s a bad thing.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the smallest smile betrayed her. “Eat your soup, Lils.”

“Gladly,” Lilia said, dipping her spoon again. “Best thing I’ve eaten all week.”

Agatha turned to leave, pretending not to notice that her hands were still shaking.

Agatha made it halfway down the hall before she realised she wasn’t breathing properly. Her pulse was still pounding, echoing in her ears, and she hated that it felt… pleasant.

She told herself she was just tired. Just overstimulated. Just—
“Agatha!”
The sound of her name made her stop short.

Rio was jogging toward her from the elevator, the soft scuff of her boots against the linoleum somehow louder than the entire ward. She looked even more endearing up close—a stray strand of hair slipping free from her bun, an anxious little crease between her brows.

Agatha turned, hands folding neatly behind her back, every line of her posture composed even as her heartbeat stumbled. “Forget something?”

Rio came to a stop in front of her, clearly a little breathless but smiling anyway. “Yeah. I mean—yes. Kind of.”

Agatha’s eyebrow lifted. “Kind of?”

Rio rubbed the back of her neck, eyes darting briefly away before meeting hers again. “I, uh… realised I don’t actually have your number.”

Agatha blinked. “My number.”

“Yeah,” Rio said quickly, then tripped over her own explanation. “You know, for… professional reasons.”

“Professional?”

Rio nodded solemnly, though her ears were going pink. “Well, I’m planning this date and, uh—there are things I might need to consult you on. Allergies. Dress codes. Wine pairings. Things you consider fun and things you don’t.” She was rambling now… adorable.

Agatha’s lips parted, a laugh threatening to escape before she bit it back. “You want my number… so you can seek professional guidance in dating me?”

Rio winced, grinning helplessly. “When you say it like that, it sounds worse.”

“It sounds absurd,” Agatha said, though her voice had softened, her eyes glittering with barely contained amusement.

“Maybe,” Rio said, shifting her weight. “But if it gets me your number, I’ll take the hit.”

For a moment, Agatha could only stare at her—the boldness wrapped in awkwardness, the shy confidence that made her stomach twist in ways she didn’t care to name.

She exhaled through her nose, held out her slightly trembling hand. “Give me yours.”

Rio blinked, startled. “Oh. Uh—yeah, right.” She fumbled for her phone, nearly dropping it in the process, and Agatha bit back another smile as she took it, tapped in her number, and handed it back.

“There,” she said smoothly. “For emergencies. Medical or otherwise.”

Rio looked down at the screen, and her smile broke wide and honest before she could stop it. “You saved yourself in my contacts as Doctor Harkness?”

Agatha’s brow lifted. “I am a doctor.”

“Yeah, but you could’ve just put Agatha.”

“I could have,” she said evenly, folding her arms, “but I suspect you’d find a way to make that sound familiar.”

Rio grinned, eyes bright with mischief. “Maybe. But I think Agatha suits you better when I say it out loud.”

For a second, the air between them shifted—something quiet and charged humming beneath the fluorescent lights.

Agatha exhaled slowly, turning half away to hide the smile threatening to surface. “You really don’t know when to stop, do you?”

Rio laughed softly, a little breathless. “Not really, no.”

Agatha reached out her hand again. “Give me the phone.”

Rio blinked, confused but obedient. “Uh… okay?”

Agatha took it, her expression unreadable as her thumb moved with deliberate precision. She changed the contact name, then handed the phone back without a word.

Rio looked down.
Agatha 💜

Rio’s smile grew, softer than before. “It’s perfect.”

Agatha looked anywhere but at her, pulse thrumming. “Try not to lose your phone,” she murmured. “I don’t intend to enter my number a third time.”

“I won’t,” Rio said, grin softening into something almost tender. “I’ll text you later.”

Agatha tilted her head, the faintest smile tugging at her lips. “I’ll look forward to the consultation.”

Rio’s grin widened, cheeks pink again. “You do that, Doctor.”

The elevator doors opened, and she stepped inside, giving a small, uncertain wave as they began to close. Agatha stood there for a moment longer than she should have, the corners of her mouth curving despite herself.

When she finally turned to go, her reflection in the glass caught her off guard—her expression softer than she’d seen in years.

She muttered under her breath, “Stop smiling like a fool,” and walked off with her heart thrumming like it had just remembered how to beat.


The hospital was silent in that particular way it only settled into after midnight. The lights were dim, the corridors muted, the air heavy with antiseptic and sleep. Most of the staff were gone. The few who remained moved in soft, tired rhythms.

Agatha sat alone in her office, the glow of her computer casting blue shadows across her desk. She had stayed late, catching up on the cases she had missed during the days she spent planted at Lilia’s bedside. 

Her notes were half-finished, charts still open, the cursor blinking patiently on an untouched paragraph.
Her phone rested face down beside the keyboard.

She wasn’t waiting for anything.

She was working.

Still, when it buzzed, she reached for it before she could pretend otherwise.

A new message blinked onto the screen

Rio: Hey. It’s Rio. Just making sure this is you and not… the morgue.

Agatha smiled, unable to help herself. She leaned back in her chair, fingers tapping against the glass.

Agatha: You’d be surprised how often I get mistaken for a dead person.

There was a pause long enough for her to imagine Rio on the other end, staring at her phone, overthinking every word. Then—

Rio: So it is you. Sorry if it’s late. I just… didn’t want you to think I wasn’t going to text.

Agatha: I hadn’t given it much thought.

That was a blatant lie.

Another pause.

Rio: Okay, that’s fair. I’m just not great at this part.

Agatha tilted her head, intrigued despite herself.

Agatha: Texting?

Rio: Yeah. I get nervous. People usually say the wrong thing when they’re face to face. I say the wrong thing when there’s typing involved.

Agatha laughed quietly under her breath, the sound soft in the still room. She could see her — that shy grin, the way her shoulders probably hunched a little as she hit send.

Agatha: Funny. Most people get bolder when there’s a screen between them. You seem to have the opposite problem.

Rio: Yeah, I guess I used up all my bravery in person.

Agatha: I hadn’t noticed you were lacking any.

There was a delay this time — longer than before. Then, the reply came through

Rio: Maybe it only works when you’re looking at me.

Agatha froze, caught entirely off guard by the honesty tucked inside the shyness. Then, slowly, she smiled.

Agatha: Careful. That almost sounded like confidence.

Rio: Almost.

Agatha set the phone down, still smiling, a soft warmth blooming low in her chest. Rio was, to her continued astonishment, adorable.
 Not in the way most people tried to be. There was no pretence. Just quiet nerves, sincerity, and that same gentle humour that had slipped past Agatha’s defences since the very first night.

Her phone buzzed again.

Rio: I’ll stop bothering you now. Just wanted to say… goodnight Agatha 🖤.

Agatha’s thumb hovered above the screen for a long moment. Then she typed,

Agatha: You’re not bothering me, Rio. Goodnight.

She locked her phone, leaned back, and stared at the ceiling with an expression she couldn’t quite contain — the faintest, secret smile curving her lips.

For someone who claimed to be bad at texting, Rio had managed to make silence feel like company.

Chapter 11

The morning light was too bright for how little sleep she’d had.

Agatha sat in her usual corner of the hospital cafeteria, a cup of bitter coffee cooling between her hands, her tablet open to the day’s patient roster — unread. The hospital hummed softly around her, nurses in motion, the faint buzz of vending machines.

Her phone rested beside her tray. She wasn’t looking at it. Not really.

Except she was — every few minutes, catching her reflection in the dark screen, remembering the thread of shy, stumbling messages from the night before. Rio, with her awkward honesty and hesitant humour, who somehow made the quiet hours feel less empty.

I get nervous… I guess I used up all my bravery in person.
 Agatha’s lips curved before she could stop them. She took a sip of coffee to hide it.

“Okay,” said a voice, full of suspicion and caffeine deprivation. “What’s that smile?”

Agatha didn’t need to look up to know who it was. Jen slid into the seat across from her, balancing her own coffee and a bagel like a detective closing in on a confession.

“I wasn’t smiling,” Agatha said smoothly.

“You were absolutely smiling.” Jen tore off a piece of bagel, watching her with open amusement. “It’s kind of eerie, actually. I almost didn’t recognise you without the permanent scowl.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “Do you ambush all your colleagues before rounds, or just me?”

“Only the ones with scandalous secrets,” Jen said, leaning forward conspiratorially. “Funny thing — Alice mentioned this morning that Rio’s been smiling nonstop since the other day. Wouldn’t happen to know anything about that, would you?”

Agatha’s head snapped up, faster than she meant. “Excuse me?”

Jen grinned. “Oh, come on. You and Firefighter Sunshine think you’re subtle? Alice lives with her. I’m fucking Alice. You do the math.”

Agatha inhaled sharply through her nose. “I don’t appreciate being the subject of pillow talk.”

“Oh, please.” Jen waved a hand. “I’m not judging. I’m thrilled. Maybe you’ll finally get laid and do us all a favour.”

Agatha froze mid-sip of coffee. “Excuse me?”

Jen’s grin widened. “You know what I mean. You’ve been wound so tight these past few months, we were starting to worry you’d calcify.”

“Jen,” Agatha said, voice low and dangerous.

Jen only laughed, standing with her tray. “Relax. I’m just happy for you, Agatha. She seems good for you.”

When Jen walked away, Agatha stayed perfectly still. Her pulse, however, had betrayed her composure entirely.

The words get laid echoed far too vividly.
 She tried to shove them aside — to focus on anything else — but her mind betrayed her, unspooling an image she hadn’t meant to conjure.

Rio — the warmth of her hands, the solid strength of her forearms, the way her voice softened when she said Agatha’s name.
 The thought of that tenderness directed at her was dizzying. Unnerving. And, if she was honest, terrifyingly enticing.

She set her coffee down with deliberate care, aware that her fingers weren’t as steady as usual.
Ridiculous. Absolutely ridiculous.

And yet—
Her phone buzzed.
She looked down.

Rio: Morning, Agatha. I hope you didn’t stay at the hospital too late last night. I hear coffee helps. 

Agatha felt a slow smile tugging at her mouth.

Agatha: My patients will be relieved to know you are monitoring my caffeine intake with such dedication.

A pause. Long enough for Agatha to wonder if Rio had gotten shy again.

Then the messages came in a quick scatter.

Rio: So… Alice saw me smiling at my phone again.
 Rio: She asked if it was you.
 Rio: And I said yes.

Another rushed string followed almost instantly
Rio: Shit. Is that okay?

 Rio: I didn’t think about it before I said it.

 Rio: I can tell her it was nothing if you want.

 Rio: Or that I was joking.

 Rio: If you’d rather keep this quiet…

Agatha let out a quiet breath, her chest warming at the anxious honesty in those messages.

She answered steadily.

Agatha: Rio, we both know keeping anything a secret in this town is impossible.

Another message.

Agatha: And I am not ashamed.

The pause afterward wasn’t nervous. It felt relieved.

Rio: Okay.

 Rio: Good. I’m really glad.

Another bubble appeared, slower this time.

Rio: So… about that date we never finished talking about…

A beat.

Rio: What are your thoughts on carnival rides?

Agatha blinked at the screen.

Her first instinct was confusion, her second a pinch of something deeper, something she usually kept tucked behind layers of poise and sarcasm. Carnival rides. She had no frame of reference. None at all.
Before she could type, a memory rose up sharp and clear, the kind that lived in the bones rather than the mind.

She was eight. Small, hopeful, the sleeves of her dress a little too long. She remembered the way the traveling carnival had lit up the edge of town like a constellation dropped too close to earth. She’d tugged on her mother’s sleeve, trying to be brave, trying not to sound too eager.

“Can we go? Just for a little while?”

Evanora had looked down at her with a slow, bored blink, a curl of amusement at the corner of her mouth—amusement that never meant anything kind.

“Really, Agatha, I do not have time to indulge childish fantasies. Those things are filthy. Loud. A waste of money. You wouldn’t enjoy it. You never enjoy anything.”

Then the drawling laugh. The dismissive wave of a hand that dismissed the child along with the question.
And that had been that.

The closest Agatha had ever gotten to a carnival ride was watching the ferris wheel turn from her bedroom window, each spin a reminder that she was on the outside of something she wasn’t meant to touch.

She stared down at the phone in her hand now, realising with a strange, twisting feeling that she had grown into someone who never questioned that. Someone who never even tried.

God, she thought, Rio is going to think I’m a strange, fucking repressed Victorian relic who cannot experience fun.

She typed before she could overthink it.

Agatha: I have no thoughts on carnival rides. I have never been on one.

Her thumb hovered over the send button for a moment, humiliation warming her cheeks in a way she hated before she pressed it anyway.

The typing bubble flickered, then steadied. Rio was thinking. Carefully. Then the message arrived.

Rio: You’ve never been on one?
Rio: That just means I get to be the first person to take you. 

Rio: Honestly… that sounds kind of perfect.

Agatha felt a small jolt in her chest.

Another message appeared almost immediately, softer and impossibly sincere.

Rio: I’d really like to fix that for you.

 Rio: I mean, only if you want me to, though.

The sincerity in it, light, hopeful, entirely without judgment or questions, hit her in a place she did not usually allow anyone near. She was seated in the quiet corner of the cafeteria, half-finished coffee cooling beside her. The hum of distant conversation filled the room, but her world narrowed to the glow of her phone.

A laugh slipped out of her. Soft. Completely genuine. Absolutely not something she ever allowed in public.

She froze.

Her eyes darted up, scanning the room. Two nurses discussing meal prep. A janitor pushing a cart. A resident she vaguely disliked inhaling soup like it was a competitive sport.

No one looked her way.

She exhaled, a hand briefly covering her mouth in disbelief at herself.

She typed back, attempting to regain some semblance of dignity.

Agatha: You are very strange.
 Agatha: And very persistent.

Rio must have been holding her phone because the reply arrived instantly.

Rio: I know. 

Rio: But you smiled, didn’t you?

Agatha stared at the message, her cheeks warming.

She had.

 And she already knew Rio would take far too much joy in that fact.

Agatha tapped her fingers lightly against her cup, the warmth from Rio’s last message still lingering under her skin. She straightened a little, smoothing her expression before she typed back.

Agatha: I smile at many things, Rio. You are simply very determined to take credit for all of them.
 Agatha: Now tell me… when exactly do you plan on taking me on this carnival date?

The typing bubble appeared almost immediately, jittery and uncertain.

Rio: Um… I was hoping you’d tell me when you’re free.
 Rio: Because I… cant wait to see you again.

Agatha felt the edges of her mouth lift. Just slightly. She checked her schedule, though she already knew the answer.

Agatha: Tomorrow night. Thursday.
 Agatha: After that my shifts turn ridiculous, so it’s the only window I have.

A beat. Then several messages from Rio in quick succession-

Rio: Tomorrow works. 

Rio: Actually that’s perfect.

 Rio: I can switch some things around.

Agatha’s brows lifted, a flicker of surprise warming her chest despite herself.

Agatha: You would rearrange your schedule?

Rio: Absolutely, Bucky owes me one.

Rio: I’ll pick you up from Lilia’s at 7. 

Rio: And… dress warm.

Agatha stared at her phone for a moment, her pulse giving a quiet, traitorous skip at the certainty in that message. She softened her posture before she even realised she was doing it.

She typed back, teasing but gentle.

Agatha: Should I be concerned about what “dress warm” implies?

 Agatha: Please reassure me you are not planning anything that involves frostbite.

Rio’s reply came quickly, and Agatha could almost picture her shy smile.

Rio: No frostbite. 

Rio: I promise you’ll be warm. 

Rio: And safe. 

Rio: With me.

Agatha’s breath caught slightly.
 A softness bloomed low in her stomach before she forced her expression neutral again, glancing around the cafeteria to make sure no one was watching her soften like this.

Agatha: Then I suppose… I will see you at 7.

Rio: Can’t wait.

Agatha set her phone down, letting herself feel that warmth for one quiet moment before schooling her face back to calm.

Tomorrow suddenly could not come fast enough.

The rest of Agatha’s shift passed in a blur she tried not to blame entirely on the firefighter who had somehow asked her out on a date involving “dressing warm.”

After finishing her rounds, she stopped in to check on Lilia. She intended a brief update, nothing dramatic, merely an objective report that her evening plans had… changed.

She barely managed, “I’m seeing Rio tomorrow night,” before Lilia practically launched upright.

“A date!? Agatha, oh I’m so pleased.”

“You are recovering from a heart attacj,” Agatha scolded, placing a firm hand on her shoulder. “Lie back down before I sedate you.”

Lilia did not lie down. She squealed. At full volume.

Agatha had to press her down again, gently but with authority, muttering, “Absolutely unhinged,” under her breath.

Lilia only grinned up at her, glowing with delighted mischief.

When Agatha returned to the floor, her composure was back in place… mostly. Her tone was sharp enough to maintain order, yet softened enough that people noticed.

Wanda passed her in the hall, eyes narrowing with amused suspicion.

Jen caught her at the nurses’ station, looked her up and down, and simply said, “Huh.”

Agatha frowned. “Explain that noise.”

Jen grinned. “Nope. I want to see how long you pretend today is normal.”

Agatha huffed and pivoted sharply, which only made Jen laugh harder.

And then, suddenly, it was the next day.

Her day off.

Which should have been peaceful, restorative, a much-needed reprieve.

Instead, Agatha woke at dawn, pulse already thrumming like she’d run a marathon in her sleep. She showered. Then showered again because the first one didn’t feel strategic enough. 

She shaved her legs. 

Then shaved them again, in case she had somehow grown new hair in the last ten minutes.

She stood in her bedroom changing outfits like she was preparing for a diplomatic summit rather than a date with a woman whose idea of a good time involved climbing burning buildings for fun.

By midmorning she was sitting on the edge of her bed in a robe, towel around her head, staring at her reflection as if it held answers to universal truths.

It did not.

Her stomach fluttered traitorously.

Tonight at seven, Rio— the firefighter who made her laugh and blush and feel young in ways she had forgotten—
was coming to pick her up from Lilia’s.

Dress warm.

Agatha groaned into her hands.

“What am I doing?”

She was Dr Agatha Harkness.
 She had conquered medical school, residency, night shifts, grumpy patients, even Lilia on pain meds.
She could survive one date.
…probably.

She hoped.

For a long moment, she didn’t move.

The swelling excitement she’d woken with had thinned into something quieter. Rawer.

A knot of doubt tightened in her chest.

What on earth was Rio doing with someone like her?

Rio was… Rio.

Sweet in that earnest, uncalculated way Agatha had never learned to be.
 Caring to a fault.
 Emotionally stable in a way that made Agatha feel both envious and unworthy.
 Steady hands. Warm eyes. A softness that didn’t make her weak but made her magnetic.

And, of course, infuriatingly attractive.
 Agatha had tried not to dwell on that part, but her mind insisted on replaying the image of Rio leaning against the doorframe of Lilia’s room, cheeks flushed, smile shy, muscles shifting under her turnout shirt.

She scrubbed both hands over her face.

She’s a firefighter. She runs into burning buildings. She saves people. She is steady and warm and good.

Agatha swallowed hard.

And I am… damaged goods.

She didn’t use the phrase lightly. It was simply what she believed about herself in the moments when her armour slipped. Years of holding everything together by force. Years of being told she was cold, difficult, too much, not enough, impossible to love. Old scars carved into the quiet places of her.

Of course Rio wouldn’t see it yet.
 No one saw the fractures at first.

Agatha looked at her own reflection as if she could argue with her own face.

Why would she want someone whose idea of a childhood treat was watching other children ride a ferris wheel because her mother couldn’t be bothered?
Why would she want someone who doesn’t know how to have fun without analyzing the risk factors?
Why would she want someone who has spent their entire adult life convincing everyone she didn’t need anything from anyone?

Her breath came out thin.

It was ridiculous, she knew.
 She was a grown woman. A competent one. A desirable one, on her good days.

But Rio made her feel… exposed.

She pressed her fingertips to her temple, closing her eyes.

What if I ruin this? 

What if she realizes I’m not soft enough?

 What if she sees every broken corner I try so hard to hide?

Her chest tightened, just for a moment, fear curling under her ribs.

Then she inhaled, slow and deliberate, grounding herself the way she had learned over decades of surviving her own history.

She opened her eyes and met her reflection again.
It didn’t magically fix the doubt.
But it steadied her enough to remember one truth she couldn’t quite shake:
Rio had asked her out anyway. Not someone else.
 Her.
And Rio didn’t strike her as the type to chase things she didn’t actually want.

Rio had been the first person in years—maybe longer—to see past Agatha’s armour.

Not the polished version she presented at work. Not the sharp-tongued, controlled, unshakeable doctor. Not the woman who always had an answer ready and a wall firmly in place.

Rio had looked at her and seen something else entirely.

She had seen Agatha when she cracked.

Not just once.
 Not just in a moment of weakness that could be brushed off or excused.

Agatha remembered the night vividly—the night she’d stood in the on call room, the night the façade slipped. She had tried to hide it, jaw clenched, shoulders rigid, but Rio had stepped close, slow and careful, as if approaching a wounded animal.

Rio had simply said, “You don’t have to pretend with me.”

And Agatha, to her own shock, hadn’t snapped back.
 She hadn’t barked, deflected, or laughed coldly.
 She had just… breathed.
 And Rio had stayed. Quiet and steady. A presence rather than a demand.

Most people saw Agatha’s sharpness and assumed it was all she was.
 Rio saw the sharpness and understood there were soft parts underneath it, bruised and hidden but still there.

No one had done that for her in a long time.

What is it about you, Agatha thought, that makes me soften even when I don’t mean to?

Because around Rio she did soften.
 In these small, inconvenient ways she pretended not to notice.

Little smiles she didn’t restrain fast enough.
 Sarcasm delivered without real bite.
 A warmth in her voice she hadn’t used in years.
 A feeling—unfamiliar and terrifying—that she could actually be… happy.

Rio didn’t push her. She didn’t demand the softness. She simply created space where it felt safe to exist.

And somehow Agatha had stepped into that space without realising she’d moved.

The thought was dizzying.

She looked at herself in the mirror again, eyes softer than before, and whispered under her breath, almost as if she needed to hear it spoken aloud,

“She sees me.”

It wasn’t a declaration.

 More a realisation.

A fragile one, but real.
And tonight, for reasons she couldn’t fully articulate, she wanted to be seen.

Agatha inhaled slowly, grounding herself, and pushed away from the edge of the bed. 

Enough spiralling. She had a date to get ready for.

She crossed to the wardrobe and opened it with purpose, even if her heart still fluttered. A glass of white wine steadied her hand—a crisp Sauvignon Blanc she poured into one of her nicer glasses. She took a slow sip, feeling the chill spread calm through her chest.

She surveyed her clothing with the intensity of someone awaiting judgment.

Nothing too formal. 

Nothing too clinical.

 Nothing that screamed I am terrified please hold my hand.

She reached for a soft knit cream sweater, the kind that skimmed her waist and hinted at shape without being overt. Feminine, warm, a little romantic. It felt… right.

Next, she chose a flowing navy skirt that brushed her calves, airy enough for summer but made of a heavier fabric that would hold warmth once the sun dipped. She paired it with low-heeled boots—practical, stylish, unlikely to get ruined by whatever mysterious “dress warm” activity Rio had planned.

She sipped her wine again, set the glass down, and moved to the mirror.

Her hair required coaxing. Not too much—just enough to look intentional. She let it fall in loose waves around her shoulders, tamed but still soft. She considered pinning it back, then decided she wanted it down. Rio liked it down.

Makeup came next. Nothing dramatic. A sweep of soft brown shadow, a hint of eyeliner to define her eyes, mascara to lift her lashes. A pink-nude lipstick that looked natural but not effortless—nothing about this was effortless.

She stepped back and looked at herself fully dressed.

Softer. Warm. Put-together. Human.

She felt her heartbeat pick up, but it wasn’t fear this time—it was anticipation. A rare, startling flicker of excitement.

Agatha exhaled, smoothing down her skirt.

She looked like someone going on a date.

And for the first time all day, she let herself believe she could enjoy it.


Rio arrived exactly on time.

Agatha heard the low rumble of the engine before she saw anything, a deep, steady sound that vibrated faintly through the quiet street outside Lilia’s house. She stepped toward the front window, feeling suddenly, absurdly sixteen, and peeked out.

Rio’s black pickup was parked at the curb. Cleaned. Polished. She had definitely spent time on it.

Then Rio stepped out.

And Agatha’s breath caught.

She had clearly made an effort. It was subtle, but unmistakable. Her dark jeans were new or nearly so, fitted in a way that left very little to Agatha’s imagination. She wore a charcoal Henley beneath a soft black fitted jacket. The look was more masculine than Agatha’s own elegance, but in a way that complimented rather than contrasted. Strong lines, soft expression.

Her hair was down, curling slightly just above her shoulders. Her boots were polished. Her posture—straight-backed but uncertain—made something in Agatha’s chest twist.

Then Rio pulled something from the passenger seat.

Flowers.

A small bouquet, wild-looking and mismatched in the most charming way: sunflowers, small white blossoms, eucalyptus. All tied with a piece of twine, clearly done by hand.

Agatha swallowed.

Fuck, that’s adorable.

Rio approached the door with the careful steps of someone preparing to approach a wild creature—slow, respectful, nervous. She glanced at herself in the small window of the door, then immediately regretted it, brushing her palms on her thighs.

She knocked.

Agatha opened the door before she could talk herself out of it.

Rio froze.
 Her eyes widened, dragged slowly from Agatha’s boots to her skirt, to the soft cream sweater hugging her waist, and finally to her hair falling loose around her shoulders.

“Wow,” Rio breathed, the word slipping out before she could catch it. Her cheeks flushed. “I mean—sorry. I meant… you look…” She swallowed, then whispered the end. “Beautiful.”

Agatha’s stomach fluttered, but she kept her voice controlled, warm but not too warm. “Thank you. And you look… presentable.”

Rio blinked. “Presentable?”

A teasing smile pulled at Agatha’s lips as she rolled her eyes. “Oh come on, we both know you look hot.”

Rio laughed nervously, shifting the bouquet forward. “These are for you. I didn’t know what flowers you liked, so I just picked the ones I thought looked good.”

Agatha stared at them for half a heartbeat too long.

“They’re lovely,” she said softly. “Thank you.”

Rio let out a quiet breath, relief loosening her shoulders. “Good. I wasn’t sure if people still… did that.”

“Some do,” Agatha said, brushing her thumb lightly against a sunflower petal. “And it’s sweet.”

Rio beamed—shy but so open it made Agatha look down just to steady herself.

“Ready?” Rio asked, voice gentle, hopeful.

Agatha met her gaze. “Yes.”

And she was.
 More than she expected.


Rio opened the truck door for her, stepping back like it was the most natural thing in the world.

Agatha raised an eyebrow at the gesture. “Really?”

Rio shrugged, cheeks flushing a little. “My abuela raised me right.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the small flutter in her chest betrayed her. She climbed into the passenger seat, smoothing her skirt as Rio gently shut the door behind her.

Inside, the truck smelled faintly of pine and whatever soap Rio used. Clean. Warm. Comforting in a way Agatha wasn’t prepared for.

Rio got in on her side, buckled up, and shot her a shy smile before starting the engine. “Ready?”

Agatha pretended to study the dashboard. “We’ll see.”

Rio laughed, soft and warm, and pulled away from the curb.

The drive was surprisingly easy—comfortable in a way Agatha rarely felt with anyone.

They talked about work in that light, surface-level way where neither wanted to make the moment heavy.

Rio told her about the new recruit who accidentally sprayed the Bucky with a hose.

Agatha snorted. “And is he still alive?”

“Barely. Bucky is forgiving, but not that forgiving.”

Agatha shook her head, amused. “Children shouldn’t be given hoses.”

“Try telling the captain that,” Rio said, grinning.

Their conversation drifted. No pressure. No awkward stops. Just simple, steady warmth.

Agatha found herself relaxing despite the fluttering anticipation still in her chest.

Then the truck slowed.

And she saw where they were.

The carnival gates were shut, the lights off, the entire place dark against the summer evening sky.

Agatha turned her head slowly toward Rio, suspicion sharp in her gaze.

“Rio,” she said carefully, “the carnival is closed.”

Rio made a thoughtful humming sound. “Observant.”

“Do you plan to trespass on our first date?” Agatha asked, arms folding.

Rio bit her lip, visibly fighting a smile. “Maybe.”

Agatha opened her mouth to deliver a lecture she absolutely did not mean, but Rio winked at her.

A full, playful wink.

Agatha’s breath hitched—just slightly, but enough that she had to turn and pretend to inspect her handbag to hide the reaction.

Rio hopped out of the truck before Agatha could recover. She walked toward someone standing off to the side, and Agatha blinked, genuinely thrown.

An older woman in her late sixties, bright scarf, with a wad of keys stood waiting beside the gate.

Rio approached her warmly, shook her hand, spoke for a moment, then jogged back to the truck and opened Agatha’s door.

Agatha blinked up at her. “You know the carnival owner?”

Rio shrugged like it was nothing. “I helped her out a couple years ago.”

“Helped her how?” Agatha asked, sliding down from the seat.

“They had a fire and safety inspection deadline. Lots of upgrades needed. They were about to lose half their rides.” Rio guided her gently toward the entrance. “I pulled some strings. Got them an extension. Helped fix a few things myself. Saved them a pretty big fine.”

“And they are repaying you by… what? Giving us the run of the place?”

Rio smiled sheepishly. “Pretty much.”

The older woman unlocked the gates and gave Rio a fond pat on the cheek before slipping away with a conspiratorial grin.

As soon as Rio and Agatha stepped through the entrance, the carnival lights flickered on.

One strand. Then another.
 Then all at once.

Bright blues, golds, reds—glowing against the night.

Rides hummed to life.
 Music drifted through the air, soft and nostalgic.
 The entire carnival—empty, quiet, beautiful—stood waiting for them.

Agatha drew in a sharp, involuntary breath.

She hadn’t expected this.
 She couldn’t have imagined this.

Rio watched her carefully, nervously, hands shoved into the pockets of her jacket.

“I wanted you to see the joy of it,” she said quietly. “Even though it’s closed for the season. So I… called in that favour.”

Agatha turned to her, unable to speak for a moment.

Rio shifted, cheeks warming. “Is it okay? I mean, if it’s too much, we can just—”

Agatha stepped closer, her voice soft, almost reverent.

“Rio… it’s…”
 She swallowed, emotion pressing unexpectedly at the back of her throat.
 “It’s perfect.”

Rio’s shoulders relaxed, a shy grin tugging at her lips.

And in the glow of the empty carnival lights, Agatha felt something inside her—some long-locked door—quietly, cautiously, begin to open.


Rio’s fingers brushed against hers once, tentative and unsure. When Agatha didn’t pull back, Rio gently laced their hands together without a word, her palm warm, steady, anchoring.

“Come on,” Rio said softly. “We’ll start easy.”

Agatha allowed herself to be guided, even though every instinct told her to maintain some distance, to keep herself composed. But Rio’s hand around hers felt… safe. Familiar, somehow. And she had no desire to let go.

The carnival stretched around them—empty, glowing, alive only for them. Music drifted in soft waves.

They stopped in front of the carousel.

The lights around the canopy twinkled in warm gold. The carved horses stood perfectly still, frozen mid-gallop, manes flying, eyes bright. The platform gleamed under the string lights, soft shadows dancing across the painted details.

A young man in a staff jacket stood beside it, giving them a polite smile. Agatha realised he must be the on-duty operator tonight—assigned specifically to follow them from ride to ride.

Rio squeezed her hand. “I figured we should start with something low stakes.”

Agatha arched one brow. “Low stakes? We are mounting wooden animals on poles.”

Rio grinned. “Exactly.”

Agatha tried—truly tried—not to let the wonder show. But her eyes lifted on their own, tracing the ornate trim of the carousel, the delicate gold leaf, the soft glow reflecting off the mirrors. She felt something tug inside her chest—something achingly familiar.

She remembered being eight years old.
 Standing at the edge of a carnival fence, nose pressed between the bars.
 Watching the horses spin, lights blurring into ribbons.
 Wanting—desperately—to be part of that spinning world.
 And hearing her mother’s dismissive scoff behind her.
 Not tonight, Agatha. Don’t be ridiculous.

She swallowed hard, pushing the memory back.

Rio’s voice cut through the ache, warm and hopeful. “Which one do you want to ride?”

Agatha lifted her chin with practiced poise. “I was unaware there were rules to selecting a plastic horse.”

Rio laughed. “They’re wooden.”

“Even worse.”

“Pick one anyway.”

Agatha’s gaze betrayed her, drifting toward a pale grey horse with a sweeping silver mane and carved roses on its saddle. She looked away quickly, unwilling to let Rio see how much she loved it.

Rio followed her line of sight instantly. “That one?”

Agatha cleared her throat. “I suppose it is… aesthetically acceptable.”

Rio’s smile softened—so gentle, so unbearably understanding that Agatha looked down at the ground to steady herself.

The attendant stepped up and nodded. “Ready when you are.”

Rio guided her onto the platform, hand still holding hers, warm and reassuring.

For one small, impossible moment, Agatha felt like that little girl again—standing outside the fence—only this time, someone had opened the gate and taken her hand, walking her in.

The carousel began to turn with a soft mechanical sigh, lights gliding across Agatha’s face in warm strokes of gold and rose. The music chimed—a lilting, old-fashioned tune—and for a moment she forgot to breathe.

Her chosen horse rose gently beneath her, the movement smooth and steady. She kept one hand lightly on the pole, posture composed, but inside her chest something fizzed and fluttered like champagne.

Giddy.
 That was the word.
 Giddy and—heaven help her—magical.

She tried not to show it. She tried very hard.

But then she glanced sideways.

Rio sat astride the horse next to her—feet planted, back straight, clearly aware of how ridiculous she looked but trying anyway for Agatha’s sake. A slightly crooked smile tugged at her mouth as she kept sneaking looks at Agatha, checking to see if she was enjoying it.

The sight made something warm bloom beneath Agatha’s ribs.

She looked away quickly, pretending to examine the lights instead of staring at Rio like a lovesick idiot.
The carousel picked up speed, just enough to send a soft breeze lifting the ends of Agatha’s hair. She felt lighter than she had in years—untethered, almost.

Rio’s voice cut softly through the music.
 “Doing okay?”

Agatha didn’t trust her voice at first. When she finally turned her head, the lights reflected in her eyes. 
Rio’s gaze caught on the expression she hadn’t meant to reveal—part wonder, part disbelief, entirely vulnerable.

Her pulse hiccuped.

“I am…” Agatha cleared her throat, smoothing her skirt needlessly. “…sufficiently stable.”

Rio’s slow smile told her she wasn’t fooling anyone.

“Stable,” Rio repeated. “Right.”

Agatha shot her a tiny glare meant to be intimidating.

It only made Rio grin wider.

The carousel rose and dipped, rose and dipped, each movement loosening another thread of tension from Agatha’s spine. The breeze smelled of popcorn and cotton candy even though no stands were open. Lights streaked past in soft arcs. For a moment, she felt as if the whole world had tilted into something quieter, gentler.

She let her gaze slide back to Rio, unable to help herself.

Rio caught her this time.

Their eyes held.

Something tender flickered between them—shy, warm, so patient it made Agatha’s breath falter.

She looked away again, lips curving despite her best efforts.

When the ride slowed, the music fading into a soft echo, Agatha’s heart sank a fraction. She wasn’t ready for it to end.

Rio stepped off her horse first, then offered her hand—steady and warm—helping her down with a care that made Agatha’s stomach somersault.

“You okay?” Rio asked again, voice low.

Agatha nodded, not trusting herself to speak.

Because she felt something she hadn’t felt in a long, long time.
Magic. 

Simple, innocent, foolish magic.
And it was all because of the woman beside her.


Rio led her deeper into the carnival, still hand-in-hand, and Agatha allowed it—partly because she didn’t want to pull away, partly because her legs felt suspiciously unsteady after the carousel.

Lights blinked along the empty midway, flickering on in welcoming patterns as if responding to their presence. The music softened to a hum.

Rio stopped in front of a row of darkened stalls.
 A moment later, the same attendant from the carousel hurried over, switched on a panel, and the game lit up: a classic ring-toss booth, targets gleaming under the fairy lights.

Rio rubbed the back of her neck.
 “Thought maybe we could try to win something.”

Agatha raised a brow. “Aren’t these rigged?”

Rio grinned. “Probably. But the owner promised to, uh… relax the rules for us.”

Agatha looked at the rings, unimpressed. “How generous.”

Rio took a ring, squared her stance, and threw.

It missed by an inch.

She tried again—closer, but still not quite.

The fourth ring landed on the edge, wobbled tantalisingly, then fell off.

Rio winced. “Okay, that one was just rude.”

Agatha hummed thoughtfully. “Would you like me to show you how it’s done?”

Rio turned, eyes gleaming with a mix of hope and challenge. “Please. Enlighten me.”

Agatha stepped forward, rolling the ring between her fingers. She tested the weight, the balance—her surgeon’s brain already calculating distance, trajectory, force. Years of precision work kicked in like second nature.

She tossed.

The ring arced cleanly through the air and landed with a satisfying clink around the centre peg.

Rio blinked. “…Are you kidding me?”

Agatha allowed herself a graceful smile. “I am a surgeon, Rio. My hand–eye coordination is impeccable.”

Rio looked between Agatha and the perfectly landed ring, jaw slack. “Okay, but that was so fucking hot.”

Agatha felt her cheeks warm—and refused to acknowledge it.
 She reached for another ring, handing it to Rio.

“Here,” she said. “Try again. Use a little less power. You are throwing like you’re trying to breach a burning building.”

Rio laughed, taking the ring from her fingers. Her hand lingered, just a second longer than necessary.

“Maybe you should guide me,” Rio said softly.
Agatha’s breath caught.
But before she could respond, the attendant called cheerfully, “That counted as a win! Pick your prize!”
Rio snapped upright. “Oh—right!”
The man gestured toward a small wall of stuffed animals. Bright. Soft. Cheerful.

Rio’s eyes scanned the wall of prizes, lips pressed together in concentration as if she were choosing something of great importance.

Agatha watched her with crossed arms, pretending indifference—even as a small, ridiculous part of her wondered what Rio’s choice would say about her.

Finally, Rio pointed.
 “That one.”

The attendant reached up and pulled down a white floppy-eared bunny with soft brown spots, its ears tumbling over its face in a perpetually bashful look.

Rio took it gently, smoothing one of the ears with her thumb before turning and offering it to Agatha with both hands.

“This one feels right,” Rio said, cheeks colouring. “It’s soft. Kind. A little shy. But still really cute.”

Agatha stared at the bunny.

At Rio.

Back at the bunny.

“Cute?” she repeated, voice tight.

Rio swallowed, suddenly self-conscious. “In a refined way. A… very mature kind of cute.”

Agatha arched one brow. “You are digging yourself a hole.”

Rio’s grin turned shy again. “I know. But you deserve something nice.”

Agatha’s breath caught—just a tiny, betraying hitch she hoped Rio didn’t hear.
 She took the bunny, intending to hold it with professional detachment…

But the plush was incredibly soft.
 And the little brown spots were endearingly imperfect.
 And it practically melted against her palm.

Her fingers curled around it before she realised they had.

“It’s… acceptable,” she managed, voice softer than intended.

Rio’s smile bloomed—slow, warm, unmistakably pleased.
 “You’re welcome.”

Agatha hugged the bunny a bit closer to her chest, cursing herself internally when Rio’s smile deepened at the sight.

“Now,” Agatha said briskly, clearing her throat and straightening her posture, “what else does your carefully orchestrated carnival experience entail?”

Rio’s eyes sparkled, mischief tempered with tenderness.
 “Come on,” she said, reaching for her hand again.
 “You’re going to love this next part.”

Rio led her toward the far end of the carnival, where the lights glowed brighter and the machinery hummed with a deeper, more eager energy. As they rounded the corner, Agatha saw it.

A thrill ride.

The kind that spun, tilted, flipped, and sent riders careening upside down while shrieking in delight—or regret.

Agatha slowed her steps.

Rio noticed immediately.
 Of course she did.

She turned, hands in her jacket pockets, rocking on her heels with a careful sweetness Agatha was starting to recognise as her version of “checking in.”

“So…” Rio said slowly, glancing up at the looming metal structure, “this one’s… a bit more intense.”

Agatha raised her chin. “Define intense.”

“It flips you,” Rio admitted. “A couple times. Maybe more.”

Agatha stared at the ride.
 It stared back.

Rio’s voice softened. “We don’t have to do it. I mean that. Only if you want to.”

Agatha refused—absolutely refused—to be the woman who chickened out on a date. Not in front of a firefighter. Not in front of this firefighter.

“Of course I want to,” Agatha said smoothly.

Rio’s eyes twinkled. “You sure?”

“Quite sure.”

Inside, Agatha was screaming.

The attendant strapped them in, the harness clicking into place. Agatha’s heart hammered against her ribs like it was preparing its last rites. Rio sat beside her, close enough that their shoulders brushed, warm and grounding.

“Hey,” Rio murmured, leaning slightly toward her. “If it gets too much, just close your eyes. I’ll be right here.”

Agatha clenched the safety bar. “I am perfectly fine.”

The ride jerked forward.

She was not perfectly fine.

The first flip came without warning.

Agatha’s eyes flew open, then shut again instantly as the world whipped upside down. She was determined not to scream but her entire soul launched upward as gravity flipped.

She managed a strained, “Oh my—!”

Rio’s delighted laugh filled the air, warm and bright.

The second flip hit.
And Agatha screamed.
Not in fear.
In joy.

A wild, unrestrained, furious explosion of exhilaration ripped out of her chest, surprising her more than the flipping itself.

Rio laughed harder, gripping the safety bar with one hand and reaching blindly for Agatha’s with the other. Their fingers brushed, then clasped.

The ride spun them again, faster, higher, the night lights blurring into ribbons of gold around them.
Agatha’s laughter grew louder—full, breathless, utterly uncontained.
 Rio joined in, and the sound of them together echoed through the empty carnival, bright and wild and alive.

When the ride finally began to slow, Agatha was breathless, gripping Rio’s hand like her life depended on it, cheeks flushed, hair windswept.

Rio glanced over, eyes sparkling. “You okay?”

Agatha took in a shaky breath.
 “I…” She swallowed, still panting softly.
 “I think I loved that.”

Rio beamed, pure sunshine.

As the ride slowed to a shuddering stop, Agatha’s breath was still caught somewhere between her ribs and her throat. Her hair was windswept, cheeks flushed, chest rising and falling in short bursts from laughing harder than she had in years.

The harness clicked open.

Rio hopped out first, a little unsteady herself, then immediately turned to offer her hand—warm, steady, grounding.

Agatha took it.

The moment her feet hit the ground, her legs wobbled.
 Rio’s did too.

They stumbled into each other, laughing—quiet at first, then breathlessly, helplessly, until the sound bounced down the empty midway like spilled starlight.

Agatha leaned into Rio without thinking, buoyed by adrenaline and joy and something softer, something she didn’t have the name or courage for.

Rio’s forehead dropped lightly against hers, both of them still catching their breath.
 Her smile was bright, unguarded, glowing in the carnival lights.

“That was intense,” Rio murmured, voice rough with laughter.

Agatha’s laugh softened into something quieter, almost disbelieving. “I feel… alive.”

Rio swallowed. “Good. You should always feel like that.”

The world narrowed.

Just them.
 The cool night air.
 The music drifting faintly.
 The lights flickering warm across Rio’s face.
 The smell of popcorn and machine oil and something sweet Agatha couldn’t name.

Rio’s gaze dropped to Agatha’s lips for the briefest second—so quick Agatha might have missed it if she hadn’t been watching her with impossible precision.

Agatha’s breath hitched.
 Rio stepped closer.

“Can I—” Rio began, voice barely above a whisper.

Agatha didn’t let her finish.

She leaned in, closing the gap in one smooth, certain movement, her hand sliding up to Rio’s jaw as their lips met.

The kiss was soft at first—gentle, warm, a question and an answer all at once.
 Then Rio exhaled a tiny sound against her mouth, fingers curling into the fabric of Agatha’s sweater, and it deepened just enough to feel real.
 Present.
 Electric.

For a long moment, the world spun in a far better way than any ride could manage.

When they finally pulled apart, both breathless, Rio rested her forehead against Agatha’s again, cheeks flushed in the golden lights.

“Wow,” Rio murmured, voice slightly shaky. “That was… wow.”

Agatha swallowed, trying to gather her pulse into something dignified.
 She failed spectacularly.

Rio bought them cotton candy from a booth the attendant hurriedly reopened, spinning the sugar into a soft pink cloud that glowed under the carnival lights. Agatha held it delicately between her fingers, eyeing the fluff with suspicion until Rio tore off a piece and pressed it to her lips.

“Just try it,” Rio murmured.

Agatha shot her a look… then took the bite.

It dissolved instantly on her tongue. Sweet. Weightless.
 She blinked, surprised. “IHow much sugar is in this?”

Rio laughed, handing her the rest, and Agatha pretended not to feel the warmth blooming in her chest at the sound.

They walked together, sharing bites of cotton candy, the white bunny plush tucked under Agatha’s arm, until the towering silhouette of the ferris wheel came into view.

Its lights flickered on—soft gold and blue, glowing against the night sky.

Rio looked at her, waiting for permission.
 Agatha answered with a small nod.

They climbed into the carriage, the metal creaking gently beneath them. Rio sat close—not touching, not pushing—but near enough that Agatha could feel her warmth.

As the wheel began its slow ascent, the carnival spread beneath them, lights stretching out like scattered stars. The night breeze lifted Agatha’s hair, brushing it softly against Rio’s shoulder.

For a moment, neither spoke.

Then Agatha inhaled, steady but quiet, and said in a voice that felt almost too fragile for her own ears-
“I don’t remember the last time I felt this happy.”

Rio turned toward her, eyes softening. “Agatha…”

“I’m serious,” Agatha continued, gaze fixed on the glowing world below. “It feels… almost unreal.” Her voice softened more. “Thank you, Rio.”

Rio reached for her hand—not grabbing, not overwhelming—just offering.

Agatha placed her hand into Rio’s without hesitation.

As they rose higher, the wind colder, the lights brighter, Agatha felt her heart squeezing in a way that was both painful and beautiful.

She looked out over the carnival, over the sweeping view, and a memory flickered, sharp and familiar.

She was a child again, pressed against her bedroom window, chin on the window sill. The ferris wheel glittered far away, rising and dipping, carrying strangers to the very top. She remembered envying the small silhouettes inside, wondering what it felt like to see the world from there, weightless, held by something bigger than herself.

She had never been invited. Never been allowed. Never felt it could be hers.
And now—here she was. At the very top.
Not looking through a window. Not watching someone else live it.
But experiencing it.
 With Rio.

The ride reached its apex.
Stillness. Silence.
 The carnival spread glittering below them, the stars far above.
 Agatha turned to Rio.
No hesitation this time.
 Rio leaned forward slowly, tenderly, giving her every chance to pull away.

Agatha met her halfway.

Their lips brushed, soft, sweet, warm in the cool night air. The world stilled around them. The kiss deepened just a breath more, their hands tightening together, their foreheads brushing gently as they parted.

Rio’s voice was barely a whisper. “I’m glad I got to show you this.”

Agatha let out a quiet breath, her chest tight with something she did not yet dare name.
 “I’m glad too.”

As the ferris wheel carried them slowly back toward earth, she held Rio’s hand the entire way down.
And for the first time in her life, she didn’t envy the people at the top— because she had been one of them.

Chapter 12

They were stepping off the ferris wheel platform, hands brushing, hearts still fluttering from the softness of the kiss they’d shared at the top, when a sudden vibration broke through the quiet hum of the empty carnival.

Agatha’s phone buzzed from inside her sweater pocket.

She paused, frowning slightly as she reached in and pulled it out.

WESTVIEW GENERAL – ON-CALL LINE
Her stomach tightened.

She answered immediately. “Dr. Harkness.”

“Doctor, sorry for the late call,” the charge nurse said, brisk and urgent. “Dr. Kale is still scrubbed into a vascular bleed. We need you for an emergency appendectomy — probable peritonitis. We’re prepping the patient now.”

Agatha exhaled, all warmth and softness shifting into clinical precision. “I’ll be there in ten minutes.”

She ended the call.

Rio was already watching her, eyes steady and concerned. “Emergency?”
“Yes,” Agatha said, slipping the phone back into her pocket. “An appendix about to rupture. It can’t wait.”

Rio nodded once. “Come on. I’ll drive you.”

“Rio, I’m sorry, the date—”

“Hey,” Rio said gently, stepping closer. “This is more important.”

Agatha opened her mouth to protest.
 Instead, she reached up and touched Rio’s arm in quiet gratitude. “Thank you.”

Rio smiled — soft, tender, grounding. “Always.”

She gave Rio’s arm a quick squeeze before Rio guided her back to the truck.


Rio pulled up to the ER entrance, truck idling beneath the bright hospital lights. Agatha unbuckled, hand hovering on the door handle before she looked back at Rio.

Rio gave her a small, encouraging smile. “Go save some lives.”

“Thank you Rio, I had a really great time tonight.” Agatha leaned in and kissed her — brief but warm, a promise more than a goodbye — then slipped out and hurried inside.

Once in the locker room, she changed into scrubs with quick, efficient movements. 

Her cream sweater still held the faint scent of sugar and cool night air. Smiling, she folded it carefully before stepping into the scrub room.

At the sink, she washed up to her elbows with precise, practiced circles as the circulating nurse approached with a chart.

“Doctor Harkness, quick rundown,” the nurse said. “Vitals holding but trending down. No allergies. Ultrasound confirms inflammation and fluid. Symptoms started earlier today.”

Agatha nodded, letting the warm water steady her focus.

“Age?” she asked.

The nurse paused.

“He’s five,” she said quietly. “A five-year-old boy.”

Agatha’s hands stilled. Just for a moment. Just long enough for a cold knot to form under her ribs.

A child.

She inhaled, slow and controlled, forcing her breath into steadiness.
Then she shut off the water, lifted her chin, and said,
“I’m ready.”
And walked toward the OR doors.

The operation began smoothly.

Agatha made the incision cleanly, movements measured and sure.
 The little boy’s vitals held steady.
 The appendix was inflamed, dangerous, but manageable.

The OR hummed with the usual rhythm — beeps, murmurs, the soft clinking of instruments.
 Agatha focused entirely on the small, delicate field in front of her.

She was calm. Precise. In control.
Until she wasn’t.

Halfway through, the suction changed tone — a faint gurgle that shouldn’t have been there.
 Fluid pooled unexpectedly.
 A vessel she had not anticipated bled faster than it should have.

Complication.

Agatha felt the bottom drop out of her stomach.

“Pressure,” she said calmly, or so she thought. Her voice was quieter than usual.
 “Clamp. Now.”

The scrub nurse moved quickly, handing her exactly what she needed.

But as the bleeding continued, just a touch too heavy, just a beat too fast, her breath hitched.

And without warning—
A flash.
Nicky.
Small. Fragile. Lying on an OR table just like this one. Still. Exposed. Vulnerable.
 The overhead light reflecting on tiny ribs that should never be under surgical lamps.

Agatha’s heart slammed painfully against her chest.

She blinked, but the image didn’t disappear — it overlapped the child before her, merging horribly, impossibly.

Her fingers faltered.

“Doctor?” the scrub nurse said softly.

Agatha didn’t respond.

Her eyes remained fixed on the field, but her attention was slipping — spiralling — her breath growing shallow.

The anaesthesiologist shot the nurse a sharp look.
 The nurse nodded once, discreet but urgent, and reached for the wall phone.

“Page Dr. Kale to OR 1,” she said, voice low and steady.

Agatha barely heard her.

Her chest tightened, breath shortening, memories crashing too hard and too fast.
 She tried to speak — to say clamp, or suction, or anything — but her lips parted uselessly.

Her hands froze.

“Agatha?”

The voice cut through the rising roar in her head.

Firm. Steady. Grounded.

Dr. Kale pushed through the OR doors, peeling off her gown from the previous surgery. She approached without hesitation, stepping to Agatha’s side.

“Talk to me,” Jen said quietly, only for her to hear. “What’s happening?”

Agatha’s breath shook. “It’s—he’s—”

Another flash. Nicky’s face. The ferris wheel lights. Rio’s hand in hers. The boy on the table.

Jen moved closer, her presence filling the space with stable, calm certainty.

“Agatha,” Jen said softly, pitched low so only she would hear. “Take a breath.”

Agatha’s breath came uneven, shallow. “I—he’s—he’s bleeding more than— I can’t—”

Her voice broke.

Jen stepped into her line of sight, blocking the surgical field just enough to anchor her back.

“Hey,” Jen said, steady, warm but firm. “Look at me.”

Agatha’s eyes were wide, unfocused.

“Agatha,” Jen repeated, voice gentler now, “you’re not alone in here. I’m right beside you. The patient is stable. Listen to the monitor.”

Beep. Beep. Beep. 
Steady.

“You’re safe,” Jen said. “He’s safe. You just got startled, that’s all. It happens.”

Agatha’s throat bobbed with a swallow. Her breathing faltered—then steadied, just slightly.

“Give me your eyes,” Jen coaxed.

Agatha forced herself to look up.
 Her vision sharpened, Jen’s face coming into focus.

“There you go,” Jen murmured. “Deep breath. You’re okay.”

Agatha inhaled, trembling.

“And again.”

She followed, the rush of panic slowly retreating from her limbs.

Jen waited until she saw clarity return to Agatha’s gaze.

Then—quietly, respectfully— “You lead, I’ll assist.”

Agatha exhaled, nodded once, found her voice again.

“Clamp,” she said.

Steady. Focused. Returning.

Jen passed it to her without hesitation, staying close but letting Agatha take control.

Together, they moved through the complication with practiced precision.

The little boy’s vitals stayed stable.
 The bleeding slowed.
 The panic faded.

Agatha reclaimed the surgery— her hands sure again, her breath even, her mind sharp.

No one in the room said anything.

But every member of the OR team felt the moment she came back.

The boy was stable.

Alive.

Recovering.

Agatha walked out of the OR with her posture perfectly straight, her expression perfectly calm, and her insides in complete disarray.

She finished her charting on autopilot. Gave instructions to the night resident. Nodded politely to the nurses who told her, “Good save, Doctor.”

Then she stepped into the corridor, intending to disappear into her office or possibly the nearest supply closet and never come out.

She didn’t make it that far.

Jen was waiting for her.

Still in her surgical cap, mask around her neck, bags under her eyes from the double shift she’d just pulled. She’d washed up quickly after helping Agatha, but her eyes were on her colleague. 

On her friend.

On the woman she’d just watched break in the OR.

“Agatha,” Jen said softly.

Agatha froze.

Jen stepped closer, her voice warm and steady. “Come on. Not out here.”

She guided Agatha down an empty hallway and into a small on-call room, closing the door behind them. 

She didn’t turn on the overhead light — just the soft lamp on the desk, the gentler glow fitting the moment.

Agatha stood rigidly in the centre of the room.

Jen leaned against the counter, arms folded, gaze steady. Not judging. Not pitying. Just present.

“Talk to me,” Jen said quietly.

Agatha opened her mouth.
 Nothing came out.

Her throat seized.
 Her breath hitched.

She hadn’t expected the spiral.
 Hadn’t expected the image.
 Hadn’t expected how violently it would shake her.

Finally she forced out, “I froze.”

Jen nodded slowly. “I saw.”

“It was a child.” Agatha’s voice cracked. “A little boy. And when the complication hit I—”

She stopped, pressing fingers to her temple, furious at the heat prickling behind her eyes.

Jen stepped toward her, cautious but sure. “Hey. It’s okay.”

Agatha shook her head sharply. “No. It isn’t. It can’t happen. Not to me. Not ever.”

Jen’s voice softened, but her words were firm. “Every surgeon has a moment.”

“Not like that,” Agatha hissed, voice shaking with humiliation and panic. “I didn’t just hesitate. I—”
 Her breath stuttered.
 “—I saw something that wasn’t there. And then I couldn’t move.”

Jen’s expression tightened with understanding, not curiosity. She didn’t ask what Agatha saw. She didn’t pry. 

She knew better.

She reached out, placing a warm hand on Agatha’s forearm. “You came back.”

“It took you walking in,” Agatha whispered.

Jen squeezed her arm gently. “You know what I saw when I walked in?”

Agatha swallowed hard, looking away.

“I saw a brilliant surgeon mid-spiral,” Jen said, voice soft but strong. “And I saw her fight her way back in seconds. I saw her finish the case flawlessly. I saw her save a child’s life.”

Agatha’s eyes flickered, uncertain. “You’re being generous.”

“No,” Jen said simply. “I’m being honest.”

A long beat.

Jen stepped closer. “Agatha… you’ve been carrying a lot. More than you admit. More than anyone should without breaking eventually.”

Agatha’s jaw tensed. “I don’t break.”

Jen smiled sadly. “Everyone breaks. The strong ones just know how to put themselves back together afterward.”

Agatha’s breath trembled.

Jen watched her a moment, then added softly, “And for what it’s worth… I’m glad you let me be there with you.”

Agatha closed her eyes, a single tear slipping down against her will.

Jen pretended not to see it.

She stepped back just enough to give Agatha space to breathe, but not enough to make her feel alone. Her voice softened, the edges rounding with something almost… vulnerable.

“You know,” Jen began, leaning lightly on the counter, “you’re not the only surgeon who’s ever frozen.”

Agatha scrubbed a hand over her face. “It doesn’t happen to me.”

“It didn’t happen to me either,” Jen said quietly. “Not until it did.”

Agatha looked up.

Jen didn’t usually talk about herself. 

“It was during my second year of med school,” Jen continued, eyes drifting somewhere far away. “We were home for the holidays. My dad and I were in the kitchen making breakfast. He was laughing at something stupid I’d said.”

Her voice caught—not much, but enough.

“And then he grabbed the counter. Went pale. Collapsed.”

Agatha’s breath stilled.

“I knew what to do,” Jen said. “I’d studied it a hundred times. But when it was him? When he was lying there on the floor?”
 She shook her head, swallowing.
 “I froze. Completely. I couldn’t even call 911 at first. My mom had to do it.”

“Jen…” Agatha whispered.

“I did compressions,” Jen said, voice small. “But I was dead inside the whole time. I wasn’t a doctor. I was just a terrified kid trying to save her dad.”

Agatha stepped closer, instinctively, silently offering support.

“He died,” Jen said simply. Not harsh. Not dramatic. Just fact. “And for weeks I couldn’t walk into class without shaking. I almost dropped out of med school.”

Agatha’s brows drew tight with shock. “You never said—”

“Of course I didn’t,” Jen said with a dry smile. “We don’t advertise this stuff. We pretend we’re invincible. That nothing touches us.”

She sighed, eyes softening.

“But things do touch us, Agatha. Especially the things that matter.”

A beat passed.

“I got therapy,” Jen said. “A lot of it. I learned how to breathe again. How to separate the past from the patient in front of me. How to trust myself after falling apart.”

Her gaze met Agatha’s, steady and warm.

“And I still became a damn good doctor.”

“You’re one of the best,” Agatha said without hesitation.

Jen shrugged lightly. “So are you. One moment in the OR doesn’t change that.”

Agatha looked away, jaw tight. “It felt like more than a moment.”

“I know,” Jen said gently. “And that’s exactly why you need to talk about it. Not tonight, maybe. But soon.”

Agatha’s lips parted in the smallest, softest fracture. “I thought I was past this.”

Jen touched her arm again, warm and deliberate. “We’re never past being human.”

A long breath left Agatha—slow, controlled, but heavy with the truth of it.

Jen gave her a small, knowing smile.
 “Go home. And if you can’t sleep… call Rio. Trust me.”

Agatha blinked. “Jen.”

“What?” Jen lifted both hands. “I’m just saying. She’d show up. And you… you could use someone in your corner tonight.”

Agatha didn’t argue.\

She didn’t have the strength to pretend she didn’t want exactly that.


Agatha changed in silence.

The locker room was dim, lit only by the flickering fluorscent light over the sinks. She peeled off her scrubs with slow, heavy movements and slipped back into her clothes. Her cream sweater felt softer than she remembered, like a piece of the night that had been stolen from her.

She tied her hair back, then let it fall again. She didn’t know what she needed.
 Only that she felt… brittle.

Before leaving, she walked up one floor and stopped just outside Lilia’s room.

The door was half-open, the lights inside low. Lilia was fast asleep, curled on her side, breathing deep and easy. A cup of tea sat untouched on the bedside table, now cold.

Agatha stepped inside quietly.

She didn’t speak.
 Didn’t move further in.

She just watched her for a moment, the soft rise and fall of her chest, the gentle relaxation in her features and let herself breathe. Just once. Just long enough to feel something settle.

“Goodnight mom” Agatha whispered under her breath, barely audible. 

She slipped out and headed for the exit.

The night air hit her like a wave — cool, sharp, and almost cleansing. She pulled her sweater tighter around her, hugging it close as she stepped beneath the yellow glow of the streetlights.

Only then did she pull out her phone.

A new text from Rio waited for her.

Rio: Hey. How did the surgery go?

Agatha stared at the message for a long time.
 She considered telling the truth — the spiral, the freeze, the way she’d seen something that wasn’t there.
But the words wouldn’t come.

Her fingers moved slowly.

Agatha: It… didn’t go too well.

She hit send before she lost her nerve.

The three dots appeared almost immediately, then vanished.

Then her phone started to ring.

Rio.

Agatha answered on the second ring, breath unsteady. “Hey, I—”

“Agatha?” Rio’s voice was soft, but laced with concern. “What happened?”

Agatha opened her mouth—to give a practiced, controlled answer.
 Instead, her breath hitched.

“I—” She stopped, trying again.
 “Rio… I froze.”

There was a beat of silence on the line.

Then Agatha’s voice cracked. “It was a little boy and I— I couldn’t move, I…”
 Her breath broke apart, shaky and uneven. “I don’t freeze. I don’t— I shouldn’t—”

Rio inhaled sharply.

“Hey, its okay.” Her tone changed instantly—soft, anchoring, no hesitation. “Are you still at the hospital?”

Agatha pressed a hand to her forehead. “Yes.”

“Where exactly?”

“The front entrance,” Agatha managed, her voice small.

“Okay. Stay there.”
 Rio’s voice was steady, firm, with exactly zero room for argument. “Don’t move. I’m coming right now.”

“Rio, you don’t have to—”

“Agatha,” Rio said gently but with iron underneath, “I want to. And I’m already in my truck.”

Agatha closed her eyes.

Her breath trembled—not with panic now, but relief.

“Okay,” she whispered.

“Stay where you are,” Rio repeated. “I’ll be there soon.”

The call ended, but Agatha didn’t move.

She stood under the hospital canopy, hugging her sweater tighter, tears still drying on her cheeks—waiting for the familiar growl of Rio’s truck to pull into the car park, carrying the one person she realised she desperately needed right now.

The growl of the black truck came before Agatha even saw the headlights.

She didn’t move.
 Couldn’t.

The truck pulled right up to the entrance, braking gently. The door flew open, and Rio was out before the engine had even settled.

She’d changed into grey sweats, a dark hoodie, hair pulled back loosely.

Rio reached her in three long strides.

“Hey,” Rio murmured, voice low and warm, and she cupped Agatha’s face with both hands, thumbs brushing away the dried tracks beneath Agatha’s eyes before fresh ones could fall. “I’ve got you.”

Agatha didn’t know whether to crumble or stand taller.

It ended up being a bit of both.

Rio slid one arm around her back, pulling her into a steady, grounding hug. Agatha’s fingers curled into the front of Rio’s hoodie, not tight, but enough to betray how badly she needed something—someone—solid.

Rio didn’t ask questions.
 Didn’t push.
 Just held her until Agatha’s shoulders finally, finally loosened.

“Come on,” Rio whispered near her temple. “Let’s get you out of here.”

Agatha exhaled. A small, shaky nod.

Rio opened the passenger door, guiding her gently into the seat, buckling her in with careful, quiet movements like she was something precious. She circled around, climbed in, and drove with one hand on the wheel and the other resting palm-up between them—an invitation.

Agatha took it.

Their fingers wove together.

They drove in silence for a minute, Agatha staring out the window, Rio glancing at her every so often like she was checking a heartbeat.

Finally, Agatha’s voice broke through the quiet, small and uncertain.

“Where are we going?”

Rio squeezed her hand gently. “My place,” she said softly. “I don’t want you to be alone right now.”

Agatha’s breath trembled at that—because she hadn’t realised how deeply she didn’t want to be alone either.

The apartment lights clicked on with a warm amber glow when Rio unlocked the door, ushering Agatha inside first.

It was nothing like Agatha expected.

Soft.
 Warm.
 Lived-in.

Plants everywhere, with lush vines draped along bookshelves and succulents clustered on the coffee table. The space felt like it breathed.

A guitar leaned against the couch, something told her it was clearly Alice’s, judging by the paint chips on the neck and the heavy metal stickers along the case.

Art prints lined the walls—local pieces, small and colourful. A mismatched but charming set of blankets folded over the back of the couch. 

It felt… safe.

Agatha stopped just inside the doorway, taking it all in.

Rio watched her with quiet, nervous eyes. “Um. It’s not fancy. Alice calls it our ‘queer gremlin nest.’ I keep threatening to buy actual matching furniture but—”

“It’s…” Agatha swallowed, the word surprising even herself. “Beautiful.”

Rio’s shoulders dropped in relief. “Yeah?”

Agatha nodded once. Slowly. 

“Yes.”

Rio stepped closer, her voice gentling. “Come sit.”

She guided Agatha to the couch, helping her settle into a nest of blankets without making it feel like she thought Agatha was fragile.

But Agatha felt fragile.

Once they sat, Rio tucked one knee onto the cushion, facing her. “Do you want tea? Water? Space? A pillow to scream into?”

Agatha startled at a soft laugh she didn’t know she’d made. “Just… stay.”

Rio nodded immediately and reached for her hand again.

Agatha’s fingers slid into hers without hesitation.

The apartment was quiet. No Alice, no prying eyes, no hospital lights, no buzzing machines. 

Just Rio. 

Warm. Safe. Present.

And for the first time that night, Agatha let herself lean, just slightly into Rio’s shoulder.

She let the warmth of Rio’s shoulder steady her, just long enough for her breath to even out. The room hummed with stillness — low lamplight, soft blankets, the faint sound of a neighbour’s TV through the wall. 

Nothing sharp. Nothing loud. Nothing demanding.

Just space.

After a long moment, Agatha’s voice broke through the quiet.

“I froze.”

Rio didn’t move, didn’t stiffen. She only turned her head slightly, listening.

“In the OR,” Agatha continued, her voice thin. “I froze. It was a child—my first since…” She swallowed, unable to finish that sentence. “And I didn’t handle it well.”

Rio squeezed her hand but didn’t speak, letting Agatha guide the pace.

Agatha stared down at her fingers curled around Rio’s. “Lilia told me months ago I should get help. Therapy. A professional. I dismissed her at the time… assumed she was being dramatic, emotional, over involved.”

A humourless breath escaped her. “She was right.”

Rio stayed still, patient.

“Tonight proved it,” Agatha whispered. “I can’t risk freezing again. Not with someone’s child on that table. Not ever.”

The admission seemed to drain something from her — a defence, a wall, something she’d kept upright for years.

Her voice wavered. “But I’m scared. Scared they’ll admit that I’m broken.”

Rio finally moved. Slowly. Carefully. She tugged Agatha’s hand into both of hers and guided it to rest against her chest, right over her heart.

“Look at me,” Rio murmured.

Agatha did — reluctantly, vulnerably.

Rio’s eyes were soft, steady, unwavering. 

“Being scared doesn’t mean you’re broken, Agatha.”

Agatha blinked fast, jaw tight. “It feels like it.”

Rio shook her head gently. “It means you care. Deeply. It means you’re human. And it means you’ve been carrying too much alone.”

Agatha looked away, shame prickling the edges of her vision. “I hate that I couldn’t control it.”

“Then we work on it,” Rio said, simple as breath. “With someone trained to help you through it. You don’t have to pretend anymore.”

Agatha’s throat tightened. “I’m not good at… this. Needing things.”

Rio’s thumb brushed her knuckles. “You’re allowed to need things. Even help.”

Agatha’s breath faltered.

A flush of self-awareness crept up her neck — sharp, humiliating, impossible to ignore. She straightened slightly, not pulling away but trying to reassemble the pieces of her composure.

“I’m sorry,” she said quietly.

Rio frowned, not in anger but confusion. “What for?”

Agatha’s gaze dropped to their intertwined hands. “This is… new. With you.” 
A shaky exhale. 
“And now here I am, falling apart on your couch like some melodramatic mess.”

Her words were tight, brittle around the edges. “You didn’t sign up for this. For me like this.”

Rio shifted closer, her knee brushing Agatha’s. “Hey,” she whispered, tilting her head to catch Agatha’s eyes. “Look at me.”
