Reluctantly, Agatha did.

Rio’s face softened with something warm and breathtakingly sincere. “You don’t ever have to apologise for being yourself with me.”

Agatha swallowed hard.

“This isn’t too much,” Rio said gently. “You’re not too much.”

Agatha blinked rapidly, tears threatening again, her voice unsteady. “I just… I didn’t want the first time you brought me here to be like this.”

Rio’s expression softened, and she reached up, brushing a thumb across Agatha’s cheekbone. She didn’t wipe a tear or rush her, just offered a gentle, steady touch meant to ground her.

The breath caught in Agatha’s throat.

She couldn’t remember the last time someone had touched her with that kind of tenderness. Not clinical or obligatory. Not careful in a detached, professional way. This was human and soft, warm with intention, full of quiet care. It made her chest ache in a way she hadn’t expected.

She felt seen, not as Dr. Harkness or the woman who never falters, but as herself. 

Simply herself.

Her eyes fluttered closed for a moment, overwhelmed by how unfamiliar and devastatingly comforting that small gesture felt.

Rio kept her voice low and warm. “Agatha, you trusted me enough to let me be there for you. That means more to me than anything else would.”

A quiet breath left Agatha, unsteady but real.

“And for what it’s worth,” Rio added softly, “I’m really glad you’re here.”

Agatha leaned in again, letting her forehead rest against Rio’s shoulder without overthinking it. She let herself be held because she needed it, and because Rio offered it so naturally.

Rio wrapped her arms around her, steady and sure, as if holding her like this was not a burden but something she wanted.

Agatha let herself be held, sinking into the warmth of Rio’s embrace. She drew in a slow breath and caught the faint trace of Rio’s cologne mingled with her own natural, earthy scent. It was warm and smoky and clean, something that wrapped around Agatha’s senses and pulled her down from the ledge she’d been clinging to all night.

She exhaled shakily, then breathed in again, this time steadier.

Rio’s hand moved in slow, reassuring strokes along her back. Not pushing, not coaxing anything more from her. Just reminding her she wasn’t alone. The simple weight of it grounded her more than she wanted to admit.

The tension in Agatha’s shoulders finally began to loosen. Her breath evened out, no longer sharp or trembling. Each inhale felt a little fuller, each exhale a little less fragile. The panic that had gripped her earlier softened into something quieter, something she could hold without being undone by it.

Rio didn’t speak. She didn’t need to.

Agatha’s breathing settled into a slow, steady rhythm, her cheek resting against Rio’s chest. The rise and fall beneath her was soothing, hypnotic, and the warmth of Rio’s arms around her created a cocoon she hadn’t realised she needed so desperately.

Her eyelids grew heavy.

Rio noticed, softening her hold but never letting go. She shifted just enough to let Agatha rest more comfortably against her, brushing a hand once more through her hair.

Within minutes, Agatha drifted.

Not a deep sleep.
 Not peaceful, exactly.
 But safe.

Her body softened, tension unwinding as she let herself surrender to the warmth and quiet. Rio stayed still, hardly daring to move, one hand resting reassuringly at Agatha’s back, the other holding her hand loosely.

For a small, quiet eternity, Agatha slept.

Until a soft clicking noise broke through the quiet.

Agatha’s brow furrowed, the sound tugging her from sleep. She didn’t move at first—Rio’s arm was still around her, warm and secure. But then the click came again, followed by a whisper.

Agatha pried one eye open.

At the front door stood Jen and Alice.

Jen’s face was split into the smuggest, most self-satisfied smirk Agatha had ever seen. Pure “I knew it” energy radiated off her like a spotlight.

Alice, beside her, had clasped both hands over her mouth, her eyes sparkling like she’d walked in on the most adorable thing she had ever witnessed in her entire life. She swayed a little, whispering something like “Oh my god” under her breath.

Agatha froze.

Absolutely froze, still half-draped against Rio’s chest.

Rio stirred, blinking awake with a soft hum, her arm tightening instinctively before she realised why Agatha had gone rigid. She glanced up—and immediately sat up straighter, cheeks flushing.

“Oh,” Rio croaked, voice still thick with sleep. “Uh. Hey?”

Jen crossed her arms, looking delighted. “Well, well, well.”

Agatha wanted the earth to open and swallow her.

Alice stepped in farther, soft-voiced and beaming. “You two look so cozy.”

Jen planted a hand on her hip and grinned like the cat that stole the whole damn dairy farm. “Wow. I mean… I told you to call Rio, not jump into her lap, but you go girl.”

Agatha sat up too fast, hair wildly mussed, sweater wrinkled, eyes wide. “I was not— I didn’t— This isn’t—”

Jen nodded, pretending to take notes. “Sure, sure. Absolutely not in her lap. Zero laps involved.”

Agatha pressed a hand to her forehead, wishing for immediate death. “This is mortifying.”

Rio leaned close, whispering to her with a soft smile, “It’s really okay.”

Jen dropped her bag and kicked off her shoes. “Honestly? I love this for you. For both of you. Continue.”

Agatha groaned.

Rio’s hand slid gently to her back. “They’re fine,” she whispered. “And I’m glad you stayed.”

Agatha peeked at her through her fingers… then dared another glance at Jen and Alice, who were now whispering excitedly like they were watching the season finale of their favourite show.

Agatha exhaled shakily. “I… should go.”

Rio blinked, surprised. “You don’t have to rush out.”

“I do,” Agatha murmured, patting herself down for her phone. “I’m due back at the hospital in…”
She finally found it on the coffee table and checked the time. Her stomach dropped. “Forty-eight minutes, actually.”

“Look at that,” Jen said, smirking. “We leave you two alone for a couple of hours and come home to spooning and emotional breakthroughs.”
 She winked at Rio. “Nice work.”

Rio covered her face with her hand. “Goodnight, Jen.”

“I’ll bet it was.” Jen teased, letting Alice drag her toward the kitchen. 

Alice swatted her. “Stop. Let them say goodbye.”

The moment they disappeared into the kitchen, the apartment grew quiet again.

Rio turned to Agatha, still soft from sleep, her hoodie rumpled, her hair a little messy. Somehow it made her even more beautiful.

“I’ll drive you,” Rio said gently, reaching for the truck keys.

Agatha shook her head. “No. I should walk. It’ll help me wake up.”

Rio hesitated but didn’t push. “Let me at least walk you to the door.”

Agatha nodded.

They made it three steps before Agatha felt Rio’s hand brush lightly against the small of her back — not guiding, just present. She didn’t pull away.

At the door, Agatha turned to her. Rio’s expression was quiet and warm, concern woven through every line of her face.

“Thank you,” Agatha said softly. “For tonight. For… everything.”

Rio smiled, a small, slow curve of her lips that seemed to melt something inside Agatha’s ribs. 
“Anytime.”

Agatha stepped closer without really thinking. “I mean it.”

“I know,” Rio murmured.

It happened before Agatha could second-guess it.
She leaned in and kissed her.

Not rushed. Not desperate. Just a tender, lingering kiss that held the gratitude, the exhaustion, the fear, and the comfort of the night all in one.

Rio stilled — then melted.

Absolutely melted.

Her hand slid up to cup the side of Agatha’s jaw, her thumb brushing lightly beneath her cheekbone in that way that made Agatha’s entire chest tighten. Rio kissed her back softly, carefully, like she didn’t want to overwhelm her but couldn’t help wanting to be close.

When Agatha finally pulled back, Rio was a little breathless, eyes soft like warm honey.

“Text me when you get there,” Rio whispered.

Agatha nodded, heart thudding. “I will.”

She walked down the apartment steps slowly, the early morning air cool against her flushed skin. Her pulse was still fluttering, unsteady from the kiss she and Rio had shared. She could still feel the imprint of Rio’s thumb on her jaw and the soft press of her lips, warm and careful lin a way that made Agatha’s breath catch even now.

Behind her, the apartment door clicked shut, but she could almost sense Rio still standing there, leaning in the doorway with that dazed, sweet smile.

Agatha let out a quiet breath.

Then a small, genuine smile found its way onto her face—one she didn’t have to force.

The street was quiet at this hour. A pale blue glow had begun to touch the horizon, the world just starting to wake. Agatha wrapped her cardigan tighter around herself and started toward the hospital.

She tried to focus on the shift ahead, on the charts and updates waiting for her. But her mind kept drifting back to the moment Rio kissed her back, soft and certain, like she wanted Agatha just as she was.

That thought settled somewhere deep inside her.

For months, she’d felt like she was unraveling one thread at a time. Pretending she was coping. 
Pretending she didn’t need anyone. Pretending that being strong meant being alone.

But tonight… something shifted.

Agatha slowed her pace, letting the realisation wash through her gently.

She could see herself getting better.

Not overnight.
 Not magically.
 Not without effort.

But she could picture it—a version of herself who wasn’t constantly braced for impact, who didn’t freeze at shadows from the past, who wasn’t carrying every burden alone.

And Rio… Rio made that feel possible.

Not because she fixed anything.
 But because she listened.
 Held her.
 Treated her like she was worth gentleness.
 Made space for her to be human.

Agatha’s chest warmed at the memory. Healing didn’t seem like a distant, unreachable thing anymore. It felt like something she could move toward, one careful step at a time.

Her phone buzzed softly in her pocket.

Rio.

Rio: Let me know when you get there. 

Please.

Agatha’s smile deepened.

She typed back,


Agatha: I’m okay. Walking in now.

 Thank you for… tonight.

She hesitated, then added,


Agatha: I’m glad I ended up with you.

She slipped her phone away and walked into the early morning calm with a steadier breath, a lighter heart, and the quiet certainty that she didn’t have to face any of this alone anymore.

 

Chapter 13

Agatha had barely stepped onto the ward when Billy practically skidded up to her, tablet in hand, eyes bright with curiosity.

“Dr. Harkness!” he said, slightly out of breath. 

“I heard you did an emergency appendectomy last night. On a kid! I can’t believe I missed it—I was off shift.”
 He made a dramatic groan. “The one time something exciting happens.”

Agatha paused.

The hallway smelled like the usual antiseptic and coffee. Nurses moved around her, machines beeped softly, and somewhere down the corridor someone laughed. It was all so normal.
 Too normal.

Her chest tightened.
 Just a little.
 The memory flashed again—the small body on the table, the sudden bleeding, her frozen hands.

Billy continued, oblivious. “Oh, and you still need to do the post-op checks on him this morning. I can grab his chart—”

For a moment, Agatha felt her breath shorten.
 A hint of the panic from the night before flickered at the edge of her mind.
 Not as sharp.
 Not overwhelming.
 But present.
 Waiting.

She stood very still.

And then— unbidden— the memory of Rio’s arms around her surfaced.

Warm.
 Steady.
 Safe.

The quiet rise and fall of Rio’s breathing beneath her cheek.
 The scent of cologne and something earthy and grounding.
 The gentle way Rio had whispered,  “I’ve got you.”

Agatha inhaled slowly.

Exhaled even slower.

The panic eased.

Not completely.
 But enough.

She looked at Billy, who was still talking a mile a minute, and for the first time in hours, not only did her chest loosen…

She smiled.

A small one, but real.

“Well,” she said, voice calm again, “let’s go then.”

Billy blinked, pleasantly surprised. “Really? Great! He’s in recovery. He’s doing fine—vitals stable all morning. I can’t wait to see the incision, your sutures are always so—”

“Teen,” she said with mild warning.

He snapped to attention. “Right. Professional. I am a professional.”

Agatha shook her head, amused despite herself, and walked beside him toward the recovery room.

Her steps felt lighter than they should have.

Because she wasn’t walking them alone, not really.

She carried Rio’s steadiness with her.

Agatha knocked softly before pushing open the door. Billy trailed behind her, clutching the chart like it was a golden ticket.

Inside, the recovery room was quiet except for the soft beeping of a monitor and the low hum of the air vent.
 The little boy—small, pale, barely five—sat curled up on the bed with his knees tucked to his chest. His mother sat beside him, eyes swollen and exhausted from a night of worry.

The moment Agatha stepped in, the boy’s chin wobbled and he let out a frightened sniffle.

The mother shot up, frazzled but polite. “Doctor Harkness. Thank you again for… everything. He’s just… he’s scared. He hasn’t stopped crying.”

Agatha softened instantly. “That’s alright. It’s been a very big day for him.”

She approached the bedside slowly, careful not to loom or rush.

“May I have a look at your belly?” she asked the boy gently.

He shook his head and whimpered, shrinking into his mother’s side.

Billy stepped forward, bright and earnest. “Hey, champ, it won’t hurt. Promise. Dr. Harkness stitched you up better than anyone.”

Agatha shot him a look, but the mother managed a tired smile.

She crouched down so she was eye-level with the boy. “You’re very brave,” she said softly. “I just need to make sure you’re healing well. That way you can go home sooner.”

The boy whimpered again, clutching the blanket. “I want Bear.”

The mother rubbed his back helplessly. “We can’t find his stuffed bear. He always sleeps with it. I didn’t think to grab another toy and now he’s terrified.”

Agatha felt something twist gently in her chest.

A missing bear.
 A frightened child.
 Hands shaking because the world suddenly felt too big.

She thought for a moment.
Then stood abruptly.

“I’ll be right back.”

Billy blinked. “Should I—?”

“Stay here,” she said, voice soft but firm.

She moved quickly down the hall, through the staff door, and into the locker room.

Her locker sat exactly as she’d left it that morning. She opened it and froze for just a second.

There, on the top shelf, sat the little white bunny with the brown spots.

The one Rio had chosen for her.
 The one she’d tucked away, telling herself she didn’t need it.

She touched one of the floppy ears with her fingertips. For a moment she hesitated—then she picked it up.

It felt soft and warm in her hands.

Perfect for a frightened child.

Agatha closed the locker gently and made her way back.

The mother looked up as Agatha returned, confusion flickering in her tired eyes.

Agatha approached the bed slowly and knelt again, holding out the stuffed bunny.

“I thought you could use a friend,” she said softly.

The little boy hiccuped mid-cry, his red eyes widening. He reached out with both hands like he couldn’t believe it was real. When his fingers curled around the rabbit’s soft ear, something in him shifted.

He hugged it instantly.

The crying stopped.

Completely.

The mother pressed her hands to her mouth, tears springing to her eyes. “Oh my god… thank you. You have no idea how much that means.”

Agatha allowed herself a small smile. “He needs comfort. That matters too.”

Billy leaned toward her and whispered, awe-struck, “Where did you get that?”

Agatha ignored him.

Instead, she checked the incision carefully while the little boy snuggled the rabbit into his chest, calmer now, breathing easier.

“You’re healing beautifully,” Agatha said quietly. “You did a very good job.”

He looked up at her over the bunny’s head and whispered, “Thank you, doctor.”

Then he hugged the rabbit tighter.

Agatha felt her chest warm in a way she wasn’t expecting—gentle, full, steady.

As she and Billy stepped out of the room, he whispered, “You’re gonna make me cry, Dr. H.”

Agatha shook her head, though her eyes softened. “Come on, Teen. We have rounds.”

But as they walked away, she let herself smile—small, private, full of something she hadn’t felt in a long time.

Hope.

By the time Agatha made it to Lilia’s room, the door was half-open and voices floated out into the hallway. She pushed it the rest of the way gently.

Sharon was there, perched on the edge of the chair with a cup of vending-machine coffee in hand. Lilia, sitting up in her bed, was halfway into her cardigan, clearly preparing to leave.

Agatha blinked, caught off-guard. “Sharon?”

Sharon looked up and smiled. “Oh Agatha dear, we were just talking about you.”

Lilia beamed. “Sharons giving me a ride home.”

Agatha stepped inside and instinctively reached for the chart at the foot of the bed. “You’re being discharged?”

Lilia smirked. “I told them I was sick of the food.”

Agatha scanned the papers so fast she nearly gave herself a papercut. “Who signed this?”

“Chief Romanoff,” Sharon answered, amused. “She swung by earlier.”

“Natasha gave her a clean bill of health?” Agatha repeated, flipping through a few more pages like the right answer might magically appear. “Already?”

“Almost clean,” Sharon corrected gently. “She wants her to take it easy for a few days. No heavy lifting, no stress, no overexerting herself.”

Agatha frowned. “That’s vague medical terminology.”

Lilia rolled her eyes and reached for her bag. “It means I’m fine, Agatha.”

Agatha planted a hand on the side of the bed, brow creasing. “You had a heart attack Lilia.”

“And I’m feeling better,” Lilia insisted, tying her cardigan. “I want to go home.”

Agatha didn’t look convinced. “Your labs were—”

“Normal,” Lilia cut in. “If they weren’t, Natasha wouldn’t have let me out. You know that.”

Agatha went silent, still staring at the chart as if it might betray some hidden danger.

Sharon leaned forward, voice gentle. “Don’t worry dear. She’ll be with me all day.”

Agatha’s shoulders loosened—barely—but enough.

Lilia reached out, catching Agatha’s hand with a light squeeze. “Sweetheart. I’m alright.”

Agatha inhaled slowly, letting the tension leak out of her posture. “I just… wanted to be sure.”

Lilia softened. “I know. And I love you for it. But I’m not going to crumble if I leave the building.”

Sharon stood, looping Lilia’s bag over her shoulder. “Besides, she’ll have me and a very large pot of soup. Nothing will happen.”

Agatha finally closed the chart and set it aside. “Fine,” she muttered, though she sounded more relieved than annoyed. “But call me if anything changes.”

Lilia smiled warmly at her. “I will.”

Agatha lingered another moment, scanning Lilia’s face and posture one last time, just to reassure herself.
Then she nodded, the worry easing just a little.

“Alright,” she said quietly. “Let’s get you home.”

After making sure Lilia was safely buckled into Sharons jeep, Agatha approached the nurses’ station with her chart tucked under her arm, the weight of a long day finally pressing into her shoulders. She was minutes away from being done, already thinking about going home to shower, change, and maybe text Rio again.

But then she saw them.

Wanda and Jen were standing at the counter in fresh scrubs, coffee cups in hand, clearly just starting their night shift. Wanda looked focused and ready. Jen looked… suspiciously energised.

And smug.
 Far too smug.

Agatha narrowed her eyes, immediately assuming the worst.

“Glad to see you’re both easing into your shift with some light gossip,” she said dryly.

Wanda blinked and exchanged a confused look with Jen. “Gossip?”

Jen’s smirk deepened. “Hello to you too, sunshine.”

Agatha planted a hand on her hip. “I’m sure you’ve already told half the hospital what you walked in on this morning.”

Wanda’s brows shot up in alarmed interest. “What exactly did she walk in on?”

Agatha froze.

Jen laughed under her breath, delighted. “Wow. You confessed that fast.”

“Shut up,” Agatha muttered, cheeks warming.

Wanda looked between them like she was watching a tennis match. “Should I be concerned?”

Jen held up one finger. “Let me clarify something before Agatha implodes. I didn’t tell anyone anything.”

Agatha huffed, unconvinced. “You were smirking when I arrived.”

“I smirk all the time,” Jen said. “It’s part of my charm.”

Wanda stepped closer to Agatha, curious. “So… what happened this morning?”

“Nothing,” Agatha said too quickly. “Absolutely nothing.”

Jen sipped her coffee loudly. “For the record, I would never share your personal business on the floor.” 
She nodded at Wanda. “You seem to be doing a great job sharing it yourself.”

Wanda gasped and turned fully toward Agatha. “Oh my god. Did something happen with Rio?”

Agatha flushed a deeper shade and took a strategic step backward. “I’m going home.”

Jen called after her, “Let me know if you need help digging the hole deeper!”

Wanda’s voice followed too, bright with excitement. “Agatha, wait, I didn’t get details!”

Agatha stepped out through the sliding doors, the cool evening air brushing against her skin like a reminder to breathe. Her shift was finally over, and she had a plan: go home, shower,  check on Lilia.

But as she crossed the parking lot, a familiar pressure crept into her chest.
 Small.
 Quiet.
 Anxiety in its earliest form, curling in her ribs the same way it had earlier when Billy mentioned the boy.

She paused beside her car, fingers curling lightly at her sides, trying to steady her breath. She could feel the tension building in her shoulders, that old instinct to brace herself.

Her phone buzzed.

The sound alone eased something.

She pulled it out and saw Rio’s name.

A selfie filled the screen.

Rio stood in the firehouse kitchen wearing her navy duty T-shirt, a wooden spoon in her hand and a pot bubbling on the stove behind her. There was a smear of flour on her cheek that she clearly hadn’t noticed. 

She looked tired, a little rumpled, but heartbreakingly warm and steady.

Her smile was crooked and teasing.

Rio: On dinner duty tonight. 

Made too much. 

Come get some before the crew inhales it like pack animals.

A laugh escaped Agatha before she could stop it.
 A real one.

The anxiety that had been gathering inside her dissolved a little, like someone had brushed away the edges of a storm cloud.

Another message arrived.

Rio: No pressure.

 Just thought of you could use some decent food.

Agatha closed her eyes for a moment.

She thought about the little boy that morning, shaking and terrified.


 How his entire world shifted into calm the second she handed him the stuffed rabbit.


 How his breathing evened, how he clung to it like it was the one safe thing in the room.

And then the thought slipped into her mind with quiet honesty-
For him, the rabbit had been comfort.

For her… Rio felt like that.

A steadying presence.


 A soft place to land.


 Warmth after a long night.


 The first thing in a long time that made her feel genuinely safe.

Her comfort.

Her stuffed bunny.

Agatha opened her eyes.

She looked at Rio’s selfie again, at the familiar warmth in her face, at the playful lift of her brow as she stirred whatever she was cooking for her crew. Something soft and certain settled in her chest.

She didn’t want to go home.

Not yet.

She wanted to see her.

Agatha typed back.

Agatha: Actually… I was thinking about you too.

I would like to see you.

Just for a bit, if thats okay?

Rio’s reply came immediately.

Rio: You were?


Yeah, of course. 


I’ll save you a plate.

 

Agatha smiled.

 

Agatha: I’m on my way.

 

She slipped her phone into her pocket, unlocked her car, and started the engine with a steadier heartbeat than she’d had all day.

She was going to the fire station.


 Because she wanted to see Rio.


 Because seeing Rio made everything feel lighter.


Because tonight, she needed her comfort too. 

 


Agatha stepped into the firehouse, the warm scent of garlic and tomatoes simmering on the stove drifting through the open garage bay. 

The low rumble of conversation and clatter of dishes carried from the crew lounge.

She walked inside, smoothing her cardigan without thinking.

Rio was in the kitchen, sleeves pushed up, a wooden spoon in hand. She was focused on the pot in front of her until she glanced up and—

Froze.

A flush crept up her neck so fast Agatha almost saw it rise.

“You… came,” Rio said softly, eyes brightening in a way that made Agatha’s chest warm.

Before Agatha could reply, two familiar voices erupted from the table.

Bucky shot up from his chair like someone had lit a match under him. “Well, look who finally shows their face!”

Tony dropped his fork, hand over his heart. “Dr Harkness, in our humble kitchen? Is this real? Someone pinch me.”

Agatha lifted an eyebrow, amused. “Hello, boys.”

Bucky swaggered over, arms wide. “Maybe now you’re here Rio will shut up talking about you.”

Tony joined him, smirking. “Yeah, Agatha this, Agatha that. Ice queen has really done a number on our ickle Vidal.”

Rio groaned. “Guys, please shut the fuck up.”

Bucky clapped her on the back. “Please. We’ve been waiting for this.”

Tony leaned in, whispering loudly to Agatha, “You know she threatened to fight me once because I said your hair looked nice?”

Rio’s eyes went wide. “Tony—!”

Agatha blinked, then smiled. “Well… he wasn’t wrong.”

Bucky barked a laugh. “Oh she’s smooth. No wonder you’re down bad, Vidal.”

Rio’s face was absolutely crimson. “Can you both go… anywhere else?”

They ignored her completely.

“It’s good to see you, Agatha,” Bucky said warmly. 

“Yeah,” Tony added, leaning casually against the counter. “Last time we saw you, Rio hadn’t defrosted you yet.”

Rio let out a suffering noise. “Oh my god.”

Agatha’s lips curved. “Well, things changed.”

Tony slapped Bucky’s arm. “See? A mature woman. Meanwhile Vidal over here nearly fainted when she got your text.”

Rio shoved him. “I did not—”

“She did,” Bucky confirmed.

Agatha hid a smile behind her hand.

Finally, Rio managed to cut through the chaos and stepped closer to her, voice gentler. “I saved you a bowl before they inhaled everything.”

From the table, Tony yelled, “Hey! We're not animals!”

Bucky added, “We are a little.”

Rio ignored them with exhausted affection and motioned Agatha closer to the stove. “It’s nothing fancy. But it’s warm.”

Agatha met her eyes. “I’m sure I’ll love it.”

Behind them, Tony whispered loudly, “She said love.”

Bucky let out a dramatic gasp. “Wedding bells. I hear them.”

Rio dropped her head into her hands. “I hate both of you so much.”

But Agatha saw the smile she was trying to hide.

Bucky noticed it too. “Alright, Vidal’s making that face. That’s our cue.”

Tony stood dramatically, grabbing his jacket. “Fine, let’s go do some actual work.”

Bucky added, “Or we can finish that fortnight campaign.”

Tony glared. “You’re on.”

They both waved as they headed toward the bay. “Have fun, lovebirds!”

Rio muttered, “I’m transferring stations,” but she sounded fond.

The moment the door swung shut behind them, the room quieted.

Rio handed Agatha a bowl and sat across from her. The dish smelled incredible—warm, rich, full of garlic and tomatoes, with soft dumpling-like pieces nestled in the sauce.

Agatha took a bite.

And nearly moaned.

She actually had to put the bowl down for a second, eyes fluttering closed. “What… what is this?”

Rio laughed softly, leaning her chin into her hand. “It’s called guiso de harina. A Puerto Rican stew. My abuela used to make it. Flour dumplings, sofrito, tomatoes, garlic, achiote… it’s simple but comforting.”

Agatha took another bite—slower this time, savouring it. “It’s delicious. I’ve never tasted anything like it.”

Rio smiled shyly. “I’m glad you like it.”

Agatha tilted her head, studying her with gentle curiosity. “Where are you from originally? Before Westview?”

Rio smiled softly. “Brooklyn was home for most of my life. But my family… we’re Puerto Rican.”

Agatha’s eyes warmed. “Puerto Rico?”

Rio nodded. “Yeah. My parents were from San Juan. They moved to New York when I was about three. Wanted better opportunities. Safer neighbourhoods. More stability, I guess.”

There was a beat—small, but heavy.

Agatha set her spoon down, sensing the shift. “Rio…?”

Rio drew in a breath, eyes drifting toward her bowl.

“They died,” she said quietly. “My parents. When I was ten. House fire. Wrong place, wrong time.” She swallowed, voice soft but steady. “I barely made it out.”

Agatha’s heart clenched. “Rio.”

Rio offered a small smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes. “My abuela came to take care of me after that. Moved states without blinking. She raised me. Taught me how to cook. Taught me how to be… decent.” 

She shrugged a little. “She was everything.”

Agatha reached across the table without thinking and took Rio’s hand. Rio looked at her, a little surprised, but didn’t pull away.

“I’m so sorry,” Agatha said softly.

Rio nodded once. “It was a long time ago. But… yeah. It shaped everything.”

Agatha squeezed her hand gently. “Is that why you became a firefighter?”

Rio looked down at their joined hands.

“Partly,” she admitted. “I think I wanted to be who I needed that night. Someone strong enough to pull people out. Someone who runs toward the flames, not away from them.” She exhaled. “Also… I hate feeling helpless.”

Agatha’s voice lowered. “You’re not helpless. You’re the opposite.”

Rio’s eyes lifted to her, soft and warm.

Agatha held her gaze. “And for what it’s worth… your parents would be proud. And your abuela too.”

Rio’s lip trembled just barely—nothing dramatic, just a flicker of emotion she usually kept hidden.

“Thank you,” she murmured.

Agatha stroked her thumb gently over Rio’s knuckles.

For a moment they simply sat there, their hands joined across the small firehouse table, the stew still warm between them, the buzz of the station distant and muted. It felt almost suspended in time.

Rio drew in a steadying breath and lifted her gaze. “Can I tell you something?”

Agatha nodded. “Of course.”

Rio hesitated—just a second—and then the truth slipped out, quiet and unpolished.

“I’m really glad you came tonight,” she said. “I didn’t expect you to. Part of me thought you’d go home, sleep, forget all about the chaos of last night.” Her voice softened. “But you didn’t.”

Agatha’s chest tightened. “I wanted to see you.”

Rio’s fingers curled a little tighter around hers at that.

“I can’t seem to stop thinking about you,” Rio admitted. “This is all new for me. These feelings. This… pull toward someone.” She looked almost shy saying it. “I’ve never felt anything like this before. Not with anyone.”

Agatha felt something warm bloom inside her, spreading slowly through her ribs, her throat, her cheeks. 

She hadn’t expected Rio to say it out loud. She hadn’t expected such openness, such gentle honesty.

She let their joined hands rest between them, her thumb tracing small circles over Rio’s skin.

“I feel the same,” Agatha said quietly.

Rio blinked, as if she wasn’t sure she’d heard right.

Agatha continued, her voice soft but certain. “You’ve changed everything for me. In ways I didn’t think were possible.” She inhaled, choosing her words carefully. “I’ve spent a long time being… closed off. Holding things together alone. Pretending I didn’t need anyone.”

Rio watched her, breath held.

“But then you,” Agatha whispered, “walked into my life. And somehow, without even trying, you made me feel… lighter. Safe. Like maybe I don’t have to brace myself for the worst all the time.”

Rio’s expression softened into something almost reverent.

“And last night,” Agatha went on, her voice barely above a hush, “when I fell apart in that OR… you were the only person I wanted to call. The only person I knew would understand without judgment.”

Rio exhaled slowly, her eyes shining with something deep and unmistakable.

“You make me believe I can get better,” Agatha finished. “You make me want to try.”

Rio leaned forward, forehead almost touching Agatha’s, her breath warm and steady.

“Agatha,” she whispered, “you already are.”

And Agatha, for the first time in years, felt it might be true.

Their hands were still intertwined on the table, warmth passing between their fingers in steady pulses.

Agatha felt Rio’s breath hitch — just the slightest tremble — as if she were holding something back. Something that wanted to move forward.

Agatha didn’t hesitate.

She leaned in.

Their lips met in a slow, deliberate kiss that felt like finally exhaling after holding her breath for far too long. Rio froze for only half a heartbeat before melting completely, her shoulders loosening, her hand lifting instinctively to cradle Agatha’s jaw.

Rio kissed her back with a soft certainty, as if she’d been waiting for this moment just as long. Agatha felt the warmth of Rio’s palm against her skin, grounding her, steadying her, pulling her closer without force — just pure intention.

Agatha’s free hand slipped to the back of Rio’s neck, fingertips threading gently into her hair. The kiss deepened by a fraction, their mouths moving together in a quiet, intimate rhythm that felt more like a confession than anything they had said aloud.

Rio let out a soft, breathy sound — part surprise, part relief — and Agatha felt it all the way down her spine.

When they finally separated, neither moved far.

Their noses brushed.


 Their breaths mingled.


 Agatha could feel Rio’s heartbeat under her fingertips.

Rio smiled first — small, dazed, entirely undone. “I don’t think I’ll ever get over how good that feels,” she whispered, voice warm and shaky.

Agatha brushed her thumb along Rio’s jaw, her own smile soft and full. “Yes,” she murmured. “Me too.”

Rio leaned in again, unable to stay apart for long.

And they kissed once more — slower, deeper, full of something steady and blooming, like the start of something neither of them could deny anymore.

 

Chapter 14

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Sunlight spilled softly through the lace curtains of Lilia’s bedroom, casting warm patterns across the floor. The house was quiet, the early-hour calm that Agatha secretly loved — the soft hum of the kettle, the scent of fresh tea leaves, the muted creak of old floorboards.

She carried a mug of Lilia’s favourite morning tea into her room, chamomile with ginger, honey, and a hintof lemon.

Lilia was already stirring, blinking awake with the gentle curiosity of someone who had never once woken up once grumpy in her life.

When she noticed Agatha standing at the bedside, her face brightened instantly. “Good morning, sweetheart.”

Agatha softened without even meaning to. “Good morning.”

Lilia pushed herself up carefully, settling against the pillows as Agatha handed her the tea. “You spoil me,” she said, smiling into the steam.

“You just got out of the hospital,” Agatha reminded her, sitting on the edge of the bed. “I’m allowed to be dote on you.”

Lilia took a long sip, humming appreciatively. “Mmm. Perfect. You always know exactly how much honey I need.”

“Too much,” Agatha said with a small laugh. “That will be changing by the way.”

Lilia’s eyes sparkled. “How are you feeling?”

Agatha looked down at her hands, folded neatly in her lap. “Fine,” she said automatically.

Lilia raised a brow.

Agatha sighed. “Better,” she corrected. “Much better.”

“And that,” Lilia said, setting her tea aside, “is wonderful to hear.”

Agatha hesitated.

Not long. Just a second.
 Long enough for Lilia’s expression to soften further.

“I think,” she began, voice quiet but steady, “I’d like to take your advice.”

Lilia’s smile widened with understanding before Agatha even finished.

“I think it’s time I spoke with the therapist you mentioned. Dr. Strange.”

Lilia reached for her hand immediately, lifting it gently between both of hers. “Oh, sweetheart. I’m so proud of you.”

Agatha’s shoulders eased. “I’m… ready. I think I need it.”

“You do,” Lilia said kindly, “and that’s not a failing. Recognising it is strength.”

Agatha nodded. “Will you help me contact him?”

“Of course I will,” Lilia said. “I’ll call his office today and set up an appointment.”

Agatha let out a quiet breath, one she hadn’t realised she’d been holding.

Lilia watched her for a moment, eyes soft and full of that quiet wisdom she wielded better than anyone. 

Then a slow smile curved her lips, one that told Agatha she’d been patient long enough.

“So,” Lilia said, tucking a strand of hair behind her ear with deliberate innocence, “are you finally going to tell me how your date went with Rio?”

Agatha blinked, caught completely off guard despite absolutely knowing this question was coming.

She looked down at her hands, suddenly very interested in the pattern of the duvet. “It was… nice.”

Lilia gave her a look. The try again, I wasn’t born yesterday look.

“Agatha Harkness,” she said, leaning forward with exaggerated anticipation, “I want details.”

Agatha felt the warmth rise to her cheeks before she could control it.

Lilia gasped softly, delighted. “Oh my god. You’re blushing.”

“I am not,” Agatha muttered.

“You absolutely are,” Lilia laughed, touching her arm. “Which means it went very well.”

Agatha lifted her gaze, the smallest smile playing at the corner of her mouth. “It did.”

Lilia clapped her hands once, triumphant. “Of course it did. She adores you.”

Agatha’s heart fluttered in a way she couldn’t quite hide. “I’m…fond of her too.”

Lilia squeezed her hand, glowing with pride. “Good. Then tell me everything over breakfast.”

After Lilia finished her tea and promised to call Dr. Strange, Agatha ushered her gently out of bed and into her favourite chair at the kitchen table. Lilia settled in easily, wrapped in her soft cardigan, looking far more alert than someone freshly discharged from the hospital should.

Agatha moved around the kitchen with familiar ease, her white t-shirt loose and soft against her frame, grey sweats sitting low on her hips. Her hair was down, slightly messy from sleep but still somehow neat, and a pair of thick-rimmed glasses rested on her nose. She looked softer than she ever tried to be, almost unknowingly gentle, and there was a small, quiet happiness about her that Lilia noticed immediately.

She pulled out eggs, butter, and a handful of herbs, heating the pan with practiced efficiency. The soft sizzle of melting butter filled the room, warm and comforting.

Lilia leaned back against the chair, watching her fondly. “You don’t have to fuss over me.”

Agatha cracked two eggs cleanly into a bowl. “I know. But I like feeding you for a change.”

Lilia smiled into her mug, eyes warm. “Then fuss away.”

Agatha whisked the eggs, trying not to let Lilia’s gaze fluster her, though she could feel the scrutiny. 

There was something different about her this morning. A looseness in her shoulders. A softness in the curve of her mouth. Her movements were lighter, almost content.

She poured the eggs into the pan, letting them cook slowly. The kitchen filled with the scent of butter and herbs, familiar and homey.

“So,” Lilia said casually, twisting her spoon between her fingers, “are you going to tell me about your date now?”

Agatha paused mid-stir, her expression tightening for just a moment before she shot Lilia a knowing look. “I knew you wouldn’t let that go.”

“Spill it Harkness,” Lilia said brightly. 

Agatha sighed, but there was softness to it. She pushed the eggs gently around the pan. “Fine.”

Lilia leaned forward, delighted.

Agatha plated the scrambled eggs and set them in front of Lilia before sitting across from her. She hesitated for a moment, smoothing the napkin on her lap.

“It was… good,” she said quietly. “Better than I expected. Better than I’ve had in a long time.”

Lilia took a bite, gesturing with her fork. “Tell me everything, and start from the beginning.”

Agatha’s lips curved. “Rio picked me up. She brought flowers. And she was… nervous.”

Lilia gasped. “Nervous? Well of course she was, you are terrifying sometimes sweetheart.”

Agatha huffed lightly. 

“She took me to a carnival. It was closed for the season, but she knew the owner from an inspection and called in a favour.”

Lilia’s eyes widened. “She rented out a carnival for you.”

“It wasn’t—” Agatha stopped. “Yes. Fine. She did.”

Lilia clapped lightly. “That is romance.”

Agatha’s smile deepened as she continued to tell Lilia about the different rides they went on.

“And afterward,” Agatha said softly, “we kissed. It felt… right.”

Lilia reached across the table and took Agatha’s hand in both of hers. Her voice softened. “And how do you feel today?”

Agatha thought about Rio’s messages.
 The fire station.
 The food.
 The kiss.
 The way Rio’s forehead had rested against hers afterward.

She swallowed. “Happy,” she admitted. “Scared. But… happy.”

Lilia squeezed her hand. “Sweetheart, that’s all I’ve ever wanted for you.”

Agatha blinked, touched. “I know.”

“And,” Lilia added gently, “she clearly makes you feel safe.”

Agatha didn’t deny it.

Because she finally knew it was true.

Lilia had just taken another bite of her eggs when a sound drifted faintly through the kitchen window—muffled voices, one of them unmistakably bright and chatty.

Agatha froze mid-sip of her tea, her brows knitting. “Do you hear that?”

Lilia grinned into her mug. “Oh, no. Sharon’s awake.”

Agatha stood halfway, peering out the window. “Who is she talking to t this hour?”

Lilia swiveled her spoon like a pointer. “Check the window.”

Agatha leaned closer to the glass and felt her breath catch.

Rio stood at the front path, still in her station sweats and boots, dark curls pulled back messily after her night shift. She held a small container of food in her hands—leftovers from her cooking the night before—and looked like she was trying very hard to smile politely as Sharon from next door gestured animatedly with both hands.

“It’s Rio?,” Lilia said, delighted. “Oh, that’s sweet.”

Agatha didn’t respond. She was too busy watching Rio’s face—earnest, tired, kind—while Sharon continued her enthusiastic saga about… whatever Sharon was always talking about.

Rio nodded politely every few seconds, but Agatha knew that look.

Trapped.

Lilia snorted. “If you don’t go out there, Sharon will keep her until dinner. Maybe tomorrow.”

Agatha stepped back from the window. “Rio’s fine. Sharon is harmless.”

Lilia raised an eyebrow. “Sharon once told me the entire genealogy of her cat. From memory. For thirty minutes.”

Agatha blinked. “She did that?”

“She still does that. Go save the poor girl before she learns the tragic backstory of Mr. Whiskerson.”

Agatha tried not to smile. She failed.

She tugged lightly at the hem of her white t-shirt, pushed her glasses up her nose, and brushed her messy-but-neat hair back from her face. Something fluttered in her chest—real, soft, impossible to ignore.

“Fine,” she said, pretending she was not already halfway to the door. “I’ll be five minutes.”

“Take your time,” Lilia called after her, thoroughly entertained. “Rio deserves a proper rescue.”

Agatha pressed her lips together, trying not to roll her eyes as she grabbed the doorknob. She was suddenly, acutely aware of her appearance — the loose white t-shirt, soft from dozens of washes, the grey sweats pooling comfortably at her ankles, her hair falling in a half-messy wave down her back, and the  glasses sliding slightly down her nose.

She didn’t look like Dr. Agatha Harkness.
 She looked… soft.
 Casual.
 Almost cozy.

The thought made her pause with a flutter of something she didn’t want to name.

Would Rio notice?
 Would she care?

Agatha inhaled and stepped outside.

The morning light caught her off guard — crisp, cool, and too honest. She cleared her throat and called, “Good morning, Sharon.”

Sharon whirled around instantly, bright as a spotlight. 

“Oh, Agatha! I was just telling your friend here about my cat’s gluten sensitivity. Did you know most people completely overlook—”

But Agatha hardly heard her.

Because her eyes found Rio.

And everything else faded.

Rio stood with her hair pulled back in a tired half-knot, loose curls escaping everywhere. Her station cargos hung low on her hips, her navy t-shirt wrinkled from the long night shift. There were faint shadows under her eyes, and she held a small plastic container in both hands as if it were a peace offering.

But what stopped Agatha was the expression.

Soft.
 Warm.
 Relieved.

Rio’s face brightened the moment Agatha appeared, so subtly and so sincerely it made Agatha’s breath catch.

And then came the embarrassment.

Because Rio was looking at her — really looking — and Agatha became hyper-aware of her bare face, her messy hair, her cozy clothes, the way her glasses sat crooked on her nose.

She had never felt more unpolished.

Or more seen.

Sharon continued rambling in the background, but Rio’s eyes kept darting toward Agatha, like she couldn’t help it. She shifted her weight, rubbing her thumb nervously over the lid of the container, trying not to stare.

Agatha’s heart warmed painfully.

Rio looked exhausted and beautiful in that effortless way only she could pull off. The kind of beautiful Agatha couldn’t quite breathe around.

And she was here.
 For her.

Dropping off food like it was the most natural thing in the world.

Agatha’s pulse fluttered, and her cheeks warmed despite her best effort to stay composed. She straightened her glasses and stepped closer, gently interrupting Sharon’s enthusiastic monologue about feline dietary restrictions.

“Sharon,” she said kindly, “I’m sure that’s fascinating, but Rio’s just gotten off a long shift. I’m afraid I’m stealing her for a moment.”

Rio let out a tiny, grateful breath.

Agatha didn’t miss it.
 And she didn’t pretend she didn’t enjoy being the one to save her.

Sharon nodded solemnly. “Of course, yes, yes. Rio dear, come back any time. I have photos of Mr. Whiskerson that you would just love.”

Rio managed a polite smile that looked like the last flicker of a dying candle. “I… would love that.”

Sharon finally disappeared inside.

The moment the door shut, Rio exhaled a long, dramatic breath. “You saved my life.”

Agatha crossed her arms, pretending she wasn’t beaming inside. “She does that.”

Rio lifted the container of food. “I brought you and Lilia leftovers. I figured you might not have eaten breakfast yet.”

Agatha looked down at it, something warm blooming low in her chest. “We have. But I’ll gladly eat again.”

Rio’s smile grew, shy and radiant all at once. “Good. I made too much.”

Agatha stepped closer without thinking. “You should go sleep, you look exhausted.”

Rio nodded. “I will. I just… wanted to see you.”

Agatha’s breath caught.

Her fingers brushed Rio’s for the briefest moment as she took the container. “I’m glad you did.”

Rio’s eyes softened, her exhaustion melting into something sweet. “Text me later?”

“Yes.” Agatha swallowed. “I will.”

Rio hesitated, then lifted her hand as if she might touch Agatha’s cheek—then stopped herself. “Okay. I’ll let you go... By the way, the glasses?” Rio made a gesture as if clutching her chest and biting her lip as she smirked walking backwards, causing Agatha to let out a snort, quickly covering her mouth in embarrassment.

Agatha watched her leave, heart aching in that new, overwhelming way she hadn’t yet learned how to navigate.

She lingered on the porch for a moment, then returned inside.

Lilia was waiting with the smuggest smile. “So. She brought you food.”

Agatha tried to look stern. “Not a word.”

Lilia sipped her tea. “I didn’t say anything.”

Agatha set the container down carefully, trying to ignore the way her hands were shaking.

But Lilia saw everything.

“Sweetheart,” she said softly, “you’re in deep.”

Agatha didn’t deny it.

Because she finally knew it was true.

 

 

 

 

 


Dr. Stephen Strange’s office was too quiet for Agatha’s liking — soft lighting, neatly shelved books, the faint scent of mint tea. Everything was curated for calm.

She hated it.

She sat rigidly in the leather chair, legs crossed, arms folded tight across her chest, as if she were preparing to survive a surgical panel, not therapy.

Strange reviewed her intake form, closed it gently, and looked up.

“Dr. Harkness. Thank you for coming.”

Agatha scoffed lightly. “Let’s not pretend this was entirely my idea.”

“Lilia scheduled it,” Strange said calmly. “But you arrived. That matters.”

Agatha lifted her chin a fraction, a small defensive gesture she didn’t even realise she made. She hated the implication that her showing up was some sort of fragile victory. “Please don’t try to butter me up.”

“Not my intention,” Strange replied, voice steady, professional. “Believe it or not, I’m on your side.”

Agatha didn’t answer. She wasn’t sure she believed that yet. She wasn’t sure she believed anyone was on her side. She sat very still, spine straight, shoulders squared, trying to look like someone who wasn’t quietly unraveling at the seams.

Strange folded his hands. “Let’s start with something simple. What brought you here today?”

Agatha’s jaw clenched. She looked away, inhaling slowly, trying to gather the pieces of herself into something sharp and unbreakable. Something she could present. Something he couldn’t see through.

She swallowed. “I had an… unstable moment at work. And I cannot afford for that to happen again.”

Her voice came out cooler than she intended, but underneath the calm was a tremor she couldn’t quite hide. 

The shame of it sat heavy in her chest.

Strange nodded as if this were familiar territory. “What kind of unstable moment?”

“A freeze,” Agatha said curtly. She could still feel the shock of it, the way her hands went useless, the operating room closing in around her. “During a procedure. A child’s procedure.”

Strange’s eyes softened—not pity, not condescension, just understanding. It unnerved her more than judgment would have.

She forced herself to continue, though her breath wavered at the edges. “My mind went somewhere it shouldn’t have. It compromised my focus. It compromised the room.”

“Did anyone get hurt?” Strange asked gently.

“No.” The word snapped out too fast. Too sharp. Too defensive. “Not this time.”

Not this time.
 The phrase echoed like a bruise.

Strange steepled his fingers. “But someone did once?”

Agatha’s throat constricted.

He didn’t push.
 He waited.

After a long moment, she said quietly, “His name was Nicky.”

Strange nodded. “Tell me about him.”

Agatha stared at her hands, fingers clasped tight until her knuckles blanched. She didn’t trust her voice at first. Her pulse thudded in her throat, and for a terrifying second she feared she wouldn’t be able to speak at all.

But she forced herself to breathe.

“He was… four,” she began, the number catching in her chest like a thorn. “He had a congenital heart defect. Multiple complications. He spent more time in the hospital than outside it.”

She felt the ache of those memories sink into her bones — the beeping machines, the small dinosaur pajamas, the stubborn bravery only children seem to possess. Her voice softened without permission.

Saying it aloud made the ache sharper. It made him real again, in the kind of way that hurt.

Strange nodded encouragingly. “Lilia told me only that you lost a patient in Boston. Nothing more.”

Agatha felt her spine loosen just slightly. “Good.”
 She didn’t want Lilia knowing the depth of it.
 She didn’t want anyone knowing, but now she was here, speaking about him in a room that suddenly felt too small.

Her expression hardened instantly, cold and precise — the mask she always reached for.

“No.”

Strange waited, still as stone.

Agatha swallowed, her throat tight. “They abandoned him. They didn’t want the… burden.” It hurt to say the word. “They left him at the hospital and never looked back.”

The memory made her chest twist — the day she realised his parents weren’t coming back. The way he asked for them less and less. The way she became the one he looked for in the doorway.

Strange’s voice was neutral but sincere. “That must have been incredibly difficult to navigate.”

Agatha let out a small, bitter laugh. “He deserved everything. And he had nothing. No family. No home.” 

Her eyes stung, vision shimmering. “Not even a chance.”

“You cared for him,” Strange said softly.

She nodded once, small and desperate. “Yes.”

“More than a surgeon normally would.”

Agatha froze.

Her breath stilled.
 Her heart lurched painfully once, like a blow.

Strange’s voice gentled further. “Did you consider caring for him permanently?”

Agatha inhaled sharply, the sound almost a gasp. She lowered her gaze, shame and longing mixing in her chest like a bruise.

A flood of memories crashed over her — looking up adoption protocols in secret, wondering what his room would look like, imagining the sound of him laughing somewhere other than a hospital.

“I wasn’t supposed to,” Agatha continued, her voice fraying. “It was unprofessional. Complicated. But he was alone. And I—”

Her voice cracked.

Strange’s tone softened into something reverent. “You loved him.”

Agatha closed her eyes.

Just long enough to breathe through the pain.

“Yes. So much.”

She blinked again, swallowing a tear before it could fall.

“He crashed in the OR,” she whispered. “Complications they couldn’t control. They tried everything. But he— he didn’t come back. And I... I wasn’t there.”

Her breath stuttered out, all jagged edges and guilt. She still felt it — the empty room after they told her, the sterile hallway she couldn’t walk down, the hollow space she never filled.

Strange’s voice remained steady. “And you’ve been carrying that alone ever since.”

Agatha nodded once, tightly, as if loosening her head even a fraction might make her fall apart.

But a name rose up anyway — warm, steady, impossible to ignore.

Rio.

Her warmth.
 Her steadiness.
 Her hands on Agatha’s shoulders when she couldn’t breathe.
 Her arms around her when she broke.
 Her voice whispering, I’ve got you.

Agatha swallowed. “One person. Maybe.”

Strange tilted his head. “Someone you trust?”

A quiet beat.

Agatha whispered, “I… think so.”

“Good,” Strange said. “Lean on them. Let them support you.”

Agatha’s breath wavered, her chest tightening in both fear and relief.

“I don’t like needing anyone,” she muttered, looking away. Needing made you vulnerable. Needing meant someone could disappear. Needing meant pain.

Strange gave her a small, knowing smile. “That’s why it terrifies you. Not because you’re weak but because you’re human.”

Agatha blinked rapidly, heat stinging behind her eyes. She refused to let the tears fall.

He waited, patient as ever.

Agatha hesitated.

Her fingers flexed in her lap. She never hesitated. She never faltered. She never allowed this kind of vulnerability to show.
 But Rio was different.

Her eyes lowered, voice soft and unguarded. “Her name is Rio.”

Strange nodded gently. “Tell me about her.”

Agatha’s throat tightened. She tried to speak clinically, the way she always did when something mattered too much.

“She’s… a firefighter. Competent. Level-headed. Calm under pressure.”

Strange hummed. “You respect her professionally.”

A breath. “Yes.”

“But that’s not what makes her the person you thought of,” Strange said, quieter now.

Agatha’s gaze darted away. “…No.”

Strange leaned back, giving her space. “So what is it about her?”

Agatha looked toward the window, searching for words in the light filtering through the blinds. The soft glow reminded her faintly of the mornings she’d woken from a rare good sleep — the kind she had recently begun to have after spending time with Rio. Warm. Gentle. Disarming.

Staying wasn’t something Agatha was used to. People either left or were taken. Rio did neither.

Strange nodded faintly. “And you trust her.”

The confession burst out of her before she could swallow it back. “…Yes.”

Her pulse jumped. She hadn’t meant to say that aloud. Trusting someone felt like holding a lit match too close to her palm.

Rio’s arms steadying her after the OR incident. 

Agatha trembling despite all her efforts to hide it. 

Rio whispering reassurances, quiet and grounding.

She swallowed. “Yes.”

“And how did she respond?” Strange asked.

Agatha exhaled shakily, closing her eyes to keep her composure. She remembered the softness in Rio’s touch, the way she had held her carefully, without pity, without judgment.

“Gently,” she whispered. “She held me. She didn’t make me feel… weak. Or broken. Or ridiculous. Just… grounded.”

Strange tilted his head. “It sounds like she offers you something you haven’t allowed yourself in a long time.”

Agatha opened her eyes, voice barely above a breath. “Peace.”

Strange didn’t change expression, but something softened in his posture — a recognition, a respect.

“And how do you feel when you’re with her?” he asked quietly.

Agatha stared at her hands, fingers curling in her lap. Her voice trembled with an honesty she wished she could hold back.

“Like I can breathe,” she whispered.

Strange nodded. “Then this person isn’t a crutch, Agatha. She’s a connection. A healthy one.”

Agatha blinked rapidly, her eyes shining. “I’m not used to needing anyone.”

“That’s not a flaw,” Strange said gently. “That’s a wound. One that’s healing.”

Agatha inhaled sharply, the truth of that cutting deep. She didn’t like how vulnerable it made her feel.

Strange watched her for a moment longer, then said, his tone measured but kind, “It’s natural to be afraid of caring again when you’ve lost someone. And it’s natural to feel anxious when someone you care for has a risky job. But fear is not evidence that something is wrong — only that something matters.”

Agatha’s breath faltered.
 Not because he was wrong.
 But because he was right — quietly, disarmingly right.

“Letting someone in doesn’t guarantee loss,” Strange continued softly. “It just allows you to feel again. And you’re allowed to feel, Agatha.”

A tear slipped down her cheek. She didn’t stop it this time.

Strange closed his notebook without looking down. “We can work on the rest. But for now… I’m glad you’re letting someone in.”

Agatha didn’t speak.

But for the first time that session, she didn’t fight the feeling in her chest.

She let it settle.

 

 

The door to Dr. Strange’s office clicked softly shut behind her.

Agatha stepped into the hallway, breathing in the cool air like she’d just surfaced from deep underwater. 

Her heels clicked down the polished floor, steady at first… then slower. Less sure.

By the time she reached the parking lot, her composure had begun to crack along the edges.

Not dramatically.
 Not visibly.

But in the way her fingers trembled when she reached into her pocket.

She opened her car door and sat in the driver’s seat without turning the engine on.

She just… sat.

Her hands shook once, sharply.

She swallowed hard.

And then she reached for her phone.

Her thumb hovered over Rio’s contact.

She pressed call.

Rio answered before the second ring.

Rio: “Hi, hermosa.”

The sound of her voice — warm, steady, familiar — made Agatha’s eyes sting.

She inhaled shakily. “I… I had my therapy session.”

Rio’s tone softened immediately. “Yeah?”

Agatha nodded even though Rio couldn’t see her. “I talked about him. More than I meant to.”

A pause. Not uncomfortable — just giving space.

Rio: “How do you feel?”

Agatha let out a trembling breath. “... I don’t know.”

More silence.
 But warm.

Then Rio asked, in a voice gentle enough to undo anyone:

Agatha closed her eyes. “No.”

Rio’s reply was soft but certain. “Come over. Alice is at Jen’s tonight. It’s quiet.”

Agatha’s breath hitched. She pulled the phone a little closer to her ear.

“Are you sure?” she whispered.

Rio: “I want you here.”

The crack in Agatha’s chest widened — not painful, just honest.

“Okay,” she breathed. “I’m coming.”

She lifted her hand to knock.

She didn’t get the chance.

A wash of warm light spilled out from the apartment — golden lamps, soft shadows, the faint smell of garlic and lingering spices from whatever Rio had cooked earlier. It felt like stepping into a pocket of warmth carved out of the world.

Rio took one look at her.

Agatha wasn’t crying. She wasn’t shaking. She looked… composed, but thinner around the edges. Like someone had quietly taken her apart and reassembled her with one piece missing. Unsteady in a way only someone who knew her could see.

Rio’s expression softened into something warm enough to melt steel.

“Hey,” she murmured, voice low and gentle, like she was afraid to startle her.

Agatha swallowed, trying to keep her breath from trembling. “Hi.”

Rio didn’t drag her into a hug.
 She didn’t rush her.
 She simply opened her arms — a quiet offer, patient and steady.

The embrace closed around her slowly, deliberately. Rio’s arms were strong but careful, like she was afraid she might break something delicate if she held too tightly. One hand slid up to cradle the back of Agatha’s head, her fingers threading into her hair with instinctive tenderness.

Her chest loosened almost painfully.

Rio didn’t speak.
 She didn’t ask questions.
 She anchored her with touch alone.

No words — just safety.

The apartment around them felt muted. The hum of the refrigerator. The soft tick of the wall clock. A lamp casting warm light across the couch. Plants in the corner. A half-folded blanket draped over the armrest. Home. Not hers, yet somehow… comforting.

After a long moment, Agatha whispered into Rio’s shoulder, “It was harder than I thought.”

Rio’s hand stroked gently through her hair, slow and soothing. “Of course it was,” she murmured. “You talked about something that mattered.”

Agatha shut her eyes. The truth of it stung. “He mattered.”

Rio pressed a soft kiss to the top of her head, almost instinctive. “I know.”

Agatha’s throat tightened again. She felt so exposed — and yet so held. “I didn’t expect it to feel like this.”

Rio pulled back just enough to see her face, her hands still resting warm on Agatha’s arms. “Like what?”

Agatha looked up into those steady brown eyes, soft and open and impossibly patient. Rio’s presence radiated warmth — not loud, not overwhelming, just a quiet light that made the tightness in Agatha’s chest ease for the first time all day.

“Like I’m allowed to breathe,” she whispered.

Rio’s smile was small, devastatingly tender. “You are.”

She took Agatha’s hand with a gentleness that wasn’t possessive, but invitational, guiding her toward the couch. They sank down together, the cushions dipping beneath their combined weight. Their knees brushed. The room glowed amber around them, soft and safe.

Rio traced slow circles over the back of Agatha’s hand, a grounding touch that steadied her pulse one heartbeat at a time.

“Tell me what happened,” she murmured. “Only what you want to.”

Agatha did.

Not in order.
 Not neatly.
 Not the way she usually explains things.

Just fragments, spoken in pieces — Nicky’s laughter.

The grief she’d buried under precision and perfectionism. 

Strange’s questions, gentle but cutting, peeling back layers she’d kept sealed for years.
Rio listened.
Every word.

 Every pause.

 Every crack in her voice.


She didn’t interrupt.

 Didn’t flinch.

 Didn’t look away.

She simply sat there, thumb moving in those slow, steady circles, holding space for Agatha to unravel and still remain whole.

When Agatha finally fell silent, her chest felt hollowed and full at the same time — like something had been torn open just enough to start healing.

Rio reached up and cupped her cheek, the pad of her thumb brushing lightly across her skin. The tenderness of it made Agatha’s breath catch, her body leaning instinctively into the touch she had spent years convincing herself she didn’t need.

“You didn’t deserve any of that alone,” Rio whispered.

Agatha’s eyes softened, vulnerability shining through the cracks she could no longer hide. “I’m trying not to be alone anymore.”

Her voice trembled — not with fear this time, but with the quiet truth of it.

Rio leaned in until their foreheads touched, her breath warm and steady. “You’re not.”

The words melted something inside Agatha, slow and impossibly warm.

“Rio,” she breathed.

Her own voice startled her — soft, trembling, pulled straight from somewhere deep she hadn’t touched in years. She felt Rio’s breath warm against her cheek, steady and patient, and something inside her chest fluttered painfully, like a door she’d kept locked was cracking open.

Rio’s eyes opened, dark and patient. “Yeah?”

Agatha tilted her head and kissed her.

Her heart leapt. For a split second she felt weightless — untethered — like the space between wanting and acting had disappeared too suddenly.

The first touch of their lips was soft, almost hesitant, more question than certainty. Agatha felt her own pulse flicker in her throat, terrified and wanting and overwhelmed.

Rio answered with a deeper one, warm and sure, and Agatha’s breath collapsed into her chest. She slid her fingers into Rio’s hair, surprised by its softness, by how naturally her hand curved around the back of Rio’s head. She pulled her closer without thinking, her body moving before her mind even caught up.

Rio’s hand found her waist, warm and solid, guiding her gently until there was no space left between them. Agatha felt the firmness of Rio’s arm, the deliberate steadiness of her touch — not demanding, not claiming, just holding her like she was something precious.

The kiss deepened, slow and unhurried, the kind that said more than words ever could. Agatha felt heat swell beneath her skin, felt her chest loosen in a way that bordered on dizzying. Her sigh ghosted against Rio’s lips — a small, involuntary sound she hadn’t meant to make — and Rio exhaled sharply at the sound, a quiet shiver running through her.

They paused only when breath demanded it, foreheads pressed together, lips still brushing, hearts stumbling in the same unsteady rhythm. Agatha’s fingers remained curled in Rio’s hair. She didn’t want to pull away. She didn’t want this to end.

Rio whispered, “Agatha…”

The sound of her name in Rio’s voice went straight through her, tightening something low in her stomach. Agatha’s voice came out steady, certain, grounded in a clarity she hadn’t expected. “Stay with me.”

Rio kissed her again—deep, reverent, full of everything she hadn’t found the words for. Agatha felt herself soften instantly, her hands tightening on Rio’s shoulders. “All night.”

Agatha pulled her close once more, pressing her face briefly into Rio’s neck, breathing in the warm, faintly smoky scent of her skin. For the first time in years, something inside her was shifting in the right direction. Something heavy loosening, something wounded beginning to trust.

And in that soft, quiet apartment, with the weight of grief starting to loosen and safety blooming around her, Agatha let herself fall into the one place she finally felt held.

Rio’s lips were still warm against Agatha’s neck when she pulled back, just enough to look at her.
 Breath mingled.
 Foreheads touching.
 Agatha’s pulse fluttered at the closeness, warmth pooling low in her stomach.
 The air felt thick, charged, trembling with something that had been building since the carnival, since the fire station, since that first shy text message under fluorescent hospital lights.

Rio brushed her thumb along Agatha’s cheek again, and Agatha leaned into it before she could think. The touch was gentle but certain, and it made her chest ache in a way that frightened her with its sweetness.
Rio whispered, voice barely there, “You’re sure?”

Agatha nodded once, slow and deliberate, her eyes never leaving Rio’s. She felt the yes form long before she said it aloud — soft, steady, real. “Yes.”

The word settled between them like a spark.

Rio kissed her again — even deeper this time, heat blooming instantly between their mouths. Agatha let out a soft, involuntary sound, something caught between a sigh and a surrender, and Rio shuddered at the sound, her fingers tightening on the fabric at Agatha’s waist as if she couldn’t help it.

Agatha tugged gently at the hem of Rio’s shirt, her fingertips skimming warm skin. Rio broke the kiss just long enough to pull it over her head, tossing it aside. Her skin was warm under Agatha’s hands — all soft muscle and gentle strength. Firefighter strength, earned strength. The kind of strength that could lift, hold, carry. The kind of strength that had held her together in the worst moment of her life.

Agatha traced her fingers along Rio’s shoulders, feeling the smooth heat of her skin, the quiet tension in her muscles, the way her breath hitched and a low sound vibrated in her chest — a sound that went straight through Agatha, tightening every nerve in her body.

And for a moment, just a moment, Agatha let herself feel everything she’d been too afraid to want.

Rio slid her hands up Agatha’s sides, under her blouse, fingertips gliding over skin that had rarely known such tenderness. Agatha inhaled sharply at the touch, her head tipping back slightly, exposing the elegant line of her throat.

Rio kissed her there.

Slow.
 Devoted.
 Like she was learning Agatha’s pulse by heart.

Agatha’s fingers curled into Rio’s hair, pulling her closer, her breath catching in little gasps each time Rio’s mouth moved lower, then returned to her lips in a needy, hungry kiss.

Clothes loosened between kisses.
 Buttons undone by unsteady fingers.
 The fabric of Agatha’s blouse fell from her shoulders.

Rio stopped.

Not in hesitation.
 In awe.

Her eyes swept over Agatha — not hungrily, but reverently, like she was seeing something she’d dreamed of touching and couldn’t believe was real.

“Beautiful,” Rio whispered, almost to herself.

Agatha felt the words like heat down her spine.

Rio kissed her again — slower now, deeper, hands framing Agatha’s face as if she were something precious. Agatha’s body pressed flush against hers, warmth meeting warmth, breath stuttering as Rio’s hands slid over her back, guiding her gently down onto the couch.

No rush.
 No frantic fumbling.
 Just two women finally giving in to a pull that had been drawing them together for weeks.

Rio settled above her, one hand braced beside Agatha’s head, the other smoothing along her waist, her hip, her thigh — mapping her slowly, carefully, like she was following the contours of something sacred.

Agatha arched into her touch instinctively, her breath breaking on a low, startled moan that Rio swallowed in a kiss so deep it made Agatha’s fingers tremble in her hair.

Rio murmured against her mouth, breathless, “Tell me if you want me to stop.”

Agatha’s answer was immediate — a soft, desperate whisper, “Don’t.”

Rio’s mouth traced a path along her jaw, her throat, her collarbone, while Agatha’s hands roamed over the muscles of Rio’s back, feeling each breath, each shiver, each moment of restraint and desire mingling between them.

Agatha’s leg slid around Rio’s waist, pulling her closer.

Rio groaned — a low, raw sound — and kissed her with a heat that made Agatha’s body light up.

Rio’s mouth was hot against Agatha’s throat, her teeth grazing skin that felt electric beneath her touch. Agatha arched into her, a sound escaping her that she’d never heard herself make before — needy, desperate, utterly undone.

“Rio,” she gasped, her fingers gripping Rio’s shoulders, pulling her closer. Rio's thigh pressed against Agatha's centre, sending a jolt of sensation throughout both of them.

Agatha reached for the waistband of Rio’s pants, her own fingers suddenly unsteady. “Off,” she murmured. “All of it. Now.”

Rio complied with a soft laugh, stepping out of her clothes and reaching for Agatha again. The press of their bare skin was almost too much — too good, too overwhelming. Agatha felt like she was drowning in sensation, in the heat of Rio’s body against hers.

Rio helped Agatha remove her own slacks, pulling down the smooth material over her long legs agonisingly slow.

They moved to the bed in a tangle of limbs, Rio pushing Agatha gently onto the soft sheets before following her down. The weight of her was perfect, grounding, exactly what Agatha needed. Rio’s mouth found hers again, kissing her with a hunger that matched Agatha’s own.

“Touch me,” Agatha pleaded against Rio’s lips. “Please, Rio. I need you.”

Rio’s hand slid between them, her touch gentle but sure as she palmed Agatha through her underwear. Agatha arched into the contact, a moan slipping out of her. “There,” she gasped. “Oh, God, Rio.”

Rio’s fingers moved in slow, deliberate circles, each movement sending sparks of pleasure through Agatha. “Así, cariño?” she murmured, capturing Agatha’s moans with her mouth.

Agatha couldn’t form words, could only nod and cling to Rio as she worked a kind of magic with her hands that Agatha had never experienced before. Rio’s touch was reverent, worshipful, as if Agatha were something precious to be cherished.

When Rio’s fingers finally slipped inside her underwear, Agatha nearly came off the bed. “Fuck,” she breathed, her nails digging into Rio’s back. Rio's fingers circling her clit with just the right amount of pressure. Agatha could feel every nerve in her body react to Rio's touch.

Rio complied, her fingers sliding inside Agatha with a gentleness that belied the intensity of the moment. Agatha tightened around her, her breath hitching with each slow, perfect thrust of Rio’s hand.

“You’re so wet,” Rio murmured, her lips against Agatha’s ear. “So perfect. God, Agatha, you feel incredible.”

Agatha’s hips moved with Rio’s hand, desperate for more, for everything Rio was willing to give as her thumb added the slightest pressure on her clit. “I’m close,” she managed to say, her voice trembling. “Rio, I’m—”

Rio caught her cries with her mouth as Agatha came apart, her body shaking with the force of her orgasm.


 It startled her — the intensity, the sudden vulnerability, the way her body trusted someone else enough to let go like that. It had been years since she’d let anyone see her like this, years since anyone had touched her with such care. 

She wasn’t used to being this open, this unguarded.

Rio held her through it, steadying her with warm hands and soft kisses, grounding her as her breath hitched and shivered. She didn’t rush Agatha’s trembling, didn’t pull away, didn’t let the moment dissolve into awkwardness or distance. She stayed right there, letting Agatha shake and gasp and come back to herself in her arms.

Her hand still moved inside Agatha until she begged her to stop, too sensitive to take any more.

They didn’t separate in the aftermath, their bodies still pressed together, skin to skin. Agatha felt weightless and heavy all at once, boneless against Rio, unable to remember the last time she’d felt this safe. Her legs were tangled with Rio’s, her face buried in the crook of Rio’s neck. She could feel Rio’s heartbeat against her chest — strong, steady, unhurried.

It anchored her. 

It soothed her. 

It terrified her in a beautiful way.

She hadn’t realised how much she’d missed being touched like this — not just physically, but with intention, with tenderness. With care. Rio’s warmth seeped into her like something she had been starved for, something she hadn’t let herself want for years.

The rest of the night unfolded in soft moans and whispered names, in tangled limbs and slow, unhurried exploration, in the kind of closeness that wasn’t about lust alone, but about trust — about choosing to be seen, to be held, to be loved.

Every time Rio touched her, Agatha felt something old inside her loosen.
 Every time Rio kissed her, she felt something bloom.
 Every time Rio whispered her name, she felt herself soften in ways she had forgotten were possible.

They didn’t rush.
 They didn’t hide.
 They let themselves feel everything.

And in the quiet between kisses, in Rio’s gentle hands and warm breath, Agatha felt a truth settle low and certain in her chest-
She wasn’t just wanted. 

She was cherished.

 

The room was dark when Agatha stirred. The soft hum of the air conditioner filled the quiet, joined by the faint glow of a streetlight filtering through the blinds and the warmth of another body pressed along her back.

For a moment, she didn’t quite remember where she was.

Then she felt it.

Rio’s arm.

Heavy, strong, warm, draped around her waist with the instinctive protectiveness of someone who held without thinking. Rio’s palm rested over Agatha’s stomach, fingers curled loosely, her thumb brushing unconsciously against her skin with every slow breath.

Agatha went very still.

Not because she was afraid, but because something inside her reacted like a quiet burst of awe.
She blinked into the dimness, letting her eyes adjust. Rio’s breath was soft against the back of her neck, warm and steady, grounding her in a way nothing else ever had. Agatha shifted a fraction, careful not to wake her. Rio didn’t stir. She only tucked her face closer into Agatha’s shoulder, tightening her hold in her sleep.

The movement made Agatha’s chest ache with a tenderness she wasn’t prepared for.

She looked down at the arm wrapped around her, familiar and warm. She traced Rio’s forearm lightly with her fingertips, memorising the shape of it. Muscle under softness. A faint scar on her bicep where Agatha had sutured her months ago. The sight made her breath catch.

She had never woken like this with anyone. Not this close. Not this held. Not this… safe.

A quiet exhale slipped from her lips.

She turned her head just enough to see Rio’s face in profile. Relaxed. Unguarded. Lips parted slightly in sleep. A curl had slipped loose across her cheek, and her usually expressive brow was peaceful and smooth.

She was beautiful like this. Soft in a way that made Agatha’s heart pull painfully.

Something shifted inside Agatha at the sight. Not sharp or frightening, but warm and gentle and somehow terrifying. Strange’s words from earlier drifted through her mind- this person isn’t a crutch, she’s a connection.

Agatha thought of the way Rio held her earlier, the way she listened without asking for anything in return, the way she never pushed, only stayed. She thought of Nicky, the grief she had carried alone for years, and how for the first time since losing him she didn’t feel like she had to carry everything by herself.

Her chest tightened with a truth she didn’t know how to hold.

She whispered the thought to herself before she could pull it back.

 

I think I could love her.

 

The realisation hit her like a jolt. Not soft, not warm, but sharp enough to steal her breath.

Love.

The word alone made her pulse stumble. Her chest tightened under Rio’s sleeping arm, and suddenly the dark room didn’t feel peaceful anymore. It felt too open. Too exposed. Her heart began to race, pounding in her ribs.

Love.

She had loved before. And she had lost.

Her mind skipped, jagged and quick, to the tiny hand she had once held in the Boston OR. To Nicky’s frightened eyes. To the way he clung to her coat every time she walked down the paediatric corridor. To the dinosaur stickers he insisted on putting on her ID badge.

She had loved him.
 She hadn’t admitted it then.
 She could hardly say it now without choking on the grief.

And still, she lost him.

Her breath shallowed, speeding up.

The room seemed to shrink around her.

Rio’s arm, warm and steady around her, suddenly felt like a weight she hadn’t earned the right to keep. Her fingers twitched within Rio’s hold, panic rising like a tide.

What was she doing?

What was she thinking?

Rio was a firefighter. A first responder. Someone who ran into danger when everyone else ran out.

Every siren.
