Every dispatch.

 Every emergency call.

Agatha’s stomach lurched, a sickening twist deep inside her. She was back in the hallway at Westview in an instant, hearing the overhead call blare through the corridor, the sharp tone of the radio, her body freezing mid-step as those awful words echoed again and again.

Firefighter down.

Her blood had gone cold in an instant. Her heart had clenched so tightly she thought it might stop. The memory washed over her now with crushing clarity.

How could she risk loving someone whose life carried that kind of danger?
 How could she let herself fall again when she knew exactly how it felt to lose someone she loved?

The thought made her press a shaking hand over her mouth, trying to muffle the harsh exhale that threatened to wake Rio.

Her eyes burned.

She stayed absolutely still against Rio’s chest, but her thoughts spiralled faster with each passing second.

 She couldn’t do this. She couldn’t lose again. She had barely survived it once. She wasn’t strong enough or whole enough to open herself to that kind of vulnerability again.

Rio deserved someone steadier, someone braver, someone who wouldn’t break at the sound of a siren.
A tear slipped down Agatha’s cheek before she could stop it.

Rio shifted in her sleep, unaware. Her arm tightened gently around Agatha in a protective hug, her face brushing closer to Agatha’s shoulder as if her body sensed something even in sleep. The warmth of the gesture made Agatha’s chest twist so sharply she almost gasped.

She closed her eyes and forced her breath to quiet, trying not to wake her, trying not to fall apart in the arms that held her so sweetly. She stayed silent, but inside she was fighting to stay above the rising tide of fear.

Because the truth was impossible to ignore now.

She could love Rio.

The thought was tender and terrifying and painfully real. And loving someone whose world could change with a single call felt like stepping toward a cliff she wasn’t sure she could survive.

She lay awake for a long time, trembling quietly while Rio held her close, completely unaware of the storm gathering under Agatha’s skin.

She blinked rapidly, drying her cheeks.

Then she told herself therapy would be enough. She told herself Dr. Strange could hold what Rio held now. She didn’t need this. She didn’t need her.

She repeated it because the alternative felt unbearable.

Agatha slowly began to peel herself away.

First, Rio’s fingers, slack in sleep around her hip.
 Then Rio’s arm, warm and heavy across her waist, which she lifted gently and eased down onto the mattress.

Rio murmured quietly in her sleep, shifting a little, and Agatha froze. Her breath caught. But Rio didn’t wake.

Agatha slipped carefully from the bed. She moved with the same silent precision she used in surgery, easing herself out from under Rio’s arm. The floor was cold under her feet, the shock of it grounding her just enough to keep going.

She gathered her clothes in silence, each movement deliberate and cautious. When she finished dressing, she stood in the doorway and looked back despite herself.

Rio lay curled in the sheets, peaceful and unaware, one hand reaching faintly toward the place where Agatha had been. Moonlight stretched across her bare shoulder, touching the soft lines of her sleeping face.

The sight made Agatha’s breath catch painfully.

She stepped closer without intending to and whispered, barely audible, “I’m sorry.”

Rio didn’t stir.

Agatha swallowed hard. “This is better,” she whispered to herself, though the words shook. “For both of us.”

But she didn’t believe it. Not really. 

Fear was simply louder than truth tonight.

She turned and opened the bedroom door with excruciating care. The living room felt colder than before, the shadows stretched long across the floor. The warmth of earlier had faded from the air.

She picked up her coat, her bag, her shoes. At the front door, her hand hovered on the knob for a long moment.

She allowed herself one last look down the hall.

One last breath.

 

I can’t love you. 

I can’t lose you.

I can’t survive that again.

 

The words stayed inside her, but they echoed like they had been spoken aloud.

Agatha stepped out into the hallway and pulled the door shut behind her. The quiet click sounded far too loud, too final.

She walked quickly down the hall, her pulse pounding, then down the stairs, her breath coming quicker as if distance alone might quiet the panic.

Outside, the night air was sharp and unforgiving. She wrapped her coat tighter around herself, trying to contain the trembling.

“It’s for the best,” she whispered.

But each step she took away from Rio felt like tearing out a stitch she hadn’t realised was keeping her together.

And Agatha Harkness, for all her brilliance, didn’t yet understand that running from this would hurt Rio.

And that it would hurt her even more.

 

Chapter End Notes

Oh Agatha ...

Chapter 15

The week that followed blurred into something cold and grey.

Agatha threw herself into work with the kind of obsessive precision that left no room to breathe. She took extra shifts. Stayed past the end of every one. Reviewed charts until the words bled together. Shadowed other surgeons. Oversaw three appendectomies and a gallbladder removal she didn’t even have to be in the building for.

She kept moving, kept working, kept doing because the moment she stopped, she felt too much.
Her phone buzzed constantly at first.

Rio: Are you okay? 

Rio: Did I say something wrong?

 Rio: Please don’t shut me out.

 Rio: Agatha?

Agatha didn’t open a single one.
By the third day, the messages slowed.
By the fourth, they stopped entirely.
Her call log showed fourteen missed calls.

 Then twelve more the next day.

 Then only two. 

Then none.

 

By day seven, Rio’s number stared from her screen in absolute silence.

Rio had stopped trying.

And that, more than anything, made Agatha’s chest constrict so sharply she had to sit down in the on-call room just to breathe.

She told herself this was safer.
 Protected.
 Necessary.

But her hands still shook every time she saw Rio’s name, and she still sturned her phone facedown on her desk like it was too bright to look at.

At home, she was barely there.

Lilia watched her with quiet worry. Agatha pretended not to see it.

“You’re never home anymore,” Lilia said softly one morning, still in her robe as Agatha grabbed her coat before the sun was fully up. “You’re working yourself into the ground.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha replied, too quickly.

“You’re not,” Lilia said gently. “Agatha, sweetheart… what happened?”

Agatha froze in the doorway, the question hitting exactly where she was weakest. Her throat tightened. Her skin felt too small for her body.

“I don’t want to talk about it,” she said, voice clipped.

“You haven’t spoken two full sentences to me in days,” Lilia continued, stepping closer. “You’re shutting me out. You’re shutting everyone out.”

Agatha straightened her coat collar. “I said I don’t want to talk about it.”

Lilia exhaled, almost flinching at how empty Agatha’s eyes looked. “Have you at least talked to Rio?”

Agatha’s jaw clenched. “Don’t.”

That was the end of that conversation.

Lilia didn’t push again.
 But she watched her.
 And Agatha felt every inch of that gaze like pressure on a cracked rib.

She went to Dr. Strange every two or three days.

She sat in his office with her arms folded tightly, spine rigid, answering his questions with clipped precision.

Strange would ask how she felt.

She would say, “Fine.”

He would say, “You’re not fine.”

She would stare at the floor until her eyes burned.

He was patient.
 Too patient.
 The kind of patient that made Agatha want to scream because it felt too much like the patience Rio had shown her.

Strange asked once, “Have you reached out to the person who made you feel safe?”

Agatha’s breath snagged.
 Her eyes flinched away.
 She shook her head.

He studied her carefully. “And does keeping your distance feel safer than admitting you care?”

Agatha didn’t answer.

She didn’t have to — he could read the war in her eyes.

 

At the hospital, people noticed.

Billy mentioned once, “You know, you’re here so much I’m pretty sure you live in the on-call room.”

Agatha had simply stared at him until he backed away.

Wanda tried checking in during a shift change. “You look exhausted. You sleeping at all?”

“I’m fine,” Agatha said again, too sharp.

Jen raised an eyebrow at her in passing. “You’re pushing yourself too hard, Harkness.”

Agatha didn’t slow down.
 She didn’t even pretend to.

She just kept burying herself deeper in work, letting the hospital swallow her whole.

Because it was easier to face complications in the OR than to face the empty space beside her in bed.
 Easier to scrub in than to confront the echo of Rio’s voice in her head.
 Easier to talk to Dr. Strange about grief than to admit she had created a new one herself.

After a particularly slow morning, EMTs rolled in a stretcher, voices clipped and efficient, and leading the handover was Alice.

Hair pulled back, uniform rumpled from a long shift, latex gloves snapped high on her wrists. She moved with the same calm competence Agatha had always admired. But the moment her eyes landed on Agatha, something tightened in her expression.

“Dr. Harkness,” Alice said, voice steady but cool.

Agatha nodded once. “What do we have?”

Alice gave a brisk report as they walked. “Fifty two year old male. Chest pain radiating to left arm, diaphoretic, pale. BP ninety over sixty. Possible MI.”

Agatha was already pulling on gloves, mind sharpening. “Get him on leads. Prepare for asrpirin and nitro. Page cardiology.”

They worked in sync without speaking.
 Alice handed over vitals.
 Agatha issued orders.
 The room hummed.

When the patient was stabilised and transferred to cardiology, Agatha pulled off her gloves and turned to step away—
“Aga— Dr. Harkness. Wait.”

Alice’s voice stopped her cold.

Agatha froze, her spine stiffening. “Yes?”

Alice stepped closer, lowering her voice, careful to keep it between them. Her eyes searched Agatha’s face — not unkind, but unflinchingly direct.

“I’m going to be honest with you,” Alice said quietly. “You look awful.”

Agatha’s jaw clenched. “Well thanks, I’ve been working.”

“You’ve been hiding.” Alice folded her arms. “And Rio’s been… a mess.”

The words hit Agatha so hard she felt her balance shift.

“Alice,” she warned.

“No,” Alice said softly, shaking her head. “I’m not trying to pry. I don’t even know what happened. Rio won’t tell me.” She exhaled, the worry in her expression unmistakable. “All I know is she’s barely sleeping. She’s quieter. She’s… hurting.”

Agatha’s breath hitched despite her best efforts to keep her face composed.

Alice softened, her tone losing its edge. “And you’re walking around here like a ghost. So whatever happened between you two? I hope you talk about it. Because this—” she gestured gently between them “—is clearly making you both miserable.”

Agatha swallowed hard, vision blurring for a heartbeat. She kept her eyes on the chart in her hand, pretending the words didn’t land exactly where her chest already ached.

“Alice,” she said quietly, “I can’t—”

Alice held up a hand. “I’m not asking for details. I’m not choosing sides. I just… care about both of you. And it’s obvious this isn’t good for either of you.”

Agatha felt something crack — not open, but inward, a collapsing feeling she couldn’t breathe around.

Alice hesitated, then added gently, “You didn’t lose her on purpose. I get that. But maybe don’t pretend you don’t miss her. I can see it. Everyone can.”

Agatha forced her throat to work. “I have to get back to work.”

“I know,” Alice said, stepping back. “Just… think about what I said.”

Agatha turned, trying to walk steadily back toward the nurses’ station.

But her eyes burned.
 Her heart pounded.
 And for the first time all week, she felt the truth clawing up her throat like it wanted out.

She missed Rio.
 Every day.

 Every night. 

Every silence.

And pretending she didn’t wasn’t saving her.

It was breaking her.

Agatha didn’t remember walking to the on-call room.
 Her legs carried her there on instinct, the same way they did after difficult surgeries or panic attacks she refused to acknowledge.
 She shut the door behind her quietly, the soft click echoing much too loudly in the empty space.

The room was dim, lit only by a single fluorescent panel humming overhead. The cot in the corner was still rumpled from whoever slept there last. Someone had left a half-finished bottle of water on the desk. 

The air felt stale. Claustrophobic.

Agatha leaned against the wall and closed her eyes.

Alice’s words replayed in her head like a heartbeat she could not escape.

Rio’s been a mess.
 You’re miserable too.
 This isn’t good for either of you.

Agatha pressed her fingers into her temples, forcing her breath steady.

It was for the best.
 She had to believe that. 

She had to.

She walked toward the cot and sat down slowly, elbows on her knees, her hands clasped so tightly her knuckles ached. Her pulse raced in her throat.

Rio will be fine.


 Rio was strong. Resilient. Surrounded by people who loved her.
 Alice. The station crew. The community. Everyone adored her.

She didn’t need Agatha.

She would get over this quickly — she would.
 Rio was warm and good and brave. People gravitated toward her.

She deserved someone who didn’t flinch at sirens or freeze at the word love. Someone who wasn’t held together with old grief and freshly opened wounds.

Someone who didn’t run.

Agatha exhaled shakily and pressed her palms into her eyes until stars burst behind them.

She told herself she was protecting Rio.
 Protecting both of them.

If she pulled away now — before she fell any further, before Rio saw the full extent of the cracks inside her, before the love blooming so painfully in her chest became something undeniable — maybe she could spare them both the inevitable loss.

Maybe she could save Rio from the parts of her that were still broken.

Maybe she could save herself from breaking again.

Her voice wavered into the quiet, barely audible.
 “It’s better this way.”

She said it again, firmer.
 “It’s for the best.”

But the words rang hollow.
 So hollow they echoed.

Agatha folded forward, her hands sliding into her hair, tugging slightly as if pain could anchor her. Her breath shook. She felt the pressure in her chest build and build until it hurt to inhale.

She tried to picture Rio moving on — smiling, laughing at the station, teasing Tony or Bucky, cooking for her crew, being soft with someone new someday.

The thought tore through her like something sharp and merciless.

She’ll be fine without me. 

She will. 

Agatha swallowed painfully.

But she wasn’t fine without Rio.

Every night she lay awake, reaching instinctively for warmth that wasn’t there.
 Every morning she woke aching, the bed cold and too big.
 Every shift she expected Rio to walk through the ER doors and flash that shy, crooked grin.

Every silence hurt.

Agatha pressed both hands to her face, willing the tears not to fall.

“Don’t do this,” she whispered to herself. “Don’t fall apart.”

Her voice cracked.

Because the truth was so much simpler, so much harder.

She missed Rio.
 More than she had any right to.

And no amount of work or distance or lies whispered into dim on-call rooms could protect her from that.

Agatha sat there for a long time, trembling quietly, holding herself together with sheer force of will, because if she let herself break, she wasn’t sure she would stop.

And still, the truth pulsed beneath every breath-
Letting Rio go wasn’t protecting her.


It was destroying her.

 

 

Later as she stood by the nurses’ station, it was too quiet.

Too full of the kind of silence that let thoughts creep in unnvited—thoughts with warm brown eyes and a voice Agatha kept hearing in empty hallways when she was tired enough.

She stared at a chart she wasn’t reading.

Wanda stood beside her with a coffee cup, observing her with that unnervingly perceptive tilt of the head she had perfected.

Before either could speak—

A blur of gold shot past the nurses’ station.

A therapy dog. 

A golden retriever. 

Off leash.

But Agatha didn’t register “therapy dog.”

 She registered memory.

She had seen that same dog before—weeks ago.

 On the afternoon Rio had crouched on the children’s ward floor, laughing as a toddler put stickers on her turnout jacket while the dog nudged at her elbow affectionately.

Her heart lurched.

“Wanda,” Agatha whispered, eyes wide. “That’s— that’s the dog.”

Wanda blinked. “A dog, yes.”

“No. The dog. The one Rio brought during her visit here.”

Wanda’s eyebrows climbed. “And what are you thinking?”

Agatha’s breath hitched. “That she might be here.”

Wanda’s lips twitched. “Ah.”

Agatha’s pulse began to race. She tried to mask it by standing straighter, smoothing her lab coat but her hands were trembling slightly.

What if Rio was nearby? 

What would she say?

 What would she do?

Wanda, of course, noticed everything.

“No reason to panic,” Wanda murmured. “It might just be a random patients dog.”

But Agatha was already spiralling inward.
Then—
“HEY—STOP—COME BACK—no, not that way, please—SHIT—!”

A young man in a navy firefighter uniform came skidding around the corner, chasing the retriever like his life depended on it.

Agatha froze.

Her heart dropped so fast it could’ve hit the floor.

Not Rio.

The disappointment was so sharp it caught her off guard.

Wanda saw all of it. 

The flicker of hope. 

The quick collapse. 

The tight swallow. 

The shift of her shoulders trying to hide the impact.

She raised a brow in quiet sympathy for the woman holding herself together with sheer willpower.

The firefighter stumbled to a stop in front of them, panting. “I—I’m—sorry—he got—out of the harness.”

Wanda hid her smile behind her coffee cup.

Agatha crossed her arms, trying desperately to regain any sense of dignity. “Who are you and why is that animal running loose in my hospital?”

The firefighter snapped upright. “I—I’m Peter! Parker. Firefighter Parker. New recruit at Station 24!”

Station 24.

 Rio’s station.

Agatha’s chest squeezed.

Peter suddenly noticed her ID badge. His eyes went huge.

“Oh no,” he whispered. “Oh no, no, no… you’re the Doctor ”

Agatha arched a brow. “Is that a problem for you?”

Peter swallowed hard. “Um. Only because—Lieutenant Vidal—I mean, Rio, she’s kind of been…”

Wanda leaned in, eyes gleaming. “Go on.”

Peter winced. “Talking about you…A lot.”

Agatha went very still.

“I mean not like a lot a lot,” Peter rushed, panicked, “but Tony was making fun of her because she—uh—really respects you and—uh—she’s been kinda moping and—OH GOD PLEASE DON’T TELL HER I SAID THAT.”

Wanda outright snorted into her coffee.

Agatha’s face heated. “Peter. Enough.”

“Yes ma’am!”
 He scooped up the retriever—who happily licked his face—and sprinted away like he feared for his life.

When he was gone, Wanda turned to Agatha, arms crossed and smirk firmly in place.

“You nearly fainted when that dog ran by,” she observed.

“I did not faint.”

“I said nearly.”

Agatha glared at her chart. “You’re imagining things.”

Wanda sipped her coffee. “And you miss her.”

Agatha’s throat tightened.

Her eyes flicked to where the dog had run, then back to the chart she still hadn’t read.

“I don’t,” she said quietly.

But Wanda only smiled that soft, knowing smile.

“Sure, Jan.”

 


Near the end of her shift, the trauma bay doors swung open just before sunset, EMT radios crackling, nurses sprinting to meet the stretchers.

Two ambulances arrived at once — the aftermath of a violent MVC.

Kate Bishop pushed the stretcher carrying a clearly inebriated man toward Agatha, her jaw tight, hair sticking to her forehead from the frantic ride in.

She caught Agatha’s eye and leaned in close enough that only she could hear.

“Ralph Bohner, small laceration to the head,” Kate murmured quietly. “He caused the whole crash. Blew a .19 on scene. Total asshole. Cops want to speak to him once you give the all clear. Good luck.”

Agatha exhaled sharply.

Perfect.

“Thanks, Kate,” she said, voice clipped.

Kate gave a sympathetic wince before peeling off to assist elsewhere.

Across the bay, nurses rushed the elderly couple—both in genuinely critical condition—to separate trauma rooms. Officers hovered near the doors, getting statements from rattled witnesses.

Jen powered toward the older woman, voice steady and commanding. Another Doctor took the elderly man. The room thrummed with urgency.

Agatha turned back to the patient, scanning the chart handed over by Kate-

 Ralph Bohner.

Mid-forties. Drunk. Smirking. 

Zero remorse.

Of course he was the one who walked away practically uninjured.

“Mr. Bohner,” Agatha said briskly, snapping into autopilot professionalism. “Let’s take a look.”

He grinned sloppily. “Hey, pretty lady. Lucky me getting your hands all over me.”

“Sit still,” Agatha said without missing a beat. “Your laceration needs cleaning.”

He winked. “I’m into that.”

Kate was right, he was a complete asshole.

Agatha bit back the urge to roll her eyes and began irrigating the wound.

Behind her, she heard movement — paramedics shifting gear, cops murmuring, the rustle of gurney sheets — and beneath all the chaos, she registered one familiar voice.

One heartbeat she wished she didn’t still know by instinct.

Rio was somewhere in the room.

Her pulse jittered, but she didn’t look.

She kept her attention on the wound.

“Hold still,” she said evenly. “You’re making this harder than it needs to be.”

He snorted. “Honey, I like it when a woman makes it hard.”

Billy muffled a laugh from across the bay.

Agatha reached for gauze on the counter behind her.

And that was when Ralph reached out.

A hand.

 A full palm.

 Blatantly grabbing her backside.

Agatha froze, breath catching sharp and fast in her throat.

Ralph chuckled. “Couldn’t help myself.”

It happened in less than a second.

Before Agatha even turned—

Rio moved.

She wasn’t just fast — she was feral.

One second Ralph was grinning.

The next, Rio had him by the shirt, ripped him forward so fast the bed creaked, and—
CRACK.

Her fist connected with his jaw.

Ralph flew backward onto the gurney, eyes rolling back, unconscious before his head hit the pillow.

The entire trauma bay went dead silent.

Even the monitors blipped quieter.

Kate froze mid-step, eyes wide.

 Billy whispered, “Holy shit…”

 Jen looked up from her patient and muttered, “Jesus Christ.”

 The officer blinked like someone had just slapped him.

Rio stood over the bed, chest heaving, jaw tight, hand still curled from the punch.

Then she lifted her eyes.

Straight to Agatha.

Only Agatha.

Nothing in the world existed for her except the woman standing a few feet away, shaken, violated, and trying desperately not to show it.

Rio’s voice was low and ragged. “He touched you.”

Agatha’s mouth parted, but she couldn’t speak.

Rio stepped closer, eyes flicking down Agatha’s body—checking for injury—then back up.

“You’re not okay,” Rio said quietly.

It wasn’t a question. 

It wasn’t an accusation. 

It was pain.

 And protectiveness.

 And everything Agatha had run from for a week.

Agatha swallowed. “I’m fine.”

“You’re not,” Rio said again.

An officer tentatively spoke up. “Lt. Vidal… technically that was assault.”

Rio didn’t look at him. “Then arrest me.”

Agatha’s breath hitched.

The officer shook his head quickly. “We’re not arresting you. He assaulted her.”

“Then we’re done here,” Rio said, still staring only at Agatha.

The trauma bay was silent again.

Utterly, painfully silent.

Rio didn’t move. 

Agatha didn’t move.

They simply stood there — a few feet apart, but it felt like a chasm.

Rio’s chest rose and fell, still tight from adrenaline. Her jaw flexed once. Her eyes… God, her eyes were swimming with something raw.

Hurt.

 Confusion.

 A plea she wasn’t saying out loud.

Agatha felt it like a punch to the sternum.

 She opened her mouth.

Say something. 

Anything. 

Explain. 

Apologise. 

Reach for her.

Her throat locked.

Nothing came out.

She could feel every eye in the room on them, but all she saw was Rio.

 Rio, who looked like she had been drowning for days.

Rio’s gaze searched hers, desperate for even the smallest anchor — a word, a gesture, a sign that she hadn’t imagined everything between them.

Agatha’s lips parted again…

Still nothing.

Her tongue felt too heavy.

 Her heart too loud.

 Her fear too sharp.

Rio’s brows pulled together, the hurt deepening.

 She swallowed hard, looking like someone had slipped a knife under her ribs.

Then — finally — she broke the stare.

It was subtle. 

Barely a shift. 

But to Agatha it felt like the ground giving way.

Rio looked away.

Her shoulders tensed, chin lifting as if bracing for impact she’d been waiting on all week.

And without another word, she turned.

She walked past the officers.

 Past Kate. 

Past Alice calling after her.

 Past Billy, who stood frozen with a chart in his hands.

She didn’t look back.

The ER doors opened automatically as she approached, the fluorescent light washing her in pale blue before she disappeared through them.

They slid shut behind her with a soft hiss.

And Agatha stood rooted to the spot, breath stuck somewhere high in her chest, the echo of that door closing hitting her harder than any punch Ralph Bohner could have taken.

Because it sounded final.

It sounded like she had just lost something she hadn’t even given herself permission to keep.

And the worst part?

She had done it to herself.

 

 


Agatha didn’t remember calling the number.

One moment she was standing in the on-call room, shaking, again, with Rio’s face etched in her memory, broken and morose.

The next, she was sitting in Dr. Strange’s office again — hours earlier than her usual appointment, the evening sun barely touching the blinds.

Strange looked up from his desk as she entered.

She didn’t bother with greetings.

She stood there—rigid, pale, her hands trembling at her sides—and said in a voice that was far too calm-
“I need help.”

Strange didn’t blink. “Sit.”

She sat.

Her shoulders didn’t relax. Her spine stayed straight as a blade. She clasped her hands so tightly her knuckles went white.

Strange watched her for a long moment before speaking.

“What happened?”

Agatha stared ahead, not at him, not at anything. “I saw her today.”

Strange didn’t need clarification. “Rio.”

Agatha swallowed, breath catching. “She was here. On a trauma call. She… intervened. And she—”

Her voice broke and she looked away sharply, as if humiliation alone could kill her.

Strange leaned back in his chair, expression neutral but attentive. “Agatha, slow down.”

“I can’t,” she said, too quickly. “If I slow down I will fall apart.”

Strange folded his hands on his knee. “Then fall apart. That’s why you’re here.”

She shot him a glare—defensive, brittle. “I don’t have time for that. I have a job. Responsibilities. I can’t just—”

“Break?” Strange offered.

“Yes,” she snapped.

Strange nodded. “And what did you do instead?”

Agatha stiffened. “I left.”

“Left her?”

Her eyes flashed. “Stop saying her name like—like—”

“Like she matters?” Strange countered.

Agatha’s breath hitched.

The room went quiet.

Strange lowered his voice. “Start from the beginning.”

She didn’t want to.

But something cracked.

 She exhaled, slow and uneven.

“She was in the ER today,” she said quietly.

“Assisting a trauma case. The… the drunk driver grabbed me. Rio saw. She…” Her throat tightened. “She hit him.”

Strange raised an eyebrow but didn’t comment on the punch. “How did you feel when you saw her?”

Agatha laughed—a single, hollow sound. “Like someone had pulled all the air out of the room.”

Strange nodded. “Because you miss her.”

Her jaw tightened.

Strange was relentless. “You miss her, Agatha. You miss her terribly.”

Agatha’s eyes burned. “I shouldn’t.”

“Why?” Strange asked softly.

“Because I left,” she whispered. “I ran. I abandoned her. I hurt her.”

“Why did you run?”

Agatha pressed a shaking hand to her mouth.

“Because I’m falling in love with her.”

The confession slipped out like a wound tearing open.

She blinked rapidly, ashamed of the tears collecting in her eyes.

Strange let the silence hold for a moment before speaking.

“And love scares you.”

Agatha’s voice trembled. “It destroys me.”

Strange’s expression softened—just barely.

“Love didn’t destroy you, Agatha. Loss did. Trauma did. And now you’re punishing yourself for wanting connection again.”

Agatha stared at him, breath shaking. “I thought staying away was protecting her.”

Strange raised an eyebrow. “Is she safer without you?”

Agatha opened her mouth—then closed it.

“Is she safer?” he repeated.

Agatha tried again. “She’s… she’s strong. She has people. She’ll be fine.”

“Is that why you’re avoiding her?” Strange asked. “Or is it because you’re terrified she won’t be fine?”

Agatha froze.

Because that was the truth.

She whispered, “I don’t want to lose her. And I don’t think I could… survive that.”

Strange nodded once. “There it is.”

Agatha’s eyes filled completely this time.

Strange leaned forward, voice steady but piercing.

“Agatha, you are grieving a child. And now you are afraid to love anyone who could hurt you by leaving—through death, through danger, through rejection. You are letting fear decide for you.”

Agatha’s breath broke. “I thought I was protecting her.”

Strange shook his head. “No. You were protecting yourself.”

The words hit her with brutal clarity.
 She flinched.

Strange continued, unyielding. “Avoidance doesn’t stop pain, Agatha. It only delays it. You are hurting her. And you are hurting yourself. And for what?”

Agatha whispered, “To feel safe.”

“Does this feel safe?” Strange asked.

Her chin wobbled. “No.”

“Are you happier now than you were when she held you after your panic attack?”

“No,” she whispered.

“Do you sleep better without her?”

“…no.”

“Does the world feel steadier without her presence?”

A tear slipped down her cheek.

“No.”

Strange softened, just slightly. “Then tell me, Agatha—why are you running?”

Agatha wiped her face with shaking fingers. “Because I don’t know how to be loved without losing someone.”

Strange nodded. “Then learn. With her. Don’t throw away something real because of ghosts.”

Agatha swallowed hard.

Strange sat back, letting the words settle.

“You still have time to fix this,” he said quietly. “But not forever. Fear may convince you you’re doing the right thing. But it will cost you everything you want.”

Agatha stared at the floor.

“And, Agatha?” he added.

She looked up.

“Go talk to her.”

Agatha’s breath stuttered.

She nodded once—barely.

Her session ended.

When she stepped out of the office, the air felt too cold. The hallway too quiet. Her pulse too loud.

But one truth finally settled beneath her ribs-

She didn’t want to run anymore.

 

 

 

 

 

 

The fire station sat in the early evening haze, its red doors catching the fading sunlight.

Agatha stood on the curb across the street for almost a full minute before she could make her legs move.

She felt exposed.
 Out of place.
 Too vulnerable in her black coat and hospital scrubs.

Strange’s voice echoed in her mind-
“Go talk to her.”
So she crossed the street.

Every step felt like walking through water.

She reached the station bay door just as it rolled open with a grinding mechanical groan. A blast of warm air and the smell of diesel washed over her. Crew members filtered in and out of her view — Tony pulling on his bunker pants, Bucky checking a hose line, Peter tightening his helmet strap.

The alarm had gone off moments before she arrived.

A call.

Bucky glanced up and spotted her first.

 His eyes widened in surprise but softened with sympathy.

“Doc,” he murmured, stepping aside so she could see past him. “You picked a hell of a moment.”

Agatha’s stomach dropped.

Rio stood near the engine, half-dressed in her turnout gear.

 Her jacket hung open. 

Her face was tense and focused, curls shoved under her helmet. 

She looked exhausted — but still heartbreakingly beautiful.

Agatha took a step forward.

Rio didn’t see her at first.

“Vidal!” Tony called. “You good on your tank?”

Rio grunted in acknowledgement, adjusting her air pack.

Agatha swallowed, throat tight.

Another step.

Then Rio turned.

Her whole body stilled.

They stared at each other — two people who had been pulled apart and snapped back into the same orbit too fast.

Rio’s eyes flickered with confusion, pain, hope… then carefully shuttered again.

Agatha felt it like physically being pushed back.

“Rio,” she managed, voice breaking on the name.

Rio didn’t move toward her, but she didn’t look away either.

Agatha stepped closer, heart hammering. “I—I’m sorry.” Her voice shook. “I didn’t… I shouldn’t have disappeared. I was scared and I—”

Rio’s expression wavered for a split second, something like hurt cracking through her.

But before either of them could say another word—
The alarm blared again.
 Louder.

 Urgent.


Dispatch crackled through the station speakers-
“All units, respond to reported factory fire. Multiple possible victims trapped. Heavy smoke. Potential structural collapse.”

The room exploded into motion.

Bucky shoved his helmet on.
 Tony leapt into the truck.
 Steve shouted orders.

Rio took one step back toward the engine — instinct, training.

Agatha reached for her before she could stop herself. “Rio—wait.”

Rio’s chest rose sharply. She looked torn between duty and heartbreak.

Agatha whispered, “I’m sorry. I was wrong. I should’ve talked to you. I—” her voice cracked, “—I didn’t leave because I didn’t care. I left because it terrified me how much I do.”

Rio froze.

Something in her expression softened — only slightly, but Agatha felt it.

“Rio, I…I-“

Then Agatha’s phone rang.

Loud. 

Shrill.

 Invasive.


She flinched and pulled it out with shaking fingers.
WESTVIEW GENERAL — PRIORITY CALL.

Her stomach dropped.

She answered. “Harkness.”

“Dr. Harkness,” a nurse said breathlessly. “We’re getting multiple incoming from the factory fire. At least four confirmed victims with smoke inhalation and burns. We need you here now.”

Agatha’s eyes snapped up to Rio.

Rio heard every word.

They stood there, both called into danger in different uniforms.

The fire engine roared to life behind Rio.

Agatha’s throat tightened painfully. “I have to go.”

Rio nodded once, slow, her face unreadable. “I know.”

Agatha stepped closer. “When you get back—”

Rio swallowed hard. “We’ll talk… after this. I promise.”

Agatha’s chest twisted.

She wanted to say more.

She wanted to grab Rio’s face and make her understand everything she had wanted to say for a week.

 She wanted to tell her she didn’t want to run anymore.

That she was in love with her.

But Rio was already backing toward the truck, climbing into her seat, mask hanging around her neck.

Bucky slammed the door beside her.

 Tony leaned out the window and shouted, “Watch your toes, Doc!”

Agatha stepped out of the bay just as the sirens ignited.

Rio’s eyes locked onto hers through the windshield.

One last look.

A promise. 

A plea.

 A heartbreak.

Then the truck peeled out of the station, lights blazing, sirens screaming into the night.

Agatha stood alone on the pavement, phone still clutched in her hand, heart pounding like it wanted to chase after the engine.

Then she turned and ran to her car— toward the hospital.

Toward the fire’s aftermath. Toward her own reckoning.
Toward Rio, whether either of them knew it or not.

Chapter 16

Chapter Notes

I tried my best with the medical terms in this chapter, apologies for any inaccuracies...

Here we go...

Agatha drove with one hand tight on the wheel, the other tapping anxiously against her thigh. The road blurred past in clean, dark lines, and she forced herself not to look at the clock again.

Ten minutes to the hospital.
 Maybe less if she didn’t stop overthinking.

The encounter at the station replayed in her mind in pieces — Rio turning, Rio’s eyes going wide, the way her face softened and hardened all at once. The way Agatha’s own voice cracked when she tried to speak.

She finally said something.
 Not enough, but something.

And Rio had listened.

Agatha exhaled shakily, her pulse still unsteady.

She cursed herself under her breath, fingers tightening. “A week, Agatha. You avoided her for an entire week like a coward.”

She could still see the hurt in Rio’s face when she couldn’t finish her apology.

She hated that she put it there.
 Hated that Rio walked away thinking she didn’t care.

Rio deserved better than the emotional brick wall Agatha had become.

The fire truck roaring out moments later… that had only twisted the knife a little deeper.

Agatha shook her head. “She’s fine,” she muttered. “She’s been on dozens of calls worse than this.”

She wasn’t panicking — not really.

 It was more like a small, persistent tightness in her chest she wished she could ignore. A quiet awareness that Rio was heading toward flames and smoke and collapsing ceilings while Agatha drove toward fluorescent lights and sterile hallways.

A normal night for both of them.
 Just… harder when she’d finally opened her mouth.

“Of all the timing,” she muttered.

Still, Rio’s last look — the softness in it, the confusion, the unspoken we’re not finished — settled somewhere warm beneath her ribs.

Tonight wasn’t the end.
 Not if she could help it.

The hospital came into view, its bright white lights stark against the early dusk. Ambulances were already backed up at the bay, EMTs moving briskly through the sliding doors.

Agatha parked crookedly, barely noticing.

She stepped out of the car, pulling her coat tight around her. The cold air hit her cheeks and cleared her head more than she expected.

She took one steadying breath.

Work first.
 Patients first.
 Her mess of a heart after.

But even as she walked toward the ER doors, one thought pulsed quietly beneath everything else:
When this is over… she has to try again. She owed Rio that much.

The ER felt like the air before a thunderclap.

Still, tense, humming with the static of anticipation.

Staff moved with quick, purposeful steps — clearing spaces, prepping bays, rolling equipment into position. The harsh fluorescent lights buzzed with an edge that made every shadow feel sharper.

Agatha walked in and immediately sensed it- The whole department was holding its breath.

“Dr. Harkness,” a nurse called from across the floor, “Trauma two and three are clear. Four’s almost done.”

Agatha nodded, already pulling on gloves, trying to let the familiar motion steady her pulse.

Wanda appeared at her elbow, soft-voiced but observant as ever. “You okay?”

Agatha didn’t look at her. “Fine.”

Wanda made a quiet sound that translated to I don’t believe you for a second, but she didn’t push. She simply handed her another pair of gloves.

Before Agatha could retreat into her professional shell, the double doors opened again and in strode Chief Romanoff — Natasha, immaculate as always despite being on hour fourteen of her shift. She scanned the room like she was charting a battlefield.

“Status?” she asked.

“Preparing all available trauma bays,” Agatha replied.

Natasha nodded, then added quietly, “Okay people, brace yourselves. We have three critical en route. Two more likely. FD says the smoke is heavy.”

Agatha’s stomach tightened, but she kept her face perfectly smooth. “We’re ready.”

Natasha’s gaze lingered on her a fraction of a second too long — perceptive, sharp, knowing.

Agatha pretended not to feel it.

Across the room, Jen pulled her trauma gown tight, snapping on gloves with practiced efficiency. She wore a focused expression, the kind she only had before major influxes.

Jen stepped to Agatha’s side. “I’m taking trauma three. If anything needs switching, shout.”

“Got it,” Agatha said.

Jen gave her a quick look — searching, a little concerned — but said nothing.

Yelena hovered beside Wanda, iPad in hand, double-checking the intake board. She bounced on the balls of her feet, antsy in that way she always got when something big was coming.

“Ambulance bay is cleared,” Wanda announced. “We have stretchers lined up in hall C, extra oxygen tanks loaded, and four nurses from peads on standby. Teen is on his way in.”

Natasha smirked. “Someone’s been very productive.”

Wanda rolled her eyes. “Someone has to be.”

Jen snorted beside them. “She means she doesn’t trust any of us to prepare correctly.”

Wanda didn’t deny it.

Agatha watched them — her people, her team — all poised, all ready, all waiting for what was about to hit them.

She felt an ache in her chest that wasn’t entirely related to the incoming disaster.

These were the people who had held her up without words.
 The same people who would know something was wrong if she let her mask slip even an inch.

She forced her shoulders straighter.

Focus. Work.
 Later — maybe — she’d have the courage to confront the mess she’d made with Rio.

Radio static crackled over the nurse’s station, breaking the silence.

A dispatcher’s voice came through, crisp and urgent:
“Ambulances en route. First victims arriving in three minutes.”

Yelena straightened like a soldier.

Jen exhaled and murmured, “Here we go.”

Wanda squeezed Agatha’s arm once — a gesture of solidarity, not sympathy.

Natasha lifted her chin, commanding the room with a single look. “Positions, everyone.”

Agatha stepped toward trauma bay two, her pulse steady but heavier than usual.

The calm was over.

 The storm was coming.

And all she could do now was brace herself, for the patients, for the fire, for the conversation she hoped she might finally have once the smoke cleared.

The ambulance bay doors slammed open with a metallic bang.

Kate, Alice and two other paramedics burst inside, pushing two stretchers at a speed that bordered on a run. Both of them were streaked with soot, faces pale under the harsh ER lights. Their uniforms smelled of smoke — sharp, chemical, heavy.

Agatha snapped immediately into motion.

“Trauma two!” she called. “Bring that one to two!”

Kate angled her stretcher left while Alice veered right, bringing a badly burned man toward Jen.

Alice’s voice cracked slightly as she called out the report.

“Male, mid-fifties, found near a collapsed section of the south wall—he’s got partial-thickness burns over his arms and chest, possible inhalation injury, BP was tanking in the rig.”

Jen was already cutting away scorched clothing. “Got it. Trauma three, now!”

Agatha moved beside Kate, examining her patient—a woman in her thirties, coughing violently, face grey with soot.

“Severe smoke inhalation,” Kate said quickly, handing Agatha the vitals sheet. “Collapsed before extraction. Rio and Bucky got her out just before the flames rolled over the ceiling.”

Agatha froze for half a heartbeat at Rio’s name—but only half.

She pushed air into her lungs and nodded. “Let’s intubate.”

Kate stayed at her side, assisting without needing direction. But Agatha saw it—the tremble in Kate’s hands, the tightness in her jaw.

She wasn’t rattled often.

Yelena rushed to their side with a laryngoscope. “Tubing equipment ready!”

Behind them, Jen barked orders, Wanda prepped IV fluids, Natasha coordinated from the centre of the room like a general orchestrating a battlefield.

Everything was moving at high speed.

But Agatha noticed Alice.

Alice hovered near Jen, her face pale and eyes glassy, trying not to show how shaken she was. Her hands were steady—but barely.

Jen spared her a quick glance. “You okay?”

Alice swallowed. “Eastview dispatched their whole EMT division to assist,” she murmured. “And—” she lowered her voice further, “—Northbridge too. It’s… it’s big, Jen. Bigger than any of us expected.”

Jen’s jaw tightened. “How many still inside?”

“We don’t know,” Alice whispered. “But the heat signatures were… bad.”

Jen placed a steadying hand on Alice’s arm. “Go get water. Then get back on the rigs. We need you.”

Alice nodded, but her gaze flickered over to Agatha—just for a second—something unspoken passing between them.

Fear. 

Uncertainty. 

Something else.

Agatha didn’t let herself think about it.

She returned to her patient, fingers swift and sure as she stabilised the airway.

Kate steadied the tubing and whispered under her breath, almost too low to hear-
“I’ve never seen fire so devastating before.”

Agatha’s pulse stuttered—but her hands never did.

She finished securing the tube and stepped back. “Ventilation ready.”

Yelena hooked up the bag valve mask. “Vitals dropping fast.”

Agatha moved closer, eyes focused, voice crisp. “Push a bolus. Prep for bronchoscopy.”

Around her, the ER buzzed—stretchers rolling, monitors beeping, staff shouting orders. Another ambulance siren wailed into the bay outside.

The storm had hit.

But beneath all the noise, one thought pressed against Agatha’s ribs with quiet, relentless weight-
Rio is still in that fire.

She swallowed hard, pushing the thought away, burying it beneath layers of clinical focus.

There was work to do. Lives to save.
And she refused to fall apart now.

The first two patients weren’t even fully stabilised when the radio blared again from the nurse’s station.

“Second wave inbound. Multiple criticals. Two with suspected severe burns, one unresponsive. Repeat — one firefighter unresponsive.”

The ER went still for half a breath.

A firefighter down.

Yelena whispered, “Oh no…”

Natasha straightened, eyes sharpening. “Everyone ready. Trauma one, two, and four cleared and prepped. Move.”

The ambulance bay doors slammed open again.

This time, chaos spilled in.

Three stretchers.
 All of them bad.

One patient was barely conscious, skin blistered and peeling in places, coughing up soot. Another had a leg bent unnaturally, a tourniquet high on the thigh, the smell of burnt fabric clinging to him.

But the third—
The third made everyone flinch.

A firefighter.
 Turnout gear half-melted.
 Helmet cracked.
 Mask gone.
 Breathing weak and erratic.

Kate and a paramedic Agatha didn’t recognise barrelled the stretcher through the doors.

“Firefighter—Eastview FD—collapsed during extraction!” Kate shouted. Her voice broke on the last word. “Pulse weak, respirations shallow, possible flashover exposure!”

Natasha’s voice cut like a knife. “Trauma bay one. Now!”

Agatha’s heart thudded painfully.
 Not Rio.
 Not her crew.

But still— still— the sight made her blood run cold.

Yelena rushed to the unconscious firefighter’s side, pulling away charred gear, revealing blistered skin and soot-streaked features.

Alice hurried behind them from the bay, her eyes wide and glassy. “He went down right before we left. They’re still pulling others out.”

Others.
 Still inside.

Agatha swallowed hard.

Jen moved quickly toward the firefighter, snapping on new gloves. “BP?”

“Fifty over thirty,” Kate said, voice shaking. “We almost lost him twice in the rig.”

“Get me fluids and airway support!” Jen barked.

Agatha turned just in time to see the patient on stretcher two—his burns deep, skin blackened in patches. 

The faint smell of charred flesh hit her nose, and she forced her stomach tight.

Her patient.

She moved quickly, sliding into her role with frightening precision.

“Let’s get him into trauma two,” she said.

Yelena nodded, voice trembling but focused. “On it.”

Across the room, the unconscious firefighter began to seize.

“Seizing! Push benzos!” Jen shouted.

Alice froze for a half-second—not from lack of training, but fear. Agatha saw it plainly.

This wasn’t just another call.
 This was a disaster.

And it wasn’t ending anytime soon.

The ER filled with frantic voices:
“His airway’s closing—get me a scope!” “Pressure’s dropping!” “Move, move—clear the line!” “We need a burn surgeon down here now!”

Agatha’s patient started to crash too.

She heard the monitor scream as his oxygen plummeted, and she moved immediately.

“Intubate him now,” she ordered.

Her hands didn’t shake.
 Her voice didn’t falter.
 She shoved everything—her fear for Rio, her guilt, her longing—deep beneath her professional armour.

“Yelena, retract—good. Wanda, push another hundred of fluids. Natasha, page the burn unit.”

Wanda’s voice was steady beside her. “Breath sounds diminished on the left.”

“Damn it. Prep for needle decompression.”

Her chest tightened—but not from panic.

This was her job. 

This she could do.

 Save lives.

 Even if the one she wanted to save wasn’t in front of her.

From the next trauma bay, Jen’s voice cut through the noise:
“Code blue!”

The firefighter.

The room froze.
 Terror—real terror—flashed through everyone’s eyes.

Natasha snapped, “Start compressions now!”

Agatha’s pulse thudded in her ears, but she forced herself to stay with her patient. She finished the decompression, inserted the tube, confirmed oxygen rising again.

But her mind—
Her mind kept flickering to the fire station.
 To the team still at the fire site.
 To Rio.

To the possibility that the next unconscious firefighter through the door could be—

Stop.

 Focus.

She pushed the fear aside.

Jen’s voice rose from Trauma One, fierce and urgent. “Come on. Come on. Don’t you dare—”
There was a crackle from the radio system at the nurse’s station.

Dispatch:
“Be advised — Civilians evacuated. Westview crew still inside. Structural integrity unstable. Heavy fire on the south side.”

The room went dead silent.
 All eyes flickered toward Agatha.

But her face stayed perfectly still.

Her heart didn’t.

The unconscious Eastview firefighter was still coding when the next ambulance pulled into the bay.

The lights strobed across the ER entrance, and Agatha felt her pulse spike instantly.
 

Another firefighter.

This one wasn’t Eastview.

Her stomach flipped.

The turnout gear was unmistakable.

WFD Station 24.

Wanda saw the shift in Agatha’s posture and moved closer, hovering just enough that she could grab her if her knees gave out.

Alice burst through the bay doors, helping push the stretcher, hair sticking to her forehead with sweat.

“Firefighter from Westview!” she shouted. “Severe burns to the shoulder and back, smoke inhalation, partial collapse—lost consciousness in the rig!”

Agatha’s heart stopped in her throat.

Not Rio.
 Please— Not Rio.

Her eyes darted to the stretcher.

The gear was smaller. Leaner.
 A familiar mop of soot-caked brown hair.

Peter Parker.

Barely twenty-three.

Sweet, awkward, eager to impress. The baby of the team.

Agatha’s knees nearly buckled.

Wanda stepped closer, shoulder brushing hers in a soft, grounding nudge.

Peter wheezed, coughing violently as Alice adjusted the oxygen mask.

“Collapsed beam clipped him,” Alice panted. “Rio and Tony pulled him out before the whole section went down. Tony’s okay. Peter went under—he inhaled a lot before they could drag him out.”

Not Rio.

But Peter was still one of theirs.

Alice flashed Agatha a worried look. “I—I don’t know where Rio is right now. They split the crew.”

Agatha’s stomach twisted as if someone had reached inside and wrung it out.

She moved on instinct.

“Trauma four,” she ordered. “Wanda, burn kit. Yelena, call respiratory for CO exposure. Alice, keep the O2 steady.”

Her voice was sharper than usual, clipped and too fast, but no one questioned her.

Peter blinked up at her, eyes watery and unfocused.
 “Doc…?” he rasped. “Didn’t… see it coming.”

Agatha squeezed his forearm. “You’re okay, Peter. We’ve got you.”

He coughed, voice shredded. “Rio… she—”

Agatha’s breath froze.

Peter wasn’t fully conscious. His eyes weren’t tracking. His voice was drifting.

But he still managed to get out, voice cracking:
“They said… can’t find her…”

The world narrowed to a pinpoint.

The air left her lungs like she’d been punched.

Wanda was beside her instantly, stepping into her line of sight like she could shield her from the words themselves.

“Agatha,” Wanda murmured, steady but firm. “Listen. He’s disoriented. He inhaled a ton of smoke. He doesn’t know what he’s saying.”

Agatha’s jaw clenched, breath shaking.

“But—he said—”

“He doesn’t know,” Wanda repeated, eyes anchored to hers. “We don’t know anything yet.”

Agatha shut her eyes tight for one heartbeat.

The panic didn’t stop.
 But it softened enough that she could inhale again.

Wanda squeezed her wrist gently. “Stay with me, Agatha. You can fall apart later. Right now, he needs you.”

Agatha opened her eyes and nodded.

Barely.

But she nodded.

“Okay,” she whispered. “Okay. Trauma four. Let’s go.”

Peter’s stretcher was wheeled away, nurses moving quickly, voices blending into a haze of orders and alarms.

Agatha stood perfectly still for a single, shaking breath.

Then she straightened her coat, forced her hands steady, and stepped back into the chaos.

“Back to work,” she murmured.

Wanda was right beside her. “I’m here.”

They moved together, bracing for whatever the fire would bring next.

Agatha had barely finished suturing the last laceration when the ER finally began to slow. The hallways were still crowded, alarms still chiming, but the frantic edge had dulled into a steady controlled chaos.

Patients were stabilised. Burn sheets in place. Fluids running.
 Peter was sedated and on oxygen, monitored closely.

For the first time in hours, Agatha let herself breathe.

She stepped out of trauma bay four, pressing a hand to her temples. The adrenaline was wearing off. 

Fatigue seeped into her bones.

Across the hall, Natasha Romanoff was speaking low into a radio, her face strained. She turned away slightly, as if to shield the device from view.

Agatha caught movement.
 A flicker of Rio’s name.
 A tone that wasn’t right.

Natasha’s posture tightened.

Agatha froze mid-step.

“What was that?” she demanded.

Natasha immediately straightened, angling her body to block the radio. “Agatha—go take a break. You’ve been running nonstop.”

“Give me the radio.”

“Agatha—”

“Now.”

Natasha didn’t move. Her jaw flexed. “You don’t want to hear this.”

A cold ripple crawled down Agatha’s spine.

“I need to hear it,” she whispered.

Before Natasha could stop it, the radio hissed sharply, a burst of static followed by a frantic voice:
“—still searching for station 24 member, female —lost contact—visibility zero—structure unstable—”
Agatha’s blood went ice-cold.

Her heartbeat punched against her ribs.

Female firefighter. 

Station 24.

Rio.

Natasha snatched up the radio, lowering the volume quickly. “Agatha. Stop. You need to breathe.”

But Agatha couldn’t hear anything anymore. Everything inside her dropped into a sickening freefall.
The hospital lights blurred.
All she could see was Rio’s back as she climbed onto the truck hours earlier.
All she could hear in her head were the words she never said.
Her coat was in her fists before she realised she’d moved.

“Agatha!” Natasha called after her. “Stop—Agatha!”

But she was already running.

Down the hallway.
 Past the vending machines.
 Past the waiting room full of smoke-stained families.

Her feet barely touched the ground.

Her mind was a violent storm:
She’s missing. She’s in there. I pushed her away. I left her alone. God—Rio—

She burst through the sliding ER doors and sprinted into the parking lot, hands shaking so badly she fumbled the keys twice before she hit the ignition.

The tires screched as she tore out of the lot.

She didn’t remember the turns she took.

She didn’t feel the seat beneath her.

Her entire world narrowed to one desperate, pounding thought-

I can’t sit here and wait.

 I can’t lose her. 

I can’t—

Her breath snagged painfully as she drove toward the orange glow blooming in the distant sky — a monstrous plume of smoke rising above the warehouses.

Sirens wailed in the distance.

Agatha pushed the accelerator harder.

She didn’t know what she was going to do when she got there.

She just knew she had to get to Rio.

Before it was too late.

Chapter 17

Chapter Notes

POV divergence for the first time within this chapter

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The closer Agatha got to the warehouse district, the thicker the smoke became- a dark, choking plume rising into the night sky. The flashing red and blue lights reflected off the wet asphalt as she turned the final corner.

She slammed her car to a stop.

And froze.

The scene was hell.

Flames licked through broken windows.
 Hoses blasted arcs of water into the inferno.
 Firefighters moved like shadows against the orange glow.
 Police held back civilians and stragglers.

Agatha shoved her door open and ran.

Her heart was pounding so violently it hurt.

She didn’t see the fire.
 Didn’t see the bystanders.
 Didn’t see the police.

She saw the crew.

Rio’s crew.

Grouped near Engine 4, helmets in their shaking hands, soot streaking down their faces.
And they were terrified.

Tony was crying openly, shoulders heaving, face smeared with ash.
 Bucky had his fists pressed against his forehead, pacing fast, jaw trembling as he muttered fragmented prayers under his breath.

Captain Rogers normally calm, steady, unshakable was barking orders into the radio, voice hoarse, desperation bleeding through every syllable.
 His hands were shaking. He kept trying to to hide them behind his turnout coat.

This wasn’t routine. This wasn’t manageable.
This was bad.

Agatha’s lungs clenched. “Where is she?”

No one heard her.

She stepped closer, louder this time, voice cracking,
“Where is Rio?!”

Tony’s head snapped up. His face broke when he saw her — relief and guilt and terror all at once.

“Doc…” His voice collapsed. “Doc, I—she—”

He couldn’t say it.
 He covered his face with both hands and sobbed.

Agatha’s stomach dropped.

She turned to Bucky.

“What happened?” she demanded, her voice near shaking.

Bucky swallowed hard, eyes red, his throat bobbing as he tried to speak. “There was a partial collapse on the east side. A wall came down. Tony got out but—” His breath hitched. “She went back for Peter.”

Agatha’s blood turned to ice.

“She went back inside?” Her voice was barely a whisper.

“For the kid,” Bucky choked out. “He was trapped. She… she got him out, but the second beam fell before we could pull her back.”

Agatha felt her knees weaken. “No… Rio…”

“They called a MAYDAY,” Bucky continued, wiping his face with a shaky hand. “Then we lost radio contact. No sound. Nothing. She’s in there alone.”

Agatha pressed a fist to her mouth, nausea rising so fast she thought she might collapse.

She turned to Steve.

He was still shouting orders into the radio, voice breaking between commands.

“Sector 2, sweep again! No one rests until we find her!” His voice cracked. “No one!”

His grief was palpable — another sign that this wasn’t just a fallen firefighter.

This was one of their own.

This was Rio.

Agatha stumbled a step closer. “Steve—Steve, look at me.”

He turned, and Agatha had never seen Captain Rogers look like this — devastated, frantic, horrified.

“Agatha,” he rasped. “We’re trying. I swear to God, we’re trying.”

She grabbed his coat, her voice trembling, “Tell me she’s alive.”

Steve’s throat worked, but no words came.

And that silence was worse than antything.

Agatha felt the world tilt. Her vision blurred.

Her voice cracked open-
“Please—someone—tell me she’s alive.”

Steve reached out instinctively, steadying her before she fell.

But he still couldn’t answer.

And the look in his eyes—
The raw ache.
 The fear.
 The helplessness—
It told her everything.

Agatha’s breath broke, a small, sharp sound that cut through the chaos around them.

Her world narrowed until it was just the fire. Just the smoke.
 Just the knowledge that Rio was somewhere in there.

Alone.

And maybe—

No.

Agatha wouldn’t let herself think it.

She stared at the burning building, tears blurring the flames into streaks of orange and gold.

She whispered one word into the smoky air, soft, broken, desperate-
“Rio…”

Agatha barely had time to absorb the sight of the destruction when sirens wailed behind her. An ambulance screeched to a stop beside Engine 4, and Alice and Kate jumped out—still in uniform, still breathless from the call they had just cleared.

Alice took one look at the burning building, then another at Tony’s destroyed expression, and her face drained of all colour.

“Did you find her?” Alice gasped, voice already breaking. 

Bucky tried to steady her, but Alice shoved past him, grabbing Steve’s turnout sleeve. “Tell me she’s out. Please—tell me she’s out.”

Steve didn’t answer fast enough, and panic flooded her eyes. 

Kate stepped in, her voice shaky but grounded. “Alice—hey—focus. We’ll help however we can.”

But Alice shook her head, tears spilling as she looked back at the flames. “No. I’m not leaving without her. Not again.”

Kate wrapped an arm around her shoulders, holding her upright just as Agatha had arrived minutes earlier—two women completely undone by the same fear.

Steve finally lowered the radio, jaw tight as steel.

“We pinpointed her last location,” he said, voice raw. “Sector 3 — east interior.”
The moment he said it, three firefighters stepped forward at once.

“I’m going.”

 “Let me go.” 

“She’d go for us.”

But Tony shoved past them.

“Fuck that,” he snapped. “I was with her. I lost sight of her. I’m going back in.”

Bucky grabbed his arm. “Tony—”

“Don’t try to stop me.” Tony’s eyes were fierce, wet, blazing with guilt. “She saved Pete. She saved me. I’m not letting her die in there.”

Agatha felt her heart slam against her ribs.

Tony was suiting up fast — gloves snapped on, helmet yanked down, mask clipped, movements jerky with panic.

Agatha stepped forward without thinking. “Tony—wait—”

He paused, just for a fraction of a second.

Agatha grabbed a fistful of his turnout gear, voice shaking so violently she barely recognised it.
 “Bring her back,” she whispered. “Don’t you dare come out without her.”

Tony’s face twisted, grief and determination warring in his eyes. He covered her hand with his.

“I’ll find her,” he rasped. 

The second he broke away from Agatha, he sprinted through the smoke — disappearing into the broken entryway like a man running into his own grave.

Agatha stood frozen, breath shaking, watching the dark swallow him.

Every second he was inside stretched tighter and tighter around her ribs.

After 5 full minutes of silence Steve barked into the radio, “Engine 4 interior, report! Tony, give me something!”

Static.

Then—
A crash somewhere deep inside the building.

Bucky cursed under his breath. “Come on, Stark. Come on…”

More static. 
“—copy—SHIT—I’m—coming out—floor’s going—MOVE!”

Agatha’s heart lurched.

Tony burst through the smoke a second later, stumbling, covered in soot, coughing so hard he nearly collapsed. Steve and Bucky caught him under each arm.

“Did you find her?” Steve shouted.

Tony shook his head violently, tears cutting through the soot on his cheeks. “No—no sign—the floors gone—I tried—I swear—”

Agatha’s stomach plummeted.

Her mind told her to run.

Run towards where Rio was lying, helpless, alone. 

“She never called back,” Tony rasped. “She never—”

The building answered for him.

A deep groan tore through the night — the unmistakable death rattle of a structure about to fail.

Steve’s eyes snapped up. “Everyone BACK! BACK! MOVE!”

Agatha didn’t move.

She stared at the building as if staring hard enough could hold it up, keep it together, force it to return Rio to her.

But the warehouse didn’t care.

With a sound like the earth splitting open—
the building collapsed.

Flames shot upward.
 Concrete folded inward.
 Metal shrieked as it tore apart.
 A wall crumbled in on itself, then another — the whole structure falling like a house of cards.

A wave of dust and smoke slammed into the ground, knocking Agatha backward onto the asphalt.

She hit hard but barely felt it.

Her ears rang.
 Her mouth tasted like ash.
 Her chest constricted as the cloud swallowed everything.

When it thinned—
There was no building.

Just rubble.

Sparks.

Fire.

And silence.

Souls being broken in real time.

Alice screamed Rio’s name so loudly it ripped something inside Agatha’s chest.
 Kate pulled her into her arms as she sobbed.
 Tony collapsed onto his knees, fists slamming on the concrete.
 Bucky froze, face twisted, tears streaming down without him noticing.
 Steve covered his mouth, shoulders shaking, his entire body trembling with rage and grief.

And Agatha—
Agatha felt her heart tear apart.

It was a physical sensation — a ripping, a hollowing, a pain so sharp she couldn’t breathe.

It was the pain of losing Nicky all over again.

“No…” she whispered. “No, please, no…”

Her voice cracked as she clutched her coat, collapsing forward onto her hands.

“Rio…”

The name fell from her lips like a prayer already grieving its own answer.

Her world narrowed to the ruins before her.

She didn’t hear Tony sobbing beside her.
 Didn’t hear Steve ordering hose streams to cool the collapse zone.
 Didn’t hear Alice crying into Kate’s shoulder or Natasha’s voice yelling from a radio for updates.

She heard only her heartbeat.

Slowing.
 Breaking.
 Screaming inside her chest-
I was too late.

 

 


↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺↺

 

 

 

Peter was almost clear of the doorway when Rio shoved him hard toward Tony.

“Go!” she barked.

Peter stumbled forward and Tony caught him, yelling her name—
But the sound was drowned out by the shriek of bending metal overhead.

Rio’s eyes snapped up.

Too late.

A massive beam tore free from the ceiling and slammed downward. She jumped back instinctively, boots skidding on fractured concrete—
The floor split beneath her.

“RIO!” Tony’s scream tore through the smoke.

She reached for the edge—fingers grazing the surface—
And then everything dropped.

Rio plunged into darkness.

The world smashed into her side, the air leaving her lungs in a violent expulsion. Concrete dust exploded around her, and then—
Nothing.

No sound.
 No pain.
 No light.

Just blackness.

Rio lay crumpled on her side in the collapsed basement, chest barely rising, soot streaked across her face. 

Blood trickled down her hairline and her arm lay twisted under a slab of concrete.

She didn’t move for what felt like hours. 

After ten minutes of nothingness Rio’s eyes opened, swollen and stinging.
 The air tasted like ash and iron.
 Her ears rang like static.

For a moment, she couldn’t tell which way was up.

Then the pain hit.

A white-hot blast through her arm.
 A deep ache in her ribs.
 A pounding throb at her scalp.

She groaned.

The sound barely existed.

“Where…” she rasped, coughing violently.

Her hand slid across the ground until she found her radio.

Static crackled weakly, voices broken and frantic.

“—lost contact—”

 “—possible firefighter down—”

 “—no response from Vidal—”

 “—get her out of there—”

Her heart lurched.

They think I'm gone.

She thumbed the transmit button.

“This… is Vidal… basement… trapped—need assist—”
 Her voice crumpled.
 The radio fizzled once.
 Then died in her hand.

Rio’s throat tightened.

“Shit… no… no…”

Panic clawed at her ribs but she swallowed it down, forcing breath after breath through tightening lungs.

Not the first time. 

Not the last.

Move.

She braced her boots and shoved against the concrete trapping her arm.

Pain tore through her shoulder like lightning.
“Fuck,” she hissed, teeth clenched.

She tried again. 

And again.

 And again.

The slab shifted—just barely.

She screamed through gritted teeth, pushing every ounce of strength she had left—
And pulled her arm free.

The pain was blinding. 

Sickening.

 But she was out.

She sagged back onto the rubble, shaking.
“Come on, Vidal,” she whispered. “Not today.”

Then another thought hit her — cutting deeper than the pain.
Agatha. 

Rio closed her eyes briefly, chest heaving.

I promised her.

 I promised I’d come back.

 I’m not dying down here. Not before I keep that promise.

She scanned the basement through the haze. A collapsed shelving unit. Broken crates. Fallen ducts. And behind them, an old maintenance door hanging crookedly on its hinges.

Rio pulled herself to her feet and staggered toward it. The tunnel beyond was narrow and uneven, carved long before the building had been updated. Most of the factory workers probably didn’t even know it existed.

Rio ran her fingers along the wall to steady herself. Her breath echoed strangely in the enclosed space.

Pain pulsed down her arm, but she kept going.

One step. Then another. She refused to stop.

I am not dying down here.
 I am getting out.

The tunnel stretched on for what felt like forever before it finally sloped upward.

Rio kept her hand on the rough concrete wall to steady herself, her breaths coming faster now. Smoke seeped through cracks overhead, drifting down in thin grey ribbons.

Then the entire world shifted.

A low groan echoed through the earth, deep enough to vibrate in her bones. Dust rained from the ceiling. 
The floor trembled beneath her boots.

Rio froze.

“No… no, no—”

A second rumble hit, louder this time. The sound of metal twisting, concrete splitting, beams snapping apart in a chain reaction of destruction.

The building was collapsing.

Rio threw herself against the tunnel wall as the ground shook violently. Chunks of ceiling crashed down behind her, sending a blast of debris forward like a wave. She shielded her head with her arms as dust exploded around her, choking the air and plunging everything into near-darkness.

The roar was deafening.
 A monster made of fire and steel.

Rio clenched her teeth, refusing to let panic win. She flattened herself to the wall and waited for the shaking to stop, her heart slamming against her ribs.

It took less than thirty seconds.

It felt like a lifetime.

Finally, the vibrations eased. The tunnel settled. Silence returned—heavy and terrible, broken only by the drip of water from somewhere deep in the darkness.

Rio coughed hard, lungs burning from the dust.

She knew what that collapse meant.

Above her… Everything was gone.

She imagined the structure pancaked into itself. Imagined the smoke rising higher. Imagined her crew staring at the wreckage in horror.

They'll think I’m dead.

Her throat tightened painfully.

Agatha. 

God.

Rio pushed the thought away and forced her shaking legs to move.

She had one way out now.

Light filtered through the slits of a manhole cover ahead, weak and waevering but still there still hope.

Rio pushed against it. It barely budged at first.

The manhole cover was rusted into place, stubborn with years of disuse.

Rio braced both hands against it and pushed again, harder this time. Her shoulder screamed. Her trapped arm throbbed with each movement.

“Come on,” she muttered through clenched teeth. “Not dying down here. Not after all that.”

She thought of the promise she’d made to Agatha when they locked eyes before she’d climbed into the truck.

“We’ll talk after,” she’d said.

There was no way in hell she was breaking that promise.

With a final surge of strength, the manhole cover scraped open an inch, then another.

Cool night air rushed in, filling her lungs. Rio shoved it aside and pulled herself upward, gritting her teeth as her bruised ribs protested.

She emerged on shaky legs into the open air beside a row of dumpsters at the far edge of the warehouse lot.

For a moment, she just breathed.

The fire was still raging, lighting up the sky in violent orange. Engines roared. Water blasted. Voices shouted. 

Her crew was clustered near the collapse zone—despair in their posture, devastation etched into the set of their shoulders.

They thought she was gone.

Rio stumbled forward, dusting concrete from her hair, leaving the manhole behind her.

Tony turned first.

His entire body jerked like he’d been electrocuted.

“Holy—” His voice cracked. “R-Rio?!”

Bucky spun so fast he nearly tripped. Kate dropped her medical gear. Steve’s radio slipped from his hand onto the asphalt.

They all stared.

Frozen.

Disbelieving.

Rio lifted a hand, managing the smallest, exhausted wave. “Hey.”

Tony let out a noise halfway between a sob and a laugh. Bucky swore loudly. Kate covered her mouth. 

Steve looked like his knees might give out.

But Rio wasn’t looking at them.

Her eyes found the one person she least expected to see here.

Agatha.

She was standing just past the engines, chest rising too fast, soot on her cheeks like war paint, staring at Rio as if looking at a ghost.

Rio blinked.

Agatha was here.
 Agatha had come.

Rio took one step toward her—
And that was all it took.

*****************

Agatha didn’t process the scream first.

She processed the silence.

The breathless, impossible silence that fell over the crew.

Then Tony’s voice broke through, ragged and disbelieving-
“Rio?!”

Agatha’s heart stopped.

She whipped around—and the world tilted.

Rio stood in the lot, battered, limping, covered in ash and dirt and blood. 


Alive. 


Alive.


For a second Agatha couldn’t breathe.


No thought. 

No sound. 

Just Rio—alive—and the brutal sound of her own heart crashing against her ribs.

Her legs moved before her mind caught up.

She ran.

Fast. Hard. Desperate.

Rio barely had time to brace before Agatha collided with her, arms wrapping around her neck, clutching her like she’d break apart if she let go.

Rio’s breath hitched as Agatha buried her face against her shoulder, shaking uncontrollably.

“Agatha—” Rio whispered, voice cracking. “What are you doing here?”

Agatha couldn’t speak.

Her sob tore out of her, raw and muffled against Rio’s soot-covered turnout coat.

She felt Rio’s arms wrap around her, one slipping around her waist, the other cradling the back of her head, holding her as close as her battered body allowed.

“I thought—I thought—” Agatha choked, words broken, breath hitching. “God, Rio, I thought you were gone.”

“I know,” Rio murmured into her hair, her voice shaking. “I’m sorry. I’m so sorry.

“You’re alive,” Agatha whispered, pulling back just enough to touch Rio’s face with trembling hands, as if she needed proof. “You’re—you’re really—”

“I’m here,” Rio breathed, forehead falling gently against hers. “I’m okay.”

The world around them faded—the shouting, the engines, the fire, the chaos.

There was only this.

Only them.

Agatha’s hands cupped Rio’s cheeks, thumbs brushing the soot and dried blood, and despite everything—despite the wreckage looming behind them—Rio smiled.

Soft. 

Relieved. 

Devastated.


Agatha’s breath trembled.


“You promised we’d talk,” she whispered.


Rio nodded, eyes shining. “Yeah. And I keep my promises.”

Behind them, a broken scream ripped across the lot:
“RIO!”

Alice emerged from the back of the rig.

She was running full-speed, Kate right behind her. Alice threw her arms around Rio’s side, careful but frantic.

Rio winced, and Agatha’s doctor brain snapped into action.

Pain response—moderate to severe. 

Guarding left side—likely ribs, maybe lung. 

Her breathing too shallow—dangerous.

Alice pulled back, crying. “Don’t ever-ever do that again, do you hear me? I can’t—”

“I’m okay,” Rio tried.

“You’re not okay!” Alice sobbed. “Look at you!”

Kate reached them, wiping tears with the back of a shaking hand. 

“Holy shit, Vidal-- you look like you crawled out of the earth.”

Rio shrugged weakly. “Not… far off.”

Agatha touched her forehead gently, feeling for heat and checking for concussion signs. “Rio, look at me.”

Rio did, breathing unevenly.

“How long were you trapped?” Agatha asked softly, still assessing. “Did you lose consciousness? Are you nauseous? Dizzy? Any chest tightness? Any—”

Rio’s eyes softened. “Agatha… breathe.”

Agatha shut her eyes, a shaky exhale leaving her as her lips parted—as if to say more—but Rio swayed.

Her knees buckled.

“No—no, no, no—Rio—” Agatha caught her under the arms before she could collapse completely. 

“Damn it—Tony! Bucky—!”

They rushed forward immediately, grabbing Rio’s weight as Agatha held her upright.

Rio blinked slowly, exhaustion hitting her like a wave.

“Sorry… guess adrenaline just ran out,” she whispered.

They lowered Rio onto the gurney.

Rio’s hand reached blindly and Agatha grabbed it immediately.

“Don’t go,” Rio whispered.

“I’m not leaving you,” Agatha breathed.

Alice leaned down and pressed a shaking kiss to Rio’s forehead. “You dumb, brave idiot.”

Kate squeezed her ankle. “We love you asshole. Don’t do that again.”

Rio blinked up at them all, dazed. “Love you too…”

But her eyes never left Agatha’s.

Not for a second.

As they rolled Rio toward the ambulance, Agatha walked beside her, still scanning—

Breathing stabilising. 

Colour returning slowly. 

Consciousness waxing and waning. 

Pulse rapid but present.

Still alive.
Still here.

Rio’s fingers tightened weakly around hers.

Agatha swallowed a sob and squeezed back.

She was not losing her.
 

Not tonight. 

Not again.


Not ever.

 

Chapter End Notes

My babies 🫶🏻

Chapter 18

The moment they lifted the gurney into the ambulance, Agatha climbed in after Rio without hesitation. 

Alice slammed the driver’s door and shouted, “Hold on!” before throwing the ambulance into gear.

Kate stayed in the back with them, hands half-raised like she wanted to help but also knew better than to get between Agatha Harkness and her injured firefighter.

The doors closed.

And suddenly the world was nothing but the tight, white box of the ambulance and Rio lying half broken on the stretcher.

Agatha’s heartbeat pounded so loudly it drowned out the sirens.

She hovered over Rio, hands trembling but skilled as they moved—checking airway, chest rise, pupils. 
Her brain was fighting itself- doctor and terrified lover, both battling for space.

Her hands cupped Rio’s cheeks first, grounding herself. “Look at me. Can you focus? Are you short of breath? Any chest tightness? Dizzy? Rio, answer me.”

Rio blinked up at her slowly. “Agatha… I’m fine.”

Agatha let out something between a sob and a laugh. “You are not fine.”

Rio smiled weakly. “Okay. I’m… semi fine.”

Kate winced from the corner. “Yeah, no, she’s not fine.”

Agatha ignored her, eyes scanning the length of Rio’s body.

Her gaze landed on the arm Rio was guarding.

Swollen. Bent wrong. A deep, ugly bruise forming beneath the soot.

Agatha felt her stomach drop.

“Rio,” she whispered, voice breaking as she gently lifted the limb, assessing. “Your arm is broken. At least one fracture… maybe two.”

Rio hissed when she touched a tender spot but forced a smirk anyway. “Had worse.”

Agatha shot her a glare sharp enough to cut steel. “And I don’t care. You hear me? I don’t care how many times you’ve walked out of burning buildings or shrugged off injuries. This is my job now.”

Rio blinked, stunned.

Agatha’s voice wavered but stayed fierce. “Keeping you alive is my job.”

Rio’s breath caught.

Her expression softened into something warm and unbearably gentle. “Agatha…”

But Agatha wasn’t done.

She checked Rio’s ribs—gently pressing two fingers along the side. Rio gasped, eyes squeezing shut, and Agatha’s heart clenched.

“Likely fractures,” Agatha murmured, tone sharp with worry. “Eight, maybe nine. Breathing’s shallow. Potential pneumothorax—Alice, step on it!”

“Already doing 80!” Alice shouted from the front.

Kate hovered closer, swallowing hard. “Anything you need, Agatha, I can—”

“Stay by the oxygen,” Agatha said without looking up. “If she declines, I’ll need you.”

Kate nodded quickly, stepping back again.

Agatha’s hand slid automatically to Rio’s throat, feeling for pulse. Too fast. Too thready.

Her voice shook. “Your heart rate’s elevated.”

Rio gave a cracked smile. “You’re touching me. Hard not to react.”

Agatha froze for one second—then leaned closer, breath shuddering. “Don’t flirt with me right now, Vidal. I’m hanging on by a thread.”

Rio’s smile softened. “Okay. No flirting. Just… watching.”
