Agatha swallowed hard, brushing soot from Rio’s cheek with her thumb. “I thought I lost you.”

Rio lifted her uninjured hand, reaching for Agatha’s wrist. Agatha grabbed it immediately, clutching like she’d drown without the contact.

“You didn’t,” Rio whispered. “I kept thinking about you. That’s what got me out.”

Agatha’s breath stuttered. “Don’t—don’t say that. You’re barely holding on—”

Rio gave a faint laugh, eyes fluttering. “Hey. Don’t freak out. I promised we’d talk after… remember?”

Agatha’s throat tightened. “You idiot,” she whispered softly. “You beautiful idiot.”

Rio’s eyes drifted for a second too long.

“No—no, stay awake,” Agatha said sharply, leaning closer. “Rio, look at me.”

Rio blinked back open slowly. “I’m here… just tired.”

“You can sleep when we’re at the hospital,” Agatha breathed. “Not before.”

Kate glanced between them, eyes glossy. “We’re almost there.”

Rio exhaled shakily. “I’m fine.”

Agatha closed her eyes briefly, tears slipping free. “You had better be.”

Rio squeezed her hand faintly. “I'm safe.”

Alice shouted, “Thirty seconds out!”

Agatha held Rio’s hand tighter.

And the ambulance sped through the night—Agatha keeping Rio awake, anchored, alive—until the hospital lights came into view.

The moment the ambulance doors slammed open, Agatha was already halfway out, glued to Rio’s stretcher as they rushed her into the trauma bay. She didn’t let go of Rio’s hand—not once—not even when the gurney jerked over the threshold.

Alice hurried to the driver’s side of the rig, panting, hair a chaotic mess.

Kate hovered near the head of the stretcher, clearly trying to be helpful but unwilling to interfere with Agatha’s frantic fussing.

Inside, Jen’s head snapped up. The second her eyes landed on Rio- covered in soot, breathing fast, arm bent wrong, her entire posture shifted.

“Bay Two!” she shouted. “Move!”

The ER team descended instantly.

Gloves snapped. 

Suction hissed. 

Monitors chirped.

Someone cut away the remainder of Rio’s turnout coat with trauma shears.

Agatha hovered at the bedside, doctor instincts kicking in despite the panic tightening her throat.

Swelling along the ulna. 

Deformity consistent with a fracture. 

Left shoulder visibly displaced—an anterior dislocation. 

Bruising across the ribs. 

Second-degree burn over the deltoid. 

Soot irritation around the mouth.

But her heart overrode all of it with a single truth-
She’s alive. She’s talking. She’s here.

Rio grimaced as Jen palpated her shoulder.

“Yeah, fuck” Rio hissed through her teeth. “That feels… really not great.”

Agatha stepped closer, her hands trembling but firm. “Jesus Jen, please—careful with her shoulder.”

Jen shot her a sharp look over her mask.

“Agatha. Back off. You know you can’t treat her.”

“I’m not treating,” Agatha muttered. “I’m supervising.”

Jen raised an eyebrow. “You’re hovering.”

Agatha ignored her.

She leaned in, brushing soot from Rio’s forehead with a gentleness she didn’t even recognise in herself. 
“I’m right here,” she whispered. “I’m not going anywhere.”

Rio gave her a tired, crooked smile. “I know. I can feel you vibrating.”

Agatha swallowed but didn’t answer.

Wanda approached, calm and efficient. “Vitals stabilising. Oxygen is helping. We’re sending her for X-rays—forearm and shoulder. CT for safety.”

Jen nodded. “Order it. Keep her here until transport is ready.”

Agatha tensed. “How long?”

“Ten minutes.”

Ten minutes felt like forever.

Jen continued her assessment, voice steady. “From what I’m seeing so far—broken forearm, likely ulna. Shoulder’s dislocated. Ribs are bruised, but I don’t hear collapse. Burns are superficial.”

Agatha exhaled shakily. Her vision blurred with sudden, overwhelming relief.

Not critical. 

Not dying. 

Not slipping away again.

Rio caught her hand with her good one. “Hey. Look at me.”

Agatha forced herself to meet her gaze.

Rio’s voice softened, barely more than a breath. “You came.”

The words hit her with a fierce, dizzying ache. Agatha gripped Rio’s fingers tighter, her voice unsteady.

“I wanted to run into that burning building for you.”

Rio’s eyes widened—shock, fear, tenderness all flickering together.

Agatha swallowed hard, her voice cracking. “I know I couldn’t. I know I wasn’t supposed to. But every part of me wanted to go in after you.”

Rio squeezed her hand, her body trembling faintly from pain and adrenaline.
 Her eyes—normally so steady, so warm—looked softer now, glassy at the edges from everything she’d just survived.

Agatha whispered against her temple, “I’m not leaving you again.”

Rio blinked slowly, as if absorbing every word, her breath catching just slightly. She shifted her hand in Agatha’s grasp—seeking more contact, more reassurance—and her voice came out small, raw, achingly sincere.

“Promise?”

The single word undid something in Agatha’s chest.

She pulled back just enough to see Rio’s face, thumb brushing gently across the soot on her cheek. “I promise,” she said, steady in a way she hadn’t felt in days. “I’m here. No more running.”

Rio let out a fragile breath, some of the tension easing from her shoulders.
 “Okay,” she whispered, eyes fluttering shut for a moment. “Okay.”

Agatha pressed a brief, trembling kiss to Rio’s forehead, holding her hand like it was the only thing keeping her anchored.

 


Rio’s private room was dim when Agatha finally slipped inside.

She’d needed the time downstairs — checking in on her own patients, handing a case off to Jen, letting her hands stay busy so her heart didn’t crack open entirely. 

But the moment her responsibilities were done, she was moving again, practically sprinting to the surgical wing.

Rio was propped up slightly in bed, left arm immobilised, shoulder wrapped, oxygen cannula in place. 

Her curls were damp from the wipe down after imaging, soot mostly gone now.

She looked exhausted.
 And alive.

Wanda stood at the bedside, adjusting the IV pump with gentle efficiency. She glanced over her shoulder the second she sensed Agatha in the doorway.

“She’s doing good,” Wanda said quietly. “We gave her something for the pain — not strong enough to knock her out, but enough to take the edge off. Ortho wants to see her in the morning.”

Agatha nodded, unable to speak yet. 

Wanda’s expression softened, slowly walking over and reaching out to squeeze Agatha’s arm once. “She kept asking if you were coming.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, but Wanda slipped out without another word, pulling the door softly closed behind her.

Rio blinked toward the sound, her pupils slightly too large, her eyelids fighting gravity. When she recognised the silhouette in the doorway, her whole face fluttered into a sleepy, relieved smile.

“Agaathaaa…” she murmured, slow and warm.

Agatha’s heart faltered.

“You’re awake,” she said gently, stepping closer.

Rio nodded once, slow and wobbly. “Mmm. Got medicated.”

“I can see that.”

Rio’s little laugh was loose, unfocused. “Feel floaty.”

Agatha eased onto the edge of the bed, hands folded too tightly in her lap. “Does it help?”

Rio’s eyes drifted shut for a moment. “Yeah… hurts less. It’s… far away.”

Agatha let out a shaky breath of her own. “Good.”

Rio blinked back open, studying her through a haze that wasn’t strong enough to hide her sincerity. “You weren’t here… before.”

“X-ray and CT took time.” Agatha swallowed. “I had patients I needed to check on. But I came as soon as I could.”

Rio nodded, accepting it without hesitation. “I knew you would.”

The simplicity of that undid her.

Agatha brushed a curl from Rio’s forehead, fingertips trembling despite her effort to stay calm. Rio leaned into the touch instantly.

“You scared me,” Agatha whispered.

Rio’s good hand inched toward hers, searching blindly until Agatha caught it. “Scared myself too… Didn’t wanna think about… not seeing you again.”

Agatha froze, breath catching.

Rio frowned faintly, trying to chase a memory. “Did we talk? At the fire?”

“Yes.” Agatha’s voice was too soft, too thin. “But we’ll talk about that when you’re a little less… compromised.”

Rio smirked — crooked, sleepy. “I’m coherent.”

“You are not,” Agatha said flatly.

Rio considered this. “…maybe not.”

Her hand squeezed Agatha’s clumsily. “Still glad you’re here.”


Agatha’s apology rose up again, heavy and urgent.


“Rio… about that night. I shouldn’t have run. I was scared and—”


Rio cut her off by squeezing her fingers again, eyes sliding half-shut. “Later. When my brain isn’t… soup.”


Agatha exhaled shakily, relief and dread tangling. “All right.”


Rio blinked up at her. “Sit closer?”


Agatha shifted without thinking, moving right up against the mattress, letting Rio rest their joined hands against her side.


Rio sighed — soft, content — eyes already drifting shut. “Better.”


Agatha watched her for a long, quiet moment. “Do you want me to stay?”


Rio didn’t open her eyes. She just whispered, “Please.”


And that was enough.


Agatha stayed.


She stayed as Rio drifted off, stayed as her breathing evened out, stayed as the machines hummed softly in the dim room. 

Rio’s hand remained tangled in hers the entire time.

The adrenaline crash was hitting her hard now — exhaustion creeping in at the edges, her body finally realising it wasn’t in fight-or-flight anymore. 

Agatha's eyes grew heavy, head dipping forward once, twice…
She nearly drifted off.

But then—
A muffled commotion echoed from the hallway.

Low voices.
 Boots.
 And Wanda’s unmistakably stern “No.”

Agatha blinked awake, gently untangling her hand from Rio’s before easing off the bed. She cracked the door open quietly… and exhaled a tired, startled sigh.

Wanda was planted in the middle of the corridor, arms folded, jaw set — a small but immovable wall of red-haired determination.

And in front of her stood:
Tony — eyes still puffy, holding a comically large bouquet of gas-station flowers. 

Bucky — gripping a stuffed animal he clearly grabbed from the gift shop without looking (a yellow bear with a patch over its eye). 

Steve — holding a casserole dish, because of course he was Steve.

All three of them looked like children being denied access to a theme park.

“Wanda,” Steve tried again, usng his Captain voice. “We just want to check on our teammate.”

“She needs rest,” Wanda said, unbothered. “You three will overstimulate her.”

Tony pointed at himself. “I am a picture of calm.”

“You punched a vending machine ten minutes ago,” Wanda replied.

“That machine took my dollar,” Tony snapped, offended.

Bucky gestured helplessly with the stuffed bear. “Can’t we at least give her this? She saved my ass twice last month.”

“No,” Wanda said firmly. “You can give it to her tomorrow.”

The three men groaned like middle schoolers denied recess.

Agatha stepped fully into the hall, rubbing a hand over her face. “What exactly is happening?”

Tony perked up the instant he saw her. “Doc! Great. You tell her. We need to see Rio.”

“No one is seeing Rio except her doctor and the woman holding her hand,” Wanda said, eyeing Agatha pointedly. “And even that was a gamble.”

Agatha flushed. “I wasn’t— I mean— I was just—”

Wanda smirked. “Relax. You’re allowed.”

Bucky cleared his throat. “So… can we see her now?”

“No,” Wanda said again.

Steve tried one last time. “Wanda, please. Just five minutes.”

Wanda didn’t move. “Captain Rogers, I have seen you go hysterical when Peggy went into labour. If you walk into that room and get emotional, Rio will try to sit up to comfort you, and she has a dislocated shoulder. Absolutely not.”

Steve deflated.

Tony dropped onto a chair dramatically. “This is emotional oppression.”

Wanda rolled her eyes. “This is called letting a patient recover.”

Agatha bit the inside of her cheek to keep from laughing.

“You can all come back tomorrow,” Wanda continued. “Preferably after coffee…And showers.”

Tony sniffed his turnout coat and winced. “Okay. That’s… fair.”

Bucky sighed. “Tell her we stopped by?”

Wanda nodded. “I will.”

Steve turned to Agatha, voice soft. “How’s she doing?”

Agatha’s chest warmed. “Resting. Safe.”

Tony’s shoulders dropped in palpable relief.

“Good,” he whispered.

Bucky left the bear gently on the counter. “Give her that when she wakes up.”

Steve placed the casserole beside it. “And this. It’s… Peggy’s recipe.”

Wanda blinked at the dish. “Steve, why did you bring a lasagna to a hospital?”

He shrugged solemnly. “It travels well.”

Agatha finally stepped forward and squeezed Steve’s arm. “Thank you. All of you.”

Tony, Bucky, and Steve nodded — each looking exhausted, relieved, and grateful.

“Go home,” Wanda ordered softly. “You’ve all done enough for tonight. And do not wake up Peter either.”

Agatha watched them walk down the hall together, quieter than she’d ever seen them.

Wanda turned back to her, expression gentler now. “Go sit with her. She’ll sleep better if you’re there.”

Agatha nodded, throat tightening. “I will.”

She slipped back into Rio’s room, closing the door quietly behind her — and Rio stirred just barely at the sound, murmuring something soft in her sleep.

Agatha moved to her side immediately.

“Shh,” she whispered, brushing a curl from her forehead. “I’m here.”

And she stayed, curled up beside her in the padded chair beside her bed, slowly letting her eyes close.

 

She woke a couple of hours later. 

Her neck hurt. Her lower back throbbed. Her right arm had gone numb where she’d fallen asleep curled awkwardly in the bedside chair.

But Rio was still there.

Breathing. 
Agatha sat up slowly, rubbing her eyes. The room was dim except for the soft glow of the monitor, its gentle beeps steady and reassuring. Rio lay on her side—well, as much as her immobilised arm and shoulder allowed—blankets tucked up to her collarbone, curls falling messily across her cheek.

Agatha swallowed hard.

The apology she’d been rehearsing for days rose up again, thick and suffocating.

I’m sorry I ran.

 I’m sorry I panicked. 

I’m sorry I hurt you because I was afraid to love you. 

Please don’t give up on me.

She wasn’t sure where to even begin.

Her eyes drifted over Rio’s face — the bruising along her cheekbone, the small burn dressing over her shoulder, the cut at her jawline. Every mark on her felt like a tally of how close they’d come to losing each other.

Agatha clenched her hands in her lap.

You deserve better than what I gave you. Better than my fear. Better than the way I left.


A soft sound broke through her spiralling.

A sleepy inhale — then a low, rough whisper-
“Aga’tha?”

Agatha’s heart flipped.

Rio blinked groggily, eyes unfocused at first… then clearing as she saw who was sitting beside her.

A slow smile spread across her face. Small. Tired. But real.

“Hey,” she murmured.

Agatha’s chest tightened with affection and guilt all tangled together. “Hi.”

Rio tried to shift, winced immediately, and sucked in a breath through her teeth.

“Don’t move,” Agatha said quickly, reaching out to steady her. “Here, let me get you something.”

She stood, crossed to the medication drawer, pulled out the prescribed pain med syringe, and connected it gently to Rio’s IV port.

Rio watched her through heavy lashes. “You look tired.”

“You look worse,” Agatha said softly.

Rio let out a rough chuckle. “Fair.”

Agatha injected the dose slowly, the monitor continuing its steady rhythm. When she was done, she set the syringe aside and sat back down beside her — closer this time.

Rio’s eyes were already growing heavier.

“Don’t pass out on me yet,” Agatha whispered, brushing a curl from her forehead. “I need you lucid for another minute.”

Rio blinked slowly. “Mm. Talking time?”

“Yes.” Agatha’s voice wavered. “Talking time.”

Rio focused on her — as much as she could through the pain meds — and reached for Agatha’s hand with her good one.

Agatha took it, threading their fingers together.

“I need to apologise before these kick in,” she said quietly. “Before you start telling me the walls are made of cheese or that I’m glowing again.”

Rio smiled sleepily. “You do glow.”

Agatha swallowed. Hard. “Rio… I’m sorry.”

Rio blinked. 

“For running,” Agatha whispered. Her voice cracked on the words. “For leaving that morning. For disappearing and shutting you out. For making you think it was you when it was me the whole time.”

Rio lay still, watching her.

Agatha’s throat tightened. “I was scared. I’m still scared. But that doesn’t excuse it. You deserved honesty — and I hurt you instead.”

Rio didn’t speak yet. She squeezed Agatha’s hand lightly, encouraging her to continue.

“I’m going to make it up to you,” Agatha said softly. “All of it. I just… needed you to hear that before the meds pull you under again.”

Rio’s eyes softened in a way that nearly undid her.

“Come closer,” she whispered.

Agatha hesitated — then leaned in until their foreheads rested together, careful not to jostle anything injured.

Rio exhaled shakily, breath warm against Agatha’s lips. “Thank you. For saying it.”

Agatha closed her eyes. “I mean every word.”

Rio smiled faintly, the meds finally tugging her down. “We’ll talk… proper… in the morning.”

“Yes,” Agatha breathed. “In the morning.”

Rio squeezed her hand once more before her eyes finally drifted closed.

Agatha stayed right there, their foreheads touching, their hands entwined, letting herself breathe for the first time in days.

 

Chapter 19

When Agatha was certain Rio had finally drifted into a deeper, steadier sleep, she slipped from the room. Her body was exhausted, but her mind wouldn’t quiet, not when it kept replaying the image of Rio hauling herself out of that manhole, alive against all odds.

A shower, she told herself. Just enough to pull herself together before her shift.

By the time she pushed through the front door, the sky outside was beginning its slow climb into morning. 

Pale light bled across the windows, soft and hesitant, brushing the edges of the quiet house. The only sound was the low hum of the refrigerator and the faint creak of the floor settling in the cool dawn air.

Agatha shut the door behind her, her fingers shaky on the lock. 

She leaned back against the wood, the breath she’d been holding finally breaking free in a ragged exhale.

Her hands were trembling.

And then the night hit her—hard—every moment returning with brutal clarity. Rio trapped beneath concrete. The collapse. The helpless waiting. The sound of Tony’s voice cracking over the radio.

And finally, Rio emerging from the shadows of that manhole.

She didn’t have time to compose herself.

Because Lilia was already there.

She appeared at the hallway entrance wearing a robe and holding a steaming mug, hair pulled back in a way that suggested she’d been up long before Agatha arrived.

And the moment she saw Agatha’s face, Lilia knew.

“Oh sweetheart.”

Agatha didn’t stand a chance.

Her face crumpled and she whispered, tiny and cracked, “Mom,” before collapsing straight into Lilia’s arms.

Lilia pulled her close, one hand in her hair, the other strong between her shoulder blades — a hold Agatha had known since she was twelve, when she showed up on Lilia’s doorstep with a backpack, a bruised heart, and nowhere else to go.

Lilia had been catching her like this ever since.

“I’ve got you,” Lilia murmured, guiding her toward her bedroom. “Come on, darling. Breathe.”

Agatha tried. The breath caught on a quiet sob anyway.

Lilia settled her onto the bed, placed the warm mug into her shaking hands, and sat beside her, brushing the hair from her face with a tenderness that dissolved Agatha’s last fragile bit of composure.

“You don’t have to fuss,” Agatha whispered weakly.

“Oh please,” Lilia scoffed softly. “I’ve been fussing over you since you tried to convince me you could look after yourself.”

Agatha huffed, a broken little laugh escaping.

Lilia gave her knee a pat. “Now. How is Rio?”

Agatha jerked her head up. “You—how did you—?”

Lilia lifted her phone. “Nat called me. She said half the staff was talking about the callout. Someone said Westview’s Engine 4 crew was hit hardest.”

Agatha’s breath stuttered.

“Then Wanda texted,” Lilia added gently. “She said Rio was hurt but alive. Not critical.”

Agatha pressed a hand to her eyes. “I’m sorry you found out like that.”

“You think I mind knowing if someone you love is in danger?” Lilia asked softly.

Agatha froze.

The word echoed.

Lilia continued, brushing her thumb across Agatha’s cheek. “Sweetheart, I’ve been keeping track of you since you were practically a child. I don’t stop now just because you pretend you’re made of stone.”

Agatha’s throat tightened painfully. “She’s okay,” she whispered. “Broken arm. Dislocated shoulder. Some bruising.”

Lilia’s shoulders relaxed. “Good. I was worried.”

Agatha blinked. “…You were?”

“Please,” Lilia scoffed. “That girl is practically family at this point. She brings me empanadas. You don’t bring me empanadas unless you’re in it for the long haul.”

Agatha choked on a laugh. “Lilia…”

“Don’t ‘Lilia’ me,” she said, smirking. “I’ve lived on this planet far too long to not recognise the look on your face.”

Agatha rubbed at her eyes. “I almost messed everything up.”

“Of course you did,” Lilia said brightly. “You panic when things matter to you.”

Agatha shot her a wounded glare. “Not helpful.”

“Oh, but it is,” Lilia said, leaning in. “Because it means this matters. She matters.”

A soft, exhausted sound escaped Agatha.

“You love her,” Lilia said warmly.

Agatha’s voice was barely air. “I—I think so.”

Lilia raised an eyebrow. “You came home crying like I’ve just announced her obituary. And you haven’t cried like that since… well.” She stroked Agatha’s cheek. “Since Boston.”

The name hit softly, reverberating with years of quiet grief.

Agatha swallowed. “It’s different.”

“It’s the same,” Lilia corrected gently. “You care. Deeply.”

Agatha looked down at her tea, voice thin. “I’m scared.”

“I know,” Lilia said. “But sweet girl… hiding won’t protect you. It never has.”

Agatha let out a shaky breath, shoulders slumping. “How do I fix it?”

“By showing up,” Lilia said simply. “By talking. By apologising. By letting her love you the way you deserve.”

Agatha stared at her. “Do you really think she…?”

“I think she made it back to you from a burning building,” Lilia said dryly. “Yes, dear. She cares.”

Agatha let out a weak, helpless laugh.

Lilia kissed her forehead. “Now go shower. You reek of smoke and look like you’ve aged about twenty years.”

Agatha groaned. “That’s rude.”

“It’s accurate,” Lilia said. “And tell Rio I send my love. And also that if she pulls another stunt like that, I’ll ground her.”

Agatha managed a real smile.

“Thanks mom,” she whispered. 

“That’s my brave girl,” Lilia murmured as Agatha rose, steadier than she’d been in days.

 

 

When Agatha returned to the hospital—hair damp, clean scrubs on, exhaustion tucked beneath thin professionalism—she headed straight for Rio’s room.

The door was mostly closed.

Mostly.

And Agatha heard voices inside.

Rio’s voice, low and warm.

 And Yelena’s… decidedly not professional voice.

Agatha stilled.

Yelena: “You know, if you need someone to help you wash your hair with your arm like that… I am very good with my hands.”

Rio barked a surprised laugh. “Belova—”

Yelena snorted a laugh, “Relax, Im just messing with you.”

Rio was still laughing when she spotted something over Yelena’s shoulder.

She immediately sat up straighter.

Yelena followed her gaze.

The temperature in the room dropped ten degrees.

Agatha stood in the doorway, arms crossed, expression like cool steel dipped in subtle murder.

Yelena froze.

“Oh shit,” she squeaked. “Doctor Harkness. How… long have you been standing there?”

Agatha stepped inside slowly. “Long enough.”

Yelena gulped.

Rio bit her lip to keep from laughing.

Agatha moved toward the bed with measured steps, her gaze still pinned on Yelena.

“Belova,” she said sharply.

Yelena straightened like a soldier in front of a general. “Yes, Doctor?”

“If you are done offering to bathe my girlfriend—”

Rio’s eyes widened slightly.

 Yelena’s soul left her body.

Agatha continued calmly, “I’d appreciate it if you finished adjusting the IV without… the vulgar inuendos.”

Yelena nodded so fast her braid whipped. “Absolutely. Silent as grave—no, no, bad metaphor. I mean—quiet. I am quiet.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “Good.”

Yelena snapped the IV line into place with lightning speed, stepped away from Rio like she was radioactive, and plastered herself against the far wall.

“I will… go now,” she announced. 

Rio couldn’t hold back her grin. “You okay, Yelena?”

“No!” Yelena squeaked, then caught herself. “I mean—yes. Fine. Wonderful. Goodbye!”

She practically ran out of the room.

As soon as the door shut, Rio burst into laughter.

“You scared the shit out of her,” Rio said.

“I did not,” Agatha sniffed.

“You absolutely did!” Rio teased, eyes sparkling. “You thought he was flirting and you looked at her like you were about to take her head clean off.”

Agatha sat on the edge of the bed and took Rio’s hand, thumb brushing over her knuckles. “I’m not… threatened.”

Rio smiled softly. “No?”

Agatha leaned down, kissed Rio’s temple, and murmured against her skin, “But she needed to know who you belong to.”

Rio’s breath caught, her fingers tightening around Agatha’s hand.

For a moment she didn’t say anything.

Then, quietly-

“Agatha… did you just call me your girlfriend?”

Agatha froze.

Actually froze.

Her entire body went still, lips parted, eyes widening with a very un-Agatha-like flash of panic.

“I—well—yes, but—Rio, I didn’t mean to assume—”

 She pulled back slightly, flustered in a way she never was with anyone else.

 “Fuck Rio, I’m sorry. I shouldn’t have said it like that. You deserve better than me blurting things out without talking first and I know I have so much to make up for and I know I hurt you when I left and I know—”

Rio cut her off with a soft, shaky laugh.

“Agatha.”

Agatha swallowed hard. “Yes?”

Rio’s eyes softened, warm and certain.

 “I would be happy to be your girlfriend.”

All the air left Agatha’s lungs at once.

She blinked, stunned, lips parting like she wasn’t sure she’d heard correctly.

“…You would?”

Rio nodded, brushing her thumb over the back of Agatha’s hand.

 “Yeah. I mean—yes. Definitely yes.”

Agatha’s shoulders dropped, relief crashing through her so forcefully she had to steady herself on the mattress.

A quiet, unsteady laugh escaped her. “I don’t know why you’d want me after everything.”

Rio squeezed her fingers gently.

 “Because you came back.”

 Her voice trembled, barely holding steady.

 “Because you were about to run straight into hell for me.”

Agatha’s breath caught. She lowered her head until her forehead rested against Rio’s, the soft brush of their noses almost painful in its sweetness. Her voice came out raw and honest.

“I’d run into a thousand fires for you.”

Rio exhaled shakily, the air between them warm. “Guess that makes it official then.”

Agatha cupped Rio’s jaw gently, thumb tracing soot-smudged skin. This time she didn’t kiss her temple. She tilted Rio’s chin up and kissed her mouth—slow, soft, lingering. A kiss that wasn’t about urgency or fear, but about choosing her. About coming home.

Rio melted instantly, her good hand curling weakly into Agatha’s scrub top, pulling her closer. Their lips moved in small, careful motions—pain meds and bruises be damned—as if they were relearning each other in this new, gentler way.

When they finally parted, breath mingled, their foreheads still touching.

Agatha’s voice was barely a whisper.

 “I’m… your girlfriend.”

Rio’s eyes softened into something warm and stunned and unbearably tender.

 “Yeah,” she whispered back. “And I’m yours.”

Agatha smiled against Rio’s lips before kissing her once more—another soft, claiming brush—just because she could.

The door creaked ope, breaking the softness in the room.

Teen stepped inside, clipboard in hand… and stopped dead.

His eyes went comically wide.

“Oh—oh! Uh—Dr. Harkness! I—I didn’t mean to—uh—interrupt anything.”

 He flailed backward a half-step, cheeks turning pink. “I swear I knocked. I think? Maybe? I probably did.”

Agatha straightened, smoothing her hair, trying to look like she hadn’t just been whispering romantic nonsense into her girlfriend’s ear.

 Rio bit back a smile.

Teen cleared his throat, eyes darting anywhere except at them.

 “Um. Right. So. I’m here because… uh… Ortho reviewed Rio’s scans.”

Rio blinked. “Yeah?”

“Yeah!” Teen said, still flustered. “And they, uh… they’ve scheduled you for surgery to set the fracture. Dr. Danvers is on for the morning list, so you’re first case.”

Agatha nodded, instantly slipping into serious mode. “Good. Earlier is better—the swelling will be manageable.”

Teen nodded rapidly. “Exactly. She’ll come talk to you before pre-op in about an hour.”

“Thank you,” Rio said gently, trying to ease the poor boy’s embarrassment.

“Yeah—yes—of course.”
 He backed toward the door, nearly hitting it with his heel. “And, um… I didn’t see anything.”

Agatha lifted an eyebrow. “Teen.”

He squeaked. “Yes ma’am?”

“Out.”

“Leaving,” he said, voice cracking adorably as he fled out the door.

The moment it clicked shut, Rio snorted.

Agatha sighed, pinching between her brows. “We’re never hearing the end of that.”

Rio squeezed her hand, smiling sleepily. “He looked happy for us.”

Agatha’s heart stuttered.

“…Yeah,” she murmured softly. “He did.”

 

Pre-op was quieter than the rest of the surgical wing, curtains drawn around bays, soft beeping from monitors echoing through the dimly lit space. Rio sat propped in her wheelchair, sling secure, blanket over her legs, Agatha still behind her like a sentinel who refused to let go.

A soft voice came from the entrance.

“Um… excuse me? Is this… Rio Vidal’s pre-op bay?”

Agatha turned just enough to see Peter Parker standing there, face bruised, eyebrow stitched, and looking painfully sheepish. 

Beside him stood a woman in her late forties with kind eyes and an expression of both exhaustion and fierce gratitude.

Rio blinked, surprised. “Peter?”

He stepped inside, biting his lip. “Hi. They’re, uh… letting me go home today. But I wanted to see you before your surgery. Oh uh, this is my aunt May.”

May nudged him gently. “Go on, sweetheart.”

Rio smiled softly. “How are you feeling?”

“Like I got thrown by a giant,” Peter admitted, rubbing the back of his neck. “But also… like the luckiest idiot alive.” His eyes went shiny. “You saved me. You came back for me when you didn’t have to.”

Rio’s expression softened. “I would never leave you, kid. You know that.”

Peter swallowed hard.

May stepped forward, her voice thick with emotion. “I don’t know how to thank you. You ran into that building when everyone else was saying it was too unstable. You got my nephew out when… when you might not have made it out yourself.”

Rio shifted slightly, wincing at the movement. “He’s worth it.”

Agatha’s hand tightened around the wheelchair handle, her heart twisting painfully at the reminder.

Peter stepped closer and gently rested his good hand over Rio’s. “I thought you were right behind me. I didn’t know— I didn’t know you fell. If anything had happened—” His breath shook. “I’m really glad you’re okay.”

Rio squeezed his fingers. “Takes more than a basement and some bad architecture to finish me off.”
Peter laughed wetly.

May finally stepped forward and surprised everyone by pulling Rio into a careful hug, mindful of her injured side. “You’re family now,” she whispered. “Like it or not. And that means we owe you dinner for life.”

Rio laughed softly. “Deal.”

Agatha blinked hard — because watching Rio be loved so openly by the people she’d nearly died protecting made warmth bloom behind her ribs.

Peter looked between them, his brows lifting in realisation. “Oh! Doctor Harkness, right?”

Agatha nodded politely. “Agatha.”

Peter’s smile turned sheepish and turned to aunt May. “Thats the one Rio talks about all the time.”

Agatha flushed scarlet.

Rio groaned. “Can someone sedate me early?”

The nurse passing by snorted.

Agatha moved to Rio’s side and gently brushed a curl from her forehead. “Don’t worry. You’ll be unconscious soon.”

Rio rolled her eyes but smiled.

Peter stepped back with May. “We should let you get ready,” he said. “But… thank you again. For everything.”

May added softly, “We’ll be sending every good thought your way.”

Agatha nodded gratefully. “Thank you both.”

Peter gave Rio one more shy wave before they left the bay.

When they were gone, Agatha looked down at Rio, voice quieter now.

“He cares about you,” she said.

Rio shrugged gently. “Hes a good kid.”

Agatha felt something settle in her chest — something warm and certain.

“You’re a good person,” she murmured.

Rio smiled up at her, tired but honest. “You say that like it surprises you.”

Agatha didn’t answer.

She didn’t have to.

Her hand found Rio’s again — steady, protective - and neither of them let go.


Rio had been wheeled through the double doors two hours and forty-five minutes ago.

Agatha had been pacing for two hours, forty-five minutes and one second.

Jen could personally confirm it.

Because Agatha’s nervous energy had started to vibrate the entire nurses’ station.

Agatha dropped into a chair, opened a patient chart, took one look at it… and began flipping through pages like she was trying to start a fire with friction alone.

Jen watched her for a full five seconds before saying, “Jesus Christ, Harkness, that chart didn’t kill your family. Calm down.”

Agatha didn’t even blink. “I am calm.”

Jen blinked slowly, the way one does when witnessing a person lie directly to their face.

“You’re shaking,” she pointed out.

“I’m cold,” Agatha snapped.

“It’s 75 degrees in here,” Jen replied. “You’re sweating.”

Agatha aggressively turned a page.

Wanda, sitting at the other end of the desk, murmured, “She’s in coping mode. Let her spiral.”

Jen shot Wanda a glare. “No. Because her coping mode is giving me a migraine.”

Agatha scribbled something so viciously on a chart that the pen tip snapped. She stared at it, betrayed. 

“Why do pens break when you need them?”

Jen pinched the bridge of her nose. “Because you’re giving it the death grip.”

Agatha grabbed another pen.

Jen snatched it out of her hand.

“HEY—”

“Nope,” Jen said, standing and planting her hand over the chart. “You’re charting wrong.”

Agatha blinked. “I invented half the shortcuts in this department.”

“And you’re charting like a feral cat today. Go sit in a corner before you misfile someone’s appendectomy under neurology.”

Wanda snorted into her coffee.

Agatha scowled at both of them, stood, paced, sat, stood again, paced again…

Jen groaned into her palms. “Oh my God. You’re worse than Alice when she quit vaping.”

Agatha whirled on her. “Rio is in surgery.”

“Yes,” Jen said patiently. “On a non-emergent fracture. One Ortho has done a thousand times. She’s going to be fine.”

Agatha opened her mouth, closed it, then whispered harshly: “What if—”

“Nope,” Jen cut in immediately. “I’m not letting you spiral in surround-sound. Sit. The fuck. Down.”

Agatha sat.

Three seconds later she popped back up.

“I need air.”

Wanda lifted a brow. “You need sedation.”

Agatha glared. “I’m going to check her chart in the system.”

Jen actually laughed. “You’re not allowed within ten feet of her chart. Romanoff locked it after you tried to override her access to get into Pre-op.”

Agatha froze mid-step. “She… what?”

Jen nodded. “Oh yeah. Full lockdown. Said, and I quote, ‘Harkness can look at it when Rio wakes up and she finally tells her she loves her.’”

Agatha nearly choked. “She said WHAT—”

Before Jen could continue torturing her, the OR doors finally opened.

Dr Carol Danvers stepped out, peeling off her cap.

Agatha stood so fast her chair skidded back.

Jen muttered, “Showtime,” under her breath and stepped aside.

Agatha stood rigid, pulse pounding in her ears, bracing for news that could either shatter her… or finally let her breathe.

Carol Danvers appeared at the end of the corridor, peeling off her surgical cap with practiced ease. She strode toward the desk, picked up a chart, and spoke with her usual cool efficiency.

“She’s in recovery. We set the ulnar and radial fractures and reduced the shoulder. Everything went smoothly.”

The air left Agatha’s lungs in a shaky rush.

“Oh… thank God.”

Carol’s eyebrow lifted as she flipped the chart open. “Did you doubt me, Harkness?” A smirk tugged at her mouth.

“Not for a second,” Agatha said, already stepping past her. “It’s just been a very long few days.”

Carol chuckled softly as Agatha hurried down the hall toward recovery, relief loosening every muscle in her body for the first time since the warehouse collapsed.

When Agatha stepped into the recovery suite, Rio was already propped up against the pillows, blinking sleepily as the last of the anaesthesia wore off. Her arm was immobilised in fresh plaster, secured neatly in a blue shoulder sling. 

One of the surgical nurses was adjusting her IV line, checking the monitors with efficient, gentle movements.

Rio’s eyes found Agatha instantly.

They lit up—bright, warm, utterly unguarded—and a dopey, lopsided smile spread across her face.

“Oh hey, Doctor girlfriend,” she slurred happily. “I dreamed about you.”

Agatha’s cheeks flamed.

 She glanced sharply away, doing her best to hide behind her hair while the nurse gave her a look that balanced perfectly between amusement and oh, honey, I’ve seen this a thousand times.

Agatha cleared her throat and marched to the foot of the bed, grabbing Rio’s chart with the intensity of someone clinging to professionalism by a thread.

“As you can see,” she said, very pointedly to the chart and not the idiotically radiant woman in the bed, “the surgery went well. We just need to keep you on your pain medication… which appears to be working extremely well.”

Rio beamed. “You’re so pretty.”

Agatha pretended not to hear that.

The nurse coughed lightly, trying not to smile. “Dr. Danvers administered morphine PCA post-op. She’s comfortable and stable. Vitals are good.” She paused, then added with a teasing tilt of her voice, “Very good.”

Agatha gave a stiff nod. “Thank you. I’ll… take it from here.”

The nurse excused herself, still smiling as she slipped out and gently pulled the door halfway closed behind her.

Only then did Agatha let out a long breath she didn’t realise she was holding.

She turned back to Rio—and her resolve cracked instantly.

Rio was smiling at her like she was sunlight.

Soft, dopey, utterly besotted.

Agatha shook her head, unable to stop the fond tug at her own lips. She stepped closer to the bed, her voice gentler, warmer, no longer pretending she was made of stone.

“You’re impossible,” she murmured.

Rio just kept staring at her, eyes soft and shining, like she’d woken up to everything she ever wanted.

Agatha perched carefully on the edge of the bed, turning to face Rio. The mattress dipped under her weight, and Rio’s eyes tracked the movement as if even that felt comforting. Agatha lifted a hand, brushing her thumb over the curve of Rio’s cheek.

“How are you feeling?” she asked softly.

Rio leaned into her palm with a dreamy sigh. “Better now.”

Agatha huffed a quiet laugh, shaking her head. “Stop being so adorable. You’re going to ruin my reputation in this hospital, Vidal.”

Rio’s smile grew slow and crooked. “Maybe it’s time everyone knew the real you.” She blinked lazily, the pain meds softening her voice. “My you.”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the gentle claim in those words. My you.

 Rio had always seen right past the armour—straight into the softer, quieter parts Agatha hid from the world. It unnerved her. It grounded her. It made her feel… known.

And she had never let anyone do that. Not since she was a teenager. Not in Boston. Not here.

 But Rio walked in like she belonged in all the locked rooms Agatha had kept closed.

Agatha’s gaze softened as she searched Rio’s face.

“You undo me, Rio Vidal,” she whispered. “I don’t know how you do it… but you do.”

Rio blinked up at her, the fog of medication making her impossibly sincere. “You undo me too,” she murmured. “You showed up for me. You came back.” Her good hand lifted clumsily, trying to reach Agatha’s wrist. “You stayed.”

Agatha caught the hand gently and threaded their fingers together, lowering her forehead to rest against Rio’s. She felt Rio’s warmth, her breath, the steady beat of her life under Agatha’s fingers. It made her chest tighten in a way that was almost painful but entirely right.

“I’m not going anywhere,” Agatha whispered. “Not again.”

Rio smiled against her cheek. “Good… ’cause I’m in love with you.”

Agatha froze.

Just for a heartbeat.

Then Rio’s eyelids fluttered, and she slurred, “Pretty sure. Maybe. Feels like it.”

Agatha felt her heart flip and settle and bloom all at once.

She brushed her fingers through Rio’s hair. “We’re going to revisit that statement when you’re not high as a kite, okay?”

Rio hummed happily. “Still true.”

Agatha kissed her forehead—soft, careful, lingering. “Rest, sweetheart.”

Rio melted into the pillows, still smiling, their hands loosely intertwined.

And Agatha stayed right where she was, watching her, protecting her, her heart slowly stitching itself back together in the quiet of that recovery room.

Chapter 20

The next day dragged on with frustrating slowness.
 Agatha kept telling herself Rio probably didn’t remember the hazy “I’m in love with you,” whispered while drifting in and out of sedation.

Of course she didn’t. 

It didn’t count. 

It couldn’t.

Agatha repeated that to herself every hour.

And every hour, someone else was in Rio’s room when she tried to check on her.

Tony crying apologies into his hands, Bucky adjusting Rio’s pillows twenty-seven times, Alice bringing half her apartment in a tote bag.

By late afternoon, Agatha finally found a quiet moment.

Or so she thought.

She rounded the corner… and stopped dead.

Lilia was in the chair next to Rio’s bed.
 A tin of cookies sat open on the table.
 Rio was chewing happily, her mouth full, crumbs on her lip.

Agatha blinked. “Lilia? What—what are you doing here?”

Lilia looked up, serene as a queen. “Well I came to visit Rio of course. She tells me she’s being discharged tomorrow.”

Agatha’s heart lurched. “Tomorrow?!”

Rio swallowed quickly. “Apparently so.”

Lilia folded her hands primly in her lap. “So of course, I asked her how she expects to look after herself with a broken arm and fractured ribs.”

Rio’s eyes went slightly wide.

“Oh, I’ll be fine,” she said, too brightly. “Alice is around sometimes.”

Lilia scoffed so hard she nearly choked. “Sometimes? Darling, you can barely tie your hair with one hand. What exactly are you planning to do when she’s not there?”

Rio flushed. “I—well—I didn’t think—”

“No,” Lilia said decisively. “You didn’t.”

Then she smiled at Rio with all the kindness of a woman about to drop a bomb.
 “So I will suggest the obvious. You’re coming to stay with us until you’re more mobile.”

Both Rio and Agatha froze.

Rio’s cookie nearly fell out of her hand.
 Agatha’s mouth opened and closed like a startled goldfish.

“Lilia, I—I can’t just—stay with you,” Rio sputtered. “I don’t want to be a burden.”

“Nonsense,” Lilia waved off. “You need attentive care. Real care. Someone who won’t let you overdo it. Someone who knows what they’re doing.”

Agatha’s brain short-circuited.

Rio staying with Lilia. 

Which meant she would be living with Rio.

 Rio.

In her house. …Where Agatha could check on her, fuss over her, keep her safe—

She snapped herself out of it before she smiled too wide.

Instead, she cleared her throat, slipping on the white-coat tone like armour. 

“Well, medically speaking, Lilia is correct. Trauma to the arm and shoulder severely limits day-to-day functioning, and early post-operative overuse can lead to setbacks, reinjury, or—”

Lilia turned slowly and pinned her with a knowing look.

Agatha’s professional veneer melted instantly.

Lilia smiled — warm, amused, victorious. “Sweetheart, you don’t need to justify it. I already know exactly why you want her close.”

Rio turned bright pink.

Agatha nearly combusted.

“I—I just meant—” Agatha stammered.

Lilia stood gracefully, gathering her cookie tin. “I’ll give you two a moment.”

She kissed Agatha’s cheek, then Rio’s forehead.

“And darling,” she told Rio sweetly, “start thinking about which room you’d like. The guest room is nice and all but the morning sun is a bit much. Agatha’s room however, has a lovely view and a kingsize bed.”

Rio made a soft choking sound.

Agatha quietly did the same.

Lilia swept out of the room with the confidence of a woman who just solved a problem no one had admitted aloud.

The door clicked shut.

Silence settled.

Rio stared at Agatha.

Agatha stared at Rio.

Rio whispered, “She’s serious, isn’t she?”

Agatha gave a tiny, resigned nod. “Oh, absolutely. That woman has never suggested anything in her life that she didn’t intend to enforce.”

Rio let out a breath, half laugh, half disbelief. “Wow.”

They looked at each other for a beat — long enough for the shock to soften into something gentler.

Agatha felt it happen before she could stop it, a small, helpless smile curled at her lips.

Rio caught it instantly, her own smile shy and warm, her ears flushing pink. “Would it… be alright with you?” she asked quietly. “Me staying there?”

Agatha searched her face — bruised, tired, but so undeniably Rio — and something inside her eased.

“It would be more than alright,” Agatha said softly. “If it means I get to keep a close eye on you… then yes.”

Rio’s shoulders relaxed, a sheepish grin blooming. “Well. Okay then. Guess that’s settled.”

 She paused, smirking lightly. “Wow. Moving in together already. What a lesbian cliché.”

Agatha snorted before she could help it and swatted her very gently on the uninjured arm. “Temporarily, Vidal. Don’t get too settled.”

Rio laughed — a quiet, breathy sound that slipped under Agatha’s ribs and lodged itself somewhere warm.

The moment lingered between them, soft and a little ridiculous. Agatha felt it—felt herself—teetering on the edge of something frighteningly tender. She tucked a loose curl behind her ear, needing an anchor, some kind of reset before she did something obvious like stare at Rio’s mouth again.

She cleared her throat lightly. “So… how are you feeling?”

Rio blinked and shifted her head toward her—slowly, carefully, because even that small motion tugged across bruised ribs. A wry smile curved at her lips.

“Besides the whole ‘Lilia adopting me against my will’ thing?”

A faint smile tugged at Agatha’s lips. “Physically, I meant.”

Rio shifted a little, wincing. “Arm hurts. Shoulder aches. Ribs feel like someone used them as a drum kit. But… manageable.”

Agatha nodded, falling gently into doctor mode. “Pain level?”

“Like a seven,” Rio admitted. “But I’m okay.”

“You don’t have to be okay all the time,” Agatha murmured.

Rio’s eyes softened.

Agatha hesitated.

This was the moment.
 Casual. Subtle. Gentle.

She could ask—just check—if Rio remembered last night’s confession.
 The one that had been echoing relentlessly in her own chest-
I’m in love with you.

Surely Rio didn’t mean it. 

Surely it was the meds. 

Surely feelings that big couldn’t happen after everything she’d put Rio through.

Agatha perched on the edge of the bed, fingers worrying at the hem of her sleeve. “Um… speaking of last night.”

Rio raised a brow. “Yeah?”

Agatha swallowed.
 God, this was ridiculous. She was a triple-board-certified surgeon, this shouldn’t be the hardest sentence she’d ever tried to form.

“Well, you were… medicated,” Agatha began carefully. “And sometimes people say things when they’re medicated that they might not… completely mean. Or remember.”

Rio blinked slowly. “Okay…”

“And sometimes they say things that sound… significant. Potentially. But perhaps aren’t actually…” She waved her hands vaguely.
 “…meant in a literal sense.”

Rio stared at her, confused but patient.

“So I just wanted to check how you’re feeling today,” Agatha continued, hating how breathless her voice sounded. “Emotionally. Mentally. You know. In case you, um… remember anything specific you said.”

Rio’s face shifted—slowly, subtly—from confusion to dawning amusement.

“Oh,” she said softly. “You mean… the part where I told you I was in love with you?”

Agatha’s heart stopped.

She froze. Completely. Absolutely.

Rio watched her reaction—every tiny flicker of panic and hope across her face—and then her own expression softened into something gentle and devastatingly sure.

“Yeah,” Rio whispered. “I remember.”

Agatha’s lips parted, but nothing came out.

“And I meant it,” Rio added quietly. “Every word.”

Agatha’s breath trembled.

She’d been prepared for denial.

 For laughter. 

For Rio chalking it up to morphine dreams and hazy edges.

But not this.
Never this.

Agatha’s voice came out a whisper. “You… did?”

Rio nodded once. Slowly. “I did. And I do.”

Agatha’s pulse skittered, wild and unsteady. “Rio…”

Rio reached for her hand—awkwardly, with her uninjured one—and brushed their fingers together.

“You don’t have to say anything back,” Rio murmured. “I just don’t want you thinking it was the drugs talking. It was me.”

Agatha felt something in her chest unfold—frail, terrified, unbelievably tender.

She didn’t respond yet.

 She couldn’t.

 But Rio’s honesty warmed the room, melted something sharp in Agatha’s ribs.

Rio gave her a small smile. “So… how are you feeling today?”

Agatha swallowed, eyes shining just faintly. “Terrified,” she admitted. “But… in a way that feels a little less like drowning.”

Rio’s thumb traced a gentle line across her hand. “Good. I can work with that.”

 

Later, Agatha was quietly reviewing labs at the nurses’ station when she became aware of it.

The feeling.

The unmistakable sensation of being watched.

She didn’t look up at first. She adjusted the chart. Scrolled once more. Pretended not to notice.

Then Jen cleared her throat.

Nothing.

Wanda shifted her weight.

Still nothing.

Agatha finally sighed and looked up, eyes sharp and already irritated. “If you’re both going to stare at me like that, you might as well spit it out.”

Jen and Wanda exchanged a look.

A long one.

Then Wanda tilted her head, voice light and entirely too curious. “So… you and Rio?”

Agatha felt the heat hit her face instantly. “No.”

Jen blinked. “That was very fast.”

Agatha crossed her arms. “That was very definitive.”

Wanda raised an eyebrow. “Was it, though?”

Agatha opened her mouth, closed it, and glared at the chart in front of her like it had betrayed her.

“This is not an interrogation,” she said stiffly. “And this isn’t high school.”

Jen smiled, unbothered. “No, but it is two people who almost count as your friends.”

“Almost,” Agatha muttered.

Wanda leaned on the counter. “And friends ask questions. Especially when someone starts hovering around a patient like they’re personally responsible for her continued existence.”

Agatha scoffed. “She nearly died.”

“Exactly,” Jen said gently. “That tends to …cause epiphanies.”

Agatha shifted, uncomfortable. “I don’t see how this is any of your business.”

Wanda smiled, soft this time. “Because you look happier. Terrified, exhausted, but… lighter.”

Jen nodded. “And because it’s okay to say it out loud sometimes. You don’t have to do everything alone.”

Agatha swallowed, jaw tightening. For a moment, it looked like she might snap.

Instead, she exhaled sharply. “This is ridiculous.”

Jen grinned. “So… is that a yes?”

Agatha snatched up her tablet. “I have patients.”

Wanda called after her, amused, “We’ll take that as a ‘to be continued.’”

Agatha didn’t turn around.
But she didn’t deny it either.

 

 

By the next afternoon, Rio had officially been discharged.

The hospital doors slid shut behind them, and Agatha felt the weight of the last few days ease just a little. Relief settled in her chest, tangled with a nervous energy she hadn’t quite learned how to name yet. She stayed close as Rio eased into the passenger seat, one hand hovering at her back longer than necessary, just in case.

The drive home was quiet in the good way. Not awkward, not strained. Just two people sharing space, glancing at each other at red lights, small smiles passing between them like secrets.

When they pulled into the driveway, Agatha was out of the car immediately. She opened Rio’s door and offered her arm without thinking twice.

“Slow,” she murmured, gentle but firm.

Rio smiled up at her, soft and fond. “You’re very serious about this.”

Agatha’s mouth curved. “I’m serious about you.”

The words surprised them both. Agatha felt her face warm but didn’t take them back. Rio’s fingers tightened around her arm, grounding, grateful.

Alice’s handiwork was obvious the moment Agatha opened the trunk. Rio’s backpack was overstuffed, clothes folded in a rush, a hoodie half-hanging out the zipper. Alice hadn’t needed much persuasion once she heard she and Jen would have the apartment to themselves. She’d hugged Rio carefully, winked at Agatha, and disappeared with impressive speed.

Agatha slung the backpack over her shoulder and guided Rio toward the house, their steps slow and synchronised.

The door opened before they knocked.

Lilia stood there, smiling warmly, eyes soft as she took in the sight of them together. “Welcome home,” she said simply.

Rio smiled, shy but sincere. “Thank you for letting me stay.”

Lilia waved them inside. “You’re always welcome here.”

Inside, the house felt calm and sunlit, a quiet contrast to the chaos they’d just come from. Agatha helped Rio out of her shoes, hands careful, fingers brushing Rio’s ankle just long enough to send a small thrill up her spine. She steadied Rio on the stairs, her palm warm at Rio’s back, her thumb making slow, absent circles as they climbed.

At the top of the stairs, Agatha paused.

Her room was just down the hall.

The thought of bringing Rio there tugged at her, tempting and terrifying. The idea of Rio in her bed, of waking up and reaching out to find her there, made her chest ache. She swallowed, reminding herself they were new, that going slow mattered.

She turned instead and opened the door to the guest room.

“This is for you,” Agatha said softly. “For now.”

Rio looked around, then back at Agatha, reading her easily. She reached out with her good hand and brushed her fingers over Agatha’s wrist, a quiet reassurance. “This is perfect,” she said. “Really.”

Agatha helped her sit, adjusted the pillows, smoothed the blanket. She noticed the way Rio’s shoulders sagged slightly once she was settled, the exhaustion finally catching up to her now that she was safe.

“Do you need anything?” Agatha asked quietly. “Water? Another pillow? Your pain meds?”

Rio smiled, tired but content. “Just… a minute to rest. The whole getting here took more out of me than I thought.”

Agatha nodded immediately. She reached out, brushing her thumb gently over Rio’s knuckles, a small, grounding touch. “I’ll let you sleep. I’ll be right downstairs.”

Rio’s gaze softened. “Okay.”

Agatha leaned in, pressing a light kiss to Rio’s temple, careful and affectionate. “Call me if you need me.”

“I will,” Rio murmured.

Agatha lingered for one more heartbeat, taking her in, then quietly slipped out of the room, closing the door with care.


She moved down the stairs slowly, still half caught in that strange, tender calm that had settled over her chest. It wasn’t until she reached the bottom step that she realised her face felt… different.

Soft.

Smiling.

The realisation barely had time to register before she looked up.

Lilia was sitting on the couch.

Waiting.

Hands folded neatly in her lap. Posture relaxed. Expression unmistakably smug.

Agatha’s smile vanished instantly.

Her mouth flattened. Her shoulders straightened. Whatever warmth had been written across her face disappeared behind instinct and pride in the space of a heartbeat.

Lilia’s eyes flicked up to meet hers, bright with quiet triumph. The corner of her mouth curved just enough to say I saw that.

“Well,” Lilia said mildly.

Agatha cleared her throat and continued down the stairs with deliberate composure, as though nothing at all had happened upstairs. “She’s resting,” she said, tone clipped and professional. “The drive tired her out.”

“Mm,” Lilia hummed, clearly unconvinced.

Agatha busied herself with the coffee table, straightening a magazine that was already aligned. “Pain’s controlled. I told her to call if she needs anything.”

Lilia said nothing.

The silence stretched.

Finally, Lilia smiled openly now, warm and victorious. “You were smiling.”

Agatha didn’t look at her. “I don’t know what you’re talking about.”

Lilia chuckled softly. “Of course you don’t.”

Agatha lifted her chin. “I’m going to start dinner.”

She walked toward the kitchen with all the dignity she could summon, back straight, expression perfectly neutral.

Behind her, Lilia leaned back into the couch cushions, entirely satisfied.

Some things didn’t need to be said out loud to be understood.

Ten minutes later, Agatha stood in the kitchen, phone in hand, scrolling with a growing frown that had settled between her brows and refused to leave.

“Comfort food” was apparently an impossibly vague concept.

Everything she found felt wrong. Too heavy. Too bland. Too involved. Too performative. She didn’t want something flashy or indulgent. She wanted something that said rest and you’re safe and I care about you—and none of the recipes seemed to convey that.

She exhaled sharply and dropped the phone onto the counter like it had betrayed her.

“This is ridiculous,” she muttered. “I can remove a fucking kidney, but I can’t—”

She stopped mid-spiral, eyes flicking toward the living room.

Lilia was sitting on the couch, glasses perched on her nose, flipping through a book like she didn’t have a care in the world. She hadn’t said a word since Agatha came downstairs, but Agatha could feel her presence the way she always could. Steady. Observant. Waiting.

Agatha hesitated, her fingers drumming on the counter. 

Then, quietly, a little begrudgingly, she said, “Lilia?”

Lilia looked up at once, already smiling. “Yes, darling?”

Agatha shifted her weight, suddenly aware of how absurd she must look standing there like a lost intern in her own kitchen. “I… need help.”

Lilia raised an eyebrow. “That’s new.”

Agatha shot her a look. “I’m serious.”

“So am I,” Lilia replied mildly, closing her book and setting it aside. She rose and padded into the kitchen, stopping beside Agatha and glancing at the abandoned phone. “What are you trying to make?”

Agatha opened her mouth.
Closed it.

Then tried again, slower. “Something …comforting. But not heavy. Something warm. Familiar. Something that doesn’t feel like I’m trying too hard.” She grimaced. “Something that says… I give a shit about you, without making a big deal out of it.”

Lilia studied her for a long moment.

Not the stove. 

Not the ingredients. 

Agatha.

“Oh,” Lilia said softly.

Agatha’s shoulders tensed. “Don’t.”

“I didn’t say anything,” Lilia replied serenely.

“You were about to.”

“I was about to help,” Lilia said, reaching for the pot on the stove and giving it a thoughtful tap. “You’re overthinking because this matters. That’s not a crime.”

Agatha looked away, jaw tight. “She’s been through enough. I don’t want to overwhelm her.”

“And you won’t,” Lilia said. “Because you’re not cooking to impress. You’re cooking to take care.”

She moved toward the pantry, already reaching for ingredients. “When you were sixteen and came home exhausted and pretending you weren’t scared of the world, what did I make?”

Agatha didn’t even have to think. “Chicken soup.”

“With lemon,” Lilia added. “And rice. And plenty of garlic.”

Agatha huffed despite herself. “You always put too much garlic.”

“Blasphemy, there is no such thing. And you always finished the bowl,” Lilia said, glancing back at her. “Because it felt like home.”

Something in Agatha’s chest softened, just a little.

“But we’ll adjust,” Lilia continued, practical now. “Less salt. Easy to eat. Gentle on the stomach. And we’ll make it together so you stop spiralling.”

Agatha blinked. “Together?”

Lilia smiled, knowing and warm. “Yes, together. You don’t have to do everything alone, Agatha. Even now.”

Agatha swallowed, then nodded once. “Okay.”

They worked side by side, Lilia chopping with ease, Agatha stirring and tasting and asking questions she hadn’t asked anyone in years. 

The kitchen filled with the scent of garlic and simmering broth, the quiet punctuated by small, easy instructions and the clink of utensils.

It felt… steady.

Halfway through, Agatha murmured, almost to herself, “I just want her to feel safe here.”

Lilia didn’t tease this time.

She simply said, “She already does.”

As Agatha stood at the stove, stirring slowly, for a moment she let herself really notice what her life felt like right now.

The kitchen was warm, the windows fogged slightly from the pot simmering on the stove. Lilia moved beside her with quiet confidence, passing her chopped vegetables without comment, humming under her breath like this was the most natural thing in the world. 

She hadn’t cooked like this in years. Not with intention. Not with company. Meals had been fuel, something grabbed between shifts or forgotten entirely. But now she was here, sleeves rolled up, listening to Lilia explain—again—why you always add the rice later, not earlier, and she felt… lighter.

Not unburdened. Not healed. Just lighter.

It surprised her.

A few weeks ago her world had been rigid, controlled, narrowed to work and walls and survival. She’d been running on adrenaline and habit, telling herself that staying busy was the same thing as staying okay. And now—now she was standing in her kitchen humming, cooking soup with Lilia, thinking about the woman upstairs who would be eating it soon.

Rio.

The thought of her sent a quiet warmth through Agatha’s chest. Not the sharp, frantic kind she’d known before, but something steadier. 

Rio was here. Not somewhere dangerous, not a text unanswered, not a presence she was trying not to want. 

She was upstairs, resting, close enough that Agatha could hear her if she called out.

For the foreseeable future, Rio wasn’t going anywhere.

And neither was Agatha.

The realisation settled slowly, almost reverently. There was no running to the hospital, no retreat into work, no carefully constructed distance to hide behind. 

Just this house. This kitchen. This moment. This choice to stay.

Agatha stirred the pot again, watching the steam rise, and felt a strange, unfamiliar ease in her chest. The urge to flee wasn’t there. The need to brace herself wasn’t there either.

She was allowed to pause.

She was allowed to be held in place by warmth and care and quiet routines.

Lilia glanced at her, catching the soft, faraway look on her face. “You’re thinking too much,” she said gently.

Agatha huffed a small laugh. “Probably.”

But she didn’t pull away from the feeling this time.

She let herself stand there, cooking and breathing and being exactly where she was, knowing that upstairs Rio was resting, healing, and that for once in her life, Agatha wasn’t planning her next escape.

She was just staying.

 

Chapter 21

Agatha and Lilia were just finishing up in the kitchen.

The soup was off the heat, the burner clicked low, and steam curled lazily toward the ceiling as Lilia reached for a lid. Agatha wiped her hands on a dish towel, feeling oddly content, grounded in the quiet rhythm of the moment.

Then—
Thump.

The sound came from upstairs.

It was solid. Heavy. Wrong.

Agatha’s heart leapt straight into her throat.

She and Lilia looked at each other in unison.

Agatha didn’t wait for comment or permission. The towel slipped from her fingers as she bolted for the stairs, panic flaring sharp and immediate.

“Rio?!”

She shoved the door open without knocking, breath coming fast, braced for something terrible.
What she found stopped her short.

Rio was standing in the middle of the room, half twisted, one arm awkwardly trapped in the sleeve of a sweatshirt, the fabric bunched up around her shoulder and neck. Her sling was caught at an angle that clearly wasn’t helping, and her backpack lay abandoned on the floor by the bed like evidence of a poorly planned escape attempt.

She looked… mortified.

“Oh,” Rio said, cheeks pink, eyes flicking up guiltily. “Hey. Um. Sorry. I could maybe use a little help? I didn’t want to bother anyone.”

Agatha stared at her for a heartbeat.

Then relief crashed through her so hard her knees nearly buckled.

She let out a shaky breath and couldn’t help the small, fond smile that tugged at her mouth. The adrenaline drained, leaving behind something warm and dizzying as she took in the sight of Rio like this. Vulnerable. Flustered. Standing in her house, wearing her care like a badly fitted sweatshirt.

“You scared me,” Agatha said, voice softer than the words suggested.

“I know,” Rio winced. “I’m sorry. I thought I could manage.”

Agatha shook her head and stepped closer, already reaching for her. “You’re not bothering anyone,” she said gently. “That’s literally why you’re here. So you don’t try to do things like wrestle with gravity and clothing at the same time.”

Rio huffed a quiet laugh, eyes flicking down. “Fair.”

“Come here,” Agatha said, the command gentle but firm.

She moved into Rio’s space without hesitation, fingers brushing warm skin as she carefully untangled fabric from sling and shoulder. Her touch was practiced, attentive, but there was something else threaded through it now. 

Awareness. Want.

Helping Rio this close made Agatha painfully conscious of everything. The warmth of her body. The way she smelled faintly of soap and antiseptic and something uniquely Rio. The way her breath hitched every time Agatha’s fingers skimmed a sensitive spot.

She slid the sweatshirt over Rio’s head slowly, mindful of the injury, murmuring soft instructions as she worked. Rio followed them easily, trusting her completely, even when she winced.

“Easy,” Agatha murmured, hands steady as she guided Rio’s arm into the sleeve. “Almost there.”

Rio sucked in a breath through her teeth but didn’t pull away. “Okay. Okay.”

The sweatshirt finally settled into place, and Agatha’s hands lingered longer than strictly necessary, smoothing the fabric over Rio’s shoulder, adjusting the sling properly. She noticed every flinch, every shallow breath, cataloguing them automatically.

“It’s almost time for your pain meds,” Agatha said quietly. “What’s your pain scale?”

She lifted her hand without thinking, cupping Rio’s cheek with careful tenderness. Her thumb brushed lightly along her jaw as she looked into her eyes, really looked.

Brown. Warm. Soft around the edges despite everything.

Rio melted into the touch like it was the most natural thing in the world. Her shoulders relaxed, her breathing slowed, and her gaze dropped—briefly—to Agatha’s lips before flicking back up again.

“Oh,” Rio said softly, a lopsided smile breaking across her face. “Um. Maybe a… six? But it’s a better six now.”

Agatha’s throat went dry.

The proximity did something dangerous to her. Want pooled low and insistent, sharp and aching, tempered only by the careful way she kept herself still. She wanted Rio with an intensity that startled her, wanted to close the distance and kiss that stupid, beautiful smile right off her face.

Instead, she swallowed and smiled faintly, thumb still warm against Rio’s cheek. “Good,” she said, voice steadier than she felt. “We’ll keep it from climbing.”

Rio’s smile softened, her voice quieter when she said, “I’m really glad I'm here.”

Agatha didn’t trust herself to answer right away.

Because the truth was loud in her chest.

She didn’t just want Rio safe.

She wanted her close. Wanted her here. Wanted this tenderness, this domestic stillness, this slow unfolding of care and desire, to stretch on as long as possible.

So she simply nodded, leaning just close enough that Rio could feel her warmth, and said, “Me too.”

Agatha closed the distance before she could overthink it.

Before the old instincts could rise up and tell her to be careful, to pull back, to protect herself from wanting too much.

She pushed past all of it.

Her hand was still warm against Rio’s cheek, thumb resting just beneath her ear, and she let herself lean in. Slowly. Deliberately. Giving Rio time to pull away if she wanted to.

Rio didn’t.

Agatha kissed her softly.

It wasn’t hurried or desperate. There was no sharp edge to it, no rush to take more than was being offered. It was gentle and lingering, the kind of kiss that came from choosing instead of reaching. From staying instead of running.

Agatha felt it everywhere.

In the way her chest loosened, like she’d been holding her breath for years and was only just now realising it. In the quiet hum under her skin, warmth spreading outward instead of burning too fast. In the steadiness of her hands, which didn’t shake the way she’d half expected them to.

This was what she wanted.

Not distraction. 

Not escape. 

Not something to numb the fear.

This.

Rio’s lips were warm and responsive, soft but sure, and when she breathed out quietly against Agatha’s mouth, something deep inside Agatha settled into place. 

The kiss held everything she hadn’t known how to say. I’m here. I choose this. I’m not leaving.

Her doubts tried to surface, faint and distant. The what-ifs. The fear of loving and losing. The instinct to retreat before it hurt.

But they didn’t win.

Because right now, Rio was here. Leaning into her with trust written into every breath. And Agatha was tried of living her life like she had to anticipate the ending instead of allowing herself the middle.

She let the kiss linger another heartbeat before pulling back just enough to rest her forehead against Rio’s, eyes still closed.

Her heart was racing, but it wasn’t panic.

It was relief.
It was desire, slow and aching and safe.
It was the quiet, steady certainty of finally doing what she wanted instead of what fear had trained her to do.

Agatha opened her eyes and met Rio’s gaze, breath a little unsteady but her voice calm when she finally spoke.

“God, I missed kissing you,” Agatha admitted quietly.

The words slipped out before she could second-guess them. Heat rushed to her cheeks the moment they landed, and she dropped her gaze for half a second before forcing herself to look back up. 

Rio’s eyes were unfocused in that particular way that came from exhaustion and pain meds and affection all tangled together. She looked a little drunk on the moment, on Agatha, and it made Agatha’s chest tighten.

Rio didn’t say anything at first. She just smiled—slow, soft, unguarded.

Agatha snorted under her breath, unable to help herself, and leaned in, resting her head against Rio’s uninjured shoulder. The contact was immediate comfort. Rio shifted instinctively, her good arm sliding more securely around Agatha’s waist, pulling her closer like it was the most natural thing in the world.

Even with one arm in a sling, even bruised and broken, there was still that quiet strength in Rio’s body. 
Solid. Grounding. The kind that didn’t announce itself but held you anyway. Agatha felt it in the way Rio’s arm stayed steady at her back, in the warmth of her chest beneath Agatha’s cheek.

“I missed you,” Rio murmured, her voice low and earnest, pressed into Agatha’s hair.

The simplicity of it hit harder than anything else could have.

Agatha tilted her head up slowly, heart pounding hard enough it felt unsteady in her ribs. She met Rio’s gaze, close enough now to see every flicker of emotion in her eyes. There were a thousand things she wanted to say—apologies, explanations, confessions—but her mouth opened and nothing came out.

Before she could find the words, Rio’s stomach growled loudly.

They both froze.

Then Rio groaned. “Mierda.”

Agatha laughed, startled and genuine, the sound breaking through the tension like sunlight. “Wow,” she said, smiling despite herself. “Timing.”

Rio groaned again, covering her face with her good hand. “I’m sorry.”

“Don’t be,” Agatha said softly, still smiling. “It’s kind of adorable.”

She eased back just enough to give Rio space, though she kept her hand resting on Rio’s forearm, thumb brushing lightly over warm skin. She didn’t want to let go entirely.

“I made soup if you’re hungry?” Agatha offered, her voice gentle now, careful in the way that came from wanting to take care.

Rio blinked down at her. “You cooked?”

Agatha arched an eyebrow in mock offence. “Yes, Vidal. I can actually make my way around a kitchen.”

Rio’s smile widened, something warm and fond settling into her expression. “Did Lilia help?”

Agatha chewed her lip, eyes flicking away for just a moment, the faintest blush creeping back into her cheeks.

Rio laughed quietly. “Thought so.”

Agatha shook her head, but she was smiling too, heart light in a way that felt unfamiliar and dangerously welcome.

Agatha led Rio downstairs slowly, their fingers laced together in an easy, unspoken way that felt worlds away from the careful distance she used to keep between herself and everyone else. She was aware of Lilia’s presence in the kitchen, of the inevitable look that would follow, but for once she didn’t brace herself for it.

She didn’t care.

Rio’s hand was warm and steady in hers, grounding her with every step. The quiet pressure of her thumb brushing over Agatha’s knuckles sent a calm through her that nothing else ever had.
 
This was all she wanted in this moment. This closeness. This simple, domestic tenderness. Everything else could wait.

When they reached the kitchen, Agatha pulled out a chair for Rio without thinking, guiding her gently into it. She moved with the ease of someone who had already decided this was her place to be. She tucked a pillow carefully behind Rio’s back, adjusting it until she was sure there was no strain on her ribs or shoulder. Rio watched her the whole time, eyes soft, lips curved in a small, grateful smile that made Agatha’s chest feel dangerously full.

“There,” Agatha murmured, hands lingering for a second too long at Rio’s back before she stepped away.

“How are you feeling, dear?” Lilia asked, her tone warm and genuinely curious.

Rio turned her head, clearly torn between answering Lilia and continuing to stare at Agatha like she was the only thing in the room. “Oh—uh,” she said, blinking once, then smiling sheepishly. “Better now, thanks, Lilia.”

Lilia hummed, a sound that held far too much meaning, and flicked her gaze briefly toward Agatha. “Mhm.”

Agatha caught the look and felt her ears warm, a familiar flush creeping up her neck. Instinct told her to step back, to smooth her expression into something neutral and untouchable. But she didn’t.

Instead, she moved closer to Rio’s side, resting a hand lightly on the back of her chair. The contact was casual, unclaimed, but it anchored her all the same. If Lilia was smug about it, so be it. Agatha had spent too long pretending not to want things.

Lilia busied herself at the stove, ladling soup into bowls with the ease of long practice. The kitchen filled with the comforting clink of ceramic and the warm, rich smell of garlic and lemon. Agatha sliced the bread into thick pieces, her movements steady, deliberate, the simple act oddly soothing.

She set a bowl in front of Rio first.

Rio lifted the spoon carefully, blew on it once out of habit, then took a bite.

She froze.

Then she let out a soft, entirely unfiltered sound that was dangerously close to a moan.

Agatha startled, then laughed under her breath. “Wow.”

Rio blinked, looking a little embarrassed but completely sincere. “I’m sorry, I just—this is incredible.”

Agatha’s mouth curved into a pleased, almost shy smile. “Told you.”

Rio’s eyes sparkled as she glanced up at her. “You are full of surprises, Harkness.”

“Oh, don’t let her fool you,” Lilia said cheerfully as she sat down with her own bowl. “I’ve been trying to teach her how to cook since she was sixteen. She was never interested. Too busy with her head in a book.”

“That tracks,” Rio said easily, grinning.

Agatha groaned. “Let’s not do the trip down memory lane right now, please.”

“Oh no,” Rio said, immediately delighted. “Let’s. I want to hear about bookworm teenage Agatha.”

Agatha shot her a look. “You’re injured. Don’t push your luck.”

Lilia smiled like she’d been waiting for this exact moment for years. She set her spoon down, eyes twinkling. “She used to read under the covers with a flashlight,” she began. “Wouldn’t sleep unless she’d finished just one more chapter.”

“Lilia,” Agatha protested, already covering her face with both hands.

“And she wore the same oversized cardigan every day,” Lilia continued. “Refused to part with it. Said it made her look ‘serious.’”

Rio laughed, bright and warm, her shoulders shaking. “That is adorable.”

“It was not adorable,” Agatha muttered from behind her hands. “It was comfortable.”

Lilia waved her off gently. “You were awkward. Brilliant. So earnest it hurt.”

Rio leaned back slightly in her chair, turning just enough to look at Agatha, her smile softening. “I wish I’d known her.”

Agatha peeked through her fingers, heart doing something strange and tight. “You know her now.”

Lilia’s laughter faded into something fond as she watched them, the two of them bent toward each other over soup and stories and warmth. The kitchen felt fuller somehow, louder with life than it had in years.

Agatha dropped her hands at last, cheeks flushed but eyes bright. She reached for her spoon, finally sitting down.

And despite herself, she laughed along.

They finished the soup slowly, the moment stretching into something quiet and almost reverent. Rio ate with obvious enjoyment, every spoonful grounding Agatha further in the simple, astonishing truth that she was here with her.

Agatha watched her more than she meant to. The careful way Rio shifted in her chair. The tiny, restrained wince when she moved her arm. The fatigue she tried to hide behind humour. She looked smaller somehow, contained by injury and exhaustion, and it pulled something sharp and protective tight in Agatha’s chest.

When Rio finally leaned back with a soft sigh of satisfaction, Agatha was already reaching for the pill bottle she’d set aside, the motion automatic.

“Okay,” she said gently. “Pain meds. You’ve eaten enough.”

Rio took them without complaint, washing them down obediently. “You’re very… thorough,” she teased lightly.

Agatha met her eyes. Because I almost lost you, she thought, but didn’t say. Instead she nodded once. 
“You were nearly crushed by a building. I’m allowed to fuss.”

Rio’s smile softened, something warm and open flickering there, and Agatha had to look away briefly just to steady herself. Being looked at like that still felt dangerous. Too much. Everything.

“The couch,” Agatha decided, already standing. “You’ll be more comfortable.”

Rio rose carefully, and Agatha hovered close without thinking, her hand settling at Rio’s elbow when she wobbled just slightly. The contact sent a quiet jolt through her—relief tangled with fear.

Agatha guided her to the couch, acutely aware of every step. She arranged pillows with almost surgical precision—one behind Rio’s back, one supporting her arm, another adjusted because it didn’t look right yet. She told herself it was practical. Necessary.

But it wasn’t just that.

Rio watched her with a fond, amused little smile. “You’re hovering.”
