Agatha paused, hands stilling. Then she looked at Rio, really looked at her, and said quietly, “You once said you were trained to catch me.” A beat. “Now it’s my turn.”

For a moment, Rio just stared at her.

Not teasing. 

Not joking. 

Just… stunned.

Something in her expression shifted, eyes going wide and soft all at once, like the weight of that landed somewhere deep. “Wow,” she breathed, almost reverent. “Okay. Yeah. I—cant believe you remembered that.”

Agatha swallowed, suddenly aware of how exposed that admission had been, but she didn’t take it back.

She simply sat beside Rio, not too close but close enough that their thighs brushed, close enough to feel Rio’s warmth, her steady breathing.

Rio leaned subtly toward her, voice low. “You’re very serious about this.”

Agatha turned to her, expression gentler than she was used to letting anyone see. “Someone has to be.”

Lilia appeared then with a bottle of red wine and three glasses, breaking the moment just enough.

“No,” Agatha said immediately. “Absolutely not.”

Lilia raised a brow. “Relax. It’s not for Rio.”

“You’re supposed to be resting,” Agatha shot back. “And alcohol—”

“Red wine is good for the heart,” Lilia replied serenely, pouring anyway.

Agatha crossed her arms. “In moderation.”

Lilia smiled like she’d won. “Exactly.”

She handed Agatha a glass and sat down, entirely unbothered.

Agatha accepted it on reflex, then immediately froze, the stem cool between her fingers. She glanced sideways at Rio, guilt flashing across her face like she’d been caught doing something terribly unprofessional.

Rio noticed, of course. She always did.

“Oh no,” Rio murmured, lips twtching. “Don’t give me that look.”

Agatha lowered her voice. “You’re on pain meds.”

“And you’ve been awake for… what, twenty-eight hours?” Rio countered gently. “Indulge a little. God knows you need it.”

Agatha hesitated, still unconvinced.

Rio leaned in closer, voice dropping conspiratorially. “Besides,” she added, eyes sparkling, “give it twenty minutes and these meds are going to have me on the same level of buzz anyway. We’ll be even.”

Agatha snorted despite herself, tension loosening in her shoulders. She lifted the glass and took a careful sip, the warmth of the wine spreading through her chest in a way that felt almost medicinal.

Lilia watched the exchange with open satisfaction.

She took a slow sip of her wine, eyes flicking between them before she spoke, voice warm and entirely too knowing. “It’s nice,” she said, almost casually, “seeing the two of you like this. Getting along. Settled.”

Agatha nearly choked on her sip.

“Lilia” she muttered, cheeks heating instantly.

Rio, on the other hand, ducked her head with a shy smile, the tips of her ears pinking in a way Agatha found deeply unfair. She glanced up at Agatha through her lashes, clearly pleased, clearly trying not to show it.

Lilia smiled wider, utterly unrepentant. “What? I have eyes.”

Agatha pressed her lips together, resolutely staring into her glass. Rio shifted slightly closer, her good shoulder brushing Agatha’s arm in quiet solidarity.

After a beat, Lilia’s expression softened. The teasing gave way to something gentler, more earnest. She turned her full attention to Rio.

“You don’t have to answer this if you don’t want to,” she said to Rio, voice warm and sincere. “But… what was it like? Being trapped in there? You must have been terrified.”

Agatha’s breath hitched before she could stop it.

Her fingers curled instinctively against the couch cushion, knuckles whitening. She hadn’t realised how tightly she’d been holding herself together until that moment. Part of her wanted to shut the conversation down immediately, to protect Rio from having to relive it, and maybe to protect herself from hearing it spoken aloud.

Rio went quiet.

Agatha watched her closely now, every muscle in her body tuned to Rio’s slightest shift. She saw the way Rio inhaled slowly, the way her jaw tightened just a bit, as if bracing herself. Agatha’s chest ached with a helpless, useless need to fix something that had already happened.

“It was loud,” Rio said finally, eyes fixed somewhere ahead. “At first. Everything’s just noise and heat and adrenaline. You don’t really feel scared right away. You’re trained not to.”

Agatha swallowed. She hated that training had taught Rio to push fear aside. Hated that it was necessary.
“But when the comms went dead,” Rio continued, voice quieter now, “and I couldn’t hear anyone anymore… that’s when it hit.”

Agatha’s throat tightened painfully. She remembered standing outside that burning building, the radio silent, the look on Steve’s face when no one replied through the radio. The memory slammed into her with brutal clarity.

“That part,” Rio admitted, “was terrifying.”

Agatha’s breath caught, sharp and silent.

Rio felt it. She turned her head slightly, meeting Agatha’s eyes, her expression gentling. “But I also knew I wasn’t alone,” she added. “Even down there.”

Agatha felt the words like a physical blow. Her eyes burned, and she blinked fast, refusing to let tears spill in front of either of them. She told herself, fiercely, that Rio was here. That she was alive. That this was not the same as Boston. Not the same as Nicky. Not another loss.

But fear didn’t listen to reason.

She frowned faintly. “You didn’t know where we were,” she said, unable to help herself.

Rio turned toward her then, fully, brown eyes softening. “I didn’t need to. I knew you’d be pacing a hole in the ground somewhere,” she said with a faint smile.

The words landed gently and devastatingly all at once. Agatha’s chest tightened, something warm and fragile blooming behind her ribs. She felt suddenly, overwhelmingly exposed. Seen in a way that didn’t feel dangerous, just… true.

Lilia hummed fondly. “That sounds about right.”

Agatha huffed weakly, but she couldn’t look away from Rio now.

Rio leaned back carefully against the couch, exhaustion evident but her voice steady. “I kept telling myself I wasn’t done yet. That I still had things to come back to.”

Her gaze flicked back to Agatha, lingering this time.

Agatha’s heart stuttered.

“And,” Rio added softly, “turns out I was right.”

Something inside Agatha cracked open.

She didn’t trust her voice. Instead, she reached out and took Rio’s hand, her grip firm, grounding, a silent promise she hadn’t yet found the courage to say aloud. Her thumb brushed gently over Rio’s knuckles, as if reassuring herself that she was real, that she was here.

Rio squeezed back.

Lilia noticed, of course. She always did. But she didn’t say a word.

Agatha sat there, holding Rio’s hand, her chest full and aching and terrifyingly alive, realising with quiet certainty that this was what staying felt like.

A couple of hours later, the house had settled into a softer, quieter rhythm.

The wine was half gone. The soup bowls had been cleared. The living room lights were dimmed low, casting warm pools of amber across the floor. Rio was slumped comfortably into the couch cushions, head tipped back, eyes heavy-lidded and unfocused, her good hand loosely curled in the blanket Agatha had draped over her without thinking.

She yawned, long and unguarded, blinking slowly afterward like the world was lagging half a second behind her.

Agatha noticed immediately.

She always did.

“You’re fading,” Agatha said gently, setting her glass aside. There was fondness in her voice, but also the familiar clinical awareness humming just beneath it. Pain meds plus adrenaline crash plus trauma equaled exhaustion. Her brain ticked through it automatically.

Rio smiled lazily at her. “Am not,” she murmured, even as her eyes slid closed for a beat too long.

Lilia watched the exchange with quiet amusement before standing. “Alright,” she declared kindly. “That’s my cue. Bedtime for the injured one.”

Rio sighed, but she didn’t argue. She shifted carefully, wincing just slightly as she stood, and Agatha was instantly there, one hand steadying her elbow, the other hovering near her back without quite touching, ready in case she faltered.

The closeness made Agatha acutely aware of everything. Rio’s warmth. The faint scent of earth and soap clinging to her skin. The way she leaned into Agatha without even thinking about it.

They moved slowly up the stairs, step by careful step. Agatha kept her pace deliberately measured, murmuring soft reminders—“Easy,” “I’ve got you,” “Tell me if anything hurts”—even though Rio was mostly just humming tiredly in response.

Inside the guest room, Agatha switched on the bedside lamp, bathing the space in soft light. She helped Rio shrug out of her hoodie, careful around the sling, then hesitated for half a second before asking, “Do you want help changing, or…?”

Rio smiled sleepily. “Help. Please.”

The word please did something unfair to Agatha’s resolve.

She turned away just enough to give Rio space, handing her a soft t-shirt and a pair of boxers from her discarded backpack, then stepped back in when Rio struggled, fingers clumsy and slow with fatigue. Agatha moved carefully, methodically, her hands gentle as she helped guide the fabric over Rio’s shoulders, down her arms.

When Rio stepped out of her sweats, Agatha’s breath caught before she could stop it.

Her gaze lingered, traitorously, on the strong line of Rio’s thigh. The muscle there was lean and defined, still marked faintly with scratches and a blooming bruise. Proof of strength. Proof of survival.

Heat curled low in Agatha’s stomach, sharp and unexpected, and she had to look away before it showed. She swallowed, steadying herself, reminding her brain that this was not the time. That Rio was injured. 

That Rio needed care, not want.

God, she wanted her anyway.

Once Rio was changed, Agatha guided her gently to the bed, helping her sit, then easing her back against the pillows. She tugged the duvet up around her with practiced tenderness, tucking the edges in just so.

“There,” Agatha murmured. “Try to sleep.”

Rio’s eyes were already half-closed. “You’re very… bossy,” she said again, voice thick and drowsy.

Agatha smiled despite herself. “You’ll live.”

“Didn't say I didn't like it,” Rio mumbled.

Agatha brushed a curl off Rio’s forehead, her touch lingering for just a heartbeat longer than necessary. 

“I’ll probably be gone by the time you wake up,” she said quietly. “I have an early shift.”

Rio frowned faintly, as much as her tired face would allow. “Don’t want you to go.”

Agatha’s chest tightened. “I know.”

She straightened, preparing to step back—
And then Rio reached out with her good hand, fingers curling weakly into the sleeve of Agatha’s shirt.

“Stay,” she murmured. Her eyes fluttered open just enough to look at Agatha properly, brown and soft and devastatingly earnest. “Please? Just… lie with me.”

Agatha hesitated.

Her mind filled instantly with a dozen concerns. Rio’s injuries. The sling. The risk of jostling her shoulder or arm. The fact that Agatha wasn’t sure she trusted herself this close to her, not when her body was still humming with want and relief and something dangerously close to love.

“I don’t want to hurt you,” Agatha said softly, even as her resolve wavered.

Rio’s grip tightened just a fraction. She looked up at Agatha through her lashes, eyes warm and pleading in a way that should have been illegal. “You won’t.”

That look broke her.

Agatha bit her lip, exhaled slowly, then nodded. “Alright. But I’m not moving.”

“Deal,” Rio murmured, already drifting.

Agatha slipped out of her shoes and carefully climbed onto the bed, easing herself under the duvet beside Rio. She lay on her side, careful to keep her movements controlled, one arm hovering uncertainly before Rio shifted closer on her own, tucking her head against Agatha’s shoulder with a quiet sigh.

Agatha froze for a heartbeat.

Then she wrapped her arm around Rio, light but protective, her hand resting between Rio’s shoulder blades. Rio’s breathing evened out almost immediately.

Agatha lay there for a long moment, listening to the quiet rhythm of Rio’s breathing deepen and slow. Each inhale, each exhale, was steady and warm against her side, a small miracle she still didn’t quite trust. Her arm stayed where it was, protective without pressure, as if some part of her believed that if she loosened her hold even slightly, the world might find a way to take Rio back.

Her heart refused to calm. It beat hard and fast, thudding in her chest like it had something urgent to say.

Agatha swallowed.

She had faced operating rooms filled with blood, held lives in her hands, made decisions that carried permanent consequences. And yet this—this felt bigger. More dangerous. More honest.

Her gaze drifted to Rio’s face, softened in sleep. No guarded smile. No teasing warmth. Just Rio, unarmored, trusting her enough to sleep like this.

Agatha’s throat tightened.

She told herself she didn’t need to say it. That Rio couldn’t hear her anyway, dulled by pain medication and exhaustion. That it could stay tucked safely inside, unnamed and contained, like she’d done for so long.

But the words pressed against her ribs, insistent.

And for once, Agatha didn’t push them back.

“I love you,” she whispered into the quiet, her voice barely more than breath.

Saying it out loud felt like stepping off a ledge she’d been circling her whole life. 

Terrifying. 
Exhilarating. 
Real. 

Her chest ached immediately after, like something long-held had finally been released and didn’t know where to go next.

She let out a shaky breath and rested her cheek lightly against Rio’s hair.

“I don’t know how to do this perfectly,” she murmured, softer still. “But I want to try. I want… you.”

Rio didn’t stir. Her breathing stayed even, peaceful, utterly unaware of the seismic shift that had just taken place inches away.

Agatha closed her eyes, the tension slowly bleeding from her shoulders. Whatever tomorrow brought—work, fear, healing, conversations she’d been avoiding—she would face it differently now.

She had said the words.

And for the first time, instead of fear tightening around her heart, Agatha felt something like hope settle there instead.

 

Chapter 22

Rio woke slowly, the way she always did now, surfacing through layers of warmth and ache and fog. For a few seconds she lay still, blinking at the ceiling, letting her mind catch up with her body. The room wasn’t hers. The light felt different. Softer.

Then it clicked.
Lilia’s house.
Which meant—Agatha.

The realisation settled gently in her chest, warm and grounding. She turned her head instinctively, careful of her arm, half-expecting to find Agatha there beside her like she had been when Rio finally drifted off the night before.

The space was empty.

Rio’s smile tugged at her lips anyway. Of course it was. Agatha would have already left for the hospital, probably before dawn, trying not to wake her, trying to do everything right. That thought alone made something fond and achy bloom in Rio’s chest.

She shifted just enough to slide her hand over the sheets where Agatha had been. The fabric was cool now, but not entirely. There was still the faintest impression of warmth, and beneath it, the lingering scent of lavender.

Rio inhaled softly.

Agatha’s shampoo.

It clung to the pillow, subtle but unmistakable, and Rio let her eyes close for a moment as she breathed it in. Somewhere along the way, it had become her favourite smell without her even realising it. Comforting. Familiar. Safe.

She’d noticed it every time Agatha moved, every time her hair brushed past Rio’s shoulder, that soft hint of lavender followed. It always soothed her, right down to her bones, like her body recognised Agatha before her mind could catch up.

Rio smiled to herself, slow and content.

Agatha had been here. Had chosen to be here.

And even in her absence, she still felt close.

Rio had known from the very first moment she met Agatha that something inside her had shifted, quietly but irrevocably. It wasn’t dramatic or loud, no thunderbolt or cinematic pause, just a subtle sense of something to come.

Rio had always been a romantic at heart. She believed in big feelings, in devotion, in the kind of love that settled deep and stayed. But she had never truly experienced it herself. She loved Alice, loved the guys at the firehouse with a fierce, loyal affection that came from shared danger and long nights and unspoken trust. That love was real and solid and necessary.

But it wasn’t that love.

What Rio had always wanted, what she had quietly carried with her since childhood, was the kind of love her parents had shared. The kind that made the world feel brighter just because the other person was in it. The kind that stole your breath and made your palms sweat and your heart race for no good reason at all. A fairytale love, she used to think, half-embarrassed by the word but unwilling to let go of it.

She had never found it.
Not until Agatha.

The first time Agatha smiled at her—really smiled, not the sharp, guarded thing she wore like armour—Rio had felt it land squarely in her chest. Warm. Disarming. Dangerous in the best way. It wasn’t flirtation exactly. It was recognition. As if Agatha had looked at her and seen her, and in doing so, invited Rio closer without saying a word.

That was the moment Rio knew.

She was going to fall for this woman.
Hard.
Fast.
And without any chance of stopping herself.

She could also tell almost immediately that Agatha was closed off, not in a cold or unkind way, but in the careful, deliberate way of someone who had learned that vulnerability came at a cost. Agatha carried herself with sharp edges and impeccable control, every word measured, every expression curated just enough to keep people at a distance. To most, it probably read as intimidating.

To Rio, it read as pain.

Beneath the precision and the biting wit, Rio could see something softer, something bruised and beautiful. A woman who had loved deeply once and paid dearly for it. A soul that ached in quiet, private ways, that kept moving forward because stopping would mean feeling too much all at once. And somehow, that didn’t scare Rio away.

If anything, it drew her closer.

There was something profoundly endearing about the way Agatha tried so hard to be unbreakable. About the way her guard slipped in small moments she didn’t even seem to notice. The warmth that peeked through when she thought no one was looking. The care she gave so freely to others while denying herself the same grace.

Rio understood that kind of hurt. She respected it.

So she didn’t push.
She waited.

Rio knew that trust, real trust, couldn’t be demanded or rushed. It had to be earned, built slowly through consistency and presence. Through showing up. Through staying when things were uncomfortable. Through proving, again and again, that she wasn’t going anywhere.

And Rio was good at that.

She stayed. She listened. She learned the rhythm of Agatha’s silences, the way her shoulders tensed before she deflected with humour, the moments when her eyes softened just a fraction. She let Agatha set the pace, even when it meant waiting longer than she wanted to.

Because Rio was patient.

And because something deep in her knew that when Agatha finally did open her heart, it would be worth every moment of waiting.

A soft knock at the door pulled Rio from her thoughts.

“Rio, dear,” Lilia’s voice called through the heavy oak. “Are you awake?”

Rio cleared her throat, shifting carefully against the pillows before answering, “Yeah, Lilia. Come on in.”

The door opened slowly, Lilia peeking in first before stepping fully into the room, her presence instantly calming. 

“Good morning, sweetheart,” she said warmly. “I just wanted to check in and see if you needed help with anything.”

Rio pushed herself up a little more, wincing faintly as she adjusted. Her hair was a mess, eyes still heavy with sleep as she scrubbed at them with her good hand. “Thanks, Lilia,” she said honestly. “I think I’m okay. Just… moving slow.”

Lilia hummed, clearly unconvinced but not pressing. She raised an eyebrow, amusement dancing in her eyes. 

“Well,” she added casually, “Agatha already called. Very clear instructions. You’re to eat something before taking your pain meds, and I’m to make sure you actually take them. And,” she paused, smiling wider, “she’ll likely call again to confirm I’ve done my job properly.”

The sound of Agatha’s name alone was enough to soften something in Rio’s chest. A small, unguarded smile tugged at her lips before she could stop it. The idea that Agatha had thought about her first thing in the morning, even in the middle of a busy hospital shift, wrapped around her like warmth.

Lilia noticed immediately.

She tilted her head, that knowing look settling comfortably into place. “Don’t look so surprised, kid,” she said gently. “When that girl cares about someone, she cares deeply.”

Rio’s smile lingered, a little shy now, a little awed. She looked down at her sheets, feeling that warmth spread, steady and reassuring.

“Yeah,” she murmured softly. “I’m starting to see that.”

 

Once they made it downstairs, Rio barely had time to sit before negotiations began.

“Honestly Lilia,” she said, trying for earnest and reasonable as she eyed the kitchen counter, “toast is totally fine. One slice. Maybe two. Dry. I don’t usually even eat breakfast anywy.”

Lilia gave her a look that suggested Rio had just said something deeply foolish.

“Toast,” Lilia repeated slowly, already cracking eggs into a bowl, “is what you eat with breakfast, not instead of it.”

Rio opened her mouth to argue, then closed it again as Lilia moved with swift, decisive confidence—pan heating, bacon sizzling, hash browns sliding into the skillet. 

The kitchen filled with the kind of smells that made resistance feel not only pointless, but cruel.

“This feels excessive,” Rio muttered, though her stomach betrayed her with a low, enthusiastic growl.

“Mhm,” Lilia hummed, not looking at her. “You need your strength if your going to heal.”

When the plate was finally set in front of her, Rio stared at it in awe. Thick slices of toast, eggs cooked just right, bacon crisp and glistening, hash browns golden and perfect. It was a feast.

She laughed softly, shaking her head. “I’m going to leave here with a bigger waistline and a deep emotional attachment to your kitchen.”

Lilia smiled serenely. “Good. That means I’m doing my job.”

Rio took a bite and nearly sighed. Warmth spread through her chest that had nothing to do with the food itself. This—being fed, being fussed over without expectation or debt—hit something tender in her.

It reminded her of her abuela.

Her abuela had been exactly like this. Food as care. Food as comfort. Food as a quiet insistence that you mattered, that you were worth the effort. If you were hurt, you ate. If you were tired, you ate. If life had been unkind, you ate, and she sat with you until the world felt a little less sharp.

Rio swallowed, blinking past the sudden sting behind her eyes.

“Yeah,” she murmured, more to herself than to Lilia. “Food was abuela’s love language too.”

Lilia glanced up, something gentle and knowing in her expression. “The best kind,” she said simply.

Rio nodded and took another bite, letting the warmth settle in her bones, thinking that maybe healing wasn’t just about rest and medication.

Maybe it was also about being fed.

Lilia looked at Rio with a quiet fondness that felt earned, not intrusive. She had a way of seeing straight through people without making them feel exposed.

“You miss her dearly,” Lilia said gently.

Rio’s smile tugged at one corner of her mouth, soft and a little sad. “Yeah,” she admitted. “She was the best.”

Lilia nodded, humming in acknowledgment, letting the weight of that truth settle between them. Then, after a moment, she tilted her head and asked, “Tell me something. What would your abuela do when you were sick or hurt as a child?”

Rio let out a small, breathy laugh, the kind that carried memory with it. “Oh,” she said, eyes drifting somewhere far away. “She made it an event.”

Lilia smiled, already knowing this would be good.

“She’d drag every duvet in the apartment into the living room and pile them on the couch like we were building a nest,” Rio continued, her voice warming as she spoke. “Didn’t matter if it was summer or winter. You were buried under blankets either way.”

She shifted slightly in her chair, careful of her arm, but her expression had softened completely now. “Then she’d make sancocho. Always sancocho. She swore it cured everything. Fever, flu, heartbreak. Probably broken bones too, if she’d had the chance.”

Lilia chuckled. “I believe it.”

“And while it simmered,” Rio went on, smiling to herself, “she’d put on these absolutely terrible telenovelas. I mean, truly unhinged. Dramatic gasps every thirty seconds, people coming back from the dead, secret twins. I didn’t understand half of it when I was little, but she’d narrate the important parts like it was a sporting event.”

Rio laughed softly, the sound fond and full. “We’d sit there all day, wrapped up together, me half asleep, her shushing me anytime I tried to complain. She’d say, ‘If you’re sick, you rest. That’s the rule.’”

Her smile dimmed just a touch, but it didn’t disappear. “It always made everything feel less scary. Like… as long as she was there, nothing bad could really happen.”

Lilia watched her carefully, her expression tender. 

“That kind of love stays with you,” she said. “It doesn’t disappear when the person is gone. It becomes a blueprint. For what you look for. For what you give.”

Rio nodded slowly, the word settling deep in her chest. A pause stretched between them, weighted but not uncomfortable. Then Rio hesitated, clearly debating with herself, before finally speaking.

“Agatha didn’t really get that growing up, did she?” she asked carefully. “Not before you.”

Lilia’s breath caught—just slightly—but Rio noticed. Her eyes shimmered, the warmth in them edged now with something old and painful.

“No,” Lilia said softly. “She didn’t.”

She looked away for a moment, gathering herself, fingers pressing into the counter as if to anchor herself. When she spoke again, her voice was steadier, but the emotion beneath it was unmistakable.

“When she came to me, she was… a shell of a person,” Lilia said. “So quiet. So careful. A timid little thing who flinched at raised voices, at doors closing too hard. Always watching, always braced for something to go wrong.”

Rio’s chest tightened.

“I don’t know the full extent of what Evanora did,” Lilia continued, her jaw tightening at the name. “But I know enough to say she didn’t treat her well. Not at all.” She paused, swallowing hard. “That woman…”

Lilia fell silent for a beat, clearly working to steady her breathing, to school her expression into something manageable before continuing.

“I lived across the street from them for years,” she said. “I remember the first time I really met Agatha. She was ten. Standing on the front porch, shaking, hugging her backpack to her chest like it was the only thing keeping her upright.”

Rio felt something ache low and heavy in her ribs.

“She’d come home from school and the house was locked,” Lilia said quietly. “No note. No warning. Just… locked.” A faint, bitter smile touched her lips. “I invited her to wait at my place. Gave her a snack. Turned on the television. She sat so straight on the couch, like she was afraid to take up too much space.”

Lilia shook her head slowly. “After that, Evanora started asking me to watch her every now and then. ‘A few hours,’ she’d say. While she went out, God knows where.” Her voice wavered. “And I told myself I was helping. That it was enough.”

Her eyes were bright now, unshed tears pooling despite her efforts. “I wish I’d been braver,” she admitted. “I wish I’d seen it for what it was sooner. I wish I’d stepped in before that child was left on my doorstep with nothing but a suitcase and a look that said she’d already learned not to expect anyone to stay.”

Silence settled between them, heavy and reverent.

Rio didn’t speak right away. She couldn’t—not without risking her voice breaking. Instead, she reached out with her good hand and rested it gently over Lilia’s on the counter. It wasn’t dramatic. Just there. Steady.

“She found you,” Rio said softly at last. “And you stayed.”

Lilia’s eyes met hers, something raw and grateful flickering through them.
“Yes,” she whispered. “I did.”

“I’ve known that girl most of her life,” Lilia said softly. “Long enough to recognise the smallest changes in her. The day she met you—” She paused, a faint, knowing smile touching her lips. “—that was the first time I noticed the spark.”

Rio’s breath caught.

“It was subtle,” Lilia went on. “So small I might’ve missed it if I hadn’t been looking for it. But it was there. In her eyes. In the way she lingered just a second longer when your name came up. In the way she pretended not to care and then cared anyway.”

She shook her head fondly. “Agatha doesn’t give her love easily, Rio. She never has. For her, love has always come with risk, with loss. So she learned to keep it tightly controlled, carefully rationed. To offer pieces of herself only when she was sure they couldn’t be taken away.”

Lilia met Rio’s gaze fully now, her expression open and earnest. “But with you… it’s different. I can see her wanting. Wanting in a way she hasn’t let herself want in a very long time.”

Rio’s mouth fell open slightly at the admission, the words landing harder than she’d expected. For a moment, she could only stare, heart pounding, something fierce and protective rising in her chest.

Then her jaw set.

A quiet, determined resolve settled over her features—not loud, not dramatic, but steady. Certain.

“I know she’s scared,” Rio said finally, her voice low but unwavering. “I know she’s been hurt in ways she doesn’t talk about. And I don’t expect her to hand herself over to me.” She swallowed. “I don’t want her to.”

Lilia’s brow lifted slightly, intrigued.

“I just want her to know she doesn’t have to be alone anymore,” Rio continued. “That she doesn’t have to be perfect or controlled or unbreakable with me. I want to be someone she can rest with. Someone she can come apart around and still feel safe.”

She exhaled slowly, grounding herself. “I’m not in a hurry. I don’t need promises or grand gestures. I just—” Her voice softened. “I want to stay. However long it takes.”

Lilia studied her for a long moment, the way one does when weighing something precious. Then she smiled—small, satisfied, and deeply moved.

“That,” she said gently, “is exactly how you love someone like Agatha.”

Rio’s throat tightened. “I don’t want to be another thing she has to survive,” she admitted. “I want to be something she can keep.”

Lilia reached out then, resting her hand over Rio’s with quiet affection. “You already are,” she said simply. “She just hasn’t let herself say it yet.”

The words settled between them, heavy and hopeful all at once.

Rio nodded, blinking back emotion, a soft, almost reverent smile touching her lips. Somewhere deep inside her, the choice had already been made—but now it felt named, solidified.

“I won’t run,” Rio said quietly. “No matter how hard it gets.”

Lilia didn’t answer right away.

Instead, she reached out, her movements unhurried, deliberate. Her fingers brushed gently along Rio’s jaw before her palm settled against Rio’s cheek, warm and steady. The touch was maternal without being possessive, grounding without expectation—an echo of the kind of care that had shaped both of them in different ways.

Lilia’s thumb stroked lightly beneath Rio’s eye, a simple, tender gesture that made Rio’s chest tighten.
“Good,” Lilia said softly. “Because neither will she. Not this time.”

Her hand lingered for a moment longer, as if committing the truth of it to memory, before she let it fall away.

Rio swallowed, blinking back the sudden sting of tears, her resolve only deepening under that quiet blessing. She nodded once, a small but absolute promise settling into place.

 

 

 

 

 

Rio had been trying very hard to be still.

It didn’t come naturally to her. It never had. Her body was used to motion, to purpose, to doing something—anything—that justified the space she took up in the world.

Lying low, resting, being waited on all felt wrong in a way she couldn’t quite articulate. Worse, it made her feel guilty. Like she was an imposition.

Especially here.

Especially with Lilia, who was still recovering herself and yet somehow insisted on fussing over Rio as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

So when Rio noticed the small trash bag sitting by the back door, tied neatly and clearly waiting to be taken out, it felt like a gift. A task. Something small enough to be safe, useful enough to matter.

She could do that.

Easing herself carefully off the chair, she moved slowly across the kitchen, conscious of every shift in her body. She reached for the bag, already bracing herself as she bent—just a little—
A sharp voice cut through the room.

“And what do you think you’re doing?”

Rio froze mid-motion.

She glanced over her shoulder, caught red-handed. “Um,” she said, straightening slightly. “I was just going to take this outside. I can manage it.”

Lilia turned fully now, arms crossing, eyes narrowing in a way that would have been intimidating if it weren’t so clearly laced with concern.

“I see one flinch, Vidal,” Lilia said evenly, “and you are not leaving the couch for the rest of the day. Kapísh?”

Rio swallowed a smile. “Yes, ma’am.”

With exaggerated care, she lifted the bag with her good arm, keeping her movements slow and deliberate. She nudged the back door open with her shoulder and stepped outside, the late autumn air cool against her skin. It felt good—fresh, grounding.

She dropped the bag into the bin and paused, surveying the backyard. Fallen leaves littered the grass in gold and rust, and she found herself mentally cataloguing what would need to be done once she felt a little stronger. Raking. Tidying. Helping.

Soon, she promised herself.

She turned back inside—and caught movement out of the corner of her eye.

Rio stilled.

Something small darted beneath the kitchen table.

Frowning slightly, she bent carefully and crouched, peering underneath.

A tiny black kitten stared back at her.

Wide-eyed. Perfectly still. Like it had been waiting to be discovered.

“…Uh,” Rio said slowly. “Lilia?”

“Yes, dear?” Lilia replied from the counter, the kettle already warming.

“I didn’t know you had a cat.”

Lilia turned at that, brows knitting in confusion. “What are you talking about? I don’t have a cat.”

Rio straightened, glancing between Lilia and the space beneath the table. “Then,” she said carefully, “why is there a cat under your table?”

Lilia turned, following Rio’s line of sight.

She blinked.

Then laughed softly. “Well, would you look at that,” she said, already lowering herself to the floor with surprising ease. “Aren’t you just a sweetheart?”

The kitten didn’t move as Lilia crouched, cooing gently, reaching out with practiced softness. It allowed itself to be scooped up without protest, a warm little bundle of black fur and curious eyes.

“It must’ve followed me in from outside,” Rio said, watching in mild disbelief.

Lilia cradled the kitten against her chest and peered down at it fondly. “Where’s your mama, hmm?”

They stepped back outside together, Lilia holding the kitten securely while Rio scanned the yard, calling softly, listening for any answering sound. They waited. Watched. Looked along the fence line, beneath the bushes.

Nothing.

After a while, Lilia sighed, the sound resigned but not unhappy. “Well,” she said as they went back inside, “I suppose that settles it.”

Rio tilted her head. “Settles what?”

Lilia smiled, glancing down at the kitten. “I seem to have a habit of collecting strays.” She chuckled. 

Rio smiled too, something warm and familiar blooming in her chest.

She had a feeling she’d just been added to that very list.

 

 

 

 

 


Agatha had survived the day.

That, in itself, felt like a victory—small, hard-won, and more fragile than she cared to admit.

She moved through her hours on discipline and instinct alone, guided by muscle memory honed over years in trauma bays and operating rooms. Her hands were steady, precise. Her voice calm and authoritative. To anyone watching, she was exactly who she had always been- composed, brilliant, unshakeable.

But beneath the surface, her focus kept slipping.

Again and again, her thoughts drifted back to the woman she had left curled in bed that morning. Rio— warm, drowsy, hair a mess against the pillow, breathing slow and even in the way that finally told Agatha she was resting. Really resting. Safe.

The image followed her all day. In the quiet moments between cases. In the sterile hush before scrubbing in. In hallways she’d walked a thousand times before, now softened by the memory of Rio’s weight beside her, the careful way Agatha had eased out of bed before dawn because she couldn’t bring herself to wake her.

Each time her phone pinged with an update from Lilia, relief bloomed, followed by a soft, inconvenient ache in her chest. She checked it more often than necessary. Once or twice, she caught herself smiling at nothing at all.

She corrected it quickly.

Not quickly enough.

“So,” Jen said mid-afternoon, leaning against the nurses’ station with an unmistakable grin, “how’s life at home with your new live-in patient?”

Agatha’s head snapped up.

“That,” she said coldly, “is none of your business.”

Jen blinked, then laughed. “Wow. Touchy.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened. She turned back to her chart, fingers resuming their steady rhythm on the keyboard, through her shoulders had gone rigid.

“Oh, relax,” Jen continued lightly. “Alice mentioned something interesting. Apparently Rio called you her girlfriend.”

Agatha froze.

Just for a fraction of a second.

Jen saw it and pounced. “I mean, I was going to ask if that was—”

“Yes, Jennifer.”

The interruption was calm. Clear. Unmistakable.

Jen stopped talking.

Agatha turned in her chair, meeting Jen’s gaze directly. There was no defensiveness in her expression now. No edge. Just certainty.

“Rio and I are… together,” she said evenly. “We care about one another very much.” Her voice didn’t waver. “And I would appreciate it if you kept out of our relationship.”

The nurses’ station went very, very quiet.

Jen stared at her.

Agatha waited.

“Well,” Jen said finally, clearly stunned, “that’s… new.”

Agatha inclined her head once. “It is.”

From a few steps away, Wanda—who had been pretending very hard not to listen—let a small, proud smile curve across her mouth. She didn’t say anything. She didn’t need to.

Agatha turned back to her screen, heart pounding now, not with fear but with something steadier. 
Something earned.

For the first time, she hadn’t deflected. Hadn’t hidden behind sharpness or silence.

She’d simply told the truth.

By the time Agatha signed off her last chart and shut down her workstation, the tension in her shoulders felt bone-deep. Relief washed over her as she slipped into her sleek black Mercedes, the familiar scent of leather and quiet enclosing her like armour.

The drive was a blur of streetlights and low music, her thoughts already three steps ahead—checking Rio, asking Lilia how the day had gone, making sure no one had let the other overdo it.

When she pulled into the drive, the house was dark but not silent. Porch light glowing warm. Curtains drawn.

Agatha stepped inside, bracing for the calm she associated with Lilia’s home—the soft hush, the lingering scent of herbs or tea, the kind of quiet that invited you to exhale.

Instead she heard laughter.
Bright, unrestrained laughter, ringing through the house.

Agatha froze just inside the door.

It wasn’t just laughter. There were squeals too—high, delighted sounds, punctuated by the faint thud of something small and energetic hitting the floor.

Her heart lurched.

She moved quickly toward the living room, confusion sharpening into concern before stopping dead in the doorway.

Lilia was kneeling on the rug, sleeves rolled up, laughing outright as she waved a large blue feather through the air with surprising agility.

A small black bundle of fur launched itself after it, skidding across the hardwood, back legs scrambling as it leapt and pounced with single-minded joy.

On the couch, Rio sat propped comfortably among pillows, arm in its sling, head thrown back in laughter so full and unguarded it stole the breath from Agatha’s lungs.

Rio pointed, thrilled. “Oh my god, did you see that one?”

Lilia cackled. “This one’s got ambition!”

The kitten leapt again, missing the feather entirely and rolling onto its back, paws flailing in a tangle of black fur and enthusiasm.

Rio laughed harder, the sound bright and unrestrained, head tipped back against the couch cushions and slapping her knee in delighted encouragement.

Agatha just stood there.

For a long moment, she couldn’t move.

Because the sight in front of her—this chaos, this joy, this utterly domestic absurdity—hit her harder than any near-miss or long shift ever had.

She took it in slowly, like she was afraid the moment might disappear if she blinked.

Lilia, kneeling on the floor, laughter softening the lines of her face, moving with an ease that came only when she felt completely at home. Rio, relaxed and radiant despite the sling, eyes bright, cheeks flushed with laughter—alive in a way that still felt miraculous to Agatha. The two of them together, so different and yet so perfectly aligned, bound by care and warmth and the easy rhythm of shared affection.

Her two favourite people.

Happy.

Truly, unmistakably happy.

Something tight and aching in Agatha’s chest loosened at last. The tension she carried every day, the vigilance, the fear that joy was temporary or dangerous had eased its grip. This wasn’t fragile. This wasn’t borrowed time. 

This was real, unfolding right in front of her.
And no one was taking it away from her.

Agatha exhaled, slow and steady, letting herself stand there in the doorway just a moment longer, memorising the scene, the laughter, the warmth, the small black blur of a kitten batting at a feather like it had always belonged there.

Lilia finally noticed her.

“Well,” she said, grinning, not even a little apologetic. “You’re back early.”

Agatha swallowed, voice coming out rougher than she intended. “Why,” she asked carefully, “is there a cat.”

Rio looked over, eyes lighting up instantly. “You’re home!”

The kitten chose that moment to launch itself at the feather again, sliding into Agatha’s shoe.

Agatha looked down.

Then back up.

Lilia smiled serenely. “She followed Rio in from the back porch.”

“It probably has fleas,” Agatha said, eyeing the small black kitten with deep suspicion, as if it might launch itself at her at any moment.

The kitten, in response, sat down and began grooming one paw with meticulous care.

“Oh hush,” Lilia said dismissively, waving a hand. “I’ve already checked her over. Ears, paws, belly. She’s perfectly clean.”

Agatha made a noncommittal sound, still unconvinced, and deliberately shifted her focus away from the kitten and onto Rio.

Which was a mistake.

Rio was looking at her with that soft, open smile—the one that made Agatha’s chest go warm and unsteady all at once. Brown eyes bright, crinkling slightly at the corners, full of unspoken affection.

Agatha felt herself soften immediately, her carefully assembled composure slipping like it always did under that gaze.

She cleared her throat, grasping for sternness. “I hope you’ve been resting.”

Rio’s smile widened, unabashed. “Haven’t broken a sweat all day.”

Agatha huffed out a quiet laugh despite herself. “That’s not what I meant.”

“I know,” Rio said gently.

For a brief moment, the world seemed to narrow to just the two of them. They held each other’s gaze, neither speaking, but everything said all the same—I missed you. I’m glad you’re here. You’re safe. So am I.

Agatha felt the tension of the day finally ease out of her shoulders.

Then something tugged at her shoe.

She looked down to find the kitten batting enthusiastically at her laces, tiny paws determined, claws catching just enough to be annoying.

Agatha sighed. “Traitor.”

The kitten responded by pouncing harder.

“And what exactly are we going to do with this one?” Agatha asked, straightening and turning back to Lilia. “Have you called a shelter?”

Lilia didn’t answer right away. Instead, she looked at Rio.

Rio immediately lifted her good hand as if to say, don’t look at me.

Lilia’s lips twitched. “Actually,” she said slowly, “I was thinking of keeping her.”

Agatha blinked. “You’re joking.”

“I am not,” Lilia replied serenely. “I’m getting old. I could use the company.”

Agatha scoffed. “Lilia, this house is never empty. You have more visitors than the ER does. Frankly, I’m surprised Sharon isn’t here right now.”

“She just left ten minutes ago,” Rio said quickly, far too pleased with herself.

Agatha stared at the ceiling. “See? Why must I be the adult in this family?”

The kitten chose that moment to crawl onto Agatha’s shoe and curl up, purring like it had won something.

Rio bit her lip to keep from laughing.

Lilia smiled, victorious.

And Agatha—despite herself—did not move the kitten.

Chapter 23

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha had always believed she was good at discipline.

She’d built a life on it. Precision. Control. The ability to want something and not reach for it if the cost was too high. It was how she survived medicine. How she survived grief.

How she was surviving this.

Sleeping beside Rio night after night was a particular kind of torture she hadn’t anticipated.

Not because Rio tried to tempt her. If anything, Rio was gentle, careful, endlessly considerate. It was Agatha’s own body that betrayed her. The way it reacted to closeness. To warmth. To the steady, grounding presence of someone who felt too good to be real.

Agatha lay awake more often than she cared to admit, tucked into Rio’s good side, acutely aware of every place they touched. The solid line of Rio’s torso beneath her palm. The subtle rise and fall of muscle under skin. The quiet strength there, coiled and contained.

Sometimes, without thinking, her hand would drift.

Not boldly. Not greedily.

Just a slow slide of fingers across Rio’s stomach as they kissed goodnight, her touch skimming warm skin, mapping familiar territory she was deliberately not exploring. Rio’s body was firm there, toned from years of work and motion, and Agatha had to bite back the instinct to press closer, to feel more, to forget herself entirely. But she knew Rio's body was still healing, and she would never forgive herself for causing her any more pain. 

It drove her wild.

The kisses were the worst part.

Because they were never hurried. Never careless.

Rio kissed her like she had all the time in the world, like there was nowhere else she needed to be, no urgency pressing at her back. Her mouth was warm and unassuming at first, soft against Agatha’s, then lingering just long enough to make Agatha’s breath hitch before easing away again. Not retreating. Just… pausing. Waiting.

It felt almost cruel in its patience.

Agatha could feel everything in those moments. The press of Rio’s body beneath her hands. The solid heat of her, steady and alive. When Agatha’s fingers skimmed over the smooth plane of Rio’s lower stomach, just barely tracing the definition there, Rio would inhale sharply, a quiet sound that went straight through Agatha’s chest.

And still, Rio never pushed.

She trusted Agatha completely.

Trusted her to lead, or to stop. Trusted her not to take advantage of the way Rio melted into her touch, the way her mouth softened and parted so easily. Trusted her restraint in a way that made Agatha ache more fiercely than want ever could.

Agatha could feel how close she was to losing herself. How easily the careful balance could tip if she let her hands linger a second longer, if she deepened the kiss just a fraction more, if she allowed herself to follow the instinct burning low in her body instead of the discipline she clung to.

Every nerve felt lit, buzzing with awareness. Her pulse thudded loud in her ears. She had to concentrate on keeping her touch reverent rather than hungry, grounding rather than claiming.

Sometimes she broke the kiss herself, breath uneven, resting her forehead against Rio’s while her hands stayed exactly where they were. Not because she wanted to stop kissing her, but because she didn’t trust herself not to want more.

Rio never complained.

She would just smile, soft and knowing, and brush her thumb along Agatha’s jaw as if to say I’m here. I understand.

That trust—that quiet, unspoken permission coupled with absolute patience—was what made it unbearable.

Agatha had faced trauma and blood and loss without flinching.

But this?

This slow, deliberate closeness, this wanting held carefully in check, this intimacy that stopped just short of relief—
It undid her.

And every night, she chose it anyway.

Later, alone with her thoughts, Agatha would lie there staring at the dark, pulse loud in her ears, frustrated and aching and profoundly grateful all at once. She hated how much she wanted. Hated how easily Rio undid her. Hated most of all how willingly she chose restraint.

And yet.

There was something almost unbearable in how right it felt to want like this and still stop. To know she could take more and choose not to. To let care outweigh desire without resentment.

It was new. Dangerous. Intimate in its own way.

Some nights, Rio would shift slightly, half asleep, and murmur her name under her breath. Agatha would tighten her arm around her, press a kiss into her hair, and whisper nothing back. She didn’t trust her voice in those moments.

Because loving Rio like this meant learning a different kind of control.

Not the kind that locked things away.

The kind that stayed.

 

 

 

 

 


The cast came off on a Thursday.

It was nothing like Rio had expected. No fanfare, no pause to mark the end of something difficult. Just a curt explanation from the tech, a warning about the noise, and then the whirr of the saw filling the small exam room. Rio startled at the sound, shoulders tensing on instinct, but she didn’t flinch. Not really.

Agatha noticed anyway.

She stood near the wall with her arms crossed, posture rigid, eyes fixed on the careful line of the blade as it cut through plaster and padding. Her jaw was tight, every muscle in her body braced as if she were the one under the blade. She didn’t look away. She didn’t blink.

The cast split cleanly and was lifted away in two pale halves, exposing skin that looked almost unreal in its paleness. Rio stared at her arm for a second like she didn’t quite recognise it, then laughed softly under her breath.

“Well,” she said, flexing her fingers tentatively. “That’s… gross.”

She rotated her wrist, slow at first, then a little more confidently, testing the movement. Her grin spread, bright and boyish, edged with disbelief and something like triumph.

Agatha only allowed herself to breathe once Rio rolled her shoulder experimentally, careful but unafraid, and smiled again. This one was different. Less tentative. More certain.

“Ribs feel okay,” Rio said lightly, as if she weren’t reporting on something Agatha had been tracking obsessively for weeks. “Little stiff. Not painful.”

Agatha nodded, filing the information away, already recalibrating every boundary she’d been living by for weeks. Her voice came out even, controlled. “Still. Desk duty for at least a week,” she said automatically. 

“No heroics.”

Rio smiled. “Yes, doctor.”

It should have marked a return to normal.

Technically, Rio was due to move back to her own place now. The cast was gone, mobility returning, work easing her back in gently. On paper, there was no longer any reason for her to be staying at Lilia’s.

However, Lilia kept finding reasons.

Give Alice and Jen “some more privacy for a while.” The weather “wasn’t great for moving things.” The kitten would “need more time to say goodbye,” and wouldn’t it be easier if Rio stayed just a few more days? Just until the weekend. Just until she felt fully steady.

Rio accepted every excuse with an indulgent smile, clearly aware of what was happening and choosing not to argue.

Agatha noticed that too.

She didn’t comment on it. She didn’t need to. But something warm and quietly grateful settled in her chest at the way Lilia folded Rio into the house as if it were the most natural thing in the world.

As if staying wasn’t an imposition.
As if Rio already belonged there.
And maybe, Agatha thought as she followed Rio out of the exam room, that was the most dangerous shift of all.

 

That night, Lilia barely made it through dinner before she checked the clock and hummed to herself.

“Well,” she said brightly, pushing back from the table with an energy that felt just a little too deliberate, “I’m off to bingo with Sharon.”

Agatha looked up from where she was stacking plates, the words taking a moment to register.

“Bingo?” Rio echoed from the couch, brows lifting.

“Yes,” Lilia said, already shrugging into her coat. “She’s been on a winning streak and insists it’s because I bring her luck.” She reached for her keys, then added lightly, “I’ll be late. Don’t wait up.”

Agatha froze mid-step.

It was subtle. Anyone else might have missed it. The way her hand stilled against the counter. The fractional pause in her breathing, like her body had reached the conclusion before her mind caught up.

Rio caught it immediately.

“Oh,” Rio said, trying — and failing — to sound casual. “Okay.”

Lilia turned then, eyes flicking between the two of them. There it was. That small, knowing smile that lived just at the corner of her mouth. Not smug. Not teasing. Simply aware.

“Well,” she said, patting Rio’s shoulder as she passed, “behave yourselves.”

Agatha blinked. “Lilia—”

“I said don’t wait up,” Lilia repeated cheerfully, already opening the door. She paused just long enough to glance back at them, warmth softening her expression. “Enjoy the quiet.”

And then she was gone.

The door closed behind her with a soft, definitive click that echoed through the house far louder than it had any right to.

The silence that followed was different.

Not awkward. Just… charged.

Agatha stood very still, acutely aware of the space Lilia had left behind. Of Rio, warm and solid only a few feet away. Of the fact that for the first time in weeks, there was no one else in the house to hear them breathe.

Rio shifted slightly, rolling her shoulders as if she, too, were adjusting to the change. “She did that on purpose,” she said quietly.

Agatha swallowed. “She absolutely did.”

Agatha stood in the quiet of the hallway and realised something had finally tipped.

Rio was alone with her now. Truly alone. No cast. No careful choreography. No fragile caution threading through every thought. She was still healing, yes—but she was strong, steady on her feet, shoulders loose, body no longer guarded in that instinctive way Agatha had memorised.

Ninety percent healed.

And Agatha was done pretending she wasn’t counting the percentage.

She watched Rio move through the living room, barefoot, comfortable, reaching for a glass of water like this was already her home. The sight hit Agatha low and sharp, a rush of want she didn’t bother suppressing this time.

She had waited. God, she had waited.

With discipline. With restraint that had burned her raw.

Enough.

Rio turned and caught her staring.

There it was. That flicker. That shared recognition that landed between them like a struck match.

Agatha didn’t think anymore.

She moved.

Rio met her halfway, just as decisive, hands fisting in Agatha’s shirt and pulling her close. The impact of it drove them both back, shoulders hitting the wall with a soft, startled thud that knocked the breath from Agatha’s lungs in the best possible way.

Their mouths crashed together.

Not slow. Not careful.

Hungry. Heated. Weeks of restraint breaking open in a single, unguarded kiss.

Rio’s hands came up instinctively, bracketing Agatha against the wall, not pinning her, just there—present, grounding, desperate to feel her beneath her palms. Agata kissed her back with equal force, lips warm and insistent, body pressing forward without hesitation.

Agatha felt it everywhere. The heat. The strength. The certainty.

She dragged her mouth away just long enough to breathe, forehead resting against Rio’s, pulse roaring in her ears. “Tell me if—”

“I will,” Rio said immediately, breathless but sure, Agatha's hands already sliding up her back. “I’m good. I want this.”

That was all it took.

Agatha kissed her again, slower this time but deeper, pouring everything she’d held back into the press of her mouth, the way her body curved in close. Rio responded with a soft sound that went straight through Agatha, her fingers tightening, grounding her there like she’d been waiting for this moment just as fiercely.

They stayed like that for a long moment—breathing hard, foreheads touching, bodies pressed close enough to feel every shift and tremor.

Agatha laughed quietly, incredulous, her control finally set down rather than shattered. “I waited,” she murmured. “I really fucking did. It was so hard not to...”

Rio smiled, flushed and radiant, thumbs brushing along Agatha’s jaw. “I know,” she said. “I felt it.”

The heat between them built steadily, unhurried but undeniable. It wasn’t frantic. It was focused. Every movement chosen, every pause charged. Agatha felt her control loosening, not slipping away, but being set down carefully, piece by piece.

Rio guided her gently, small shifts, quiet breaths against her neck. Agatha followed, attentive to every response, every subtle change. The world narrowed to warmth and closeness and the way Rio fit against her like this had always been inevitable.

At some point they ended up in the bedroom without either of them remembering who led the way.

Their mouths connected like magnets, breath mingling, teeth nipping with an urgency that had been building for far too long. Agatha’s hands moved with a purpose she hadn’t allowed them in weeks, sliding under Rio’s shirt to find warm skin, tracing the lines of muscle she’d been trying not to think about for weeks. Rio’s response was immediate, a low sound in her throat that sent a jolt straight to Agatha’s core.

Agatha braced herself above Rio just long enough to assess, to gauge what she needed. The answer was written across her face — flushed skin, eyes dark with want, mouth already kiss-swollen.

“Agatha…please.”

Agatha kissed her again without hesitation, all the hunger she’d been suppressing finally unleashed. Rio arched into her, no longer holding back, no longer guarding herself against what they both knew was inevitable.

Rio responded to each touch with a soft gasp or a quiet murmur of pleasure that only fuelled Agatha’s desire.

She broke the kiss just long enough to pull Rio’s shirt over her head, tossing it aside without a glance. Her bra followed, and then it was just skin against skin, heat meeting heat, heartbeats racing together.

“Beautiful,” Agatha murmured against Rio’s throat, her lips tracing patterns along the sensitive skin there. She felt Rio swallow hard, her pulse quickening under Agatha’s mouth.

“You too,” Rio managed, her hands finding Agatha’s shoulders, tugging insistently. Agatha obliged, shedding her own clothes between frantic kisses, never wanting to be away from Rio’s touch for more than a second.

When they were both bare, skin to skin from chest to toes, Agatha paused for just a moment, drinking in the sight of Rio beneath her. The street lights filtering through the curtains painted her in soft golds and blues, accentuating every curve, every line of her.

She was breathtaking.

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, reaching for her. Agatha lowered herself back down, their bodies aligning perfectly as they moved together, seeking friction and connection, giving and taking in equal measure.

Weeks of denial were culminating in a collision of limbs and breathless kisses, hands gripping too tight, bodies moving with an urgency that bordered on ferocious.

Agatha found herself mesmerised by the wet heat between Rio’s thighs, her fingers gliding easily through slick folds, finding the spot that made Rio’s breath catch and hold.

Her mind fractured into sharp, brilliant pieces.

She’s here.

 Not fragile. Not breakable. Warm and solid beneath her hands, moving with her, meeting her without hesitation. Every part of Agatha that had been braced for weeks loosened all at once, and the release was dizzying.

The sounds Rio made when Agatha touched her like this were intoxicating — soft whimpers, little gasps, her hips moving instinctively to meet Agatha’s hand. Watching her fall apart was addictive, and Agatha found herself wanting to push Rio just a little further each time, wanting to see how much she could take before she couldn’t hold back anymore.

In turn, Rio’s touch was electric. The way her fingers moved over Agatha’s skin was reverent, like every inch of her was something to be appreciated. When she finally, finally moved lower, her touch was sure, her intent clear. Agatha felt her own breath quicken, her heart rate spike as Rio’s fingers pressed into her, filling her, the sensation almost overwhelming.

They fit together in a way that felt impossibly right, their bodies moving as one, each seeking their own pleasure while simultaneously wanting to give the other everything. It was a feedback loop of sensation, each moment building on the last, pushing them both closer and closer to that inevitable release.

Agatha had the strange, disorienting sense that the world had gone quiet.

Not faded.
 Stopped.

Rio was beneath her hands, warm and real, and when Agatha lifted her head and met her gaze, everything else fell away. The room. The house. Time itself. It was just the two of them, suspended in that charged, breathless space where nothing existed beyond what they were choosing.

Rio was watching her.

Not passively. Not waiting.

Actively holding her gaze, eyes dark and intent, pupils blown wide with want and trust and something that made Agatha’s chest ache. There was no hesitation there. No doubt. Just a steady, unflinching presence that said I am here with you. All the way.

Agatha felt it like a physical blow.

Her hands tightened instinctively, not to restrain but to anchor herself, palms memorising the heat and solidity of Rio’s body as if she were afraid it might vanish if she blinked. Her breath stuttered, her heart thudding so loudly she was sure Rio could feel it.

This is it, she thought, dizzy. 

This is what it feels like.

She had never been able to hold eye contact like this before. Not when things mattered. Not when vulnerability crept too close. But now, she couldn’t look away even if she wanted to. Rio’s gaze held her, steady and unwavering, and Agatha realised with a sharp, almost painful clarity that she was seen.

Completely.

Loved in real time.

Her thoughts scattered, fragmented under the weight of it. I love you pulsed through her, wordless but absolute, settling deep in her chest until it felt too big to contain. The feeling was overwhelming, heady, almost frightening in its intensity. She felt lightheaded, unmoored, like the ground had dropped out from under her and she was falling straight into Rio’s eyes.

When she moved, it was instinctive, driven by that pull.

Her touch deepened, her presence sharpened, but she never broke eye contact. Neither did Rio. They stayed locked there, breathing each other in, the connection between them loud and undeniable.

Agatha felt it cresting in her lower belly first, a swelling warmth that left her dizzy and unsteady, like standing too close to the edge of something vast. The love hit her again then, overwhelming in its clarity. 

I love her. The thought was so sharp and sudden it nearly undid her.

Rio’s eyes softened, deepened, as if she felt it too.

They stayed locked together as their orgasm peaked, breath hitching in unison, bodies tightening instinctively as the sensation surged through them. 

There was no single movement that caused it.

No act to point to. Just the culmination of touch and gaze and weeks of held-back want finally breaking open.

Agatha’s grip tightened as the feeling swept through her, stealing the air from her lungs. She opened her mouth in a silent scream as the pleasure rippled through her, vibrating from her spine to her toes.

Rio made a soft, breathless sound, her hands anchoring Agatha there as the intensity washed over them both, shared and undeniable.

And then it eased.

Not abruptly. Not cleanly.

But slowly, like a tide pulling back, leaving warmth and closeness in its wake.

Agatha rested her forehead against Rio’s, eyes closed now, breath trembling as she came back to herself. 

Her hands stayed exactly where they were, unwilling to let go.

When she finally opened her eyes again, Rio was still watching her.

Still here.

Still smiling like the world had just tilted and somehow landed exactly right.

Agatha stayed there, forehead resting against Rio’s, both of them panting, still catching up to their own bodies. Her hands hadn’t moved. She wasn’t ready for them to. The warmth lingered everywhere, a soft, echoing hum that made her feel lightheaded and strangely anchored all at once.

For a few seconds, neither of them spoke.

Rio’s eyes were still on her, unfocused and tender, dark with aftershock and something softer underneath. The world felt distant, muffled, as if it had stepped politely aside to give them this moment.

Agatha swallowed.

Her chest felt too full, her heart still racing, the truth pressing insistently at the back of her throat. She hadn’t planned to say it. Hadn’t rehearsed it or weighed the consequences the way she usually did. It simply existed now, undeniable.

She leaned in just enough that her lips brushed Rio’s ear.

“I love you,” she whispered.

The words left her softly, almost reverently, like a confession she’d been holding in far longer than she realised. Saying them didn’t feel frightening. It felt grounding. Like setting something precious down exactly where it belonged.

Rio stilled.

Then her arms tightened around Agatha, solid and sure, pulling her closer without urgency, just presence. She didn’t rush to respond. She didn’t need to. Her hand slid up Agatha’s back, warm and anchoring, her breath steadying against her skin.

They didn’t stop.

Not after the first time. Not after the second.

Each time blurred into the next, urgency giving way to laughter, then back again, the volume rising with every round as restraint slipped further and further out of reach. Agatha was dimly aware that the house had thin walls. She was also dimly aware that she no longer cared. The thought surfaced once, flickered, and vanished under the pull of Rio’s hands and mouth and the dizzying sense of finally not holding herself back.

By the time Rio laughed breathlessly and pressed her forehead to Agatha’s shoulder, Agatha felt loose in a way she hadn’t in years.

“Okay,” Rio said, still smiling, still too close. “I think I need water before I fall over.”

Agatha huffed out a quiet laugh. “Come downstairs with me.”

Rio barely managed to shove on boxers and an old T-shirt. Agatha grabbed her robe, tying it with far less care than she usually applied to anything, cheeks still warm, pulse still loud. They didn’t make it more than a few steps without colliding again, hands roaming automatically, mouths meeting between half-whispered laughter.

They were a mess.

They kissed on the stairs. Nearly missed a step. Rio giggled when Agatha bumped her hip into the banister, and Agatha hissed a warning that carried absolutely no authority.

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, grinning.

“Keep moving,” Agatha muttered, though she was the one who stopped to kiss her again.

They turned the corner into the kitchen—
And froze.

“Oh,” Sharon said.

Agatha felt the blood drain from her face.

Lilia and Sharon were standing at the table, bingo cards spread out, coats half-off. 

Sharon stared very intently at the wall. The counter. The ceiling. Anything but the two of them tangled together in the doorway.

Lilia, meanwhile, looked pleased.

Deeply. Unmistakably. Smugly pleased.

Agatha’s hand dropped from Rio’s waist like it had been burned. She straightened too fast, robe clutched closed, posture snapping back into something stiff and defensive that fooled absolutely no one.

“You’re—” Agatha stopped. Cleared her throat. Tried again. “You’re home.”

“Yes,” Lilia said serenely, eyes sparkling. “Earlier than planned.”

Agatha nodded too many times. “I— we—” She gestured vaguely toward the fridge. “Water.”

Sharon coughed loudly. “Thirst work.”

Agatha closed her eyes.

Just briefly. Just long enough to regret every life choice that had led her here.

Rio, traitor that she was, pressed her face into Agatha’s shoulder, shoulders shaking with barely-contained laughter.

Lilia glanced between them, taking in the flushed cheeks, the rumpled clothes, the way Agatha couldn’t quite meet her eye. Her smile softened, though it never lost its knowing edge.

“I told you I’d be late,” Lilia said gently.

Agatha muttered, “You absolutely did not specify how late.”

Sharon was still very committed to not looking at either of them. “I’m just going to… make tea,” she announced, already moving.

Agatha nodded stiffly. “Excellent. Tea. Great.”

Rio finally looked up, still grinning, entirely unashamed. “Hi,” she offered.

Lilia smiled warmly at her. “Hello, sweetheart. Glad you’re feeling better.”

Agatha remained rooted to the spot, mortified, ears burning, very aware that this was the least dignified she had felt in years.

And, irritatingly—
Also the happiest.

 

Chapter End Notes

I love writing them 🖤

Chapter 24

Rio eventually moved back into her apartment.

Lilia took the news personally.

She tried not to, truly she did, but it showed anyway—in the way she sighed dramatically while helping Rio pack, in the way she found reasons to press leftovers into her hands, in the way she lingered at the door just a little too long on the day.

“I suppose I’ll just rattle around the house by myself now,” Lilia said mournfully, patting Ebony the kitten as if she, too, were being abandoned.

Agatha glanced up from where she was carrying a box toward the door, eyebrow lifting.

“I still live here,” she said evenly.

Lilia sniffed. “You’re hardly ever home.”

Agatha paused, considering that. Then, with absolutely no apology in her tone, she replied, “Yes. I wonder why.”

Rio hugged her tight, murmuring reassurances and promises to visit often, to come for dinner, to call. Agatha watched the exchange with fond amusement—and a quiet, selfish relief.

Because while she loved Lilia dearly, she was grateful for the shift.

Grateful for the privacy.

For the fact that when she and Rio crossed the threshold of Rio’s apartment, there would be no knowing smiles, no carefully timed exits, no one pretending not to hear them laugh or move or exist together. The space was smaller, messier, undeniably Rio’s—and Agatha found she adored it.

Agatha couldn’t get enough of her.

When she wasn’t at the hospital, she was finding excuses to be where Rio was. Stopping by the firehouse with coffee she absolutely did not need to bring. Leaning against lockers while Rio joked with her crew, watching her move through that world with easy confidence and affection. The firefighters clocked it immediately—the way Agatha’s sharp edges softened around Rio, the way her eyes followed her without apology.

And when they weren’t there, they were tangled together in Rio’s bed, limbs overlapping, laughter muffled by pillows, the windows cracked open to noise of the streets and night air. Sometimes it was all heat and hunger, weeks of waiting still echoing in their bones. Sometimes it was quiet—Agatha tracing absent lines along Rio’s ribs, Rio’s fingers carding through Agatha’s hair while they talked about nothing at all.

It startled Agatha, how natural it felt.

How easy.

Since the night she’d whispered I love you without planning to, without bracing for impact, something fundamental had shifted inside her. 

The fear she’d expected never came. 

Instead, the words settled into her, warm and solid, like they’d been waiting for her all along.

She found herself saying it often.

Softly, when Rio handed her a mug of coffee in the morning. Casually, when she was halfway out the door to work. Quietly, into the curve of her shoulder when they were pressed together in the dark.

Sometimes Rio would laugh and say it back, bright and easy. Sometimes she’d go still for a heartbeat, like the words still surprised her, before smiling and pulling Agatha closer.

Agatha said it because she could.

For both of them, it became a matter of quiet coordination. 

They learned each other’s schedules the way some people learned tides or seasons, with instinct and attention rather than effort. Shifts overlapped imperfectly, nights ran long, sleep came in fragments—but somehow, they always found each other in the margins. A shared hour before dawn. Dinner at midnight. 

Time bent around them.

One evening, as if it were nothing at all, Rio handed Agatha a spare key.

They were standing in the narrow kitchen of the apartment, the city humming faintly through the open window. Rio had dropped it into Agatha’s palm with a casual flick of her wrist, not even looking at her.

“For when you finish work late,” Rio said lightly. “And don’t want to wake Lilia.”

Agatha had closed her fingers around it slowly, understanding immediately what it actually meant.

Please come back to me. 

Please don’t go anywhere else.

 Please let this be your place too.

She hadn’t teased. Hadn’t deflected. She’d simply nodded and slipped the key onto her keyring like it had always belonged there.

 

At the hospital, the shift in Agatha hadn’t gone unnoticed.

She was still formidable. Still precise. Still devastatingly sharp when incompetence crossed her path. But the edge had softened just enough that it startled people who knew her well.

Wanda noticed first—the way Agatha’s shoulders were less tense between cases, the way she lingered a fraction longer at the end of conversations.

Jen noticed second.

“She’s… nicer,” Jen said one afternoon, squinting at Agatha like this was a diagnosis she didn’t quite trust.

Agatha didn’t look up from her chart. “I assure you, I am exactly the same.”

“Mm,” Jen hummed. “You didn’t threaten anyone today.”

“No one pissed me off enough.”

Wanda just smiled to herself.

Even Teen, against all odds, had managed not to irritate Agatha lately. Or perhaps Agatha had simply stopped taking the bait. Either way, it had been noted.

So when Jen caught up to her at the end of a long shift, charts tucked under her arm, the grin she wore was sharp with intention.

“Hey, Harkness,” she said. “Scheduling says we miraculously have Saturday night off. Wanda and Alice are free too. Kate’s working but finishes at nine.”

Agatha accepted the charts automatically, already suspicious.

“We’re going to the Witches Road,” Jen continued, entirely too pleased with herself. “If you and Rio can leave the bedroom long enough to join us?”

Agatha stopped walking.

She turned slowly, fixing Jen with a look that would have once ended the conversation entirely. Now, it only made Jen grin wider.

“We’ve all noticed,” Jen added cheerfully. “You’ve been… busy.”

Jen sighed dramatically, adjusting the charts under her arm. “I am sick to death of hearing Alice mope around the apartment saying she misses her best friend.”

Agatha’s brow furrowed despite herself.

“She keeps standing in the kitchen like a sad little lamb,” Jen went on. “Staring into the fridge. Sighing. Saying things like, ‘Rio used to text me memes,’ or ‘Rio and I haven’t had a proper hangout in weeks.’..It's depressing me Agatha. Give Alice her friend back.”

Agatha exhaled through her nose, equal parts irritated and caught. She couldn’t deny it. The last few weeks had been a bubble. Rio’s bedroom had become a world unto itself—warm, insular, safe. They rarely ventured out when they weren’t working, content to stay wrapped in each other, talking, touching, existing without audience. They heard Alice and Jen come and go but rarely saw them or interacted outside of the hospital. 

The idea of giving up one of their precious evenings—of sharing Rio with the noise and presence of other people—felt like an intrusion she wasn’t eager to welcome.

Agatha glanced down at the charts in her hands, then back at Jen.

“I’ll speak to Rio,” she said carefully.

Jen laughed. “I’ll take that as a yes.”

Agatha watched her walk away, already pulling her phone from her pocket, thumb hovering over Rio’s name.

She felt it first — a subtle shift in her attention, a quiet pull low in her chest that made her pause.

She looked up.

Rio was standing at the end of the corridor.

For a second, Agatha genuinely thought she might be hallucinating. Long shift. Low blood sugar. Wishful thinking. But then Rio smiled—small and fond, like she’d been caught doing something sweet and slightly indulgent—and lifted the Tupperware container in her hands.

Agatha smiled before she realised she was doing it.

Rio crossed the floor easily now, no hesitation in her step, no guarded movements. She looked good—comfortable, a little flushed, hair pulled back messily like she hadn’t planned on being seen. The sight of her there, in this place, in the middle of Agatha’s world, hit harder than it had any right to.

“Hi,” Rio said softly, like this was the most normal thing in the world.

Agatha stared at her. Then at the container. Then back at Rio.
 “You—” She stopped. Restarted. “What are you doing here?”

Rio shrugged, entirely too casual for someone dismantling Agatha’s composure cell by cell. “I was at the firehouse. We had downtime. I made empanadas.”

Agatha’s knees actually went weak.

“I knew you had a long shift,” Rio continued, opening the container just enough for the smell to escape. 

Warm. Savoury. Comforting. “And I figured hospital food is… whatever crime against humanity they’re committing this week.”

Agatha swallowed hard.

She was still getting used to how fucking adorable Rio could be.

This woman had come to her hospital, during a long shift, with homemade food, because she thought of her. The thought hit her square in the chest, dizzying and almost painful in its tenderness.

She wanted—very suddenly, very intensely—to kiss Rio senseless.

To pull her in by the collar and forget where they were. To press her mouth to Rio’s cheek, her jaw, her smile. To show her exactly what this meant.

She did none of those things.

Because Jen was three steps away, watching with the sharp, feral interest of someone about to collect evidence.

Agatha glanced sideways and caught Jen’s eye.

Jen raised an eyebrow.
Slowly.
Deliberately.

Agatha turned back to Rio and lowered her voice. “You realise,” she said, carefully, “that if I so much as touch you right now, Jennifer will never let me hear the end of it.”

Rio’s smile widened, delighted. “Oh? Why’s that?”

Agatha huffed out a quiet laugh, fighting the urge to reach for her anyway. “She just lectured me about how I have kidnapped you from Alice and we need to start socialising more.”

“Mm,” Rio agreed. She nudged the container closer. “I wouldn’t mind being kidnapped by you.”

Agatha felt that land somewhere low and dangerous.
