She accepted the container with exaggerated care, like it was something sacred, something earned. “I was actually just about to text you,” she admitted, glancing down at her phone as if to prove it.

“Oh yeah?” Rio said, leaning in closer now, voice soft, curious, teasing. “What were you going to say?”
Agatha paused.

Her hand itched again, to grab Rio by the collar and close the distance properly. Instead, she curled her fingers around the Tupperware a little tighter and sighed.

“Jen has invited us to the Witches Road on Saturday night,” she said, rolling her eyes. “Apparently to prove that we aren’t living in some sort of… bubble.”

Rio’s face did something criminal.

She pouted. Properly. Lower lip out, brows drawing together in exaggerated disappointment. “But we are in a bubble,” she said, entirely sincere. “I love the bubble.”

And god help her, Agatha did too.

The quiet mornings. The late nights. The way the world narrowed down to just the two of them and whatever space they happened to be occupying. It was warm and safe and indulgent, and Agatha had no desire to give it up.

“So,” Agatha said, a little too quickly, hope sneaking into her voice despite herself, “I’ll tell her no?”


She could already picture it. Saturday night, uninterrupted. Rio’s bed. No obligations. No commentary.

Rio hummed, considering it, eyes flicking briefly to Agatha’s mouth before she smiled. “Nah,” she said gently. “We’ll go.”

Agatha’s heart sank.

“We haven’t actually hung out with others as a couple yet,” Rio continued, soft but certain. “Not properly. It could be fun.”

Agatha scoffed, trying not to look as disappointed as she felt. The image she’d been clinging to—of them tangled together, the rest of the world politely excluded—faded a little more with each word.

“Fun,” she repeated, flatly.

Rio laughed, clearly catching it, and leaned in just enough to bump her shoulder against Agatha’s. “Hey,” she said. “We’ll still come back to the bubble after.”

Agatha glanced at her, lips twitching despite herself.

“…Fine,” she conceded. “But if Jen makes one comment—”

“I’ll save you,” Rio promised cheerfully.

Agatha shook her head, resigned and fond all at once.

She lifted the container slightly, protective instinct kicking in immediately, her mouth tilting into a faint scowl.
 “I’m not sharing these.”

Rio’s smile softened, something warm and indulgent lighting her eyes. She stepped closer without hesitation, close enough that Agatha could feel the heat of her, the familiar comfort of her presence cutting straight through the irritation still clinging to her mood.

Before Agatha could say another word, Rio leaned in and pressed a soft, unhurried kiss to her lips.

Not rushed. 

Not hidden. 

Just… there.

Agatha’s breath caught, reflexively, her fingers tightening around the container as if that was the only thing keeping her upright.

“All yours, mi amor,” Rio murmured, the words wrapped in a teasing warmth that felt entirely unfair.
She winked—actually winked—before turning smoothly and heading back down the corridor, utterly unaware of the devastation she’d just left in her wake.

Agatha stared after her.

The name echoed in her head, low and intimate in a way nothing else ever had. Mi amor. My love. The translation landed fully formed and devastatingly effective.

Her knees very nearly buckled.

She let out a small, involuntary sigh, shoulders dropping as if her body had decided it was done pretending to be composed. Any lingering irritation evaporated instantly, replaced with something buoyant and ridiculous and deeply inconvenient.

God help her, she was fucking smiling again.

She was still smiling when a voice cut in from her left.

“You guys are so adorable.”

Agatha stiffened.

Slowly, she turned her head to find Wanda leaning against the nurses’ station, chin propped in her hand, watching her with open amusement and far too much fondness.

The smile vanished.
Mood ruined.

Agatha straightened, spine snapping back into place, face carefully neutral once more. “You saw nothing.”

Wanda grinned. “I saw everything.”

Agatha sighed, clutching the Tupperware like a shield. “If you tell Jennifer—”
“Oh, I’m absolutely telling Jennifer,” Wanda said cheerfully.

Agatha closed her eyes for just a second.

So much for dignity.

 

 


Rio was working Friday night.

Agatha told herself she’d be fine.

She drove back to Lilia’s after her shift and went through the motions on autopilot. Showered. Changed. Slid into the familiar bed that had been hers for years. The house was quiet in the way it always was at night, old and settled and safe.

Too quiet.

Ebony jumped up beside her as soon as Agatha lay down, a small, warm weight curling against her hip. Agatha absently stroked her fingers through the kitten’s soft black fur, the repetitive motion meant to soothe them both. 

Ebony purred immediately, loud and insistent, pressing her head into Agatha’s hand.

Agatha stared at the ceiling, hand moving on instinct, listening to the steady tick of the clock down the hall. She tried reading. Tried scrolling aimlessly on her phone. Tried reminding herself that this was normal, that couples didn’t need to spend every night together.

Her bed felt wrong.

Too wide. Too still. The space behind her felt conspicuously empty, like something essential had been removed and her body hadn’t been informed yet.

Ebony shifted, pausing mid-purr. She lifted her head, ears flicking, as if she could feel the tension radiating off Agatha’s rigid frame. Agatha’s hand slowed, then stilled altogether.

After a moment, the kitten wriggled free, hopped lightly off the bed, and padded toward the door without looking back.

Agatha watched her go, chest tightening at the quiet betrayal.

“Well,” she murmured to the empty room, voice barely audible. “Fair enough.”

The door clicked softly as Ebony slipped out, undoubtedly headed for Lilia’s room, drawn to calmer waters.

At one in the morning, she turned onto her side.

At two, she sighed for the third time in as many minutes.

By three, she gave up.

She dressed quietly, grabbed her keys, and slipped out of the house without waking Lilia. The drive across town felt automatic, muscle memory taking over as the streets blurred past.

She didn’t overthink it. Didn’t justify it.

She just knew where she needed to be.

Agatha parked outside Rio’s apartment and let herself in with the spare key, the soft click of the lock echoing louder than it should have in the stillness. 

Inside, the apartment was dark and quiet, Alice and Jen’s shoe’s lined up beside the door indicating they were both home, likely asleep in Alice’s room.

Agatha kicked off her shoes and padded into Rio’s bedroom.

She curled into Rio’s bed like it had been made for her, pulling the covers up and turning onto her side, facing the door. Sleep didn’t come immediately, but the tension eased. Being there was enough. She drifted in and out, aware of time passing without really tracking it.

At six in the morning, the door opened softly.

Agatha stirred, consciousness surfacing slowly as the mattress dipped behind her. Familiar warmth pressed in close, careful and practiced. Arms slid around her waist, drawing her back until she was flush against a solid chest.

Rio.

The recognition settled before Agatha fully woke, relief washing through her in a quiet wave. Rio’s breathing was slow and tired, her nose nudging gently at the back of Agatha’s neck as she tucked herself in, seeking contact like it was instinct.

Agatha exhaled, tension she hadn’t realised she was holding finally letting go.

She shifted just enough to settle more comfortably, a small sound leaving her throat without thought. 
Rio’s arms tightened reflexively, a soft hum vibrating against her skin.

“Hey,” Agatha murmured, voice rough with sleep.

Rio pressed a brief, sleepy kiss to her neck. “You’re here,” she whispered. “Thought you were staying at Lilia’s tonight.”

Agatha’s hand reached back, fingers curling around Rio’s forearm, grounding herself in the solid reality of her. “I couldn’t sleep,” she admitted quietly. “So I came here.”

Rio smiled into her neck, warm and unguarded. “Good,” she said simply.

They lay there like that, bodies aligned, breaths slowly syncing. Outside, the town was beginning to wake, but inside the room everything felt still and contained, like time had paused just for them.

By ten a.m., Agatha finally woke.

It was later than she ever slept, even on days off, and the realisation drifted in slowly, cushioned by warmth and weight. Rio was still wrapped around her from behind, arm slung heavy and protective across her waist, breath warm and even against the back of Agatha’s neck. There was a solidity to it that made moving feel not just inconvenient, but wrong.

Agatha lay there for a few moments longer than necessary, eyes open, staring at nothing in particular while her body stubbornly refused to cooperate with the idea of getting up. Something about Rio’s hold did that to her—made her softer, slower, less inclined to pull herself away from comfort. It was deeply inconvenient.

And entirely Rio’s fault.

She shifted just slightly, testing the waters. Rio made a small sound in her sleep and tightened her arm reflexively, nose nudging closer like she was seeking heat even unconsciously.

Agatha smiled despite herself.

She knew Rio would need the sleep. Night shifts always took more out of her than she admitted, and Agatha had no intention of being the one to wake her. So, reluctantly, she extricated herself inch by careful inch, peeling Rio’s arm away and replacing it with a pillow like a peace offering.

Rio barely stirred.

Agatha paused at the edge of the bed, watching her for a moment—hair a mess, face soft in sleep, utterly unguarded. The sight tugged at her chest in that quiet, familiar way.

Coffee, she reminded herself.

She dressed quietly, pulling on jeans and her tank top, then hesitated at the doorway before reaching for the nearest thing on the chair. One of Rio’s WVFD hoodies. It was oversized and smelled faintly like laundry soap and Rio herself. Agatha tugged it on without overthinking it, sleeves swallowing her hands.

Down the hall, she could already hear movement. The low murmur of voices. A laugh that sounded suspiciously like Alice. Possibly Jen. Definitely too awake.

Agatha sighed softly.

She debated retreating. Considered the option of simply lying back down and pretending she didn’t exist until noon. But her body was already staging a rebellion—head dull, shoulders tight, that familiar ache that only caffeine ever truly fixed.

Resigned, she padded into the kitchen.

The floor was cool beneath her feet, the apartment bright with late-morning light and the sound of life already in progress. Agatha squared her shoulders, hoodie sleeves pushed up just enough to free her hands, and headed straight for the coffee machine like it was a lifeline.

She could survive anything.

But not without coffee.

When Agatha stepped into the living area, she stopped short.

Alice and Jen were sprawled on the floor amid a half-dozen cardboard boxes, their contents spilling out in careful disarray. Tangled strings of fairy lights lay coiled like sleeping snakes. Tissue paper rustled softly as Alice lifted ornaments one by one, turning each between her fingers with quiet concentration. Some were chipped. Some mismatched. All of them unmistakably old.

Jen held one up to the light, squinting at the faded paint and dulled glitter.
 “Where did you even get these from,” she said, snorting, “1950?”

Alice’s mouth curved into a small, fond smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes.
 “Probably,” she said. “They were Mom’s.”

The word settled between them, heavier than the ornaments in Alice’s hands.

Jen’s expression changed immediately. The humour drained from it, replaced by something sheepish and regretful. “Ah,” she said softly. “I—sorry. That was… not my best moment.”

She shifted closer without making a big deal of it, bumping her shoulder gently against Alice’s. Her hand hovered for half a second before settling on Alice’s knee, grounding and apologetic all at once.

“They’re kind of amazing, actually,” Jen added, quieter now. “Very… witchy chic.”

Alice laughed under her breath, the sound warm despite the sadness threading through it. “That’s her, yeah.”

Agatha watched the exchange from the doorway, unseen for a moment longer than she intended.

 Something in her chest eased at the sight of it—this small, unguarded tenderness between them.

Then one of the floorboards creaked beneath her weight.

Alice looked up first, surprise flickering into recognition. “Oh—hey.”

Jen followed her gaze, eyebrows lifting as she took in Agatha in Rio’s oversized hoodie, hair still sleep-tousled, eyes not quite fully awake yet.

“Well,” Jen said, a slow, infuriatingly pleased grin spreading across her face, “if it isn’t Agatha Harkness, out of the bedroom for a change.”

Agatha didn’t even look at her. She moved straight toward the coffee machine like it was a lifeline, shoulders still a little stiff with sleep, Rio’s oversized hoodie hanging loose around her frame.
“Fuck off, Jennifer,” she said flatly.

“Charming as always,” Jen replied, rolling her eyes. “Never change.”

Agatha poured herself a mug of black coffee, the smell alone making her feel marginally more human. She took a careful sip, letting the bitterness ground her before she trusted herself to say anything else.

Behind her, Alice was kneeling among the boxes, holding up a string of lights like she’d just uncovered buried treasure.

“I usually wait for Rio to decorate,” Alice said brightly, trying to inject cheer back into the room, “but she’s been a bit… busy lately.” She shot Agatha a look that was equal parts teasing and fond. “So I thought I’d make a start on the Christmas stuff. Wanna help?”

Agatha stared into her mug for a second too long.

Christmas.

She took another sip, buying herself time. The caffeine hadn’t quite hit yet, and she knew better than to answer before it did. When she finally spoke, her voice was measured, deliberately neutral.

“Thanks,” she said, “but I’ve never really been the festive type.”

The reaction was immediate.

Alice’s hand slipped, the delicate glass bobble wobbling dangerously before she caught it with a sharp inhale. She froze, eyes wide, like Agatha had just said something deeply alarming.

Jen, meanwhile, huffed under her breath as if this confirmed a long-held suspicion.

Agatha noticed both reactions at once and frowned. She turned back toward them, mug still warm in her hands. “What?”

Alice cleared her throat, clearly choosing her words carefully. “Does… Rio know that?”

Agatha blinked. The question caught her off guard.

She thought about it—really thought about it. About the conversations they’d had, the nights they’d spent tangled together, the way time had blurred into warmth and closeness and sleep. Christmas hadn’t come up. Thanksgiving barely had. They’d both worked, eaten leftovers, collapsed into bed like gravity demanded it.

“No,” Agatha said slowly. “The topic hasn’t come up.” She hesitated, then added, genuinely puzzled, “Why is that a problem?”

Jen snorted, already opening her mouth.

But Alice cut her off with a sharp whisper, urgent and emphatic. “Rio loves Christmas.”

Agatha stilled.

“Like,” Alice continued, eyes wide, hands gesturing helplessly at the boxes around her, “loves it. It’s her favourite time of year. She usually has this stuff up the second Thanksgiving is over. Sometimes before.”

Agatha’s brow furrowed. That didn’t match the Rio she’d been living with the past few weeks. Rio hadn’t mentioned decorating. Hadn’t mentioned plans. Hadn’t even complained about missing it.

They hadn’t done much for Thanksgiving either. Both of them on shift, both exhausted. They’d eaten something quick, curled up together afterward, content enough not to notice what they were skipping.

At the time, it had felt natural.

Now, it felt… off.

“Oh my god,” Jen said, seizing the opening with glee. “You broke her.”

Agatha shot her a glare sharp enough to cut. “Do not finish that sentence.”

“Oh, I’m finishing it,” Jen said cheerfully. “Your icy little heart has rubbed off on her. You turned her. She’s gone full Grinch.”

Agatha ignored her, but the words stuck anyway, needling at something deeper.

Because if Rio loved Christmas—really loved it—then why hadn’t she said anything?

Why hadn’t she insisted? Decorated anyway? Pulled Agatha into it with that easy enthusiasm she brought to everything else she cared about?

Agatha’s chest tightened, unease curling low and unwelcome.

She looked back at the boxes scattered across the floor. The lights. The ornaments. The history embedded in them.

Something didn’t sit right.

And for the first time, Agatha wondered if, without meaning to, she’d made herself too comfortable being the centre of Rio’s world—without noticing what Rio might have quietly set aside to stay there with her.

 

Agatha made a point of helping with the decorations.

Not hovering. Not standing off to the side with folded arms and dry commentary. She knelt on the floor with Alice and Jen, untangling lights, holding boxes steady, passing ornaments without complaint. It was deliberate, even if she didn’t say so out loud. She needed to understand why Rio hadn’t mentioned Christmas at all. Needed to know whether this was coincidence, or something she had missed.

Or something Rio had chosen to bury.

Agatha had always had an aversion to this time of year. Not the lights themselves, or the music, or even the forced cheer. It was deeper than that, rooted somewhere old and raw. Lilia had discovered it early on, back when Agatha was still a teenager with too many sharp edges and not enough language for them.

She remembered Lilia trying. Gently at first. Decorating the house. Putting on music. Baking things that smelled warm and sweet and hopeful. Inviting Agatha to join in, coaxing her with patience rather than pressure.

Agatha had tolerated it.

But the season itself had never softened for her.

Because every December dragged Evanora back into sharper focus.

Christmas in that house hadn’t been magical. It hadn’t been special. It had been indistinguishable from any other day, except louder in its absence. No excitement. No warmth. No ritual. Just the same cold indifference wrapped in winter light.

Agatha remembered watching other children at school in the days leading up to the holidays, vibrating with anticipation. Trading stories about presents and traditions, about trees and baking and family. She’d listened silently, already knowing she would return home to a house where nothing changed.

No tree. 

No gifts.

 No celebration.

Just neglect dressed up as normalcy.

The contrast had been unbearable. The knowledge that something was happening everywhere else that she wasn’t allowed to touch. That joy was real, but not for her.

So she learned early not to want it.

Now, sitting on the floor with a coil of lights in her hands, Agatha paused.

Her thoughts drifted, unbidden, to Rio.

To Rio’s abuela.

She imagined a small apartment filled with colour and noise. Music playing too loudly. A tree decorated with mismatched ornaments collected over years. Food simmering on the stove. A younger Rio bouncing on her heels, unable to sit still, face lit up with the uncomplicated joy Agatha had only ever observed from the outside.

Rio had grown up with warmth.
 With rituals.
 With someone who showed love loudly and often.

Agatha had always known that in an abstract way. She’d seen it in how Rio moved through the world—open, generous, unguarded. In the way she loved with her whole chest, never rationing affection, never holding joy at arm’s length the way Agatha had learned to do.

But standing there with the lights biting faintly into her palms, the truth of it settled deeper.

Of course Christmas mattered to Rio. 

Of course it did.

And suddenly, the silence around it made sense.

Agatha’s chest tightened, a slow, uncomfortable ache spreading behind her ribs. Not anger. Not quite guilt. Something quieter and heavier than both.

That was when Rio appeared in the doorway.

She looked half-asleep, hair still rumpled, one hand rubbing at her eyes as she took in the scene. Boxes on the floor. Alice and Jen mid-sort. And Agatha, sitting among the decorations with a coil of lights tangled in her hands.

Rio froze.
Her eyes went wide.

“Shit,” she said immediately, voice thick with sleep and panic. “Agatha, I’m sorry, I didn’t realise Alice would be doing this today.”

She shot Alice a look that was pure accusation. What the fuck dude?

Agatha watched her carefully.

Noticed the way Rio’s shoulders had gone tense. The way she was hovering, uncertain, like she’d just walked in on something fragile and wrong. The guilt was written all over her face, and it twisted something sharp and painful in Agatha’s chest.

She set the lights down slowly.

“Rio,” she said, steady but direct, “why haven’t you put the decorations up yet?”

Rio blinked. “What?”

“Alice said you usually do it straight away,” Agatha continued, cutting cleanly to the point. “Why didn’t you this year?”

Alice and Jen exchanged a look—one of those silent, mutual decisions—before Jen cleared her throat loudly.

“Wow, would you look at the time,” she said. “Alice, we should—uh—check the other box.”

“Yes,” Alice agreed far too quickly. “Very important box. Somewhere else.”

They disappeared down the hall, giving them the space without ceremony.

Rio shifted her weight, suddenly very interested in the floor.

“It’s not a big deal,” she said lightly, too lightly. “We don’t have to decorate every year.”

Agatha didn’t miss the tell. The way Rio bit her lip. The way her hands fidgeted at her sides.

Agatha raised an eyebrow.
“Rio.”

The single word carried everything—patience, expectation, and the quiet certainty that Agatha would not be lied to.

Rio exhaled, shoulders slumping as the fight went out of her. “Okay,” she admitted. “Fine.”

She hesitated, then said it all in one breath, like ripping off a bandage. “Lilia said you hate Christmas. That it kind of… triggers you. So I didn’t want to put anything up this year.”

Agatha’s mouth fell open.

Of course Lilia would meddle. With the best intentions. With love and protectiveness and just enough missing context to cause damage anyway.

Agatha looked at Rio properly then.
At the way she was avoiding eye contact. At the careful distance she’d put between herself and the decorations. At the way she’d quietly folded something she loved away for Agatha’s comfort without ever mentioning it.

Her heart ached.

This woman—this beautiful, ridiculous, generous woman—had willingly given up something that brought her joy just to avoid hurting Agatha. Not out of obligation. Not out of fear. Out of love.

Agatha stood abruptly, the movement decisive.

“Come here,” she said.

Rio looked up, startled, then crossed the space between them without hesitation. She wrapped her arms around Agatha’s waist automatically, like this was muscle memory now. Agatha slid her hands up Rio’s back, settling them at her shoulders, grounding herself in the familiar solidity of her.

She tipped her head back to meet Rio’s eyes.

“I don’t ever want you to hide or change anything for me,” Agatha said, voice firm despite the emotion tightening her throat. “Ever.”

Rio frowned slightly. “Agatha, I just—”

“I know,” Agatha interrupted gently. “And I love that you thought about my feelings. I do.” She swallowed, thumb brushing unconsciously along Rio’s collarbone. “But I don’t want to be the reason you make yourself smaller. Or quieter. Or less joyful.”

Rio’s eyes softened.

“If Christmas makes you happy,” Agatha continued, her voice dropping, more vulnerable now, “then that makes me happy. Even if it’s… complicated for me.”

She let out a breath she hadn’t realised she’d been holding. “I love you. And I want all of you. The parts I understand and the parts I’m still learning.”

Rio stared at her for a long second.
Then she smiled.
Not the teasing grin. Not the easy charm. Something gentler. Something touched.

“You sure?” she asked softly.

Agatha didn’t hesitate. “I’m sure.”

Rio leaned down and pressed her forehead to Agatha’s, arms tightening around her waist.

“Okay,” she whispered.

“Now help me untangle these fucking lights before I lose my shit,” Agatha said, laughing as she looked back down at the impossible snarl of wires and bulbs abandoned on the floor.

Rio laughed too, the sound bright and relieved, and dropped back down beside her without hesitation. “Okay, but if this turns into a break-up level argument, that’s on you.”

Agatha huffed, but she shifted closer anyway, knees bumping, shoulders touching as they worked side by side. Their hands brushed repeatedly, small sparks of familiarity and ease passing between them.

From the doorway, Alice peeked back in, watched them for a beat, then smiled to herself and quietly retreated.

As the lights slowly began to cooperate, Rio leaned over and pressed a quick kiss to Agatha’s temple. 

“Thank you,” she murmured.

Agatha didn’t look up. She just let her shoulder rest against Rio’s. “You’re welcome.”

And for the first time in a long while, the idea of Christmas didn’t feel so unbearable.

It felt… nice.

Chapter 25

Chapter Notes

My wife always has last approval on these things and after reading my "smut" told me to tone it down a little. And she is kinda the boss of me so we compromised ...

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha and Rio walked into the Witches Road hand in hand, trailing just behind Jen and Alice.
Agatha was acutely aware of it. Of the way their fingers were laced together, solid and intentional. Of how easily Rio walked beside her, shoulders relaxed, posture open, like she belonged anywhere she decided to stand. They looked—Agatha realised with a faint jolt—exactly like what they were.

A couple.

The kind people noticed without meaning to.

Agatha barely registered the whoops and clapping coming from the far table where Wanda and Yelena were already seated. Her attention was caught entirely by Rio—by the way she scanned the room with easy confidence, the way she smiled at the bartender without hesitation, the way she seemed to take up space without apology.

Agatha had spent most of her life entering rooms like this braced for impact. Measuring exits. Preparing for scrutiny. But tonight, she felt oddly… shielded. Anchored by the warm weight of Rio’s hand in hers.

“Do my eyes deceive me?” Wanda called out, grinning as she leaned back in her chair. “Dr. Harkness out in the wild?”

Agatha’s instinctive response was immediate and sharp. Her shoulders tightened. Her grip on Rio’s hand firmed.

She shot Wanda a glare that could curdle spirits and turned halfway toward the door, already calculating how quickly she could retreat without it looking like a retreat.

And then Rio squeezed her hand.

Just once. Gentle. Deliberate.

Agatha looked at her.

Rio smiled back, soft and grounding, brown eyes warm with understanding. Not teasing. Not coaxing. Just there. A quiet reminder: I'm right here with you.

The tension in Agatha’s chest eased, fraction by fraction.

She exhaled, squared her shoulders, and turned back toward the table.

“For the record,” Agatha said dryly, forcing a smile as she approached, “I do, in fact, leave the house.”

“It's a Christmas miracle. God bless us, everyone” Yelena said, lifting her glass in mock salute. 

Agatha snorted despite herself.

Since she and Rio had made things official, something in Agatha had shifted—subtly, but undeniably. 
Knowing Yelena was no threat had loosened a knot she hadn’t even realised she’d been carrying. She tolerated her now. Occasionally even enjoyed her presence.

That didn’t mean she’d stopped paying attention.

Agatha’s eyes flicked, unbidden, to anyone who lingered too close to Rio. Anyone whose gaze lingered a second too long. Her posture shifted instinctively, angling herself just enough to claim space without making a scene.

Protective. 

Possessive. 

Unashamed.

Rio noticed, of course. She always did.

She bumped her hip lightly against Agatha’s, a quiet reassurance, her thumb brushing over Agatha’s knuckles in that absent, affectionate way that made Agatha’s chest ache.

She was here. 

She was choosing this. 

She was choosing Agatha.

Agatha softened visibly, though she doubted anyone else noticed.

 

By the time Kate finally joined them, breathless and apologetic with her coat still half on, Agatha realised—somewhat to her own surprise—that she was actually enjoying herself.

The table was loud but not overwhelming, the kind of noise that blended into warmth rather than chaos. Laughter came easily. Conversation flowed without effort. And being seated beside Rio helped more than Agatha would ever admit out loud. Rio’s knee pressed against hers under the table, grounding and constant. Her hand found Agatha’s thigh absentmindedly when she laughed, thumb tracing small, idle circles that kept Agatha tethered to the moment whenever the room threatened to feel too big.

They’d endured some teasing earlier, of course.

Jen had made at least three comments about them “emerging from captivity,” each one met with Agatha’s sharp, perfectly timed retorts that shut her down to the table’s delight. Even Alice had laughed, shaking her head fondly as Rio hid her face in Agatha’s shoulder.

Somehow, without Agatha noticing when it happened, the attention had shifted.

They weren’t the spectacle anymore.

Agatha found that she liked that.

She’d even allowed herself to be talked into one of the festive cocktails Rio had insisted on ordering for her—something involving cranberry and rosemary and candy cane garnish. She’d rolled her eyes, taken a cautious sip… and then finished the whole thing.

Now she was halfway through her third drink, warmth humming pleasantly through her veins, edges softened just enough to be dangerous.

“So, Wanda,” Agatha said suddenly, leaning back in her chair with an ease that surprised even her, “do tell us—how is the Chief doing these days?”

The words landed with surgical precision.

Wanda choked mid-sip, coughing hard enough that Yelena had to pat her on the back while the rest of the table went abruptly, gloriously silent.

Agatha watched it all with open fascination.

It was common knowledge, really. Unspoken but universally understood. Natasha Romanoff—Chief Romanoff—recently divorced, visibly shaken, and suddenly spending an awful lot of time with Wanda Maximoff. The rumour mill had been working overtime, but no one had dared poke the subject directly.

Until now.

“She’s—” Wanda spluttered, wiping at her mouth, eyes darting around the table like she was searching for an escape route. “She’s fine. I mean. As far as I’m aware.”

The effect was immediate.

Smirks appeared. Brows lifted. Yelena leaned back in her chair, grinning like she’d just been handed a gift.

“Oh come on,” Alice said, delighted, leaning forward. “Spill it. We all know there’s something going on.”
Wanda groaned, dropping her face into her hands. “There is not—”

“Wanda,” Jen said sweetly, “you’ve been smiling at your phone like a teenager for weeks.”

Kate nodded. “It’s kinda obvious.”

Agatha leaned back further, utterly at ease now, a smug little smile tugging at her mouth. For once, the spotlight wasn’t on her. She wasn’t the subject of speculation or whispered commentary. She got to watch someone else squirm.

It was deeply satisfying.

Beside her, Rio leaned in close, lips brushing Agatha’s ear as she whispered, “You’re a menace.”
Agatha didn’t look away from Wanda. She just lifted her glass slightly in a silent toast, eyes bright with mischief.

“I learned from the best,” she murmured back.

And as laughter broke out around the table and Wanda tried valiantly to change the subject, Agatha felt something settle comfortably in her chest.

She belonged here.

 

 

It started subtly.

One song ended, the low murmur of conversation filling the bar for a beat — and then the opening notes of a Christmas song slid in, unmistakable and unapologetic. Groans rippled through the room, followed immediately by laughter.

“Oh God,” Jen said, already grinning. “Here we go.”

The bartender turned it up anyway. Someone near the dartboard whooped. Another table started singing loudly and badly, arms slung around each other’s shoulders. Soon the whole bar tipped into something communal and ridiculous, voices overlapping, lyrics half-remembered but enthusiastic.

 

"Who's got a beard thats long and white?" The bar tender sang loudly.

"Santa's got a beard thats long and white!", the crowd sang back.

Agatha watched it all with cautious neutrality.

She didn’t join in. Didn’t retreat either. She stayed where she was, Rio warm and steady at her side, glass loose in her hand. The noise pressed in, festive and earnest in a way that usually made her itch.

Then she noticed Rio wasn’t singing.

She laughed when Alice butchered a line. Smiled when Jen leaned into it theatrically. But her mouth stayed closed, teeth worrying gently at her lower lip like she was holding something back.

Agatha felt it immediately.

That familiar restraint. That instinct to dim herself.

Agatha glanced at her again, really looked — at the soft light catching in her eyes, at the way joy hovered just under the surface, waiting for permission.

So she took a breath.

And then she sang.

"Must be Santa, must be Santa, must be Santa, Santa Claus"

"Who's got boots and a suit of red? Santa's got boots and a suit of red"

For once, she wasn’t watching joy from the outside.

She was inside it.

As the night wore on, the table descended into a kind of cheerful disarray.

Kate and Yelena had vanished to the bathroom together once without comment. Twice with raised eyebrows. By the third disappearance, Agatha stopped pretending there was any plausible deniability left. 

Kate returned flushed to the tips of her ears, laughing a little too loudly at absolutely nothing, while Yelena’s hair was decidedly more disheveled than when she’d left, her expression smug and unapologetic.

Agatha took a slow sip of her drink and leaned toward Rio. “If they go back a fourth time, I’m calling it.”

“Calling what?” Rio asked innocently.

“A hotel to book them a fucking room.” Agatha replied.

“No, listen,” Jen said, gesturing vaguely with her glass. “It’s all about angles. People underestimate the importance of leverage when it comes to scissoring.”

Wanda stared into her drink like it might save her.

Across from them, Alice had lost the battle entirely. Her head had tipped sideways, resting against the back of the booth, mouth slightly open, breathing slow and even. Every so often she twitched, like she was still trying to participate in the conversation from another plane of existence.

Agatha surveyed the scene with detached fondness.

This chaos, this unfiltered mess of people who cared about one another wasn’t something she would have chosen once. Wouldn’t have tolerated for long. And yet, here she was, content enough not to leave, amused enough to stay.

Beside her, Rio leaned in, warm and close, her voice low and conspiratorial.

“Can we go back to the bubble yet?”

Agatha turned to look at her properly.

Rio’s eyes were a little glassy, her smile loose and affectionate, the festive lights reflecting softly in her gaze. She looked happy. Comfortable. Entirely at ease.

Agatha didn’t hesitate.

She nodded, emphatically. “Oh, thank god.”

She was already reaching for her bag when she added, “Grab my coat before Jen starts a PowerPoint.”

Rio laughed, sliding out of the booth and snagging it from the back of the chair. “You don’t want to hear about her top five—”

“Not even a little,” Agatha said firmly, standing and looping an arm around Rio’s waist.

They made their excuses quickly—gentle nudges, fond goodbyes, Alice barely stirring as Rio kissed her temple and promised breakfast. Wanda mouthed thank you at Agatha like she’d been rescued.

Rio tucked her arm through Agatha’s, pressing close as they walked. “Bubble time,” she said happily.

Agatha smiled, genuine and unguarded, and leaned into her. “Bubble time.”


They walked home together hand in hand, the cold biting pleasantly at their cheeks, breath puffing white in the glow of the streetlights. The city felt quieter at this hour, like it was winding down with them. Rio swung their joined hands back and forth as she hummed the tune that had been playing earlier in the bar, soft and a little off-key, completely unselfconscious.

Agatha let herself listen.

“I had a really good time,” she said after a moment, the words surprising even her as they left her mouth. She glanced sideways at Rio, then back to the pavement. “I didn’t think I would.”

Rio slowed just slightly, giving her attention without interrupting.

“It isn’t easy for me to make friends,” Agatha continued, voice quieter now, more thoughtful. “Or… to let people in. I usually feel like I’m performing something when I’m around groups. Like I’m waiting for the moment it gets exhausting and I have to leave.”

She squeezed Rio’s hand, grounding herself in the warmth of it. “But tonight didn’t feel like that.”
Rio didn’t rush to respond. She just walked with her, close enough that their coats brushed, listening in that steady way she had. When she finally spoke, her voice was warm and sure.

“You didn’t have to be anything tonight,” Rio said. “You were just… you.”

Agatha huffed a small, disbelieving laugh. “That’s usually the part people don’t enjoy.”

Rio stopped walking.

“I enjoy it,” Rio said simply. “All of it. The sharp bits. The quiet bits. The parts you think you need to apologise for.”

Rio smiled, thumb brushing over Agatha’s knuckles. “I noticed.”

“I wanted to kiss you,” Rio said, grinning. “But I waited.”

Agatha snorted, warmth blooming in her cheeks that had nothing to do with the cold. “I’m glad you did. You would have threw off my timing.”

As they climbed the stairs, Rio glanced back at her. “Same time next year?”

Agatha pretended to consider it, lips quirking. “Let’s not get ahead of ourselves.”

But she didn’t pull her hand away.

And when they approached the front door, shedding coats and cold and noise, Agatha knew—with a quiet certainty that settled deep—that nights like this didn’t scare her anymore.

Not when she got to walk home like this.

With Rio.
