Sunday put Agatha on the late shift, which she’d greeted with muted relief when she first saw the schedule. It felt safer than an early start, easier to recover from the faint throb behind her eyes that suggested the last Christmas cocktail the night before had been one too many.

Still, the feeling followed her.

It settled low in her chest as soon as she stepped through the hospital doors — a subtle, unwelcome tightness that made her slow half a step without knowing why. The air felt heavier than usual. Charged. Agatha shook it off immediately, irritation flaring at herself. Lack of sleep. Residual alcohol. Nothing more.

She was not someone given to superstition.

The surgical floor was already awake when she arrived, fluorescent lights buzzing faintly overhead, the familiar scent of antiseptic and stale coffee grounding her in routine. The unease lingered anyway, threading through her as she walked, like her body had registered something her mind hadn’t caught up to yet.

Teen was at the nurses’ station, animated as ever, hands moving as he spoke. Wanda stood opposite him, posture slack with exhaustion, coffee clasped in both hands like a lifeline.

“And then she starts yelling that we’re all incompetent,” Teen was saying. “Full volume. Security had to come up at one point because she was threatening staff.”

Agatha approached, eyes already scanning the board, trying to settle into the familiar rhythm of work. The dread eased just a fraction. This, she understood.

“Mmm,” she hummed in acknowledgement, barely listening. Difficult patients were nothing new.

Teen noticed her then and straightened. “Oh — morning, Dr. Harkness.”

“Morning,” Agatha replied automatically, fingers already reaching for her tablet.

“She’s been… a lot,” Teen continued, emboldened by the audience. “Honestly, some people are just mean for sport. Especially with that last name.”

Something inside Agatha went cold.

Not sharply. Not all at once. Just enough to make her still.

Wanda noticed immediately, eyes flicking to Agatha’s face.

Teen, meanwhile, realised his mistake far too late. Colour rushed to his cheeks. “I—I didn’t mean— I mean not you, obviously, I just—”

Agatha turned slowly.

“What do you mean,” she asked, voice calm to the point of being dangerous, “that last name?”

Teen swallowed. “I—well—it’s just—”

“Teen,” Agatha said gently, firmly. “Tell me.”

He hesitated, then gestured weakly toward the chart rack. “The patient in ninety-eight. She’s been causing a scene all night. Screaming at staff. Refusing treatment.” He winced. “Ms. Harkness.”

The dread snapped into focus.

Agatha felt it hit her like a physical blow, air leaving her lungs in a sharp, involuntary breath. She reached out without thinking, fingers closing around the chart Teen was holding.

Wanda stepped closer at once. “Agatha?”

Agatha didn’t answer.

She flipped the chart open, eyes moving fast, clinical instinct overriding shock for just long enough to process the words. Oncology consult. Behavioural flags. History of noncompliance.

Then the name.

EVANORA HARKNESS

For a second, the noise of the ward receded entirely. Agatha’s vision narrowed, the letters on the page blurring at the edges as if they were burning straight through her.

She dropped the chart.

It hit the counter with a sharp crack before sliding to the floor, pages splaying open like something exposed.

Wanda’s hand hovered near Agatha’s arm, not quite touching. “Agatha,” she said softly. “What’s going on?”

Agatha stared at the fallen chart, chest tight, pulse pounding in her ears. Memories surged unbidden — cold rooms, sharp words, absence dressed up as discipline.

She forced herself to breathe.

“Room ninety-eight,” she said at last, voice low and stripped of warmth. “Who’s covering her?”

Teen shook his head slowly. “No one permanent. She’s… difficult.”

Agatha nodded once.

“I’ll take it,” she said.

Wanda’s eyes widened. “Agatha—”

“I’ll take it,” Agatha repeated, bending to retrieve the chart, fingers gripping it too tightly.

She straightened, her composure snapping back into place with practiced precision. Spine straight. 
Expression neutral. Mask firmly locked on.

But Wanda saw it — the tension beneath the surface, the way Agatha’s jaw was set too tight, her eyes too sharp.

Agatha turned toward the corridor without another word, Evanora’s name echoing in her head with every step.

The dread she’d felt upon entering the hospital finally made sense.

Some ghosts didn’t stay buried.

And this one had just checked herself in.

Chapter End Notes

Merry Christmas everyone... except Evanora Harkness. Bitch

Chapter 26

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The walk to room ninety-eight felt interminable.

Agatha had made the journey down that corridor hundreds of times, could have navigated it blindfolded, but tonight every step stretched, heavy and deliberate, like she was wading through something viscous. 

Her badge brushed soft against her coat with each movement, a small, grounding sound she clung to more than she liked.

In the space between the nurses’ station and the door, she cycled through emotions so quickly it was almost dizzying.

Anger came first—hot and immediate. A sharp flare at the audacity of Evanora’s presence here, in her hospital, demanding attention, mistreating staff, wearing the same last name like a provocation.

Confusion followed close behind. The dissonance of it all. The fact that Evanora was here at all. Sick. 
Mortal. Reduced to a patient in a bed instead of the omnipotent force Agatha’s memories insisted she was.

Annoyance crept in next, brittle and defensive. At fate. At herself. For agreeing to take the case instead of doing the sensible thing and handing it off, putting as much professional and emotional distance between herself and that woman as possible.

Then fear.

It arrived quietly, insidiously, coiling low in her chest. Not fear of Evanora as she was now, but fear of what she had been. Of how easily her presence could still drag Agatha backward into old patterns, old wounds. Fear that no amount of titles or authority could fully protect her from becoming that smaller, quieter version of herself again.

And finally—numbness.

By the time she reached the door, something inside her had gone very still.

Agatha paused, hand hovering just short of the handle, and leaned slightly to peer through the narrow window set into the door.

The room was dim, lit mostly by the weak glow of the city beyond the rain-streaked glass. Evanora sat upright in the bed, turned away, her profile sharp against the grey light. Rain lashed the window in uneven sheets, the sound faint but persistent even through the thick hospital glass.

From this angle, Agatha could see it clearly.

Evanora was smaller.

Her shoulders sloped inward now, no longer squared with authority. Her neck looked thinner, her skin almost translucent beneath the harsh lighting. The woman who had once seemed to loom over Agatha’s entire world now looked… diminished. Frail, even, in a way that felt both unsettling and deeply disorienting.

Agatha’s memories had never allowed for this version of her.

In her mind, Evanora was always towering. A looming presence that filled rooms and silences alike. 
Hands that could grip an arm too tightly, fingers that could twist painfully into hair to enforce obedience.

A voice that cut and controlled with precision, leaving no room for resistance.

Seeing her like this made Agatha’s stomach twist.

She straightened, drawing in a slow, measured breath, feeling it expand her chest, anchor her where she stood. The professional mask slid into place almost automatically, years of practice making the motion seamless.

What are you doing? she thought, not unkindly, but honestly. You should have handed this off.

She knew that. Had known it the moment she’d read the name on the chart. Distance was safer. Distance was cleaner. Distance was what she would have advised anyone else in her position to take.

Instead, here she was.

Standing outside the room of the woman who had destroyed her childhood, about to step back into her orbit of her own free will.

Agatha closed her eyes for a brief moment, then opened them again, resolve settling in where fear had been.

Whatever happened next, she would not be that child again.

She placed her hand on the door.

Her fingers barely brushed the handle when a hand landed on her shoulder.

Firm. Grounding. Unmistakably real.

Agatha startled, breath hitching sharply as her body reacted before her mind caught up. She hadn’t heard anyone approach — she’d been too deep inside her own head, too focused on the battle she was bracing herself for.

She turned slowly.

Chief Romanoff stood behind her, expression set with calm determination, posture squared in a way that brooked no argument. Wanda was beside her, eyes wide and slightly out of breath, her concern so naked it almost hurt to look at.

“Agatha,” Natasha said gently, but with an authority that left no room for misinterpretation, “I think it’s best you give me the patient’s chart and step away from the door.”

Her voice was even. Careful. The kind of tone used when someone was standing too close to the edge.
Agatha stared at her as if through water.

She didn’t move.
 Didn’t speak.

Her hand remained curled around the door handle, knuckles whitening as if letting go might send her tumbling.

“Agatha, please,” Wanda said softly.

That did it.

Something in Agatha’s gaze shifted — awareness flooding back in all at once, like surfacing too quickly. She blinked, chest rising sharply as she took in the scene properly this time: the two women in front of her, the quiet hallway, the door she had been seconds away from opening.

The reality of it landed all at once.

What she had almost done.

She loosened her grip on the handle slowly, fingers trembling as they fell away. Her arm dropped to her side, suddenly heavy.

“I—” Her voice faltered. She cleared her throat, trying again. “I can handle it.”

Natasha didn’t argue. She simply held Agatha’s gaze, steady and unflinching. “I know you think you can,” she said quietly. “That doesn’t mean you should.”

Agatha swallowed hard.

If they hadn’t stopped her — if she had gone in there alone — would she really have been able to keep her composure? Would she have stood her ground against the woman who had made her childhood a battlefield? Against the woman who had abandoned her without looking back?

Or would she have crumbled the moment Evanora opened her mouth?

The thought made her stomach twist.

Wanda stepped closer, her voice barely above a whisper. “You don’t have to do this.”

Agatha’s shoulders sagged, just a fraction, the fight draining out of her all at once. The certainty she’d felt moments ago dissolved into something shakier, more honest.

“No,” she admitted quietly. “I don’t.”

Natasha extended her hand. “Give me the chart.”

After a beat — one last, lingering glance at the door — Agatha did.

As the folder left her hands, it felt like relinquishing something dangerous. Not responsibility. Protection.

Natasha nodded once, decisive. “I’ll reassign the case.”

Agatha let out a breath she hadn’t realised she’d been holding, her legs suddenly unsteady beneath her.

The door to room ninety-eight remained closed and Agatha felt the memories crash over her once again.

 

 

 

Rio didn’t think much of the lack of replies at first.

Agatha had long shifts. Impossible ones. There were days when she disappeared into surgery and emerged hours later with a single apologetic text and a heart emoji, like a breadcrumb left behind to say I’m still here. Rio trusted that. Trusted her.

So when her first message went unanswered, Rio shrugged it off, slid her phone back into her pocket, and got on with her shift.

The second one, too.

By the third hour, she’d started checking her phone a little more often than necessary, thumb hovering over Agatha’s name before she caught herself and forced it down. She’s busy, Rio told herself. She’s fine.

But five hours in, the silence stopped feeling neutral.

It sat wrong in her chest, a low, persistent pressure that didn’t ease no matter how much she tried to distract herself. Even on Agatha’s worst days, even when she was slammed and exhausted and running on fumes, she always found a second to check in. A single emoji. A sorry my love, it’s been hectic. 
Something.

This was nothing.

By the time Rio clocked out, she didn’t hesitate.

She didn’t go home. Didn’t sit in her truck to think it through. She turned the key and drove straight toward the hospital, hands tight on the steering wheel, jaw clenched as the sky began to lighten at the edges.

The sun was just starting to rise when she pulled into the hospital parking lot, the early morning light pale and unfotgiving. Agatha was due to finish in about an hour. Rio told herself she was just stopping by. Just checking in. Maybe surprising her with coffee. Maybe walking her out when her shift ended.

That was the story she stuck to as she shut off the engine.

But her chest still felt tight as she crossed toward the entrance.

The emergency department was quieter than usual. No line spilling out into the waiting area. No agitated pacing. No raised voices. If anything, it felt oddly subdued, like the building itself was holding something in.

That made it worse.

So why haven’t I heard from you? Rio thought, unease sharpening into something colder.

She was almost inside when she spotted Wanda near the exit, jacket half on, shoulders slumped with exhaustion as she rummaged through her bag. Rio slowed, relief flaring briefly at the familiar sight.

“Hey, Wands,” Rio called gently. “Have you seen Agatha anywhere?”

Wanda looked up, surprised, a tired smile flickering across her face before it faded just as quickly.

“Oh—hey, Rio.”

Something in her expression tightened.

Wanda glanced around the department, then reached out, guiding Rio by the arm around the corner, away from the nurses’ station and the few lingering staff. That small, deliberate movement set off every alarm Rio had.

“Actually,” Wanda said quietly, “she went home a couple of hours ago.”

Rio stopped short. “She did?”

Wanda nodded, her mouth pressing into a thin line. “There was… an incident.”

Rio felt her stomach drop.

“A patient came in last night,” Wanda continued, choosing her words carefully. “She caused a bit of a scene. Security got involved. At first I thought the name was just a coincidence.”

She hesitated, then looked Rio square in the eyes.

“It wasn’t.”

Rio’s breath left her in a rush. “What do you mean?”

Wanda swallowed. “It’s her birth mother. She’s here.”

The world seemed to tilt.

Rio felt the colour drain from her face, her mind racing to keep up. She knew pieces of Agatha’s past — enough to understand how catastrophic this was. Enough to know this wasn’t just difficult.

It was devastating.

“Oh shit,” Rio whispered.

“Agatha tried to brush it off,” Wanda said. “Tried to take the case herself. Nat stopped her. Thank god she did.”

Rio closed her eyes briefly, jaw tightening. Of course she tried to handle it alone.

“She took off not long after that,” Wanda finished. “Didn’t really say where she was going.”

Rio nodded slowly, heart pounding now, worry tipping into something sharper and more urgent.

“Did she… did she seem okay?” Rio asked, though she already knew the answer.

Wanda’s expression softened, sad and knowing. “You know how she is. She said she was fine.”

That answer told Rio everything.

“But,” Wanda added quietly, “she was shaken. More than she wanted to admit.”

Rio exhaled, forcing herself to stay upright, to stay steady. “Thanks, Wanda.”

“Of course,” Wanda said, squeezing her arm gently. “Let me know how she is, yeah?”

“I will,” Rio promised.

She turned back toward the exit, already pulling her phone out again, thumb hovering over Agatha’s name as her thoughts raced.

Where did you go? 

Are you alone? 

Why didn’t you call me?

One thing was painfully clear now.

Agatha hadn’t just left work early.

She’d run.

And Rio was going to find her.

Rio headed straight for Lilia’s.

There was no real debate in her mind about it. If Agatha was hurting — if she was shaken enough to leave work without a word — she would gravitate toward the place that had always meant safety. Toward Lilia. 
Toward familiarity and quiet and someone who loved her without conditions.

The drive felt longer than it should have.

Rio’s thoughts spiralled despite her best efforts to keep them in check. Images rose unbidden — Agatha as she’d described her childhood in fragments and half-sentences, the careful way she avoided certain memories, the way she brushed off pain with humour or silence. Rio knew that pattern too well now. 
Knew how quickly Agatha folded inward when old wounds were touched.

She’ll say she’s fine, Rio thought grimly. She always does.

She bit her lip hard enough to sting, grounding herself as the house came into view.

By the time she pulled up outside Lilia’s, her heart sank further. Agatha’s sleek black Mercedes wasn’t there. The driveway was empty save for Lilia’s car. But the kitchen lights were on, warm and steady, and Rio could see Lilia’s silhouette moving inside, familiar and comforting in a way that only made the absence sharper.

Rio climbed out of the truck slowly, dread pooling heavier with each step toward the door.

She knocked softly.

A moment later, the door opened and Lilia smiled, the same warm, welcoming expression she always wore when Rio came by.

“Rio, dear, what—” Lilia began.

Then she really looked at her.

The smile faded instantly.

Lilia’s eyes softened with concern, her posture shifting as she took in Rio’s tense shoulders, the worry etched plainly across her face.

“Oh,” Lilia said quietly. “What’s wrong?”

“She’s not here, is she?” Rio asked, her voice tight. She already knew the answer.

Lilia shook her head slowly. “No,” she said. “What’s happened?”

She stepped aside without another word, ushering Rio into the house. The familiar scent of coffee and herbs wrapped around her, but it did little to ease the knot in her chest.

Rio didn’t bother sitting.

“She hasn’t answered any of my texts since last night,” Rio said, words spilling out now that she’d started. “I thought she was just busy, but it kept going. I went to the hospital this morning. Wanda was there.”

Lilia’s expression grew more serious, her attention sharpening.

“She said Agatha left early,” Rio continued. “There was a patient admitted. Someone with her last name. I guess they thought it was a coincidence at first.”

Lilia went very still.

“But,” Rio said, swallowing hard, “it wasn’t.”

Silence fell heavy between them.

“It’s Evanora,” Rio finished. “She’s here. In the hospital.”

Lilia’s face fell.

For a heartbeat, she looked older somehow — lines deepening, shoulders stiffening as if bracing against something long-buried. Then anger flared across her features, raw and unmistakable.

“Oh,” Lilia said, her voice low and dangerous. “That woman.”

She turned away abruptly and began to pace, movements sharp and restless. The calm, measured presence Rio knew so well fractured completely, replaced by something fierce and incandescent. Twenty years of restraint snapped all at once.

Ebony lifted her head from her spot on the floor, ears flicking in confusion as she watched Lilia stride back and forth.

“She has no right,” Lilia muttered. “No right to show her face again. Not after—”

She stopped herself, dragging a hand through her hair, breath coming faster now.

Rio watched, startled. She had never seen Lilia like this — never seen her lose her composure, never seen such unfiltered rage aimed at anyone.

“She tried to take the case herself,” Rio said quietly. “Nat stopped her.”

“Thank god,” Lilia snapped. “Thank god someone did.”

She turned back to Rio, eyes blazing. “Agatha always thinks she has to face things alone. Always. She learned that from her.”

The word her dripped with contempt.

Rio nodded, chest aching. “I don’t know where she went,” she said. 

Lilia’s anger softened into something like fear then, worry cutting through the fury.

“No,” she said slowly. “If she didn’t come here… then she doesn’t want to be seen like this.”

Rio’s stomach dropped.

They stood there together in the quiet kitchen, the weight of Agatha’s absence pressing down on them both.

“We’ll find her,” Lilia said at last, resolve settling in her voice even as her hands trembled faintly. “We will.”

Rio nodded, jaw set, determination burning hot beneath the fear pooling in her chest.

“I’m going to check my apartment,” she said. “Maybe she went there. I just figured you’d be the first place she came to, considering…”

She trailed off, not quite able to articulate the weight of what Agatha was carrying.

Lilia’s expression softened in a way that felt almost unbearably tender. She stepped closer and cupped Rio’s cheek, her thumb brushing gently along her jaw.

“My dear,” Lilia said quietly, “you are her safe place now.”

The words settled deep, heavy and affirming all at once.

Rio swallowed hard and nodded once, leaning briefly into the touch before pulling away. “I’ll call you,” 
she promised, already backing toward the door.

The drive back to her apartment was shorter, but no less frantic. Her thoughts churned relentlessly — please be there, please be there — even as another part of her knew better. Agatha didn’t hide where she might be found easily.

When Rio burst into the apartment, she nearly collided with Alice in the kitchen. Alice was standing in front of the counter in socks and an oversized hoodie, pouring cereal with the bleary focus of someone barely conscious.

“Oh—hey,” Alice mumbled. “You’re up early.”

“Have you seen Agatha?” Rio asked, already moving past her.

Alice blinked, processing. “Nah, dude. Haven’t seen her since—” She yawned. “—whenever you left last.”

Rio was already halfway down the hall.

She checked the bedroom. Empty. The bed untouched. The room cold in that unmistakable way that meant no one had slept there.

Her chest tightened.

She tried calling again as she stood in the doorway, thumb pressing the button with more force than necessary.

Straight to voicemail.

“Agatha,” Rio murmured under her breath, frustration and fear bleeding together. “Where are you?”

She lowered the phone, pacing once, then stopping abruptly.

Think, she told herself. Where would she go if she didn’t want to be seen?

Not Lilia’s. 

Not here.

Somewhere familiar. Somewhere quiet. Somewhere she could disappear without being alone.

The answer hit her all at once.

“Oh,” Rio breathed. “I’m an idiot.”

She spun on her heel and bolted for the door.

“Hey—where are you going?” Alice called after her, spoon halfway to her mouth.

“Out,” Rio said, already gone.

The irony twisted sharply in her chest as she drove — that the place she’d left was the place she’d needed to come back to all along.

The firehouse.

“This is where I go when the noise gets too loud.” 
“You can come up here whenever you want,”

Rio had told Agatha about the firehouse roof months ago, recommended it as a quiet place to escape.

Somewhere she didn’t have to explain herself.

Rio pulled up out back and didn’t bother parking properly. 

She jumped out of the truck, heart pounding, and ran toward the rear entrance. The metal stairs rattled beneath her boots as she took them two at a time, breath burning in her lungs.

Please, please, please.
At the top, she stopped short.

Agatha was there.

Curled into one of the old chairs they kept for overnight shifts, a thin blanket pulled tight around her shoulders. Her posture was folded inward, knees drawn up slightly, chin tucked down like she was trying to take up as little space as possible.

She looked impossibly small.

Not the brilliant surgeon.
 Not the sharp-witted woman who commanded rooms.

Just someone exhausted. Hurt. Trying to hold herself together.

Rio’s chest ailed with it.

She crossed the room quietly, as if loud movement might scare her off, every instinct screaming to gather her up, to shield her, to undo whatever damage had been done.

“Agatha,” Rio said softly.

Agatha didn’t look up at first.

But when she did, Rio saw it immediately — the emptiness behind her eyes, the fragile, fractured composure she rarely let anyone witness.

Rio knelt in front of her without hesitation, hands gentle as they came to rest on Agatha’s knees.

“I’ve got you,” she said, voice steady even as her heart threatened to split open. “I’m here. Mi amor, look at me,” she coaxed softly, her thumb brushing beneath Agatha’s chin as she lifted her face.

Agatha’s skin felt cold.

That alone sent a sharp ache through Rio’s chest. Agatha always ran warm, always grounded in her body even when her mind raced. This—this distant stillness—was different.

When Agatha’s eyes finally met hers, Rio felt her breath catch.

They were unfocused, glassy, like she was looking through Rio instead of at her. Somewhere far away. 

Somewhere Rio couldn’t follow without permission.

“Oh, baby,” Rio murmured, voice breaking just a little despite her best effort to keep it steady. “You’re not here, are you?”

Agatha didn’t answer.

Her lips parted as if she meant to speak, then closed again. Her shoulders curled inward instinctively, the blanket tightening around her like armour. She looked small. Not physically—Agatha was still all sharp lines and presence—but emotionally, folded in on herself, trying to survive the moment instead of live inside it.

Rio’s heart fractured at the sight.

She shifted closer, careful not to crowd her, one knee pressing gently against the chair, anchoring herself where Agatha could feel her. Rio kept one hand under Agatha’s chin, the other resting lightly on her knee, a constant, grounding point.

“You don’t have to talk,” Rio said quietly. “You don’t have to explain anything. I just need you here with me, okay?”

Agatha’s throat worked.

“I—” she started, then stopped. Her jaw trembled faintly, the tiniest betrayal of how hard she was holding herself together.

Rio leaned in until their foreheads touched, breathing slowly on purpose, deep and even. She knew this—knew how dissociation felt, how the body retreated when the past became too loud.

“Breathe with me,” Rio whispered. “Just for a second.”

She inhaled deliberately.

Agatha didn’t follow at first.

So Rio stayed. Didn’t rush. Didn’t fill the silence with reassurances that Agatha wasn’t ready to believe. She just breathed again, steady and patient, until finally—barely—Agatha’s chest rose in a shallow imitation.

“There you go,” Rio said softly. “That’s it.”

Agatha’s eyes fluttered, focus sharpening by degrees. The faraway look receded just enough for recognition to take hold.

“Rio,” she whispered, voice hoarse.

The sound of her name nearly undid Rio entirely.

“I’m here,” Rio replied instantly. “I’m not going anywhere.”

Agatha’s composure cracked then—not dramatically, not all at once—but in a quiet collapse that felt somehow worse. Her shoulders sagged, the tension draining out of her body like she’d finally run out of strength to keep standing.

“She—” Agatha swallowed hard. “She’s here.”

“I know,” Rio said gently. “Wanda told me.”

Agatha shook her head weakly. “I wasn’t ready. I thought I was. I thought—” Her breath hitched. “I thought I could be… someone else.”

Rio’s jaw tightened, anger flaring briefly on Agatha’s behalf before she forced it down. This wasn’t about rage. This was about holding her.

“You don’t have to be anyone else,” Rio said firmly, but softly. “Not with me.”

Agatha’s eyes filled, finally, tears clinging stubbornly to her lashes. She looked ashamed of them, like they were another failure she hadn’t planned for.

Rio cupped her face fully now, thumbs brushing beneath her eyes without wiping them away. “Hey,” she murmured. “None of that. Don’t apologise for being hurt.”

Agatha let out a broken breath that sounded suspiciously like a sob.

“She —” Agatha’s voice faltered completely this time. “She did such awful things Rio”

Rio pressed her forehead more firmly against Agatha’s, grounding them both. “You don’t have to tell me everything,” she replied. “But you can. Whenever you’re ready.”

Agatha leaned into her then, finally giving up the fight to stay upright. Her head tipped forward until it rested against Rio’s shoulder, fingers clutching weakly at the fabric of Rio’s jacket like she was afraid she might vanish.

Rio wrapped her arms around her fully, slow and certain, pulling Agatha close enough that she could feel her heartbeat.

“You’re safe,” Rio whispered into her hair. “You’re with me. I’ve got you.”

Rio stayed exactly where she was.

She didn’t loosen her hold when Agatha’s fingers curled tighter into her jacket. Didn’t flinch when Agatha’s breath broke again, sharper this time, the sound of someone who had been holding herself together for far too long and had finally reached the limit of that strength.

“It’s okay,” Rio murmured, the words steady even as her own chest ached. “I’ve got you. I’ve got you.”

Agatha shook against her, a small, involuntary movement, like her body was trying to decide whether it was safe to fall apart. Rio shifted carefully, angling herself so Agatha could lean more fully into her. One arm wrapped around Agatha’s shoulders, the other cradled the back of her head, fingers threading gently through her hair.

Agatha let out a sound that wasn’t quite a sob, but close enough that it made Rio’s throat tighten painfully.

“I didn’t even go in,” Agatha whispered finally, her voice muffled against Rio’s shoulder. “I thought I could. I told myself I was ready and then—” She swallowed hard. “I froze.”

Rio closed her eyes briefly, relief and heartbreak crashing together. “That doesn’t mean you failed,” she said immediately. “That means you listened to yourself.”

Agatha gave a humourless huff. “I ran.”

“No,” Rio said, firmer now, though still gentle. She leaned back just enough to look at Agatha’s face again, making sure she had her attention. “You protected yourself. There’s a difference.”

Agatha’s eyes were red-rimmed now, unfocused but present. She looked unconvinced. “She still… wins,” she said quietly. “Just by existing.”

Rio’s jaw tightened. She brushed her thumb slowly along Agatha’s cheek, grounding, deliberate. “No,” she said. “She hurt you. That’s not winning. And it doesn’t erase who you are today, who you have become.”

Agatha’s gaze dropped again, shame flickering across her face like a reflex she couldn’t quite control. “She knows exactly what to say,” she admitted. “Even without seeing me. Just knowing she’s there… it’s like I’m twelve again.”

Rio nodded. “Yeah,” she said softly. “Trauma doesn’t care how old you are now.”

That seemed to land.

Agatha sagged slightly, some of the fight leaving her shoulders. “I didn’t want you to see me like this,” she said. “I didn’t want… to bring this into us.”

Rio felt something fierce and protective rise in her chest.

“Hey,” she said, tilting Agatha’s face gently until she had to look at her. “This is part of you. That means it’s part of us whether we name it or not.” Her voice softened again. “And I don’t scare that easily.”

Agatha’s lips trembled. “You should.”

Rio shook her head. “No. I love you. That includes the mess. Especially the mess.”

Agatha stared at her, like she was trying to decide whether to believe it. Then, finally, she exhaled—a long, shaky breath that felt like surrender.

“I don’t think I can go home yet,” she admitted.

“Okay,” Rio said immediately. No hesitation. “Then we don’t.”

She glanced around the quiet room, the early morning light creeping in through the high windows. “We can stay here a minute longer. Or we can go somewhere else. Your call.”

Agatha considered it, then nodded faintly. “I don’t want to be alone.”

Rio tightened her arms around her. “You won’t be.”

She shifted carefully, easing Agatha up just enough that she could sit more comfortably, still tucked close, still supported. Agatha leaned into her again without resistance this time, her weight trusting, heavy in a way that spoke of exhaustion rather than fear.

Rio pressed a soft kiss into Agatha’s hair.

“We’ll take this one step at a time,” she said quietly. “You don’t have to be strong today. I’ll do that part.”

Agatha closed her eyes, forehead resting against Rio’s collarbone.

For the first time since disappearing, her breathing evened out.

And Rio stayed there with her, holding the space steady, until the worst of the storm passed.

 

 

 

 


Back at the hospital, Lilia arrived with purpose.

She wore her softest cardigan, the one staff always commented on, and carried a canvas tote filled with neatly folded, freshly knitted hats in pastel colours. A gift for the neonatal unit — something she’d planned to do in a few weeks’ time, but today felt… appropriate. Necessary. It gave her a reason to be here that no one would question.

She smiled. 

She thanked people. 

She accepted gratitude with gracious nods and warm words.

No one noticed that the tote wasnt empty when she left the unit.

By the time she reached the surgical wing, Lilia moved differently.

Her steps were quiet. Measured. Her posture loose in a way that suggested calm, but her eyes were sharp now, scanning room numbers with surgical precision. She wasn’t angry in a loud way. She was focused.

There was only one destination.

Room 98.

Lilia stopped outside the door for half a second — not to hesitate, but to listen. The room was quiet save for the steady beep of monitors and the faint sound of wind against glass.

She entered without knocking.

Evanora lay propped up in the bed, thinner than Lilia remembered, her skin sallow under the hospital lights. She turned her head as the door closed, irritation already forming before she could place the visitor.

Her eyes narrowed.
She studied Lilia’s face, searching memory.
Then something clicked.

“…Lilia?” Evanora said, surprise threading through the word.

Lilia smiled.

It was polite. Controlled. Entirely devoid of warmth.

“Yes,” she said softly. “Hello, Evanora.”

Before Evanora could speak again, Lilia’s hand dipped into her tote with a smooth, practiced motion. In one fluid movement, she stepped forward and pressed a long, sharp knitting needle beneath Evanora’s chin — not enough to pierce skin, but enough that the pressure was unmistakable.

Enough that Evanora froze.

Lilia leaned down, bringing her face level with Evanora’s, her voice dropping to a near whisper.

“If you raise your voice,” Lilia said calmly, “or call for help, or so much as flinch, I will hurt you.”

Evanora’s breath hitched.

Lilia continued, eyes burning now. “I won’t kill you. That would be far too easy.”

She adjusted the pressure slightly — just enough to make the point crystal clear.

“But I will make myself unforgettable.”

Evanora swallowed hard, her bravado evaporating under the weight of Lilia’s gaze.

“You left a child,” Lilia said, every word measured. “A twelve-year-old girl. On my doorstep. With no explanation and no intention of ever coming back.”

Evanora scoffed weakly. “She was difficult—”

The needle pressed closer.

“She was brilliant,” Lilia snapped quietly. “And terrified. And still desperate for you.”

Her voice trembled now, but she didn’t pull away.

“You do not get to come back into her life,” Lilia said, “and you do not get to harm her again. Not with words. Not with looks. Not with your existence.”

Evanora’s eyes darted around the room, searching for an escape that didn’t exist.

“If I hear,” Lilia continued, “that you asked for her by name, or complained about her, or so much as acknowledged her presence again—”

She smiled then. Not kindly.

“I will make sure every single person who matters knows exactly who you are.”

She leaned closer still. “And believe me, Evanora, I have a lot of friends in this town”

Slowly, deliberately, Lilia removed the needle and slipped it back into her tote.

She straightened, smoothing her cardigan as if nothing had happened.

Evanora lay rigid, breathing shallowly, eyes wide with fear and fury.

Lilia looked down at her one last time.

“You don’t get to ruin her,” she said softly. “That privilege is gone.”

Then she turned and left the room, footsteps once again light and unhurried.

Outside, she paused only long enough to steady herself.

For Agatha.

Always.

Chapter End Notes

Lilia is the GOAT

Chapter 27

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The rooftop had changed while they sat there.

What had started as a pale, grey morning had slowly bled into late afternoon, the light thinning and cooling until the town below looked washed in steel and shadow. One by one, small points of warmth began to glow beneath them — strings of Christmas lights flickering on along shopfronts, windows, and lampposts, tentative at first, then steady. Soft colour crept back into the streets, red and gold and green pushing gently against the cold. The wind had picked up too, sneaking through the gaps between buildings, curling around exposed skin with quiet persistence.

Rio noticed long before Agatha did.

She noticed the way the cold crept in, the way Agatha’s shoulders tensed almost imperceptibly, the way her fingers curled tighter into the fabric of Rio’s sleeve as if her body was bracing for something even her mind hadn’t caught up to yet. Rio had learned, over the last few months, to read those signs the same way she read smoke patterns or strutctural shifts, like small warnings that mattered.

She didn’t say anything at first.

Agatha was still pressed close to her side, gaze unfocused, breathing steady but shallow, like she was conserving energy just to stay present. Like every breath was a deliberate choice. Rio felt the weight of her there, not heavy, but real, and something protective settled deep in her chest. This wasn’t a moment to fill with words. 

This was a moment to just be present for Agatha.

She shifted subtly, angling her body so she took the brunt of the wind, her arm firm around Agatha’s shoulders. She could feel the chill seeping in anyway, could feel how Agatha leaned into her without even realising she was doing it. The trust in that—unthinking, instinctive—made Rio’s throat tighten.

Eventually, quietly, Rio stood.

“I’ll be right back,” she murmured, already shrugging off her jacket and tucking it more securely around Agatha’s shoulders. The motion felt almost reverent. As if she were wrapping something fragile instead of a woman who had survived more than most people ever knew.

Agatha nodded faintly, trusting, eyes never leaving the skyline.

Rio moved fast, the cold biting sharper now that she’d stepped away. She slipped back inside the firehouse, heart still tethered to the spot she’d left, and returned a minute later with a thick station blanket tucked under one arm and two mismatched mugs in the other. Steam curled up immediately, fragrant and sweet.

Hot cocoa. Extra sugar. A small comfort against the December chill. Something her abuela would have done.

As she crossed back toward Agatha, Rio felt a strange mix of things swirl together, relief that she could do something useful, fear that it wouldn’t be enough, and a quiet, steady resolve that surprised even her.

She couldn’t fix what had been done.

But she could be there for her.

Which, right now, felt like everything.

She draped the blanket around Agatha first, careful and deliberate, wrapping it snugly like she was sealing warmth into her bones. Agatha made a small sound of surprise, then leaned into it instinctively, fingers clutching the edge.

“M’lady,” Rio smiled, pressing the mug of hot cocoa into Agatha’s hands. “Careful. It’s hot.”

Agatha blinked down at it like she’d forgotten warmth could be held. She nodded once, fingers curling around the ceramic, absorbing the heat slowly.

Rio took her place beside her again, close enough that their shoulders and hips touched beneath the blanket. She didn’t suggest leaving. Didn’t comment on the cold or the time or the way Agatha’s nose was starting to pink.

She waited.

Minutes passed in companionable silence. The town hummed below them, distant sirens and traffic softened by height and air. Agatha sipped the cocoa absently, eyes still far away, but the tension in her body had eased just a little more.

Then something shifted.

Agatha tilted her head upward, brow furrowing faintly as she felt something cold brush her cheek.
She blinked.

Another followed. Then another.

Snow.

Not the heavy kind, not yet. Just small flurries, soft, tentative flakes drifting lazily out of the sky like they were testing the idea of landing.

Agatha lifted her face fully now, watching them fall.

And then, finally she smiled.

It was small. Almost shy. But it was real.

It broke across her face like dawn, softening the hard lines grief and fear had etched there all day. Her shoulders relaxed, breath leaving her in a slow, awed exhale.

“Oh,” she murmured. “It’s snowing.”

Rio watched her, something warm blooming in her chest that had nothing to do with the blanket or the cocoa. 

She took in the way Agatha’s eyes followed the flakes, the way the tension drained from her posture, the way the world seemed to narrow down to this quiet, beautiful moment. This was what she wanted to protect. This quiet, rare softness that Agatha gave so sparingly.

“It’s beautiful.” Agatha whispered.

“Yeah,” Rio said softly, her eyes not leaving Agatha’s now soft features. “It really is.”

Agatha held her mug closer, tilting her head back, letting the snow dust her lashes and melt against her skin. For the first time since Rio had found her, she looked present. Not braced. Not retreating.
Just… here.

The love Rio felt in that moment was steady and consuming, the kind that didn’t demand or overwhelm but rooted itself quietly and refused to be shaken. She loved Agatha not for her strength alone, but for this too, for the vulnerability she trusted Rio enough to show.

Rio shifted closer, tucking the blanket tighter around them both, her arm warm and solid at Agatha’s side.
 She didn’t interrupt. Didn’t name the moment.

She waited until Agatha’s breathing had settled again, until the snow seemed to soften the edges of the city and the quiet felt earned.

Then, gently, “Do you want to talk about it?”

Agatha didn’t answer right away.

She watched the snow fall for a long moment, lashes blinking slowly as flakes melted against them. 

Rio followed her gaze, letting the silence stretch, reminding herself that this wasn’t something to hurry. This was Agatha choosing to speak at all. Rio felt a familiar, fierce protectiveness rise in her chest, not loud, not angry, but solid. 

When Agatha  finally spoke, her voice was steady, but distant, like she was narrating something she’d lived with for years.

“I’ve thought about that moment for… twenty years,” she said.

Rio turned slightly toward her, attention narrowing completely.

“Every version of it,” Agatha continued. “What I’d say. How I’d stand. Whether I’d be calm or cruel or clinical.” A faint, humourless smile touched her mouth. “I had entire speeches prepared.”

Rio nodded, encouraging but silent.

“I imagined telling her she ruined me,” Agatha said quietly. “Or that I didn’t need her anymore. Or that I’d succeeded in spite of her.” She swallowed. “Sometimes I imagined saying nothing at all. Just… looking at her and letting her see what she walked away from.”

Her grip tightened on the mug.

“I thought if I planned it enough, it wouldn’t hurt,” she admitted. “Like preparation could make it barable.”

Rio felt her chest ache, but she didn’t interrupt.

“But when I saw her through the window,” Agatha said, her voice faltering for the first time, “my mind went completely blank.”

She shook her head slightly, as if still confused by it.

“There was no anger. No strength. Just this… awful, hollow recognition.” Her breath hitched. “Like my body remembered her before my mind could catch up.”

Rio’s hand tightened around her shoulder.

“She didn’t look like the monster I remembered,” Agatha went on. “She looked small. Frail. And somehow that made it worse.” Her jaw clenched. “Because it didn’t erase anything she did. It just… stripped away the excuse that I needed to hate her.”

She exhaled shakily.

“She used to leave me alone for days,” Agatha said softly. “Food on the counter if I was lucky. Notes telling me not to touch anything. Not to bother her.” Her voice stayed even, but her eyes burned. “I learned how to be quiet because noise annoyed her. I learned how to disappear because that was easier for her.”

Rio’s heart broke a little more with every word.

“I spent years thinking that if I was good enough, smart enough, useful enough, she’d come back,” Agatha whispered. “And when she didn’t… I decided it must have been my fault.”

She finally turned to look at Rio then, eyes raw and searching.

“So when I stood there today,” she said, “all I could think was — what if she looks at me and still doesn’t care?”

The snow fell softly between them.

Rio lifted Agatha’s hand, fingers threading together deliberately, anchoring her to the present. “She doesn’t get to define you,” Rio said gently. “She lost that right the moment she walked away.”

Agatha nodded, but her voice wavered. “I know that. Intellectually. But the child part of me still wants… something. An apology. A reason. Proof that I mattered.”

Rio squeezed her hand, grounding, certain. “I think that’s a reasonable thing to want,” she said quietly.

Agatha leaned into her, resting her forehead against Rio’s shoulder, the weight of the day finally pressing in now that she wasn’t holding herself upright alone. “I hate that she still has that power over me,” she admitted.

Rio pressed a soft kiss into Agatha’s hair, lingering there. “She doesn’t,” she said gently. “Not anymore.” She pulled back just enough to look at her. “Agatha, I think you’re the bravest person I’ve ever known.”

Agatha let out a small, sad laugh. “Rio, you risk your life every day. You’re surrounded by brave people.” She shook her head. “I’m not one of them.”

Rio turned fully toward her then, cupping her cheek so Agatha couldn’t look away. Her thumb brushed beneath Agatha’s eye, tender and deliberate. “Don’t do that,” she said softly. “Don’t shrink yourself because of what she did to you.”

Her voice warmed as she went on. “I love you. I love your strength. I love your stubborn determination.” A smile tugged at her mouth. “Hell, I even love when you’re mean.”

Agatha huffed, a wet chuckle breaking free as she wiped at her eyes. “Even though my nose is all snotty?”

Rio laughed, genuine and unrestrained, the sound cutting clean through the heaviness. “Especially your snotty, disgusting nose.”

Agatha laughed with her then, the sound fragile but real, and for a moment the weight of Evanora — of the past — loosened its grip just a little more.

Around them, the snow had stopped being tentative.

It gathered quietly now, settling into the folds of the blanket pooled across their laps, dusting Agatha’s knees and the toe of Rio’s boot in soft white. Every so often, a flake caught in Agatha’s hair and melted there, cold and fleeting, like the last remnants of something finally beginning to pass.

Agatha noticed it absently, brushing at the fabric once before letting her hand fall back into Rio’s. She took a slow breath, one that felt deliberate instead of reactive.

“I think…” she began, then paused, as if checking in with herself before continuing. “I think I’m ready to go.”

Rio turned her head slightly, searching Agatha’s face for any sign of hesitation. There wasn’t any. Just exhaustion. And resolve.

“Okay,” Rio said gently. 

Agatha glanced down at the snow collecting on them and huffed out a quiet, almost fond laugh. “Before I turn into an icicle.”

Rio smiled. “Yeah, I didn’t wanna say anything but I lost sensation in my fingers ten minutes ago.”

She shifted carefully, brushing snow from the blanket and helping Agatha stand, keeping one hand at her back as they moved. Agatha swayed slightly, not from weakness so much as the weight of the day finally settling into her bones, and Rio steadied her without comment.

As they gathered their things, Rio spoke again, softly. “We should head to Lilia’s,” she suggested. “She’s probably been freaking out that I haven’t called her yet.”

Agatha considered it for only a moment before nodding. “Yeah,” she said. “I don’t want her worrying.”

Something eased in Rio’s chest at the agreement. She squeezed Agatha’s hand once, warm and reassuring. 

“She’ll be really glad to see you.”

Agatha glanced back at the rooftop one last time, the quiet, the snow, the strange pocket of peace it had given her — then turned away without regret.

“Thank you,” she said quietly as they headed for the stairs. “For being here with me.”

Rio didn’t hesitate. “Always.”

She leaned in then, unable to resist, pressing a gentle kiss to Agatha’s lips, soft, unhurried, meant more as reassurance than anything else.

It lasted all of two seconds.

Agatha pulled back with a startled laugh, wiping at her nose. “Oh my god—sorry—”

Rio froze, then burst out laughing, the sound bright and unrestrained. “Hey,” she said between laughs, “I said always. That includes snotty kisses.”

Agatha laughed too, the tension dissolving completely now, embarrassment warming her cheeks. “You’re disgusting Vidal. Sweet, but disgusting.”

They descended together after that, still smiling, snow drifting lazily above the town as Rio helped Agatha into the truck.

As they drove through the quiet streets toward Lilia’s house, the cab of the truck still held a weight of unspoken things but it had shifted.

Agatha sat back in the passenger seat now, no longer quite so tightly curled in on herself. Her shoulders were still drawn forward, but her hands rested looser in her lap, fingers unclenched, the rigid tension from earlier softened by the small, shared laughter they’d left behind on the rooftop.

She hadn’t said much since they’d left the firehouse, but the silence felt different now. Less brittle. Less like she was holding herself together by sheer force of will.

Rio kept one hand on the wheel and the other resting lightly on Agatha’s thigh, a steady, reassuring presence rather than a demand. Agatha didn’t pull away. If anything, she leaned subtly into the touch, her knee angling closer, as if she’d finally given herself permission to accept the comfort being offered.

“Have you eaten yet?” Rio asked gently. “I can pick something up on the way?”

Agatha smiled, a little tired but genuine, and shook her head. “I’m not really hungry.”

Rio squeezed her thigh, the pressure affectionate but firm. “You still have to eat, mi amor.”

Agatha huffed softly. “I’m sure Lilia will force something on me the moment I walk through the door.”

Rio just hummed in response, eyes still on the road but Agatha knew that hum well enough to recognise it for what it was.

Rio wouldn’t truly relax until she’d seen Agatha eat something herself.

When they turned onto Lilia’s street, Rio slowed instinctively.

A maroon car sat parked along the curb.

Rio frowned, eyes flicking to it. “Huh,” she murmured. “Wonder who—”

“Shit. Why is Natasha here?” Agatha said quietly beside her.

Rio glanced over just in time to see Agatha’s face drain of colour.

“Oh God,” Agatha added, breath hitching. “I bet I’m fired, aren’t I?”

The words landed sharp and panicked.

“No,” Rio said immediately, squeezing Agatha’s thigh firmly. “No. Look at me. You’re not fired.”
Agatha didn’t look convinced.

Rio pulled the truck into the driveway and turned off the engine. “You didn’t do anything wrong,” she said again, softer now but no less certain. “And if anyone has a problem with how today went, they’ll have to go through me.”

That earned a weak huff of a laugh from Agatha, but the tension didn’t leave her shoulders.

They were barely inside the house when Agatha heard her name.

Not spoken directly but contained.

“…I’m serious, Lilia,” Natasha was saying, her voice low, controlled, edged with authority. “You need to stay away from Evanora. Whatever happened today, whatever you said — it cannot happen again.”

Agatha stopped in the entryway.

Rio’s hand tightened around hers immediately, instinctive, grounding.

Lilia stood near the living room window, posture composed, hands folded neatly in front of her as if she were discussing the weather. Natasha faced her, coat still on, expression tight with concern and something sharper underneath.

“Oh come on Natasha, I didn’t do anything illegal,” Lilia replied calmly. “I simply just spoke to her.”

“You threatened a patient,” Natasha said evenly. “Enough that she’s made noise about feeling unsafe im my hospital.”

Lilia’s mouth curved into a polite smile that did not reach her eyes. “She has spent a lifetime making other people feel unsafe. I find it difficult to be moved by her discomfort.”

“Lilia,” Natasha warned.

Agatha’s chest tightened.

Natasha turned then — and saw them.

Her expression shifted instantly. “Agatha. Rio. I didn’t realise you were back.”

“It’s fine,” Agatha said quietly. Too quietly. “I heard.”

Lilia turned at once, all sharp edges softening. “My girl.”

Agatha stepped forward this time. “Am I in trouble?” she asked, voice level but thin.

Natasha shook her head immediately. “No. Absolutely not. You did nothing wrong.”

Agatha exhaled, but the tension didn’t leave her shoulders. “Then why does it feel like everyone’s talking around me?”

Natasha hesitated, then chose honesty. “Because I’m now aware of the situation and history with you and our new patient, I just wanted to check in.”

Something cold settled in Agatha’s stomach.

Rio felt it and slid her arm more securely around Agatha’s waist.

“She’s made it very clear,” Natasha continued, “that she wants nothing to do with you medically. I’ve assigned Dr Kale to her care.”

Agatha nodded. “Okay”

“But,” Natasha added, gaze flicking briefly to Lilia, “she has complained. Vaguely. About feeling threatened.”

Agatha’s eyes snapped to Lilia.

Lilia met her gaze steadily. “I reminded her of boundaries,” she said simply.

Natasha sighed. “Those boundaries need to be maintained from a distance.”

“Lilia will stay away from her” Agatha said immediately. “We both will.”

“I know,” Natasha said gently. “This isn’t about your restraint. It’s about preventing escalation.”

Lilia’s voice cooled. “You’re asking me to do nothing.”

“I’m asking you,” Natasha replied carefully, “to let the hospital handle her. To let me handle her.”

A beat.

Lilia studied her for a long moment and then nodded, slowly. “Very well.”

Natasha let out a breath she’d clearly been holding. “That’s all I needed to hear.”

Agatha’s voice softened. “She stays, but she stays away from me.”

“Yes,” Natasha said. “That’s the plan.”

Lilia placed a warm hand at Agatha’s back. “You are safe in this town,” she said firmly. “No matter who decides to pass through.”

Natasha tightened her coat. “I’ll check in tomorrow,” she said to Agatha. “As your colleague. Not your boss.”

Agatha met her eyes and nodded. “Thank you.”

Natasha returned the nod, already halfway to the door. Her hand was on the handle when Lilia spoke again, entirely too casually.

“Oh,” she added sweetly, “give Wanda my love, dear.”

The effect was immediate.

Rio made a strangled sound that she quickly turned into a cough, ducking her head. Agatha clapped a hand over her mouth, shoulders shaking as she very nearly lost the battle to stay quiet.

Natasha froze.

Slowly, she turned back around, colour blooming unmistakably across her cheeks. “I—” she began, then stopped, clearly realising there was no dignified recovery here.

Lilia just smiled at her, serene and mischievous all at once.

Natasha let out a breath, shook her head with a helpless, incredulous huff, and opened the door. “Goodnight, Lilia,” she said, pointed but fond.

“Goodnight, Chief,” Lilia replied, utterly pleased with herself.

The door closed softly behind Natasha, and for half a second the house was silent.

Then Rio burst out laughing, Agatha following a beat later, pressing her face briefly into Rio’s shoulder as she tried — and failed — to contain it.

Lilia turned back to them, smoothing her cardigan as if she hadn’t just dropped a conversational grenade. “What?” she asked innocently.

Agatha wiped at her eyes, still smiling. “You’re unbelievable.”

Lilia’s smile only widened as she straightened, clasping her hands together as if resetting herself. “Well,” she said briskly, “I’ll get started on something to eat. Something tells me none of you have eaten in a while.” Her gaze flicked pointedly to Agatha.

Agatha shot Rio a brief I told you so look before following Lilia into the kitchen.

“Lilia,” she said, unable to help the edge in her voice, “are you going to tell me what happened at the hospital?”

Lilia waved a dismissive hand as she began pulling pots from the cupboard. “I merely told that old, decrepit cunt to stay away from you. That’s all.”

Agatha nearly choked on thin air.

In the twenty years she’d known Lilia, she could count on one hand the number of times she’d heard the woman swear. And now she’d dropped the c-word without so much as blinking.

Lilia turned when Agatha stayed silent, taking in the look of pure shock on her face. “Oh, sweetheart,” she said mildly, “do you really think that’s the worst thing I could call her? You’d be appalled if I told you what I actually think.”

Agatha barked out a laugh, the last of the tension loosening in her chest. “Who are you and what have you done with Lilia?”

“Oh hush,” Lilia replied, already moving on. “Go ask Rio if she wants that carbonara I made her last time.”

Agatha sighed, recognising a deliberate subject change when she heard one, and accepted that Lilia wasn’t going to elaborate. She headed back into the living room.

She stopped short.

Rio was fast asleep on the couch, still sitting upright, head tipped back slightly, mouth parted. A soft, almost inaudible snore escaped her.

Agatha’s chest tightened.

Rio had worked the night before. Had come straight to find her. Had stayed steady and present and uncomplaining, setting her own exhaustion aside without a second thought just to make sure Agatha was okay.

The sight undid her.

Agatha moved quietly, pulling a throw from the armchair and draping it gently over Rio’s shoulders. She crouched, brushing her thumb once along Rio’s cheek before pressing a light kiss to her temple.

“Thank you,” she murmured, too softly to wake her.

Rio didn’t stir.

Agatha walked back into the kitchen with a soft smile on her face.

“She’s out cold,” Agatha said softly, glancing back toward the living room.

Lilia hummed in quiet acknowledgment, hands moving with practiced ease as she continued preparing food, the rhythm of it as familiar and grounding as ever.

“And you,” Lilia added without looking up, “will be just as exhausted once all this finally settles.” She finally turned, fixing Agatha with a gentle but unmistakably firm look. “Go put on something comfortable. After you eat, you’re getting some rest.”

Agatha opened her mouth to argue, then thought better of it.

She nodded instead and made her way upstairs, moving on autopilot. She peeled off her damp clothes, dropping them in an untidy heap, and stepped into the shower. Warm water spilled over her shoulders, steam blooming around her, loosening muscles she hadn’t realised she’d been holding tight all day.
She tilted her head forward, letting the water run down her back, and only then did she look down at herself.

Her gaze caught on the scar just above her knee.

It was thin and pale now, a white line against her skin, easy to miss if you weren’t looking for it. But Agatha had always known exactly where it was. Her fingers drifted there without conscious thought, tracing the familiar shape.

She remembered the moment it happened with uncomfortable clarity.

She’d been ten. Walking home from school, backpack heavy, shoes scuffing the pavement, when one of the neighbour’s dogs had gotten loose. It had chased her down the street, barking and snarling, and she’d run harder than she ever had before. She’d almost made it home.

Almost.

She’d tripped just short of the front gate, her knee slamming into the concrete, fabric tearing, skin splitting open. She remembered the shock more than the pain at first — the wet warmth spreading down her leg as blood soaked through her trousers.

She remembered limping inside.

And she remembered Evanora’s scream.

Not fear. Not concern. Rage.

Agatha could still hear it, sharp and shrill, cutting straight through her. What have you done now? Evanora had shouted, furious about the mess, about the interruption, about the inconvenience. She hadn’t looked at the wound once.

“Clean yourself up,” she’d snapped.

So Agatha had. Alone. Sitting on the bathroom floor, hands shaking as she tore at cheap toilet paper, wincing as she pressed it to the cut. She remembered watching the paper dissolve too quickly, streaked red, and the panic that followed- not about the injury, but about using too much paper.

What if Evanora noticed?
 What if she got angry again?

The water from the shower blurred her vision as the memory pressed in, her throat tightening.
Looking at the scar now, decades later, Agatha traced the line once more. It wasn’t just a mark on her body. It was proof. Another small reminder of a childhood lived in the dark, where pain was an inconvenience and comfort didn’t exist.

She let her hand fall away and straightened slowly, forcing herself to breathe.

Unbidden, another image rose up — Lilia kneeling in front of her years later, gently cleaning a scraped knuckle, pressing a bandage into place, kissing it like it mattered. Like she mattered. Lilia had done it again and again over the years, tending not just to cuts and bruises, but to all the quiet injuries Agatha never learned how to name.

She smiled faintly to herself.

Lilia was still doing it.

Not with bandages now but with food, with shelter, with fierce protection and steady love. With insisting she rest. With standing guard when the past tried to reach for her again.

Agatha’s thoughts drifted then, as they so often did, to Nicky.

To the way she had flinched, for years, from the idea of adoption and how quickly she’d shut it down whenever it crept too close. She’d told herself it was practical, responsible, that her life was too demanding. But beneath that, there had always been the deeper fear: that whatever had shaped Evanora lived somewhere inside her too. That cruelty, neglect, emotional absence might be something inherited rather than learned.

The idea of passing that on had terrified her.

She could never imagine making Nicky feel the way she had felt as a child, so small, unwanted, like an inconvenience. She couldn’t imagine looking at someone who depended on her and feeling nothing but irritation or resentment.

She couldn’t imagine hating someone that much.

Least of all a child.

Agatha had loved Nicky. Fiercely. Completely. In ways that had surprised her with their intensity and scared her with their permanence. That love had come so easily it had dismantled every lie she’d told herself about being incapable of it.

Which was what made the truth hurt the most.

The knowledge that her own mother had never been capable of loving her — not in any way that mattered — was something Agatha knew would never fully stop aching. It wasn’t a wound that healed. It was one she carried.

But standing there now, under the steady warmth of the shower, Agatha reminded herself of the truth she was still learning to hold onto.

She was not unlovable.

She never had been.

What mattered, and what she had to keep choosing to focus on, were the people who had loved her. Who continued to love her. Who had seen her at her worst and stayed anyway.

Lilia, with her quiet constancy and fierce protection.

Rio, with her warmth, patience, and unwavering presence.

Agatha shut off the water and reached for a towel, the steam curling around her like a gentle cocoon. As she wrapped it around herself, she felt something settle — not peace, not yet, but something sturdier.

Hope.

And this time, she didn’t push it away.

 

Chapter End Notes

Happy New Year when it comes 🖤 Thank you all so much for following along so far with this story. All your comments and kudos have made my 2025 incredible.

Happier times again soon!

Chapter 28

Chapter Notes

New tag who this? 👀

The week before Christmas arrived with unnerving speed.

As far as Agatha was aware, Evanora was still a patient at the hospital. She didn’t ask for updates. She didn’t check the board. She didn’t look at the census longer than necessary. But she noticed other things — the way Jen’s eye twitched almost imperceptibly after certain consults, the way her jaw tightened when she came back from that end of the floor. Whatever was happening in room ninety-eight, it wasn’t pleasant.

Jen never commented on it. Not to Agatha, anyway. And Agatha was grateful for that restraint.
She had made her peace — or something close enough to pass for it. She went about her days with the same efficiency and precision she always had. She rounded. She operated. She taught. She corrected Teen with her usual sharpness. If she occasionally took the longer route to radiology or adjusted her schedule to avoid a certain hallway, that was simply logistics. Nothing more.

Room ninety-eight did not exist for her.

Natasha checked in regularly, always under some professional pretext or another — a question about scheduling, a clarification about a case, a casual “while I’ve got you” in passing. Agatha appreciated the concern, even as she bristled against it. She didn’t want to be handled gently. She didn’t want the careful phrasing or the sympathetic looks that crept into conversations when people thought she might break.

She wasn’t fragile.

What she wanted was normalcy. Distance. Time.

The sooner Evanora was discharged, the better.

And, to her credit, Lilia stayed away from the hospital exactly as promised. No surprise visits. No pointed comments delivered in sharp tones. Agatha suspected it wasn’t from lack of temptation — but from respect.

Things in life were… good for Agatha.

The realisation still caught her off guard sometimes, arriving quietly in the middle of ordinary moments — pouring coffee, walking through the hospital corridors, waking up tangled in Rio’s sheets — and leaving her briefly disoriented. Good was not a state she had ever trusted for long. But lately, it seemed to hold.

And it was almost entirely because of the people around her.

She’d grown closer to Jen and Alice in a way that felt accidental but inevitable, the kind of intimacy that came from proximity and shared routines rather than grand gestures. Between Agatha staying over at Rio’s most nights and Jen crashing at Alice’s more often than not, they’d fallen into an easy rhythm — late-night takeout, half-watched movies, arguments over music, and the quiet solidarity of people who saw each other at their worst and didn’t flinch.

It was… strange. Comforting. A little surreal.

Wanda hovered at the edges of it all, and Agatha knew exactly why. Natasha’s influence was obvious — the subtle check-ins, the casual “how are you holding up” slipped into conversation like it was nothing. 

But Wanda never pushed. She didn’t prod or psychoanalyse. She gave Agatha space, met her sharp banter with dry, perfectly timed comebacks, and stayed when things got quiet instead of filling the silence.
For the first time in her life, Agatha had friends.

Real ones. Not colleagues. Not people bound by convenience or obligation. People who chose her.

And then there was Rio.

Rio, who slept warm and solid beside her, who made space for her without ever making her feel like a burden. Who noticed without interrogating. Who loved her with an ease that still made Agatha’s chest ache in disbelief.

Agatha thanked the universe every morning she woke up next to her — not dramatically, not aloud, but with a quiet, reverent gratitude that settled deep in her bones. Other than Lilia, no one had ever made Agatha their first choice. Their priority. Their person.

Rio did it without hesitation.
Without conditions.
Without asking Agatha to be anything other than exactly who she was.

“Dr. Harkness, Debbie Jenkins was admitted again.”

Teen’s voice cut cleanly through Agatha’s thoughts, sharp enough to pull her fully back into the present. She looked up from the chart she’d been half-staring at, blinking once as her mind recalibrated.

Agatha exhaled slowly. “Shit,” she muttered. “Again?”
 She straightened. “Symptoms?”

Teen fell into step beside her as they started down the corridor, tablet already in hand. “Severe abdominal pain, intermittent but escalating. Nausea, vomiting. She’s had episodes of dizziness, occasional shortness of breath, tachycardia without a clear trigger. Low-grade fevers that come and go.” He scrolled as he spoke. “Labs are clean. CT, MRI, ultrasound — all unremarkable. Autoimmune panel negative. Infectious disease cleared her. Cardiology cleared her.”

Agatha frowned. “And yet she looks like hell every time she comes in.”

“Exactly,” Teen said. “She’s not faking it.”

“I know,” Agatha replied without hesitation.

They moved briskly, Agatha’s mind already working through possibilities — rare conditions, atypical presentations, things that slipped through diagnostic cracks because medicine didn’t like uncertainty. 

Patients like Debbie Jenkins haunted her. People who were clearly, undeniably ill but didn’t fit neatly into any algorithm.

They reached the room and paused briefly outside the door.

“Let me lead,” Agatha said quietly. “Watch her baseline. Watch what she doesn’t say. She's spreading herself too thin.”

Teen nodded.

Perched beside her was a little girl no older than three.

Her daughter Gabby.

She sat cross-legged on the bed, clutching a stuffed rabbit that had clearly seen better days, babbling happily to no one in particular as she bounced the toy against the mattress. She looked utterly unconcerned by IV poles and monitors, delighting instead in the echo her voice made in the room.

Gabby stared at her solemnly for half a second before offering, “Teddy,” and holding the toy up like an introduction.

“My family doesn’t speak to me anymore,” Debbie continued quietly. “They’re very religious. Having a baby out of wedlock was… unforgivable.” Her mouth tightened. “And her father left when I told him I was pregnant. So it’s just us.”

The words landed heavier than they should have.

Agatha nodded once, professional but warm. “Let’s focus on you. We’ll take care of the rest.”

She slipped back into work mode easily, the familiar focus settling over her as she reviewed Debbie’s vitals and lab history. She adjusted the IV rate, tapped notes into the chart, and rattled off additional tests — repeats, targeted panels, a few less obvious studies that required persistence rather than protocol.

“I’ll go put these in,” he said, already turning toward the door.

She met his eyes, a deliberate pause stretching just long enough to make him nervous. “I have a special job for you today.”

His face lit up instantly. “Seriously?” he breathed. “Oh my god, thank you. I won’t let you do—”

Agatha smiled, entirely innocent.

By the end of it she looked utterly spent, eyes glassy with exhaustion, voice hoarse from answering the same questions again and again. Agatha had promised her a break, pain management, and answers — even if those answers took time.

She scanned the ER floor out of habit.

Monitors beeped steadily. A trauma bay curtain swayed as someone passed behind it. At one of the beds, Teen stood hunched over a grown man, carefully suturing a small cut on his finger. The man was whimpering theatrically, clutching his hand like he’d narrowly survived an amputation.

Three stitches. Maybe.

Agatha did not see Gabby.

The blood drained from her face so quickly it made her dizzy.

She forced herself to keep moving, expression smoothing into professional neutrality as she approached. She gave the patient a polite, tight smile. “Almost done,” she said evenly, resisting the urge to roll her eyes at the volume of his complaints.

Then she turned her attention to Teen.

“Dr. Caplan,” she said calmly. “A moment, please.”

Teen flinched.

He finished the suture with hurried precision, murmured something apologetic to the patient, and straightened. The tension in his shoulders was immediate and unmistakable. Teen swallowed. “I— I’m sorry, Dr. Harkness. The ER got slammed, and I was technically free so I thought—”

Agatha’s face went pale in a way that had nothing to do with anger and everything to do with fear.

“William,” she said quietly.

That made his eyes widen. She almost never used his real name.

“Where. Is. She?”

Before he could answer — before he could even stutter an excuse — a small, high-pitched squeal echoed through the ER.

And stopped dead.

She grinned.

Agatha dropped into a crouch in front of her, her expression softening instinctively. “Mommy’s very tired right now,” she said gently, “so she’s getting some rest. But”—she lowered her voice conspiratorially—“I did tell Santa that you’ve been a very good girl while Mommy’s been resting.”

She winked.

“It’s okay,” Rio said easily, waving it off. “Don’t worry about it.” She looked down at Gabby with a grin. “We were just about to go get something to eat anyway, right?”

Gabby nodded enthusiastically, already scanning the hallway for whatever adventure came next.

Rio looked back at Agatha, eyes warm and inviting. “Wanna join us? I hear the cafeteria’s doing macaroni today.”

She said it like it was the most enticing offer in the world.

Agatha huffed a laugh, shaking her head. God help her — if Rio was there, she’d probably eat anything.


They ended up in the cafeteria, tucked into a corner table away from most of the noise. “You’re really good with her,” Agatha said quietly.

Rio glanced up, a faint blush creeping into her cheeks. “She’s easy,” she said with a soft laugh. “You should meet Steve and Peggy’s kids sometime. Absolute chaos. Feral, the lot of them.”

Agatha smiled, but her gaze lingered on Rio — on the way she leaned in close, patient and warm, on how Gabby clearly trusted her without question.

Her thoughts drifted, uninvited and heavy.

She wondered, not for the first time, what Rio would have been like with Nicky. What that might have looked like — mornings, bedtime stories, scraped knees soothed by steady hands. She wondered who she herself might have been if things had gone differently. If Nicky had lived. If she’d followed through with adoption.

And then the thought twisted further.

If he had survived… would she have ever left Boston? Would she have rebuilt herself here? Would she have met Rio at all?

“You okay?”

Rio’s voice cut gently through the spiral.

Agatha blinked, realising she’d gone still, fork hovering uselessly in her hand. She shook her head slightly, grounding herself. “Yeah. Sorry. Just… thinking.”

Rio studied her for a moment longer, concern flickering across her face — then softening. She always knew. It was uncanny sometimes, the way she seemed to read Agatha without needing words.

She didn’t push. Didn’t demand explanations.

She just reached out, brushing her fingers briefly against Agatha’s hand — a silent reminder that she was here, that this moment was real, and that Agatha didn’t have to carry every thought alone.

Just as they were finishing up, a daycare worker Agatha had spoken to earlier approached their table, a little out of breath, apologetic already written across her face.

“Dr. Harkness, I’m so sorry for the delay,” she said. “I tried to free up space sooner, but one of the nurses was stuck in surgery and couldn’t pick up their little one until later. I can take Gabby down now, if you still need me to?”

She softened the last part, crouching slightly, her tone bright and inviting as she directed it toward Gabby.

Agatha nodded. Out of the corner of her eye, she caught the brief flicker on Rio’s face — disappointment, gone almost as quickly as it appeared — before Rio schooled her expression into something warm and encouraging when Gabby turned to her, clearly seeking approval.

“That sounds fun, right, Gabs?” Rio said easily, pitching her voice light, reassuring. “You’ll get to hang out with some friends.”

That was all it took. Gabby beamed, hopped down from the chair, and slipped her small hand into the daycare worker’s without hesitation.

Rio watched them go with a soft, lingering smile.

Agatha watched Rio.

There was something achingly tender about her like this — hands tucked into the pocket of her hoodie, shoulders relaxed, eyes following Gabby until she disappeared around the corner. It wasn’t performative. It wasn’t effortful. It was instinctive, quiet, and deeply grounding.

Agatha’s chest tightened.

God, she loved her. Fiercely. In a way that startled her anew every day. Everything about Rio, her steadiness, her warmth, the way she showed up without ever being asked made Agatha fall harder, deeper, more irrevocably.

And then the thought hit her.

Not gentle. Not abstract.

A sharp, visceral flash of complete want.

The sudden, overwhelming image of herself pregnant, of Rio putting a baby into her, fucking her so hard that they miraculously conceived a baby of their own. With tanned skin, brown eyes and Agatha’s mane of curly hair. 

Agatha’s breath hitched.

Her body reacted before her mind could catch up.

Rio spun instantly, concern snapping into place. “You okay, mi amor?”

Agatha grabbed her water, downing it far too quickly, eyes wide, pulse racing. She cleared her throat, face flushed hot with shock and something dangerously close to desire.

“Yep,” she said too fast. “Yeah. Totally fine. Just—wrong pipe.”

Rio eyed her, suspicious but smiling. “You sure?”

Agatha nodded emphatically. “Absolutely. Never better.”

Rio laughed, shaking her head, and turned back toward the exit.

Agatha sat there for a beat longer, staring down at her tray, heart still pounding.

Where the fuck did that come from?

She didn’t have an answer.

“I should probably head back,” Rio said casually, already leaning in to press a soft, familiar kiss to Agatha’s lips. “You coming over later?”

“Um— yeah,” Agatha replied, blinking once as her brain caught up. “I’ve got a couple of things to finish up first.”

“Alright,” Rio said easily. “I’ll see you back home then.”

She leaned in again, stealing another gentle kiss before stepping away.

It struck Agatha, not for the first time, how little she reacted to it now. The same woman who used to bristle at even the suggestion of public affection — especially at work, of all places — hadn’t hesitated for a second. Rio had done that to her. Somewhere along the way, the instinct to flinch had disappeared. 

Agatha no longer cared who saw when Rio showed her love, or when Agatha accepted it openly.

She watched Rio walk away down the corridor, waving at familiar faces, completely at ease.

And then the thought she’d been avoiding crept back in.

The thought landed with equal parts disbelief and alarm.
