But seeing Rio with Gabby had cracked something open. Something instinctive. Something deep and undeniably real.

Agatha exhaled slowly, rubbing a hand over her face.

Jesus, she thought. What the fuck is wrong with me?

Whatever it was, she knew one thing for certain.

She didn’t hate it.

 


When Agatha eventually walked into Rio’s apartment after her shift, she stopped just inside the door.

The lights were low, warm rather than dim, and the slow, unmistakable hum of Sade’s By Your Side drifted through the space, wrapping the room in something intimate and unhurried.

Rio was in the kitchen, fresh from the shower, hair twisted into a messy knot that left her neck bare and still damp. She wore a loose tank top and boxers, the fabric clinging in places it had no right to. The hem of the tank rode up as she worked the cork free from a bottle of red wine, exposing toned stomach and the sharp, elegant cut of her hip bones. Her arms were faintly flushed from the heat of the water, muscles relaxed but powerful, familiar and devastating all at once.

For a split second, she wasn’t here.

She was back in the cafeteria, watching Rio with Gabby — watching the ease with which Rio stepped into care and patience and quiet joy, like it had always belonged to her. And then the thought surged up again, uninvited and overwhelming.

Rio giving her a family.

Not just loving her. Not just staying. But something deeper, more physical and irrevocable — Rio knocking her up, binding their lives together in a way that couldn’t be undone, a future written into Agatha’s body as surely as into her heart.

The intensity of it made her dizzy.

“Hey,” she said, setting the bottle down. “You’re home.”

That was it.

Hard.

Chapter 29

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The snowfall over the past few days had been heavy and unyielding, blanketing roads faster than the town could keep up. Plows struggled to keep secondary streets clear, black ice forming in deceptive patches overnight. Rio had barely seen a structure fire lately- instead, her shifts were filled with car stalls and spin-outs, drivers stranded on shoulders with frozen engines and white-knuckled fear. Tow trucks were backed up for hours. Everyone was tired and cold.

Inside the ER, it showed.

Slips and falls filled the board. Wrist fractures, concussions, torn ligaments from missed steps on icy sidewalks. Elderly patients brought in bundled in coats still dusted with snow, apologising for taking up space. It was the kind of winter that wore people down quietly, piling small emergencies on top of one another until everything felt precarious.

By the time Christmas Eve arrived, the snow had blocked most main roads and most people were confined to their homes. Unless of course, you worked for emergency services. 

Agatha had told Rio and Lilia days earlier that she had volunteered for the double shift, carrying her through the night and into Christmas evening. Rio was also scheduled to work, neither of them particularly surprised by it, and both quietly relieved to have purpose threaded through a day that still carried complicated edges.

Lilia had insisted on one thing.

Dinner. The day after Christmas. No arguments.

She framed it as a new tradition, as something special to mark the day, her eyes bright with meaning. Agatha, to her own surprise, had not bristled. The resentment that once clung to the season had loosened its grip, softened by love, and the thought of sitting down at Lilia’s table no longer filled her with dread.

It filled her with something close to gratitude.

When Agatha clocked in that morning, she did not head for the board or the nurses’ station first.

She went straight to Debbie.

Debbie had been admitted over a week ago now, and the decline had been gradual but unmistakable. Each day seemed to take a little more from her. By Christmas Eve, she struggled to sit upright without assistance, her limbs heavy and uncooperative. Even lifting her arms long enough to wrap them around Gabby often left her breathless.

Gabby had began to notice.

She hovered closer now, quieter, her small hands clutching at her mother’s sleeve as if afraid that letting go might make something worse. Debbie tried to smile for her, tried to be strong, but the effort showed in the tremor of her hands and the way exhaustion settled into her bones.

By the third day after her being admitted, social services had begun to circle.

Agatha intercepted them personally.

The suggestion of a temporary foster placement was framed as protocol, as procedure. Reasonable, even. Agatha heard the words and felt something cold and familiar settle in her chest. She remembered Nicky. Remembered the reports, the visits, the quiet devastation of watching a child passed from place to place under the guise of care.

She would not allow it to happen again.

Debbie, pale and shaking, spent what little strength she had left begging Agatha to keep her baby safe. The desperation in her voice was raw and unmistakable.

Agatha listened.

Then she acted.

Under strict conditions, all carefully documented and defensible, Gabby was placed in the hospital’s day care between the hours of nine in the morning and six in the evening, with scheduled visits to Debbie woven throughout the day. There would be no sudden removals. No unnecessary separations. The foster parent who would take her in the evenings was interviewed by Agatha herself before approval was given, every detail scrutinised.

The justification was clinical.

Any additional stress, Agatha argued, posed a significant risk to Debbie’s already fragile health.

It was irrefutable.

Debbie looked at her like she had hung the moon.

Like she was something close to an angel.

Agatha, standing at the foot of the bed, felt the familiar ache of grief and resolve twist together in her chest. She was not doing this to be kind.

She was doing it because she saw a mother who wanted to fight for her daughter.

Rio had become a familiar presence in the hospital in a way no one had quite anticipated.

On days when her lunch break stretched long enough, or when she had time to spare before a night shift, she would skid through the snow in her truck and slip through the side entrance headed straight for the daycare. She never made a fuss about it. No grand announcements. Just a quiet check-in at the desk and a grin that had the staff waving her through without question.

Gabby spotted her every time.

“Riiiii-oooo!” she would squeal, abandoning whatever puzzle or crayon she’d been given, barreling toward her with uncoordinated enthusiasm.

Rio always met her at eye level, dropping into a crouch with her arms wide open. “There she is,” she’d laugh, catching Gabby mid-run and scooping her up just long enough to spin her once before setting her back down. “What’s up, tiny human?”

High fives and fist bumps were mandatory each time. On particularly energetic days, Gabby insisted on jumping into Rio’s arms so she could be lifted up high, giggling uncontrollably while Rio exaggerated the effort, grunting theatrically.

“Whoa, you’re getting heavier,” Rio would say, earning an small gasp.

“I am not!” Gabby protested.

“Oh yeah?” Rio would grin. “Then how come my arms are this tired?”

The daycare staff watched fondly from the sidelines as Rio sprawled on the floor with Gabby, building block towers only to knock them down with dramatic sound effects, or sitting cross-legged while Gabby carefully applied stickers to Rio’s sleeves like medals of honour.

Before night shifts when Gabby had to go back to her foster placement, Rio would keep things quieter.

She’d sit with Gabby in a small reading nook, Gabby tucked against her side as Rio read picture books in exaggerated voices, making up sound effects that earned snorts of laughter. When Gabby’s attention drifted toward the hallway that led back to her mother’s room, Rio would gently redirect it.

“Hey,” she’d say softly, tapping the page. “What do you think happens next?”

It wasn’t about replacing anything. Rio knew that.

It was about distraction. About giving a three-year-old permission to laugh in a place that often swallowed joy whole. About making the hours feel lighter, even if just for a little while.

And every time Agatha passed the daycare and caught sight of Rio sitting on the floor, hair mussed, jacket discarded, Gabby perched proudly beside her, something warm and unsteady bloomed in her chest.

It wasn’t just that Rio was good with children.
It was that she showed up.
Every time.

As Agatha rounded the corner after checking in on Debbie, she slowed instinctively.

The tone of the voices ahead of her made something in her chest tighten. They were low, controlled, pitched deliberately so they wouldn’t carry. The kind of voices people used when they didn’t want to be overheard.

Natasha and Jen stood just outside the corridor that led to room ninety-eight.

Agatha stopped short, heart sinking.

“She’s demanding discharge,” Jen was saying quietly, irritation threaded with unease. “Tonight. Says we’re holding her against her will.” Jen scrubbed a hand over her face. “I’ve paged psych, but Chief… I have a horrible feeling, what do we do if they discharge her? Medically she’s stable enough, and mentally—” She shook her head. “She’s delusional but she’s very good at manipulating. And I don’t know what she’ll do in this state.”

Natasha’s expression was grave, jaw set in a way Agatha had learned meant she was already thinking several steps ahead. “I agree,” she said. “As soon as psych makes their evaluation, loop me in. If she discharges, I want it documented immediately.”

Jen swallowed. “And then?”

“Then I’ll alert the police,” Natasha said without hesitation. “Nothing dramatic. Just eyes open. Welfare checks if needed.” Her gaze flicked briefly down the corridor, toward the room they were both carefully avoiding naming. “We don’t take chances with someone like her. Get me her last known address.”

Agatha stood frozen just out of sight, every word landing like a weight in her stomach.

Discharge.

Tonight.

I don’t know what she’ll do in this state

Her fingers curled slowly at her sides, nails biting into her palms as she tried to steady her breathing. Evanora loose in the world again, unconfined, unmonitored, felt like the ground shifting beneath her feet.

She took a quiet step back before either of them could notice her, retreating the way she’d learned to as a child.

Silent. Careful.

Already bracing for possibility of Evanora no longer contained to room ninety-eight. 

 

 


Psych arrived with paperwork and calm voices, the kind designed to soothe without pronising anything.

The attending psychiatrist walked beside Natasha, tablet tucked against her chest, while Jen followed a half-step behind, jaw tight. An orderly waited with them as they made their way down the corridor toward room ninety-eight.

“After reviewing the case notes we’re recommending transfer,” the psychiatrist said quietly as they walked. “Inpatient psychiatric facility. Secure transport.”

Natasha nodded once, visibly relieved. “Approved.”

Jen let out a slow breath. “She’s been escalating. She’s been making comments, like she’s in another time one minute then here the next.”

“That seems consistent with your assessment,” the psychiatrist replied. “She’s lucid enough to argue, but not enough to self-regulate. There’s fixation, emotional regression, and increasing hostility when she feels challenged.”

“And the cognitive decline?” Natasha asked.

“Most likely early Alzheimer’s,” the psychiatrist confirmed. “Memory fragmentation. Confabulation. But I still want to see her to confirm your casenotes Dr Kale. If she is as threatening as you stated in fluctuation, I will need to implement certain security measures. Someone like this can be very deceiving when they’re lucid. ”

Jen swallowed. “Which makes her unpredictable.”

“Yes,” the psychiatrist said simply. “And dangerous.”

They reached the door.

The orderly stepped forward and pushed it open.

The room was empty.

The bed was stripped down to a flat sheet. The IV pole stood abandoned, tubing coiled loosely where it had been disconnected. The heart monitor was dark. Evanora’s coat was gone.

For a moment, no one spoke.

Jen was the first to move, stepping fully inside and scanning the room like she expected Evanora to be hiding behind the curtain. “What the fuck?” she muttered.

Natasha’s expression hardened instantly. “When was she last seen?”

The orderly checked the hallway, then his pager. “She was documented in bed less than twenty minutes ago.”

The psychiatrist’s face drained of colour. “She shouldn’t have been left alone.”

Jen’s stomach dropped. “I gave her a sedative.”

Natasha was already pulling out her phone. “Lock down the unit. Security now.”

“She could be anywhere,” the psychiatrist said, voice tight.

Natasha looked back at the empty bed, the abandoned IV line swaying slightly in the disturbed air.

“I dont think she planned to leave the hospital,” Natasha said quietly.

Jen’s blood went cold, her gaze snapping to Natasha. “Agatha.”

The psychiatrist swallowed. “We have to find her.”

Silence slammed down between them.

Natasha didn’t hesitate. “Hospital-wide alert. Missing patient. I want eyes on every exit, every stairwell, every unit.”

Jen felt her pulse thunder in her ears. “God.”

Evanora Harkness was no longer contained to room ninety-eight.

 


Agatha was adjusting Debbie’s IV when the daycare worker knocked softly and stepped inside.

“Hi Debbie,” she said gently. “I’m here to take Gabby back downstairs.”

Debbie frowned, confusion flickering across her tired face. “Oh… she already went.”

Agatha stilled.

“Went?” she repeated carefully. “Went where?”

Debbie shifted against the pillows, clearly uneasy now that she was saying it out loud. “A woman from the hospital came to get her. She said there’d been a delay and that Gabby should’ve been downstairs already.”

Agatha’s fingers tightened around the bedrail. “What woman?”

“Older,” Debbie said slowly. “Grey hair. Very stiff. She had a badge clipped to her coat.” Debbie hesitated, then added, “She didn’t seem happy about being here.”

The daycare worker exchanged a look with Agatha. “Did she say anything else?”

Debbie swallowed. “She said, ‘Children make everybody late.’” Debbie’s brow furrowed. “She said it like it was… a rule. Like she was annoyed it needed explaining.”

The room went still.

Agatha felt the words hit her square in the chest.

Children make everybody late.

Evanora’s voice echoed in her head with horrifying clarity, precise and cutting, the kind of sentence delivered as judgment rather than observation.

She could see it. Evanora standing by the door when Agatha was small, coat already on, keys in hand, eyes sharp with irritation.

‘Children make everybody late’.
 You are an inconvenience Agatha.

Agatha’s breath left her in a quiet rush. Her vision blurred at the edges as her body reacted before her mind could catch up. 

No. It wasn’t possible. 

“That’s all she said?” Agatha asked, her voice carefully neutral.

Debbie nodded. “She whispered something to Gabby, I…I couldn't make it out but it sounded like she called her a name. It sounded like… Agatha? I’m sorry Dr Harkness, I was so tired I could have just imagined it..”

The words barely left Debbie’s mouth when Agatha’s phone vibrated violently against her hip.

Once.

 Then again.

The sound felt deafening in the quiet room.

Agatha pulled it out with fingers that suddenly felt numb. Her eyes skimmed the notification, and the world seemed to tilt beneath her feet.

HOSPITAL ALERT: CODE GREY. LOCKDOWN. MISSING PATIENT.  ALL STAFF REMAIN VIGILANT. REPORT SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY IMMEDIATELY.

Her breath left her in a sharp, silent rush.

There it was.

Confirmation.

Evanora.

Agatha’s hand tightened around the phone until her knuckles ached. Her heart was pounding so hard she could feel it in her throat, each beat louder than the last.

“She had a badge,” Debbie said weakly, watching Agatha’s face with dawning fear. “She said she worked here.”

Agatha looked up slowly.

Her expression had changed completely.

“I have to report this,” she said, voice low and deadly calm. “Don’t worry Debbie, everything will be alright.”

The daycare worker nodded immediately, already reaching for the door. Debbie’s eyes widened as tears began to fall and her breathing quickened. 

“Dr Harkness,” Debbie whispered. “What’s happening? Where is my daughter?”

Agatha didn’t answer.

She was already moving, already calling security, already running through floor plans in her head. 

Stairwells. Exits. Elevators. Blind spots.

She had to find her. 

Find them both.

As she rounded the corner just outside the ER, she saw Natasha mid-conversation with two security guards. Their postures were tight, shoulders squared, voices low but urgent.

Natasha looked up.

The moment her eyes met Agatha’s, the colour drained from her face.

“Is it her?” Agatha shouted, the words tearing out of her before she could stop them. She didn’t slow down. Didn’t lower her voice. “Is it Evanora?”

“Yes,” Natasha said quickly, hands lifting in a reflexive attempt to calm her. “But listen to me. The hospital is in lockdown. Security has confirmed she hasn’t left the building. We will find her.”

Agatha let out a sharp, broken laugh that held no humour at all. “She kidnapped my patient’s child, Nat.”

Natasha froze.

“What?” she said, the word barely audible.

“She impersonated daycare staff,” Agatha snapped, rage and terror colliding in her chest. “She took a three-year-old girl and walked her out of a patient’s room like she belonged to her. No one knows where she took her.”

For a split second, Natasha looked genuinely shaken.

“Oh my God.”

She turned sharply to the security guards still standing there, their expressions pale now, the weight of it finally landing.

“Notify the police,” Natasha ordered, voice iron-hard. “Now! This is a child abduction.”

One of the guards was already moving, hand to his radio.

Agatha exhaled, the breath unsteady, panic written plainly across her features as she raked a hand through her hair and turned in a slow circle, the corridor suddenly too long, too quiet.

Where are you, Evanora?

Chapter End Notes

Sorry for the lack up updates and shortness of this chapter, I'll be honest, motivation has been pretty low this past week.

I have parts of the next few chapters written but I'm not sure when I'll be able to update again but thank you for reading and commenting each time 🖤

If you have followed this story so far then I thank you with all my heart.

Chapter 30

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

“Agatha, I need you to go to the attending locker rooms and stay there until I tell you to come out,” Natasha said firmly.

Agatha stared at her like she’d misheard.

“Are you insane?” she snapped, the words tearing out of her as panic finally broke through whatever restraint she’d been clinging to. “I’m not sitting on my ass while that psycho has Gabby.”

Her heart was hammering now, loud enough she could feel it in her throat. Every instinct in her body was screaming move, find her, do something. Standing still felt impossible and wrong.

“Agatha,” Natasha said, lowering her voice, forcing calm into every syllable, “we will find her. The police are on their way. Security is sweeping the building.”

Agatha shook her head, fury and terror tangling in her chest until she couldn’t tell one from the other. Images kept flashing through her mind unbidden- Gabby’s small hand in someone else’s grip, Evanora’s voice dripping with contempt, that phrase echoing like a bruise.

Children make everybody late.

“The last thing I need,” Natasha continued, just as evenly, “is Evanora getting her claws into you too.”

That landed harder than Agatha expected.

Because it was true.

Because some small, traitorous part of her knew that if Evanora saw her now—raw, exposed, desperate—it would be like blood in the water.

Wanda jogged up then, breathless, eyes wide with alarm. “What’s going on?” she asked quickly. 
“Someone said a child is missing too?”

Natasha closed her eyes briefly and rubbed at her temple, the strain finally cracking through her composed exterior. “Yes,” she said quietly. “A three-year-old. And it’s connected.”

Agatha swallowed, her throat tight, her hands trembling at her sides. She hated this. Hated being sidelined. Hated that the one time she wanted to act, to protect, to stay and fight, she was being told to step back.

“Please,” Natasha said again, this time softer, almost raw. She met Agatha’s eyes. “Just… please. Stay in the staff room until we’ve secured her. I can’t do this if I’m also worrying about you too.”

For a moment, Agatha looked like she might argue anyway. Her jaw clenched. Her shoulders were rigid, every line of her body screaming defiance.

Then she turned sharply on her heel.

“I’m not hiding,” she said flatly as she stalked toward the staff room. “I’m waiting.”

The distinction mattered to her, even if no one else heard it.


The door to the staff room shut behind her with a dull, final thud.

Agatha ripped her white coat off like it was strangling her, the weight of it suddenly unbearable. She flung it to the floor without looking and collapsed into one of the padded chairs, the vinyl creaking under her. Her elbows came down hard on her knees as she buried her face in her hands, fingers threading into her hair and gripping tight at the roots like she could anchor herself there.

She squeezed her eyes shut.

You can’t just sit here.

The thought pulsed in time with her heartbeat, loud and insistent. The room felt too small, too still, like it was mocking her. Every second stretched thin and sharp.

Gabby needed her.

The image of the little girl’s face rose unbidden, all wide eyes and unfiltered trust, the way she’d wrapped her arms around her mother’s neck earlier that day. Agatha’s chest constricted painfully.

Debbie couldn’t do anything in the state she was in. Too weak to sit up, too exhausted to fight, trapped in a hospital bed while someone else walked away with her child.

And Agatha was here.

Waiting.

Useless.

Her breath stuttered as anger surged, hot and bitter. She pushed her palms harder into her eyes, as if pressure alone could force the panic back into order.

She had to do something.

Standing still went against everything she was. She had built her entire life around action, around fixing, cutting, saving. Doing was how she survived. Doing was how she stayed ahead of the fear.

And Evanora—
Agatha’s jaw clenched.

She knew firsthand how cruel her mother could be. Not the loud, chaotic cruelty people expected, but the quiet, precise kind. Words chosen to cut. Neglect disguised as indifference. Punishment delivered with a smile.

And now Evanora was sick. Confused. Slipping.

The thought chilled her more than anything else.

If that cruelty had survived intact while everything else fractured… if Evanora’s mind was blurring past and present, mistaking a child for the daughter she’d once discarded…

Agatha’s stomach twisted.

She pressed her forehead to her knees and drew in a shaky breath.

I will not let her do this again.

Not to another child.

Not on her watch.

Agatha made it exactly five minutes.

Five long, miserable minutes of staring at the same scuffed tile, of listening to the hum of the vents and the distant echo of raised voices down the hall, before the need to move became unbearable.

She pushed up out of the chair and crossed the room in three strides, easing the door open just enough to peer into the corridor. Her pulse spiked immediately, instinct flaring. She scanned left, then right.

No Natasha.

Good.

She was just about to slip out when the sound of hurried footsteps and sharp voices carried toward her. Agatha froze. Without thinking, she pulled the door almost shut again, leaving it open the barest crack.

“This just keeps getting better, fuck,” Natasha snapped as she strode down the corridor, her voice tight with frustration. Agatha could hear the anger underneath it now, the strain finally bleeding through the professional calm.

Wanda hurried alongside her, breathless. “Babe, slow down. What now?”

Agatha leaned closer to the door, heart hammering.

“Security just called,” Natasha said, dragging a hand through her hair. “The police are struggling to get here because of the fucking snow. Roads are a mess. They’re stuck.”

Agatha’s stomach dropped.

Of course they were. She pictured the roads outside, buried under weeks of snowfall, cars stalled, sirens muted by snowfall and ice.

Wanda reached out suddenly, grabbing Natasha by the arm and pulling her to a stop. The abruptness of it startled Agatha, even through the crack in the door.

“Nat. Look at me,” Wanda said firmly.

Agatha watched as Wanda cupped Natasha’s face with both hands, grounding her the way Agatha knew Rio would have done. Natasha’s shoulders were rigid, her jaw clenched so tightly it looked like it hurt.

“You need to calm down,” Wanda continued, softer now but no less steady. “Panicking won’t help. Take a breath. Think. What do we do?”

Natasha took a steadying breath, leaning into Wanda’s touch as if drawing strength from it. When she spoke again, her voice was calmer, more controlled.

“We split up,” she said. “We know this hospital better than anyone. I’ve left Kale in charge of the ER. Security is sweeping the basement levels first. You take the paeds wing. I’ll search the surgical floor.” Her jaw tightened. “She can’t have gone far.”

Wanda’s mouth curved into a small, resolute smile. She nodded and began to turn away, already shifting into motion beforeNatasha caught her by the waist, pulling her back without hesitation.

The kiss was brief but unmistakable. A silent promise pressed into a single moment.
Agatha’s eyes widened behind the door. She’d known, of course. Everyone had. But seeing it actually happen was different.

Natasha rested her forehead against Wanda’s for a heartbeat.

“Thank you,” she murmured.

Then she was gone, turning sharply and striding down the corridor toward the surgical floor, every inch of her all business again.

Wanda stayed where she was for just a second longer, watching Natasha disappear around the corner. 
Then she straightened, squared her shoulders, and headed toward the paeds wing.

Once both of them disappeared in opposite directions down the corridor, Agatha waited.

She counted her breaths. One. Two. Three.

Then she slipped out of the staff room, closing the door behind her with deliberate care. Her senses sharpened instantly, every sound magnified, every flicker of movement registering as potential threat. She stayed close to the walls, moving with the quiet efficiency of someone who knew exactly how to exist unnoticed in hostile spaces.

Now she knew the search pattern.

Basement. Paeds. Surgical.

Which meant there were places no one was looking.

Her jaw set.

Agatha turned toward the stairwell and took it two steps at a time, heart pounding, lungs burning as she climbed toward the radiology floor. Her thoughts narrowed, laser-focused as she realised this wasn’t panic anymore. This was instinct. The same instinct that guided her hands in surgery, that told her when something was wrong before the monitors ever did.

Halfway up the next flight, she slowed.

Something was wrong.

She reached the landing and stopped dead.

At the top of the stairs leading higher, just barely visible against the dull concrete, was a small arm of plush fur, limp and unmistakable.

Agatha’s breath caught.

She climbed the remaining steps slowly now, dread coiling tighter with every movement, until the object came fully into view.

Teddy.

The stuffed bear Gabby never went anywhere without. The one she’d proudly introduced to Agatha on their first meeting, held up like a sacred thing. The bear’s button eye stared back at her, one ear bent, abandoned on the stairwell like a breadcrumb.

Agatha crouched and picked it up with shaking hands.

Her chest constricted violently.

She looked up.

The stairwell didn’t continue past the next landing.

There was no floor above radiology.

Only the roof.

“Oh God,” she whispered.

Adrenaline flooded her system, cold and electric. Every fear she’d been holding back slammed into place with brutal clarity.

Agatha surged to her feet and sprinted up the final flight of stairs, Teddy clenched tight in her fist, the echo of her footsteps pounding like a countdown.

Because she knew.

This was worse than she first thought.

And she was done being afraid.

 

 


Rio hadn’t thought much of the callout at first. Snow-related assists had become routine over the last few weeks, the firehouse working in tandem with the local plow crews as storms stacked on top of storms and the roads grew more treacherous by the day. Stalled patrol cars. Jackknifed sedans. The quiet, unglamorous work of winter.

She was used to it.

Still, as she climbed into the fire truck, tugging her gloves on and settling into the familiar hum of the engine, her thoughts drifted easily and instinctively to Agatha. They always did when her hands were busy and her mind had room to wander.

She wondered how Agatha was holding up on shift. Whether she’d eaten. Whether she’d remembered to sleep. Whether she had time to visit Gabby that day.

“So, Vidal,” Bucky called from the driver’s seat, the snow plow at the front of the truck clanking softly as he pulled out of the fire house. “You and Doc spending the day together tomorrow?”

Rio smiled without meaning to, the kind that started somewhere in her chest and spread outward. It was automatic now, unguarded. The guys had noticed months ago. Teased her relentlessly at first. Then, when it became clear this wasn’t just a fling, they’d stopped.

“Nah,” Rio said easily. “She’s working tomorrow. Double shift.”

She felt a familiar flicker of pride mixed with worry. Agatha never did anything halfway. It was part of what Rio loved about her, even when it scared her a little.

“But,” Rio added, glancing out the window as snow drifted past, “we’ll do our own thing on the twenty-sixth.”

Tony perked up immediately from the passenger seat, eyebrows waggling. “Oh, I bet you will.”

Rio leaned forward and smacked the back of his head without hesitation. “Shut up, Stark.”

Tony laughed, rubbing at the spot. “Hey, watch the hair.”

“I meant,” Rio said, grinning now despite herself, “we’re going to Lilia’s for dinner. A very normal, very wholesome dinner.”

Bucky snorted as he eased the truck into gear. “Sure it is.”

It didn’t take long to find the stranded patrol cars. They hadn’t made it far from the station at all, two cruisers half-buried in snow at the edge of the road, hazard lights blinking uselessly against the white.

Rio jumped down from the truck as soon as it rolled to a stop, boots crunching hard into packed snow. 

Tony was already grabbing the cable, and together they moved on instinct, muscle memory taking over as they worked to secure the first patrol car to the back of the engine. Ahead of them, Bucky was manoeuvring the truck, lining it up to plow a clean path forward.

“Hey, Jimmy,” Tony called out with a grin as he approached Deputy Jimmy Woo, cable slung over his shoulder. “Need a hand, or you wanna sit there and enjoy the weather?”

“Fuck off, Stark, and move it,” Jimmy shot back, though there was no real heat in it. His gaze shifted. 
“Hey, Rio.”

“Hey, Jimmy,” Rio replied easily, crouching to help Tony fasten the cable. “How’s Mrs. Woo?”

Jimmy snorted. “Pissed I’m out here on Christmas Eve, no doubt. I was five minutes from clocking off when we got the call from the hospital.”

Rio stilled.

“What?” she asked, straightening slowly.

Jimmy shrugged, tapping snow from his gloves. “Some wacko patient from Westview General went AWOL. Kidnapped a little girl.”

The words hit Rio like a punch to the chest.

Her breath caught, sharp and sudden.

“Hey, Woo, less chatting, more driving!” another officer yelled from the second cruiser, still stuck farther back.

Tony finished securing the cable and gestured for Jimmy to get back in the car. “All set. Hop in.”

“Wait,” Rio said, her voice cutting through the noise.

She followed Jimmy to the driver’s side, her heart already racing. “What was the patient’s name?”

Jimmy paused, frowning slightly as he climbed into the seat. He typed into the computer mounted on the dash, the glow reflecting faintly off the windshield.

“Uh… Evanora Harkness,” he said. “And the kid’s Gabriella Jenkins. Why?”

The world tilted.

Rio felt the blood drain from her face so fast she had to brace herself against the door.

“Buckle your seatbelt, Jimmy,” she said flatly.

“What—?” he started.

She shut the door firmly before he could finish and turned on her heel, sprinting back toward the fire truck. She hauled herself into the cab, hands shaking as she slammed the door shut.

“Bucky,” she said, already yanking her seatbelt on, “get us to the hospital. Now.”

Bucky stared at her, confused. “Rio, what—”

“MOVE. GO!” she shouted, voice cracking like a whip.

That snapped him out of it.

“Jesus—okay, okay!” Bucky swore, slamming his foot on the gas. The engine roared to life as the truck lurched forward, snow spraying up around them. In the side mirror, Rio saw the patrol car finally ease free of the embankment, still tethered behind them.

“BUCKY!” Tony shouted from the road, hands thrown in the air as his figure shrank rapidly in the distance. “What the fuck, man?”

Rio didn’t look back.

All she could see was Agatha’s face.

And all she could think was that somewhere in that hospital, Gabby was alone with the worst person Agatha had ever known.

She fumbled with her phone, nearly dropping it as the truck jolted over uneven ice. She dialled Agatha’s contact, thumb hovering anxiously as the call rang out, each tone stretching longer than the last.

“Come on, baby,” she muttered under her breath, voice tight. “Answer the damn phone.”

No answer.

Her knee bounced uncontrollably as she tried again, eyes fixed on the road ahead even though she wasn’t the one driving.

“You wanna tell me what the hell’s going on?” Bucky asked, knuckles white on the steering wheel as the fire truck barrelled toward the hospital, Jimmy’s patrol car fishtailing behind them on the cable.

Rio swallowed hard. “Agatha’s mother,” she said finally. “She took a kid from the hospital.”

Bucky’s expression darkened instantly. “Jesus.”

 

At the same time—
Agatha slowed as she reached the door leading up to the rooftop, heart pounding so hard it drowned out everything else. Instinctively, she patted down her scrub pockets, already forming the words she needed to say to Natasha.

Nothing.

Her hands stilled.

She checked again. Thigh pocket. Waistband. Chest.

Nothing.

Her stomach dropped.

“Shit,” she whispered, panic flaring as the realisation hit. Her phone was still in her white coat. The coat she’d torn off and left crumpled on the staff room floor.

She closed her eyes for half a second, forced herself to breathe, then pushed the door open anyway.

 

Chapter End Notes

Lets go Agatha!!!

Chapter 31

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The rooftop door creaked as Agatha pushed it open.

Cold air rushed in immediately, sharp and biting, carrying the faint hiss of falling snow and the distant hum of the town below. The roof lights cast long, harsh shadows across the concrete, turning every vent and railing into something vaguely threatening.

“Gabby?” Agatha called, keeping her voice low, controlled. Not wanting to startle. Not wanting to provoke.

Her heart was hammering so hard it felt like it might bruise her ribs.

She scanned the roof quickly. HVAC units. A maintenance shed. Snow piled unevenly along the edges. No small footprints that she could see immediately, but the wind was already covering the ground again, erasing evidence as fast as it appeared.

“Evanora,” she said next, more firmly.

Silence.

Agatha moved forward slowly, Teddy clutched in her hand like a talisman, the cold wind chilling her bare arms. Every instinct she had was screaming now, her body buzzing with adrenaline, fear sharpening her senses into something almost painful.

Then she heard it.

A small, sniffling sound. Soft. Unmistakably childlike.

Agatha froze.

“Gabby,” she said again, gentler now. “It’s okay. I’m right here.”

She followed the sound toward the far corner of the roof, near the low wall that overlooked the street below. And that’s when she saw her.

Gabby was sitting on the ground, knees pulled up to her chest, small hands fisted into her jacket. Snow clung to her curls and the shoulders of her coat. Her face was blotchy with tears.

And standing over her—
Evanora.

She looked smaller than Agatha remembered, bundled in an oversized coat that swallowed her frame, her hair wild and unkempt. But her eyes were sharp. Focused in the wrong way.

In her right hand, she held something that made Agatha’s breath stop entirely.

A No.10 blade scalpel.

It caught the rooftop light as Evanora shifted, the blade glinting dully, her fingers wrapped around it with careless familiarity.

“Stand up,” Evanora said without turning around. “You always slouch. Always making a fool out of me.”

Agatha’s blood ran cold.

“Evanora,” she said carefully, each word measured. “Step away from her.”

Evanora turned then, her expression shifting, confusion flickering briefly across her face before settling into something disturbingly familiar.

She looked at Gabby.

Then at Agatha.

Her lips curled, not quite a smile. Not quite a sneer.

“I know you,” Evanora said slowly. Then, suspicion crept into her voice. “Who are you?”

Agatha forced a steady breath into her lungs, even as her pulse roared in her ears. “It’s me, Evanora,” she said gently. “Agatha. Your daughter.”

Evanora’s brow furrowed. Her gaze flicked sharply to Gabby, then back to Agatha, as if she were trying to line two mismatched pictures up in her mind. The confusion was visible now, creeping in around the edges of her expression, unsettling and volatile.

Then she laughed.

It was short. Harsh. Cutting.

“Don’t lie to me,” Evanora snapped. “You people always lie.” She lifted the scalpel slightly, the blade glinting as she punctuated each word. “You think I don’t recognise your interference? You’re from social services, aren’t you? Always sniffing around. Always trying to take what isn’t yours.”

Agatha’s stomach twisted.

Without breaking eye contact, Evanora reached back and grabbed a long metal pole leaning against the maintenance shed. With a sudden, alarming burst of strength, she rammed it through the handles of the rooftop door, jamming it tight. The metal rang out sharply as it wedged into place, echoing across the roof.

Agatha felt her heart drop straight through her chest.

The door wasn’t opening now.

Not from either side.

“There,” Evanora said, breath coming fast, eyes bright with something close to triumph. “Now you can’t run off and spread your lies to the world.” Her gaze snapped back to Gabby, possessive and sharp.

“This is between me and my daughter.”

Agatha swallowed hard, fighting the urge to lunge forward and grab Gabby outright. She could see it now, the fracture in Evanora’s mind, past and present bleeding together.

“She’s not me,” Agatha said, voice steady through sheer force of will. “She’s a little girl. And she’s scared.”

Evanora frowned, eyes narrowing as if the world wasn’t aligning the way it should. “She’s always scared,” she said. “She’s always been a coward!”

Agatha took one slow step closer.

“You’re hurting her,” she said quietly. “And you don’t want to do that.”

For a moment, something wavered in Evanora’s expression.

And far below—

Sirens.

The sound cut through the cold air like a blade.

Evanora jerked toward the edge of the roof, peering down as flashing red and blue lights spilled across the snow-covered street. A fire truck crawled into view, hauling a police cruiser behind it, lights strobing wildly against the surrounding buildings.

Her breath hitched.

She spun back toward Agatha, fury igniting across her features. “You!” she screamed, arm snapping up as she pointed the scalpel straight at her. “You called the police!”

Gabby’s sobs escalated instantly, the sirens and shouting overwhelming her. She cried harder now, small hands shielding her ears, body shaking.

Agatha lifted her hands slowly, palms open, forcing herself to stay calm even as fear clawed up her spine.

“No,” she said firmly. “Evanora, listen to me. I didn’t call anyone.”

Even as the words left her mouth, Agatha could feel how thin the line was beneath her feet. One wrong tone, one hint of accusation, and everything could fracture. She forced her shoulders to stay relaxed, forced her breath to slow, even as her pulse thundered in her ears.

Evanora didn’t lower the blade.

Agatha felt the flash of terror then, sharp and bright. Not for herself. For the way the scalpel trembled in Evanora’s hand, for how close Gabby was to her, for how easily this could tip into something irreversible. 

She took a careful step forward instead, keeping her movements deliberate and as non-threatening as possible.

Every instinct screamed at her to grab Gabby and run. To end this by force. But she knew better. She had lived through Evanora’s cruelty once already. She knew how the woman reacted when she felt challenged or cornered. Fear made Evanora vicious. Control made her reckless.

“You’re not well,” Agatha continued, her voice steady despite the storm raging inside her. “And that little girl is not your daughter. Her name is Gabriella Jenkins. She’s three years old. Her mother—Debbie—is my patient. And right now, she’s terrified.”

She watched Evanora closely as she spoke, cataloguing every flicker of reaction the way she would a patient on the brink. The tightening jaw. The narrowing eyes. The way Evanora’s fingers flexed around the handle of the scalpel.

Evanora’s grip tightened.

Agatha felt her chest constrict painfully at the sight. She thought of Debbie, pale and helpless in a hospital bed, begging her to keep her baby safe. She thought of Gabby’s trust, the way she had reached for Agatha’s hand without hesitation earlier that day. She could not fail them.

“You took her from her mother,” Agatha said gently but clearly. “But this doesn’t have to get worse. It can end here.”

The words were chosen carefully. No blame. No condemnation. Just truth, wrapped in an offer of an exit.
She swallowed hard, shoving down the old rage, the years of hurt, the instinct to recoil. This wasn’t about her. It couldn’t be.

Not about the little girl she had been. Not about the scars Evanora had left behind. If she let any of that surface now, Evanora would sense it. Exploit it. Twist it.

“If you put the scalpel down,” Agatha said, “and let Gabby come with me, we’ll get you help. Real help. You don’t have to do this.”

As she said it, Agatha locked her gaze onto Gabby for just a second, letting the child see her calm, her certainty. A silent promise passed between them.

It's okay, I’ve got you.

 

 

 

 


The hospital loomed out of the snow as the fire truck rolled into the emergency bay, tires crunching hard against ice.

Rio barely registered the building at first. Her focus was on getting there, on movement, on the tight, coiled urgency that had been riding her chest since Jimmy said the names out loud. She jumped down from the cab before the truck fully stopped, boots hitting pavement, breath fogging sharply in front of her.

Then something tugged at her attention.

A ripple of motion at the edge of her vision.

Rio slowed, frowning, and followed the instinct upward.

At first, she saw nothing but the roofline swallowed in snowfall and grey light. Then she saw movement again. 

Her heart dropped.

Three figures could just be made out on the rooftop.

One impossibly small.

“No,” she whispered, dread detonating all at once. “No, no—”

She was already moving, panic sharpening every edge of her awareness. Natasha and two security guards burst through the ER doors at the same moment, radios crackling, faces tight with alarm.

“Fucking finally! We haven’t found them yet,” Natasha snapped to Jimmy as she rushed forward. “No sign on any floor—”

Rio didn’t hesitate.

“Nat, look,” she said, cutting in sharply, pointing up at the roof, her voice raw. “There’s people up there. That has to be them.”

Natasha followed her line of sight, her breath catching as her gaze snapped upward. Her expression blanched instantly.

“Security—move!” she barked.

The guards were already running, disappearing back inside toward the stairwells, boots pounding against tile.

Jimmy radio'd back to the station requesting more back up while Rio stood frozen for half a second, eyes locked on the roof, watching the figures shift against the snow. 

One of them moved too erratically. Too close to the edge.

Nats radio crackled.

“Chief, stairwell access is blocked,” a guard reported, breathless. “Rooftop door’s jammed. We can’t open it from inside.”

Rio exhaled sharply, something feral flashing through her chest.

“Shit.”

She spun toward Bucky, already knowing what she was going to say.

“Get me up there.”

Bucky stared at her. “Rio—”

“Now,” she snapped, already climbing onto the side of the truck and grabbing the ladder rungs. Her hands were steady despite the storm ripping through her chest. Snow stung her face as the ladder began to whine, metal shifting as it extended upward.

“Vidal!” Jimmy shouted, hurrying toward the truck, one hand raised. “Don't even think about it! You need to wait. We’ve got backup coming—this isn’t protocol.”

Rio shot him a look over her shoulder, eyes blazing.

“Fuck that!” she barked. “That’s my girlfriend up there. You can write me up later.”

“Rio—” Jimmy tried again.

Bucky didn’t even look at him. He swore under his breath and slammed his hand down on the controls. 

“Jesus, Vidal. Hold on.”

The ladder surged higher.


Back on the rooftop, Agatha’s concern sharpened into something close to panic.

Gabby had gone quiet.

The small, broken whimpers had faded, replaced by a frightening stillness. Her head lolled against her shoulder, eyes fluttering, lashes heavy with snow and exhaustion. The cold was sinking into her tiny body faster than Agatha could stop it.

No. No, no.

Agatha’s chest tightened painfully.

She was running out of time.

“Evanora,” Agatha said, voice cutting through the wind, “listen to me. That little girl is not your daughter.” She took another careful step forward. “I am. Your issue is with me, not her.”

“Stop lying!” Evanora shrieked, screwing her eyes shut as if the truth itself offended her.

Something in Agatha snapped.

“If I were lying,” Agatha shouted, her composure finally cracking, “then how would I know that for my tenth birthday you left me alone to go on a fucking date with the local pastor and didn’t come home for two days?”

Her voice broke, rage and grief colliding as tears burned behind her eyes.

“Or the time the school called because I was sick,” she went on, chest heaving now, “and you left me on the back porch in the rain to teach me a lesson for interrupting your day! I was seven years old!”

The words tore out of her, years of silence collapsing all at once.

Evanora’s eyes flew open.

She stared at Agatha, really looked at her, the confusion draining away as recognition finally locked into place. The moment stretched unbearably long.

Then Evanora’s mouth twisted into a familiar sneer.

“You’re still evil,” she said coldly. “Just like you were back then.”

Agatha laughed sharply, the sound broken and incredulous. “I’m not the one who kidnapped a little girl at knifepoint.”

“I was correcting a mistake!” Evanora barked, her voice rising as she took a slow step toward Agatha.

Another.

Her attention had shifted completely now. Gabby was no longer the focus. The child sagged limply against the wall, eyes slipping closed, fingers barely twitching.

All of Evanora’s fury was fixed on Agatha.

And Agatha understood with chilling clarity what that meant.

If she didn’t end this right now, Gabby wouldn’t make it.

Agatha moved without thinking.

She lunged, reaching for Evanora’s wrist, aiming to knock the scalpel from her grasp before she could register what was happening. For a split second, she almost had it.

Then Evanora reacted.

Faster than Agatha expected, the older woman twisted sharply, her free hand clamping down around Agatha’s forearm with surprising strength. At the same time, the hand holding the scalpel swung downward in a wild, reflexive arc.

Agatha felt the impact before the pain.

A sharp, tearing sensation flared just above her hip as the blade caught her side, slicing through the thin fabric of her scrubs. She gasped, breath hitching violently as she stumbled back, instinctively clutching at the wound.

Cold air hit exposed skin.

Agatha looked down in detached disbelief as small drops of red began to dot the snow at her feet, stark against the white.

Her mind snapped into motion immediately, the surgeon in her taking over even as her heart hammered.
Soft tissue, she assessed automatically. Shallow. Not arterial. Not deep enough to be catastrophic.

A flesh wound.

Painful. Bleeding.

But survivable.

She tightened her jaw, forcing herself upright despite the burn radiating through her side, eyes never leaving Evanora.

Because if she let herself focus on the pain for even a second—

Gabby would be lost.

“Agatha!”


The sound of Rio’s voice cut through the wind, raw and broken.

Agatha’s head snapped up just in time to see Rio vault from the ladder onto the roof, boots skidding slightly on the snow as she landed. For a split second, she looked feral—eyes wide, chest heaving, every line of her body pulled taut between terror and rage.

Evanora reacted instantly.

The moment Rio appeared, Evanora’s attention snapped back to Agatha, her face twisting with alarm and fury. She stepped closer, shoes slipping slightly in the snow, the scalpel lifting higher in her grip.

And then Rio saw it.

The dark stain spreading along Agatha’s side. The way her hand was pressed there, fingers slick, shoulders held rigid through sheer will.

Rio’s breath hitched violently, a strangled sound tearing out of her before she could stop it.

“Oh my god—”

Her gaze darted wildly, taking everything in at once- Evanora standing rigid and wild-eyed, the scalpel flashing in her hand, the metal pole jamming the door and the small red spots of blood on the snow beside Agatha.

“No,” Rio whispered. “No, no, no…”

She moved instinctively toward Agatha, panic overriding everything else—

“Rio.”

Agatha’s voice cut through it. Calm. Grounded. Commanding in a way that left no room for argument.

“Rio, I need you to take Gabby to safety right now,” Agatha said, each word measured despite the pain burning through her side. “She’s showing signs of hypothermia. She needs to get warm. Now.”

Rio’s head snapped toward Gabby, and whatever was left of her composure shattered at the sight.

The little girl was curled into herself on the snow, too still, her breath shallow and uneven. Her cheeks were pale beneath tear tracks already freezing cold.

“Oh—God,” Rio whispered.

She dropped to her knees immediately, heedless of the snow soaking through her pants, one gloved hand hovering over Gabby’s small shoulder before finally settling there. Even through layers, the cold of her body shocked her. She was freezing cold.

Rio moved without thinking about it.

Her jacket was off in seconds, shrugged from her shoulders and wrapped tightly around Gabby, cocooning her small frame, pressing every scrap of warmth she had into the child. She pulled Gabby close, tucking her chin protectively, rocking slightly as if that alone could fix this.

“I’ve got you,” she murmured desperately. “I’ve got you, sweetheart. Stay with me.”

She looked up then—back to Agatha.

Her eyes were shining, panic spilling over, her voice breaking around the truth she didn’t want to say.

“Agatha,” Rio whispered. “I can’t leave you here with her.”

The thought felt unbearable. Like being asked to tear herself in half and choose which part to abandon.

Agatha met her gaze.

Blood soaked through the side of her scrubs, dark and stark against the white, but her eyes were steady. Fierce. Anchored entirely on Rio.

“Rio, please,” Agatha said softly now, the edge gone from her voice. “She doesn’t have much time.”

The words landed like a physical blow.

“Leave her, with me.” Evanora sneered.

Rio’s throat closed. Tears blurred her vision as she looked down at Gabby, then back at Agatha—at the woman she loved, standing alone with a blade between her and safety.

For a long, agonising moment, she looked utterly torn—caught between instinct and duty, between Agatha and Gabby.

Then she swallowed hard.

Her jaw set.

She nodded once, sharp and decisive, even as tears spilled freely down her face.

“I’m coming back,” Rio said fiercely, the promise trembling but unbreakable. “I swear to you.”

Agatha gave her the faintest nod. Enough.

Rio’s gaze shifted then—just for a moment—from Agatha to Evanora.

The look in her eyes was no longer panicked.

It was cold.

Deliberate.

“You touch her again,” Rio said, her voice low and deadly over the wind, “and I will end you. I don’t care who the fuck you are, or what’s wrong with you. I will kill you.”

Evanora sneered, lifting the scalpel a fraction higher, but there was something uncertain in her eyes now. 

Something that recognised a predator.

Rio didn’t wait for a response.

She clutched Gabby close, pressing her face briefly into the child’s hair as if stealing strength from the moment. Then she backed toward the ladder, every step reluctant, every instinct screaming—
Her eyes never left Agatha.

Not for a second.

Even as she turned to descend, even as the ladder waited below, Rio watched her—burning the image into herself like a vow.

Hold on.

I’m coming back.

 

(Authors Note- I did consider leaving this here for another cliffhanger... but decided to show some mercy instead.)

 

 

 


“I always knew you had that perversion,” Evanora hissed, her voice sharp with disgust. “You were rotten from the start. Evil. I should have killed you the moment you left my body.”

Her eyes locked onto Agatha with frightening clarity, as if the fog in her mind had parted just enough to sharpen the blade of her tongue.

Agatha felt the words hit her like a physical blow. Her breath stuttered, pain flaring hot in her side, but something else burned hotter still.

“Well why didn’t you?” she cried, the words tearing out of her before she could stop them. “Why didn’t you just kill me back then and get it over with?”

The snow whipped between them, clinging to Agatha’s lashes, melting against her flushed skin. For a moment, the roof felt impossibly small. Trapped. Like her childhood all over again.

Evanora didn’t answer right away.

Instead, her mouth curled into a slow, wicked smile.

“I suppose I lacked imagination,” she said lightly. “But I’ve been given another chance now, haven’t I?”

 Her grip tightened around the scalpel. “To fix that mistake. To correct what I left behind with that… that woman.”

Her lip curled in pure venom.

“That witch Calderu.”

Something in Agatha snapped.

“Don’t you dare talk about her,” Agatha said, her voice shaking with fury. “Leaving me with Lilia was the only good thing ever did for me.”

Evanora laughed, a harsh, broken sound.

“She filled your head with nonsense,” she spat. “Made you weak. Made you think you deserved love.”

Agatha straightened despite the pain, despite the blood soaking through her scrubs, despite the fear clawing at her chest.

“She saved me,” Agatha said, each word steady and absolute. “She fed me. She held me. She taught me what love actually looks like. Everything good in me exists because you weren’t there to destroy it.”

Evanora’s smile faltered.

Just for a second.

Then her face hardened, eyes bright and unhinged.

“You were my biggest mistake” she said fiercely. “You always were.”

Agatha shook her head slowly, tears slipping free now, freezing cold against her skin.

“No,” she said. “I stopped being yours the day you walked away.”

The wind howled across the rooftop, sirens echoing faintly below, the city holding its breath.

Evanora took a step forward, scalpel catching the light.

Agatha didn’t retreat.

Not this time.

She planted her feet in the snow, heart pounding, mind razor-sharp despite the fear screaming through her veins.

“You don’t get to hurt anyone else,” Agatha said quietly. “Not me. Not Gabby. Not ever again.”

The ladder rattled against the edge of the roof.

Agatha heard it before she saw them, the metallic scrape followed by the thud of boots. She lifted her head just in time to see Rio haul herself up first, snow clinging to her navy t-shirt, breath coming fast and hard. 

Jimmy followed a second later, gun already drawn, boots skidding slightly as he cleared the ladder and took in the scene.

They were still too far away.

Evanora stood with the scalpel raised, her body angled possessively toward Agatha, eyes sharp and unblinking.

Rio froze for half a second before she moved slowly and carefully.

She kept her hands visible, palms open, her voice low and steady despite the violent pounding in her chest.

“This stops now,” Rio said. “You’ve done enough damage Evanora.”

Evanora’s head snapped toward her.

Good.

Rio took another step, then another, angling her body so she stood squarely in Evanora’s line of sight. She wasn’t charging or making any sudden movements. 

She was drawing attention, pulling it away from Agatha bit by but.

Jimmy stayed back, gun raised, trying to match Rio’s pace without escalating the situation.

“Ma’am,” he called, measured. “I need you to put the blade down. We’re here to help you.”

Evanora sneered, her gaze flicking briefly to the gun before locking back onto Rio.

“And who are you supposed to be?” she demanded.

Rio stopped walking.

She could sense Agatha behind her now, close enough to sense the subtle sway in her stance and the uneven rhythm of her breathing. Out of the corner of her eye, Rio caught the dark smear still spreading along Agatha’s side.

Too much blood.

Her chest tightened.

“I’m nobody,” Rio said evenly. “Just someone who wants to make sure nobody else gets hurt tonight.”

Evanora laughed, sharp and brittle.

“Another one,” she scoffed. “Always someone sticking their nose where it doesn’t belong.”

“Maybe,” Rio replied, taking another careful step, boots crunching softly in the snow. “But I’d rather die than let you anywhere near her again.”

Evanora hesitated.

Just for a fraction of a second.

Rio seized it by subtly positioning herself closer to Agatha, her body now almost fully between Evanora and the woman she loved. She didn’t touch Agatha yet, but she wanted to put as much of a barrier between her and Evanora as possible.

Jimmy swallowed and adjusted his grip on the gun. He looked nervous, but he held steady.

“Ma’am,” he said again, voice firmer now. “We can do this the easy way.”

Evanora’s attention flicked back to Agatha, then snapped to Rio as she noticed the movement.

“No,” Evanora hissed. “You stay where you are.”

Rio stopped instantly.

Hands still open.

“Okay,” she said softly. “I’ll stop.”

But her eyes never left the weapon in Evanora’s hand.

And her body stayed angled protectively toward Agatha.

Behind her, Agatha swallowed and forced herself upright as another wave of dizziness hit. She could feel the cold settling deeper now, the ache at her side burning and numb all at once.

Rio sensed the shift, her jaw tightening. 

“Agatha,” Rio said quietly, without turning. “Talk to me.”

“I’m here,” Agatha answered, though her voice wavered. “I’m okay”

Evanora smiled.

Cruel. Knowing.

“She’s fading,” Evanora said. “She’s weak.”

Rio’s eyes darkened.

She took one more step forward just asAgatha swayed.

Just once.

Then her knees buckled.

“Agatha—!”

Rio moved on pure instinct. She lunged, arms wrapping around Agatha’s torso just in time to keep her from hitting the ground. Agatha’s weight sagged fully into her, breath leaving her in a soft, broken sound as her head tipped forward.

“I’ve got you,” Rio murmured urgently, panic clawing up her throat as she tightened her grip. “I’ve got you, my love.”

Behind them, Evanora let out a sound that wasn’t quite human.

A roar of fury.

“No!” Evanora screamed, her face twisting with rage as she surged forward, scalpel raised high. “Leave her!”

Rio felt it before she saw it. The rush of air behind her. The sharp instinctive certainty that she was about to be hit. She shifted her body without thinking, turning just enough to shield Agatha, bracing for pain she never questioned taking while cradling Agatha in her arms. 

The gunshot cracked through the air.

Loud and Final.

Evanora jerked mid-step, the scalpel slipping from her fingers as her body arched violently. A choked sound tore from her throat before she crumpled forward, hitting the snow-covered concrete with a heavy, wet thud.

She groaned, clutching at her back, fury dissolving into shock and pain.

For a heartbeat, no one moved.

Then chaos exploded.

“Police! Don’t move!”

The rooftop door burst open as Bucky and Tony slammed through it, muscles straining as they forced the jammed pole aside. Two uniformed officers surged in behind them, weapons drawn, boots pounding against the snow covered concrete.

“Weapon down!” one officer shouted, though Evanora was already writhing on the ground, hands empty, breath ragged.

Jimmy lowered his gun slowly, hands shaking now that the moment had passed. His chest heaved as he stared at Evanora, disbelief and adrenaline written across his face.

“I—I had a clear shot,” he said hoarsely. “She was about to—”

“You did good,” Rio snapped at Jimmy, though her voice shook and she still couldn’t bring herself to look at him. 

Her entire world had narrowed to the woman sagging in her arms.

Agatha was conscious, but only just. Her skin was pale beneath the falling snow, her breath uneven and her pupils slightly unfocused. She blinked slowly, like the effort of keeping her eyes open cost her something.

Rio felt it immediately.

“Baby—,” Rio said, panic spilling over now, no longer contained. She dropped to her knees with her, arms tightening instinctively as if she could physically hold her together. Her hands trembled as they pressed at Agatha’s side, warm blood soaking through her gloves. “Hey. Hey, look at me. Stay with me. Please.”

Agatha winced, her head lolling slightly before she forced it upright again, stubborn even now. She squinted at Rio, trying to focus, her words coming out slow and slurred.

“Ri… you’re—” She swallowed. “You’re freaking out. It's fine”

Rio let out a broken laugh that sounded dangerously close to a sob. “Yeah,” she breathed. “Yeah, because you’re bleeding and pale and this is not fine.”

Agatha lifted a shaky hand, fingers brushing weakly against Rio’s t-shirt like she was grounding her instead.

“I’m okay,” Agatha murmured, the words thick on her tongue. “Just… dizzy. Lost a bit of blood. It could be worse.”

Rio shook her head violently, tears blurring her vision. “You do not get to say that right now. You do not get to downplay this.”

Agatha managed the faintest crooked smile. “Now who’s the bossy one?”

Rio pressed her forehead against Agatha’s, breath hitching, her voice dropping into something raw and pleading. “Don’t scare me like that. Don’t ever do that again.”

Agatha’s eyes fluttered but stayed open. “Still here,” she whispered. “Promise.”

Rio exhaled shakily, gripping her tighter. “Good,” she said fiercely. “Because I’m not letting you go.”

Natasha moved in with calm, decisive speed, her voice cutting cleanly through the chaos.

“Alright,” she said firmly, already shrugging out of her coat. “I’ve got her.”

Wanda, Kate, and Alice were their in an instant, the four of them moving with the kind of coordination that only came from years of shared emergencies. Wanda slid in at Agatha’s shoulders, Kate took her legs, Alice steadied her hips. The stretcher was already waiting, snow dusting the metal frame.

“Agatha,” Natasha said, dropping into Agatha’s line of sight, her tone gentler now. “We're here, we're going to move you onto the stretcher, okay?”

Agatha blinked, slow but present, her eyes finding Natasha’s face.

“I’m fine,” she slurred faintly, stubborn even now. “Just… dizzy.”

Natasha gave her a look that managed to be both fond and no-nonsense. “You’re bleeding and hypothermic. I’ll decide if you’re fine.”

They lifted her carefully, smoothly, lowering her onto the stretcher. Agatha hissed softly at the movement, fingers tightening reflexively in the fabric of Rio’s shirt.

Rio didn’t let go.

She clung to Agatha like the world would end if she loosened her grip, one hand fisted in Agatha’s sleeve, the other cupping her face. Tears streamed freely now, unchecked, her breath coming in broken pulls.

“I’m here,” Rio kept saying, over and over, like a mantra. “I’m right here mi amor. I’ve got you.”

“Rio,” Natasha said quietly, resting a steady hand on her arm. “We need to move her.”

Rio shook her head, lips trembling, panic raw and unfiltered. “I can’t—Nat, I can’t let go. Please.”

Agatha turned her head weakly on the pillow, eyes finding Rio through the blur. She lifted her hand with effort, fingers brushing Rio’s cheek, smearing tears with her thumb.

“Hey,” Agatha murmured, words thick but deliberate. “I’m… not going anywhere.”

Rio let out a strangled sound, pressing her forehead to Agatha’s for just a second before Natasha gently but firmly eased her back.

“You can walk with us,” Natasha said. “But you have to give them space to work.”

Reluctantly, shaking, Rio loosened her hold. Her hand lingered until the very last moment, fingertips trailing against Agatha’s wrist as the stretcher began to roll.

“I love you,” Rio said hoarsely.

Agatha’s mouth curved into the faintest smile, eyes never leaving her. “I know,” she whispered. “I can hear you crying from here.”

It wasn’t enough to make Rio laugh.

But it was enough to keep her moving, tears still falling as she followed close behind, refusing to be more than a step away as they rushed Agatha toward the stairwell and safety.

Chapter End Notes

That was fun right?

Right?

Chapter 32

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha would have liked to say she took the pain like a champ. That she didn’t flinch, didn’t curse, didn’t instinctively try to smack Jen’s hand away when the first stitch went in.

That would have been a lie.

They’d started with a local anaesthetic, Jen warning her gently before the needle went in. Agatha braced herself, jaw clenched, reminding herself she could handle this. She was a surgeon. She had done this to other people a thousand times over.

It was different when it was her.

The anaesthetic dulled the sharpest edge of the pain, but it didn’t erase it. There was still pressure. Still the awful awareness of tugging and pulling at skin that was already too tender. She inhaled sharply, fingers curling into the mattress.

Across from her, Rio went rigid.

She flinched at the sight of the needle, at the faint pull of thread, her shoulders tensing like she was bracing for impact. Her eyes were glossy, rimmed red, lashes clumped together where tears had gathered. 
She kept swallowing hard, jaw clenched tight, clearly trying to keep it together.

Agatha noticed it right away.

Rio wasn’t sobbing. She wasn’t making a scene. She was doing that thing she always did when she was scared out of her mind, standing too still, breathing too carefully, like if she didn’t move the world might not notice how close she was to breaking.

“Hey,” Agatha murmured, voice tight. “Why dont you go check on Gabby.”

Rio shook her head immediately, a sharp, almost angry motion. “I’m not leaving you again.”

Her voice wobbled despite the firmness of her words. She took a half step closer, hands hovering uselessly at her sides, fingers twitching like she was resisting the urge to grab Agatha and pull her away from all of it.

The room kept moving. Bodies in. Bodies out. Blood on gloves. A nurse stepped over something slick near the doorway.

Then Wanda appeared.

Agatha saw her through the haze—Wanda stopping short just inside the room. Saw the way her face drained of colour as her eyes landed on the blood soaked into Agatha’s scrubs. On the dried smear at her side. 

On Rio, openly breaking.

Wanda’s hand flew to her mouth. Her eyes flicked from Agatha to Rio and back again, horror dawning fast and sharp.

“Oh my God,” Wanda breathed.

The first stitch drew a broken sound from Agatha’s throat.

Rio sucked in a breath like she’d been punched. Her eyes filled instantly, tears spilling over despite her best efforts. She scrubbed at her face quickly, turning her head just enough to hide it, but Agatha caught the way her shoulders shook once, just once, before she forced them still again.

“Oh God,” Rio whispered, barely audible. “Cant you give her something for the pain?”

The second stitch made Agatha gasp despite herself. Rio’s breath hitched sharply, her hands curling into fists at her sides.

Agatha hated this part more than the pain.

She hated watching Rio worry.

“I’m okay,” Agatha said, though the words came out strained. She tried to soften her voice, to make it believable. “Look at me. I’m fine.”

Rio looked back at her then, eyes swimming, face tight with restraint. She nodded quickly, too quickly, like she was afraid if she didn’t agree she might fall apart completely.

“I know,” Rio said, voice thick. “I know you are.”

But she didn’t sound convinced.

By the third stitch, Agatha was gripping the edge of the gurney hard enough that her knuckles ached. Her breathing stuttered despite her best attempts to control it.

Natasha sighed, sharp and decisive. “That’s enough.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha protested automatically, the words slurring together.

Natasha didn’t look at her. “You’re getting morphine.”

Agatha barely registered the IV being adjusted before the world softened. The pain ebbed, sliding away into something distant and manageable. Her body grew warm and heavy, her thoughts slow and loose.

“Oh,” she murmured faintly. “That’s… better.”

Through the haze, she became aware of Rio again, closer now, her composure finally cracking. Rio’s tears fell freely, silent but unstoppable, her hand clutching the bed near Agatha’s shoulder like she needed something solid to hold onto.

Rio’s face was turned slightly away, like she was still trying to spare Agatha the sight of her breaking.
Agatha lifted her head a fraction, effortful.

“Hey,” she murmured softly. “Breathe.”

Rio’s breath shuddered. She turned back then, pressing her forehead gently against Agatha’s arm, tears soaking into the fabric.

“I almost lost you,” Rio whispered. “I can’t— I can’t lose you, mi amor.”

The words sank in slowly, settling somewhere deep in Agatha’s chest. Even through the haze, she understood this wasn’t just about tonight. It wasn’t just the blood, or the stitches, or the way everything had nearly gone wrong.

This fear was older than that.

Agatha smiled faintly, unfocused but sincere, and lifted her hand with effort, brushing her fingers along Rio’s cheek. 

“I’m not going anywhere,” she said quietly. “I promise.”

Rio’s breath broke, a soft, wrecked sound, and she leaned into the touch like she’d been holding herself together by force alone.

Agatha closed her eyes for a moment, thoughts drifting and sharpening all at once. She’d seen this kind of fear before. In her own fears. The way love turned fragile when too much of it had already been taken away.

She thought about Rio’s past experience of loss. Parents gone too soon. An abuela who had been everything, and then wasn’t.

 It sat there in Rio’s panic, in the way she clung to Agatha’s hand, the way her eyes tracked every flinch in her face.

Agatha’s thumb moved slowly, grounding them both.

“I’m still here,” she murmured, more for Rio than herself. “I’m not leaving.”

Rio nodded, small and shaky, pressing their joined hands to her lips. 

When Jen tied off the final stitch, she sat back and looked at Agatha properly for the first time. 

“Well,” she said, tugging off her gloves. “Not exactly a badass scar. But definitely a badass reputation.”

Agatha huffed a weak laugh.

Jen’s mouth twitched, then flattened again. “That was… brave. Going after her like that.” A beat. “And incredibly stupid, Harkness.”

Agatha smiled, slow and loose, the morphine finally settling in fully. “Aw, Jenny,” she murmured. “Don’t tell me you were worried about me.”

Jen scoffed immediately, like the word offended her. “Please. I was annoyed.”

She turned away to dispose of the sharps, shoulders tense.

“…when I heard you hurt.”

Agatha caught it anyway. The hesitation. The way Jen didn’t look back. She felt something warm bloom in her chest that had nothing to do with the drugs.

“Mmh,” Agatha said sleepily. “That sounds like concern.”

Jen shot her a glare over her shoulder. “As if.”

Rio let out a shaky breath that might have been a laugh, her hand tightening just slightly around Agatha’s.

Alice chose that moment to reappear, leaning against the doorway with a knowing look and a grin she didn’t even try to hide.

“Right,” she said casually. “That’s why you started tearing up the second Nat told you to prep for a stab wound. Specifically Agatha’s stab wound.”

Jen shot her a glare sharp enough to cut glass. “I did not.”

Alice just raised a brow.

Jen’s eyes went wide. She busied herself with gathering supplies that absolutely did not need gathering. 

“I’m… getting more saline,” she muttered, already halfway to the door.

Alice laughed softly as Jen made her escape.

Rio snorted, the sound surprised out of her, and she met Alice’s eyes. They shared a quiet, conspiratorial grin.

Natasha reentered a moment later, her expression all business but her tone gentler than before.

“The cops wanted to talk to both of you,” she said. “I told them now isn’t the time. They’ll be back later for statements.”

“Thank you, Nat,” Rio said, relief clear in her voice.

Natasha nodded, then turned her attention to Agatha, adjusting the IV with practiced ease. “I’m going to give you a little time to rest. You lost a fair amount of blood, so the fluids will help. Jen will be back shortly to check your levels. We’ll decide then if you need a transfusion, but for now I think we can avoid it.”

Agatha hummed faintly, eyes already drifting shut.

Natasha’s gaze softened for just a moment before she stepped back.
 “Try to sleep,” she said gently. “You’ve earned it.”

Agatha heard the door close. Felt the room settle.

Then the soft brush of Rio’s fingers against her forehead.

She cracked one eye open.

Rio was still there, still wrecked, her gaze fixed on the stitches at Agatha’s side like they might vanish if she watched closely enough.

“My love?” Agatha murmured.

Rio’s eyes snapped up to meet the one blue eye searching for her. Whatever fragile control she’d been holding onto shattered.

“I couldn’t protect you,” Rio said, the words tumbling out. “I— I thought… when I went down that ladder, I thought I’d never see you again.”

Her voice broke completely then, sobs racking her as the wall she’d kept upright since they’d entered the room finally collapsed.

Agatha opened both eyes now, vision still hazy with morphine, her body instinctively trying to move toward Rio despite the ache in her side. Every part of her wanted to reach out and soothe her.

She had never had someone care for her like this.

She’d known love from Lilia, steady and constant, shown in warm meals and safe spaces and quiet reassurance. But this—this raw, unguarded grief at the thought of losing her—was something else entirely.

Agatha had spent her life thinking of herself as self-contained. Singular. Someone whose absence would register, perhaps, but never devastate.

And yet here was Rio, breaking apart at the idea of a world without her.

The thought settled heavy and strange in Agatha’s chest.

For the first time, she understood that her existence mattered to someone in a way she had never allowed herself to imagine.

The irony wasn’t lost on her. For the past year, Agatha had kept her heart carefully guarded, afraid that if she let herself love Rio fully, she would only lose her.

Now here was that same woman—the one who had been unshakable in Agatha’s darkest moments—standing in front of her, breaking under the very same fear.

It struck Agatha with startling clarity that strength had never meant fearlessness.

It meant loving anyway.

And if Rio had carried her through despair with such patience and empathy, then Agatha would have to learn how to do the same. To meet her where she was. To hold her steady now, the way Rio had held her so many times before.

She owed her that.

But... Agatha was still Agatha. And not even a morphine-softened brain could stop the words from slipping out.

“You’re getting snot on me.”

For a split second, Rio froze—then her sobs broke apart into wet, breathless laughter. She scrubbed at her face, shaking her head as that familiar gap-toothed smile finally made its way back, the one Agatha had learned by heart, the one she found herself thinking about when she closed her eyes.

Agatha studied her through half-lidded eyes. The fear was still there, tucked beneath the surface, but it wasn’t swallowing her whole anymore. Agatha felt something steady settle in her own chest in response.

“Hey,” she murmured. “Come here.”

Rio hesitated, then leaned closer, careful of Agatha’s side, perching awkwardly on the edge of the bed. Agatha lifted her hand, slow and deliberate, and rested it over Rio’s heart.

It was racing.

“See?” Agatha said quietly. “Still here. Both of us.”

Rio swallowed, nodding, and covered Agatha’s hand with her own. Her pulse slowly began to steady beneath their palms.

Agatha’s eyes fluttered, exhaustion pulling her under again.

“I love you,” she murmured, barely louder than a breath.

Rio bent down and pressed a gentle kiss to Agatha’s forehead, lingering there.

“I love you too,” she whispered. “Sleep. I’ll be right here.”

And this time, when Agatha let her eyes close, she didn’t fight it.

 

 

 


When Agatha woke, it was to the sound of hushed voices.

She kept her eyes closed at first, not ready to let the light in, letting herself orient by sound alone. The room felt calmer than before. Quieter. The chaos had moved on without her.

“Just… please let her rest a little longer,” Rio murmured nearby. “She’s been through enough.”

“Rio,” Natasha said gently. “She needs to know.”

Needs to know what?

Agatha’s throat felt dry as sandpaper when she spoke. “Needs to know… what?”

Her voice came out rough, the effort of it pulling sharply at her side as she tried to sit up. She hissed under her breath, immediately regretting it.

Rio was there instantly, hands steady as she helped ease Agatha back into a better position. “Easy, carino,” she murmured.

Agatha lifted a hand, palm out, insisting she was fine despite the grimace she couldn’t quite hide.

Only then did she open her eyes.

Natasha and Wanda stood in the doorway. Their expressions were somber, heavy with the kind of news Agatha had delivered herself far too many times.

Her stomach sank.

“Debbie Jenkins passed away this morning,” Natasha said quietly.

The words settled into the room, final and irrevocable.

Agatha went still.

“Oh,” she said quietly.

It was the most she had in her.
