Rio’s hand tightened around hers. Agatha didn’t look at her yet. She could already feel the guilt forming, familiar and sharp, even before it found language.

“She wasn’t alone,” Wanda said gently. “Gabby was asleep beside her.”

That landed harder.

Agatha closed her eyes briefly. Catalogued the sensations out of habit—the hollow behind her ribs, the weight pressing down on her chest, the sharp pull of responsibility. She had intervened. She had delayed social services. She had hoped.

Hope was dangerous.

“When?” Agatha asked.

“Just after sunrise,” Natasha replied. “She went peacefully.”

Agatha nodded once. Accepted it. Peacefully was as much mercy as this world ever allowed.

A pause.

“And Gabby?” she asked, already bracing.

Rio’s breath caught. “She’s with child services for now. Temporary. They said she was very quiet.”

Agatha swallowed.

“She asked for you,” Rio added softly. “Both of us.”

Something in Agatha’s chest tightened painfully.

“I need to see her,” Agatha said.

Natasha hesitated. “Agatha—”

“I need to,” she repeated, steady now. Not as a surgeon. Not as a doctor. As something else entirely.

Rio met her eyes. She didn’t argue. Just nodded. “We will.”

Agatha leaned back against the pillow, exhaustion pressing in again, heavier than before. Her gaze drifted, unfocused, until it caught on something small taped to the wall across from her bed.

A crooked paper snowflake. 

A handwritten sign that read Merry Christmas in uneven marker.

Morning light filtered weakly through the window. 
Christmas morning.
Agatha closed her eyes.

And she hated Christmas again.

 

Chapter End Notes

Merry Christmas...

Chapter 33

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha’s usual instinct in moments like this was to disappear into work. To stay busy. To keep moving until the weight of it all dulled enough to be manageable.

With the current situation, she was unable to run. 

When the police arrived, they seemed to sense the heaviness in the room immediately, the grief that hadn’t yet settled but hung thick in the air. They approached carefully, keeping their voices low and notebooks already in hand.

“Miss Harkness,” one of them began, measured and formal. “I’m very sorry for the loss of your mother, Evanora Har—”

He didn’t get any further.

“That fucking cunt was not my mother,” Agatha snapped, the words cutting sharp and fast. “Dont waste your breath on condolences.”

The room went still.

Even Agatha was faintly surprised by the venom in her own voice but she didn’t take it back.

Some losses deserved mourning. Others didn’t.

By the time the officers finally left, offering a slightly too cheerful “Merry Christmas” on their way out, Agatha had reached the end of her patience.

“I need to get out of here,” she said flatly.

Before Rio could react, she tore the IV from her arm and swung her legs over the side of the bed. Pain flared immediately as the stitches pulled, sharp and punishing, and she sucked in a breath through her teeth.

Rio went pale. Her hands came up, hovering in front of her, caught between the instinct to stop Agatha and the fear of making things worse.

“Mi amor,” she said carefully, forcing calm into her voice. “Slow down. You’re still recovering.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha snapped. “I’m a doctor. I don’t need help.”

“Agatha, stop!”
Rio’s voice cut through the room, echoing off the walls.

Agatha froze instantly, one foot barely touching the floor, her breath catching in her chest. The pain in her side throbbed, her body reminding her all at once that she was injured, that she was tired, that she was not as steady as she wanted to be. For a split second, embarrassment flared hot and defensive, followed quickly by something more uncomfortable. Fear. Not of the injury, but of what would happen if she stopped moving and let everything catch up to her.

“You are not running from this,” Rio said, her voice lower now but no less firm. “You will lie back down and rest until Jen says you are cleared to go home.”

Agatha swallowed. Every instinct she had was screaming to push back, to reclaim control, to insist she was fine because that had always been safer than admitting she was not. If she kept moving, she would not have to feel the weight of Debbie’s death, or relive the events of last night.

She turned to look at Rio.

The trembling woman who had cried into her shoulder hours ago was gone. In her place stood someone solid and immovable, grief sharpened into resolve. Rio’s jaw was set, her eyes dark with determination and love, the kind that did not bend simply because Agatha wanted to disappear into motion.

“Please,” Rio said softly. “I know you’re upset, but you nee— I need you to rest.”

The last part came out barely above a whisper, like she was afraid asking too much might break something between them.

Agatha hesitated, the familiar urge to argue rising automatically. To insist she was fine. To insist she could keep going.

Instead, she sat back against the bed.

“Fine,” she said quietly. “But only because it’s you.”

Rio’s mouth curved into a sad, relieved smile. “Thank you.”

Only then did Agatha really look at her.

Rio looked exhausted in a way that went beyond physical fatigue. Her shoulders sagged now that the adrenaline had drained away. There were dark shadows beneath her eyes and her movements slower, less precise. It dawned on Agatha that Rio probably had not slept at all. Had been running on fear and love and stubborn determination for hours.

Rio pulled the chair closer again and sat, her hand returning to Agatha’s like it belonged there.

For a while, neither of them spoke. The room was quiet except for the steady beeping of a monitor and the distant sounds of a hospital settling into early morning.

Eventually, Rio’s grip loosened.

Her breathing evened out, deepened. Her head tipped forward slightly, then back, mouth falling open as sleep claimed her without ceremony. A soft snore escaped her, barely audible but unmistakable.

Agatha blinked, then smiled despite herself.

She turned her head to look at Rio properly, fondness swelling in her chest. This was new. Not being alone with her thoughts. Not spiralling unchecked. Rio was here now, anchoring her without even trying, simply by existing in the same space.

Life was different because of her.

Safer. Fuller. Harder in ways Agatha had never expected, because now there was someone who could pull her back from the edge.

But the guilt still lingered.

It sat heavy and insistent beneath the warmth. Debbie’s face. The undiagnosed symptoms. The chart Agatha had read and reread. The nagging sense that something had been there, buried in lab values or progress notes, something she had missed.

She closed her eyes briefly, then opened them again.

Carefully, quietly, Agatha slid her hand from Rio’s slack fingers. Rio did not stir, only snored softly again, completely out now. Agatha eased herself to the edge of the bed, moving slowly to avoid pulling at her stitches. Pain flared, but she welcomed it. It kept her focused.

She stood, steadying herself, and glanced back once more.

Rio slept on, vulnerable and trusting, utterly unaware.

Agatha’s chest tightened.

“I’ll be right back,” she murmured, though Rio could not hear her.

Then she slipped out of the room, sock clad and determined, already turning over Debbie Jenkins’ case in her mind as she headed toward the room she no longer occupied.

Because if she had missed something, Agatha needed to know.

She moved through the corridors with practiced ease, keeping her head down and her steps measured. The hospital was quieter now and it was easy enough to slip by without drawing attention. Her side ached with every step, but she ignored it. 

She reached the staff room without incident.

Inside, she changed quickly, peeling out of the torn, bloodstained scrubs and pulling on a clean set from her locker. The routine steadied her more than she cared to admit. When she turned, she spotted her white coat folded neatly over the back of a chair, exactly where someone must have left it for her.

Her phone was still in the pocket where she left it.

Agatha let out a quiet breath, slipped the coat on, and made her way towards where she knew she would be obsessing over medical notes for the next few hours.

 


When Rio woke and found Agatha gone, she didn’t panic.

She knew Agatha too well for that.

It was in her nature to look for answers, to chase certainty until her body or mind forced her to stop. Rest, for Agatha, only came after understanding. Rio also knew the guilt would be there already, heavy and insistent. The quiet belief that she should have seen something sooner. Done something differently. 

Saved Debbie.

Rio checked her watch and frowned slightly. Nearly three hours had passed.

She sighed as she stood, muscles stiff from the cramped, barely padded chair. Stretching carefully, she rolled her shoulders and headed out into the corridor, already knowing where she would find Agatha.

The hospital was unusually quiet. Christmas morning had thinned the foot traffic, and the snowfall outside had kept most visitors away. The halls felt hushed, almost deserted.

When Rio reached the floor where Debbie’s room had been, she spotted Wanda standing near the door, peering through the small window with a worried expression.

Wanda noticed her immediately and offered a sad smile.

“I came to get you earlier,” she said softly. “But Agatha asked me not to wake you.”

Rio nodded, understanding.

She stepped closer and looked through the window, expecting to see Agatha bent over charts, searching relentlessly for something she might have missed.

Instead, Agatha stood with her back to them, utterly still, staring out at the snowfall beyond the glass. The white outside fell endlessly, quiet and indifferent.

“Jen already checked on her,” Wanda added. “She’s medically fine to be up and about. She’s just been standing there for about twenty minutes.”

Rio watched her for a moment longer, her chest tightening.

That, she realised, was worse.

Rio had never seen Agatha like this.

Agatha was always in motion, always doing, always finding something to fix or outrun. Stillness did not suit her. The only time Rio had ever seen her truly at ease was when they were tangled together in bed, the world kept at a distance by shared warmth and quiet.

This was different.

“We’re snowed in,” Wanda said softly behind her. “If you manage to get her to move, come by the nurses’ station.”

Wanda squeezed Rio’s arm gently, her gaze flicking once more through the window to where Agatha stood unmoving, before she turned and walked away.

Rio waited until Wanda disappeared down the corridor before pushing the door open.

It creaked softly, the sound barely noticeable over the low hum of the hospital. Agatha didn’t turn. She stood exactly where Rio had seen her through the window, arms folded across her chest, shoulders squared, gaze fixed on the slow, relentless fall of snow outside.

For a moment, Rio stayed by the door.

Then she crossed the room and stopped beside her.

She didn’t speak. She didn’t reach out. She simply stood there, close enough that their sleeves brushed, sharing the same quiet.

Minutes passed that way.

Agatha finally exhaled, long and slow, as if she’d been holding her breath without realising it.

“Is Wanda gone?,” she asked softly.

Rio nodded, even though Agatha wasn’t looking at her. 

“You should have woke me up.” Rio said after a beat. 

“I needed you to sleep,” Agatha answered. “At least one of us should.”

Rio shifted closer. “You don’t have to do this alone.”

Agatha turned her head then, just enough to look at Rio from the corner of her eye. There was no sharpness in her expression now. Just fatigue. And something heavier.

“I know,” she said.

Rio swallowed. “Agatha… you did everything you could. I know you did.”

Agatha nodded immediately without hesitation.

“I know,” she repeated.

Rio blinked, surprised. “You do?”

“Yes.” Agatha’s gaze returned to the window. “Because there was nothing else to do.”

Silence settled again, denser this time.

“I went through her chart,” Agatha continued calmly. “Every note. Every lab. I wasn’t missing anything obvious. It was always there, just buried. A constellation of things that looked manageable on their own.”

Rio listened, heart heavy, eyes fixed on Agatha’s profile.

“She had an undiagnosed cardiomyopathy,” Agatha said. “Subtle. No family history flagged. Her heart muscle was gradually weakening, but not enough to trip alarms. The shortness of breath, the fatigue, even the arrhythmias could all be explained away by stress, infection, pain.”

Agatha swallowed once.

“Then her electrolytes crashed overnight. Potassium dropped just enough, calcium followed. That was the trigger. It pushed an already fragile heart into a lethal rhythm.”

Rio’s chest tightened.

“By the time it declared itself, it was catastrophic,” Agatha went on. “No warning signs you’d catch in time. No intervention that would have changed the outcome. Even if she’d been on telemetry. Even if I had been standing right there.”

She finally turned to Rio then, eyes steady, certain.

“It was fast,” she said quietly. “And it was unavoidable.”

The words were steady. Certain. Final.

Rio let out a breath she hadn’t realised she’d been holding. Relief and grief tangled painfully in her chest.

Agatha finally turned fully toward her.

“I needed to know that,” she said. “Not just for me but for Gabby.”

Rio reached out then, resting her hand against Agatha’s arm. “You didn’t fail her.”

Agatha covered Rio’s hand with her own. “No,” she said softly. “She died. Those aren’t the same thing.”
Rio leaned in, placing a soft kiss on Agatha’s shoulder, grounding them both.

“Come on, my love,” she murmured. “Let’s go home.”

Agatha let out a quiet scoff and gestured toward the window, where the snow continued to fall thick and unrelenting. “And how, exactly, do you propose we get home in that?”

Rio smiled, stepped closer, and wrapped her arms carefully around Agatha’s waist, mindful of the stitches. She buried her face briefly in Agatha’s hair, breathing her in.

“I can carry you,” she said simply. “I still have my snow boots on.”

That earned a soft, startled laugh from Agatha. She turned fully toward Rio, looping her arms around her shoulders, their foreheads brushing together.

“Show-off,” she murmured, the word fond, threaded with relief.

Rio’s grin turned mischievous.

Before Agatha could protest, Rio bent and carefully scooped her up, one arm firm beneath her knees, the other steady at her back.

“Rio!” Agatha yelped, laughter bubbling out of her as she instinctively clutched at Rio’s shoulders.

Rio smirked, rolling her tongue against her cheek like she was barely holding back a laugh. “Just doing my part to keep you off your feet, m’lady.”

Agatha shook her head, breathless and amused. “You’re a fool, Vidal.”

“Yeah,” Rio said easily, adjusting her grip, eyes warm. “But I’m your fool.”

Agatha’s smile softened.

She leaned in, careful of her side, and kissed Rio gently. It was unhurried and sweet, a quiet promise wrapped in warmth, before the heaviness of the day seeped back in.

Rio carried Agatha down the hall toward the nurses’ station like it was the most natural thing in the world, careful with her steps, unbothered by the attention they were drawing.

The nurses’ station was unusually lively. Jen, Alice, Wanda, Kate, and Natasha were all gathered around the desk, mid-laughter, the tension of the night before finally cracked just enough to let something lighter through.

They all looked up at once.

Jen’s eyebrow arched immediately, lips curling into a familiar smirk. “When I said limit movement,” she drawled, “this is exactly what I meant.”

Then she glanced at Alice. “Why don’t you ever lift me like that?”

The laughter came fast and loud.

Alice’s grin vanished as she looked from Jen to Rio, then down at herself, doing the math. She opened her mouth, shut it again, then huffed. “I’m not built for… whatever that is.”

Alice was at least a foot shorter than Jen, and while she was undeniably fit, the mental image of her attempting to hoist Jen bridal-style was absurd enough to make even Agatha snort.

Rio tightened her hold just slightly, grinning unabashedly. “For the record,” she said, “I offer this service selectively.”

“Isn’t your style more of an over-the-shoulder situation?” Kate said, tilting her head thoughtfully.

Wanda blinked. “What does that even mean?”

Kate grinned. “You know. Like—”

She didn’t finish the sentence. Instead, she stepped forward, hooked an arm around Alice’s legs, and hoisted her effortlessly over her shoulder.
“—this.”

Kate grunted with the effort, adjusting her grip.

The room erupted.

“Dude, what the fuck?” Alice groaned, now upside down, hair hanging toward the floor. “Why is everyone picking on me today?”

Jen laughed so hard she had to grab the desk for support. Agatha wheezed against Rio’s shoulder, and Rio just shook her head, smiling like she’d walked into the best possible version of chaos.

Kate patted Alice’s leg. “Purely educational.”

Rio eased Agatha down onto one of the chairs with exaggerated care, as if she were made of glass. Agatha barely had time to settle before Natasha leaned in, close enough that only she could hear.

“You should call Lilia,” Natasha murmured. “I told everyone to keep what happened last night quiet, but she’ll know something’s off. She always does.”

Agatha let out a soft sigh. She’d known this moment was coming. The missed calls had been sitting heavy in her pocket ever since she’d found her phone tucked safely in her coat, impossible to ignore forever.

“I know,” she said quietly.

Her gaze drifted back to the group, and despite herself, she smiled. Rio was now attempting something frankly unhinged, positioning herself between Wanda and Kate and testing the feasibility of lifting both of them at once, laughing as they protested.

Agatha shook her head fondly.

She nodded once to Natasha, then pulled her phone from her pocket and rose carefully, moving a few steps away to give herself some privacy. The laughter behind her followed, warm and alive, as she braced herself to make the call she’d been avoiding.

The call rang only once before Lilia’s voice came through the line.

“There you are, my girl,” she said warmly. “I was starting to worry. Are you all right?”

Agatha closed her eyes briefly at the sound of her. In the background, she could hear Sharon asking who was on the phone, followed by Lilia’s gentle but unmistakable hush. The faint clink of glass gave it away. 
They had already started on the festive drinks.

“Yes,” Agatha said. “I’m fine. I’m sorry I didn’t call sooner. Things have been a little… chaotic here.”

The pause on the other end was brief, but telling.

“Agatha,” Lilia said softly, the warmth sharpening into focus. “What happened, dear?”

Agatha took a steadying breath. There was no point easing into it. She told her everything. Evanora taking Gabby. The rooftop. The cold. Jimmy pulling the trigger… and Debbie.

She glossed over the stab wound, downplayed it deliberately, framing it as a superficial scratch rather than what it had been. She told herself it was kinder that way.

Even so, she could hear the change immediately. The background noise faded. The easy cadence of Lilia’s voice steadied, sobering as the weight of it all settled in. Agatha pictured her sitting down, glass set aside, listening with full attention now.

When Agatha finally finished, the line was quiet.

Too quiet.

And Agatha knew, with absolute certainty, that no matter how carefully she had edited the truth, Lilia had heard everything that mattered.

“Oh, Agatha,” Lilia said softly, the words wrapped in care. “I’m so sorry, sweetheart. Do you want me to come get you?”

Agatha closed her eyes for a moment, letting the warmth of the offer settle in her chest. It mattered, knowing she was wanted, that someone would drop everything to be there for her.

When she opened them again, her gaze found Rio.

She was moving through the nurses’ station with Wanda and Kate draped over her shoulders like trophies, laughing as the others doubled over, breathless with amusement. The sight was absurd and perfect all at once. Alive, loud…safe.

Agatha smiled, something soft and steady blooning in her chest.

Those were her people.
 And she was exactly where she was meant to be.

“No, thanks, Lils,” she said gently. “I’ll be all right.”

And for the first time, she knew it was true.

"Merry Christmas my girl"

"Merry Christmas mom."

Chapter End Notes

this was kinda rushed but wanted to post before the shut down tomorrow. Promise I'll have more on Gabby's situation updated in the next chapter ☺️

Chapter 34

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

It had been five days since Debbie passed away, and Agatha had already returned to work.

She’d ignored Lilia’s concern. Sidestepped Rio’s protests. Slipped back into the familiar rhythm of the hospital like it was muscle memory, because standing still had never been her strength. Work was easier than grief. Easier than thinking too long about the things she couldn't fix.

Gabby had been returned to the same temporary foster placement she’d stayed in while Debbie was hospitalised, and Agatha had done her best to push thoughts of the little girl to the back of her mind. It was simple enough, in theory. The placement was safe. Vetted. One Agatha herself had reviewed while Debbie was still alive. 

Gabby was cared for. Protected.

What more could she reasonably ask for?

What Agatha hadn’t anticipated was how hard it would be to watch Rio accept the same information.

When social services told them it would be best not to maintain contact for now, citing the trauma of the rooftop and the importance of letting Gabby “settle,” Rio had gone quiet in a way that felt worse than anger. She nodded. She listened. She agreed.

And then she sulked.

It wasn’t dramatic. Just a heaviness that followed her home. A sadness she didn’t bother trying to hide. Rio wore her heart openly, and the absence of Gabby had left a visible mark.

Agatha took the news hard too. She just swallowed it better.

Where Agatha buried the ache and kept moving, Rio carried it with her, every thought written plainly across her face. And watching that—watching Rio hurt over someone Agatha had tried so carefully not to think about—made it harder to pretend she’d left it all behind.

“I was thinking,” Wanda said lightly, leaning against the counter, “that we should all do the Witches’ Road for New Year’s. Now that you’re feeling better.”

Agatha barely looked up. She was hunched over a chart, pen moving steadily, chewing at her lip as she made another note in the margin.

“Nothing wild,” Wanda continued, undeterred. “Just a couple of drinks. Watch the ball drop. Pretend we’re normal people for a night.”

“Yeah, sure,” Agatha said absently.

Wanda paused.

She tilted her head, studying Agatha for a beat. “Wow. Careful. Your enthusiasm might knock someone over.”

Agatha blinked, realising too late that she’d answered on autopilot. She capped the pen and slid the chart back into the pile on the counter, forcing her shoulders to relax.

“Sorry,” she said, managing a small smile. “That actually does sound like fun. I think I could use the change of scenery to be honest.”

Wanda lifted an eyebrow, studying her. “Okay,” she said carefully. “What’s wrong?”

Agatha exhaled, the sound quiet but heavy. “I can’t stop thinking about her,” she admitted. “That little girl. Debbie was her whole world. And now…” She trailed off, jaw tightening. “Now she doesn’t have anyone.”

Wanda nodded slowly. “Didn’t she get placed with that foster family in Eastview? The one you found before Debbie passed?”

“Yes,” Agatha said. “But that was only meant to be temporary. Just until Debbie recovered.” She shook her head. “Now she’s there while they look for something more permanent, and I don’t have any say in where she ends up. No influence. No oversight.”

Wanda leaned back against the counter. “Have you asked about visiting her? Just to check in.”

Agatha’s mouth twisted. “Social services think seeing me would bring too much of that night back for her. Too many associations.” A beat. “And maybe they’re right.”

She hesitated, fingers tapping once against the chart in front of her.

“But something’s bothering me,” she added quietly. “I can’t shake the feeling that there’s more to this. Not medically. Just… instinctively.”

Wanda watched her for a long moment. “You trust those instincts for a reason.”

Agatha let out a faint, humourless breath. “Yeah. And they’re rarely this loud unless they want something from me.”

Wanda softened. “Or someone.”

Agatha didn’t respond right away.

Jen appeared behind Agatha just in time to catch the tail end of the conversation.

“Well, hello, lesbians,” she said brightly. “What petty gossip are we sharing today without me?”

Agatha shot her a withering look, then scoffed and turned on her heel, stalking off down the corridor without a word.

Behind her, Jen’s voice followed, genuinely confused. “What? What did I say?”

Wanda winced and shook her head. “Jen.”

“What?” Jen repeated, baffled. “That was inclusive.”

As Agatha rounded the corner into the emergency department, she scanned the board out of habit. Nothing critical. Teen was already helping a patient who’d slipped on the ice, demonstrating how to properly test weight-bearing with earnest concentration. The snow had finally begun to recede over the past few days, but black ice still plauged the sidewalks, catching people out when they least expected it.

“Dr. Harkness,” Yelena said, appearing at her side. “There’s a woman in reception asking to see you.”

Agatha frowned slightly. “Me? What’s wrong with her?”

“Other than the blue eyeshadow?” Yelena replied dryly. “Nothing obvious.”

She smirked and walked off before Agatha could ask another question.

Agatha huffed out a quiet laugh. Blue eyeshadow was a crime. Unless you were a clown. Or performing in community theatre.

As she approached reception, she spotted the woman immediately. Elderly, neatly dressed, with just enough pale blue eyeshadow to suggest effort rather than confidence. She was chewing her lip, hands folded tightly in front of her, posture tense with nerves.

Agatha softened her approach.

“I’m Dr. Harkness,” she said gently. “How can I help you?”

The woman looked up, relief flooding her features. “Oh, Dr. Harkness, thank you for seeing me. I know you must be terribly busy, being a doctor and all—”

Agatha waited, eyebrow lifting slightly when the rambling continued without direction.

“Oh—sorry,” the woman said quickly. “My name is Susan. My husband and I are fostering Gabriella Jenkins. Her mother was—”

“Is everything okay?” Agatha cut in, her pulse spiking. “Is Gabby all right?”

Susan’s eyes widened. “Oh goodness, yes. She’s fine. Physically, at least.” She hesitated, then sighed. 

“I’m actually here because, well,  she keeps asking about you.”

Agatha went very still.

“She cries for her mother,” Susan continued softly. “All the time. But she also says she misses you. And someone named Rio.” She gave a small, apologetic smile. “I knew Debbie was a patient here, and I thought… this seemed like the best place to start looking for a Dr. Harkness.”

The noise of the department seemed to fade around them.

Agatha swallowed hard, her chest tightening as Gabby’s face flashed in her mind. “She’s been asking for us?” she asked quietly.

Susan nodded. “Every day.”

And suddenly, the quiet nagging feeling Agatha had been carrying all week had a name.

“Yes,” she said quietly. “She knows us.”

Susan nodded, relief and worry tangled together in her expression. “That’s what I thought. She talks about you like you’re… safe.” She hesitated. “I wasn’t sure if that was appropriate, but she’s three. She doesn’t really understand why some people disappear and others don’t.”

Agatha closed her eyes for half a second, steadying herself. When she opened them again, her voice was controlled, professional, but there was something raw underneath it.

“Has she been having nightmares?” she asked.

Susan blinked, surprised. “Yes. She wakes up crying most nights.”

“And does she settle when someone stays with her?” Agatha continued.

“Yes,” Susan said slowly. “If I sit with her. Or if I tell her stories.”

Agatha nodded. That tracked. Gabby had usually needed presence more than words.

“I’m not here to cause trouble,” Susan added quickly. “Social services advised against contact, and I understand that. Truly. But I didn’t feel right ignoring her when she keeps asking. She asked me this morning if you were both mad at her.”

Agatha’s breath caught.

“No,” she said immediately, a note of fierceness slipping through. “Absolutely not.”

Susan’s shoulders eased a little. “I thought you might say that.”

Agatha glanced toward the emergency bay, then back at Susan. “Did you come alone?”

“Yes. My husband is with her.”

Agatha nodded once, decision crystallising even as her heart raced. “Okay. Thank you for coming to me. That was the right thing to do.”

Susan studied her carefully. “I don’t want to overstep. I just… I think she needs continuity. Something familiar.”

“So do I,” Agatha said before she could stop herself.

A beat passed. Then Susan smiled, small and hopeful and handed Agatha a piece of paper with an Eastview address scribbled down.

 “I think that would mean the world to her if you both came to visit.”

Agatha reached for the piece of paper then pulled out her phone from her pocket, fingers already moving on instinct.

“I'll arrange it with Rio now. And Susan?” she added.

“Yes?”

“Please tell Gabby that we both asked about her.” Her voice gentled despite herself. “And that she hasn’t been forgotten.”

Susan nodded, visibly moved. “I will.”

As she turned to leave, Agatha stood there for a moment longer, the noise of the emergency department rushing back in around her. Then she lifted the phone to her ear and made the one call she’d been trying not to make all week.

Rio answered on the second ring.

“Hey,” she said softly.

Agatha closed her eyes. “She’s been asking for us.”

The line went quiet.

Then Rio sucked in a sharp breath. She didn't need to ask who Agatha was referring to. “Is she okay?” she asked immediately. “What happened?”

The worry in her voice was unmistakable. They’d both been careful lately, skirting around Gabby’s name like it might shatter something fragile if spoken too often.

Agatha didn’t waste time. She told her about Susan. About the visit. About the way Gabby kept asking for them, how she cried for her mother but still looked for familiar faces.

“She misses us. I knew that fucking social worker was wrong, I had a gut feeling all week, I should have told her to go fuck herself.”

“Im sure they had their reasons.” Rio said, not unkindly.

A beat passed.

“So what do we do?” Rio asked, grounding herself the way she always did.

Agatha didn’t hesitate. “We go see her. Tonight. You’re still off at six, right?”

There was a pause. Then Rio tried, and failed, to sound casual. “Yeah! I mean—yes. That sounds good.”

Agatha smiled to herself as she ended the call, a quiet warmth settling in her chest. She was relieved at the thought of seeing Gabby again, but just as much at the sound of something lighter in Rio’s voice. Joy had crept back in, tentative but unmistakable, and it felt like a small victory.

By the time her shift finally ended, Agatha was practically sprinting out of the hospital. The cold hit her immediately, sharp and biting, and she had to steady herself when her heel skidded slightly on the icy tarmac on the way to her car.

She made it to the firehouse in record time.

The red engine was still parked neatly inside the bay, shutters half-lowered, and Agatha felt a flicker of relief. No late call-out. No delays.

She climbed out of her black Mercedes and followed the sound of voices upstairs to the living quarters.

The space looked exactly as she expected. Tony was sprawled across the couch, talking animatedly at Peter, who looked deeply unimpressed. Bucky and Steve were at the kitchen counter, cleaning up what was clearly the aftermath of dinner.

Steve noticed her first.

“Hey, Dr. Harkness,” he called easily. “Good to see you. How’re you feeling?”

Agatha smiled politely, opening her mouth to answer—
“Doc,” Tony cut in, already vaulting over the back of the couch, “you’re officially a badass. Come on, let’s see the war wound.”

“Fuck off, Stark,” Agatha said flatly. “Don’t be a creep.”

She didn’t have to move.

Rio appeared at her side instantly, stepping just slightly in front of her, body angled in a way that made her intent clear. Protective. Unyielding. Agatha could swear she almost heard her girlfriend growl in the process.

Hot.

Tony froze, then lifted both hands in surrender. “Hey, hey. I’m just saying, Vidal—your girl’s a hero.”

Rio didn’t soften, but Agatha felt her relax a fraction beside her.

“Yes well,” Agatha said dryly. “I prefer to stay a hero who is fully clothed thanks.”

That earned a laugh from Steve and Bucky in the kitchen.

Rio turned to face her fully, the edge in her posture melting away the moment her eyes met Agatha’s. A soft smile spread across her face, the familiar one she always wore when long days finally ended and they found their way back to each other.

“You ready to go?” Rio asked quietly.

Agatha smiled in return, the noise of the room falling away until it felt like it was just the two of them. 
She nodded once, sure and unguarded, and lifted her hand to cup Rio’s cheek, thumb brushing gently along her jaw.

Rio had a way of doing that to her. Making the world smaller. Making everything else feel less urgent.
For a moment, Agatha forgot about charts and foster placements and everything waiting beyond the doors.

She leaned in just enough to rest her forehead against Rio’s, breathing her in, grounding herself in the familiar warmth.

“More than ready,” Agatha murmured.

They were halfway to the door when Rio suddenly stopped. “Wait,” she said, already turning and jogging back into the firehouse.

Agatha watched, puzzled, as Rio disappeared and then reappeared moments later, something clutched carefully in her hands, her expression uncharacteristically shy.

Agatha’s breath caught.

“Teddy?” she asked softly. “Where on earth did you get that?”

It was Gabby’s stuffed bear. The same one she’d dropped on the rooftop in the chaos, small and forgotten in the aftermath.

Rio shifted her weight. “Tony grabbed it that night,” she admitted. “I had it cleaned. I was going to bring it to her, but then they said we shouldn’t see her, so I…” She trailed off, rubbing the back of her neck.

Agatha felt her chest tighten. She could see it now, how deeply that week had settled into Rio’s heart, how the little girl had carved out a space there without either of them noticing.

“She’s going to be so happy to have him back,” Agatha said gently.

Rio smiled, hopeful and a little nervous, clutching the bear like it was something precious.

The drive to Eastview passed too quickly.

Agatha kept one hand steady on the wheel, eyes on the road, while the other part of her attention stayed fixed on Rio.

Rio hadn’t stopped fidgeting with the stuffed bear since they’d pulled out of the firehouse lot. She smoothed Teddy’s fur, adjusted the bow at his neck, then did it all over again, her grip tightening and loosening like she couldn’t quite get comfortable.

Agatha reached over at the next red light, leaving one hand on the wheel as she threaded her fingers through Rio’s. She squeezed gently, grounding, familiar.

“Hey,” she said softly. “Relax, baby. She’s going to be happy to see you.”

Rio exhaled, but the tension didn’t fully leave her shoulders. “What if she’s upset we took so long?” she asked quietly. “She’s so small, Agatha. She won’t understand why we weren’t there.”

Agatha glanced over at her, heart aching at the naked worry in her voice. “She understands more than you think,” she said. “And what she’ll understand most is that you came back.”

Rio swallowed. “I just keep thinking about her asking for us. About her waiting on us.”

Agatha squeezed her hand again. “And now she doesn’t have to.”

The light changed. Agatha pulled the car forward, the tires crunching softly over leftover ice as Eastview came into view. A modest neighbourhood. Warm porch lights. Decorations still hanging from gutters, half-forgotten but glowing.

They turned onto a quiet residential street and slowed.

Rio straightened in her seat, clutching Teddy to her chest like armour. Agatha felt her own nerves flare then, sharp and sudden. Seeing Gabby again meant letting herself feel everything she’d been holding at bay all week.

Agatha parked, cut the engine, and turned toward Rio.

“Whatever happens,” she said gently, lifting Rio’s chin so she had to meet her eyes, “we show up calm. We show up kind. That’s what she needs.”

Rio nodded, eyes shining. “Okay.”

They sat there for a moment longer, breathing in sync, before opening the doors and stepping out into the cold together.

And as Agatha locked the car, Teddy tucked carefully under Rio’s arm, she had the strangest, clearest thought-

Some moments don’t feel like beginnings until you’re already standing in them.

Chapter End Notes

I have a thing for growling Rio apparently 😅

Chapter 35

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha paused on the porch, drawing in a slow breath. She could feel Rio beside her, practically vibrating with nervous energy, which was oddly disarming. Rio was usually the calm one, the steady presence. 

Seeing her wound this tight made Agatha’s chest ache.

She squeezed Rio’s hand, a quiet reassurance, then lifted her other hand and knocked.

The door opened almost immediately.

Susan stood there, looking more tired than Agatha remembered, the strain of the past few days etched into her face. Still, she smiled when she saw them, genuine and warm.

“Oh, Dr. Harkness,” she said. Her gaze flicked to Rio. “And you must be Rio.”

“Please,” Agatha said gently. “Call me Agatha. And yes—this is my partner, Rio Vidal.”

Susan’s smile softened further. “It’s lovely to meet you properly. Please, come in. You’ve actually picked a very good time.” She stepped aside, lowering her voice just a little. “She was asking about you both again, she got a little upset.”

Agatha and Rio exchanged a look, something unspoken passing between them, before following Susan inside.

The house was large but unmistakably lived in. Family photographs lined the walls, framed moments of holidays, graduations, children frozen mid-laugh. The air smelled faintly of something warm and familiar, like soup or baked bread.

It felt like a home.

As they stepped farther into the house, Agatha heard it first.

Soft sniffles. The uneven sound of someone trying, and failing, to be quiet about crying.

Susan led them into the living room, and the sight stopped Agatha cold.

Gabby was curled in on herself at one end of the couch, knees tucked up, arms wrapped tightly around a cushion like it was the only thing keeping her anchored. She looked impossibly small, smaller than Agatha remembered, swallowed by the furniture and the space around her.

Something in Agatha’s chest cracked open.

For a split second, the room blurred and she wasn’t standing in a stranger’s living room anymore. She was a child again. Too quiet. Too aware. Sitting with the same tight, folded posture, trying to take up less space in a world that had already decided she was on her own.

Alone.

 Scared.

 Waiting for someone who might not come back.

Agatha swallowed hard, forcing herself to stay present.

Gabby heard them then. Her head lifted slowly, cautiously, like she wasn’t sure she wanted to see who had come in. Her eyes found the doorway, and then they widened when she noticed them.

Gabby froze.

She didn’t smile right away. She didn’t move. She just stared at them, as if afraid this might disappear if she blinked. Agatha felt Rio inhale sharply beside her, felt the tension ripple through her body as she braced herself for rejection, for confusion, for anything that might hurt this child further.

Agatha didn’t step forward. She knew better than to rush a moment like this.

A heartbeat passed.

Then another.

Rio moved first.

She crouched down slowly, deliberately, bringing herself to Gabby’s level. She held out the stuffed bear in both hands, offering it like something sacred.

“He’s missed you, cariño,” Rio said softly.

That was all it took.

Gabby’s face crumpled and brightened all at once. She slid off the couch in a rush, padding across the room with sudden urgency. She snatched Teddy from Rio’s hands and flung her arms around Rio’s neck with all the force her small body could muster.

Rio caught her instantly, steady and sure, one hand supporting her back, the other cradling her head as Gabby pressed her tear-streaked face into Rio’s shoulder.

Agatha felt tears sting her eyes before she could stop them.

She turned her head slightly, breathing through it, overwhelmed by the sight of Gabby clinging to Rio like she’d been holding that hug inside her all week. By the sound of Gabby’s small sobs easing into hiccupped breaths, Agatha knew this was something she’d needed far more than words.

Susan seemed to sense the intimacy in the moment, her eyes also glassing over as she pressed a hand to her chest. Rio was still crouched on the floor, Gabby wrapped around her like she might disappear if she loosened her grip, and Susan looked at the three of them like she’d accidentally stepped into something sacred.

“I’ll give you three a moment,” Susan said softly. “Can I get you something to drink? Tea, coffee?”

Agatha sniffed, not wanting to give away that she too was overwhelmed by the scene unfolding in front of her. She glanced briefly at Rio, at the way her arms were wrapped securely around Gabby, her chin resting protectively atop the child’s curls.

“Two teas would be lovely.”

Susan smiled, wiping at her eyes as she moved through to the kitchen, giving them space without needing to be asked twice.

Agatha crouched down level with Rio and Gabby, her movements slow and careful, like she was approaching something fragile. Her hand came up to smooth the curls on the little girl’s head, fingers brushing briefly against Rio’s wrist in the process. Rio glanced up at her, eyes shining, and shifted just enough to make room for Agatha beside them.

“We’re so happy to see you, Gabby. We missed you very much,” Agatha said, her voice breaking just slightly despite her efforts to keep it steady.

Rio nodded along, murmuring softly, “So, so much,” her thumb rubbing small, soothing circles into Gabby’s back.

Gabby pulled her face from Rio’s neck and turned to look at Agatha, still clutching Teddy tightly in one hand. Rio kept an arm around her, anchoring, present, letting Gabby choose where to lean.

“Susie says mommy went to heaven and I can’t see her anymore,” Gabby said in as serious a voice as a three-year-old could manage.

Agatha felt the words settle heavy in her chest and wondered, briefly and painfully, how much of that statement Gabby actually understood. How much was just repetition, and how much was already grief taking root.

Rio inhaled softly beside her, steady but tight, her hand finding Agatha’s knee for just a second, grounding them both.

“But she said Doctor Haknest and Rio didn’t… but you couldn’t come see me. But you’re here.”
Agatha’s heart clenched.

“Yes, sweetheart, we are right here. We’re not going anywhere,” Agatha said, her voice gentle but certain, as she twirled one of Gabby’s curls around her finger. She felt Rio’s hand slide over hers then, covering it, reinforcing the promise without a word.

Rio gave the girl a small squeeze. “We’re here now,” she added softly. “And we’re really glad to see you.”

Agatha kept her expression calm for Gabby’s sake, but somewhere deep inside, she was mentally murdering the social worker who had decided absence was the kinder option. Some children didn’t need distance. They needed continuity. Familiar faces. Faces that stayed.

For the next hour, Gabby came back to life.

Agatha watched from the edge of the room as Rio settled onto the floor with her, sneakers kicked aside, jacket forgotten. Gabby dragged toy after toy over, narrating each one with solemn importance. Rio listened like every detail mattered, asking questions, letting Gabby correct her, laughing when the rules changed halfway through the game.

Every so often, Rio would glance up and catch Agatha watching.

She’d smile softly, that familiar warmth returning to her eyes, the kind Agatha hadn’t seen all week. The tightness in Rio’s shoulders had eased. Her laughter came easier now. Seeing it loosened something in Agatha’s chest she hadn’t realised she’d been holding closed.

This, she thought, was what they both had needed just as much as Gabby did.

Susan excused herself partway through the visit, murmuring something about a phone call. Agatha barely noticed at first, too absorbed in the sight of Gabby curled happily against Rio’s side, chattering about Teddy like he’d been on a long journey of his own.

When Susan returned, something was off.

Her smile didn’t quite reach her eyes, and she hovered near the doorway for a moment before approaching Agatha. Agatha stood immediately, instincts flaring.

“Is everything all right?” she asked quietly.

Susan lowered her voice, careful. “That was Geraldine. Gabby's social worker.” She hesitated. “She said they’ve been trying to reach Deborah’s parents. To inform them about… the situation.”

Agatha’s stomach dropped.

“She said they’re coming for the funeral,” Susan continued, glancing toward the living room where Gabby was laughing softly. “And they’d like to meet Gabby.”

Agatha felt the shift immediately, like a cold draft through an otherwise warm room.

She forced her expression into something neutral, professional, schooling her features the way she’d learned to do long ago. Inside, anger sparked sharp and immediate.

Debbie had told her about them. The way her parents had turned their backs the moment they found out she was pregnant. The silence that followed. The years of absence. Where had they been when Debbie was exhausted and scared and sick? Where were they when she was alive?

And now, suddenly, they wanted to meet Gabby.

Agatha’s gaze drifted back to the living room, to Gabby leaning into Rio’s side, safe and laughing, unaware of the complication quietly approaching her small world.

Once gabby had tired, Susan thanked them both for visiting and they promised Gabby they would come back again soon.

As they got into the car, Agatha immediately felt the change in Rio.

The tension she’d carried all week had melted away, replaced by an easy lightness that showed in the way she buckled her seatbelt and leaned back with a quiet, satisfied sigh. The visit had done something to her. Given her back a piece of herself Agatha hadn’t even realised was missing.

Agatha felt it too, but hers came with restraint.

She kept her eyes on the road as she pulled away from the curb, Susan’s words echoing faintly in the back of her mind. Gabby’s grandparents. The funeral. The request to meet. The conversation she knew was coming.

She didn’t say any of it.

Not yet.

Rio deserved this moment. The uncomplicated joy of knowing Gabby was safe, that she still remembered them, that the bond hadn’t been imagined. Agatha swallowed the words and let the quiet stretch, choosing instead to listen to Rio hum softly to herself, content in a way she hadn’t been all week.

The drive back passed quickly. By the time they reached Rio’s apartment building, night had settled in fully, the town quieter than usual.

Inside, the apartment was empty.

No familiar voices. No sign of Alice or Jen. The space felt unusually still.

Agatha realised, a little absently, that she hadn’t even checked the schedule earlier that day. Hadn’t noticed who was working late or staying elsewhere. She’d been too consumed with the anticipation of seeing Gabby again to think about anything beyond the visit.

Rio toed off her boots and glanced around, smiling. “Guess it’s just us.”

Agatha watched her for a moment, the quiet settling between them, the unspoken weight of everything waiting to be said pressing softly at the edges.

Just us, she thought.

The quiet felt heavier now, thick with everything they had been holding back all day. Rio was still standing there, jacket half on, eyes bright and a little unsteady, like she didn’t know whether to laugh or cry.

Agatha crossed the room without saying a word.

She took Rio’s face in both hands, thumbs brushing warm against her cheeks. “Hey,” she murmured. “Look at me.”

Rio did. Her breath caught.

“You’re shaking,” Agatha said softly.

“I know,” Rio whispered. “I just… today. Seeing her. Thinking we weren’t allowed to. Thinking I might never—”

Agatha didn’t let her finish.

She kissed her.

It wasn’t tentative. It wasn’t careful. It was full and deep and desperate in the way only relief could be. Rio made a small sound of surprise before melting into it, hands grabbing at Agatha’s sweater like she needed something solid to hold onto.

Agatha pulled her closer, careful of her side but not gentle in the way that held back. This was a kiss meant to say you’re here, I’m here, we made it.

When they broke apart, Rio was breathing hard, forehead resting against Agatha’s.

“Hmm, what was that for?” she murmured, half laughing, half wrecked.

Agatha smiled, eyes dark and warm. “You needed it.”

“So did you.”

Agatha didn’t deny it. Rio had been more than careful around her while she was healing, afraid that she would hurt her.

She leaned in again, slower this time, kissing her with a heat that lingered. Rio’s hands slid to Agatha’s back, pressing her closer, like she was afraid any space between them might let the fear creep back in.

They moved together without thinking, backing toward the couch, bumping into it awkwardly before sinking down in a tangled heap of limbs and soft laughter. Rio ended up half in Agatha’s lap, their faces still close, breath mingling.

The kiss finally slowed, though neither of them really pulled away. Rio stayed close, hands still gripping Agatha’s sweater, forehead resting against hers as she tried to catch her breath.

“You know what the worst part of this week was?” Rio murmured.

Agatha smiled faintly. “The part where I got stabbed?”

Rio snorted softly. “That was a strong contender. But no.” She hesitated, cheeks warming just a little. “It was trying not to touch you.”

Agatha lifted a brow, amused. “Excuse me?”

“I’m serious,” Rio said, laughing quietly. “Every time I saw you, all patched up and stubborn and pretending you were fine, I had to physically remind myself you were healing and not… available.” She shook her head. “It was torture.”

Agatha’s smile turned slow and dangerous. “Poor you.”

“You have no idea,” Rio said. “You kept looking at me like you always do. And I couldn’t even pull you close without worrying I’d hurt you.”

Agatha’s hands slid to Rio’s waist, warm and steady. “You could have still touched me baby.”

“Not like I wanted to,” Rio admitted, eyes dark with something affectionate and hungry all at once.

Agatha leaned in, brushing her nose against Rio’s. “Well,” she murmured, “I’m cleared for light activity.”

Rio’s laugh came out low and breathless. “Doctor, you’re very bad for my health.”

“Well then” Agatha said softly, kissing her again, “I think you deserve a reward for your resilience.”

Rio kissed her like she had been waiting all week for permission.

Agatha broke the kiss, trailing her lips along Rio’s jaw. Then down to her throat, pressing kisses to her skin, feeling the thrum of Rio’s pulse beneath her lips.

She could hear the soft sounds Rio was making, the quiet breaths, the whispered moans, and she could feel her chest rising and falling, faster and faster, and it made Agatha want more, want to give her more.

Agatha wanted to memorise this, every single second, every touch, every sound, every breath.

She slid her hand down Rio’s toned stomach, her fingers dancing along her abs as she slipped her them under Rio’s sweater and pulled it up, breaking contact just long enough to pull it over Rio’s head.

Agatha dropped the sweater on the floor, her eyes flicking up to Rio’s, heat pooling in her core at the way Rio was looking at her. At the way she was waiting for her, her cheeks flushed, her lips parted and her eyes so dark.

Agatha reached out, her fingers brushing across the seam of Rio’s sports bra, sliding across the swell of her breast.

Then down, trailing across her ribs, her stomach, the small happy trail, down to the waistband of her sweatpants.

She hooked her finger under the elastic and tugged, and Rio lifted her hips, letting Agatha pull the fabric down.

Agatha dropped to her knees in front of her, pressing a kiss to Rio’s hipbone and then lower, following the edge of her boxers down her thigh and nipping lightly with her teeth..

Rio was breathing faster now, and Agatha looked up at her, watching her chest rise and fall, watching the way her lips were parted, the way she was looking down at Agatha like she wanted her just as much as Agatha wanted her.

Agatha pressed another kiss to the inside of Rio’s thigh, her fingers trailing up, her touch so light. Then she leaned in and pressed her mouth to her centre, still over the soft fabric of Rio’s underwear, and Rio made the softest sound, something between a moan and a whimper.

Agatha pulled at the fabric with her fingers, and Rio stepped out of them, her breath catching in her throat.

“I bet you’ve been so pent up all week baby, I hope you haven’t been a bad boy and done anything without me?” Agatha teased with a smirk.

Rio shook her head. “No mi amor,” she breathed. “Ive been good, so good.”

Agatha leaned in and kissed her again, this time without the fabric between them, and Rio’s fingers slid into her hair, her back arching, her breath leaving her lungs.

 “ay dios mío.”

Agatha dragged her tongue up, parting Rio’s folds, circling her clit. She could feel Rio trembling under her touch, could hear every soft sound, every quiet moan, and it just made her want to do this more, give her more, make her feel everything Agatha wanted her to feel.

She looked up, watching Rio as she touched her, as she tasted her. And she felt that jolt of heat between her own thighs as she started to feel her own underwear become ruined. 

She flicked her tongue across Rio’s clit and felt her gasp, felt her grip tighten in Agatha’s hair.

“Fuck,” Rio breathed. Her voice was low, shaky.

Agatha did it again. And again. And again, circling her tongue, feeling Rio shake against her, feeling her arch into her touch.

Agatha slid her hands up Rio’s thighs, her fingers digging into her flesh, holding her where she wanted her, and then she slid one hand between Rio’s legs, her fingers dipping into her, just barely.

Rio moaned, her hips shifting, seeking more of her touch.

“Fuck,” she whispered.

Agatha crooked her finger, pressing up, and she felt Rio shake again. She did it once more, and then she pulled back just enough to look at Rio, to watch her, to see what she was doing to her.

“Agatha,” Rio gasped. 

Agatha smiled hovering just above where Rio wanted her.

"Use your words baby."

"Please, mi vida, I need you inside."

Agatha leaned back in, licking up through her centre again, sucking her clit, and Rio cried out, her fingers twisting tighter in Agatha’s hair. Agatha then slid her fingers deeper, pressing up again, again, again, and Rio was shaking against her, her moans filling the room, her hips rocking into Agatha’s touch.

Agatha kept going, kept touching, kept tasting, and it was so good, so fucking good, to give Rio this, to feel her come undone, to feel her let go. Agatha kept her fingers moving, kept her tongue circling, until Rio cried out again, until she shook and trembled and came against Agatha’s mouth.

And then Agatha slowed, her touch growing softer, gentler, easing her through it until Rio went limp against the couch cushions.

“ Mierda,” she murmured. She sounded dazed.

Agatha pressed a kiss to the inside of her thigh and then climbed up to straddle Rio's hips, her hands coming to Rio’s cheeks.

She kissed her, soft and slow. “I love you” she whispered against her lips.

Rio opened her eyes slowly, her hand coming up to cup Agatha’s face.

“I love you too,” Rio said quietly. Then she shook her head, smiling a little, like she needed to say it better. “But not in a small way. Not in a careful way.”

She lifted her other hand, cupping Agatha’s face the way Agatha had done to her.

“I love you in the way that makes a place feel like home,” Rio continued softly. “In the way that makes everything before you feel like it was just leading me here. I love you in the way that means I’m not afraid of tomorrow anymore, because I get to face it with you.”

Her forehead rested against Agatha’s.

“So yeah,” she murmured, breath warm between them. “I love you. All of you. Always.”

Agatha felt it land somewhere deep and unguarded.

Not like a spark. Like a settling.

For a split second, her mind went blank, every sharp thought she usually reached for just… gone. All that was left was the weight of it. Of being seen. Chosen. Claimed without hesitation.

This is what safe feels like, she realized, startled by the thought.

Her chest tightened, eyes burning, and she leaned into Rio without thinking, like her body knew before she did that this was where she belonged. Not bracing. Not waiting for the catch.

Just held.

Don’t lose this, she thought fiercely.
Don’t ever forget how this feels.

Chapter End Notes

If you have ever heard the song Geraldine by Glasvegas then you will know I HAD to name the social worker this.

Anyway, I had to give my babies some sexy time because it had been too long.

Chapter 36

Chapter Notes

So sorry for the wait for this one, life has been crazy!

Also want to recognise two very talented artists who have created beautiful illustrations based on this story which you can find on my twitter @covencrafted

thank you so much to Teen and Peoniesandteacups 🖤 I am forever grateful

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha woke slowly, body heavy and warm, the kind of deep, lingering tired that came from being thoroughly undone the night before.

For a moment she lay still, eyes half-lidded, letting the memories surface in fragments. Rio’s hands, sure and insistent. The way her voice had softened when she said her name. The way everything had blurred into heat and laughter and breathless closeness until time stopped meaning anything at all.

Her muscles ached in a way that made her smile.

Not the sharp pain of injury or exhaustion, but the dull, intimate soreness that came from being worshipped. 

She shifted slightly and felt it again, a reminder written into her body. Rio’s weight over her. Rio’s mouth on her skin. The way they had moved together like they were discovering something new and inevitable all at once.

Agatha turned her head and found Rio still asleep beside her.

She took a slow breath, eyes tracing the smooth line of muscle along Rio’s back and arms, the way strength sat so naturally in her body. Even at rest, Rio looked powerful, solid in a way that felt both grounding and impossibly attractive.

Agatha’s mind again, drifted back to the night before, to the way those same arms had held her, lifted her, shifted her with an ease that had left her breathless and laughing in equal measure. Rio had moved her like she was something precious, not fragile, guiding her with confidence and care, always checking in, always aware of every reaction.

It struck her then how much trust was wrapped up in that. Letting someone else take control. Letting herself be moved, held, wanted so openly.

She smiled softly to herself as reached out, barely brushing her fingers along Rio’s arm. It was enough to make her stir.

Honey-brown eyes blinked open, meeting blue.

“G’morning, princesa,” Rio murmured, voice thick with sleep and a lazy smile tugging at her mouth.

Agatha narrowed her eyes, but there was no real heat in it. “What did I say about calling me that?”

Rio’s smile only widened as she shifted closer, sliding an arm around Agatha and burying her face into the warm curve of her neck.

“Lo siento, mi reina.”

Agatha laughed, soft and helpless, like she’d forgotten how to be anything but this, and pushed at Rio’s shoulder in half-hearted protest.

“Much better,” Agatha murmured, smiling as she threaded her fingers through Rio’s hair. Rio was still nuzzling into her neck, lips brushing soft, lazy kisses along her throat.

“Mmm. As much as I’d love to stay in bed all day,” she said, “I promised Lilia I’d help with her New Year’s rituals.”

That made Rio finally pull back, brows knitting in confusion.

“Her… what?”

Agatha snorted quietly at the expression on her face. “Honey, you are aware Lilia’s a witch, right?” she said with exaggerated seriousness.

Rio blinked. “Well, yeah, but I thought it was more like a… kooky hobby?”

“Oh, she takes it very seriously. And I’m absolutely telling her you called her kooky.”

Rio’s eyes widened, properly alarmed now. “You wouldn’t dare.”

Agatha hummed as she rolled onto her back, hands laced behind her head. “Maybe she’ll turn you into a frog.”

“Well, lucky for me,” Rio grinned, leaning in, “I have a beautiful princess to kiss me and break the spell.”

Agatha stopped her with a finger to her lips, one eyebrow arching.

“Of course,” Rio corrected smoothly, smirk softening. “A queen.”

Agatha hummed contently as Rio kissed her. 

They spent a little longer than planned tangled in the bedsheets, the morning stretching soft and unhurried around them.

Eventually, reality intruded in the form of sunlight creeping higher up the wall and the distant awareness of time ticking on without them. Rio groaned dramatically when Agatha finally rolled away to sit on the edge of the bed.

“You’re mean,” Rio said, rubbing her face into the pillow. “You lure me into happiness and then abandon me for witch duties.”

Agatha glanced back over her shoulder, already reaching for her clothes, lips curved in a fond smile. 

“You’re coming with me.”

Rio peeked up at her. “I am?”

“Absolutely. If I have to endure Lilia’s incense and chanting, you can suffer too.”

Rio considered this, then flopped back onto the mattress. “Fine. But if I get hexed, I’m coming for you.”

Agatha leaned down to steal one last kiss, slow and lingering, before finally, reluctantly, pulling them both out of bed.

 

 

The drive to Lilia’s was filled with gentle touches. Agatha drove with one hand on the wheel, the other drifting across the console to rub Rio’s thigh absentmindedly, her thumb tracing slow, familiar circles. 

Rio, half-turned in her seat, threaded her fingers through Agatha’s hair, lightly scratching at her scalp whenever she stopped at a red light.

It felt easy. Natural. Like something they’d been doing for years instead of months.

Agatha couldn’t remember the last time she’d felt this carefree, this quietly happy, without the usual edge of tension sitting beneath it. For once, she wasn’t bracing herself for loss or waiting for something to fracture. She was just… here, in a car, being touched by someone who loved her.

When they stepped into the familiar home she shared with Lilia, she was immediately met with the strong, earthy scent of sage and frankincense, smoke lingering in the air like a memory.

Beside her, she noticed the subtle scrunch of Rio’s nose, the way she bit her lip to suppress a smile—trying very hard to be respectful, and failing in the most endearing way.

“Oh, there are my girls,” Lilia said warmly as she opened the door, already ushering them inside. “Have you eaten yet? No, of course you haven’t. Sit down, I’ll make you both some pasta.”

They barely had time to protest before they were being herded into the kitchen. Ebony appeared almost instantly, slipping soundlessly from the hallway like a shadow, her black tail flicking once before she made a beeline straight for Agatha. She wound herself around Agatha’s ankles with clear purpose, brushing insistently until Agatha sighed and bent to scoop her up.

Agatha and Rio shuffled in together, Agatha balancing the cat easily on her hip as Ebony settled in like she belonged there, stealing soft touches and exchanging quiet laughs at Lilia’s frantic energy. Even once they sat at the table, Ebony claimed Agatha’s lap instantly, her paws kneading contentedly as their chairs were angled close, their hands finding each other under the edge without thinking.

Rio glanced around, eyebrows lifting slowly.

The kitchen looked like a cross between a witch’s apothecary and a Bath and Bodyworks—bundles of herbs hung from the cabinets, candles and soaps crowded every surface, tarot cards fanned across the table, and strangely… a lone bongo drum sat between a bowl of oranges and a stack of notebooks.

“…What’s all this, Lilia?” she asked.

Lilia, already filling a pot with water, replied without turning. “My coven and I are preparing for the New Year, of course.”

Rio straightened slightly. Agatha’s mouth twitched, sensing an oppertunity.

“Yes, Lilia,” Agatha said mildly, voice carrying a peculiar edge, “please do tell Rio what kind of rituals you’ll be doing tonight.”

Rio shot her a look, but missed the subtle wink Agatha threw Lilia as she finally turned around.

Lilia smiled sweetly—then carefully arranged her face into something deliberately casual. “Oh, just the usual. A few spells, a small sacrificial ceremony, and then right before midnight, we all strip naked and dance around the yard chanting our manifestations to the moon.”

Agatha deserved an award for how perfectly neutral she kept her expression.

Rio’s face, on the other hand, went through several stages—shock, horror, and finally deep suspicion.

“…You’re fucking with me, right?”

She looked between them, clearly waiting for one of them to crack.

“You girls should join us, Oh, Sharon’s bringing the animal bones again,” Lilia added offhandedly. “Last year she tried reading the future in a goat skull. Bit messy, but very accurate.”

Rio’s eyes widened. “A goat skull?”

Her gaze flicked instinctively to Ebony, who was still curled comfortably in Agatha’s lap, utterly unbothered by the conversation. The cat merely blinked slow and languid, tail giving a lazy flick, as if animal bones were the least interesting thing she’d heard all day.

Lilia turned back to the stove, dropping the pasta into the boiling water like she hadn’t just said something unhinged. “You know what, you girls should come, we need someone for the possession.”

Rio’s face paled even more, “Possession?”

“Last year Sharon got a little carried away,” Lilia said thoughtfully. “Started speaking in tongues, and I swear I’ve seen her wandering the yard since at night, in a trance, just staring at her flowerbeds. So this year we’ll need someone else. Someone with a stronger spirit.”

Agatha nearly lost it.

She pushed back from the table and stood abruptly as Ebony leaped onto the floor, turning away from Rio just in time. She buried her face in the open fridge, shoulders shaking as she pretended to study the contents, laughter muffled by the hum of the appliance.

Before Rio could manage more than a strangled noise, the front door opened.

“Sorry I’m late, Lilia!” Sharon called brightly as she stepped inside, floral-print shirt cheerful as ever, grocery bag looped over her arm. “Traffic at Walgreens was a nightmare. I swear I could’ve cursed that checkout boy for moving so slow—”

She stopped short, spotting Rio.

“—Rio, dear, are you alright?”

Rio hadn’t blinked. Her face had gone chalk-white, eyes tracking Sharon’s every movement like she might start floating off the ground at any second.

That did it.

Agatha snorted loudly from inside the fridge, clapping a hand over her mouth as laughter finally broke free. Lilia followed suit immediately, her booming laugh filling the kitchen.

Sharon jumped, startled, looking between the three of them in utter confusion. “What did I miss?”

Rio dragged her hands down her face, breathing deeply, trying and failing not to laugh herself.

“Just these two,” she muttered, shooting Agatha and Lilia a glare softened by a smile, “being an absolute menace.”

Agatha crossed the room and cupped Rio’s face in both hands, squishing her cheeks just enough to draw out an exaggerated pout.

“I’m sorry, baby,” she said, utterly unapologetic. “It was too easy. You should’ve seen your face.”

She stole a quick kiss from Rio’s pursed lips before letting her go and turning to help Sharon unload the groceries.

Rio scowled after her. “You’re mean. And I expected better from you, Lilia. Now I see where Agatha gets it from.”

Lilia waved a dismissive hand. “You love me. Don’t lie.” She paused, then added casually, “Oh—and Dottie the realtor mentioned a couple of two- and three-bedroom places, like you asked. I wrote them down somewhere…”

She shuffled through a stack of papers before producing a small slip with a few addresses scribbled on it.

Agatha’s smile faded instantly.

Beside her, Rio’s spine went rigid.

“You’re moving?” Agatha asked quietly. “You didn’t say anything.”

Rio scratched the back of her neck, eyes flicking everywhere but Agatha. “I—uh. I was just… checking some stuff out.”

Lilia, sensing the shift, glanced between them. “Sharon, dear, why don’t you come help me finish up in the living room?”

Once they were alone, Rio turned back to Agatha, shoulders tense.

“After you called yesterday,” she said, voice lower now, more careful, “and said Gabby wanted to see us… I asked Lilia if she knew of anything available.”

She swallowed.

“I know it’s probably silly and might never happen, but I figured if Gabby ever wanted to you know, come stay with us, she’d need a place that didn’t feel like a college dorm. And—” her face flushed a deep red, “—if you… maybe wanted to live with me, we’d need our own space.”

Her gaze stayed fixed anywhere but on Agatha.

Agatha’s throat tightened as she took in the sheepish look on Rio’s face. This incredible woman—already planning ahead, already thinking in what ifs—was considering how to care for a little girl who needed help. Who needed love.

Agatha hadn’t thought her heart had room for more, but somehow it made space anyway.

Then one thought pushed sharply to the front of her mind.

She hadn’t told Rio about Gabby’s grandparents. That they might take her. That this fragile hope could be temporary.

Her chest twisted with the weight of it. On one hand, Rio was offering to take on an orphaned child she’d bonded with. In the same breath, she was asking Agatha to move in—to build something together, to be part of that future.

And Agatha stood there, caught between the love being offered to her and the truth she was still holding back.

Just as Agatha opened her mouth to speak, her phone rang.

The sound shattering the moment entirely.

She glanced down at the screen—Westview General—and her chest sank even as her spine straightened out of habit. Duty sliding back into place.

She answered quickly, voice shifting without effort as she listened, asked two sharp questions, then closed her eyes briefly.

“I’m on my way,” she said, already reaching for her coat.

When she hung up, Rio was watching her with quiet understanding.

“Go,” Rio said softly. “I’ll meet you at the bar later?”

Agatha nodded, relief and regret tangling together. She leaned in, kissed Rio quickly but deeply, forehead resting against hers for a beat longer than necessary.

“I’m sorry,” she murmured. “Try not to fall into any cauldrons while I’m gone.”

Rio huffed a laugh, squeezing her hand. “Oh, ha ha.”

Agatha smiled, just a little, before turning toward the door— promising herself she would tell Rio about Gabby’s grandparents tomorrow.

 

 

When Agatha arrived at the hospital, Wanda was waiting for her, already apologetic as Agatha pulled her white coat from its hook and shrugged it over her purple sweater and dark jeans.

“I’m sorry to drag you in,” Wanda said quietly as they walked. “They insisted on speaking to you directly. Jen tried to give them as much information as she could, but they wouldn’t hear it. Kept saying they needed her doctor.”

Agatha scoffed under her breath. “Funny how they suddenly give a damn now that their daughter is dead.”

When Wanda had called earlier to explain that Debbie’s parents had shown up demanding answers, Agatha had forced her expression into something neutral in front of Rio. She hadn’t wanted to open that door without enough time to deal with the fallout. Part of her had also wanted to see them first. To look them in the eye.
 She had questions of her own.

“They seem… pretty upset,” Wanda offered carefully.

“I’ve seen plenty of crocodile tears,” Agatha replied flatly.

Wanda led her to the waiting room.

An older man and woman sat hunched together in a row of plastic chairs, hands clasped, shoulders bowed. They looked small, defeated. Everything a grieving parent should look like. 

Agatha squared her shoulders and walked in, professionalism settling over her like armour, even as irritation simmered beneath it.

“Mr. and Mrs. Jenkins?” she said evenly. “I’m Dr. Harkness. I was Deborah’s physician while she was here at Westview General. I understand you have some questions about her passing.”

Mrs. Jenkins looked up first.

Agatha immediately noticed the signs—red-rimmed eyes, swollen lids, the deep, exhausted lines of someone who hadn’t slept. The grief on her face was raw, unpolished. Real.

It caught Agatha off guard.

“Thank you for seeing us,” Mrs. Jenkins said, voice unsteady. “My husband and I… we’re still in shock. You’ll have to forgive us. We just—we just want to understand what happened to our—”

Her voice broke, the word lodging painfully in her throat.

Mr. Jenkins reached for her hand, enveloping it in both of his, pressing a gentle kiss to her temple as tears slipped freely down his own face.

Mrs. Jenkins drew in a shaky breath, wiped at her cheeks, and straightened as best she could.

“I’m sorry,” she said, clearing her throat. “She was our little girl. I just can’t believe she’s… she’s really gone.”

Agatha stood there, the practiced responses she’d prepared dissolving one by one.

This wasn’t the reaction she’d imagined. Not from the parents Debbie had told her about, the parents who had turned their backs when she needed them most.

Agatha drew a slow breath and began.

She explained Debbie’s symptoms as clearly as she could—how she’d come in short of breath, how he vitals had initially been stable, how the early imaging hadn’t shown anything that raised immediate alarm. She walked them through the tests that had been ordered, the labs that had been run, the treatments they’d started the moment Debbie was admitted.

She chose her words carefully. Not the clipped precision she used in consults, but something softer, steadier. She made space for pauses, for questions, for the way grief bent logic and time to most people experiencing it.

“The complication that caused her collapse was sudden,” Agatha said gently. “Rare. Even in hindsight, there were no warning signs that would’ve allowed us to predict it.”

Mrs. Jenkins pressed a hand to her mouth, nodding slowly as tears welled again. Mr. Jenkins asked questions in a low, measured voice about timelines, about protocols, about whether anything could have been done differently.

Agatha answered every one of them without defensiveness. She didn’t rush. She didn’t deflect. When there were uncertainties, she named them honestly. When there were limits, she acknowledged them.

“I’m so sorry,” she said, not as a formality, but as a fact. “We did everything we could for her.”

The room was quiet when she finished.

Mrs. Jenkins reached for a tissue, dabbing at her eyes. Mr. Jenkins squeezed her hand. There was grief there still—heavy and unmistakable—but the sharp edge of anger Agatha had braced for never came.

“I can see you cared for her,” Mrs. Jenkins said finally, voice hoarse. “She wasn’t alone, was she?”

Agatha shook her head. “No. She wasn’t.”

Something eased, just slightly, in the set of their shoulders. They exchanged a look—shared, silent—and then Mr. Jenkins nodded once.

“Thank you for explaining it to us,” he said. “We… we appreciate your honesty.”

Agatha inclined her head, professionalism holding, even as something complicated settled in her chest.

“Forgive me,” Agatha said carefully, “but when I asked Debbie if there was anyone we could contact, she told me her parents had cut off all communication. That you hadn’t approved of her pregnancy.”

Mr. and Mrs. Jenkins both looked up at that, confusion crossing their faces almost in unison.

“Dr. Harkness,” Mrs. Jenkins said quietly, shaking her head, “Debbie wasn’t estranged. She ran away.”

Mr. Jenkins tightened his grip on her hand as she continued.

“We’d been looking for her for almost six years. We didn’t know she was pregnant—we didn’t even know where she was. We argued when she was seventeen. She was going through a rebellious phase, and I found drugs in her pocket. I confronted her about it, and the next morning… she was gone.”

Her voice wavered, but she pressed on.

“We went to the police. They didn’t care. They treated her like just another junkie who’d chosen to disappear.” A sharp breath. “We searched for her every day. And now—now we finally have answers, and it’s… it’s too late.”

Agatha listened, something cold and heavy settling in her chest.

The grief in Mrs. Jenkins’s voice wasn’t performative or convenient. It was threaded through every word, every pause. This was a mother who had been missing her child for years—and had only just found her again in the worst possible way.

Shame crept in suddenly, sharp and unwelcome.

Agatha felt it settle heavy in her chest as she thought about the assumptions she had made, the judgments she had been so ready to pass on the two grieving parents sitting across from her. Guilt followed close behind, tangled with an instinct she had not wanted to examine. 

“I’m very sorry for your loss,” Agatha said quietly as she stood and turned toward the door.

“Our granddaughter. Gabriella,” Mrs. Jenkins said, stopping her. “You’ve met her?”

Agatha paused.

She drew in a slow breath, her back still to them, eyes closing despite herself.

Images came unbidden.

Rio with Gabby perched on her shoulders.

Gabby holding out Teddy to Agatha with her dimpled cheeks and radiant smile. 

The fragile, foolish fantasy of the three of them building something that looked like a future.

She opened her eyes and turned back.

“Yes,” she said, steadying her voice. “She is a beautiful, remarkable little girl. She lights up every room she’s in. She likes chocolate milk but not strawberry. Her favourite colour is yellow because she says it looks like the sun. And she needs to hold onto someone when she falls asleep. That part is important.”

She stopped to swallow the lump in her throat.

“I hope you take very good care of her.”

Agatha did not wait for a response. She turned and walked away before she could lose her composure, heading back toward the staff room with her breath tight in her chest.

It’s for the best. They can give her the life she deserves. They are her family.

“There you are,” Jen said as she came in, tossing her scrub cap into her locker. “I hope they didn’t give you too hard a time. Nat’s been sweating, convinced they were about to try some kind of negligence suit.”
