She turned and took one look at Agatha’s face.

“Oh shit. They did?”

Agatha wiped at her cheeks, only then realising tears were falling. She huffed out a weak attempt at a laugh.

“No. Just… they weren’t what I was expecting.”

Jen frowned. “Douchebags?”

“No,” Agatha said quietly. “Decent people.”

Jen studied her. “Then why do you look like someone punched you in the stomach?”

Because that’s exactly what it feels like.

Chapter End Notes

Next up... Rio finds out 🥺

Chapter 37

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha would never have called herself a style icon. She preferred clothes that were comfortable, practical, and quietly flattering. Things that signalled competence first, with just enough femininity to soften the edges. When Jen asked what she planned to wear to the bar that night, Agatha had described the maroon slacks and white silk button-up she owned, the one that skimmed her figure just enough to feel dressy without trying too hard.

Jen had scoffed.

“Predictable,” she’d said.
Something about that had lodged under Agatha’s skin. Was she really that predictable?

“Well, at least you know Rio’s already in love with you,” Jen had added, not unkindly. “God knows why, but I’m sure she’s used to those outfits.”

That was what really got under her skin.

Because what if Rio had noticed? Not in a critical way, but in the quiet, observant way she noticed everything else. What if Rio had clocked how little effort Agatha made sometimes, how she’d never really dressed to be seen, only to be appropriate?

Agatha told herself it didn’t matter. Rio loved her. She’d said so. But the thought lingered anyway, sharp and uncomfortable. Love wasn’t supposed to mean complacency.

And so Agatha found herself standing in Jen’s apartment, tugging at hemlines and smoothing unfamiliar fabrics, trying on outfit after outfit that felt bold, revealing, almost unrecognisable. Each one a small rebellion against the version of herself that had learned to never ask for more attention than necessary.

She caught her reflection in the mirror and felt a strange mix of nerves and resolve, this was definitely …different but she didn’t hate it. 

They had ultimately settled on what Jen called her “old faithful” little black dress.

It was fitted enough to trace the natural curve of Agatha’s hips, the shape she secretly admired in the mirror when no one was looking. The hem fell just above her knee, revealing a careful, deliberate amount of skin without tipping into anything excessive. The short sleeves skimmed her shoulders, leaving her pale, toned arms exposed in a way that felt both elegant and faintly daring.

It wasn’t outrageous.


But it was intentional.

They hadn’t needed to do much to her hair. Jen worked in a few products, coaxing Agatha’s natural curls into something softer, fuller, letting them spill past her shoulders in glossy waves that felt effortless but undeniably styled.

“I am like fucking Michelangelo,” Jen declared as she finished applying a deep red lipstick, steady-handed and precise. She stepped back, eyeing her work critically. “Honestly, it’s annoying how good your skin is. You barely need makeup.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the faint flush in her cheeks betrayed her.

The final touch was a classic pair of black stiletto heels. Jen crouched to adjust the straps, then stood back slowly, arms crossed, taking in the full picture like a curator admiring a prized exhibit.

“Rio’s going to have a heart attack when you walk in there,” she said with satisfaction.

Agatha glanced at herself in the mirror again, this time lingering a little longer. The woman staring back at her looked polished, composed… but also softer somehow. There was a quiet confidence in the set of her shoulders, in the curve of her mouth.

“Hmm,” she said lightly, tilting her head. “I suppose this will do.”

Jen barked out a laugh. “Oh, admit it, Harkness. You look damn good and you know it.”

Agatha tried for indifference, but she couldn’t quite suppress the small, satisfied flicker in her chest. It wasn’t vanity. It was something closer to surprise. She wasn’t used to seeing herself framed like this—styled for desire instead of authority. It felt… vulnerable. But not in a bad way.

Her attention shifted when she turned and caught sight of Jen, who was mid-conversation and entirely unbothered by the fact that she was standing in nothing but her underwear. Jen gestured animatedly while stepping into a bright pink dress, chatting as if this were the most natural thing in the world.

“Zip me?” Jen said, turning her back without ceremony.

Agatha blinked once before stepping forward, fingers carefully pulling the zipper up along the smooth line of Jen’s spine.

It struck her then, how foreign this all felt.

She had never had this growing up. No sleepovers. No shared mirrors or whispered conversations about crushes. No easy laughter while getting ready for a night out. She had always chosen study over socialising, privacy over people. There hadn’t been time—or maybe she hadn’t allowed there to be.

Standing here now, in a friend’s apartment, helping zip up a dress while trading mild insults and talking about the women they loved, she felt something loosen quietly inside her.

This was ordinary. Almost embarrassingly so.

And yet it felt extraordinary.

Agatha caught herself laughing—actually laughing—at something Jen said about Rio’s inevitable reaction. The sound surprised her. It wasn’t restrained or polite. It was warm.

She hadn’t realised how much she’d missed out on until she was standing in the middle of it.

“All right, Sandy,” Jen said brightly, tossing Agatha a black coat and grabbing her purse. “Let’s go get your Danny Zuko.”

Agatha rolled her eyes as she caught the coat, even as a smile betrayed her. “Oh god, not the Grease reference.”

But she didn’t correct her. And she didn’t miss the way her chest warmed at the implication. It was ridiculous, and a little embarrassing, and strangely comforting all at once. Being teased like this felt… exciting.

The Witch’s Road was busier than Agatha had ever seen it, the low hum of voices and music spilling out into the street. She felt a flicker of gratitude that Wanda had pre-ordered them tickets. No waiting, no uncertainty. One less thing for Agatha’s mind to catalogue as a potential problem.

Inside, the familiar chaos wrapped around her.

Jen led the way, weaving confidently through the crowd toward the booth they always claimed, her hand briefly brushing Agatha’s elbow as if to keep her anchored.

Wanda and Nat were already there, seated closer than Agatha had ever seen them in public. Nat looked relaxed, loose in a way that only came with a couple of drinks, her knee angled toward Wanda without hesitation. Across from them, Kate sat with her chin propped on her hand, looking bored out of her mind as Billy talked animatedly, his hands moving almost faster than his words.

Kate clocked them and shot upright. “Finally! What took you guys so—”

Jen and Agatha shrugged out of their coats.

Kate stopped mid-sentence.

Her eyes widened as they landed on Agatha. “Holy shit Agatha, you look amazing. Rio is going to freak the fuck out.”

Heat crept up Agatha’s neck, a reflexive response to being seen like this. She straightened instinctively, chin lifting, professionalism trying to reassert itself.

“I don’t know what you’re referring to, Bishop,” she said coolly.

Jen rolled her eyes, smiling fondly.

“And where are Alice and Rio?” She asked, making Agatha grateful for the change in focus.

Kate pointed toward the bar. “Drinks run.”

Agatha followed the line of her finger and found them immediately. Two familiar silhouettes with their backs turned, laughing about something she couldn’t hear.

Her pulse picked up.

She didn’t know exactly what she was bracing for. Maybe Rio’s reaction. Maybe her own. Either way, she knew she was about to find out as Rio and Alice turned from the bar and started toward them, drinks balanced carefully on a tray.

Rio’s focus was entirely on not spilling anything. Agatha could tell by the way her face was scrunched in concentration, tongue caught just slightly between her teeth as she navigated the crowd. It was endearing in a way that made Agatha’s chest ache.

It also gave her time.

Time to take in Rio properly.

She’d chosen tight black jeans that showed off the powerful lines of her thighs with every step, muscle shifting beneath denim in a way Agatha had always admired. The cropped green silk button-up sat open just enough to flash a teasing glimpse of Rio’s stomach, the defined planes of her abs appearing and disappearing with each careful shuffle forward. And, of course, there were the Doc Martens. 

Unmistakably Rio.

Agatha felt a flicker of something low and warm curl through her, quickly followed by a quieter thought she hadn’t expected. Pride. This woman was with her. Chose her.

Rio was about five feet away when she finally lifted her gaze from the tray, clearly satisfied she’d made it through the worst of the crowd. 

Her eyes found Agatha.

And everything stopped.

Agatha watched Rio’s expression fracture and reform all at once. Happiness gave way to surprise, then something softer and almost hungry. Her mouth parted, her eyes roaming openly from Agatha’s hair to her dress to the heels she almost never wore.

For one suspended moment, Agatha wondered if she might actually be able to hear her heart over the music.

Alice stepped in beside Rio just in time, steadying the tray as Rio nearly forgot she was holding it at all.

Jen barked out a laugh from the booth. Kate muttered something under her breath that sounded suspiciously like, “Called it.”

Alice reached the booth first, slipping past a visibly stunned Rio.

“Looking good, Harkness,” she said easily, setting the tray down and handing out the drinks before leaning in to press a quick kiss to Jen’s lips.

Rio followed a second later, slower now, like the air had thickened around her.

She set the tray down carefully, almost mechanically, and then stepped into Agatha’s space without hesitation, hands coming to rest on either side of her waist.

“Mi amor…” Rio breathed.

Agatha’s pulse spiked.

“You look… you look…”

For one fragile second, doubt crept in.

She imagined Rio laughing softly and saying it wasn’t her. That it was too much. Too showy. Too different from the woman she’d fallen in love with. Agatha felt absurd for even thinking it, but the fear flared anyway. She wasn’t used to stepping outside her armour. She wasn’t used to dressing to be desired.

Rio’s thumbs pressed gently into her hips, grounding her.

“You look,” Rio said again, voice thick with something deeper now, “incredible.”

Agatha blinked.

Rio shook her head slightly, as if words were failing her. “You were already beautiful this morning. You’re beautiful in scrubs. In that purple sweater you pretend isn’t your favourite. But this…” Her eyes dragged slowly from Agatha’s curls down to the curve of the dress. “This feels unfair. You didn’t give me a heads up.”

A soft laugh rippled through the booth, but Rio didn’t look away.

“You look like you walked in here knowing exactly what you do to me,” she murmured, quieter now, just for her. “And I swear to God, if anyone else stares for more than two seconds, I’m throwing hands.”

Agatha felt the tension in her shoulders melt into something warmer. Rio wasn’t pulling away. She wasn’t confused.

She was undone.

“You like it?” Agatha asked, softer than she meant to.

Rio leaned in, brushing her lips just barely against Agatha’s ear.

“I love it,” she whispered. “But not as much as I'm gonna love tearing it off you.”

Agatha leaned in and kissed her, warm and certain, hands sliding up around Rio’s shoulders. The heels brought them nearly eye to eye for once, and the closeness felt grounding instead of strange. Rio’s hands tightened at her waist as the kiss deepened, unhurried and sure.

“Alright, lovebirds,” Wanda called out with a laugh. “Save it for midnight, huh?”

Rio pulled back just enough to rest her forehead against Agatha’s, smiling softly.

They slid into the booth beside Wanda and Nat, knees brushing under the table as everyone shuffled to make space.

Billy’s eyes widened the moment he realised who was now sitting across from him.

“Dr. Harkness! It’s good to see you. You look amazing. I mean, you always look good, I just mean you look extra good. Not that I mean that like I’m attracted to you because, you know, I’m gay, but—”

“Teen,” Agatha cut in smoothly. “Be cool man. And I suppose you can call me Agatha since we’re not in the hospital.”

Billy’s face lit up like she’d handed him an award. “Oh. Okay. Sure. Agatha.”

Agatha paused.

Her expression shifted immediately. “Actually, no. That feels weird. Dr. Harkness is fine.”

The table burst into laughter as Billy’s excitement deflated just as quickly.

Agatha leaned closer to Rio, brushing her nose lightly against her hair.

“So. I take it running sage through Lilia’s house went well?” she murmured, smoothing the collar of Rio’s shirt as if it needed adjusting.

Rio sniffed at herself, frowning. “I took two showers and I still smell like a spiritual bonfire. I swear that woman is walking fire hazard, I had to confiscate two of those weird ass looking candles.” She laughed shaking her head fondly, “did everything go okay at the hospital?”

Agatha’s fingers stilled.

She looked into Rio’s eyes, bright and relaxed from the music and company. Happy. Carefree. 

For a split second, the truth pressed at the back of her throat. She should tell her. She should mention Debbie’s parents, the conversation, the likelihood that Gabby would be leaving.

But she couldn’t bring herself to dim that light right now.

She forced a small smile. “Yes. All good.”

As the drinks flowed, the mood shifted into something looser, warmer. When Pink Pony Club came on, Wanda and Jen dragged Agatha onto the dance floor before she could protest. Rio stayed back with Nat, but Agatha could feel her watching.

And she let herself be watched.

She swayed her hips more boldly than usual, exaggerating a turn when she caught Rio’s eye. The answering look she received sent a thrill through her. For once, she wasn’t the composed surgeon. She wasn’t the guarded one. She was just a woman dancing, laughing, letting the music carry her.

Three songs passed before she realised how breathless she was. She couldn’t remember the last time she had let herself go like this. Maybe she never had.

Grinning, she signalled to Jen and Wanda that she needed a drink and made her way back toward the booth, slowing as she caught the tail end of Rio and Nat’s conversation.

“Her grandparents seem really nice,” Nat was saying. “I’m glad she’s going to have someone to look after her more permanently now.”

Agatha stopped.

She saw it the moment the words landed. The flicker of something breaking across Rio’s face. Shock first. Then hurt. Then the careful, practiced smoothing over.

“That’s great news,” Rio said evenly. “I’m glad she has family that can take care of her.”

Agatha’s stomach dropped.

Time seemed to slow as Agatha watched Rio murmur something polite, excuse herself from the booth, and slip away without looking back. The door closed behind her, quiet but final.

Agatha’s chest seized.

Rio had left.

The thought hit fast and sharp, blooming into something worse before she could stop it. Her mind filled in the gaps immediately, cruel and efficient. Of course she’d left. Agatha had lied by omission. She had hidden something that mattered. She had let Rio hope for a future she hadn’t been honest about.

This is what happens, a familiar voice whispered. This is what always happens when you get comfortable.
Her pulse roared in her ears. The music, the laughter, the warmth of the bar all fell away, replaced by the cold certainty she knew too well. 

Love given. Love withdrawn. 

Punishment for wanting too much.

She was already moving.

Heels slipping slightly as she pushed through the crowd, breath coming too fast, too shallow. Her hands felt numb as she shoved past bodies, barely registering the startled looks she earned. She needed to get outside. She needed to see Rio. 

The door flew open and the cold night air hit her like a slap, sharp and unforgiving.

Her eyes darted wildly, panic tightening her vision, heart hammering so hard it hurt. For one terrifying second, she didn’t see her.

She’s gone.

Then—there.

Rio was leaning against the brick wall just outside the bar, eyes closed, face tilted up toward the night sky as if she were trying to steady herself.

Agatha’s knees nearly buckled with relief and fear colliding all at once.

“Rio…”

Rio’s eyes snapped open as she turned. “Agatha? What are you doing out—”

Agatha didn’t let her finish.

She crossed the distance in a few frantic steps, breath uneven, hands coming up helplessly, hovering between Rio’s face and the front of her shirt. She grabbed at both, grounding herself however she could.

“Baby, I’m so sorry,” she rushed out, words tumbling over each other. “I didn’t tell you about Gabby’s grandparents. I swear I was going to tell you tomorrow. I just didn’t want to ruin your evening. Please forgive me, my love. Please don’t leave me.”

The last words broke something open in her.

Rio froze, eyes widening as she took in Agatha properly. The panic etched into her face. The tears she hadn’t even realised were falling. The way her hands trembled like she was bracing for impact.

Rio understood immediately.

This wasn’t about tonight. Or Gabby. Or even the omission.

This was about loss. About being left.

Without hesitation, Rio cupped Agatha’s face, thumbs brushing gently beneath her eyes, wiping away the tears.

“Hey,” she said softly. “Hey. It’s okay, mi amor. I understand why you didn’t tell me. I’m not mad. I’m not going anywhere.”

“But you—you left,” Agatha hiccupped. “I thought—”

Rio leaned in, hands firm and steady, forcing Agatha to look at her. “Agatha. I promise you, I’m not going anywhere. I just needed some air. I’m sorry if I scared you.”

Then she pulled Agatha into her arms, holding her close, one hand cradling the back of her head as Agatha collapsed into her. Rio stayed there, solid and umwavering, until she felt Agatha’s breathing slow, her body easing back from the edge.

After a long moment, Rio pulled back slightly, her hands sliding down Agatha’s arms. She noticed the faint goosebumps rising along her skin, the way Agatha was rubbing her own arms in a small, unconscious attempt to warm herself.

“Come on,” Rio said gently. “Let’s get back inside before Kate actually punches Billy in the face.”

Agatha let out a soft, watery laugh, though her arms looped back around Rio’s waist as if she wasn’t quite ready to let go. She looked up into those warm brown eyes and saw it clearly now—the hurt Rio was trying so hard to tuck away. The brave face. The careful composure.

“I’m so sorry, Rio,” she said quietly. “I know how much you adore that little girl.”

Rio’s mouth curved into a half-smile, but it didn’t quite reach her eyes. She glanced down between them, nodding faintly.

“Yeah,” she admitted. “I do. But at least she has someone looking out for her. Someone who can give her a good life.” She swallowed. “I just hope we get to say goodbye before they leave.”

Agatha leaned in, pressing a soft, deliberate kiss to Rio’s mouth.

“I’ll make sure of it,” she promised.

They walked back inside together, fingers loosely intertwined, the warmth of the bar wrapping around them again. 

At the booth, Wanda had migrated fully onto Natasha’s lap, arms draped around her shoulders. Jen and Alice were nowhere to be seen.

“There you are, Agatha Doctor Harknesssss,” Billy slurred dramatically as they slid into their seats opposite him and Kate, who made an exaggerated circling motion near her temple to indicate he was well past tipsy.

“This is why teenagers aren’t allowed to drink,” Agatha said dryly.

“I’m twenty four—no wait—I’m twenty five!” Billy protested, swaying slightly.

“Hmm. Are we sure about that?” Agatha arched a brow.

“Billy, water. Now,” Nat said firmly, sliding his drink away with practiced authority.

Wanda leaned in close to her ear. “Mmm, I love it when you act all mommy” she murmured—except not quietly enough.

The entire table heard.

Kate’s eyes went wide as she looked between Agatha and Rio, biting her lip to contain her laughter. 

Agatha wasn’t so successful, a snort escaped before she could stop it, her hand flying to her mouth.

“Wanda, dear,” Nat said quickly, already standing. “Bathroom. Now.”

Agatha and Rio shuffled out of the booth to let them pass.

“Are you guys going to—hiccup—have sex in the bathroom?” Billy asked innocently, one eye half-closed.

The table erupted. Natasha’s face turned an impressive shade of red as she dragged Wanda away from the cackling trio behind them.

Alice and Jen returned just then, arms full of fresh drinks and a tray of shots.

“Where’d they go?” Alice asked, setting everything down.

“They’re going to fuck in the bathroom,” Rio said casually, accepting a beer.

“But it’s almost midnight?” Jen replied, not even looking up as she distributed the shots.

Kate stared at her. “That’s your reaction to them basically getting caught out?”

Jen snorted. “Please. I’ve walked in on those two way too many times in an on-call room to be shocked anymore.” She placed a glass of ice water firmly in front of Billy. “Hydrate.”

Wanda and Nat eventually reappeared a few minutes later, greeted by a chorus of knowing looks and a handful of shameless teasing about quick triggers and suspiciously flushed faces. Before anyone could linger on it too long, the DJ’s voice cut through the noise, announcing the countdown to midnight.

Agatha turned slightly toward Rio, the hum of the bar fading at the edges.

“You know,” she said softly, “earlier, when you talked about living together… did you really mean it?” She hesitated, then added, “Even if things didn’t work out with Gabby?”

The countdown began.

Ten.

Rio turned fully to face her, the world narrowing to the space between them. Her eyes shone, hopeful and careful all at once. “You’d still want that?” she asked. “Just… me? Us? Our own place?”

Agatha smiled, lifting a hand to tuck a loose strand of hair behind Rio’s ear, her thumb lingering there like it belonged. “More than anything.”

Five.

Rio’s face lit up, a full, unguarded smile breaking free. “Then yes. I absolutely meant it. I want to build a home with you, Agatha. Wherever that is.” Her voice softened. “You’re my everything.”

Agatha felt the weight of that settle warmly in her chest. “Then let’s find us a home.”

The crowd erupted.

“Happy New Year!”
 
The crowd surged around them, voices rising, glasses clinking, laughter spilling into the air as midnight hit. Agatha barely registered any of it. Her focus stayed fixed on Rio, on the warmth of her hands, on the certainty in her smile.

They leaned into each other as the bar erupted, a kiss shared amid the noise and confetti, unhurried and sure. Agatha felt something settle quietly inside her as she held Rio there, solid and real and choosing her back.

The world didn’t feel so sharp anymore.

She wasn’t bracing herself. She wasn’t waiting for something to fall apart.

She was standing exactly where she wanted to be, with the woman she loved, already imagining a door they would open together.

 

Chapter End Notes

House hunting next!

Some serious talks and an emotional goodbye ...

Chapter 38

Debbie’s funeral was held on a Friday.

The sky had been a dull, undecided grey all morning, not quite raining but threatening to. Agatha stood beside Yelena near the back of the small chapel, both of them dressed in black, their presence professional but respectful. They had each played a part in Debbie’s final days. It felt wrong not to come.

The service was modest. A handful of family friends. A few distant relatives. Mr. and Mrs. Jenkins sat in the front row, shoulders touching, hands clasped so tightly their knuckles had gone pale. Grief hung thick in the air, heavy and unmoving.

A decision had been made not to bring Gabby.

She was too young, Susan had said gently. The noise, the finality of it, the lowered voices and tearful embraces. It would be confusing at best. Frightening at worst.

Agatha had agreed outwardly.

Inside, it had felt like another small, quiet ending.

Earlier that week, Susan had called her directly.

“I was wondering,” she had said carefully, “if Rio might like to sit with us while the service is going on. Just in one of the side rooms. Gabriella’s been asking about her.”

Agatha had closed her eyes at that.

Susan had continued, voice warm but practical. “Her grandparents plan to take her home with them after the funeral. We thought… it might be good for her to say goodbye in her own way. Somewhere calmer.”

Not a formal goodbye. Not something dramatic.

Just Rio sitting on the carpet with her. Maybe holding Teddy. Maybe explaining, in the steady way she did, that sometimes goodbye didn’t mean forgotten.

Agatha had relayed the message to Rio that night.

Rio hadn’t hesitated.

“Of course,” she had said immediately. No discussion. 

Now, as the priest’s voice echoed gently through the chapel, Agatha found herself glancing toward the small side hallway where Susan and Rio were waiting with Gabby. She imagined Rio crouched down to Gabby’s height, speaking softly, letting the little girl cling to her if she needed to.

She imagined Gabby’s small hands wrapped in Rio’s shirt.

It struck Agatha then how strange it was, the shape of love. How it had grown so quickly around a child who was never meant to be theirs.

At the front of the chapel, Mrs. Jenkins stood to speak, her voice trembling as she described Debbie’s stubbornness as a child, her laugh, the way she used to insist on yellow birthday cakes because they “looked like sunshine.”

Agatha swallowed hard.

Yellow.

She could picture Gabby’s little face as she’d declared it her favourite colour for the same reason.

When the service ended and people began to file outside toward the cemetery, Agatha lingered near the aisle, watching as Debbie’s parents were embraced by relatives.

In a few minutes, they would walk down that side hallway.

In a few minutes, a small girl would be placed in their arms.

And Rio would have to let go.

After saying goodbye to Yelena, Agatha slipped away from the main chapel and made her way down the quiet side hallway. The murmur of voices faded with each step, replaced by something softer.

The door to the small sitting room was slightly ajar.

She paused when she heard Rio’s voice.

It was low, steady, the same tone she used as if calming someone at a scene. But gentler. Softer around the edges.

Agatha stepped inside quietly.

Gabby was curled into Rio’s side on a small upholstered chair, Teddy tucked under her chin. Rio had one arm wrapped securely around her, the other smoothing slow circles over her back.

“Your mommy’s body stopped working,” Rio was saying carefully. “Sometimes that happens, even when nobody wants it to. It’s not because she didn’t love you. And it’s not because you did anything wrong.”

Gabby’s small fingers twisted into the fabric of Rio’s shirt.

“But where is she?” she whispered.

Rio swallowed once before answering.

“She’s not somewhere you can visit,” she said gently. “But that doesn’t mean she’s gone from you. When someone we love dies, the part of them that loved us doesn’t disappear. It stays with us. In the stories we remember. In the things they taught us. In the way they made us feel safe.”

She brushed a curl away from Gabby’s forehead.

“When my mamá and papá died, I was little too,” Rio continued softly. “And I thought that meant I was alone. But my abuela told me something important. She said love doesn’t stop just because someone’s body does. It just changes shape.”

Gabby blinked up at her, wide-eyed.

“What shape?” she asked.

Rio smiled faintly. “Sometimes it’s the voice in your head that sounds like them when you’re trying to be brave. Sometimes it’s remembering what they liked. Or how they laughed. Sometimes it’s just knowing that if they could choose anything, they’d choose for you to be happy.”

Gabby was quiet for a moment.

“Mommy likes yellow too,” she said finally.

Rio’s expression softened. “Oh yeah?”

“Like the sun.”

Rio nodded. “Then maybe when you see something yellow, you can think of her. Like she’s sending you a little hello.”

Gabby pressed her face into Rio’s chest then, small shoulders trembling.

“I no want to forget her,” she murmured.

“You won’t,” Rio promised immediately. “And your grandma and grandpa won’t let you.”

Agatha felt her throat tighten in the doorway.

Rio didn’t look nervous. She didn’t stumble over her words. She spoke with the quiet certainty of someone who had lived this kind of loss and come out the other side still capable of love.

Gabby’s fingers were still tangled in her shirt, holding on.

And Rio was letting her.

Agatha heard footsteps in the hallway before she saw them.

The low murmur of voices. The careful clearing of a throat. She knew, even before she turned, that this was the moment she had been quietly bracing for all afternoon.

Debbie’s parents approached with Susan beside them. Mrs. Jenkins’ eyes were swollen from crying, a tissue clutched tightly in her hand. Mr. Jenkins carried himself with a kind of brittle composure, grief barely contained beneath it.

“Thank you for coming today, Dr. Harkness,” he said solemnly.

Agatha inclined her head. “Of course.”

The door opened wider.

Inside the room, Rio and Gabby both looked up.

For a second, no one moved.

Then Susan stepped forward gently. “Okay, Gabby sweetie. It’s time to go with Grandma and Grandpa.”

Gabby’s small face crumpled just slightly before she caught herself. She turned back to Rio, offering a brave, wobbly smile.

Agatha watched Rio carefully.

From the outside, she looked steady. Strong. She knelt down so she was eye-level with Gabby, hands resting lightly on the little girl’s shoulders. But Agatha saw it—the faint glassiness in her eyes, the way she blinked a little too hard before smiling.

“Will you come visit me?” Gabby asked, looking up at Rio, then flicking her gaze to Agatha as if making sure the promise would hold.

Rio’s expression softened in a way that made Agatha’s chest ache.

“Sure, kiddo,” she said gently. “Maybe not all the time. But I promise we’ll come visit you soon, okay?”

Agatha knew what Rio wasn’t saying.

That New Jersey to Chicago was more than twelve hours by car. That life had a way of getting complicated. That sometimes promises were harder to keep than they sounded.

But Rio didn’t let any of that touch her voice.

Gabby stepped forward and wrapped her arms around Rio’s neck. Rio hugged her back tightly, eyes closing for a moment longer than necessary.

When they pulled apart, Gabby turned to Agatha.

“Bye, Doctor Agatha,” she said solemnly.

Agatha crouched down, brushing a hand over the little girl’s hair. “Goodbye, Gabriella. Be brave. And remember what we talked about.”

Gabby nodded once, clutching Teddy to her chest.

Then she slipped her small hand into her grandmother’s.

Agatha stood beside Rio as they watched the family walk down the hallway. Neither of them spoke. They simply stood there, shoulders nearly touching, until the sound of footsteps faded and the door at the end of the corridor closed.

Without turning, Agatha reached down and hooked her fingers through Rio’s beside her.

Their hands fit together instinctively, familiar and grounding.

She kept her gaze fixed on the now-empty hallway, on the place where Gabby had disappeared from view, because she knew the second she looked at Rio—really looked at her—the careful composure would fracture.

Rio’s grip tightened in response, just once.

They stood there in the quiet aftermath, grief shared but unspoken. Neither of them trusted their voice. Neither of them wanted to be the first to let it crack.

So they didn’t look at each other.

They just held on.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Over the next few weeks, they threw themselves into the promise they had made on New Year's Eve.

They would build a home. Together.

It wasn’t just talk. Between shifts and long nights, they toured houses, argued gently over kitchens and closet space, and sent each other listings at ridiculous hours.

Thanks to Lilia’s connections, they eventually found it—a spacious three-bedroom house tucked into a quiet street not far from Lilia’s place. 

Close enough to the hospital. Close enough to the fire station.

The day finally arrived when they would move in.

Agatha hadn’t slept.

She had lain awake the entire night, staring at the ceiling, her mind running through worst-case scenarios with clinical precision. What if this was too fast? What if living together changed things? What if she ruined it? What if Rio realised she was too difficult, too guarded, too much?

Happiness always came with a warning label in Agatha’s experience. She had learned to look for the crack before the fall.

Rio had been on shift, unable to curl around her and quiet the spiral the way she usually did. She’d called before dawn instead, voice warm and steady.

“I’ll meet you at the house later, okay? We’re doing this.”

We’re doing this.

With an overly emotional farewell to Lilia the next morning, Agatha loaded her modest collection of belongings into her black Mercedes. A few boxes. Books. Clothes. The essentials of a life that had always felt temporary.

“Lilia, I’m literally two streets away,” Agatha said dryly as Lilia pulled her into a crushing hug. “Why are you crying?”

“I’m just so proud of how far you’ve come, my girl,” Lilia replied, brushing at her eyes. “I’m happy for you.”

The words lodged somewhere tender.

When Agatha pulled into the driveway of the new house, Rio’s truck was already there.

Agatha turned off the engine and sat still for a moment, hands resting on the steering wheel.

Their driveway.

She stepped out slowly, gaze sweeping over the small front garden, the porch, the windows that would soon hold their things.

Their house.

The word felt foreign and enormous.

She had never been part of a their before.

Their kitchen. Their couch. Their mornings.

Their bed.

The thought sent something equal parts fear and longing through her chest. 

The front door opened.

Rio stepped out onto the porch, grinning, sleeves rolled up, already looking like she’d claimed the place.

“There you are,” she called.

Agatha closed the car door gently and let herself smile back.

“Welcome home.” Rio said, wrapping her arms around her waist. 

And suddenly, any doubt and fear Agatha had was gone. 

 

 


Agatha would have loved to claim she had taken a leading role in the decorating and logistics of moving.

In reality, she hadn’t.

Rio was good at it. Naturally good. She could look at an empty room and immediately see where the couch should go, where the light would hit best in the mornings, which wall needed colour and which needed to breathe.

She moved through the house with a kind of quiet certainty, sleeves rolled up, measuring tape clipped to her jeans like she’d been waiting her whole life for this.

And she worked.

Lifting. Carrying. Repositioning heavy furniture with a grunt and a laugh when Agatha inevitably offered “helpful direction.” A faint sheen of sweat gathered at her temples, darkening the collar of her T-shirt. 

At one point she dragged the couch a full foot to the left, stepped back, squinted at it, then dragged it right back again without complaint.

Agatha mostly stood back and watched.

She told herself it was because Rio clearly had a vision. Because too many opinions would only complicate things. But the truth was, she liked watching her.

The flex of muscle beneath fabric when she lifted a box. The way she pushed her hair back with the back of her wrist, leaving a faint streak of paint near her temple. The soft hitch in her breath when she set something heavy down and rolled her shoulders.

And Agatha found herself appreciating every single second of it.

They hadn’t done it alone. Tony had arrived first with a rented truck and an unnecessary amount of commentary. Bucky had carried furniture like it weighed nothing, Peter trailing after him with wide-eyed enthusiasm and too many questions about load-bearing walls.

Alice, Kate, and Yelena had claimed the painting as their territory, turning it into a chaotic, paint-splattered event complete with loud music and increasingly questionable straight lines. Yelena insisted she had “excellent artistic instincts.” Kate disagreed loudly.

Jen didn’t even pretend she would be participating in the heavy lifting.

“Oh absolutely not,” she had said, stepping neatly around a box labeled kitchen. “My talents are intellectual.”

Instead, she stationed herself beside Agatha on the floor of the living room with a stack of home-style magazines, legs crossed, glasses perched low on her nose as she flipped through pages with dramatic seriousness.

“This is a warm neutral,” she’d announce, tapping a page. “You two are a warm neutral couple. No millennial greys. And we are absolutely not doing farmhouse chic.”

Agatha had rolled her eyes, but she hadn’t moved away.

They debated colour swatches. Argued over throw pillows. Googled the proper pronunciation of feng shui three separate times.

And somewhere between the laughter, the paint fimes, and the steady thud of furniture being placed into position, Agatha felt it settle in her bones.

At some point, Lilia and Sharon arrived like a well-organised storm, arms full of trays and foil-covered dishes that could have fed half the neighbourhood. 

Within minutes, they had transformed the still half-unpacked kitchen into something warm and lived-in, pushing boxes aside to create a makeshift buffet along the counter.

The house, which had echoed that morning, now hummed.

Cold beers were passed around. Someone put music on through a phone speaker. Laughter bounced off freshly painted walls that still smelled faintly of drying paint and new beginnings.

Agatha stood in the doorway to the kitchen, a beer cradled loosely in one hand, her other arm folded across her waist as if holding something steady inside herself. She watched the chaos unfold.

Jen and Tony were bickering over whether the couch was technically mid-century modern or just “expensive-looking.” Lilia’s laugh rang out, full and unapologetic, at something Alice had muttered under her breath. Sharon was insisting everyone take seconds before they had even finished their first plate.

The house was loud, alive and full.

Agatha felt something unfamiliar settle in her chest. She had finally found her people. 

Warm arms slipped around her from behind, solid and certain, and Rio’s chin rested gently on her shoulder.

“You okay, mi amor?” Rio murmured, voice low and private against her ear.

Agatha’s smile deepened. She placed her hand over Rio’s forearm, leaning her head back so it rested against Rio’s collarbone, letting herself sink into the contact without hesitation.

She took in the scene one more time—the people, the noise, the life already blooming inside these walls.

“Better than okay,” she said softly, turning her head and capturing Rio’s lips in a soft kiss.

Someone wolf-whistled from the kitchen.

“Alright, we get it,” Tony called out. “New homeowners, very romantic. Now tell me—what are you two doing with the two spare rooms? Home gym? Office? Sex dungeon?” Lilia smacked him upside the head.

Sharon perked up immediately. “It’s a good size for a family home, actually.”

There was a beat.

Agatha felt Rio’s arms tighten slightly around her waist.

“A family-sized home?” Jen echoed lightly, arching a brow as she sipped her beer. “Three bedrooms is ambitious for just the two of you.”

The room didn’t go silent, exactly—but it shifted. The energy softened into something curious and warm.

Agatha felt heat rise up her neck.

They hadn’t really talked about it. Not properly. Not beyond the edges of the Gabby conversation, which had been wrapped in grief and what-ifs. 

They had talked about space. About light. About proximity to work.

Not specifically about children.

Rio cleared her throat.

“Yeah,” she said simply. “Eventually. I want kids.”

Agatha’s heart skipped.

Not whispered. Not hedged. Not a joke.

Just stated.

She turned in Rio’s arms, blinking up at her. “You want kids… plural?”

Rio smiled, almost shy but not embarrassed. “Yeah. I do.”

Agatha swallowed. “H-how many?”

Rio shrugged like it was the most natural thing in the world. “Two.”

Agatha’s eyes widened. “Two?”

Rio laughed softly. “Yeah. So they always have someone. Someone to build forts with. Someone to blame when they piss us off.” Her voice warmed. “I always wished I had a sibling.”

The simplicity of it hit Agatha square in the chest.

It wasn’t about numbers. It was about feeling like you belonged.

Rio dipped her head slightly, brushing her nose against Agatha’s. “I just… I’d like a house that’s loud. Full. A little chaotic. With you in it.”

There was a collective, unashamed chorus of “Aww” from the kitchen.

Jen clutched her chest dramatically. “Oh my god.”

Kate actually wiped an imaginary tear.

Agatha didn’t hear most of it.

She was too busy staring at the woman in front of her, heart melting in real time, realising that the future Rio imagined—messy, noisy, shared—had her at the centre of it.

"Sounds like a good plan."

Afterword
